title: Slopes Called No Place For a Football Lineman
description: FALLSBURG, N.Y., Jan. 31 In a perfect demonstration of the Don't do as I do, do as I say principle, Buddy Ryan, the New York Jets' defensive line coach, succeeded in keeping Randy Rasmussen on the sidelines the other day.

title: Nixon to 1976 Candidates: Don't Be Eager Too Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 Richard Nixon, who has been running for office for 26 years with  as he said  mixed results, offered some advice today to candidates for the Presidency in 1976: Don't be too eager.

title: MAPLE LEAFS TOP ISLANDERS BY 53
description: TORONTO, Jan. 31 (UPI)Gary Monahan scored a pair of goals and Paul Henderson picked up a goal and three assists tonight as the Toronto Maple Leafs rallied to defeat the New York Islanders, 53.

title: Sadat Says Far Right and Left Sought to Undermine Regime
description: CAIRO, Jan. 31President Anwar elSadat tonight accused leftwing and rightwing extremists of having sought to undermine his regime and turn the clock back to the days before the 1952 revolution, led by Gamal Abdel Nasser.

title: Tuesday's Fights
description: Miami BeachTommy Hicks, 180 pounds, Ithica, N.Y., outpointed Johnny Judgins, 196, Miami, Fla., 10 rounds.

title: Control Data Index Cost Put at 3Million
description: ST. PAUL, Jan. 31The Control Data Corporation spent $3million to prepare the computer tapes it destroyed as part of the settlement of its antitrust case against the International Business Machines Corporation, according to court records here.

title: POLICE DRUG LOSS NOW $73MILLION
description: About onefifth of all the heroin and cocaine seized by the police here between January, 1961, and December, 1972, has been stolen from the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

title: Jack Anderson Aide Charged With Holding Stolen Documents
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  A reporter employed by Jack Anderson, the syndicated columnist, was arrested by Federal agents today on charges of receiving and possessing documents stolen by a group of militant Indians during a sixday occupation of the Bureau of Indian Affairs building here last November.

title: Ellsberg Witness Testifies Pentagon Asked CoverUp
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 A retired Air Force colonel swore today that he had seen a Defense Department memorandum ordering that Government studies of the Pentagon papers be removed from the files.

title: Kin of Those Still Missing Still Wait
description: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Jan. 31For Bernice Smith, the waiting continues.

title: Mayor Entertains Volunteer Workers Honored by Panel
description: Mayor Lindsay was host at party at Gracie Mansion last night to honor 37 individuals and groups cited by a panel for outstanding voluntary service to their fellow New Yorkers.

title: Lilly Earnings Climb
description: Record sales and earnings for the fourth quarter and the year ended Dec. 31 were reported yesterday by the Dow Chemical Company.

title: NEWS TALK IS HELD
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31President Nixon announced today that he would send Henry A. Kissinger to Hanoi on Feb. 10 for three days in an effort to make the peace in Vietnam more secure and lay the groundwork for reconstruction of Southeast Asia.

title: Private Hearings Set In Black Youth's Death
description: MORRISTOWN, Jan. 31 A citizens panel formed to investigate the killing of Williams Wells, by a policeman outside a Bernardsville tavern on Jan. 13 plans to conduct public and private sessions.

title: Prof. Elizabeth F. Baker Dies; Taught Economics at Barnard
description: Dr. Elizabeth Faulkner Baker, professor emeritus of economics at Barnard College and the author of studies on the displacement of human labor by machines, died Sunday in Portland, Ore. She was 87 years old.

title: POLICE STUDYING ARMOR FOR CARS
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he was seriously looking at the possibility of equipping police cars with bulletproof glass and reinforced steel to protect policemen from the recent Wave of attacks.

title: PIER UNION ON COAST ENDS MERGER TALKS
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 31 (UPI)  The West Coast longshoremen's union completely and finally broke off today its merger talks with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: CONGRESS MOVES TO CURB JUSTICES
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Congress took the first step today to challenge the Supreme Court's authority to order basic changes the nation's criminal justice system without legislation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SNAP JUDGMENTS There are nearly 700 strikingly happy photographs bedecking both floors of the Kodak Gallery and Photo Information Center, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43d Street (2626170). They were all taken by amateurs in this country, Canada and Mexico, the finalists among 260,000 photos submitted for the 1972 Kodak International Snapshot Awards, socalled because the contest was run through 90 newspapers.

title: Sports Today
description: Manhattan vs. St. Joseph's and Fairfield vs. Detroit, at Madison Square Garden, Eighth Avenue, and 33d Street. First game 7 P.M. (RadioWNBC, 7 P.M.)

title: COMPANY YIELDS BUS FRANCHISES
description: HARTFORD, Jan. 31  The Connecticut Railway & Lighting Company, its buses out of service for 16 weeks, today gave up its franchise to make room for other companies to get into the business.

title: Arthur Daley
description: Gambling is anathema to the prim and proper puritans in the National Football League. Yet they have just completed a gigantic gamble that could affect the fates and fortunes of all teams for many years to come. They have selected college seniors in the annual player draft and no guarantees accompany such blind bargains.

title: Mrs. Minnie Salzman, Painter Who Began Career at 78, Dies
description: Mrs. Minnie Reich Salzman, who became a landscape painter at 78 and had her first oneman show at the Chase Gallery in New York at 80, died yesterday at her home, 1120 Park Avenue. She was 86 years old.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: CITY PUTS STRESS IN CAPITAL BUDGET ON FIGHTING CRIME
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced a record capital budget of $2.448billion in which he stressed and interlocked public safety and the growing role of neighborhoods as his prime concerns.

title: Ellsberg Witness Asserts Pentagon Asked Coverup
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 31 A retired Air Force colonel swore today that he had seen a Defense Department memorandum ordering that Government studies of the Pentagon papers be removed from the files.

title: Jersey Eases Standards On Abortion Prosecution
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. said today the state would not prosecute any licensed physician who performed an abortion to preserve the health of a pregnant woman.

title: OTC LIST MIXED; AMEX ISSUES DIP
description: Afternoon profit taking erased early gains yesterday, causing prices to close mixed on the overthecounter market and slightly lower on the American Stock Exchange. Trading volume increased.

title: Military Mail to Vietnam Will Be Halted March 1
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Postal Service announced today that it would refuse as of March 1 all personal letters mailed to military personnel in Vietnam.

title: Sydney Cabinet Bars Whitlam From Exporting Rams to China
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 31 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has suffered an embarrassing rebuff by his Cabinethis first political setback since taking office nearly three months agoover the sensitive issue of exporting 30 of Australia's prized Merino rams to Communist China.

title: CREDIT STANDING OF CON ED SLIPS
description: The credit standing of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York was downgraded yesterday by a major bond rating service because the utility's earnings are not high enough to give investors the protection they used to have.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A $142,728 civil complaint charging a medical supply company with Medicare fraud has been announced by the United States Attorney Herbert Stern. Mr. Stern said the action had been filed in Newark Federal Court against Jay Brower, proprietor of the G & D Surgical and Drug, Company of 225 North Dean Street, Englewood.

title: THOMAS P. BRADY, MISSISSIPPI JUDGE
description: JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 31Judge Thomas Pickens Brady of the Mississippi Supreme Court, intellectual godfather of the segregationist Citizens Council movement founded in this state in the 1950's, died today after undergoing heart surgery in. Houston. He was 69 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FEBRUARY 1, 1973

title: Chinese Envoy in Tokyo
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (AP)  Mi Kuochun arrived today to open Communist China's first diplomatic mission in Japan. The official, who will be charg d'affaires, was accompanied by 10 members of his staff. Mr. Mi was a director of China's National Machinery Export and Import Corporation and a technical adviser to the Council for the Promotion of International Trade.

title: European Conferences: A Brief Guide
description: WASHINGTON. Jan. 31It has been a time of unusual diplomatic activity, not only in conjunction with the Vietnam ceasefire but also on problems involving many European countries. What follows is a summary of, the major negotiations currently involving the United States.

title: Blood Donor Week Declared
description: TRENTON, Jan, 31 (AP) Governor Cahill today proclaimed the week of Jan. 28 to Feb. 3 as Blood Donor Week and urged New Jerseyans to help end the blood shortage by donating blood.

title: LOAN RATES RISING AT BANKS QUIETLY
description: The nation's largest banks faced with soaring loan de mend and rising money costs are quietly raising their lending rates and tightening up significantly the terms and conditions of the loans they are negotiating.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: TUESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: HERCULES PLANT CUTS WORK WEE??
description: KENVIL, Jan. 31The Kenv works plant of Hercules, Inc announced today that it wa?? being forced to switch its 29 employes to a fourday wor week because of its failure t?? receive a defense contract.

title: Series of Short Films by Women Comes to Whitney Screen
description: The second package of short subjects by women film makersartists presented yesterday at the New York Cultural Center graphically illustrates that many of the eight contributors offer a good deal less than meets the eye or mind. The creative drive is obvious in all the shorts but only a few, unfortunately, seem worthy of the effort expended.

title: ROYAL AND REGAL WINS 3D STRAIGHT
description: MIAMI, Jan. 31 (AP)Royal and Regal made the $25,000 Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah his third straight triumph as he finished a length ahead of Ahgle Light and 1 lengths ahead of Kinsman Hope.

title: 2 Rams Obtained
description: George Allen, the Washington Redskins' coach, predictably traded two of his choices to the Los Angeles. Rams for experienced players yesterday, as the National Football. League's annual draft of college players ended. The 26 teams completed two days of choosing 442 players by completing the last 10 of the 17 rounds in the selection process. The teams thus assumed exclusive rights to sign these players and of the 260 claimed yesterday about 90 will win jobs next summer in the training camps.

title: Budget Cuts Scored by Black Caucus
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Members of the Congressional Black Caucus criticized cutbacks by the Nixon Administration in key domestic programs today and promised legislative efforts to restore funds for what they described as the critical areas of housing, employment, civil rights, education and drug abuse.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Islanders' LineUp NASSAU COLISEUM, 8 P.M.
P.O.W.'s Greeters Told to Deemphasize the Military
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Jan. 31He will come from a quiet, slowmotion world. There, in the endless hours, days; years, sounds were probably events and changes in temperature and humidity were experiences. There, food, clothing and shelter were basic, drab and bare. Language was simple.

title: Insurance Group Says New Bumpers Permit Needless Damage to '73 Cars
Japanese Airline to Buy 14 McDonnell Aircraft
description: TOKYO, Jan. 31 (UP1)Toa Koku, a Japanese airline, has. decided to buy 14 DC941 jetliners from the McDonnell Douglas Company.

title: Planning Unit Approves Complex Over F.D.R.Dr.
description: After nearly two years of negotiation and debate, the City Planning Commission voted yesterday to allow three medical institutions to expand their facilities by building on a platform over thte Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive.

title: City Notes a Decline in 2 Air Pollutants
description: Sharp declines in two major air pollutants during the last year were reported yesterday by the city's environmental officials, who also expressed some concern about a possible future rise in those pollutants.

title: Chess: It's the Score, Not the Status, That Counts, at Tournaments
description: There is no distinction in chess between professional and amateur. The organizing committees of the large invitational international tournaments select participants by their world rankings and never inquire whether a player ever accepted a money prize or a fee for a lecture or simultaneous exhibition.

title: City Details Plan for State TakeOver of Relief and Medicaid
description: New York City proposed yesterday to go out of the welfare and Medicaid business by transferring $565milion a year in benefit payments to the state budget and 16,000 city employes to the state payroll.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Jets Go for Offense
description: Despite having a healthy Joe Namath all last season, the New York Jets finished with a mediocre and disappointing 77 wonlost; record, so everyone naturaly assumed they would seek to shore up their defenseespecially the pass rush, which came in for some hard criticism, even from the coaches.

title: Rehabilitated Addicts Earn Marine School Diplomas
description: Eighteen months ago Paul Hankins was on his way to nowheresvillea burnedout junkie with nothing to look forward to but his next fix.

title: All Freed P.O.W.'s to Get Lifetime Baseball Pass
description: Each prisoner of war returning from Indochina will receive a goldplated lifetime pass good for any professional baseball game, Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, announced yesterday.

title: Rehabilitated Addicts Earn Marine School Diplomas
description: Eighteen months ago Paul Hankins was on his way to nowheresvillea burnedout junkie with nothing to look forward to but his next fix.

title: Senate Confirms Brennan and Lynn For Cabinet Posts
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Peter J. Brennan as Secretray of Labor and James T. Lynn as Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Sales Top $3Billion
Press Center Files Suit To Assist N.B.C. Reporter
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) The newly formed Press Information Center filed its first Freedom of Information Act suit today on behalf of a broadcast reporter seeking information on alleged counterintelligence activities against the New Left by the Federal. Bureau of Investigation.

title: Advertising: McCann's Creator
description: McCannErickson, domestically the seventhlargest agency with such bountiful clients as CocaCola, Exxon and Buick, has been operating for years and years with three creative groups but no single creative director.

title: Hanoi Aide Confers in Soviet On CeaseFire Situation
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31 (AP) North Vietnam's Foreign Minister, Nguyen Duy Trinn, conferred today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, on the ceasefire situation in South Vietnam and then left for home, Tass reiported.

title: Richardson Orders a DefenseCut Study
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Secretary of Defense Elliot L. Richardson announced today that in an effort to find areas for potential cuts he had initiated a sweeping review of the $79billion defense budget sent to Congress three days ago.

title: The North Vietnamese Prepare For First Peaceful Tet in Years
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Jan. 31 (Agence FrancePresse)Fire crackers sputtered in the streets of Hanoi far into last night as the nation prepared for its first peacetime Tet, or Lunar New Year, in years.

title: Antiabortion Move Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Representative Lawrence J. Hogan, Republican of Maryland, a Roman Catholic; proposed yesterday a constitutional amendment that would overturn the Supreme Court decision legalizing abortion.

title: Boy Dragged by Bull Dies
description: HOUSTON, Jan. 31 (UPI)Bennie L. Cooper, 11 years old, Who was dragged a block by a runaway bull, died yesterday. On Monday, the boy tied a rope around his waist and tried to hold the bull, but it bolted and ran.

title: East and West Open Talks For Parley on Force Cut
description: VIENNA, Jan, 31  Twelve countries from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and seven from the Warsaw Pact met here today to begin preparations for a conference later this year on the withdrawal of forces from Central Europe.

title: FuelOil Crisis Feared
description: Government energy planners, in a new appraisal, have warned that the fueloil shortage could become a crisis before spring if there is a sustained cold wave. Details on Page 62.

title: JERSEY IS DEFIED BY A SAVINGS UNIT
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31State efforts to prevent a savingsandloan office from fleeing a preIdominantly black neighborhood here that is plagued by violent crime failed today. The bank disclosed that it would close rather than try to continue to do business under what it regards as a daytoday state of siege.

title: Descendant of Founder Heads Pratt Institute
description: Richardson Pratt, the acting president of Pratt Institute since last June, has been appointed president of the school his greatgrandfather founded in 1887, it was announced yesterday.

title: CELTICS SET BACK CAVALIERS, 9489
description: BOSTON, Jan. 31 (AP)The Boston Celtics spotted Cleveland a 19point firhalf lead and then rallied behind Don Chaney and Jo Jo White tonight for a 9489 National Basketball Association victory over the Cavaliers.

title: Top Officials Resign From Poverty Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  President Nixon accepted today the resignations of the two top officials of the Office of Economic Opportunity, the antipoverty organization he is planning to dismantle.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Census Analysis Shows a Deciline In 2Parent Homes for City's Youth
description: Less than threequarters of the city's young people under the age of 18 live with both parents, and in the case of blacks the proportion is only about half.

title: Peterson's Trumpet Heralds Hannibal In Vanguard Jazz
description: Marvin Peterson is a young jazz trumpet player who has been enlivening several groups in recent months not only with the brassy exuberance of his trumpet playing but also with his warm, engaging personality. Mr. Peterson has now formed his own group, called Hannibal, which played at the Village Vanguard Tuesday night and last night.

title: N. C. STATE BEATS MARYLAND AGAIN
description: RALEIGH, N. C., Jan. 31 (AP) David Thompson scored 7 points in A hurry midway through the second half and gunned unbeaten North Carolina State to an 8978 Atlantic Coast Conference  basketball victory over Maryland tonight. State's wonlost record is 150. Maryland is 142, with both losses to State.

title: Nixon to 1976 Candidates: Don't Be Eager Too Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Richard Nixon, who has been running for office for 26 years with  as he said  mixed results, offered some advice today to candidates for the Presidency in 1976: Don't be too eager.

title: Nixon, Restating Opposition to Amnesty, Stresses Punishment
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31President Nixon reiterated today his opposition to amnesty for those who refused to serve in the military in the Vietnam war. Instead, he stressed the need for criminal penalties and said, We cannot provide forgiveness for them.

title: Giants Gamble on 2
description: The New York Giants finished drafting 15 players yesterday, and the best summary of what they got can be expressed in three words: they don't know.

title: $3.5 MILLION LEFT FROM NIXON DRIVE
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The principal finance committee for President Nixon's re  election campaign reported today that it raised more than $35  million since last April and ended the year with a cash surplus of about $3.5million.

title: U.S. LOSES TWO F4'S IN GULF OFF DA NANG
description: HONOLULU, Jan. 31 (UPI)The commander of United States forces in the Pacific announced that two F4 jet fighters crashed in the. Gulf of Tonkin off Vietnam today during a routine patrol mission.

title: Walter C. Louchheim Jr. Dead; Banker, Civic Leader in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Walter C. Louchheim Jr., by vocation an investment counselor and by avocation a philosopher and a patron of music and drama, died this morning at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: Bill to Aid Transit Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) Senators Lowell P. Weicker, Republican of Connecticut, and Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, introduced today a bill that would allow states and cities to use almost half the Highway Trust Fund for mass transit systems. They said in a statement that Representative Edward P. Boland, Democrat of Massachusetts, would introduce identical legislation in the House.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner directed the East FlatbushCanarsie District 18 school board to permit pupils from the largely black Tilden Houses in Brownsville to attend the virtually allwhite Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie for at least the next two years. The local board ha.d proposed phasing out the Tilden pupils after next year.

title: U.N. Charts Show. Big Gap Among Nations in Lifespan
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 1Life expectancy among the black people of the underdeveloped countries in Africa is less than half that of the population in some of Europe's more advanced countries.

title: Dividend Is Raised
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday a 3.3 per cent decline in 1972 net income although fourth quarter net ran 1.4 per cent higher than the like 1971 period.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Stennis's Condition Still Very Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31Senator John C. Stennis, one of the capital's most powerful political figures, was in very serious condition today at Walter Reed Army Hospital after being shot and robbed in front of his home last night.

title: One Bebefit From Talks With Soviet On Ecology: U.S. Antelope May Live
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 31Soviet success in saving a rare antelope in the arid steppes of Central Asia from extinction may help the United States save a similar beast in the American Southwest, American officials reported today.

title: People and Business
description: Another high Administration officialthe second in two days  announced yesterday that he would join United Air Lines. John P. Olsson, 44, Deputy Under Secretary of Transportation, will become an assistant to the president of United.

title: Mr. Heath's Mission
description: The talks beginning today in Washington between President Nixon and Prime Minister Heath of Britain can be crucial for Unit and ed States relations with the European Economic Communityindirectly for the future of the Atlantic Alliance.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Who were Parker and Davis? Or Jupiter, the horse? Or Tim. McCoy? Ask Ira Smolin, the genial man who sits surrounded by, printed nostalgia in his shop at 1215 Lexington Avenue (between 81st and 82d Streets).

title: U.S. OLYMPIC GROUP BACKS LAKE PLACID
description: Hopeful that its third choice may prove a charm, the United States Olympic Committee hastily certified Lake Placid, N. Y., yesterday as the American representative to bid for the host site for the 1976 Winter Olympics.

title: Levitt Backs Uniformity In PublicEmploye Pension
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31 (AP) State Controller Arthur Levitt expressed his support today for the new, uniform statewide publicemploye pension system proposed by a state commission studying retirement systems.

title: DETROIT FIVE PLAYS FAIRFIELD TONIGHT
description: The University of Detroit, with a 124 wonlost record and six straight victories, faces Fairfield University in the second game of a basketball doubleheader at Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: POLICE DRUG LOSS NOW $73MILLION
description: About onefifth of all the heroin and cocaine seized by the police here between January, 1961, and December, 1972, has been stolen from the Police Department, Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday.

title: Knowlton Trial Testimony Ends As Witness Denies Inpropriety
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31The fense in the Federal tax trial of former State Senator Willard B. Knowlton rested today after calling Its third witness, a consulting engineer to the New Jersey Turnpike who denied any impropriety in the awarding of a $10.6million highway contract.

title: Bridge:
description: Bridge organization at various levels requires the services of a great many dedicated people. But it would be difficult anywhere to find a bridge administrator who could match the efficiency of Marthe Charles of Plainview, L. I.

title: U.S EASES CURBS ON CROPS IN MOVE TO CUT FOOD COST
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31The Nixon Administration acted today to put millions of acres of idle farm land back into production and thus help check the rise in food prices.

title: Climb in Interest Rates Resumes Across a Broad Front
description: The recent sharp climb in shortterm interest rates, which some analysts think may be leveling off, resumed yesterday across a broad front and put even additional upward pressure on the banks' 6 per cent prime lending rate.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 25 Pupils Treated for Shellac Effects

title: Navy Resists Prices; Less Steak on Mena
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP)  With food prices rising, the Navy has ordered mess cooks to substitute hamburger for steaks and chops.

title: Nixon Acknowledges American Jailed in China Is C. I. A. Agent
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 When John T. Downey was a Yale senior in 1951, a classmate later recalled, a Central Intelligence Agency recruiter visited the campus.

title: Records
description: Richard Strauss is still best known for the works he wrote in.the first 45 years of his life. After Der Rosenkavalier, a few flickering exceptions aside, his oeuvre is pretty much terra incognita for the average concertgoer, and even for the, average record listener.

title: Seven Food Places Listed As HealthCode Violators
description: Gordon Chase, the city's Health Services Administrator, has announced the names of seven more foodprocessing establishments cited for violations of the Health Code.

title: Chinese New Year to Dawn in Burst of Parades, Song and Dance
description: The tenacious hold of a debatable tradition reinforced by an uptodate sense of commercialism will touch off an explosion of fireworks and pageantry tomorrow at midnight when residents of Chinatown begin a weekend salute to the new lunar year the Year of the Ox.

title: Market Place: Eastern Sound: A Case Study
description: When is a company important enough to rate writeup by a New York Stock Exchange member firm?

title: Notes on People
description: Susan Agnew, the 25yearold daughter of Vice President Agnew, is scheduled to sail today as an employe aboard the medicalservice ship Hope, bound for Latin America. Miss Agnew will serve as assistant to the director for audiovisual education. When the Hope reaches Brazil, Miss Agnew is expected to remain working aboard ship and in schools around the city of Maceio. The ship's director, Dr. William Walsh, said before the Hope sailed from Baltimore that Miss Agnew's job involved secretarial skills and skills in dealing with people. Miss Agnew is to be with the ship for 10 months. Until recently, she was working in occupational therapy at a state mental in Maryland.

title: Trade Surplus of the U.S. With China at $28Million
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (UPI) The United States ran up $28million trade surplus with China in its first full year of bilateral trade with China, a Commerce Department announcement said today.

title: SAMUEL ARGUES FOR HIS OTB PLAN
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31Howard J. Samuels, president and chairman of the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation, said today that it would be a management disaster for the state to attempt to take over control of offtrack betting across the state.

title: Lefkowitz Asks Metropolitan to Confer on Sales
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has asked the Metropolitan Museum of Art not to dispose of any more items from its collecdons without prior notice to his office.

title: WHEAT FUTURES SHOW ADVANCE
description: Earlymorning buyers pushed wheat futures ahead yesterday, perhaps inspired by a Department of Agriculture report that revised downward this year's carryover wheat supplies. Another factor that traders considered is expectation of better exports later in the week.

title: Oil Scarcity Halts Heat 6 Hours In All City's Housing Projects
description: Heat was shut off yesterday for six hours for the occupants of about 156,000 apartments in all of the city's publichousing projects because of a fueloil shortage.

title: NOFAULT SAVINGS REVISED UPWARD
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31The State Superintendent of Insurance said today that there was a good chance that the proposed nofault insurance bill would provide drivers with premium savings beyond the 13 per cent average cut mandated in the legislation.

title: U.S. Aides Say Cold Wave Could Spur FuelOil Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31In a fresh appraisal, Governmeat energy planners have con eluded that the fueloil shortage could reach crisis proportions before winter ends there is a sustained cold wave.

title: College Names President
description: DUDLEY, Mass., Jan. 31 (AP) Dr. Darcy C. Coyle, management professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, was appointed today as president of Nichols College effective July 1.

title: Scribner Pushes Canarsie Integration
description: Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner directed the community school board of Brooklyn's District 18 yesterday to admit children from the largely black Tilden Houses project in Brownsville to the now virtually allwhite Isaac Bildersee Junior High School 68 in Canarsie for at least the next two years.

title: Although Fear Is Creeping In Indirectly, Couple Finds Best of All Worlds Here
description: She could see the watchman in the lobby, just a few yards away. In a few seconds, the elevator would be swooping her upward to the 30th floor, to her books and her husband and their view of the harbor.

title: Stennis's Condition Still Very Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Jan, 31Senator John C. Stennis, one of the capital's most powerful political figures, was in very serious condition today at Walter Reed Army Hospital after being shot and robbed in front of his home last night.

title: People in Sports: Green Lured by Track : Green
description: Some amateur track stars are jumping to the professional circuit so fast that the promoters don't have time to set up news conferences to make the announcements. The latest to join the money runners is Jim Green the former University of Kentucky sprinter Green turned pro yesterday, he disclosed, but denied the move would prevent him from competing in the Masonbixon amateur meet in Louisville on Feb. 10.

title: NaturalGas Torches Barred
description: ALBANY, Jan. 31 (UPI)The Public Service Commission yesterday prohibited the use of natural gas in decorative torches. Gas companies were given 20 days to comply with the order. The P.S.C. said such use of natural was wasteful when the natural resource was in short supply.

title: Five Are Slain in Ulster in TwoDay Shooting Wave
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 31The body of the fifth assassination victim in Northern Ireland in two days was found today at the side of a highway in West Belfast, about a mile from where he had been abducted at gunpoint. He was the fourth Roman Catholic to die in the latest wave of shootings.

title: Upset Over Crime, Victim Refuses to Stay and Fight
description: For the first thirty years of her life, Mrs. Ellen Kenwood Gross thought of herself as the essential New Yorker, thriving on the excitement and cultural diversity of the city. She traveled a lot and always looked forward to coming home; she would tell her friends how, she wanted to have children and raise them here.

title: State Loses Fight to Keep Savings Unit In CrimeRidden, Black Newark Area
description: NEWARK, Jan. 31State efforts to prevent a savingsandloan office from fleeing a predominantly black neighborhood here that is plagued by violent crime failed today. The bank disclosed that it would close rather than try to continue to do business under what it regards as a daytoday state of siege.

title: The Education Budget
description: The President's budget represents a retreat from virtually all the advances made since 1965 in the Federal Government's involvement in education. Those advances had been carefully planned with a view to subsidizing the areas of greatest need, particularly in the urban and rural slums.

title: Thefts Are Linked to Forgery
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy said yesterday that he agreed with the finding olthe medical examiner in Brooklyn that Detective Joseph N. Nunziata  whose apparently forged signature appeared on the withdrawal receipt for some of the heroin missing from Police Department custodykilled, himself on March 29.

title: Dr. Ragnar Frisch Dead at 77; Economist Won '69 Nobel Prize
description: OSLO, Norway, Jan. 31 (AP) Prof. Ragnar Frisch, the Norwegian economist who shared the first Nobel Prize for economic science with Jan Tinbergen of the Netherlands died today at the age of 77.

title: Burt Reynolds Recalls Era of the Private Eye in 'Shamus':The Cast
description: "What are you doing in the tub?""I'm taking a bath.""Taking a bath with your clothes on?""Saves on laundry bills."It's a joke; a rotten joke to be sure; but a joke anyway. The shamus, McCoy, isn't really taking a bath. He was worked over by some hired thugs the night before, and in the tub is where his pal Springy finds him the next morning  ready for jokes, ready for punches, for kisses, for just about anything, in Buzz Kulik's "Shamus," a game but not especially good movie that means to put the private eye back into some kind of current relevance.The attempt has been made often enough before. But this time it is made with a mixture of contemporary satire and knowing nostalgia that keeps proving itself more interesting than the movie it is supposed to support. Just possibly, the private eye, that last refuge of unfettered consciousness, is a less immortal pop-culture hero than some would like to imagine. When "Shamus" goes back to "The Big Sleep," and it goes back quite openly, it can parody certain personagesthe beautiful bookstore girl behind glasses; General Sternwood in his hothousebut it can't really capture people, or what they stand for in a society that is, like any society, a system of deep and necessary inter- dependencies.Thus, Marlowe, in "The Big Sleep," could be not just the eyes but also the conscience of his world, as McCoy cannot, because in "Shamus" there is nothing to which a conscience can attach itself. People aren't more wicked. They are more brutal, but if anything less wicked. The case that McCoy breaks, the plot of the icy millionaire, Hume (Ron Weyand), to export government arms illegally, may be fraught with danger; but is is given its meaning by the dopey Col. C. C. Hardcore (John Ryan), who sells off surplus tanks as if they were used cars, and so it becomes another one of the film's game but rather lame little jokes.As the tough and artful shamus, Burt Reynolds has both a dramatic role to play and a public image to live up to; and I think he does better with the former than the latter. I'm not sure how you would play an insatiable lover in a PG-rated movie that has you rolling out of your bed of passion each morning still wearing your boxer shorts, but Reynolds plays it for bemused embarrassmentwhich is not bad, considering the options.In some respects, appreciative, oddly courteous, Reynold's relations with his womenespecially with the innocent Alexis (reasonably managed by Dyan Cannon)are the closest "Shamus" comes to approximating the circle of moral good fellowship that films like "The Big Sleep" erect against the corrosive mists of the studio-created night.The approximation isn't close enough, and "Shamus," which is full of appealing New York locations and much inventive action, ultimately amounts to little more than the kind of situation melodrama that the movies these days offer for excitement. On this level it is workmanlike, well-paced, modest, sometimes scary, and sometimes genuinely funny. It opened yesterday at Loews State 2 and Loews Cine and other neighborhood theaters.

We always regarded him as someone who would ultimately receive either national fame or notoriety, says Albert Rosenblatt, who now heads the District Attorney's office in Dutchess County, New York, where he and Liddy once worked together. That was absolutely predictable, Mr. Rosenblatt said. He was a man of extraordinary ambition.

title: The Screen: 'Steelyard Blues' Arrives
description: "Steelyard Blues" is an appealing movie if only because all of the people connected with it seem so utterly convinced that they are making a Third World film disguised in the shape of an eccentric caper comedy. I like its earnestness, its brow furrowed with mission.It reminds me of the little boy who covered himself with vanishing cream and then walked through a dinner party in the fond belief he was invisible. He was not, nor is the essential, simple-hearted evangelism of "Steelyard Blues," which does have, as a matter of fact, some bright things in it.There is an early, pre-credit sequence in which Veldini (Donald Sutherland), serving time for larceny, is confronted by a marvelously self-assertive black inmate who asks whether Veldini is dangerous, rather in the way you might ask someone if he's from St. Louis. "Yes," says Veldini, a little uneasily. "I'm dangerous.""I been dangerous since I was 14," says the black man cheerfully. "By the time they lost my records, I'd killed eight guys, at least. . . . You pretty tough kid, but you ain't dangerous."Sutherland, playing a sad-faced, gentle, demolition-derby driver, gives the impression of someone who's too thin because his passion will not let him rest. He hasn't time for proper meals while he works on plans to wreck every car manufactured in America between 1940 and 1960. His impossible dream: a giant demolition derby involving not just passenger cars, but dump trucks, school buses, pick-up trucks, delivery vans, trailers, campers and, at the finale, mobile homes.He is, of course, the visionary loser who, by the definition of this film, is a positive force for true freedom and justice. So too is Iris (Jane Fonda), a $100-a-a-night hooker who does not know she's being humiliated until she's beaten up by the police at the direction of the district attorney (Howard Hesseman). He is not only an occasional customer but also Veldini's brother.Like Iris and all the others who come under Veldini's mad revolutionary spell, Eagle (Peter Boyle) hasn't any passion of his own. Eagle is a schizoid, out-of-work circus man ("there's not much call for human flies these days") who hasn't a thought one way or the other about the yoke of the automobile economy.Intuitively, he recognizes Veldini's genius, and, through him, he worships the spirit of liberation. In "Steelyard Blues" liberation is represented by a plan to raid a Navy yard to steal an electrical circuit that, in turn, will allow the innocents to fly off to a better world in a refurbished PBY of World War II vintage.Alan Myerson, whose credits include work with San Francisco's improvisational satire group, The Committee, and Chicago's Second City, directed the film. He clearly has a sense of humor, but the movie often is totally confused in ways that can be credited to either the directing or writing.Different shots within a single scene do not match. When comedy goes thin, the volume of the rock score (actually a very good one) on the soundtrack is raised to such a fierce level that it sounds like a radio in the projection booth. It has to have no relation to the movie.It may be because Miss Fonda's and Sutherland's soberly humanitarian left-wing political views are so well known that they lend a heaviness to "Steelyard Blues" that it would not have if we were not so aware. I doubt it, however. They are two performers I admire very much, but this film, which may be up to their politics, is not up to their talents. Their presence gives it more importance than the material warrants."Steelyard Blues," which opened yesterday at the Beekman, is the sort of caper comedy in which you cannot even take the graffiti ("Off the pigs," says a penciled inscription in a jail cell) without suspecting a lot of ponderous premeditation.

title: Let Us Pray
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.This morning it is time for the 1973 observance of the annual National Prayer Breakfast in the nation's capital, when Richard M. Nixon joins various Government leaders and selected clergymen in offering public prayers to God. Presumably the prayers will be as carefully screened as the people present. For caesaropapism inevitably seeks to accommodate inward spiritual impulses to the uses of government and the trappings of state.

description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Jan. 31 (Agence FrancePresse) Cambodia's Information Min. ister said today that promising contacts had been established between Government troops and antiGovernment forces since President Lon Nol ordered a halt in offensive military operations.

title: UnSound Bridge
description: Thanks to a ruling earlier this month by a Federal District Court judge, opponents of the proposed bridge across Long Island Sound will have a little more time to marshal their forces for the battle that still lies ahead. Prodded by Governor Rockefeller, who is inexplicably sold on this mammoth threat to the water, air, wetlands, housing and tranquillity of Oyster Bay and Rye, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the State Department of Transportation have been acting as though the project were an immediate necessity. But Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon, suspending premature hearings on approach roads, rightly finds no urgency in this matter whatsoever.

title: JERSEY RELAXES ABORTION RULES
description: TRENTON, Jan. 31Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr'said today the state would not prosecute any licensed physsician who performed an abortion to preserve the health of a pregnant woman.

title: Prayers in School Pressed
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 31 (UPI) A bill introduced in the Texas Senate yesterday would permit silent prayers in public schools. Its sponsor, Walter Mengden, Republican of Houston, said the Supreme Court decision forbidding school prayers was ridiculous.

title: Watergate Conviction
description: The conviction of two of the senior officials in President Nixon's campaign organization for criminal conspiracy, burglary and wiretapping of the Democratic National Committee's Watergate headquarters proves that this sinister operation was no trivial escapade by unimportant persons. It was part of a larger, farflung, wellfinanced plan to use political espionage and sabotage techniques to disrupt and defeat the political opposition. The intrusion of these policestate methods into domestic politics is without precedent and deserves the most thoroughgoing exposure and condemnation.

title: TV: Johnson Interview
description: Lyndon Johnson wasn't the first President to recommend Federal aid to education. Harry Truman reconunended Medicare and was called a Socialist and a Communist and everything else. So, in this country, long before Lyndon Johnson came into a position of power, our leaders were recommending great advances....
