The curbs, effective Monday, were adopted after the Bundesbank, the West German central bank, had bought $700million to $800million yesterday. On Thursday the bank took in $200million.

title: JOHNSON PLANNED POLITICAL RETURN
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 2Shortly before his death, former President Lyndon B. Johnson told friends that he was tired of sitting on the sidelines and was planning to take an active interest in politics once again.

title: GERMANS INCREASE PAYMENTS SURPLUS
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 2 (Reuters)West Germany's basic balanceofpayments surplus rose to a provisional 14.23billion marks ($4.45billion) last year from 6.92 billion marks ($2.17billion) in 1971. The Bundesbank announced today.

title: A. & P. Will Oppose Gulf & Western's Tender Offer
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company will oppose a tender offer by Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., to purchase 3.75 million A. & P. shares, it was announced yesterday.

title: ALEXANDER OUSTS SMITH IN TENNIS
description: RICHMOND. Feb. 2 (AP) John Alexander toppled Stan Smith, 46, 63, 64, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Fidelity World Championship Tennis circuit tournament tonight.

title: FRANK ROBERTS
description: Frank Roberts, editor of The Fort Wayne (Ind.) JournalGazette, died yesterday in the Veterans Hospital in Marion, Ind. He was 78 years old and lived in Fort Wayne.

title: Mrs. Court Advances
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feb. 2 (UPI) Topseeded Mrs. Margaret Court stormed back from firstset loss tonight to whip Julie Heldman, 26, 60, 61, in a quarterfinal of the $25,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament. Rosemary Casals defeated Valerie Ziegenfuss, 61, 75.

title: MAX BRAUER DIES; HAMBURG MAYOR
description: BONN, Feb. 2Max Brauer, an antiNazi German emigr who returned to become the first postwar, mayor of Hamburg, directing this North Sea port's reconstruction, died here last night. He was 85 years old.

title: St. Regis Sets Venture
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to participate with Svenska Cellulosa, A.B., in the construction of a Kraft linerboard plant in Sweden in late 1975.

title: A.T.&T. Seeking Approval Of $87Million Expansion
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday with the Federal Communications Commission for permission to build approximately 35 million additional channel miles of telephone facilities at an estimated cost of $87million. The facilities would be used for interstate message (voice) and private lines services.

title: Fahnestock Draws Censure From S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Securities and Exchange Commission censured today the New York investment firm of Fahnestock & Co. for violating Federal securities laws and suspended most over the counter activities of its Bethlehem, branch for 90 days.

title: Petition Filed Against DCA
description: BOSTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)The DCA Development Corporation, recording a net loss of $3million for the nine months ended Sept. 30, against $428,330 income in the 1971 period, said today a group of its creditors have filed an involuntary bank ruptcy petition against the company. DCA has been in deficit operations for the past several quarters. Responding to the petition, the firm says it will try to make arrangements with its creditors under chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: Rangers Visit the Bruins, Seeking 7th Victory in Row
description: The last time a New York hockey team played in Boston, it createdin some fans' thinkingthe biggest stir in that city since the Tea Party. The Islanders were that New York team, and they shocked the Bruins by outslugging them, 97.

title: Contracts Are Awarded
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Boeing Company has been awarded an Air Force contract worth $14million for Minuteman III missiles. A $5.1million Navy contract for engineering services on shipboard weapon systems was received by Vitro Laboratories Division of Automation Industries, Inc. North American Rockwell Corporation obtained a $4.7million addition to a pact previously awarded by the Air Force for radar testing.

title: 30 Cardinals Named; Three Are American
description: ROME, Feb. 2Pope Paul VI today nominated 30 new cardinals from all continents, ineluding three Americans.

title: Howe, Noll Move to Final of Court Tennis Doubles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2Sam Howe and Eddie Noll, the defending champions, gained the final of the United States open court tennis doubles championship with the amateur pair of Luis Dominguez of New York and Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia today at the Racquet Club.

title: PETER C. ROCCO
description: Peter C. Rocco, director of the childcare division of Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and director of its office of operations, died apparently of a heart attack, Thursday evening. He was 45 years old and lived at 8431 Bay 16th Steet Brooklyn.

title: Equity Financing
description: John Blair & Co. said yesterday it Intends to purchase up to 200,000 of its common stock for use in connection with its existing employe stock option plan and other corporate purposes. The company said that so far this year it had purchased 38,800 of its shares pursuant to the repurchase program. The company's stock was down  at 10 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Eugene Archer, ExFilm Critic For Times, Dies on Coast at 42
description: Samuel Eugene Archer, a former motionpicture reviewer and reporter for The New York Times, was found dead Tuesday, apparently of natural causes, at his Los Angeles apartment. He was 42 years old.

title: Woman, 60, Is Found StrangledIn Her East Harlem Apartment
description: A 60yearold woman was found choked to death in her ransacked East Harlem apartment yesterday. One of her neighbors said the victim's welfare check had arrived Thursday.

title: Music: Lincoln Address
description: ST. LOUIS SYMPHONY ORCHESTRA, Walter Susskind conducting, with Janet Baker, mezzosoprano, and William WarHeld, narrator. At Carnegie Hall.

title: Tanker Port Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (Reuters)The Senate Commerce Committee announced today that it would hold hearings starting Feb. 28 on proposals for major offshore development projectsincluding ports to handle huge tankers.

title: Senseless Shooting ...
description: The senseless shooting of Senator John Stennis in front of his Washington home was a reprehensible act of a kind becoming all too common in the streets America today. While earnestly hoping for Senator Stennis's recovery, we also hope that the country will be sufficiently shocked by the depravity of the perpetratorswho calmly said to Mr. Stennis: Now we're going to shoot you anyway, and then did so after he had turned over his wallet and watch without offering any resistanceto insist at last on effective guncontrol laws at the Federal level.

title: Storm Damage to Trees Is Problem for Germans
description: LUNEBURG, West Germany, Jan. 23A severe storm that hit heavily timbered areas of Lower Saxony last November with winds of over 100 miles an hour felled millions of trees and has left thousands of foresters and farmers with the problem of what to do with the lumber.

title: DR. JOSEPH R. TOVEN EXN.Y.U. PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Joseph Richard Toven, emeritus professor of Spanish and Portuguese at Washington Square College, New York University, who was active in aiding foreign students, died yesterday of a heart ailment in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 71 Vernon Place, Mount Vernon, N. Y.

title: Sailor Cleared in Rioting
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 2 (UPI)Charges against a black sailor for taking part in racial disorders aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk were dismissed today after an officer told the courtmartial that the sailor tried to help calm the violence last October. Airman Apprentice James D. Jackson, 20 years old, was cleared of rioting charges after Comdr. Ben W. Cloud, executive officer of the Kitty Hawk, testified that the salior's attitude changed from hostile to helpful as the conflict aboard the carrier grew worse. The airman still faces two charges of assault and one of disrespect to officer.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: *** Jorgensen's Inn, Route 23, Stockholm, N. J. (201) 6977355.

title: FORCES TALKS STALL OVER RUMANIA ISSUE
description: VIENNA, Feb. 2  An East West meeting to prepare for a conference on force reductions in Central Europe opened formally here on Wednesday but has been stalled since over the issue of who is to be a full participant.

title: The Yellowstone Grizzlies
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.The Yellowstone grizzly bears are doomed to extinction in this century if the present national park management program is not halted at once. Such is the forecast of a report presented at park headquarters by John Craighead. John and his brother, Frank, are well known biologists and top authorities on the bears.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesJohnny Gant, 141, Washington, outpointed Ely Yares, 143, Philippines, 10 rounds.

title: Antiques: Federal Style
description: For the second time in this century a tambour desk by John and Thomas Seymour has set a new record for Federal furniture sold at auction. The new high of $41,000 was established last weekend, eclipsing the previous record of $30,000 paid by Henry Francis du Pont in 1930 for a desk that is virtually identical in proportions and similar in detailing.

title: CAHILL ASKS STUDY OF MINORITY HIRING
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2Governor Cahill today ordered a study aimed at guaranteeing blacks and members of other minority groups work on construction projects undertaken by the state or supported by state funds.

title: Fighting in Capital Feared As Moslems Protect House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Hanafi Moslems here have bricked over some windows and chopped down trees around their threestory mansion where seven of them were killed two weeks ago.

title: HARLEM MAN IS HELD IN KIDNAPPING, RAPE
description: A, 55yearold man was charged by the police with kidnapping and rape last night when a 20yearold woman, who said she had been held prisoner for two days, was found in his Harlem apartment.

title: West Germans Set Measures to Stem Inflow of Dollars
description: ZURICH, Saturday, Feb. 3The West German Cabinet, meeting in emergency session, ordered the tightening of foreignexchange controls early today to stem an influx of dollars that had reached crisis proportions. The curbs, effective Monday, were adopted after the Bundesbank, the West German central bank, had bought $700million to $800million yesterday. On Thursday the bank took in $200million.

title: ROSI MITTER MAIER CAPTURES SLALOM
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, Feb. 2 (AP)  Mittermaier of West Germany skied flawlessly down the Cannon Barrel track today to win the slalom, her first World Cup victory of the season.

title: Education and Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The publication of the Federal budget early each year is supposed to give an indication of how Federal money is intended to spent in the 12month period that begins the following July.

title: 4 Rockets to Study Aurora
description: CHURCHILL, Man., Feb. 2 (AP)Four rockets designed to study the aurora borealis were successfully launched early today in northern Manitoba. J. T. Faulkner, suuperintendent of the Churchill Research Range, said that three of the rockets had been launched from Churchill and a fourth, from Gillam, about 174 miles south. Two rockets were launched for the National Research Council of Canada and two for the U.S. National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The two agencies are cooperating in the study.

title: Bologna Court Lifts Last Tango Ban; State Plans Appeal
description: ROME, Feb. 2A Bologna penal court today lifted a ban on Last Tango in Paris and acquitted five defendants of obscenity, including the film's director, Bernardo Bertolucci, and its stars, Marlon Brando and Maria Schneider.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: ALEXANDER OUSTS SMITH IN TENNIS
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 2 (AP)John Alexander toppled Stan Smith, 46, 63, 6.4, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 Fidelity World Championship tennis circuit tournament tonight.

title: Rising Prices Threaten Family's Budget
description: For one Long Island family of five that keeps a careful budget, Phases 1, 2 and 3 of President Nixon's economic program all added up to the same thing: rising prices.

title: Mexican Musicians Placated
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 2 (UPI) A strike by the Symphony Orchestra of Mexico's National Fine Arts Institute ended officially today, but the musicians were still without a conductor. The 200 musicians went on strike two weeks ago, after their conductor, Carlos Chavez, Mexico's best  known living composer, stated publicly that they were mediocre. Mr. Chavez settled the strike yesterday by resigning.

title: DOLLS REVIVE ROCK IN AN UPTOWN DEBUT
description: The New York Dolls are the current darlings of this city's underground rock'n'roll scene, and Tuesday night they slithered cheerfully up to Kenny's Castaways (84th Street off Third Avenue) for their first uptown engagement.

title: Expected Move Due to Loan Demands by Corporations
description: Four large banks, led by the Franklin National Bank, yesterday raised their prime rates, the minimum rates they charge on loans to their most creditworthy corporate customers.

title: Boggs's Pilot Reported Aware of Weather Peril
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI)  Government safety experts reported today that the pilot of the airplane in which Hale Boggs, the House majority leader was lost last fall knew that bad weather might cloud the Alaskan mountain pass that lay across his flight path.

title: Man Held 2 Years in Tombs Is Cleared
description: A man who spent more than two years in the Tombs awaiting trial was acquitted of a double murder charge early yesterday in State  Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: A PostVietnam Era
description: In this country and abroad many words have been spoken in recent years about the glowing prospects peaceful greatpower coexistence in the world; of the 1970's, if only the irritant of the Vietnam war could be removed. Now that the moment is at hand, all the diplomatic projects now under way or about to be launched assume a special importance.

title: Johnson Stamp Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP A postage stamp in memos of Lyndon B. Johnson is sched uled ot be issued on Aug. 21 which would have been the lat President's 65th birthday. Th Postal Service traditionally sues memorial stamps after th death of a President. Mr. John son died Jan. 22.

title: Thieu Acts to Open Talks With Vietcong Next Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3President Nguyen Van Thieu announced today.that he had ordered a senior diplomat, to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.

title: Women's Liberation in the Comics: The Jokes Are on Everybody
description: Ms. Joanie Caucus, a middleaged wife and mother in a comic strip called Doonesbury, recently liberated herself. She took off on a motorcycle to live in a commune for a while and now does her mothering in a daycare center where, she says, I get paid for it!

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesJohnny Gitnt, 141, Washington, outpointed Ely Yares, 143, Philippines, 10 rounds.

title: Prison Psychiatrist Held. In Plot for Inmate to Kill 3
description: TRENTON, Feb 2The staff psychiatrist at the state prison here was arrested and jailed today, charged with attempting to get a convicted murderer in the prison to arrange the killing of the doctor's former wife and two members of her family.

title: On to South Africa
description: WASHINGTONJames Baker, a 38yearold American diplomat, is to arrive tomorrow at Jan Smuts Airport in the Republic of South Africa. The publicity given his arrival and activities in the next two years will belie the importance of is relatively lowranking position in the economic section of the U.S. Embassy. For James Baker is blackthe first black American to be assigned to segregationist South Africa.

title: RATE OF JOBLESS, AT 5%, IS LOWEST SINCE JULY, 1970
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The nation's unemployment rate dropped further in January, to 5 per cent of the labor forcethe lowest since July, 1970, when the same rate was reached as unemployment was heading upward.

title: Explosive Is Set Off In Cafeteria, Injures 90 in Miami Beach
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 2A container of gasoline was taken into a crowded cafeteria late tonight and an explosion was set off that injured at least 90 persons, most of them elderly, fire officials reported.

title: Dance: Taras Revivals
description: Even during the excitement of last summer's Stravinsky Festival at the New York State Theater by the New York City Ballet it was evident that not all the ballets presented were masterpieces and that some of them were not even at all good. But the total experience was worthwhile. Few people could have expected that almost all of these ballets would have eventually been, taken into the City Ballet repertory. Some of them should have been allowed to rest in peace.

title: Sonny Gluck, Who Played On Original Celtics, Dead
description: Edward (Sonny) Gluck, a basketball star of the original Celtics and the old Philadelphia Warriors in the nineteen twenties and thirties, died Thursday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 70 years old and lived at 65 Cardinal Road, Manhasset, L.I.

title: MET'S ODALISQUE TERMED GENUINE
description: PARIS, Feb. 2Daniel Wildenstein, the gallery owner who had a year to evaluate here the attribution of the Metropolitan Museum's Odalisque in Gray, told The New York Times there was no doubt whatsoever in his mind that the painting was by Ingres. He thereby found himself in complete disagreement with Thomas P. F. Hoving and Theodore Rousseau, director and curator in chief of the museum, who attribute the painting to Ingres's assistant, Armand Cambon.

title: In Memory of Clemente
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP) The Police Athletic League here is naming a center in a depressed Puerto Rican neighborhood after Roberto Clemente, the late Pittsburgh Pirate star. Clemente died last month when an airplane carrying relief, supplies to Nicaraguan earthquake victims crashed at sea.

title: Soybeans Soar Above $5 Mark On Prospect of Greater Demand
description: Soybeans, which have traded on several occasions at $5 a bushel in futures trading, soared above that level yesterday setting a new historic high of $5.08 a bushel. The beans closed at the new high level in terms of the March delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: JURORS QUESTION AIDE TO MACKELI
description: The chief assistant district attorney of Queens was questioned yesterday by a special grand jury seeking to determine whether the Queens prosecutor's office had tried to hinder and obstruct the investigation of a case in which some members of the office were involved.

title: New Jersey Biriefs
description: The highway death toll was reduced in New Jersey in 1972 for the first time in three years and the fatality rate for each mile traveled was the lowest in the state's records.

title: Jewish Activist in Moscow Seized by Police in Street
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (AP)Soviet secret police arrested a leading Jewish civilrights advocate on a crowded Moscow street today in a violent incident.

title: Ellsberg Judge Denies Dismissal Motion
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 2The judge in the Pentagon papers trial denied late this afternoon defense motions to dismiss the case or declare a mistrial.

title: Watergate Judge Wants U.S. to Revive Its Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The judge in the Watergate trial charged in blunt language today that the recently concluded criminal proceeding had failed to get to the bottom of the case and urged the Government to resume its investigation.

title: People in Sports Buford Sold to Japanese Nine
description: Don Buford, Baltimore's switchhitting outfielder may be the only player late for spring training this early in the year. He has to report to Fukuoka, Japan, by Feb. 12 to join the Lions of Japan's Pacific League. The Orioles announced yesterday they had sold Buford's contract for an undisclosed sum. Spring training is already under way in the Far East.

title: Lions Triumph, 8457
description: Bob Evans scored 24 points and Darryl Downing hit for 21 in leading Columbia to an 8457 victory over Dartmouth last night in University Gym. The victory gave the Lions a 511 overall record and a 3.2 mark in the Ivy League.

title: Title Bobsled Washed Out
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 3 (UPI)Rain and rising temper. atures forced cancellation today of the twoman National Amateur Athletic Union bobsled championships. Temperatures rose to 40 degrees as heavy rain fell on the Mount Van Hoevenberg bobrun. The fourman event has been rescheduled for tomorrow, officials said.

title: Watson, on 133, Leads by 4 In Hawaii With Ozaki Next
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 2Tom Watson, a 23yearold second, year campaigner on the pro golf tour, scored a 65 today and led the $200,000 Hawaiian open with a 36hole aggregate of 133 or 11 under par.

title: Philadelphia Judge Voids Sunday Supermarket Curb
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2 (AP) A Municipal Court judge ruled today that the state law banning Sunday sales in supermarkets was unconstitutional.

title: Civitico and Appel Art at 2 Galleries
description: The new vogue for representational painting has its peculiarities. One of these is that such painting, quite often, reaches back into the pastand not always the distant pastin order to establish its authority. Two current exhibitionsthose of Bruno Civitico at the Robert Schoelkopf Gallery, 825 Madison Avenue at 69th Street, and Thelma Appel, at the Kornblee Gallery, 58 East 79th Streetare cases in point.

title: Notes on People
description: Recently, Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, said he was refusing to submit to hijackingprevention searches at airports. The Senator said members of Congress should be immune from such searches. He hinted that the issue of his being searched Was related to his investigation, as a member of a Senate aviation committee, of the Federal Aviation Administration. Yesterday, the F.A.A. fined Delta Air Lines $2,000 for allegedly permitting the Senator to board one of its planes on Jan. 15, in Indianapolis, without a search of his person or baggage. The agency said it was also investigating a similar charge against Allegheny Airlines.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOUR DE FORCE If it is not precipitating, if it is not subzero cold, if air quality is acceptable and if you would like a Sunday of convenient colorful contrast,. here is a suggestion for tomorrow. Go to Chinatown around noon, or late in the afternnoon and see what is to be seen of the New Year festivities (there are a dragon dance troupe and two lion dance troupes working the sidewalk in front of the Transfiguration Church, 29 Mott Street, at 12:30) and, of eat.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Rubinstein Book Tells of Youth

title: Nixon Name Among Dozens Proposed for a Nobel Prize
description: OSLO, Norway, Feb, 2 (AP)The director of the Norwegian Nobel Institute confirmed today that President Nixon was among dozens of candidates proposed for the 1973 Nobel Peace Prize. The deadline for nominations was yesterday.

title: Bridge Foes Signed Up at Boat Show
description: At 4:05 yesterday afternoon, Mrs. Patricia (Toby) Kennedy and Mrs. Mary Lou Barbolini sent out for Cokes. We're parched, they said. Telling all these people at the National Boat Show why they should ban the bridge is a fulfilling, but a tiring, deal.

title: Newark Board to Shift Black Teacher
description: NEWARK, Feb. 2Members of the Board of Education, after a week of rising tensions between blacks and whites at Vailsburg High School, agreed unanimously tonight to accept the request of a controversial black teacher from the mainly white institution to be transferred.

title: ... in the Middle East?
description: Mr. Brezhnev has now aligned himself alongside President Nixon in singling out the Middle East as the most immediate challenge for the diplomacy of peacemaking. When it receives two imminent visitors, the Nixon Administration will have a natural opportunity to take some new initiatives. King Hussein of Jordan is due in Washington next week. Israel's Premier, Golda Meir, will arrive three weeks later.

title: Market Place: Hide and Seek In Profit Trends
description: Just how much information is a major company expected to provide for the public at the end of the year? Some major corporations take the position that financial results for the full year are enough without a breakdown for the final quarter.

title: THIEU ORDERS AIDE TO MEET VIETCONG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3President Nguyen Van Thieu announced to day that he had ordered a sen for diplomat to begin talks in Paris with the Vietcong on the political future of South Vietnam.

title: MRS. BOGGS GIVEN EDGE IN PRIMARY
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2Mrs. Hale Boggs seems to have the edge over four opponents in a special Democratic primary election tomorrow to select Mr. Boggs's successor as Louisiana's Second District representative.

title: FASHION TALK
description: When fashion people hark back to the nineteenfifties, which they do very often these days, they're not thinking about toreador pants and Bermuda shorts. It's the good old days they're fondly recalling, before the chemise, when a dress was a dress, bolstered by a full complement of undergarments and fortified by coats, jackets, hats and gloves.

title: News Summary and Index SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1973
description: International

title: COLONELS SCORE DYER Q'S, 118106
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 2 (AP) The Kentucky Colonels shook off a bad case of firsthalf ineptitude tonight and posted a 118106 victory over San Diego in American Basketball Association play.

title: STATES CONSIDER CLEANAIR ORDER
description: New York and New Jersey environmental officials began yesterday to look at more stringent air pollution control measures in the light of a court decision that could cut two years from the time they have to achieve cleanair standards.

title: Agnew, in Bangkok, Pledges More U.S. Aid to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 2 (UPI)Vice, President Agnew promised more military and economic aid to Thailand today in his meetings with the country's leaders.

title: Buckley Muses About the Senate
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2After two years in office, Senator James L. Buckley has suggested that the Senate might consider putting itself on a twoyear cycle, with committees reporting out bills one year for consideration on the Senate floor the next. Such a system, according to the New York ConservativeRepublican, would enable Senators to use their scarce time more effectively and would do away with arbitrary deadlines requiring hurried, patchwork approaches to important bills.

title: LISTS EASE AGAIN ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Investors' concern over inflation and weakness in the dollar overseas continued to depress prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Berlin Quartet Presents First Of 25 Concerts
description: The EastWest cultural thaw continues: After four years of negotiation, the first instrumental ensemble from East Germany, the Berlin String Quartet, has arrived in America (and as part of the exchange agreement, our Cleveland Quartet will visit East Germany in April). Thee four musicians, all in their 30's and members of the Staatskapelle (the orchestra of East Berlin's Deutsche Staatsoper), will give 25 concerts in this country in the next five weeks, and their first New York appearance was Hall Wednesday night.

title: Westinghouse Unit to Close
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 (UPI) The Urban Systems Development Corporation, a unit of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, is shutting down its modular housing systems plant in Fredericksburg, Va., for lack of firm orders, Westinghouse said. The plant's 150 employes will be laid off by the end of February.

title: Suspect Seized in L.I. Burglaries
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 2A tug of war with a rake between a prospective robbery victim and a man described by the police as a cat burglar responsible for stealing money from 150 Levittown homes in the last seven months resulted in the capture of the suspect early today.

title: Report Praises Poverty Program Despite Officials' Negative View
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2Controversy arose today over unpublished evaluation report thatcontrary to Administration opinion  concluded that the nationwide Community Action Program had been highly constructive in meeting Nixonl Administration goals.

title: Art: Exhibition Gives Hodler His Due
description: Ferdinand Hodler, the subject of an important exhibition that opened at the Guggenheim Museum yesterday, occupies such a curious position in the history of late 19thcentury painting that one hardly knows whether to say that this excellent summary brings him back into the mainstream of art history where he belongs, or reveals his peculiar isolation within it. In either case, the exhibition is long overdue, and plaudits are in order all along the line for the institutions that provided the opportunity and the individuals who made the most of it.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Bar to Medical Students Is Debated in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2 A decision by the University of Buenos Aires to tighten admission policies for its school of medicine has ignited a debate over the medical profession in Argentina and has resulted in the dismissal of the university rector.

title: ROSI MITTERMAIER CAPTURES SLALOM
description: SCHRUNS, Austria, Feb. 2 (AP) Rosi Mittermaier of West Germany skied flawlessly down the Cannon Barrel track today to in the slalom, her first World Cup Victory of the season.

title: Senate President Sits In for Cahill
description: TRENTON, Feb. 2 (AP)Senate President Alfred N. Beadleston, Republican of Monmouth, was sworn in today as acting Governor while Governor Cahill vacations for two weeks in California.

title: 2 Canadian Exchanges To Discuss Merger Plan
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (Reuters) Members of the Canadian and Montreal Stock Exchanges will discuss a plan to merge the two exchanges Feb. 15, according to a joint announcement by the exchanges. The plan was prepared by the governing bodies of the exchanges.

title: Screen: Shorts Series at Film Forum
description: A GROUP OF EXPERIMENTAL FILMS: ICE by J. J. Murphy, 9 minutes; IN PROGRESS, by J. J. Murphy and Ed Small, 20 minutes; ASPECTS OF THE HILL PART I; THE HILL by Naomi Levine, 12 minutes; PROJECT ONE (OP PRINTER) by Dave Lourie, 14 minutes; MR. PELICAN (OP PRINTER) by Robert Lange, 16 minutes; THE REPEATER by Stacy Keach, 17 minutes. At the Film Forum 256 West 88th Street.

title: Books of The Times
description: To his polemical writings on Katanga and the United Nations, Conor Cruise O'Brien has now added a volume on the troubles in Northern Ireland that will make his already embattled name even more controversial. It is an indication of the turbulent atmosphere that envelops every discussion of the Irish troubles that this

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: 3 Brothers Deaths Held Nonviolent

title: Nixon and Heath Conclude Talks and Return to Capital
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., Feb. 2 (UPI)  President Nixon and Prime Minister Heath of Britain concluded nine hours of talks on matters ranging from trade and economics to the Vietnam peace settlement.

title: MILTON C. BALDRIDGE
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 2  Milton C. Baldridge, retired secretary and director of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., died, apparently of a heart attack, at Santa Barbara Cottage Hospital on Wednesday evening. He was 77 years old and had been a resident of Bronxville, N.Y., until he moved here twoyears ago.

title: A THIRD LIBEL TRIAL FOR ALIOTO IS DENIED
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2A Federal judge ruled today that Mayor Joseph L. Alioto was not entitled to a third trial of his libel suit against Look magazine, which in 1969 accused him of being enmeshed in a web, of alliances with members of the Mafia.

title: Cell of Hatred
description: In my cellso aloneTo whom can I pour out my fierce hatred? My gaze is barred by a bolted door High walls shut out the sun's rays Wretched existence! My bowl and my straw pallet stink The only shirt, the only pair of trousers, are in rags My feet freeze in their rings of steel Half a mat to sleep on.

title: WASHINGTON SAILOR HELD IN KILLING OF 4
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (UPI) F.B.I. agents and Washington policemen arrested an AWOL sailor tonight on charges of allegedly killing four men, wounding a deputy sheriff and attempting to extort $10,000 front a real estate broker over nine days in nearby Maryland.

title: Department Stores Show Sales Gains
description: Leading department stores in New York achieved moderate sales gains during January, a survey by The Times showed yesterday. Stores in the city registered a 3 per cent over all gain during the month compared to the corresponding period of 1972. The area gain, which includes sales in the city stores and their suburban branches, was 5 per cent.

title: ... Mindless Killing
description: Even in this violent era, the slaying of Turkey's Consul General in Los Angeles, Mehmet Baydar, and his young Vice Consul for no discernible reason is particularly shocking. The man held for the shootings, who has pleaded not guilty, once said in an interview that 26 members of his Armenian family had been killed Turkey and the Soviet Unionbut whether or not this was true, it would still be an act of insanity to hold Mr. Baydar or Bahadir Demir responsible.

title: Man Trapped in Blaze
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 2 (AP) William L. Cromer, 41 years old, died of smoke inhalation today when he was unable to escape a burning frame house of a friend because the windows had been nailed shut to keep out burglars, the authorities said. He was alone.

title: Groundhog Sees Shadow
description: PUNXSUTAWNEY, Pa., Feb. 2 (UPI)A groundhog emerged from its burrow atop Gobbler's Knob at sunrise today, saw its shadow and scurried back into its hole. According to tradition, that signified six more weeks of winter.

title: Mays Becomes Teed Off At LateArriving Namath
description: SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Feb. 2The New York glamour team in the American Airlines golf tournament, Willie Mays and Joe Namath, broke up today when the Mets' outfielder got teed off and refused to play with the Jets' quarterback, who was 40 minutes late for the teeoff. But the incident apparently didn't hurt either's game.

title: U.S. BANKS AGREE ON ALGERIAN LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The ExportImport Bank and 24 commercial banks have agreed to lend $307.6million to the Government of Algeria to finance a pipeline and a liquefaction plant for the shipment to the United States of liquified natural gas.

title: Sinatra to Perform at White House
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 Frank Sinatra, entertainer, friend of Vice President Agnew and contributor to Republican campaigns, has been invited to an evening in his honor at the White House.

title: Lack of Funds Said to Bar Organizing Housing Court
description: Administrative Judge Edward Thompson, head of the Civil Court here, warned a group of state legislators yesterday that he could go no farther in setting up a new housing court unless funds for the court were committed.

title: Soviet Farm Minister Out
description: MOSCOW, Saturday, Feb. 3 A long expected shakeup of high Soviet officials in the wake of the disastrous 1972 agricultural year was disclosed early today.

title: ARMS TO CAMBODIA AND LAOS DEBATED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2A disagreement has reportedly broken out within the Nixon Administration over whether the recently concluded agreement for a ceasefire in Vietnam allows the United States to continue military aid to Laos and Cambodia.

title: Magnavox Teams With Teleprompter On FayTV System
description: The Magnavox and Teleprompter corporations have demonstrated a new paytelevision system that will permit cable TV subscribers to press a button, select and be automatically billed for movies, sporting events and other special programs.

title: COMPETITION URGED ON FUND SALES FEES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)The Justice Department today recommended that mutual fund dealers be permitted to compete on prices. Under present law, the original seller of mutual funds sets a price and commission that remains the same no matter how many resales occur.

title: Man Held 2 Years in Tombs Is Cleared
description: A man who spent more than two years in the Tombs awaiting trial was acquitted of a double murder charge early yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Watergate (Cont.)
description: In a letter printed on this page today, an official the Committee for the Reelection of the President makes the valid point that testimony in the Watergate trial did not establish that former Attorney General John N. Mitchell, campaign chairman, and former Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, finance chairman, personally approved any specific espionage activity against the Democratic party. A reading of the actual transcript of the trial shows that the testimony of Hugh W. Sloan Jr., former treasurer of the committee, was less conclusive than had first appeared to us on the basis of news accounts. The Times regrets the erroneous statement in our editorial of Feb. 1.

title: Formal Backing Granted for a Chicago Board Options Exchange
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2The Securities and Exchange Commission gave the formal goahead today to the Chicago Board Options Exchange. The exchange will be registered as a securities exchange, effective yesterday.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: RUTHERFORD, N. J., Feb. 2  What stands 6 feet 6 inches, weighs 265 pounds and provides more protection for a quarterback than an armed bodyguard?

title: Truce Supervisors Vote To Put Inspectors in Field
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 3After several days of fruitless debate, the International Commission of Control and Supervision voted this morning to send out its regional inspection teams on Monday, Canadian officials said, thus setting up the first machinery for actually monitoring the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: Agnew, in Bangkok, Pledges More U. S. Aid to Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Saturday, Feb. 3 (UPI)Vice President Agnew promised more military and economic aid to Thailand yesterday m his meetings with the country's leaders.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Philip Morris Lifts Prices Of Cigarettes; Others Due
description: Wholesale prices for both filter and nonfilter cigarettes were raised yesterday for the first time in nearly three years. The increase, fourtenths of a cent a pack, was announced by Philip Morris U.S.A., and was expected to be followed by other cigarette makers. It also was expected that the increase would be passed along quietly to consumers in the form of 1cent increases for a pack of cigarettes, and increases of 4 or 5 cents for carton. Trices of cigarettes dispensed by vending machines were expected to remain the same or increase slightly.

title: Prison Psychiatrist Held In Plot for Inmate to Kill 3
description: TRENTON, Feb 2The staff psychiatrist at the state prison here was arrested and jailed today, charged with attempting to get a convicted murderer in the prison to arrange the killing of the doctor's former wife and two members of her family.

title: Vanished Evidence
description: The basic reason for publication of the Pentagon Papers was to provide the American public with an authentic account of the decisionmaking process which committed this country to more than a decade of undeclared war in Indochina. The story thus unfolded was a chronicle of questionable judgments compounded by deliberate deception, designed to gain the support of Congress and the public for a disastrous military adventure.

title: Julie of the Wolves Wins Newbery Book Prize
description: The NewberyCaldecott Medals, considered the most prestigious annual awards for children's books, were announed in Washington Thursday by the children's services division of the American Library Association.

title: WALL ST. HOUSES PLANNING MERGER
description: Burnham & Co. and Drexel Firestone, Inc., two major investment houses, disclosed yesterday that they planned to merge and form a new organization to be called Drexel Burnham & Co.

title: NIXON'S MESSAGE ON STATE OF UNION IS FIRM ON CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2President Nixon, whose budget cuts and pledges to dismantle social programs have stirred angry debate on Capitol Hill, sent to Congress today a State of the Union Message that was unyielding in his intention to hold down spending.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Fort Dix Sergeant Is Charged In Death of Recruit After Hike
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 2 (AP) The Army announced today that charges of mistreatment had been brought against a staff sergeant In connection with the death of a private who was undergoing basic training.

title: Train Kills Rail Surveyor
description: A 22yearold member of a survey team inspecting railroad facilities of the Hudson Division of the Penn Central Railroad was killed when he was struck by a train yesterday, morning at West 177th Street near the Morris Heights station in the Bronx. The police of the Highbridge station identified the victim as Thomas DeBrunner of 3432 Irwin Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Text of the President's Message on State of Union
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP)Following is the text of President Nixon's State of the Union Message sent to Congress today:

title: Two U.S Wrestlers Lose In World FreeStyle Event
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 2 (AP)Two American freestyle wrestlers, Bob Orta and Dan Fey, were lefeated by their Soviet opponents today in firstround natches of the 12th internaional freestyle wrestling tourlament at Tbilisi, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. Soviet press agency, reported.

title: Bridge Foes Signed Up at Boat Show
description: At 4:35 yesterday afternodn, Mrs. Patricia (Toby) Kennedy and Mrs. Mary Lou Barbolini sent out for Cokes. We're parched, they said. Telling all these people at the. National Boat Show why they should ban the bridge is a fulfilling, but a tiring, deal.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Agrico Chemical to Expand
description: The Agrico Chemical Com pany, a subsidiary of the Williams Companies, announced yesterday that it would construct a $46million agricultural chemical complex on the Verdigris River east of Tulsa, Olda. The facility has a design capacity of 425,000 tons of ammonia and 600,000 tons of urea ammonium nitrate solutions a year, and is scheduled to go into operation Jan. 1, 1975.

title: Marcos Decree Offers Amnesty to Communists
description: MANILA, Feb. 2The martiallaw Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos is seeking to consolidate popular support by offering amnesty to Communist party members and sympathizers, especially the youth.

title: Boat Show Rides Economy Waves
description: Sales rose, sails dropped. Attendance fell, spirits grew. Expenses went up, costs diminished. That's about where the National Boat Show stood yesterday as the final weekend began.

title: Two Painful Years Later, a Hostess Returns to Her Real People
description: Robert Scull, who was wearing a purple and black cowboytype shirt under his black and white tweedmix beard, said he was a guest, just like everyone else.

title: The Economics
description: WASHINGTONThere is a paradox in the response that is coming from Congressand from the public for that matterto President Nixon's economic and budgetary plans.

title: The mathematics of taste
description: De gustibus non disputandum. What a ridiculous idea. If we don't argue about taste, what is there left to dispute? Whether grass is green or whether matters of fact are true? Taste until recently has been abandoned to the mad caprice of critics or just about anyone else who was pretty sure he knew what he liked.

title: Rural Swaziland Seeking Industry
description: MBABANE, Swaziland Landlocked Swaziland is looking beyond the pastoral charm of her scenic landscape to the green promise of industrial profits.

title: The classifiers of classified documents are breaking their own classification rules
description: The problem of classified documents, which has so bedeviled the Government, scholars and journalistsnot to mention Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony Russo and Prof. Samuel L. Popkinis usually discussed in a political vacuum. The three main questions hotly debated in scholarly circles are: Who should classify? What should be classified? How long should it remain classified? Whatever the right theoretical answers may be, however, they can have little to do with the real world of classified documents.

title: UNSERKELLY PAIR HOLDS GOLF LEAD
description: LAS CROABAS, P.R., Feb. 3 The frontrunning team of Del Unser, a Philadelphia Phillies outfielder, and Leroy Kelly, the Cleveland Browns star back; stayed ahead in the run for the $10,000 first prize in the American Airlines Golf Classic. Their lead, however, was cut to one stroke.

title: What Standards?
description: The impact of activities that cost the public millions, sometimes billions, of dollars has not been measured. One cannot point with confidence to the difference, if any, that most social programs cause in the lives of Americans.

title: Miss Roberts Fiancee
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., Feb. 3 Miss Ellanor Thompson Roberts and Russell Joseph Notides, seniors at Lake Forest College, plan to be married in the summer.

title: The KneeHigh Man
description: To understand most fully the Six tales retold here one would need tremendous comprehension of, and feeling for, the black experience. Most readers today, but especially the nonghetto reader, lack such knowledge and so will miss the innuendos which glimmer in the tales. Julius Lester mentions having loved to listen as his Methodist minister father and other ministers exchanged stories on a summer evening. During such listening sessions he must have gained much knowledge of hidden meanings, for the black preacher was then, as today, the leader and teacher of his people.

title: In South Africa, Blacks Progress
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa Although economic injustices in South Africa are still staggering, 1972 saw a trend toward better wages for the nation's black workers.

title: St. Albans Hospital Is Prepared To Aid P.O.W's From Vietnam
description: No one at the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens knows exactly when the prisoners of war will arrive or how many will be processed there, but the staff of the 607bed hospital, now only half full, is ready and waiting. They are waiting not only for the returning Vietnam servicemen but also for their families who will arrive there for reunions.

title: CUBA'S ECONOMY SHOWS GAIN IN '72
description: HAVANA, Feb. 3 (Reuters)The Cuban economy is showing signs of recovery, despite internal problems of mismanagement and low productivity.

title: Thief Lets No Word Get Out
description: ACCRA, Ghana, Feb. 3 (Agence FrancePresse)Telecommunications between Ghana and the outside world was blacked out for more than a day last week as a result of the theft of 135 feet of underground cable. The Post and Telecommunication Department said it lost about $30,000 in revenue.

title: Brazil Reaches Out to Africa
description: RIO DE JANEIROOnce a month the Ulsni sails from here for West Africa with a cargo of salt, sewing machines, kerosene, refrigerators, stoves and other manufactured products.

title: Monetary Storm Clouds Thereaten
description: PARIS  Once again the monetary storm clouds have gathered; yet what remains in the way of shelter is still pretty flimsy.

title: West German Bargemen Report Increased Harassment in East
description: BONN, Feb. 3  If I want to go to Berlin it goes through right away, said the barge captain on the Elbe. But if want to go over to West Germany it's as if I was bewitched.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: After reading J. Anthony Lukas's article (As Massachusetts Went, Jan. 14), would like to say that I was born in a small town in the Berkshires in what was then called Massachusetts. I thought as a child that my father was the original New England Yankee and that it was a cardinal sin to vote for any candidate other than a Republican. Many years have passedlince then and I realize that we have to support change. But how to account to my father, if I should meet him in Heaven, for the fact that his state was the only one in the Union to vote for George McGovern is more than I can fathom. The Revised Map of New England indicates what temporal steps have already been taken.

title: SHOP TALK
description: ROCHELLE  PARK The atmosphere of a, foreign marketplace, complete with thatched huts, hanging lanterns and rugs on the walls, adds to the excitement of buying things from faraway places, And that Is the atmosphere created at Pier 1 Imports.

title: Licit and Illicit Drugs
description: The Consumers Union Report on Narcotics, Stimulants, Depressants, Inhalants, Hallucinogens, and Marijuanaincluding Caffeine, Nicotine, and Alcohol. By Edward M. Brecher and the editors of Consumer Reports. 623 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $12.50.

title: I'm Not a ShowmanI Hate All That
description: PHILADELPHIA CLAUDIO ABBADO, Italy's entry in the podium superstar sweepstakes, is strikingly handsome In an aristocratic Roman way. He is built like a sportsman and wears skintight togs to prove it; he has a smile that dazzles despite Bugs Bunnyish teeth; he has Iong, dark hair that becomes seductively disheveled when set in motion, and he looks considerably younger than his 39 years. What is lacking to complete the prize package is a flamboyant personality to project these assets into the figure of a conductorial glamour boy.

title: Federal Freeze Imperils Housing Projects in Area
description: The future of more than $1billion worth of housing planned for 39,899 families in the metropolitan area has been placed in doubt by the recently announced freeze of Federal funds for housing subsidies.

title: New & Novel
description: Berlin in the 1930's would seem an ominous address for a Jewish familybut the Westheimers and their friends cling to their city with an inexplicable myopia. As they are progressively ejected from one social sector after another (schools, jobs, even their homes), the feeling persists that the unpleasantness will one day blow over.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given Eastem Standard Time

title: Miss McLeod Bride in West
description: DURANGO, Colo., Feb. 3Miss Constance McLeod and William Gay Ballantine, students at Fort Lewis College, were married here this afternoon in the college's chapel. The Rev. John Jaume of Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church performed the ceremony in Spanish.

title: Article 6  No Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (UPI) A 20foot angled backhand shot by Dan Maloney at 12 minutes, 33 seconds of the third period tday enabled the Chicago Black Hawks to tie the Philadelphia Flyers, 22, in a National Hockey League game.

title: Kissinger To Hanoi
description: WASHINGTONOnce again, President Nixon's ambassador extraordinary was preparing for another special conference. The site; Hanoi. The time: Feb. 10, to 13. The purpose: to begin a dialogue, that, could move relations with North Vietnam, from hostility towards normalization.

title: Joseph Boyd Again Named To the Governor's Staff
description: Joseph H. Boyd, Governor Rockefeller's former appointments secretary, has been named his special assistant for legislative liaison.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: In a recent Last Word column, Mark Van Doren at Columbia, Charles Simmons took a cheap shot at the Collegea remark that, in my opinion, was unpardonable in an otherwise moving remembrance.

title: Pollution
description: We might just say to the Feds we don't see any way that's possible to do it and if you think you can do it come up and try it.

title: Jane Keeney, Student, Is Betrothed
description: SOMERSVILLE, Conn., Feb. 3  Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Keeney Jr. of Somersville and West Hyannisport, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Dove Elise Keeney, to Peter Walker Burns, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. E. S. Burns Jr. of Kailua, Hawaii.

title: 70 Women Who Harmonize
description: MONTCLAIRTo a group of women in northern New Jersey, there's no business like show business.

title: ARTS CURRICULUM IS HELD A SUCCESS
description: A pilot project aimed at making the arts a more vital part of public school curriculum been judged a success by the private foundation that provided $346,000 for the experiment.

title: Bay State Tax Collections
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)Massachusetts tax collections through December continued at a record high pace over the previous year, according to the latest monthly report from the Department of Corporations and Taxation.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: The Metropolitan Life. Insurance Company has signed an agreement with a tenant organization to sell Riverton Houses, a 12building, 1,232unit housing project in Harlem for $15.3million.

title: 600 Blacks Were Elected in 11 Southern States in 1972
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Blacks made a significant showing in elections in the 11 states the South last year, placing 600 blacks in public office, the Voter Education Project said today.

title: U.S. and Britain
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister. Edward Heath and President Nixon see most world problems in much the same light, so the annual meetings between them are usually routine affairs. But last week, when the British leader arrived in Washington for another round of talks, Mr. Nixon said this conference was enormously important.

title: ST. LOUIS TEACHERS OFFERED $800 RAISE
description: ST, LOUIS, Feb. 3 (UPI)The Board of Education offered striking schoolteachers a conditional $800 acrosstheboard pay rise tonight in an effort to end a twoweekold strike.

title: 2 HELD IN BROOKLYN IN DOUBLE MURDER
description: Two unemployed laborers, one of them said by the police to be in a methadonetreatment program, were arrested yesterday by Brooklyn detectives and charged with the double murder of a Brooklyn teacher and his collegestudent roommate nine days ago.

title: Potting Shed Skeletons
description: WITH the basic knowhow and sufficient tender loving care, anybody can grow a cabbage, a tomato, a petunia or a philodendron, right?

title: Burial Costs Increased
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Boston is raising burial fees in 18 cemeteries between 12 to 20 per cent, effective next Monday. T. J. Tiernan, director of cemeteries, said the increases were necessary because of increased costs of union), labor, supplies and materials. Mr. Tiernan said the average cost of a burial now ranged from $225 to $240 but could go as high as $260.

title: Comsat Planning to Acquire Three Improved Satellites
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) The Communications Satellite Corporation said yesterday that it plans to acquire three improved satellites, to be designated Intelsat 4A, to meet increasing global demands for transmission service.

title: Nobody Ever Died Of Old Age
description: What life is like for those who face death

title: Miss Ankner Bride Of John M. Forelle
description: Miss Patricia Ankner of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Ankner of Palos Verdes, Calif., was married here yesterday afternoon to John Michael Forelle of Oyster Bay, L. I., son of Mr. and Mrs. Conrad Forelle of the Muttontown section of Oyster Bay and Westhampton Beach, L. I. The Rev. Norman Stanton performed the ceremony in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: Progress Is Slow in Uganda
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Since Gen. Idi Amin seized power two years ago, Uganda's economic growth rate has been about one per cent.

title: Building a cosmopolitan wardrobe
description: From all over the world they come sailing into New Yorkthe newest creations of designers large and small, famous and littleknown. From a casual pants outfit by a new Japanese designer to a peasant dress by Yves Saint Laurent. In no other city do shoppers have such a choice of domestic and foreign fashions from which to build a cosmopolitan wardrobe.

title: Stacey Howard Plans Bridal
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 3  Miss Stacey Ann Howard and Gary Edward Robinson have set Sept. 3 as their wedding date. They plan to be married at the Drake Hotel here.

title: In a Horrible City Money Can Be Made
description: LAGOS, NigeriaLagos is horrible, an expatriate businessman said at a recent cocktail party. I wake up to the warm, moist aroma of open sewers, the water, electricity and telephones don't work, the traffic jam begins at my garage.

title: Nixon Back at Camp David After Departure of Heath
description: THURMONT, Md., Feb. (AP)President Nixon returned to his retreat at Camp David today after an overnight trip to the White House where he bade farewell to Prime Minister Heath of Britain, who flew home to London after a round of intensive talks with the President.

title: Sports Week
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Sierra Leone Adds Crops
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone  The discovery in Sierra Leone last year of the world's third largest diamond  a 968.9carat stone the size of a hen's egg  has brought this West African, country some fortune and a little fame.

title: A Dying Copper Town Now Wants to Mine, and Purify, Its Past
description: Alice, Colo., went the way of 200 other small communities in the past ten yearsgone from the face of Rand McNally maps. A turnpike gobbled up Bill's Place, Pa., while DeSoto Beach, Fla., is now part of ... Cape Kennedy. The post office at Fairylawn, Ida., has closed because the only time the ranchers are there is when they run the cattle up the junipers.

title: Miss Catapano Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Catapano of Fresh Meadows, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marion Catapano, to Gary Hugh Hare, son of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Hare of the Bronx.

title: Met College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: IOWA BLAST TOLL CLIMBS TO 12 DEAD
description: EAGLE GROVE, Iowa, Feb. 3 (AP)The death count in the explosion and fire that leveled two buildings and damaged third rose to 12 today with the discovery of two more bodies, state officials said.

title: East Germany Widens Ties
description: EAST BERLIN, Feb. 3 (Reuters)East Germany and Ethiopia have established diplomatic relations starting last Thursday, the East German news agency A.D.N. reported.

title: THE OPENINGS
description: THE WHITE WHORE AND THE BIT PLAYERTomorrow, St. Clement's, 7. A play by Tom Eyen.

title: Duke Upsets 3dRanked Maryland, 8581, as Melchionni Scores 39 Points
description: DURHAM, N. C., Feb. 3 (AP) Maryland, No. 3 in the nation before an 8978 loss to North Carolina State this week, was beaten by another Atlantic Coast Conference basketball opponent today as Gary Melchionni scored 39 points in leading Duke to an 8581 victory.

title: Novick on A Recent Killing
description: I MAMU AMIRI BARAKA (a.k.a. LeRoi Jones, the author of Dutchman and The Slave) has written a play that is quite strikingly not the sort of play that Mr. Baraka might be expected to write. It is called A Recent Killing; it has lain in Mr. Baraka's trunk for a number of years; and it is now finally on view at the New Federal Theater on East Third Street.

title: Chaotic Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENHThe outlook for a ceasefire in Cambodia is becoming more optimistic. Sporadic military clashes continue, but on a small scale, and there are signs that the North VietnameseVietcong component of the antiGovernment forces is reducing its activity and may be pulling away from areas of combat.

title: Nixon Budget Reflects Use of 3 Tactical Rules
description: The first budget of the second Nixon Administration marks the end of an era that began with the pursuit of both guns and butter, the Vietnam war and the war on poverty, and ended with excessive inflation and excessive unemployment  and with the collapse of the international monetary system to boot.

title: Bridge
description: Abysmal ignorance is the normal state of bridge players as far as the laws of their game are concerned. This ignorance is not important, since the laws are available to be consulted when need arises, and in tournament play a director will give an authoritative interpretation.

title: Scholarship Stomp Proves a Success
description: PLUCKEMIN  Success is beginning to overwhelm the Pee Wee Russell Memorial Stomp.

title: Other Americans Lead City's Foreign Stock
description: Other America  as the Census Bureau collectively calls West Indian, Caribbean and South American countries now ranks first as a place of origin among New York City residents of foreign birth.

title: Mary Billings, A Nurse, Plans To Be Married
description: BRANFORD, Conn., Feb. 3Dr. and Mrs. William C. Billings hare announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Shirley Billings to Lionel Stewart Jackson Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jackson of North Haven and East Hampton, L. I. The future bridegroom's father is publisher of The New, Haven Register and Journal Courier.

title: Alberta Fusco Affianced
description: CRESTWOOD, N. Y., Feb. 3Mr. and Mrs. Albert Fusco have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alberta Ann Fusco, to John Francis Kozma, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kozma of Bayside, Queens, N. Y. Miss Fusco, a graduate of the State University of New York at Cortland, is a teacher in the Hawthorne School, Mount Pleasant School District, New York. Mr. Kozma is a member of the New York City Police Department.

title: Spring Drought Is Feared
Sudan Woos Foreign Capital
description: KHARTOUM, Sudan  In the last year and a half President Gaafar alNimeiry has survived a Communistsupported coup, reached an agreement with southern rebels ending a 7year civil war and dramatically reversed his nation's economic policies.

title: Stamps
description: GEORGE GERSHWIN, whose blending of the native idiom, jazz and classic, made him an immortal of American music, is receiving a philatelic tribute in addition to the many tributes he received during his shortlived career and in the years since.

title: L.I. Skiers Have Flurry of Day Trips
description: Now that the snow and cold weather have returned, Long Islanders can finally turn their thoughts once again daytrip skiing.

title: WOMEN'S LOBBY SEEKS NEW GOALS
description: A women's lobby and other coalitions that formed during the abortiondefense alert, before the United States Supreme Court decision that defused their main issue, are now elated to find themselves holding together as they line up additional targets for their energies.

title: Entrapment
description: A respected prosecutor who participated in a bribery scheme ... a Federal agent who posed as a twogun Mafia mobster ... clandestine tape recordings of payoff discussions... $15,000 in marked money. They were some of the elements of a trial in Manhattan Federal Court last weeka trial that raised the crucial question of entrapment: How far can the Government go in using. stealth and strategy to investigate and convict someone of a crime?

title: Sixties Going On Seventies
description: At eleven, writes Nora Sayre, I used to haul a lumpy spaniel to the park, in order to tangle his leash with that of exMayor LaGuardia's small white bulldog. LaGuardia was old and unwell; he looked cross. Each day, he shouted Don't! as I launched the spaniel at him. It was an honor to annoy the former mayor, who died soon after this abuse.

title: The Cultural Life of Nicaragua Slow to Recover From Quake
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 2The earthquake of last Dec. 23 all but destroyed the heart of Nicaragua's small but fertile cultural and intellectual life.

title: 10Year Rift Over Lost Ship Near End
description: Ten years ago at about 1:30 A.M. a routine radio message, involving a stock purchase, was received by a Southern coastal radio station. It was the last word received from the specialized bulk carrier Marine Sulphur Queen and her crew of 39.

title: Tourists Returning to Egypt
description: CAIRO  Egypt earned about 60million in foreign currency from tourists last year. That is $140million at the official rate, or $90million at the rate given to tourists, which is more nearly in line with the real value of the Egyptian pound.

title: STENNIS CONTINUES TO SHOW PROGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) Senator John C. Stennis continued to improve today. Officials at Walter Reed Army Medical Center said the Mississippi Democrat put on his eyeglasses today and combed his own hair for the first time since he was shot last Tuesday night.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTON AND POETRY

title: Writer as Wretch and Rat
description: A recent correspondent accused Capricorn here of having a lazy mind, and God knows it's true. This month, I'm not even going to try to think, but will talk instead about the plight of the writerwhich can be done while cracking nuts and whistling the Grand Canyon Suite.

title: Dutch Church
description: UTRECHT, the Netherlands  At Eucharistic rite last Sunday, the Primate of the embattled Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands, Bernard Cardinal Alfrink, and five of his six brother bishops took communion. The seventh and youngest member of the Dutch hierarchy, the Most Rev. Jan M. Gijsen of Roermond, remained halfhidden in a back pew.

title: Marine General Appointed To U.N. Group in Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 3 (AP)  Maj. Gen. Fred E. Haynes of Dallas will become senior United Nations member of the Korean Military Armistice Commission next Tuesday, the United Nations Command has announced.

title: Marine Corps Names New Sergeant Major
description: WASHINTGON, Feb. 3 (UPI)  The new sergeant major of the Marine Corps is Clifton A. Puckett, a combat veteran of three wars who witnessed the flagraising on Iwo Jima in 1944.

title: CELTICS CONQUER 76ERS, 104 TO 100
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (UPI) The Boston Celtics broke tight game wide open tonight by scoring 8 straight points in the last 2 minutes 9 seconds to defeat the Philadelphia 76ers, 104100.

title: The Fall and Rise Of Jimmy Hoffa
description: Over the years the various writings about the case of Jimmy Hoffa have been of a depressingly low standard. Generally they are heavily slanted either pro or con the former boss of the Teamsters Union, and poorly written to boot. Walter Sheridan's book exhibits the usual faults: Hoffa is depicted in an unnecessarily harsh light, while Sheridan's style is almost unreadably drab a succession of flat, declarative sentences, unleavened by reflection. The book is relentlessly chronological  most chapters end at the end of a given yearand far too long. Are there no editors at Saturday Review Press?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The offer by United Nations Secretary General Waldheim to mount a strictly humanitarian reconstruction operation in Vietnam without any discrimination is a news item which is most timely and most welcome.

title: At the Automat, Real Estate Is a Profitable Dish
description: It reads like one of those hypothetical braintwisters in managementschool case books: Company X is an old restaurant and foodretailing chain with a national reputation. But the golden dawn of 60 years ago has become a sunset of red ink. The company has not turned an operating profit since 1968, and 1970 and 1971 were disasters.

title: Yorkshire Housewives Told About Collards
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 3 (UPI)Finally, the people of Yorkshire, England, have been told what Southern collards are.

title: Bronx Project Backed
description: The City Housing and Development Administration has given a $22million commitment to a builder to rehabilitate 1,000 apartments in the rundown South Bronx, the largest project undertaken by the often controversial Municipal Loan Program. Details, Page 44.

title: FRANCIS E. SMITH
description: Francis E. Smith, who retired in 1965 as a senior art buyer for Young & Rubicam, the advertising agency, died Wednesday in Doctors Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here and in Paris.

title: Gene Mechanic Weds Ruth Chapin
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 3 Miss Ruth Elizabeth Chapin was married here this afternoon to Gene Barry Mechanic, son of Mrs. Eveline Mechanic of Fairlawn and Arthur Mechanic of Hillsdale. The cere mony, written by the couple was performed by Rabbi Jeraid Bobrow at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Chapin, parents of the bride.

title: History Class Eats Way Through Italy
description: MAPLEWOOD  It was from his honors students that Anthony G. Procopioi, a history teacher at Columbia High School, first got the message about a year ago. Eating pasta, they told him, is really much better than talking about it.

title: SCHOMBURG FILES GET HARLEM SITE
description: The city has acquired a blocklong site in Harlemon Lenox Avenue between 135th and 136th Streetsto house the Schomburg Collection of black literature and history, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: Idyllic Madagascar Develops Industry
description: TANANARIVE, Madagascar The picture of Madagascar as an idyllic, unchanging island at the end of the earth is being dramatically redrawn.

title: WOMENS LOBBY SEEKS NEW GOALS
description: A womens lobby and other coalitions that formed during the abortiondefense alert, before the United States Supreme Court decision that defused their main issue, are now elated to find themselves holding together as they line up additional targets for their energies.

title: True Knight Takes Seminole at Hialeah
description: MIAMI, Feb. 3The strategy for Darby Farm in today's $64,000 Seminole Handicap at Hialeah was obvious. Send His Majesty out on the pace and then, should he falter, True Knight, his stablemate, would come along and pick up the pieces. That's just the way it I happened, but all too literally.

title: Other News From Indochina
description: TRUCE OBSERVERS Communist and allied delegates to the Joint Military Commission and members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision of the Vietnam ceasefire met for the first time today in Saigon. Officials said that the international commission would start sending out field inspection teams tomorrow.

title: 6 KILLED, 17 HURT AS GUNFIRE RAKES BELFAST STREETS
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, Feb. 4At least six people were killed and 17 were reported wounded during a night of violence in Belfast, as British troops fought guerrilla gunmen and sectarian assassins roved the streets.

title: MISS YOUNG LEADS IN SPEED SKATING
description: OSLO, Feb. 3 (AP)Sheila Young of Detroit won the 500 and 1,000 meter races today in the amateur world sprint championships and took the lead in a bid for her first international speed skating title.

title: A Guide to the Mysteries of Form 1040 ...
description: Johnnie M. Walters, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, is optimistic about the agency's efforts to simplify the tax returns. The effort went so far as to change that archaic word spouse to husband or wife. So you can see that this was no routine face lift.

title: Air Force Five Triumphs
description: AIR FORCE ACADEMY, Colo., Feb. 3 (AP)The Air Force Academy defeated Corpus Christi, 7253, in college basketball today for its 11th victory in 17 games. Corpus Christi is 107.

title: NEW CHINA SEEN BY JOSEPH ALSOP
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31To a reader whose memory reaches back a decade or so, it might have seemed as if Joseph Alsop had done a sudden aboutface on the subject of Communist China.

title: Old Eagle Morgue Is Dying
description: The Brooklyn Eagle morgue perhaps the most valuable single source of information for scholars of the borough's history  is dying a slow death of neglect and decay in the basement of the main branch of the Brooklyn Public Library.

title: The Chief Awards
description: Novice A (Doris Miller, Judge)Arlene Knych's toy, Petite Lamb Chop (195 plus points).

title: Islanders Strike Early, Hang on to Tie Sabres, 11
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 3The New York Islanders achieved a poor man's moral victory tonight when they skated to a 11 tie against the wonder team of the National Hockey League, the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Arolithi Welcomes Greeks Bearing Gifts
description: AROLITHI, CreteDeep in the rugged interior of westcentral Crete, far from the touristfilled tavernas fringing the Mediterranean, the 100 or so residents of this mountain village waited in the large, muddy clearing that was their village Square.

title: Home Improvement
description: TODAY'S homeowners have been showing an increasing interest in the use of materials that create an outdoorsy or natural look on interiorsparticularly as regards wall coverings and panels. An early development was the use of burlap, cork and similar materials in lieu of standard wallpaper, but the trend became even more dramatic some years ago when homeowners started using weathered barn siding  actually torn off old barns in rural areas  to panel interior walls of dens, halls and even living rooms.

title: Drive to Get Good Judges Is Begun in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3 (AP) The formation of a broadbased citizens group aiming to get good judges elected in Philadelphia has been announced.

title: 2 CeaseFire Control Units Hold First Saigon Meeting
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 4Communist delegates to the Joint Military Commission appeared in downtown Saigon today for the first time to meet with members of the International Commission of Control and Supervision of the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: WALL STREET
description: A popular theory in Wall Street is that 1973 will be the year of the blue chip, the year when investors return to those fundamental values to be found in solid, if unspectacular, companies in basic industries with sound earnings prospects.

title: Rebel Leader Optimistic On a Laotian CeaseFire
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 3A high leader of the Communistled Pathet Lao arrived here tonight from Hanoi and said that he hoped a Laotian ceasefire would be concluded quickly.

title: Mont Blanc Holds Breath on Olympic Bid
description: MEGEVE, France, Feb. 3In alliance with the Mont Blanc resorts nearby, official Megeve is touching wood (the French version of knocking on it) for the prize Denver rejected.

title: DominguezBijur Duo Wins Open Court Tennis Doubles
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3The lamateur team of Luis Dominguez of New York and Jerry Bijur of Philadelphia won the United States open court tennis doubles championship today in straight sets at the Racquet Club.

title: Stennis
description: WASHINGTONThey came out of the shadows on the treelined street, took his wallet and watch, and shot him twice with a smallbore pistol. I think it's reasonable to assume that they did not know his identity, a police inspector theorized. They just saw an expensive car with inaugural plates and figured he'd have some cash.

title: A Train on the Soul Track
description: IN THE current lexicon of Black street usage, a Jones is a habit born of need. I've developed a new one recentlya Jones, that isalong with a lot of other folks in town, for the Saturday morning television show called Soul Train (Channel 5 at 11).

title: The 10th Man Theme: American League's Overture to Lost Fans
description: In the baseball box scores this summer, he will be listed as the dh, the designated hitter for the pitcher. He may be Rico Carty or Harmon Killebrew or Tony Oliva or some other American Leaguer with a good bat and aging legs. He will be deployed strategically by the manager, analyzed by the statistician, enshrined by the historian and probably he will be mis understood by the fan.

title: Few Enter Morocco's Open Door
description: RABAT, MoroccoThe Moroccans have the welcome mat out for potential investors to visit Morocco, says an official document of the United States Department of Commerce. But in the last year or so few investors have entered the door.

title: Innsbruck Expected to Get '76 Winter Games Today
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Feb. 3For the third time, the International Olympic Committee has received the same response from a United States city desiring to stage the 1976 Winter Games to the questionHow will the games be financed?

title: Hunt for Peking Man Quickens
description: When Christopher G. Janus, a wealthy Chicago stockbroker, visited China last June, one of his hosts pulled him aside. Help us find the Peking Man, he implored Mr. Janus. If you can return him to us, you will be a hero to the Chinese people.

title: Princeton Awaits Squash Devotees
description: PRINCETON  For four days this month, this sedate university town will be transformed into the squashracquets capital of the United States.

title: Zaire Is Emphasizing Diversification
description: KINSHASA, Zaire An. American tire plant herethe. first in this Central African countryhas in many ways become the key to needed diversification of the Zairean economy.

title: New Paltz Sinks Maritime
description: New Paltz State scored its third basketball victory of the season, beating New York Maritime, 6963, yesterday. New Paltz has a 314 wonlost record. Maritime is 28.

title: Miss Sherry Sue Gold Fiancee of John Bloom
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 3 Miss Sherry Sue Gold and John Alexander Bloom, seniors at the State University at Albany, plan to marry. Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Gold of Great Neck and Livingston Manor, N. Y., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Jack Bloom of New York and Mrs. Beverly Bloom of Great Neck.

title: R. B. Greenwald to Wed Sherry Axelrod
description: ENGLEWOOD, N. J., Feb 3 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert E. Axelrod have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Michele Axelrod to Robert Bruce Greenwald of Miami. The wedding is planned for June at the Regency Hotel in New York.

title: No Ox at Year of Ox Fete
description: WESTWOODFriday night ushered in the Chinese New Year, and the Year of the Ox (4671) was celebrated in traditional style at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Pon Yang.

title: Connally
description: WASHINGTON  Like a king in search of an heir, the President, it is said, wants a strong man of his own philosophical bent to take over the Nixon legacy. That man, made to order: John Connally, the suave but tough Texan whom Mr. Nixon reportedly holds in such awe. The presumed scenario: Mr. Connally would, at the proper moment, be named Secretary of State, in a strong position from which to run for President as a Republican.

title: JERSEY FAMILIES RETURN TO HOMES
