description: ART

title: Point of View
description: That African countries stand in great need of trained manpower is beyond doubt, but some countries are in greater need than others. At one end of the spectrum is Egypt, which has trained teachers and doctors for whom employment is not available in their own country. But Egypt does have shortages in engineering and other fields.

title: Nassau Plans Pass For Entry To Parks
description: MINEOLA, L. I.Because nonresidents have been reported to be using false identification to use Nassau County recreation facilities, County Executive Ralph G. Case announced last week that starting March 1 all county residents will have to have, a leisure pass with their photograph on it to prove their identification.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:The article by Prof. Stuart A. Taylor of Harvard, Room at the Top? Not For Blacks (Jan. 14), was embarrassing to most blacks. Professor Taylor makes the point that black scholars . . . often yield to the temptation to conduct research on the historically disadvantaged . . . and (this is) often judged to be a small price to the black scholar If he or she can make some progress in correcting some wrong perceptions Americans have about our struggle . . .

title: Momentous Momente
description: LONDON CRITICS are, of course, paid to carp. But occasionally there comes a moment when they must throw caution to the winds and fire a salute. This I now do: The final version of Karlheinz Stockhausen's Momente, which had its first performance in December at Bonn and on Jan. 15 reached London on the first leg of a tour that takes in France, Belgium, Switzerland and Italy, is a landmark in postwar musical history.

title: Orthodox Council Backs Chief Rabbi
description: The Rabbinic Council of America, a prominent Orthodox group, has affirmed its support of the office of the Chief Rabbinate in Israel as the sole religious authority in all matters concerning religious problems in Israel.

title: Treasure Hunting: A. Regal Reward
description: NOT long ago, a treasure hunter pushed his spade into the edge of a swamp in Wilton, Conn., and unearthed a 20pound fragment of the most famous piece of sculpture in early American history, a large equestrian statue, of George III, the last king of the American colonies, that stood 200 years ago in New York City's Bowling Green Park.

title: Recordings
description: TRADITION tells us that choral music, as far as the record business is concerned, does not tend to enjoy cornucopian sales unless it happens to be Messiah or the War Requiem. Yet the flood of new choralorchestral issues thrusts forward a dozen works, some of them masterpieces, in six albums ranging over two centuries, the implication being that there must be a public for this music somewhere, and in consequence it is well worth doing. Question: Is it always done well? It's notoriously difficult to achieve an acceptable recorded balance between an amateur choir and a professional orchestra. Reverse the equation and you see at once how ludicrous this becomes: a recording of Beethoven's Ninth with a professional chorus and an amateur orchestra. Who needs it?

title: DISPUTE GOES ON AT SANTA BARBARA
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Feb. 3  Four years after the oilwell blowout in the Santa Barbara Channel on Jan. 28, 1969, the conflict continues over howor whetherthe channel should be developed by the oil industry.

title: ExZoo Chief Will Miss His Elephants
description: Some men like dogs; others like horses. Ronald Ellis goes for elephants. In fact, he has had a close relationship with elephants for 36 years at the Prospect Park Zoo.

title: Miss Acker To Be Bride
description: WILMETTE, Ill., Feb. 3 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Flint Acker have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Catherine Elizabeth Acker of Washington, to Virginius Nelson Vaughan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Vaughan Jr. of Chatham, N.J.

title: Frank Watson to Wed Margaret J. Schenkel
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 3Mr. and Mrs. James M. Schenkel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret J. Schenkel, to Frank A. Watson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Watson of Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Lorraine W. Besch Betrothed. To Ens. Paul B. Sanwick Jr.
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Feb. 3  Mrs. Robert Woodruff Besch of Short Hills and South Casco, Me., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Lorraine Wrightson Besch, to Ens. Paul Bainbridge Sanwick Jr., U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanwick of Denver.

title: Art Notes
description: ANNE BRODZKY, editor of artscanada, checked in from Toronto the other day with the cheery news that art is alive and well in the chilly northand what's more, artscanada is on top of it. And what's artscanada? Not exactly a bigtimer like, say, Artforum, but one whose editing, photography and integrity of approach make it the best of its breed in Canada (that's easy) and are gaining it more and morewell, resonancein the noisier art world across the border.

title: Florence Weinsoff, TV Producer, Wed
description: Miss Florence Weinsoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Weinsoff of New York and Long Beach, L. I., and David Anton Friedman, son of Mrs. Rose G. Friedman of New York and Isadore Fried, man of Los Angeles, were married here yesterday evening at the Plaza by Rabbi Meyer Machlis.

title: Liberia Expands Agricultural Output
description: MONROVIA, LiberiaLiberians were unpleasantly reminded last year of the disadvantages of heavy reliance on a single commodity.

title: Fayetteville, N.C., Paper Set
description: FAYETTEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 3 (AP)Six businessmen here announced plans Thursday to establish a daily morning newspaper to be called The Fayetteville Post. Richard R. Allen, a construction company officer and president of the newly chartered Cumberland Publishing Company, said that publication would begin as soon as possible. No date was set. The Fayetteville area, which includes the big Fort Bragg Army complex, is now served by The Fayetteville Observer, an afternoon newspaper.

title: Scholarship Program Is Offered
description: OLD WESTBURY, L.I. The New York Institute of Technology, which serves about 5,000 students at its 725acre estate here, announced this week a $5million scholarship program for high school students.

title: Dade County Rejects Florida Jetport Site
description: MIAMI, Feb. 3The controversy over Greater Miami's new jetport has been rekindled by the Dade County Commission, casting a shadow over the future of the sixyearold project.

title: Man Is Slain After He Aided a Woman in the Subway
description: An unidentified man was shot and fatally wounded on a Manhattan subway platform last night after he had reportedly sought to keep the gunman from pestering a young woman.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: BRANFORD, Conn.Pushed in from the broad reaches of Long Island Sound by a gentle southeast wind, a dense fog blotted out the dark, rocky islands, known as the Thimbles, that lay seaward of us, and we were alone in a strange, gray world.

title: Shoulder to Shoulder to Shoulder to Shoul
description: ROME  We know very little about the future, but one thing seems pretty sure: the world population will double its present size in thirty years.

title: Patrolman Using Shotgun Kills a Gunman in Harlem
description: A radio car patrolman using a shotgun that he was not authorized to carry shot and killed a gunman yesterday on a Harlem apartmenthouse landing after, the police said, the gunman had fired at him twice. The police said later that the gunman's cartridges were blank.

title: World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 3A Western oil group, which has been producing a third of Libya's petroleum, has offered to hand over a 25 per cent interest to Libya immediately and 50 per cent in 10 years, under threat of nationalization.

title: Tasmania Is Down Under the Land Down Under
description: IT is a Sunday morning in Swansea, Tasmania (pop. 680). Great Oyster Bay sleeps. The golf links off Waterloo Point are empty. The public bar at the Swan Inn is locked tight.

title: Susan Denison Engaged
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 3Miss Susan Lea Denison and Roger DeWitt Elsas plan to be married on April 7. Announcement of their engagement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. J. Robert Myers, stepfather and mother of the future bride, who is the daughter also of the late Philip A. Denison. Her fianc's parents are Jason M. Elsas of New York and Mrs. Edmund M. Granville of Northport.

title: Hollywood, From A to Zukor
description: HOLLYWOOD.

title: Chess: TieBreaking For the U.S. Championship
description: The threeway match to break the tie for the United States chess championship got under way last night at the La Salle Hotel in Chicago. Each player  Lubomir Kavalek, Samuel Reshevsky and this writer  will meet the others twice.

title: 2 OFFICERS ARE SHOT BY CONVICT IN COURT
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 3 A man who had just been convicted of rape seized guard's gun in the Bergen County Courthouse here today, and shot and wounded two sheriff's officers before he was shot three times in the stomach by other officers, authorities reported.

title: Mrs. Heywood Broun Dies; Writer's Widow, ExDancer
description: Mrs. Heywood Broun, widow of the newspaper columnist who had been president of the American Newspaper Guild, died yesterday at her home, 55 East End Avenue.

title: Shipping Season on Great Lakes Is Extended Further Into Winter in a Test
description: SAULT SAINTE MARIE, Mich., Feb. 3  The Great Lakes, the nation's only major waterway frozen into uselessness for several months each year, is about to end the longest shipping season in its history.

title: Police Support
description: Since the days of the early Dutch settlement of Manhattan, crime in the streets has been the problem of authorized policemen. There were turbulent times when the police have needed the assistance of the National Guard, even the United States Army. And there were decades, particularly in the last century, when the welltodo carried arms and hired private police to patrol their neighborhoods. In recent years, private guards have returned and unpaid house patrols have been set up.

title: GOVERNOR SCORES BUCKLEY'S MOVE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Governor Rockefeller said today that Senator James L. Buckley's plan to introduce a Constitutional Amendment to overturn the United States Supreme Court's recent abortion ruling would feed divisiveness which the court's decision has abated.

title: Point of View
description: Regional Administrator, Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Acting O.E.O. Chief Discerns Marxism In Poverty Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Howard J. Phillips, chosen by President Nixon to oversee the dismantling of the Office of Economic Opportunity, said today that the Federal antipoverty agency had been founded on a Marxist notion.

title: Bob Charles Is Victor, In South African Golf
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 3 (AP)  Bob Charles, the New Zealand lefthander, fired a finalround, twounderpar 70 today and won the South African golf championship with a sixunderpar 282.

title: ROCKEFELLER ASKS HANDGUN CURBS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 3Governor Rockefeller today sent to the Legislature a bill designed to more strictly regulate the possession of hand guns in the state.

title: Vonnegut's Responsibility
description: Mother Night is the Vonnegut book that has not been reviewed anywhere, ever, because it was sold first into paperback for a handy sum: he needed the money for his large family. And paperbacks don't get reviewed; so it has been ordained. Authors always feel that readers should know and care more about this kind of literary imperative than they do; there is more to what makes reputations than is taught in classes on literature.

title: Feminine Plural
description: In a memo to The New Yorker staff, Wolcott Gibbs once said that too many writers ended their short stories with some sentence like Suddenly Mr. Holtzmann felt tired. A similar note of vaguely cosmic resignation pervades this collection, tempting the reader to respond irritably, If this is growing up, don't want it. Maybe literary fashion is to blame for this tone; the conventional short story encourages the author to squeeze out a bittersweet revelation by way of conclusion. But more likely, Miss Spinner has assembled 10 stories about just one facet of growing up. She attempts to forestall this objection in her Foreword: In a time when the position of women in society is being reassessed, ... these stories have a particular and hopeful relevance. If they are telling us that growth is painful, they also make it clear that dispensing with illusion is the first necessary step on the path to maturity. And that it carries with it its own undeniable rewards. My copy of the book didn't mention any rewards. Mostly it showed me young women forced into such delightful options as madness, impotent rage, marriage of convenience, and passive acceptance of what Miss Spinner calls adult compromise. Yearning hopelessness looks like women's lot. (The music in the studio seemed to be urging violently and clumsily for something that was not to be had. Something inside her felt as if it were enclosed in a cage too small for it, and she could not breathe. Read as a set of Cautionary Tales, this would make a fine consciousnessraising text.

title: Lisbeth Levenson Plans June Wedding
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., Feb. 3Mr. and Mrs. Sam Levine have announced the engagement of Mrs. Levine's daughter, Miss Lisbeth Lynn Levenson, to Heywood Henry Adler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias Adler of White Plains. A June 9 wedding is planned. The bridetobe, who attended La Combe in Roll, Switzerland and Le Fleuron in Florence, Italy, graduated from the TobeCoburn School for Fashion Careers. She is boutique buyer with L. A. Schulman, the White Plains specialty store founded and owned by her grandfather, Louis A. Schulman. Her stepfather is a textile converter.

title: Miss O'Shea Is Fiancee of James Pfohl
description: POINT LOOKOUT, L. I., Feb. 3Miss Elizabeth Marie O'Shea and James Mathis Pfohl, president of Plaxall Inc., a Long Island City, Queens, plastic packaging concern, plan to be married Feb. 17 in New York at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: The CeaseFire
description: SAIGONShrouded in secrecy, the seven American helicopters flew into a Communistheld town about 70 miles north of Saigon. The aircraft picked up three score uniformed men and returned to Saigon's Tan Son Nhut airport. Out of one helicopter stepped Lieut. Gen. Tran Van Tra, the chief Vietcong delegate to the fourparty. Joint Military Commission that is to help monitor the ceasefire in South Vietnam.

title: Miss Mary Malsin Is Bride Of Robert Merrow in Suburb
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 3Miss Mary Malsin was married here this afternoon to Robert Lord Merrow, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Griswold Merrow of Noroton, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Peter H. Samson of the Unitarian Community Church in White Plains performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Malsin, parents of the bride.

title: GERIATRICS AIDES OFFERED TRAINING
description: The Frederic D. Zeman Center for Instruction, which has one of the largest geriatrics training programs in the country, is preparing for its spring semester, with a record enrollment of more than 200 people.

title: ST. JOHN'S SUBDUES ARMY. FIVE, 8070
description: WEST POINT, Feb. 3  St. John's slowed the pace during the final eight minutes tonight, opened a 2313 scoring drive and posted an 8070 victory over Army.

title: Pakistani Parties Are Split Over Draft Constitution
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 3 Political parties here are at loggerheads over the draft of a constitution that is scheduled to be enacted in the next few months.

title: South Korea Will Legalize Abortions in Some Cases
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 3 (AP)Abortion will be legalized on a limited basis in South Korea within three months under a new health law approved by the Extraordinary State Council.

title: Anne Marie Diskin To Wed in Summer
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Feb. 3  Miss Anne Marie Diskin and Robert A. Smalley Jr., graduates of St. Leo College, plan to be married this summer.

title: Questions On Whether Boom Will Slow in '73
description: WASHINGTONThe most important issue raised by President Nixon's annual economic report last week was not the report's detailed forecast of the economy for 1973. Rather it was whether the boompace expansion of the economy will, start to slow after midyear, a development that the report said was both probable and desirable.

title: Drought Vexes Rhodesia
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia Almost complete failure of the summer rains has caused severe losses of Rhodesian, food crops that seem certain to bring the country the most serious economic setback in recent years.

title: City Aid to Udalls Cove
description: The announcement last week that the city would allocate funds to purchase and preserve New York's last remaining marshland signaled a victory in a long and bitter struggle by conservationists  but one serious challenge remained.

title: CITIES ASSAIL NIXON ON REVENUE SHARING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (UPI) Two groups speaking for the nation's cities charged today that the Nixon Administration had broken the President's promise to avoid using revenue sharing as an excuse to wipe out Federal aid programs.

title: INDIANAPOLIS LOSES SCHOOL BIAS CASE
description: INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 3, (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit, Chicago upheld this week a ruling by United States District Court Judge S. Hugh Dillin that the Indianapolis school system had practiced racial segregation from 1954 to 1968.

title: Shows, Lectures
description: THE dates have been set for spring flower shows on the East Coast. The Philadelphia Flower Show will be held at the Philadelphia Civic Center, March 1118. The Long Island Garden Show will be held at the Long Island Arena, Commack, March 918. The New England Spring Garden and Flower Show will be held at the Commonwealth Armory, Boston, March 1725. The New Jersey Flower Show will be held at the Morristown National Guard Armory, March 1725.

title: Martin Jumps 449 Feet To Lead Ski Flying Meet
description: IRONWOOD, Mich., Feb. 3 (AP)Jerry Martin of Minneapolis soared 449 feet today to break the Copper Peak record and take the early lead in the first day of official jumping in the Samsonite ski flying meet.

title: As Copper Goes So Goes Zambia
description: LUSAKA, Zambia  When Northern Rhodesia, a former British protectorate, became independent Zambia in 1964, her main problem was how to develop not only the vast copper wealth but also a meager agricultural economy.

title: Navy Wins Last Two Bouts To Top Lehigh on Mat, 21.15
description: BETHLEHEM, Fa., Feb. 3 Navy won the last two bouts here today to defeat Lehigh's wrestlers, 2115, for its eighth victory in 12 meets. The losers have an 115 wonlost record.

title: Letters: Realities On the Kwai Bridge
description: To the Editor Alvin Smith's story from Thailand, The Kwai Bridge: The Reel and the Real (Travel Section, Dec. 17) recalled a day and night I spent in the Kanchanaburi area in 1970 while with the United States Information Service.

title: A. T. PierceGrove Weds Ann Fowler
description: MADISON, Conn., Feb. 3Miss Ann Denman Fowler and Antony Terence PierceGrove, both of New York, were married here this afternoon in St. Andrews Episcopal Church by the Rev. James D. Schulthess.

title: Kirkland College Accredited
description: Kirkland College, the women's side of Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., was accredited last week by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.

title: ACROSTIC PUZZLE
description: Guess the words defined below and write them over their numbered dashes. Then transfer each letter to the correspondingly numbered square in the pattern. Black squares indicate word endings. The filled pattern will contain a quotation reading from left to right. The first letters of the guessed words will form an acrostic giving author's name and title of work.

title: This Is Front Page News
description: STOP the press! There's a new front page in the works. As a matter of fact, it's the Front Page, and the redhot news this morning is that the Ben HechtCharles MacArthur play which first bowled over Broadway audiences back in 1928 is headed for the screen.

title: The Devil, you say
description: In one of his periodic admonitions, Pope Paul VI recently warned the world of the reality of Satan and the evils of Satanism. Though his statement (see box, p. 26) spoke of Satan as a spiritual entity rather than a fleshandblood creature stalking the earth, progressive Roman Catholics were acutely embarrassed. An American Catholic Scripture scholar remarked, No uptodate theologian believes that Satan is a person. Enlightened secular humanists wrote off the papal warning as one more lamentable Pauline faux pas. Asserting the personal reality of Satan was just what one might expect from the man who attempted (unsuccessfully, as it turned out) to prevent Catholics from using the birth control pill. Satan, indeed!

title: 84 Men in Blue Graduating as Nurses
description: Between 8 A.M. and 4 P.M. most weekdays, Patrolman Eugene E. Smith, a 20yearveteran of the force, patrols a beat in the BushwickRidgewood section of Brooklyn. However, for three nights a week over the last two and onehalf years he has changed into the starched white uniform of a student nurse and learned how to give pills, change a derssing and make patients feel comfortable.

title: Farms
description: WASHINGTON  For a President with a professed faith in free enterprise and free markets, it was a golden opportunityand last week Richard Nixon seized it. He made another drastic cutback in the amount of acreage permitted to lie idle as part of the nation's crop control program and thereby moved the farmer closer to a peacetime free market than he had been in the last 40 years.

title: Regular Posting of Price Bids Ended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  As part of a deemphasis of price regulation in Phase 3 of the Nixon Administration's economic stabilization effort, the Cost of Living Council has stopped making regular public announcements of applications for increases in prices of food and health care.

title: MatraSimca, Far Ahead, Drops Out as Engine Fails
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3A Frenchmade MatraSimca took a decisive lead tonight in the TwentyFour Hours of Daytona, first of this year's schedule of manufacturers championship endurance races. Far back, 11 laps down, were a pair of Porsche Carreras driven by American crews

title: Gold Production Is Slowing
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  In South Africa, all that is gold does not glister.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: SHIPP, 18, SECOND
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 3  Rod Milburn, disappointed over his lateround selection in the recent pro football draft, equaled the world indoor record in the 50yard high hurdles tonight at the 33d annual Greater Cleveland Knights of Columbus track meet.

title: Widow Says Metropolitan Sold 3 Beckmann Paintings for Half What They Were Worth
description: The widow of Max Beckmann, the German expressionist, and her agent estimate the value of three paintings sold by the Metropolitan Museum of Art at twice what the museum got for them. Two qualified dealers lend support to this appraisal.

title: Billy Roy, at Piano, Shares Singing Bill With Jane Harvey
description: Billy Roy, a small man with startled eyes and an outrageous tan, sits behind a miniature piano at Soerabaja, Lexington Avenue at 74th Street, singing songs that are chosen with rare taste and knowledgeability and projecting them with a keen insight into what each song calls for.

title: Tourism Thrives in Gambia
description: BATHURST, GambiaIn this former British colony, where there is still a trace of Victorian dowdiness, the favorite Gambian greeting to foreigners is, Are you Swedish?

title: 2D LATIN FESTIVAL GIVEN AT GARDEN
description: Salsa, the Latinrock music played by secondgeneration Latins in the United States, took a back seat at the second Latin Music Festival in Madison Square Garden on Friday evening. At the first festival last November, salsa was militantly up front and on display, but on Friday the more formal talents of Tito. Rodriguez, Ricardo Ray and Bobby Cruz dominated.

title: A new New Novel, but not a New New Novel
description: NATHALIE Sarraute is the kind of novelist who never gives us the mixture as before. Like all serious artists, like Eliot, she knows that ... each venture/ is a new beginning, a raid on the inarticulate. And in a special sense her novels are raids on the inarticulate, for what provides in them continuity in change is the attempt to convey subverbal experience, what she has christened tropisms or subconversations. She has explained these as minute instinctive reactions that surface fleetingly into consciousness as wordless sensations.

title: Tight Grip on Spending
description: President Nixon took a strong hold on the nation's purse last week with the issuance of a tight budget and a challenge to Congress to accept his program or face the consequences. The President cast the budget in a new role as a guard against inflation and warned that the bright economic promise of 1973 was attainable only if Congressmen do not exceed the increases in Federal expenditures that I have proposed.

title: Travel Notes: A Bullish Market
description: HOWEVER uncertain the future looks to some economists, people in the travel business would seem to have good reason to smile. The men who watch and project statistics for the industry all agree that the growth in tourism of the past few years is going to continue. One of the reports that has given the industry's leaders confidence to add to their instinctive optimism came recently from The Economist Intelligence Unit, a research department of the London weekly; it predicted a steady increase in foreign travel by Americans. Furthermore, it said, U.S. tourists are setting patterns in tourism that will be felt in the next 10 to 15 years by citizens of other countries as these become more affluent. Another study, an annual report on world travel trends and markets prepared for the American Society of Travel Agents (A.S.T.A.), says, Tourist prospects in the U.S. for both domestic and international travel were never brighter.

title: At Home With John Wilcock, an Influential Man Nobody Knows
description: ON the cluttered porch of an unpainted cottage on the Aegean island of Mykonos, John Wilcock was talking about his two lives. In the first he is one of the most widely read travel writers in the world, oracle of the nittygritty of inexpensive, traditional tourism; in the second he is an apostle and chronicler of the radical underground. If you count the sum total of all the travel booki I've sold, he said, it comes to over 800,000. And yet, who ever heard of me? It's just one of thoge ironies. I'm better known by people who don't even know me as a travel writer.

title: Peter Lane Donnelly Marries Miss Joyce Elizabeth Arbon
description: Miss Joyce Elizabeth Arbon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Arbon of Glen Head, L. I., was married here yesterday afternoon to Peter Lane Donnelly, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Donnelly of Oyster Bay, L. I. The ceremony was performed in the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. James Stewart. A reception was held at the Union Club.

title: BONN RULES OUT NEW REVALUATION
description: BONN, Feb. 3Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt today ruled out another upward revaluation of the West German mark.

title: SEAFARERS GAVE $100,000 TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3  A Seafarers International Union political fund put $100,000 into President Nixon's reelection campaign just before Election. Day, after the Justice Department had abandoned an earlier effort to prosecute the union for illegal contributions.

title: New Year Is Celebrated By Chinese in the City
description: Chinese folk dances, karate and kung fu exhibitions, a magic act and music ushered in the Chinese New Year, known as the Year of the Ox, yesterday.

title: Three Orioles in Fold
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 3 (AP)An infielder, Bobby Grich, an outfielderfirst baseman, Terry Crowley, and a rookie pitcher, Bob Galasso, signed today with the Baltimore Orioles.

title: Program at Paterson College Is Attacking Urban Ills
description: WAYNEWilliam Paterson College will turn out this spring the first 15 graduates, in a new master's program that is designed to train the men and women who may some day cope with the socials ills of the inner city.

title: The Navy
description: The Navy, torn of late by racial rioting and other disorders aboard its ships and at shore bases, has quietly set about to weed out those it considers to be misfits and malcontents. A Pentagon official in Washington said last week that a total of 2,905 servicemen, of whom 378 are black, would be affected. Most of those involved in the program have served at least one year and are said to be eager to leave the service.

title: Ethiopia's Wine Output Up
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaIn the Central Highlands surrounding Addis Ababa, the grape harvest is beginning at pukam, Gooder skid Holeta.

title: Hackensack Becoming New Ft. Lee
description: HACKENSACK Six highrise apartment houses have been opened along Prospect and Overlook Avenues in the last two and onehalf years, and four new ones are scheduled for completion in 1973.

title: Stories of growing old and up
description: Books for children about senile dementia? You must be kidding. Why would anyone want to bother a kid's head with stories about senility?

title: N. F. L. Draft is Analyzed on a ClubbyClub Basis
description: The returns on pro football's annual draft of college players are so far away, and often defy, analysis in any event, that it is hard to say four days later which teams did well and which did poorly. But it is possible to define goals club by club and review how each one went about achieving those goals. The review follows:

title: OneThird of Black Families Are Fatherless in Brooklyn
description: Slightly more than one third of Brooklyn's 155,000 black families are headed by women in homes lacking a father, according to a New York Times analysis of Census Bureau statistics.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  In an uncharacteristic display of personal feeling, George P. Shultz, the Nixon Administration's economic superchief, gave fresh support last week for the view that raising prices in Phase 3 of the wageprice stabilization campaign is likely to be easier than in Phase 2.

title: Soviet Orbits Relay Satellite
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3 (UPI) The Soviet Union put into orbit today a new Molnia 1 communications satellite to help relay telephone, telegraph and television signals to remote areas of the country. The first of the Molnia series went into orbit in 1965. Tass, the Soviet Press agency, said the latest satellite would help relay television programs to points in the far north, Siberia, the Far East and Central Asia.

title: Dog Show Official Dies
description: Richard D'Ambrisi of New Providence, N. J., who had been director of obedience at the American Kennel Club since last June, died of a heart attack on Jan. 26. He was 54 years old.

title: Kalamazoo Defeats Alma
description: ALMA, Mich., Feb. 3 (AP)Jim VanSweden scored 27 points to pace Kalamazoo to a 7368 victory over Alma in a Michigan Intercollegiate Athletic Association basketball game today.

title: All Dogs Can Be Taught Quickly
description: Who would believe, a dog could be trained to do the basic obedience commands of heel, sit, down, stay and come in five minutes?

title: Developing Africa Stresses SelfReliance
description: ADDIS ABABA, EthiopiaIf the developed countries can't do more to help us, they could try to avoid hurting us.

title: Ann Buchanan Plans Nuptials
description: WEST FALMOUTH, Mass., Feb. 3The Rev. Albert B. Buchanan, former rector of Calvary Episcopal Church, just off Gramercy Park in New York, and Mrs. Buchanan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Blair Buchanan, to William Baxter Tytus, son of Dr. and Mrs. John S. Tytus of Seattle.

title: AROUND THE
description: SCENTED GERANIUMS

title: PRODUCTION FAILS SOVIET CONSUMER
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 3The final economic statistics for 1972 show that the Soviet leadership was unable to keep its promise to the average citizen to expand consumer production faster than basic heavy industry.

title: Canada's Truce Mission Stirs Some Anxieties at Home
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 3Canada's truce mission in Vietnam, now one week old, has stirred an embarrassing controversy here.

title: Saturday's Children We Hit A Live Nerve
description: WESTPORT, Conn.According to an old rhyme, Fridays child is loving and giving, while Saturdays child has to work for its living.... But in this wealthy suburb, where weekend tedium can be a way of adolescent life, the citizens have to work hard to entertain Saturday's children.

title: Late Listings for Today's TV
description: The following information about today's television programs was not available in time to appear in Section 2:

title: Deborah Weil Has Nuptials
description: MOUNTKISCO, N. Y., Feb. 3Miss Deborah Helen Weil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Alan Weil, was married here this noon to Samuel Parker Harrington, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Timothy Harrington of Milwaukee.

title: February
description: For a long time February was the year's final month, and that is why it now is the catchall for calendar corrections. It once provided the early Romans whatever time was needed to round out the year and start a new one even with the sun. Along with this, it was a time for correction of human error, for penance and apology so that a man could start the new year square with his conscience. It got its name from Februarius, a feast of purification.

title: Calendar of Dog Show Events
description: Today  Bulldog Club of America specialty match, V.F.W. Hall, Kirkman and High Streets, Union, N. J.; entries from 11 A.M.; judging 1:30 P.M.

title: MARKETS IN REVIEW
description: Stock prices were crunched on Wall Street last week, caught between the jaws of monetary worries.

title: The Message A Basic Change in Social Philosophy
description: The President who had quickfrozen the economy, breached the Bamboo Curtain and ended the endless war once again found himself and the nation at a historic crossroads. The new turning point, as he limned it in his State of the Union Message to Congress on Friday, concerned our very philosophy about the relationship between the individual and the state. And, indeed, the issues raised in that message, and in the budget message Mr. Nixon presented to Congress four days earlier, were unmistakably historic.

title: Killy Defeats Nindl in Final Of Pro Skiing Giant Slalom
description: BURNSVILLE, Minn. Feb. 3 (AP)  JeanClaude Killy of France won the giant slalom today at the St. Paul Winter Carnival's pro ski meet.

title: Panel Discusses Africanization
description: Africanixationthe movement by nationals of African countries to run local businesses and manage their own economic affairshas become an increasingly prominent aspect of African development. Three Ghanaian businessmen, who own new enterprises, discussed the trend with Brendan Jones, economic correspondent for The New York Times. Excerpts from the discussion which was taped at the Ghana Broadcasting Corporation in Accra, follow:

title: $257,000 Law Study Grant
description: BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP)The Federal Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has awarded a $257,000 grant to the Boston University Center for Criminal Justice to study implementation of the righttocounsel ruling of the United States Supreme Court. The 1972 ruling stated that anyone who could be sent to jail on conviction of a crime has the right to legal counsel.

title: VIETNAM FIGHTING AT A VIRTUAL HALT
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb. 4  Fighting in South Vietnam reportedly ground to a virtual halt yesterday, a week after the formal ceasefire went into effect.

title: Foreigners Adapt To Nigerian Edict
description: LAGOS, NigeriaA couple of years after Raymond W. Baker, a young American businessman here, nursed sickly trucking firm  Jim Trucking Ltd.to the status of a profitmaking enterprise, the federal military government declared trucking, along with 54 other businesses and services, restricted to Nigerian ownership.

title: Columbia University Vessel Slated for Scientific Cruise
description: USHUAIA, Argentina, Feb. 3 (AP)  A Columbia University research vessel, the Robert D. Conrad, is, preparing to embark on working cruise of a month in the South Atlantic.

title: Criminals At Large
description: THE CASE OF THE POSTPONED MURDER. Does the title sound familiar? It does indeed. Though Erie Stanley Gardner has been dead since 1970, he left an allbutfinished manuscript in his files. The Case of the Postponed Murder (Norton, $5.95) is now offered to his readers, minus (in the publisher's words) the author's usual final draft polishing and checking, as the 85th title in a series that started in 1933 with The Case of the Velvet Claws. This new one is not much different from the first, or the 15th, or the 84th. Gardner found his formula at the beginning and relentlessly pursued it. Here we have Perry Mason and his crew engaged to find a missing woman. Things are not what they seem, and everything of course ends up in a courtroom with Mason applying the coup de grace. For the Gardner fans.

title: Action on Prisoners
description: For almost five years, a simple gravestone in a military cemetery in St. Louis has marked the mass grave of nine Marines, casualties of the battle of Khe Sanh in South Vietnam in February, 1968. The nine bodies were found after an American patrol was ambushed.

title: Assembly To Consider New Statute On Abortion
description: TRENTON  The Assembly's Judiciary Committee will discuss this week a new abortion statute for New Jersey.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: Women have an innate skepticism and an innate curiosity, and they are less motivated by superficials. Furthermore, men buy on impulse while women buy on needs.

title: New York
description: If you think the way we have to run welfare is a mess, said a New York City bureaucrat, just take a look at Medicaid. It's an administrative nightmare.

title: Post Defeats Kings Point For 15th Victory in Row
description: BROOKVILLE, LI., Feb. 3Pete Haubner, a 6foot3inch senior reserve guard, helped C. W. Post to its 15th consecutive victory tonight as the Pioneers defeated Kings Point, 5748. Haubner scored 14 points and added five assists.

title: From China With Love
description: The new relationship between China and Western Europe is one of the most fascinating and least noticed changes in the rapidly shifting diplomatic pattern. Several European nations now belonging to NATO have been at war with Russia more than once but few have been at war with China, Therefore, despite differences on Ideology, there is little inherited tradition of hostility.

title: Ellsberg Not a Sporting Event
description: LOS ANGELESIn 1963, in one of the landmark rulings that characterized the Warren era, the Supreme Court held that a trial is not a sporting eventa contest to be won by any means, up to and including the withholding of important evidence.

title: Abode of Peace Has Sluggish Economy
description: DAR ES SALAAM, TanzaniaWith its sheltered, palmringed harbor, warm breezes and relaxed pace, Dar es Salaam lives up much of the time to its Arabic namethe Abode of Peace.

title: L.I. Sound Study Unit Cites Loss of Sanctuaries for Man
description: WHITE PLAINS  The decline in undeveloped sanctuaries for man and the rise In water temperature caused by electric power plants were cited in reports by a group studying what has to be done to preserve the Long Island Sound.

title: J. R. Michels Weds Nancy Hocker
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., Feb. 3Miss Nancy Ellen Hocker was married here this noon to John Rudolf Michels. Both are graduates of the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration. The Rev. James Cashman performed the ceremony in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church.

title: UPSTATE INMATES ARE KEPT IN CELLS
description: About 700 inmates in the Great Meadow Correctional Institute in Comstock, N. Y., have been locked in their cells since Thursday, prison officials said yesterday.

title: South African Blacks Striking to Raise Meager Pay
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 3One of the Zulus on strike in the South African east coast port of Durban is 60yearold Mrs. Annie Msomi. Seven years ago when Mrs. Msomi began working for a Durban textile factory her weekly pay was a little over $4, out of which she had to pay for her own transportation to and from her home 20 miles away.

title: Head of Alcoholism Center Asks New Aid for Drinkers
description: The executive director of the Fellowship Center, an alcoholicrehabilitation agency at 8 East Third Street, warned yesterday that rising drug addiction must not overshadow the less spectacular but more epidemic disease of alcoholism.

title: Concorde
description: LONDONAfter all their dreams for the AngloFrench Concorde supersonic airliner, the British and French Governments were plunged in gloom last week: They are producing an aircraft at massive cost and nobody seems to want it.

title: BUSH SAYS G.O.P. NEEDS CONNALLY
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. George Bush, Republican National Committee Chairman, said today that the Republican party needs people like John Connally and that I would like to see him change his registration.

title: It's Decision Time at Parkehester
description: Margaret Feely, an Irish cook who does heavenly crepes in the Hotel Pierre kitchen of a show business celebrity, means to buy herself piece of Parkchester's 129 acres.

title: Agency Urges Incentives To Re use Solid Wastes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3In a report withheld by the Office of Management and Budget, the Environmental Protection Agency has recommended using subsidy payments or tax incentives to promote the reuse of municipal and industrial solid waste.

title: Industry Sought For Bantustans
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa  When a country of 18 million nonwhites and 4 million whites operates under a policy of separate development of the races, much of that country's energy must be directed at providing jobs for its nonwhites.

title: Nancy Klebanow Engaged
description: SANDS POINT, L. I., Feb. 3  Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Klebanow have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Klebanow, to Jeffrey Linder, son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry Linder of Valley Stream. The wedding is planned for early September.

title: Robert S. Thanhauser Jr. to Wed Merrie Spaeth, Former Actress
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3Miss Merrie Marcia Spaeth, a former actress who ran unsuccessfully last fall as a Republican for State Representative in Philadelphia, plans to be married May 13 to Robert S. Thanhauser Jr. of New. York, who is with the C. E. Unterberg, Towbin Company, investment bankers.

title: MRS. JUDA QUASTEL
description: Mrs. Henrietta Jungman Quastel, formerly a psychologist here, the wife of Dr. Juda H. Quastel, professor of neurochemistry at the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, died there Thursday. Her age was 67.

title: Uganda Is Making Neighbors Uneasy
description: NAIROBI, KenyaThe economic deterioration that political turmoil is bringing to Uganda has not yet seriously harmed her partners in the East African Community, Kenya and Tanzania, but in coming months it might do considerable damage, economists fear.

title: UTILITY IS GRANTED DELAY ON CLEAN AIR
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 3The American Electric Power System, the nation's largest producer of electricity, has won a significant victory in its fight against West Virginia's stringent standards for clean air with the intervention of Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr.

title: Senegal Diversifies With Vegetables.
description: DAKAR, SenegalIt was nearly noon as Fritz Marschall, the managing director, supervised the packing of cantaloupes at the big BudSenegal commercial farm covering some 900 acres of newly cleared land on the outskirts of Dakar.

title: Ervin Assuming Leadership in Effort to Reassert the Authority of Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 Sam J. Ervin Jr. has a jowly, lined face resembling the Appalachian foothills. He frequently slaps his thigh and chortles as he tells courthouse anecdotes, and at the age of 76, he would seem to be about as rebellious in nature as a retired country preacher.

title: Art Is Going to College, Too
description: New Jersey boasts an increasing number of small, private galleries devoted to the works of its native artists and graphics from New York, and the art lover in search of an afternoon's reward can spend a pleasant time in them. Browsers are equally welladvised to try the college art galleries in their neighborhoods.

title: Yes
description: THE play is not the thing, or certainly not the only thing. If it were, publishers would print playwrights' works in every binding from Moroccan leather to Underground Tacky, and potential viewing public would be freed from the expense and bother of theatergoing and would laze at home suburbia playing out roles in John Updike's Couples. Drama critics, no longer needed to castigate the ineptitude of actors, might find themselves in for a period of tough sledding, but many outofwork actors would be cheered at that thought.

title: COAST RACE GOES TO SINGLE AGENT
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 3 (AP) Single Agent upset Kennedy Road and Autobiography with a frontrunning triumph today in the $56,350 San Pasqual Handicap at Santa Anita Park.

title: Hopeful Brezhnev

The political settlement in Vietnam can be expected to have a positive effect on relations among states involved in one way or another in events in Indochina. Moreover, this shows it is possible to find a peaceful and just solution of other conflicts, to liquidate the danger from existing hotbeds of war, above all in the Middle East....

description: After serving a year as acting director, Elizabeth Scholtz has been named director of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. Miss Scholtz was said to be the only woman heading a major urban botanic garden in the United States

It could happen in 1973 as an improvised solution to a problem, and it might eventuallysay in two or three yearsbecome a formal racing format.

title: Terese Douglas to Wed
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 3 The engagement of Miss Terese Douglas to Robert Schwartzwald, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Schwartzwald, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Spencer Douglas. The future bride is a senior at George Washington University. Her father is president of Reader Mail Inc., creators of newspaper features. Mr. Schwartzwald is a senior at Pennsylvania State University. His father is vice president and a director of the Whitney Stores.

The resuit was the Central Six school integration program.

And when that is the case there are always some smart entrepreneurs around ready to create a proper vehicle.

Miss Couttet was clocked in 1 minute 34.23 seconds over the 1,400meter course, marked by 48 gates. Elena Matous of Italy was second in 1:34.61.

title: Movies
description: FUNNY, but it's her face that you remember: Poutish. Babyfaced. Darkeyed. Sensual. As though the faces of Fonda, Bardot and Moreau had been superimposed one upon the other, and then the cheeks puffed out with a bicycle tire pump, and the hair frizzed by one of those 1940's home permanents. It's the face of Maria Schneider, the 20yearold French actress who, along with Marlon Brando, shows you almost everything you've always wanted to know about sex in Last Tango in Paris, which opened Thursday at the TransLux East at porno house prices$5 a ticket.

To cost $7, with seats assigned as checks are received, the trip will start at the Council's office at 9 A.M. and will return the same day at 6 P.M. Phone (212) 2272450.

description: PRESIDENT NIXON'S proposed budget of $268.7billion for fiscal 1974 projects the gross national product this calendar year at $1,267billion, up 10 per cent from $1,152billion last year. . .Corporate profits this year are expected to total $108billion, up 14.8 per cent from last year. Personal income is projected at $1,018billion.

title: Ireland

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 4 (UP)The first black American foreign service officer assigned to South Africa arrived today.

title: MAYORS TOUR CITY AND ASSAIL NIXON FOR CUTS IN FUNDS
description: With protests that the Nixon Administration had welshed on a financial commitment to cities, 11 Mayors yesterday visited three Manhattan sites where, they said, the need for continued Federal financial aid was dramatically evident.

title: Screen: 'Greatest Athlete':Disney College Farce Is at the Music Hall The Cast
description: "Life is not so simple. You have got to make the dream happen," says John Amos, the black college coach in "The World's Greatest Athlete," in a serious moment during a series of concocted competitions in which he is a loser. Well, the dream does happen in this farce, which has landed at the Radio City Music Hall, fresh from Walt Disney's dream factory. But it's a dream that is more often simple-minded than simple and generally as hilarious as finishing fourth in the mile run.It should be stressed, however, that this ribbing of the Tarzan myth runs a good, clean course that should grab all red-blooded sports fans up to and including the 14-year-old group. It might be added that everyone from coach Amos to Jan-Michael Vincent, in the title role, athletically tries without much success to make all this good-natured nonsense funny.One gets the feeling very soon that all concerned are involved in what appears a series of random gag situations. The athletes of Merrivale College depicted here can't avoid tripping over their own feet, which, for no convincing reason, drives our coach to go on an African safari. There he discovers the answer to his dream. And that is Jan-Michael Vincent, as the young, long-haired, blond, muscular Nanu, orphan son of missionaries, who may speak only pidgin English but can run, jump and throw like Jim Thorpe.There are many extracurricular complications, of course, such as Nanu's pet tiger and Roscoe Lee Browne, who plays Nanu's suspicious, Zambian witch doctor-godfather. Both show up at Merrivale. Tim Conway, as the fatheaded assistant coach, is momentarily turned into a tiny Tim by the angered witch doctor. And then there is Dayle Haddon, the pretty tutor, who adds romance to the course.As Merrivale's one-man team, Nanu sets records in everything from the 100-yard dash to the pole vault. However, Mr. Vincent and the rest of the cast good-naturedly do their things with speed but little discernible style, all under the uninspired direction of Robert Scheerer.Mr. Vincent, although laconic, is a handsome figure of an athlete. His coach, Mr. Amos, is spirited and willing and gives the impression that he knows he's kidding, while Mr. Conway as his assistant is properly energetic and woebegone but not really funny. Even Howard Cosell makes a guest appearance, joshing his own, authentic verbose delivery as a sports broadcaster."It's kind of hard saying good-by to 'The World's Greatest Athlete,'" coach Amos intones when our hero finally decides to return to Zambia. But it isn't, really.

title: Proposed Land Swap With Rutherford Draws Concern at Fairleigh Dickinson
description: RUTHERFORD, Feb. 4 Borough school officials here seem delighted, but many teachers and students at Fairleigh Dickinson University seem concerned because of a proposed land swap between Rutherford and the university.

description: The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday asked to see the economic data used by four Eastern banks to justify the increases in interest rates on business loans that they announced Friday.

title: Japanese Envoy to Peking
description: TOKYO, Feb. 4 (AP)  The Japanese Government will appoint Heishiro Ogawa, presi dent of the Foreign Service Training Institute, as the nation's first Ambassador to Peking, Government sources said today. They said that the appointment would be made Tuesday. The sources added that China was expected to announce her ambassador to Japan soon.

title: Topless Dancing Stirs Protest
description: PENNSAUKEN, Feb. 4 Wearing nothing except platform shoes and silver Gstrings, dancers glide these nights into the dull red spotlights bathing the bar of the Club Lido, this area's first topless nightclub.

title: State Agents Learn How to Snuff Out Cigarette Cheating
description: In an effort to stem the costly tax losses caused by cigarette bootlegging, the state has completed the retraining of a group of 57 tax agents and has opened negotiations with other states on the possibility of an interstate strike squad.

title: Bridge:
description: The cradle of world team championships, rather improbably, is the tiny island of Bermuda in the Atlantic. It wis there in 1950 that the first of the present series of world championship contests was played, on the initiative of the late Norman Bach, and the competition is expected to return there a guarter of a century later, in 1975. Six teams representing different zones will compete for the Bermuda Bowl.

title: Dealers Unit Volunteers To Appraise Art Sales
description: The Art Dealers Association of America has volunteered to appraise museum art without fee and to handle any sales at limited fees.

title: Records: By Stravinsky
description: The use of national categories in esthetic analysis is as tempting as it dubious. Igor Stravinsky's music, for instance, can be looked at as stretching between two potes. Early in his composing career and intermittently later on his works were full of the Russian side of his artistic personality, barbaric, religious and mystical. But neoclassicism and the austere formalism of his last years suggest something more French.

description: DALLAS, Feb. 4 (AP)General Portland, Inc., said yesterday that it had completed a longterm contract to purchase cement from Mexico's Cementos Anahuac Del Golfo, S. A.

Rabbi Harry Bronstein performed the ceremony in the Parkside Plaza in the Bronx. The bridegroom's father arrived here Saturday to attend the wedding and plans to remain in the United States. His, son and the bride emigrated from the Soviet Union last year. She is a singer and her husband is a technician for musical instruments.

title: INSPECTION TEAMS SENT TO 7 SITES TO MONITOR TRUCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 5In the first major step toward monitoring the Vietnam ceasefire, which began a week ago Sunday, the International Commission of Control and Supervision this morning dispatched seven regional teams around South Vietnam.

title: 4 Banks Asked to Justify Increases in Loan Rates
description: The Administration's Committee on Interest and Dividends yesterday asked to see the economic data used by four Eastern banks to justify the increases in interest rates on busMess loans that they announced Friday.

title: Pope Says Vietnam Truce Is Marred by Violations
description: ROME, Feb. 4 (Reuters) Pope Paul VI said today that the Vietnam ceasefire was full of violations and stressed the need for justice, brotherhood and universal peace.

title: Bills by Nixon and Muskie On Waste Differ Sharply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4The Nixon Administration is preparing to send Congress a bill to reduce the Federal role in solid waste management and resource recovery largely to that of policeman for the disposal of toxic industrial wastes.

title: 2 Officers Accuse Herbert of War Crimes Hoax
description: An Army general and a colonel charged in a nationwide television broadcast last night that a hoax had been perpetrated by retired Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert, a highly decorated veteran of the Korean and Vietnam wars, in his contention that he was removed from command because of his complaints about war crimes in Vietnam.

title: DR. LEO ROSENBERG
description: Dr. Leo Rosenberg, a specialist in physical medicine and rehabilitation, died Wednesday in Dayton, Ohio. He was 71 years old and formerly practiced here.

title: DR. IVAN LAWLER
description: MAPLEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 4 Dr. Ivan C. Lawler, who retired as medical director of the New York Life Insurance Company in 1958, died yesterday in the Hospital Center at Orange. He was 76 years old and lived at 20 Euclid Avenue.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOUR IN HAND The Cleveland Quartet is a house string group at the State University at Buffalo and is playing Carnegie Recital Hall, 57th Street and Seventh Avenue (CI 77459), at 8 tonight. It is not to be confused with the Cleveland Orchestra, which outnumbers it, plays Carnegie Hall downstairs tonight and tomorrow night and, unlike the quartet, comes from Cleveland.

title: Israel Is Building MissileBoat Fleet; First Ready Feb. 19
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 4A fleet of warships described as the forerunners of the next generation of missile boats is being built for the Israeli Navy in a Haifa shipyard.

title: Cambodia Reports 2 Highways Are Attacked by Communists
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 4 (UPI)The Cambodian command reported that Communist guerrillas attacked Government troops today on the highway that connects the capital with the country's only deepwater seaport at Kompong Som.

title: U.S. Bombs in Laos Again
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 4 (AP)The Pacific military command reported that United States aircraft, including B52 bombers, continued operations over Laos today at the request of the Laotian Government. No details of the bombing were disclosed. The operations have continued daily since the Vietnam ceasefire began.

title: Hospital Here May Buy Union Offices
description: St. Vincent's Hospital Medical Center of New York is negotiating to buy the headquarters building of the National Maritime Union, the shiplike structure at 36 Seventh Avenue, at 12th Street.

title: British Football Results
description: RUGBY LEAGUE

title: Deming to Aid Colgate.
description: HAMILTON, N. Y., Feb. 4 (AP)The University of Buffalo lost its associate athletic idirector, a former head football coach, Robert Deming, to Colgate University, where he has been named defensive coach. Deming was in charge of Buffalo's intercollegiate program since football was discontinued in 1970.

title: Easier Drug Penalty Urged
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 4 (UPI)Art Linkletter, the television personality whose daughter died while on LSD and who subsequently became an adviser on drugs to President Nixon, said over the weekend that he favored softer penalities for firsttime marijuana users.

title: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1973
description: LONDON, Feb. 4An executive of the vast publishing empire controlled by Lord Thomson of Fleet called a colleague the other day and said: Did you hear about the strike?

title: ZAMBIA DECLINES TO OPEN BORDER
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, Feb. 4Zambia announced today that she was keeping her border with Rhodesia closed despite Rhodesia's decision last night to reopen her own frontier.

title: Wives Waiting for P.O.W.'s With Hope and Anxiety
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 4Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.

title: Subsidy SqueezeOut
description: One constructive byproduct of the steep rise in food prices is the pressure it has put on the Administration to start dismantlingwe hope permanentlyme expensive structure of agricultural subsidies carried over from the Great Depression and subsequent efforts to restore and maintain farm income.

title: CARTER WORK GIVEN BY ARS CAMERALIS
description: The Ars Cameralis Ensemble's concert of postwar works for wind instruments Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall consisted of meritorious music played for a minimal audience in mostly maximal performances.

title: RAIDERS CONQUER NORDIQUES, 5 TO 4
description: Striking for two quick goals in the second period, the New York Raiders managed to record a 54 victory yesterday over the Quebec Nordiques in a World Hockey Association gaine at Madison Square Garden.

title: SQUEEZE CATCHES THE BOND MARKET
New Jersey Sports
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., Feb. 4Morristown likes a winrier and, so far, Ed Blackmon has produced one.

title: HUSSEIN TO PRESS PEACE BID IN U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 4King Hussein of Jordan has ruled out any resumption of hostilities with Israel from his territory before a new attempt is made to reach a political settlement in the Middle East.

title: P. O.W. CONDUCT BARRED AS TOPIC
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 4Military sources said today that military escorts have been told to change the subject tactfully if a returning American prisoner of war begins discussing possible violations of the military code he might have committed in captivity.

title: Wives Waiting for P.O.W.'s With Hope and Anxiety
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 4Sybil Stockdale bought a new Persian rug last year on her 25th wedding anniversary, but she has not put it down yet. She is waiting for her husband, Capt. James Bond Stockdale, who has been a prisoner in North Vietnam for almost eight years.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Victim of Dispute In Subway Named

title: Mob Favors Pinelands for Burials
description: TOMS RIVER, Feb. 4When agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation found the body of Emanuel Gambino in Colts Neck Township last week, some lawenforcement agents were only partly surprised.

title: UnserKelly Win by 5 Strokes In Ballplayers' Golf Tourney
description: LAS CROABAS, P.R., Feb. 4Leroy Kelly, Cleveland Browns running back, and Del Unser, Philadelphia Phillies outfielder, won the $10,000 first prize today in the American Airlines golf tournament at the El Conquistador Hotel and Country Club. They carded a finalround 5p and won by five strokes, with a 177 total, 35 under par.

title: Tapes Help Museum to Offer Centuries of Exotic Music
description: They sit in cases in the Andr Mertens Galleries for Musical Instruments at the Metropolitan Museum of Art those serpents and shawms, those basset horns and bagpipes, those two Strads and the early pianos, tons, nyckelharpas and tanburas. They are part of one of the great collections of its kind, and since the galleries were opened in 1971, the public has been admiring them.

title: At 78, Jean Renoir Tries TV Writing
description: HOLLYWOODJean Renoir, a film maker whom the knowledgeable include among the world's dozen great directors, made his last movie 10 years ago, and poor health will probably keep him, at 78, from directing again. But he has written a twohour play, Carola, for the Hollywood Television Theater that will be shown in New York on WNET/Channel 13 and other educational stations tonight a 8 P.M.

title: City to Begin Drive Today To Speed Street Repairs
description: More than 45 inspectors of the Department of Highways will fan out into the five boroughs today to check holes cut into streets by utilities for proper marking and restoration.

title: Dill Jones, Pianist, Is Stellar Attraction With JPJ Quartet
description: The JPJ Quartet  a name drawn from the initials of the last names of Budd Johnson, tenor and soprano saxophones, Bill Pemberton, bass, and Oliver Jackson, drums  has gone through an unusual realignment since it was cut loose by Earl Hines, who had used the three musicians as his rhythm section.

title: KAVALEL AND BYRNE DRAW IN U.S. CHESS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP)Lubomir Kavalek and Robert Byrne, two chess grandmasters, agreed to a draw after 12 moves tonight in the second game of the United States Chess Championship playoffs.

title: Offshore Threat
description: To an Army Corps of Engineers proposal for an oil superport off the New Jersey coast, Governor Cahill has given the only appropriate answer: Unacceptable. Because tankers that will presumably be bringing oil from the Middle East are too big for exiting ports, the Corps recommended a point off Long Branch where oil would be carried ashore by hose or barge.

title: Nonresident Autoists Seek Equal Parking Privileges
description: IRVINGTOINT, N. Y., Feb. 4 A dispute between two Westchester County villages over who can park at a rail, road station here has touched off a legal battle that could eventually reverse a trend toward tighter restrictions on commuter parking throughout the metropolitan area suburbs.

title: New City Planning Chief Intends To Consult Local Units on Aims
description: The incoming chairman, of the City Planning Commission said yesterday that he believed communities would be more receptive to scattersite publicaided housing if they were consulted beforehand, and if designs conformed more to the neighborhood  threestory structures, forinstance, instead of highrisers.

title: Innsbruck, '64 Site, Gets '76 Olympics
description: LAUSANNE, Switzerland, Feb. 4  The International Olympic Committee voted today to hold the 1976 Winter Games in Innsbruck, the Austrian city which staged them so successfully in 1964 despite a lack of snow.

title: Niederhoffer Wins Again In Cowles Squash Racquets
description: Victor Niederhoffer of New York, the United States champion, won the Harry Cowles invitation squash racquets championship yesterday at the Harvard Club. In winning the tourney for the fifth time, he turned back Robert Hetherington of Buffalo, 157, 1510, 1511, in the final.

title: Edward A. Mahar, City Editor Of JournalAmerican, Is Dead
description: Edward A. Mahar, a reporter for The New York JournalAmerican and its city editor from 1955 until his retirement at the end of 1965, died Saturday night at his home, 4616 193d Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 72 years old.

title: I.R.S. Opens Extra Offices To Aid Area's Taxpayers
description: The Internal Revenue Service is opening satellite offices for the incometax filing period so that free assistance, in the preparation of returns can be offered close to all taxpayers' homes.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Man Slain in Subway Dispute Identified

title: ISLANDERS LOSE TO SABRES, 5 TO 1
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 4 (UPI)Jim Lorentz scored two goals and Doug Rombough scored the first goal of his National Hockey League career as the Buffalo Sabres defeated the New York Islanders, 51, tonight.

title: DR. HERBERT BIRCH OF EINSTEIN DEAD
description: Dr. Herbert G. Birch, professor of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and recipient of the 1971 Kennedy International Award for studies of the relation of malnutrition and other social problems to mental retardation, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Suffern, N.Y, His age was 54.

title: Schlee Wins Hawaii Golf For First Tour Victory
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 4It was a long wait but John Schlee finally won a tournament on the Professional Golfers' Association tour today. The 33yearold Texan, who was deserted by his sponsors early in his career, swept off with the $40,000 first prize in the Hawaiian open by two strokes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Reduced Pare for the Elderly

title: HEATH FEARS EFFECT OF U.S. WITHDRAWALS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) Prime Minister Heath of Britain said today that unilateral United States troop withdrawal from Europe might push some of America's Western European allies into making deals with the Communist nations. He refused to name the vulnerable allies but said Britain was not one of them.

title: Susan Trentacoste
description: Trentacoste, the fancyfruitandvegetable business established in 1898 by his father, the late Salvatore Trentacoste.

title: CITY POLICEMAN SLAYS ASSAILANT
description: A patrolman riding in an unmarked car as a backup escort for a regular radiocar patrol in upper Manhattan yesterday morning fired 11 shots from two guns and killed a man who reportedly attempted to shoot him with a pistol that failed to fire.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Hearings on Flood Plains Due Tomorrow in Morris
description: TRENTON, Feb. 4 Public hearings on 47 miles of flood plains in the Raritan River Basin are scheduled for the next three Tuesdays this month In Morris, Hunterdon and Somerset Counties.

title: Tax or Ransom?
description: Publication at long last of the secret law under which the Soviet Government decreed last August that Soviet Jews emigrating abroad must pay compensation for the education they have received increases the danger of a headon SovietAmerican confrontation on this issue.

title: CeaseFire Violations Said to Be Minor
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam. Monday, Feb. 5Only isolated minor incidents broke the truce in South Vietnam yesterday as the ceasefire moved into its second week.

title: Lynn Frisbie Has Nuptials
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 4 Miss Lynn Ann Frisbie and Dr. Edwin Cosby Holstein were married here this afternoon in the Andover Chapel of the Harvard Divinity School by Rabbi Terry Bard.

title: Congress to Open Talks on News Source Privacy
description: Congressional hearings will begin today on legislation that would prevent courts, grand juries and other governmental authorities from forcing newsmen to testify about their confidential sources of information.

title: Princeton Ties for Ivy Lead By Beating Brown, 7652
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 4Outscoring Brown, 4023, in the second half, Princeton defeated the Bruins, 7652, tonight and moved into a firstplace tie with Pennsylvania in the Ivy League basketball race.

title: Pro Track Group Readies A Surprise: Is It Keino?
description: The International Track Association, which detailed its initial plans for the first professional track and field tour last November, will make another major announcement here today.

title: Young Marketing People Scored
description: In the eyes of many of their bosses, young people moving into marketing and sales, today are unrealistic about how fast they should advance and how much they should be paid; selfcentered; generally show great selfconfidence, and are sometimes irreverent of company traditions.

title: GIRL, 16, ABDUCTED AND RAPED 2 DAYS
description: A 16yearold Queens girl was abducted at gunpoint from a Jamaica bus station and taken to an abandoned house where she was attacked sexually, during nearly two days of captivity that ended Saturday.

title: Thoeni, Winning Slalom, Takes 2d Place in Cup
description: ST. ANTON, Austria, Feb. 4 (AP)  Gustavo Thoeni of Italy took a step toward an unprecedented third World Cup ski championship today when he won the Kandahar slalom.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: Egyptian Purge Centers on. Mass Media,
description: CAIRO, Feb. 4Newspapers here published the names today of 64 intellectuals who were dismissed yesterday from the Arab Socialist Union, Egypt's only political party.

title: Corporate Profiles
description: Following a morning board meeting last Thursday, Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., announced a tender offer for 3.75 millioh shares in the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company at $20 per share.

title: Fresh Meadows Work Wins Praise for Police
description: The Educational and Cultural Fund of the Electrical Industry presented certificates of merit yesterday to policemen of the 107th Precinct in recognition of their community activities.

title: BUCKS ARE UPSET BY BULLS, 12199
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 4 (AP)Bob Love, alternating, between the pivot and a forward position, scored a career high of 49 points today as the Chicago Bulls beat the Milwaukee Bucks, 12199, in a National Basketball Association game. The Bulls, who defeated the Bucks for the second time in four meetings thissason, moved within 5%2 games of the Midwest Division leaders.

title: Iris S. Wolfe Is Bride
description: KINGS POINT, L. I., Feb. 4 Miss Iris S. Wolfe was married here this afternoon to Asher S. Levitsky. Rabbi Harold Spivack performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's brother and sisterinlaw, Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Wolfe. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Yale Wolfe of New Bedford, Mass., and the late Mr. Wolfe. Her husband is the son of Boris H. Levitsky of WilkesBarre, Pa., and the late Mrs. Levitsky.

title: Exchange of Soviet and American Environmental Experts on Common Problems Will Begin This Month
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A benign invasion of the United States by Russian environmental specialists will begin this month and continue throughout the year.

title: Stennis Is Resting Well; Condition Still Very Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis rested well during the weekend but is still listed in very serious condition from gunshot wounds received in a robbery last Tuesday night, a spokesman for Walter Reed Army Medical Center said today.

title: A Fund Optimist Looks at Stocks
description: BOSTON, Feb, 4  The gloom is fantastic on Wall Street, observed Carl P. Gieg, but the situation isn't as bad as the stock market seems to indicate.

title: A.E.C. Hears Critics of Atomic Plants
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4During the many hearings that have marked the development of nuclear power in recent years, critics have unsuccessfully tried to force the Atomic Energy Commission to examine publicly the hazards involved.

title: Laver Subdues Emerson In Richmond. W. C. T. Final
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 4 (UPI)Topseeded Rod Laver defeated a fellowAustralian, Roy Emerson, 64, 63, today, to take his second straight World Champion Tennis circuit tournament.

title: Jobs Rotated to Fight Boredom
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 3 Steve Applehanz, dressed in dungarees and sports shirt, carefully checked over the huge panel of lights and dials that controlled the operations of the General Foods pet food plant here.

title: Advertising: Theater for J.W.T.
description: The American Film Theatre, which in October in theaters throughout North America will begin to show a series of new films based on famous plays, has named J. Walter Thompson to handle its $2.5million advertising program.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Gotbaum Won't Back Lindsay Again
description: Victor Gotbaum, the labor leader who has long been one of Mayor Lindsay's strongest political allies, said yesterday he would not support the Mayor if he ran for reelection this year.

title: AllAmerican at G. & W.
description: When Charles G. Bluhdorn slows down long enough to reflect on his personal success during the last 15 years, he is inclined to take on a patriotic glow.

title: Jobs Rotated to Fight Boredom
description: TOPEKA, Kan., Feb. 3Steve Applehanz, dressed in dungarees and sports shirt, carefully checked over the huge panel of lights and dials that controlled the operations of the General Foods pet food plant here.

title: Cooper, on Harpsichord, Wins Deserved Cheers
description: There were cheers for Kenneth Cooper at Tully Hall on Friday night, and he certainly deserved them. His harpsichord recital had just the right combination of everything needed to satisfy a demanding concertgoer. There was old and new music in familiar and unfamiliar guises, and all of it was played to a turn.

title: Losing Coach at Rice Sits Like a Winner
description: Strange thing seem to occur at RiceArkansas games, especially to Rice coaches.

title: RIFT IN TEAMSTERS DILEMMA TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A bitter and widening rift between the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, and his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, is complicating the Nixon Administration's politically rewarding romance with the big union, teamster and Administration sources report.

title: Canarsie Residents Postpone Boycott of Schools Until Feb
description: Residents of the Canarsie section of Brooklyn agreed yesterday to hold off until Feb. 28 any school boycott action to protest Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's rejection of a controversial plan to rezone District 18 schools.

title: Personal Finance: Benefits for Young
description: Most people think you have to be old to collect Social Security benefits But one of the lesser known facts about Social Security is that millions of children get monthly checks as the dependents of retired, disabled or deceased workers.

title: Body of Coed Is Found Near Bostorn
description: BILLERICA, Mass., Feb. 4 (UPI)A nude and frozen body found in a wooded area was identified today as that of a Boston University coed who had beep missing since November. She was the seventh young woman killed in a series of unsolved murders in the Boston area since last summer.

title: Senator Jackson Calls on U.S. To Recognize Peking Promptly
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (UPI) Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, called today for prompt American diplomatic recognition of the Peking Government of China and the severing of formal diplomatic ties with the Nationalist Government in Taiwan.

title: Rangers Crush Flames For 8th Straight, 6 to 0
description: Two minorbut irrepressible members of the surging Rangers' cast stole the show from the stars last night as the New Yorkers methodically tore apart the Atlanta Flames for a 60 victory.

title: MENUHINS PERFORM IN BEETHOVEN SERIES
description: One of the nice things about seeing and hearing Yehudi and Hephzibah Menuhin perform together is their absolute unanimity. They appeared at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium in the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Friday night as part of a Beethoven series, and the perfection of their ensemble supplied mucli of the pleasure in their playing. Each knows from long association, or can intuit, what the other is going to do. The most minute rubato, even at a fast pace, is exactly matched.

title: 2 Presumed Dead in Andes
description: MENDOZA, Argentia, Feb. 4 (AP)Argentine botder po lice reported today that two mountain climbers from the United States presumably died while trying to reach the top of the 22,835foot Acorecagua in the Andes, the highest peak in the Western Hemisphere. The two were identified as Janet Johnson, a school teacher from Denver, Colo., and John Cooper, an engineer employed by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. They were part of an eightmember mountainclimbing team from the United States. Six were rescued in good condition.

title: FIRST SCHOOL STRIKE ENDS IN CLEVELAND
description: Cleveland's first school strike ended last night as striking nonteaching employes ratified a new oneyear contract, while talks in the Philadelphia teachers' strike went before television cameras, The Associated Press reported.

title: MISS YOUNG TAKES ICE SKATING TITLE
description: OSLO, Jan. 4 (UPI)Valery Muratov of the Soviet Union regained the top position and Sheila Young of Detroit maintained United States supremacy in the women's field today by winning the world amateur sprint speed skating championships.

title: Mayoral Race Faces a Thinning on March 3
