description: The first skirmish in the mayoral warand the first thinning out of the ranks of mayoral candidates  is set for March 3 when the liberal New Democratic Coalition is scheduled to endorse a candidate. There are now four liberal Democratic mayoral hopefuls, but in four weeks there will be, for all practical purblessingsn of the coalition will mean workers and money for the candidate receiving them and, for the three losers, solid evidence that their candidacies are weak and cannot even command the support of their liberal peers.

title: Israel Is Building MissileBoat Fleet; First Ready Feb.19
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 4A fleet of warships described as the forerunners of the next generation of missile boats is being built for the Israeli Navy in Haifa shipyard.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE IMPLOSION CONSPIRACY. By Louts Nizer. 495 pages. Illustrated. Doubleday. $10.

title: France May Shift Pacific ATests Underground
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 4 France is preparing to shift to underground tests in her controversial nuclear program in the Pacific, according to reports received here from, the headquarters of the experiments in Papeete, Tahiti.

title: Bronx Woman's Body Found
description: Willie Lou McClerkin, 35 years old, of 2011 Monterrey Avenue, the Bronx, was found dead yesterday in the backyard of an abandoned tenement about six blocks from her home in the East Tremont area, the police said. The police said the woman apparently had died from a blow on the head with a rock or some other blunt object. Her body was discovered by a resident of the area.

title: Phase 3: A Tiger by the Tail
description: WILTON, ConnWhy did the Nixon Administration announce on Dec. 11 that wage and price controls would be continued, and exactly a month later announce that most of them had been repealed?

title: Neat Apartments With a Park Envisioned at Site of Bronx Ruin
description: In the South Bronx, they call the complex of onceelegant brick apartment buildings on Bryant Avenue the DMZ. The five buildings and their central courtyard look as if they had been blasted with cannon and burned over with napalm.

title: AGNEW IN SINGAPORE ON HIS ASIAN TOUR
description: SINGAPORE, Feb. 4 (AP)Vice President Agnew arrived in Sinapore today for his fifth Southeast Asian stopover in six days.

title: KNICKS SET BACKCAVALIERS 11497
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 4The Pearl was a natural gem of great beauty to the New York Knicks tonight as they completed an exhausting nineday schedule of seven National Basketball Association games with a 11497 victory over the Cavaliers before a lively crowd of 11,044 at Cleveland Arena.

title: HUSSEIN TO PRESS PEACE BID IN U.S.
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 4King Hussein of Jordan has ruled out any resumption of hostilities with Israel from his territory before a new attempt is made to reach a political settlement in the Middle East.

title: Fundamental Shift In Insuring Policing Proposed by State
description: The New York State Insurance Department, in its first comprehensive overhaul since the widespread industry scandals at the turn of the century, disclosed yesterday that it was proposing fundamental and sweeping changes in its policing of insurancecompany financial practices.

title: Gregg and Haywood Pilot Porsche to Daytona Victory
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 Peter Gregg, a 31yearoldautomobile dealer, and Hurley Haywood, a 24yearold parttime student in business administration, proved today that the tortoise can beat the hare under the right conditions.

title: Nixon and Spending: President Sees Victory
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4At his news conference last Wednesday, President Nixon was asked, How do you respond to criticism that your impoundment of funds abrogates power or authority that the Constitution gave to Congress?

title: ANDRE BARSACQ, 64, OF PARIS STAGE, DIES
description: PARIS, Feb. 4Andr Barsacq, a designer, director and author for the French stage, as well as owner of the Atlier Theater, died today In a hospital after a heart attack a week ago. He was 64 years old.

title: Sao Paulo Biennial: Seeds of Growth
description: SAO PAULO, BrazilFour years ago, when a large number of national and international artists boycotted the Sao Paulo Biennial in protest against Brazil's military regime and the repression of intellectuals and artists, the show ran into serious problems. Prominent by their absence at the last two events were artists from the Netherlands, Sweden and the United States. But organizers of the 12th Biennial, which will open Oct. 5 and run through November, hope to make it sufficiently exciting to break down the boycott and to add a new dimension to the biennial.

title: Peace With Charity
description: President Nixon dispatched Henry Kissinger to Hanoi with a commendable mission to advance the cause reconciliation. Yet, at the same time, Mr. Nixon closed his heart and mind to pleas for similar acts of reconciliation toward his own country's draft resisters and antiwar exiles.

title: Auxiliary Police Return to Their Patrols, But in Civilian Clothes and After Additional Training
description: With a twoway police radio beneath his plaid jacket, David J. Crane and his partner, William A. Ginard, both volunteer auxiliary policemen, resumed patrol this past weekend with special instructions on how to patrol in civilian clothes.

title: Crucial Year for Chain
description: For the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, 1973 is likely to be one of its most crucial years.

title: Past And Future
description: LONDON, Feb. 4Mr. Kissinger is right. It would be hard to find any American who from the beginning took a consistent, principled position on Vietnam. There are not many claimants for the holiness award.

title: GEN. R. F. STEARLEY OF AIR FORCE DEAD
description: BRAZIL, Ind Feb. 4 (AP)Maj. Gen. Ralph F. Stearley, retired, former commander of the 20th Air force on Okinawa during the Korean War, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 74 years old and lived here.

title: MAYORS TOUR CITY AND ASSAIL NIXON FOR CUTS IN FUNDS
description: With protests that the Nixon Administration had welshed on a financial commitment to cities, 11 Mayors yesterday, visited three Manhattan sites where, they said, the need for continued Federal financial aid was dramatically evident.

title: Controversial Pet Lion Going to Lionesses' Den
description: CLINTON, Conn., Feb. 4A pet lion that fascinated and alarmed townspeople here as it was led about on a leash and rode in the cab of a pickup truck is to be exiled, tomorrow to a breeding farm in Florida.

title: Indian Tribe in Montana Weighs Major Offer to Strip Mine Coal as Profitable but Perilous
description: LAME DEER, Mont., Feb. 4 While fuel executives and government officials warn that the country faces an energy crisis that may dim the lights in the East, the remnants of the Northern Cheyenne sleep uneasily here these wintry nights, worrying whether the white man's talk of a power shortage may finally silence the Cheyenne.

title: Donald Miller Weds
description: Miss Susan Trentacoste, school and mailorder advertising manager at Seventeen magazine, was married yesterday afternoon to Donald Howard Miller, an account executive with Penthouse magazine. The Rev. Frederick Hoseli and Rabbi Joseph Gelberman performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: Dr. John W. Manigaulte Of Queensborough College
description: COMMACK, LI., Feb. 4Dr. John Wesley Manigaulte, professor of history at Queensborough Community College, died Friday of a heart ailment, at his home, 240 Townline Road. His age was 58.

title: GAINS REPORTED AS TRUCE CHIEFS CONFER IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 5An official spokesman said yesterday that the meeting in Saigon between the heads of the two peacekeeping commissions was one of the most constructive steps accomplished in a week. The commissioners met earlier in the day.

title: G.I.'s Are Leaving Vietnam for the World
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 4  They had been marking time, waiting for the ceasefire. But now the last G.I.'s in Vietnam are moving out, most of them heading back to the world, as they call home.

title: Industrial Material Prices Moved Higher in January
description: Prices of industrial commodities and materials rose at an alarming clip during January, the National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday in a report by its business survey committee.

title: PAPER SEES QANTAS COOL ON CONCORDES
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 5 (Reuters)  Qantas, Australia's international airline, is not expected to pick up its options to buy four Concorde supersonic airliners, the national daily newspaper, The Australian, reported today.

title: G. O. P. CHAIRMAN IN BERGEN TO QUIT
description: PARAMUS, Feb. 4Anthony J. Statile, the chairman of the Bergen County Republican Committee, announced today that he was resigning on Feb. 27.

title: All OF NEW YORK BECOMES SCHOOL
description: For 61 highschool juniors and seniors, all of New York will become a school.

title: Duquesne Tops Villanova
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4 (UPI)Ruben Montanez and Jack Wojdowski combined for 44 points today to lead Duquesne to an 8465 basketball victory over Villanova, which suffered its eighth loss of the season against nine victories. The Dukes, with an 115 wonlost record, trailed 4234 early in the second half but scored 17 straight, points in a fourminute stretch. Montanez had 27 points, Wojdowski 17, to offset the 36 points scored by Torn Ingelsey.

title: TV: WNEW Checks Pulse of Bellevue Hospital
description: Recently, I asked a cab driver to take me to Bellevue Hospital. Instantly suspicious, he asked Ya hoit? and checked to see if any blood might be staining the ratty upholstery. Assured that his passenger was clean, the driver then proceeded to tell, with considerable relish, a Bellevue horror story, something about a girl going to the hospital for something physically minor and being mistakenly carted off to the psychiatric ward for several days.

title: Nixon Back in Capital After Camp David Stay
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) President Nixon returned to the White House tonight after a day at his Camp David, Md., retreat working on messages to Congress and relaxing with his wife.

title: EXPLOSION IN IOWA STILL UNEXPLAINED
description: EAGLE GROVE, Iowa, Feb. 4 (AP)The police were still undecided today on the cause of a Friday evening blast that killed 12 persons, left a 13th missing and presumed dead and leveled three business firms.

title: INQUIRY ON GRAFT TO BEGIN IN MIAMI
description: MIAMI, Feb. 4A special state prosecutor will begin an inquiry tomorrow into allegetions of widespread corruption in the courts and local governments of Miami and Dade County.

title: Nine Killed in Ulster
description: A weekend of violence in Northern Ireland left nine men dead and more than 20 wounded. Among those killed were six men shot by British soldiers. Page 3.

title: PETERSON TAKES WRESTLING HONOR
description: TBILISI, U.S.S.R., Feb. (AP)  Ben Peterson, an Olympic gold medalist from Comstock, Wis., beat the SoViet champion, Gennady Strakhov, today and won the 198pound class championship at an international wrestling tournament.

title: The Police and Society
description: WASHINGTONCrime brings fear.. Fear breeds terror. And with terror comes the destruction of the spirit and the freedom of a people. Although great strides have been made in combating crime, fear and terror still exist among us. More hard work lies ahead.

title: Ruth F. Raphael Wed
description: ROSLYN, L. I., Feb. 4Miss Ruth Feige Raphael and Leonard Ingber were married here this afternoon in the Shelter Rock Jewish Center. The bride's uncle, Rabbi Myron M. Fenster, and Rabbis Nissim Mengel, Joshua Hertzberg and Norman Strizoer officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Alvin Raphael of Bayside, Queens, and the late Mr. Raphael. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Ingber of Brooklyn.

title: Broker Weds Irene Siegle
description: Miss Irene Siegle of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Siegle of Yorktown, Va., was married here yesterday afternoon to Robert H. Goodkind, son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. Goodkind of Woodsburg, LI., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Mrs. John Bright Lord, 77; ExHead of SpenceChapin
description: Mrs. Ruth Johnstone Lord, widow of John Bright Lord, who was a stockbroker in New York and a banker in Darien, Conn., died yesterday at her Hobe Sound home in West Palm Beach, Fla. She was 77 years old and resided also at 3 East 77th Street and West Hampton Beach, L. I.

title: Races for Posts Just Below Mayor Are Wide Open
description: With a flood of candidates publicly considering a race for Mayor this year, politicians with ambitions for the lower offices are having trouble acquainting the voters with their aspirations.

title: 2 Young Brothers Die In a Fire in Fanwood
description: FANWOOD, Feb. 4 (UPI) Two young brothers were killed today and their mother was hospitalized for injuries suffered in a fire that swept through the family's woodframe house in this Union County community.

title: Job for the U.N.
description: Secretary General Kurt Waldheim's offer of a United Nations relief and reconstruction program to all the peoples of Vietnam without discrimination is one that should be taken up with alacrity by all sides, especially the United States.

title: Carol Sue Samberg Bride of B. G. Lipsky
description: Miss Carol Sue Samberg, daughter of Mrs. Harry H. Samberg of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Samberg, a physician, was married here yesterday afternoon to Burton G. Lipsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Lipsky of Rochester. Rabbi Henry Hyman performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: Duquesne Tops Villanova
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 4 (UPI)Ruben Montanez and Jack Wojdowski combined for 44 points today to lead Duquesne to an 8465 basketball victory over Villanova, which suffeied its eighth loss of the season against nine victories. The Dukes, with an 115 wonlost record, trailed 4234 early in the second half but scored 17 straight points in a fourminute stretch. Montanez had 27 points, Wojdowski 17, to offset the 36 points scored by Tom Ingelsby.

title: 18 Die in Mexican Accident
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 4 (UPI) Eighteen persons died and 49 others were injured today when an overloaded passenger bus turned over on a dark highway, the police said.

title: FASHION TALK
description: The makers of expensive clothes on the whole are a conservative lot. They venture rarely into uncharted waters. The system works well enough when lifestyles are constant. But in a time of flux it often results in beautiful collections that survive like dinosaurs in a world they're not really adapted to. So the potential customers go elsewhere for their kicky clothes, making the traditionalists hew more nervously to the tried and true.

title: Sweeping Changes In Corporate Policy Urged in Britain
description: LONDON, Jan. 28Sweeping changes to make private corporations more responsive to the public interest and more accountable to their stockholders, customers and employes have been recommended by a committee of inquiry set up by the Confederation of British Industry.

title: Damage Is Heavy in Passaic Flood
description: Weekend flooding appeared to have done the most damage in Passaic County, where the Passaic River crested at three feet above flood level at 3 P.M. yesterday.

title: Patman Says Nation Is Lagging In Effort to Meet Energy. Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4, (AP) The United States is moving too slowly in its efforts to cope with a developing energy crisis, the outgoing chairman of the Congressional Joint Committee on Defense Production said today.

title: ANDY RAZAF, 77, LYRICIST, IS DEAD
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP) Andy Razaf, composer and lyricist who wrote the words for such songs as Honeysuckle Rose, Ain't Misbehavin and Stompin' at the Savoy, died yesterday in a North Hollywood hospital at the age of 77.

title: Red Smith
description: There are these young guys, Bill Ballon and Don Kessler, friends and partners in various enterprises, who had a bet on the Super Bowl. Kessler had the Miami Dolphins. The stakes were a $1,000, dinner for four, the two guys and their wives. After the Dolphins stomped the Washington Redskins, Ballon would have taken potluck at McDonald's, but Kessler had other ideas. They consulted Craig Claiborne, who used to be the truffles critic for The New York Times, and he suggested the Four Seasons. Paul Kovi, director of the restaurantjoints that serve dinners at $250, a cover don't just have managerssaid but certainly, he would create a menu suitable to the occasion.

title: Onassis Family Drops In for Finale of Boat Show
description: Less than two hours before the end of the 63d National Boat Show yesterday, a Greek yachtsmani showed up with his wife and a 12yearold boy.

title: The Teacher
description: CHAPEL HILL, N. C.It was a hot night in early September, 1968. I was tense and anxious. My niece later said that I talked all night long in my sleep. On the morrow I would go into a classroom where I would be black and all of the others there would be white. What would happen and how would it work out? I was anxious that everything would go along all right. That I would perform all right.

title: Kahane Charged in Israel With Inciting Arabs to Go
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 4 (UPI)Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the militant Jewish Defense League, was charged today with inciting Arabs to leave Israel. The Jerusalem magistrate's court released him on 1$1,480 bail but set no hearing date.

title: RIFT IN TEAMSTERS DILEMMA TO NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4A bitter and widening rift between the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Frank E. Fitzsimmons, and his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, is complicating the Nixon Administration's politically rewarding romance with the big union, teamster and Administration sources report.

title: News Summary and Index MONDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: CITY POLICEMAN SLAYS ASSAILANT
description: A patrolman riding in an unmarked car as a backup escort for a regular radiocar patrol in upper Manhattan yesterday morning fired 11 shots from two guns and killed a man who reportedly attempted to shoot him with a pistol that failed to fire.

title: RESHUFFLE IS DUE IN VATICAN CURIA
description: ROME, Feb. 4The appointment of 30 new Cardinals by Pope Paul VI heralds a major shuffle in the Roman Catholic Church's central administrative body, the Roman Curia.

title: Mr. Nixon's Health Program
description: The conventional wisdom these days holds that President Nixon acted like Ebenezer Scrooge when he prepared the welfare portions of his new budget. There may well be room for criticism of many cutbacks on social and educational services. But a close look at the health care program the White House has proposed for fiscal 1974 suggests that the outlook in this area is not so bleak and that there is a good deal of justification for some of the reductions that have been made.

title: Nine Killed in Ulster
description: A weekend of violence in Northern Ireland left nine men dead and more than 20 wounded. Among those killed were six men shot by British soldiers. Page 3.

title: City Got Overpayment Of Quarter of a Million
description: The city has been overpaid $253,823 under a state program for maintaining and operating sewage treatment plants, according to an audit released yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt.

title: Laborites to Visit Vietnam
description: LONDON, Feb. 4 (UPI)A British Labor party delegation will leave Thursday on a factfinding tour of North Vietnam and South Vietnam, a party spokesman said today.

title: Seychelles Ketch Stormy First to Finish Rio Race
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 4 (AP)The ocean yacht Stormy, registered in the Seychelles Islands and skippered by a 72yearold Dutch millionaire, Kees Brynzeel, won the 3,500mile CapetowntoRip Race today.

title: Male Basketball Star Is School's Best Cook
description: SUTTON, N.H., Feb. 4 (AP) James L. Foley is 6 feet 4 inches tall, weighs 200 pounds and is the secondbest rebounder on the Kearsarge Regional High School basketball team.

title: Music: Vienna Byways
description: Pierre Boulez's Thursday night program with the Philharmonic seemed carefully planned to form an arch through Viennese music. It rose from excerpts from Schubert's Rosamunde through Mahler's five Rckert Songs to Webern's Variations and then dropped back through the same composer's Six Pieces for Orchestra to Wagner's prelude and LoveDeath from Tristan and Isolde. The last is not Viennese, of course, but it has its place in any historical trajectory involving Mahler and Webern.

title: The World of the Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4Every long and greatly publicized trial creates a world of its own. It is as if some natural disaster had swept away everything but what is happening to the participants,

title: Stage: Black Childhood in Alabama
description: A black childhood in Alabamaits scars, its beauties, its understandingsthat is the raw subject matter of Lamar Alford's musical thoughts. It is now being given by the La Mama Experimental Theater Company, and It has style, guts and compassion. Which is a rather unusual combination.

title: Softball League Expands
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 4 (AP)Major League Softball, Inc., awarded franchises today to teams in Philadelphia and Charlotte, N. C.

title: Sports Today
description: Yonkers Raceway, Central and Yonkers Avenues, 8 P.M.

title: PRICES CLOSE OFF ON AMEX AND OTC
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthe counter market finished lower yesterday after selling pressure in the afternoon erased earlier gains.

title: Sexism in the Theater Can Be a Boon
description: Sexism in the commercial theater has paid one positive dividendthe unusual number of women who have become initiators and groundbreakers with companies of their own, five such women agreed yesterday. They formed a panel at the luncheon meeting of Drama Desk, the association of New York drama critics, editors and reporters, in the Belasco Room at Sardi's.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Off at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Eleven parents and community activists, demanding the removal of the principal of Public School 50 in Jamaica, Queens, locked themselves inside the school for eight and a half hours yesterday and prevented 850 students from entering the building.

title: Cambodia Held Sure of U.S. Air Support
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 5  An authoritative Cambodian source said today that the United States had assured this county that it would resume bombing in Cambodia if the North Vietnamese troops resumed offensive operations against Government troops.

title: SENATE APPROVES SCHOOL AREA BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5The Assembly today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that, would reduce from 20,000 to 15,000 the minimum number of pupils in average daily attendance needed to constitute a community school district in New York City.

title: Bluegrass Shows a New Vigor As 2 Join Country Gentlemen
description: Bluegrass music in New York hit a high Sunday. Two concerts, one hi the evening, one at night, attracted large audiences for the Bluegrass Club of New York. The featured group the Country. Gentlemen, with the added support of Mike Auldridge on dobro (slide guitar) and Ricky Skaggs, violin, proved to be an unusually wide. ranging and communicative ensemble.

title: Tkachuk Gets Ranger Post
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Feb. 5 (AP)The Texas Rangers made several changes in their front office today, including the hiring of Doug Tkachuk as public relations director. Tkachnk had worked for the Dallas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association. Burt Hawkins, the former press relations director, was named traveling secretary and news media director.

title: Kretchmer Quits His Post To Explore Mayoral Bid
description: The city's Environmental Protection Administrator, Jerome Kretchmer, resigned yesterday so be could explore the possibility of running for Mayor.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: MRS. GEORGE SHIVELY
description: Mrs. Hilda Cleveland Shively, wife of George J. Shively, a retired senior editor of Doubleday & Co., died Friday at their home, 200 Bronxville Road, Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Cities Reassured on CableTV Rights
description: Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Com1 mission, sought yesterday to allay the fears of local government officials that the commission seeks to deprive the cities of the right to franchise and regulate cable television systems.

title: Advertising: Mail by Project X
description: For an unidentified client, Dillon, Agnew & Marton, an international direct mail company, is about to launch Project Xa mailing to every business and fun location around the world where an American tourist may touch foot this summer. There are 2.5 million of them.

title: BROKER SENTENCED TO SIXMONTH TERM
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5 (AP)  A member of the Schenectady School Board has been sentenced to six months in Federal prison for violating a court order barring him from operating a securities brokerage.

title: An Unusual Rabbinic Court judges Social Problems
description: BOSTON You're not taking human life, argued Rabbi Samuel I. Korff. It wasn't there to begin with.

title: Opening of Johnson Ranch As National Park Speeded
description: JOHNSON CITY, Tex., Feb. 5 (UPI)Lyndon B. Johnson's hill country ranchland along the Pedernales River will be opened to the public by June as a national park.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION CONTINUES TO RISE
description: Steel production for the week ended Feb. 5 continued to rise, as it has since the final week of 1972 according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. Output for the week ended Feb. 3 rose by 0.8 per cent to 2,875,000 net tons and an index level of 117.8. This was up from 2,851,000 tons a week earlier.

title: LORILLARD RAISES CIGARETTE PRICES
description: The Lorillard division of the Loews Corporation yesterday became the second major cigarette maker to raise its prices.

title: Widespread Security Theft Is Scored by Kleindienst
description: Widespread theft of stocks and bonds threatens a serious disruption to the securities business, comparable perhaps1 to skyjacking in the airline business, Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said here yesterday.

title: Suspect in Slaying of Gambino Admits He Demanded Ransom
description: A man who Federal authorities say confessed to killing the 29yearold nephew of Carld Gambino, the reputed Mafia chieftain, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to seven counts of extortion.

title: Fire Call Rouses Thief
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Members of Engine Company 24, responding to concurrent fire alarms last night, were away Oom their station for about an hour. When they returned they found the firehouse looted and their color television set missing  for the fifth time in less than a year.

title: Jersey Backs OutofState Waste Curb
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  A bill giving the Commissioner of Environmental Protection the power to stem the tide of solid and liquid waste coming into New Jersey from New York and Pennsylvania received final legislative approval today in the Senate.

title: William H. Walling Dead at 77; ExHead of Printing Industries
description: William H. Walling, a past president of Printing Industries of America, died yesterday in Utica, N.Y., where he had gone for a meeting of the Graphic Arts Mutual Insurance Company, of which he was chairman. He was 77 years old and lived at 1022 Sunset Road, Stamford, Conn.

title: Mayoral Uncertainties
description: An unusually large number of political uncertainties continue to cloud New York City's mayoral election this yearuncertainties over issues and problems and solutions; over candidacies and even over the dates on which the primary balloting will take place. To set the dates for primary voting is a responsibility of the State Legislature, and the lingering confusion over dates needs swift resolution.

title: Irked Actor Terms Fare Unfair
description: What fare is fair for a ride on a Penn Central train from Darien, Conn., to Grand Central Terminal in midtown Manhattan? The Penn Central says it is $2.90.

title: Meadows Sports Center Clears Last Legal Hurdle
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The Stale Supreme Court today approved the results of an environmental study of the proposed Hackensack Meadowland sports complex and removed the final legal barrier to construction of a football stadium for the New York Giants.

title: Stage: Phillip Dean's Freeman Bows
description: There are some plays that seem to be carved out of a man's experience. Such play is Phillip Hayes Dean's Freeman, which arrived at the American Place Theater last night. Last season Mr. Dean gave us The Sty of the Blind Pig with the Negro Ensemble Company. Freeman is not so ambitous as that remarkable first play, yet it has a most truthful vitality.

title: Kitty Hawk Crewman Pleads Guilty on Charges of Rioting
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 5 (AP)Bennie R. Halt, a 23yearold sailor from Denver, pleaded guilty today to taking part in a riot aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk.

title: $670Million Suit1s Filed In Chemical Blast in 1971
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., Feb. 5 (UPI)A $670million suit has been filed against the Government and the Thiokol Chemical Corporation by survivors of a chemical plant explosion in which 26 persons were killed.

title: HOLDUP DESCRIBED AT BROWN'S TRIAL
description: Two of the victims of the holdup of a West Side bar took the witness stand yesterday to describe the incident for which H. Rap Brown and three others are on trial, charged with armed robbery and the attempted murder of several policemen.

title: F.D.A. Official Says Cautious Policy on Licensing New Drugs Has Prevented Medical Disasters in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The United States has probably been spared several widespread medical disasters because of a cautious policy in licensing new drugs, an official of the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Inder, Page 39

title: Assemblyman W. C. Knights Of Genesee County, 56, Dies
description: ALBION, N.Y., Feb. 5 (AP)Assemblyman William C. Knights Jr. died today in Arnold Gregory Hospital. He was 56 years old.

title: Inco Reports Rise For Sales and Net
Brooklyn Fire Kills Invalid
description: A 72yearold invalid died yesterday in a fire in his apartment in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn. Firemen identified the victim as Victor Barrow of 949 Prospect Place. The cause of the fire was not ??ediately determined.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Man Convicted in '67 Slaying Seeks to Have Case Reopened
description: Attorneys for a aman convicted of manslaughter filed papers yesterday in State Supreme Court to reopen his case on the ground that the Manhattan District Attorney's Office and the Police Department had manufactured evidence against him.

title: Vario Tax Trial Begins
description: A Federal Court jury was selected in Brooklyn yesterday to try Paul Vario Sr., reputed Mafia figure, on charges that he had failed to disclose income from gambling operations. The 58yearold defendant, who lives in Island Park, L.I., made headlines last October when a trailer In his junkyard in Canarsie, Brooklyn, was identified by District Attorney Eugene Gold as a Mafia headquarters. He is accused of having failed to pay income taxes on unreported income of $36,400 in 1965 and $3,500 in January, 1966.

title: C. L A. Discloses It Trained Men From 12 U.S. Police Agencies
description: The Central Intelligence Agen cy has acknowledged training policemen from about a dozer city and county police forces the United States on the han dling of explosives, the deter tion of wiretaps and the organi zation of intelligence files.

title: Capital Women Sell Blood
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) Members of the National Organization for Women lined up outside a Washington commercial blood bank today to raise money in support of the equal rights amendment. About 30 Washington area women were on hand to sell their blood when the bank opened.

title: NIXON'S POPULARITY FOUND AT HIGH POINT
description: President Nixon's popularity rating reached 68 per cent, matching his previous high, point, following the announcement of the peace settlement in Vietnam, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ASPEN, Colo., Feb. 5 (AP)Cecilia Teague of East Burke, Vt., won the Bingham Cupthe women's version of the Roch Cuptoday by placing sixth in the downhill after a thirdplace finish in the slalom last Thursday.

title: Tkachuk Gets Ranger Post
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Feb. 5 (AP)The Texas Rangers made several, changes in their front office today, including the hiring of Doug Tkachuk as public relations director. Tkachuk had worked for the Dallas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association. Burt Hawkins, the former press relations director, was named traveling secretary and news media director.

title: SAIGON BYPASSES ACCORD IN FREEING MANY PRISONERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5The Saigon Government has reportedly released thousands of military and civilian prisoners in the last few days, turning them loose on their own despite provisions of the Paris ceasefire accord requiring that they be turned over to North Vietnam or the Vietcong.

title: City Primary Appears Set for May 31
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5Republican legislative leaders have virtually agreed upon a date for New York City's primary for the coming municipal election a May 31 primary for all offices.

title: A Patman Goal: Amend Economic Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The possibility of a partisan fight in Congress over extension of the Economic Stabilization Act took shape today.

title: Senate Votes to Require Approval of Budget Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to require confirmation, for the first time, of the director and deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget in the White House.

title: DONALD T. MULLANE
description: Donald T. Mullane, a member of the New York bar since 1934 specializing in estate and trust law, died Sunday in Jewish Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 624 Fort Washington Avenue.

title: Saigon and Vietcong Aides Hold First Paris Meeting
description: PARIS, Feb. 5  Delegates from the Saigon Government and the Vietcong met alone together here today for the first time. Their purpose was to prepare for the South Vietnamese political negotiations provided in the ceasefire agreements. The negotiations are to test whether the hostile sides can eventually reach a nonviolent settlement to their generationlong dispute.

title: SENATE PASSES AIRPORT AID BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5  In a doublebarrelled challenge to President Nixon, the Senate approved today an airport development bill almost identical to one that the President vetoed last fall and added language designed to force the President to spend all the money provided by the legislation.

title: Politics at Sea
description: To the many unanswered questions about Nixon campaign financing left in the wake of the Watergate trial, some new ones have been added by the yearend statement filed with Congress by the Finance Committee to Reelect the President.

title: Article 9  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: ARTHUR HUCK, LED CHILD CARE GROUP
description: Arthur Huck, who retired in 1959 as executive director of the Children's Aid Society of New York, died Saturday in Boston. He was 81 years old.

title: Arthur Daley
description: It was such a glorious opportunity, too. All that the International Olympic Committee needed to do was turn on the heat ever so slightly at an executive committee meeting over the weekend in Lausanne, Switzerland. That would have neatly thawed out of existence the 1976 Winter Olympics and eliminated one of the most vexing problems to have troubled the Olympic fathers for the last dozen years.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Kretchmer Quits Environment Post

title: China's No. 2 Man at U.N. To Be First Envoy to Japan
description: TOKYO, Feb. 5 (AP)Chen Chu, China's deputy representative at the United Nations, will be Peking's first Ambassador to Japan, the Japanese Government said today.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
Bill Filed for Faster Trains On WashingtonBoston Run
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Legislation to improve highspeed rail service between Washington, New York and Boston was introduced in the Senate today by Senator Vance Hartke, Democrat of Indiana, and Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., Republican of Connecticut.

title: NEWARK SURVEYS WATER SUPPLIES
description: NEWARK, Feb. 5A spokesman for the city said today that Newark had hired two engineering firms to conduct a $1million study of the city's overtaxed potable water sourcas and recommend ways of obtaining more water.

title: U.S. DEFENDS ARMS TO LAOS, CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The State Department said today that it was clearly understood by North Vietnam that the United. States could continue military aid to Laos and Cambodia under the agreement for a ceasefire in Vietnam.

title: Penney Seeks Insurer
description: Directors of the J. C. Penney Company, Inc., and the Educator & Executive Company approved yesterday a proposal for the merger of Educator & Executive into Penney.

title: 3 Sailors Die in Boiler Blast at Sea
description: Three sailors were killed and eight others injured yesterday when a boiler exploded on a Navy destroyer as she cruised in the Atlanta.

title: Tax Relief Is Urged by White House Advisory Panel to Help Industry in Pollution Battle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5A tax policy advisory committee to the White House Council on Environmental Quality recommended today several changes in the tax laws to promote environmental improvement.

title: CEASEFIRE UNITS TAKE THEIR POSTS
description: MY THO, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 6International peacekeeping teams fanned out across South Vietnam yesterday, but had not yet begun their work of monitoring violations of the ceasefire pact.

title: A Chance For the Senate
description: Members of Congress are making more noise than they have in years about the need to reassert themselves as a coequal branch of Government with the Presidency and the Supreme Court. It may well be too late for that, but there are a few things Congress could do and one of them would be to insist that President Nixon submit the name of a man of stature and experience as the new director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: 345 French Doctors Fight for Abortion
description: PARIS, Feb. 5In an act of defiance against both the Government and the law, 345 French doctors admitted publicly today that they had performed abortions.

title: Former Key Aide Of Tunisian Leader Flees From Prison
description: TUNIS, Feb. 5  A former Government minister who was a key aide of President Habib Bourguiba has escaped from a prison here where he was serving a 10year term on charges of high treason.

title: Swiss, Austrian Sledders Pace Title Practice Runs
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 5 (UPI) Taking advantage of good weather, 32 sleds from 12 nations put in a long afternoon of practice today for next weekend's world twoman bobsled championship. The Swiss and Austrians had the best times.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: NEW CARS SELLING AT A RECORD PACE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 5Newcar sales in January started 1973 off on the same record pace the industry enjoyed in 1972 with both domestic and import sales at highs.

title: 2 Goals by Jarrett Help Crusaders Beat Cougars
TV: BurtonTaylor 2Part Movie Begins Tonight
description: The American Broadcasting Company is being struck by disaster, not once but twice, this week. This time, at least for the moment, it has nothing to do with Jack Paar or Dick Cavett. It involves the two somewhat bigger names of Richard Burton and Elizabeth Taylor.

title: SENATORS PRESSING WATERGATE INQUIRY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Senate Democratic leaders moved today to set up a fivemember select committee with a broad mandate to investigate the Watergate affair and related charges of political sabotage during the 1972 Presidential primaries and election.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: OutofState Waste Curb Clears Senate in Trenton
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  A bill giving the Commissioner of Environmental Protection the power to stem the tide of solid and liquid waste coming into New Jersey from New York and Pennsylvania received final legislative approval today in the Senate.

title: Music: Recent Works
description: As a title for a newmusic series, The Continuing AvantGarde has an aptly defiant tone to It at a time when the avantgarde is being proclaimed dead in every other article one picks up. But there will always be an avantgarde, of course; the difficulty lies in distinguishing what is really new from what merely calls itself new.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: A legislative study commission yesterday recommended amendment to the State Constitution to replace the prohibition against legalized gambling with a law giving the Legislature discretion to authorize various forms of gambling.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: RUGBY UNION

title: Parole Offiber Group Backs Governor's DrugLaw Plan
description: The 250member State Narcotics Parole Officers Association gave its strong support yesterday to Governor Rockefeller's proposal for stiff mandatory sentences for drug sellers.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PROXIMITY Pace College is a neighbor of Chinatown downtown branch, that is, just across the street from City Hall, not its Westchester operation. That may offer a clue to the reason why the college is dedicating February to an observance of the Chinese New Year. One of the most challenging events will take place in 90 minutes today, in the college's Schimmel Center Pavillion, Spruce and Williams Street (2853627).

title: Meadowlands Stadium For Giants Is Cleared
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The State Supreme Court today approved the results of an environmental study of the proposed Hackensack Meaddowlands sports development and removed the final legal barrier to construction of a football stadium for the New York Giants.

title: NOMINEE TO F.T.C. FAVORED BY PANEL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Lewis A. Engman assured Senators today of his determination to be an aggressive and independent consumer advocate as chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: A CURE PROPOSED ON PH.D. STUDIES
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5A speciel state commission on doctora education recommended today that the state ban all eurren or proposed Ph.D. programsat public or private universitiesthat do not pass a new test of high quality and clear need.

title: Caso Terms Tax Stability His Top Priority for 1973
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 5Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso listed tax stability as his first priority in 1973 as he delivered his State of the County message today to 50 department heads and deputies.

title: Gamble, Penn Football Coach, Honored
description: Harry Gamble, coach of Pennsylvania's surprising football team last season, received the Joseph M. Sheehan Memorial Award yesterday as the coach of the year in the East's major college ranks. This was the third straight year an Ivy League coach won the prize given by the Football Writers Association of New York. Bob Blackman of Dartmouth and Frank Navarro of Columbia won the award in The award is named for the late New York Times assistant sports editor.

title: NEWSMEN BLOCKED AT TRUCEUNIT SITES
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam,: Feb. 5 (UPIAttempts by newsmen to cover the first deployment of Vietnam truce inspectors were blocked at at least three of the sites, where the ceasefire teams arrived today.

title: Airports Get 10Day Delay On BoardingGate Guards
description: The nation's airports wed a temporary restraining order yesterday that blocked for 10 days the implementation of an emergency Presidential order requiring armed local law enforcement officers to be stationed at airline boarding gates before all commercial flights.

title: Cuban Exiles in Spain Lock Eagerly to U.S.
description: MADRID, Feb. 5Napolen Navarro, a 29yearold Cuban who does not like Premier Fidel Castro, will leave here shortly for Miami with his wife, Martina, and his 10yearold daughter Teresa.

title: Waldheim and Mrs. Gandhi Talk in India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 5Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations, seeking a breakthrough in the tangled relations between India, Pakistan and Bangladesh, conferred today with Prune Minister Indira Gandhi.

title: Study Says City Bungled Renewal Job
description: The Scott Commission charged yesterday that two city administrations had so mismanaged a 12yearold urbanrenewal project in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn that it was a dismal failure that had cost millions of dollars in Federal funds and resulted in extensive human misery and vast property deterioration.

title: Blue Cross RateRise Bid Fought by City and Labor
description: City officials joined organized labor yesterday in opposing an application by the Blue Cross for a rate increase averaging 9.3 per cent. It would affect more than two million subscribers.

title: West Wrestlers Beat East In N.C.A.A. Meet, 24 to 14
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 5Two injury defaults in the late bouts helped the West rally to defeat the East, 2414, tonight in the seventh annual National Collegiate allstar wrestling meet before a capacity crowd of 3,000.

title: Two Killed in Plane Crash
description: MORRIS, Ill., Feb. 5 (UPI)Two brothers were killed here yesterday when their rented singleengine Cessna plane crashed into a wealthy neighborhood and burst into flames. The victims were John Van Rheenen, 29 years old, and his brother, Antonius, 27, both natives of Amsterdam.

title: Symphony Hails Black History Week
description: The Symphony of the New World began its celebration of Black History Week with an epic vengeance Sunday, presenting two concerts of classical music, jazz and recitations at Philharmonic Hall. All told, there were some six and a quarter hours of culture to be consumed, not counting the betweenconcerts soulfood dinner at the hall's downstair's restaurant. If the totality represented something of an endurance test for one's sitzfleisch, it did add up to a cumulatively impressive panoply of achievement.

title: U.S. Gets Soviet Loan Of 41 Major Paintings
description: Fortyone important paintings from the Soviet Union, including works by Matisse, Czanne, Picasso and Van Gogh, will be shipped to the United States next month for showing in, the National Gallery of Art in Washington and in the Knoedler Gallery here.

title: Sales and Earnings Rise Seen by Levitz for the Year
description: The Levitz Furniture Corporation, Pottstown, Pa., reported yesterday that sales in the fiscal year ended Jan. 31 rose 70.7 per cent to $326.3million from the year before. Sales in the final quarter rose 44.4 per cent to $94.3million, according to Ralph Levitz, chairman.

title: 2 Public Employe Groups Representing 700,000 Unite
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Two organizations of public employes announced today that they had agreed to merge, forming a new organization representing 700,000 workers.

title: Unified Legislature And a New Charter Proposed by Allende
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb 5 (UPI) President Salvador Allende Gossens, warning that his leftist Government would crush subversion, issued a campaign platform tonight, proposing new constitution and a onetouse People's Assembly. He addressed more than 480,000 supporters at a rally in the National Stadium,

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top teams, with points figured on a 10987654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records and total points:

title: Keino Joins Pro Track Tour,𠀠Renewing Rivalry With Ryun
description: Kipchoge Keino, track and field's most versatile distance runner, signed a professional contract with the International Track Association yesterday.

title: Life Term for Corona
description: Juan V. Corona was denied a new trial yesterday in Fairfield, Calif., and sentenced to 25 consecutive life terms for the murder of 25 itinerant farm workers. Page 20.

title: BOOK BAN BEATEN IN CONNECTICUT
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., Feb. 5The Board of Education, by a vote of 5 to 4, decided tonight against banning two controversial books from clasrooms in Ridgefield's public schools.

title: Lindsay Will Lobby To Reverse Freeze On Housing Funds
description: Mayor Lindsay, joined by three potential rivals in the next mayoral election, announced yesterday the start of an intensive national lobbying effort to reverse the Nixon Administration's freeze on Federal housingsubsidy funds.

title: Violations Charged
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., and the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company filed suits yesterday charging each other with violations of securities laws, as the companies maneuvered for position in their proxy fight.

title: Mailer's Guests ($50 a Couple) Hear His Plan on Secret Police
description: Norman Mailer, the selfstyled embattled aging enfant terrible of the literary world, has just turned 50, and to celebrate the occasion last night he threw himself an elegant $50acouple birthday party at the Four Seasons Restaurant.

title: Indians Name Farm Chief
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 5 (AP)Bob Quinn was named today as the director of minor league operations and scouting for the Cleveland Indians. He had been director of the Milwaukee Brewers' minor league operations. He succeeds Phil Seghi, recently named Indians' general manager.

title: Salt Lake City: After Olympics Bid
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 5 The wandering 1976 Winter Olympics have settled in Insbruck, Austria, now that a monthlong debate over this city's bid for the games has ended with the simple finality of an announcement that no Federal money would be available.

title: Mills Charges Travesty of Tax Law In Some Benefits From Capital Gains
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that the thing that disturbs me the most in the current tax law is the ease with which the income from certain kinds of investments can be treated as if it were a capital gain, and taxed at half the rate that applies to ordinary income.

title: Samuel Sillen, Editor of Marxist Journals, Dies
description: Dr. Samuel Sillen, a Marxist literary critic and writer who in recent years wag also a medical editor and author, died of cance yesterday ate University Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 89 Cleveland Drive, CrotononHudson, N. Y.

title: TWO PROTESTANTS HEED IN BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 5  The British Government threw down the biggest challenge so far to Protestant militants today by ordering two Protestants to be detained as terrorists. They had been arrested last Thursday.

title: Amnesty Strategy Parley Set for Paris
description: The drive for total amnesty for all war resisters will take a new dimension in Paris from Feb. 19 to 22, when three groups hall a strategy conference for exiles and their supporters.

title: John Mizerak, 77,Winner Of $1Million Lottery, Dies
description: LITTLE FALLS, N. Y., Feb, 5 (AP)John Mizerak, who won $1million in the New York State lottery last September, died today in Little Falls Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Inspectors Find Few Utility Companies Are Identifying Street Cuts by Color Code
description: Milton Jolkower, a Highways Department inspector who covers midtown Manhattan, went out yesterday morning to see if utility companies had placed identifying colors, as required, on the street cuts they have made since Dec. 9. He found none.

title: Oscar Peterson Plays Jazz Piano, At the Maisonette
description: For the last 20years Oscar Peterson has been one pf the most dazzling exponents of the flying fingers school of piano playing. His performances have tended to be beautifully executed displays of technique but woefully weak on emotional projection.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 5Someday this spring, with the sun shining brilliantly, a pay loader will rumble down Montgomery Street and stop in front of St. Peter's College. After some speeches and ceremonies, the big machine will start moving earth, marking the official groundbreaking for a $5million sports complex.

title: ExTreasurer of State Files Not Guilty Plea
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5John A. Kervick, former Treasurer of the State of New Jersey, pleaded not guilty today in Federal Court here to charges that he had extorted $113,000 from an engineering concern while in office.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETS IMPOUNDED FUNDS BELOW ESTIMATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The White House reported today that President Nixon was holding $8.7billion in Federal funds in reservesubstantially less than estimated by a Democratic Congressman last month.

title: Australia Will Keep a Token Force in Malay is and Singapore
description: CANBERRA, Australia, Feb. 5Australia said today that she would continue to participate in the defense of Malaysia and Singapore, in partnership with Britain and New Zealand, despite a pledge by the new Labor party Government here to bring home all Australian combat units in Southeast Asia.

title: DOROTHY MARSH
description: Dorothy Marsh McGavack, for 20 years director of foods and cookery for Good Housekeeping magazine, died of a heart attack Saturday at her home, 3555 80th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 77 years old.

title: Chock Full O'Nuts Seeking Schrafft's
description: The Chock Full O'Nuts Corporation is negotiating to buy 25 Schrafft restaurants in the East from Pet, Inc. Officials of both companies refused yesterday to confirm or deny that negotiations were under way.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Jap. 13 OpEd article entitled The Conflict Over the Delaney Clause requires clarification of the basic issue.

title: Senate Votes to Require Approval of Budget Aides
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 the Senate voted overwhelmngly today to require confirmation, for the first time, of the director and deputy director of the Office of Management and Budget in the White House.

title: Fireman Saves Bronx Baby
description: Fire Lieutenant Earl Maloney of Engine Company 92 rushed through the flames of a burning South Bronx apartment and saved a 15monthold baby moments after the child's mother escaped the flames herself by leaping from a window, the Fire Department reported yesterday. As the 47yearold officer carried the child, Steven Anderson, from the blazing apartment at 1018 Summit Ave., he administered mouthtomouth resuscitation.

title: Judge Weighs Ellsberg Motion to Bar Evidence Based on 2 Secret Documents
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 5The defense in the Pentagon papers trial asked the judge today to preclude the Government from presenting evidence based on two of the top secret documents in this case. The judge said he would consider the request.

title: ME RISE POSTED FOR SHORT TERN
description: The price of shorttern noney continued to creep higlpr yesterday, but interest rates on bonds leveled off. Specialists said the Govern nent's move to seek justifica tion from four Eastern banks that raised their prime rates to 6 per cent Friday served to inspire greater confidence in Phase 3 ana frightened some shorts into coy ering their po sitions. Treasury issues managed small gains in price, except for intermediate maturities that are receiving competition from the refinancing that ends tomorrow.

title: McMahon 76ers' Scout
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (UN) The lowly Philadelphia 76ers, looking toward the National Basketball Association draft in the spring, hired Jack McMahon as a scout today. McMahon is a former player and coach of the Cincinnati Royals and San Diego Rockets.

title: Basketball Ratings
description: The top teams, with points figured on a 10987654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records rind total points:

title: STREAKING LAKERS TO OPPOSE KNICKS
description: A rare eventa visit by the champion Los Angeles Lakers takes place at Madison Square Garden tonight as the National Basketball Association schedule allows the New York Knicks to entertain their transcontinental, rivals for the secand and last time this season.

title: Notes on People
description: Mayor Lindsay and Mayor Vladimir Promyslov of Moscow and about 60 other persons had lunch at Gracie Mansion before the two mayors took a helicopter overview of the city. The officials had met last year at a conference in Tokyo, and Lindiay aides said that at that time Mr. Promyslov declined to discuss the situation of Soviet Jews. Yesterday, however, Mr. Promyslov told Mr. Lindsay that they could discuss any problem the Mayor is interested in.

title: DCL and Lenders Agree On Debt Repayment Terms
description: DCL, Inc., cashpinched parent company of Diebold Computer Leasing, announced yesterday that it had successfully completed negotiations with group of lenders headed by the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company to stretch out repayment of $17.9million of debt.

title: DOMINICANS HUNT GOERRLLA BAND
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 5 (UPI)A small band of uniformed guerrillas from Cuba landed on the south coast of the Dominican Republic today and moved into the interior, the Dominican Army said. It charged former President Juan Bosch with having close ties with the group.

title: Engineer Corps Scored By Douglas as Enemy
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 5 (UPI) United States Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas called the United States Army Corps of Engineers the environment's public enemy No. 1 today and also criticized the Atomic Energy Commissions nuclear power plants, the Interior Department and the Tennessee Valley Authority.

title: Last American Killed Before the Truce Is Buried in Arlington
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The Army buried one of its own today, Bill Nolde.

title: JOHN W. ORR
description: John W. Orr, an editor with The Shelby (Ala.) Reporter and formerly a public relations man here, died Saturday of a heart ailment in Montevallo, Ala., where he lived. His age was 50.

title: Traffic Tickets Ignored
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 (AP) Of all the traffic and parking tickets issued by Philadelphia police last year more than a third went unpaid. Scofflaws, according to a Traffic Court Judge, cost the city $4million in 1972. The police issued about two million violations and more than 700,000 did not result in payment.

title: Beyond Cosmetics
description: WASHINGTON  Now that a new Congress has convened, it is especially appropriate to take dispassionate stock of our nation's economic strengths and weaknesses. Such an examination is essential to determine what legislative and administrative action is necessary in the ensuing months to move us toward those goals that we all seeka dynamic economy, adequate jobs for an expanding labor force, higher standards of living for our people, more stable price levels and improvement in our international balance of payments.

title: Canadian Named Chairman Of Vietnam Truce Group
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5 (Reuters)Michel Gauvin of Canada today was named chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision, the fournation organization charged with policing the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: Searcy Keeps St. John's Jumping
description: More rebounding help is coming St. John's way for the stretch run toward a postseason tournament berth and maybe even greater glory thereafter. Beaver Smith, a freshman described as a little Ed Searcy, has become eligible with the change of the National Collegiate Athletic Association academic eligibility rule.

title: FLEXIBILITY URGED IN NARCOTIC CAM
description: ALBANY, Feb. 5The Conservative party in the state and the chairman of the Legislature's black caucus urged today that Governor Rockefeller modify his proposal for mandatory life imprisonment for all adult drug dealers.

title: family food fashions furnishings
description: ARMONK, N. Y.The new black family on the block often gets a warm smile from the white neighbors on moving day. Sometimes an even warmer casserole. But the invitations to those allwhite cocktail parties aren't arriving with such regularity, they say. And when they do, some black women in Westchester automatically send their regrets.

title: Bruins' Problems Seem Likely To Speed Sanderson's Return
description: Because of the Boston Bruins' recent difficulties, the dismissal of Coach Tom Johnson and a lost spirit in a team that used to believe it was invincible, the time is ripe for Derek Sanderson to rejoin the club. Sanderson has the Bruins' negative factors going for him as he negotiates a return to the National Hockey League, and it wouldn't be surprising if he rejoined the club within a few days.

title: Jailing of Prison Doctor Opens 400 Parole Cases
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The chairman of the New Jersey Parole Board said tonight that the board was reviewing all parole cases that were processed by Dr. William King, the staff psychiatrist for the Trenton State Prison who has been charged with plotting the murder of his former wife and two members of her family. two members of her family.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1973

title: Equity Financing
description: The Central & South West Corporation, autility holding company, yesterday said it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission 1.2 million common shares to be sold at competitive bidding. The company said it would use proceeds to repay shortterm borrowings and from time to time to purchase additional common shares of its subsidiary operating companies. The company' stock was down  at 47 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Robert Lazarus Sr., Executive Of Federated Stores, Dies at 82
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 6 Robert Lazarus Sr., chairman emeritus of the F. & R. Lazarus Company department store, and vice president and director of Federated Department Stores, Inc., died yesterday. He was 82 years old.

title: Charles Liebman Is Dead; ExEditor of The Chief, 83
description: Charles Liebman, who retired in 1967 as editor and advertising manager of The Chief, weekly civil service newspaper here, died Saturday of a stroke in Sanford, Me., where he had moved in October. His age was 63.

title: The Nobel Prize Isn't Worth It
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The interesting thing about President Nixon's nomination to receive the Nobel Peace Prize is that he did not intervene to stop his admirers from entering his name in this unhappy competition.

title: Stennis Condition Better, But Still Very Serious
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis continues to show improvement from two bullet wounds suffered in a holdup last week but remains in very serious condition, his doctors reported today.

title: Agnew Says U.S. Intends To Maintain Its Thai Bases
description: SINGAPORE, Feb, 5 (UPI)Vice President Agnew told Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today that the Nixon Administration would keep American military bases in Thailand to prevent possible Communist expansion to the south, a highlevel Singapore source said.

title: Cooler Ride
description: Even against a wintry backdrop, the prospect of airconditioning in every cityowned subway car and bus by 1980 is an alluring one for New Yorkers. The most uncertain part of the undertaking announced by Mayor Lindsay and Chairman Ronan of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, remains the airconditioning of the venerable IRT lines, with their smaller tunnels and shorter cars; but tests with pilot equipment have encouraged hope that the IRT trains will not lag too far behind those on the BMT and IND lines in becoming tolerable for hotweather travel.

title: Weekend Boxing
description: Sendai, JapanKuniaki Shibata, Japan, knocked out Kimio Shindo, Japan, 7 rounds, featherweights.

title: Connection Agent Is Indicted by U.S. In Narcotics Sales
description: The principal Federal narcotics agent in the celebrated French Connection case of 1962  who has been working as an East Side bartender and as an investigator for crime Writers, has been dieted on charges of selling heroin and cocaine, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: 2.5% Christiana Discount In du Pont Tie Defended
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP)  An investment banker today defended his company's recommendation that E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Co. and Christiana Securities merge on terms, discounting Christiana's net asset value by 2.5 per cent.

title: People and Business
description: The expected appointment of G. Bradford Cook as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission is seen by many Wall Streeters as a defeat for Peter M. Flanigan, the wellconnected assistant to the President for international economic affairs. Mr. Flanigan, considered the mantosee by businessmen interested in reaching high Administration officials, has been the chief sponsor of another candidate for the job  C. Calvert Knudsen, a senior vice president of the Weyerhauser Company.

title: Dollar Is Uncertain
description: The dollar posted a ragged and uncertain performance in a nervous foreign exchange market yesterday. In some instances, the United States currency strengthened in relation to foreign currencies. But it was lower in relation to both the German mark and the British pound.

title: WHITE HOUSE SETS IMPOUNDED FUNDS BELOW ESTIMATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The White House reported today that President Nixon was hold ing $8.7billion in Federa funds in reservesubstantially less than estimated by a Democratic Congressman Iast month.

title: Bridge Across Broadway
description: The trustees of Columbia University and Barnard College have agreed to replace what has often seemed a policy of reluctant coexistence with a new relationship of institutional and fiscal integration without assimilation. Under the plan undergraduates on either side upper Broadway's great divide will be able to take full advantage of courses, libraries and research facilities on both campuses. The arrangement means that the two institutions prefer to live together and share each other's wealth, without binding marriage tiesnot an unfashionable compromise.

title: REBUILDING OF INDEX IS ASKED BY TELEX
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 5 (AP) The Telex Corporation asked a Federal judge today to order! the Control Data Corporation to reconstruct a computerized index to documents gathered in an antitrust case against the ternational Business Machines Corporation or to order I.B.M. to make its own file system available to Telex

title: JOHN H. GIBBON JR., HEART SURGEON, 69
description: Dr. John H. Gibbon Jr., who performed the world's first successful openheart operation using a machine that totally bypassed the heart, died yesterday on a tennis court in Philadelphia. Dr. Gibbon, apparently the victim of a heart attack, was 69 years old.

title: Top Black Aide, Leaving Post, Extols Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5If I had a son, if I should have a son, I would want him to have the same qualities that Richard Nixon has, Robert J. Brown said as he prepared to leave his post as special assistant to the President.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: N.C. SPATE DOWNS N.CAROLINA, 7673
description: RALEIGH, N.C., (AP)Secondranked North Carolina State preserved its unbeaten record with a comeback in the closing minutes tonight, defeating eighthranked North Carolina, 7673, in an Atlantic Coast Conference basketball game.

title: Film on Wolves Is Banned
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 5 (UPI)Broward County school officials have banned further use of an Audubon Society nature film because it has a scene of wolves mating. The 15minute film depicting the plight of endangered species was pulled back from school use after several showings because of one complaint, a school official said.

title: Corona Sentenced to 25 Life Terms; His Motion for New Trial Is Denied
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Feb. 5 (UPI)Juan V. Corona was sentenced today to 25 consecutive terms of life imprisonment for the biggest mass murder in United States history.

title: RODINO URGES BILL ON NEWS SOURCES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5The new chairman of the House Judiciary Committee called today for swift Congressional action on legislation that would prevent newsmen from being forced to testify about their confidential sources.

title: MARRY DENT NAMED COUNSEL FOR C.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 Harry S. Dent, the White House political coordinator during President Nixon's first term, was named today general coonsel to the Republican National Committee.

title: Chess:
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 5  The first game played in the threeway tiebreaking match for the United States chess championship pitted Lubomir Kavalek against Samuel Reshevsky. The game, adjourned after 40 moves, will resume tomorrow night at the LaSalle Hotel here.

title: ExPoliceman Sentenced in Slaying of Detective
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 5A former New York City patrolman who had been convicted of manslaughter in the shooting of a New York City detective was sentenced twice in Nassau County Court today because of a misinterpretation of the law by the judge.

title: After War and CeaseFire, the South Vietnamese Communist Groups Remain a Mystery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5One of the mysteries of the Vietnam war has been the other side, those South Vietnamese Communists and nationalists whowith the support of North Vietnamhave battled the Saigon Government and the United States to a standstill.

title: Jailing of Prison Doctor Opens 400 Parole Cases
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The chairman of the New Jersey Parole Board said tonight that the board was reviewing all parole cases that were proc essed by Dr. William King, the staff psychiatrist for the Trenton State Prison who has been charged with plotting the murder of his former wife and two members of her family.

title: DR. EDWARD H. KRAUS
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. Dr. Edward H. Kraus, a mineralogist, who retired as dean of the College of Literature, Science and Arts of the University of Michigan in 1945, died Saturday. He was 97 years old.

title: Pentagon Property Listed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (REUTERS)  The Department of Defens esaid today that it con trolled 282 million acres, 7 per cent of, it overseas. In an annual accounting to Congress of its, property, the Pentagon said that about 58 per cent of Defense Department land was in the public domain.

title: Revaluation Suggested
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 5 The United States is renewing pressure on Japan to revalue the yen and is telling Europeans they must absorb more Japanese exports.

title: Roberts First at Garden In Motorcycle Cup Race
description: Steve Hernandez, who drove east from California with his dad; Kenny Roberts, who flew in from Houston, and Bren Moran, who came up from Greenwich Village, were kind of representative of the motorcycle riders entered in the third annual Yamaha Silver Cup at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: Emma Dot Partridge, 87, Headed Women's Groups
description: Emma Dot Partridge, who, as executive secretary of the, National Federation of Business and Professional Women, organized National Business Women's Week, died Saturday at her home, Ill East 37th Street. She was 87 years old.

title: CEASEFIRE UNITS TAKE THEIR POSTS
description: MY THO, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 6International peacekeeping teams fanned out across South Vietnam yesterday, but had not yet begun their work of monitoring violations of the ceasefire accord.

title: Earth Tremors Reported Along New England Coast
description: BOSTON, Feb. 5 (AP)Southeastern Massachusetts and the Rhode Island coast experienced a mild earth tremor Saturday morning, and an official of the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory said that probably an earthquake is the most logical explanation.

title: STOCK LIST PLODS TO DROWSY FINISH
description: The stock market, well into the fourth week of what Wall Streeters call an intermediate decline, eased a bit further yesterday in slow trading.

title: SHMUEL LAPIN, 43, EXPERT ON YIDDISH
description: Shmuel Lapin, executive secretary of the YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, an organization that does study and research on the Yiddish language, culture and history, died Sunday in Hillcrest General Hospital, Jamaica, Queens, after a long illness. He was, 43 years old and lived at 10205 Roosevelt Avenue, Flushing, Queens.

title: Surprise Irish Election Set for Feb. 28 by Lynch
description: DUBLIN, Feb. 5Prime Minister John Lynch of the Irish Republic today ordered a general election to be held on Feb. 28.

title: Bridge: Lucky Declarer Capitalizes On a 3% Chance for Victory
description: An early claimant for the distinction of being the luckiest declarer in 1973 is Paul Heitner of Mount Vernon. In the diagramed deal, which helped his team win the New Jersey Knockout Team title a week ago, he capitalized on a 3 per cent chance to make a game after the opponents twice missed a possibility to defeat him.

title: A TooLarge Son Of Bret Hanover Grows Up at Last
description: YONKERS, Feb. 5It took two years for John Hayes Sr. to turn Big Bret into a racehorse. Now the 53yearold trainer from Oshawa, Ontario, appears ready to reap the benefits of his patience. The regally bred 4yearold son of Bret HanoverColleen Napolean is the 31 morning line favorite for tomorrow night's third and most advanced division of the Hopeful Pacing Series for 3 and 4 yearolds at Yonkers Raceway.

title: SHOP TALK
description: Europeans, for reasons known only to themselves, have long been wearing, gold framed eyeglassesthat is, the Europeans who either are willing to settle on one shape for life or have enough money to keep buying different styles.

title: To Halt Ulster Killing
description: Can nothing be done to halt the senseless sectarian warfare that claimed a score of lives in Northern Ireland in the last week? Are there no leaders in the Protestant and Catholic communities of Ulster with enough stature and courage to join together and cry enough?

title: U.S. Experts Begin Haiphong Sessions On Clearing Mines
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI) A team of United States Navy demolition experts headed by Rear Adm. Brian McCauley met in Haiphong today with the city harbormaster and other North Vietnamese officials to discuss plans for clearing away American mines and reopening the port the Pentagon reported.

title: Hutton to Buy Firm
description: E. F. Hutton & Co., one of the nation's largest investment houses, announced plans yesterday to acquire R. S. Dickson, Powell, Kistler & Crawford, a regional investment banking and brokerage firm based in Charlotte, N. C.

title: Some Banks Lifting Rates On Loans as Prime Stalls
description: Some of the nation's largest banks are quietly taking action to raise their lending rates even while their posted prime, or minimum, charges on business loans remain stalled at 6 per cent as a result of political pressure from Washington.

title: Connection Agent Is Indicted by U.S. In Narcotics Sales
description: The principal Federal narcotics agent in the celebrated French Connection case of 1962  who has been working as an East Side bartender and as an investigator for crime writers  has been in dicted on charges of selling heroin and cocaine, Federal authorities announced Yesterday.

title: Slumping Bruins Oust Johnson
description: Tom Johnson of the Boston Bruins, who holds the finest coaching record in National Hockey League history, was dismissed yesterday following his club's monthlong slump.

title: SAIGON BYPASSES ACCORD IN FREEING MANY PRISONERS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 5The Saigon Government has reportedly released thousands of military, and civilian prison ers in the last few days, turn ing them loose on their own despite provisions of the Paris ceasefire accord requiring that they be turned over to North Vietnam or the Vietcong.

title: Jailing of Prison Doctor Opens 400 Parole Cases
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The chairman of the New Jersey Parole Board said tonight that the board was reviewing all parole cases that were pro cessed by Dr. William King, the staff psychiatrist for the Trenton State Prison who has been charged with plotting the murder of his former wife and two members of her family.

title: Airports Get 10Day Delay On BoardingGate Guards
description: The nation's airports won a temporary restraining order yesterday that blocked for 10 days the implementation of an emergency Presidential order requiring armed local law enforcement officers to be stationed at airline boarding gates before all commercial flights.

title: Protest at Great Meadows Maintained by 650 Inmates
description: COMSTOCK, N.Y., Feb. 5More than 650 of the 1,396 inmates of Great Meadow Correctional Facility, a maximumsecurity prison here, remained locked in their cells today in a continuation of a nonviolent protest that began last Thursday.

title: Market Place: Realty Data Rein Eased by State
description: Some years ago, when there was a boom in real estate syndications, Sponsors of these limited partnerships liked to project earnings for five to 10 years out.

title: Life Term for Corona
description: Juan V. Corona was denied a new trial yesterday in Fairfield, Calif., and sentenced to 25 consecutive terms of life imprisonment for the murder of 25 itinerant farm workers. Page 20.

title: In Memoriam: A Country Continues to Play Sports
description: Israel regards future participation in the Olympics and other international sports events as a must, the country's bestknown athlete said here yesterday.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)Sales and redemptions of United States Savings Bonds both increased in January, the Treasury Department said today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
People in Sparts: Mets Sign Two Pitchers
description: Jim McAndrew and Ray Sadecki, pitchers for the New York Mets, have signed contracts for the 1973 season, the club announced yesterday. McAndrew, who won 11 games and lost 8, received a raise after enjoying his best season of five with the Mets. The 28yearold righthander had a 2.80 earnedrun average, the 11th lowest in the National League.
