Sadecki, a 32yearold lefthanded relief pitcher who will be working in his 13th major league season, appeared in 34 games, winning two and losing one.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE LIGHT GARDEN OF THE ANGEL RING. By Peter Levi. 287 pages. Illustrated. BobbsMerrill. $8.50.

title: 3 Nagas and 5 Soldiers Reported Killed in India
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 5 (Reuters) Three Naga guerrillas and five Indian soldiers were killed in a battle after an army convoy was ambushed near the southern Nagaland border Saturday, The Press Trust of India, the country's main news agency, reported today.

title: Hussein Arrives in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 CAP)King Hussein of Jordan arrived here today, under strict security, He is to confer with President Nixon tomorrow, have lunch with Secretary of State William P. Rogers and then return to the White House for a dinner. Conferences with other officials are scheduled before the King's departure at the end of the week.

title: GeorgiaPacific Buying A Boise Cascade Forest
description: The GeorgiaPacific Corporation and the Boise Cascade Corporation announced an agreement yesterday for Georgia Pacific to buy substantially all of Boise Cascade's timber and wood products operations based at Fort Bragg, Calif., for about $120million in cash.

title: G.M. Holding Dividend To the Usual 85 Cents
description: Directors of the General Motors Corporation yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of 85 cents a share on 286 million shares outstanding, payable March 10 to 1,268,000 commonstock holders. The company has paid a similar dividend in the first quarter of each year since 1966.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: New StateAid Controls. Are Urged to Save Cities
description: TRENTON, Feb. 5  The State Task Force on Urban Programs, noting the slow pace of progress toward solution of Newark's financial problems, called today for drastic new stateaid controls and broadened responsibility for meeting the financial crises of New Jersey's cities.

title: COURT SEVERS 8 FROM CAMDEN 28
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 5 The cases of eight of the defendants in the Camden 2 case were severed from those of the rest today at the re quest of the Government a few minutes before Federal Judge Clarkson Fisher began indo?? trinating prospective jurors for the trial here.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: About Inflatable Boats
description: After ceasing to be dazzled by the glittering array of larger craft at New York City's recent National Boat Show, one became aware of the remarkable variety of inflatable boats now being manufactured.

title: Gypsum Officer Resigns
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 5 (UPI)The president and chief operating officer of the National Gypsum Company, Darwin D. Tucker, resigned today. Colon Brown, chairman, as assumed the post.

title: STATE AID TO TOWNS IS CALLED TOO LOW
description: The State Assembly's Republican majority leader, John E. Kingston, declared yesterday that cities were getting state revenuesharing out of proportion to towns, and promised to fight to revise formulas in the towns' behalf.

title: STATE TO CONTINUE PLAN FOR SEWAGE
description: State officials outlined plans here yesterday that they hope will keep the sewagetreatment program alive in the face of fund cutbacks by President Nixon.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: LONDON, Feb. 5Britain's Appeal Court today lifted its ban on a television documentary flint about Andy Warhol, the American artist, and movie marker. The film, made by David Bailey, the photographer, focuses on interviews with Mr. Warhdl and his associates and includes scenes showing Mr. Warhol and Mr. Bailey in bed together and a woman using one of her breasts as a paint brush. The ban was obtained Jan. 16, just before it was to have been shown, by Ross McWhirter, editor of the Guinness Book of Records, on the ground that the Independent Broadcasting Authority, which supervises commercial television, had approved it without seeing it though press reports had indicated it was abscene.

title: Neediest Cases Fund Tops Previous Drive
description: The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund exceeded its predecessor yesterday by almost $1,700 with contributions from nearly 12,500 donors adding up to $1,022,448.67.

title: Eyen's The White Whore and Bit Player Arrives
description: Candy Darling in the role she was born to play, reads the advertisement for Tom Eyen's The White Whore and the Bit Player. Although one would question, on factual grounds, the word born, this is a role suited to this female impersonator's talents and one that she has already played in one semblance or another.

title: PARK AIDE GUILTY IN ATLANTIC CITY
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 5 (AP)Robert Glass, a defendant in the extortionconspiracy trial of six present and former Atlantic City officials, changed his plea today to guilty from not guilty.

title: UNION OPPOSES A. & P. ON WAREHOUSE PLAN
description: Tentative plans by the A.&P. food chain to close a large warehouse complex in Garden City, L. I., and a satellite operation in Maspeth, Queens, led yesterday to charges by teamsters union local that 800 jobs would be lost and, employe pension funds endangered.

title: Press Shield Law Advances
description: SANTA FE, N. M., Feb. 5 (UPI)The New Mexico State Senate passed by a 3vote margin today a press shield law that allows the State Supreme Court to make the final determination of whether a newsman must disclose his source.

title: HOSPITAL LEADERS FEAR COST PINCH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5Leaders of the American Hospital Association warned today that new Federal policies would force some institutions to cut patient services and even face bankruptcy.

title: Laos Reported Suffering Big Losses
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 5With Communist forces attacking heavily in many areas, the military situation of the Laotian, Govenment has deteriorated sharply, military, sources reported today.

title: ANN VALENTINE
description: A memorial service for Ann Valentine, a United Nations secretary killed Jan. 29 returning from Cairo on an Egyptian airliner that crashed in Cyprus where she was stationed, will be held in the chapel of the World Council of Churches, 777 United Nations Plaza, at 12:30 P.M. on Feb. 14.

title: The CabinetMaker
description: We do not have a Cabinet in the historical sense defined by Webster: an advisory council of a President composed of the heads of the executive departments of the government. The President needs such a Cabinet.

title: 8 of the Camden 28 Face Separate DraftFile Trial
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 5The cases of eight of the defendants in the Camden 28 case were severed from those of the rest today at the request of the Government a few minutes before. Federal Judge Clarkson Fisher began indoctrinating prospective jurors for the trial here.

title: U.S. Gets Soviet Loan Of 41 Major Paintings
description: Fortyone important paintings from the Soviet Union, including works by Matisse, Czanne, Picasso and Van Gogh, will be shipped to the United States next month for showing in the National Gallery of Art in Washington and in the Knoedler Gailery here.

title: FASHION TALK
description: Whatever happened to Giorgio di Sant'Angelo?

title: C.I.A. Discloses It Trained Police From 12 Agencies
description: The Central Intelligence Agency has acknowledged training policemen from about a dozen city and county police forces in the United States on the handling of explosives, the detection of wiretaps and the organization of intelligence files.

title: Parun, Emerson, Solomon Win in Spectrum Tennis
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6 (AP) Onny Parun of New Zealand ousted ninthseeded Allan Stone of Australia, 63, 16, 76, in the opening round of the $50,000 professional indoor teams tournament at the Spectrum today.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of 1.5 million shares of the Houston Lighting & Power Company common stock at $46.25 per share was made yesterday by underwriters headed by Morgan Stanley & Co., and Dean Witter. The company's stock was up  at 46 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: A Drive in Congress Links Trade to Soviet Exit Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Representative Wilbur D. Mills has decided to use his power as Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee to block any liberalization of trade with the Soviet Union unless Moscow rescinds its exit fees and freely allows Jews and others to emigrate, a Congressional source said today.

title: CAVALIERS DEFEAT CELTICS, 110106
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 6 (UPI)Lenny Wilkens poured in 31 points and Austin Carr added 28 tonight to lead the Cleveland Cavaliers to a 110105 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics.

title: Rockefeller Sees Billions Saved By Plan for Uniform Pensions
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to approve a uniform retirement plan for new public employes that has been proposed by a state pension commission.

title: 22 Dakota Indians Seized After Clash With the Police
description: CUSTER, S. D., Feb. 7 (AP)An estimated 200 protesters seeking a stiffer charge against a man accused of stabbing an Indian clashed with the police in downtown Custer today, and officials said 22 of the Indian demonstrators were arrested.

title: Brown Is Named for First Time As a Participant in Bar Holdup
description: H. Rap Brown, the black militant, was identified by a witness in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday as the man who wielded an M2 carbine and joined in the holdup of a West Side bar at about 3 A.M. on Oct. 16, 1971.

title: Late Rally Sinks East
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 6 (UPI)Willie Wise led fourth  quarter scoring surge as the West wiped out a 1point deficit and stunned the favored East, 123111, tonight in the sixth American Basketball Association All  Star game.

title: Annual Ceiling Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A special committee of senior members of Congress agreed in principle today to a major reform in the way Congress deals with Government spending, including a ceiling every year on total spending that would apply to Congress itself.

title: MRS. J. ARCHER TURNER
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., Feb. 6Mrs. J. Archer Turner, the former Helen Carr and the widow of the former chairman and president of the Turner Construction Company, died Sunday at her home here. She was 89 years old.

title: Insurer Is Seeking To Raise Holdings In a Western Unit
description: The American General Insurance Company announced yesterday an offer to buy the outstanding common shares of the CaliforniaWestern State Life Insurance Company that it doesn't already own for $20 al share.

title: Service Set for Prof. Chang
description: A memorial service for Chang Hsinhai, a former Chinese diplomat who was professor of humanities at Fairleigh Dickinson University, will be held Saturday at 4 P.M. in the United Nations Chapel, 777 United Nations Plaza. Professor Chang died Dec. 5 in Shanghai at the age of 74 on a visit as a guest of the People's Republic of China.

title: 7 TO CO TONIGHT IN HOPEFUL PACE
description: YONKERS, Feb. 6The YonkersRoosevelt Hopeful pacing series, designed to encourage, enrich and to add experience to lightly raced 3yearolds and 4yearolds, will be continued at Yonkers Raceway tomorrow night. Following the three divisions slated to be contested here tonight, the fourth preliminary onemile test will have seven starters aiming for the lion's share of the $5,000 gross purse.

title: SOVIET SKATERS TAKE WIDE LEAD
description: COLOGNE, West Germany, Feb. 6 (AP)  Two smooth and spectacular Soviet couples dominated today's compulsory program at the European figureskating championships and gave the Soviet Union a nearunbeatable lead in pairs.

title: Squatters Must Go  but When?
description: HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 6It's like paradise, said a squatter on an island in the Hudson River near this city.

title: State and Conservationists Eye Hudson Islands
description: WATERFORD, N. Y., Feb. 6 New York State has begun looking toward the acquisition of Peebles Island, one of the largest islands in the Hudson still privately owned, in negotiations that have sparked a new interest in all the islands of the river, focused on a controversy over squatters' rights and raised questions about tax revenue.

title: Aircraft Belt Rule Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Pilots and passengers of light aircraft would have to wear shoulder harnesses and seat belts for takeoffs and landings under a rule proposed today by the Federal Aviation Administration. In a notice of the proposed rule in the Federal Register, the agency said it would receive comment on the planned regulation until April 30. No date was set for the proposed rule to go into effect.

title: Berry, Parker and Schmidt Honored
description: Two of the Baltimore Colts' brightest stars, Raymond Berry and Jim Parker, plus Detroit's angry linebacker, Joe Schmidt, were named yesterday to pro football's Hall of Fame.

title: Fanny May Average Yield Of 7.711% Set on Mortgages
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (Reuters)  The average yield on fourmonth commitments to purchase Federal Housing Administration  Veterans Administration mortgages was 7.711 per cent at today's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association said today. This was up from 7.695 per cent at the previous auction on Jan. 23.

title: Meskill's New Budget Calls for Tax Cut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 6Gov. Thomas J. Meskill presented to the General Assembly tonight a $1.26billion budget that would require tax reform, reduced taxes and a more moderate increase in spending than in recent years.

title: Minesweepers Begin Preparatory Work Off Haiphong
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Defense Department announced today that four United States Navy minesweepers had been ordered to begin clearing an anchorage on the approaches to Haiphong Harbor as a preliminary step toward destroying hundreds of mines that have blocked North Vietnamese ports for nine months.

title: PRICES OF BONDS SNOW DECLINES
description: Bond prices fell early yesterday under the impact of the latest disturbances in the foreignexchange market but regained some of its losses to finish the session with only a small overall decline.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Tomorrow, Feb. 8

title: Honest Wrestling: A Gentle Giant
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 6The last honest wrestling match seen through these bifocals pitted Jock Sutherland, then coach of the Pittsburgh Steelers, against Stanley Woodward, then sports editor of The New York Herald Tribune, in the Pittsburgh home of Frank Souchak, a star end on Sutherland's 1937 University of Pittsburgh team. Stonley, Jock said, I don't suppose you would care to wrostle. Stanley was fresh from a bout with pneumonia, but he never could resist a challenge. He removed his glasses, which left him sightless, and they stripped to the waist. They assumed the positionright hands clasped, left behind the other's neck. Stanley lunged for a headlock and missed. Jock was on top when a quarterton of gristle hit the tiles with a horrid splat! Everybody had one more drink.

title: 17 Killed as Fire Sweeps Through School in Paris
description: PARIS, Wednesday, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Fifteen children and two adults were killed in a fire that swept through a school in northeastern Paris last night.

title: Annual Ceiling Is Proposed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A special committee of senior members of Congress agreed in principle today to a major reform in the way Congress deals with Government spending, ineluding a ceiling every year on total spending that would apply to Congress itself.

title: Knicks Fall to Lakers
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, who have been picking up steam lately in defending the National Basketball Association championship, extended a winning streak and shattered one for the New York Knicks last night as they scored a 9590 victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: TV: Rrloir's Carola
description: A great movie director, Jean Renoir, has dusted off his unproduced, play, Carola, for the Hollywood Television Theater. Costarring Leslie Caron and Mel Ferrer, this curiously awkward and longwinded enterprise was shown Monday and last night over WNET/Channel 13, running for two hours.

title: Institute on Aging Urged
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri, today introduced a bill to establish a National Institute on Aging for expansion of biological and behavioral research in the aging process. President Nixon vetoed a similar bill last fall.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 6Seven years ago the center of his life moved from the basketball court to the classroom. Despite his absence from the game, Prof. Dick Holub of tht Fairleigh Dickinson University English Department, hasn't forgotten the sport that meant so much to him for four decades.

title: Hearing Scheduled In Gulf & Western And A. & P. Suits
description: The fight between Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., and the Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company over a tender offer for shares of the latter will move to Federal court here Friday.

title: Issac Bashevis Singer's Mirror Staged at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN  Isaac Bashevis Singer's The Mirror, Which is now playing in repertory, at the Yale Repertory Theater, is an, erotic and moral fable dramatizing, among other things, the dangers of fulfilling daydreams.

title: Dallas Franchise Is Sold
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 6 (UPI) A New Jersey corporation acquired the Dallas Chaparrals American Basketball Association franchise today and will move the team to Jersey City.

title: Poverty Program Backers To Lobby at Capitol Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6More than 4,000 people, mostly from the New York area, are scheduled to converge on Capitol Hill tomorrow in a demonstration of support for the antipoverty programs that are threatened by President Nixon's budget cuts.

title: Notes on People
description: The former President of Argentina, Juan D. Pern, arrived in Bucharest, after a flight from Rome. The purpose of 77yearold Mr. Pern in going to Rumania was not clear, however. A dispatch from Rome said he would visit the Otopeni Sanatorium, a geriatric clinic near Bucharest. But a Pern spokesman in Rome denied that the aging former President would undergo treatment at the clinic. In Bucharest, the Government news agency, Agerpress, said Mr. Pern was visiting at the invitation of the Rumanian Institute for Cultural Relations. And back in Rome, Pern aides said that, after Rumania, their man would visit China.

title: Johnson and Truman Hailed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) The House spent more than an hour today eulogizing the late President Lyndon B. Johnson. The Senate paid formal tribute to the late President Harry S. Truman.

title: Chemical Spill Kills Fish
description: DOWNINGTON, Pa., Feb. 6 (UPI) Environmental Protection Agency officials said today that a chemical spill after the derailment of a Penn Central tank car had killed fish and plant life along a threemile stretch of Brandywine Creek. The spill gave off a noxious yellow cloud that forced evacuation yesterday of 1,500 res

title: BONN BUYS AGAIN TO ASSIST DOLLAR
description: BONN, Feb. 6Another wave of dollars struck the West German foreignexchange markets today, compelling the Bundesbank in Frankfurt to intercede with purchases of $1.3billion of United States currency.

title: Bridge: Playing Even for Tiny Stakes Can Result in Fine in Britain
description: Some two years ago a small West Coast club whose patrons played duplicate games, plus occasional rubber bridge for a minuscule stake, was harassed by the local police. The resultant prosecution for illegal gambling was successfully defended with the help of expert proof that bridge is a game of skill.

title: PhasedOut Stabilizers
description: The fate of most wageprice stabilizers is to slink out of office, reviled and unmourned. Even in wartime, the dislocations and red tape attendant on economic regulation often make the administrators of the control program seem public enemies, rather than heroes.

title: Continental Telephone Raises Its Profits to Peaks
description: The Continental Telephone Corporation reported yesterday that it had closed out 1972 with its highest quarterly results. This helped produce new highs in revenues, sales an earnings for the full year.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Wide Spending Reforms Urged in Congress Study

title: Stennis Has Surgery
description: Senator John C. Stennis, who was shot a week ago in a holdup, underwent emergency surgery yesterday for internal complications. His condition was described as grave at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Page 44.

title: GAMBLING INQUIRY COSTS COACH JOB
description: NORMAN, Okia., Feb. 6 (UPI) The University of Oklahoma announced today it had requested and received the resignation of an assistant football coach, Joe Granato, because of Granato's association with a Federal gambling investigation.

title: CITY CHALLENGES CLEANAIR STAND
description: Fred C. Hart, the city's Commissioner of Air Resources, and his predecessor, Robert N. Rickles, yesterday challenged the view of state environmental officials on the city's ability to meet cleanair standards by 1975. But they differed on how to meet the standards.

title: City Council Committee, Led by Troy, Asserts Its Leadership on the Budget
description: Under its new chairman, Matthew J. Troy Jr., the City Council's Finance Committee served notice yesterday on the Lindsay administration and the Board of Estimate that it expected to take the lead in the budgetmaking process.

title: Fleet's Role Seen Unchanged
description: MANILA, Feb. 6 The commander of the Seventh Fleet said today that the role of the fleet would not change basically despite the Vietnam ceasefire. It will maintain the balance of power, said the fleet commander, Vice Adm. James L. Holloway 3d, in a talk with the press on the guidedmissile cruiser Oklahoma City, which is visiting here.

title: DR. H. HUDNALL WARE JR.
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 6 (AP)Dr. H. Hudnall Ware Jr., chairman of the obstetrics and gynecology department at the Medical College of Virginia from 1942 to 1967, died today at his home. He was 74 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: COLUMBIA, S. C.Tomorrow is the fifth anniversary of the Orangeburg massacre in which three black students were slain by South Carolina highway patrolmen who fired buckshot from shotguns.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP)The Agriculture Department said today that the commodity operation of the San Francisco brokerage firm of Dean Witter & Co., Inc., has been put on a threeyear probation for violating a Federal rule requiring segregation of customer accounts.

title: ERVIN VOWS JUSTICE IN WATERGATE CASE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. of North Carolina, who has been chosen by Senate Democrats to head an investigation into all aspects of the Watergate case, promised today that he would conduct the inquiry without partisan considerations.

title: U.S. MONEY MOVE CALLED POSSIBLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Two members of President Nixon's Council of Economic Advisers left open today the possibility of action by the United States to cure the continuing big deficit in its balance of international payments unless international solutions were agreed upon. However, they did not imply that any action would be taken soon.

title: Concorde: Profit Is Not the Sole Question
description: Has the Concorde supersonic airliner, so often threatened with cancellation, finally come to the end of the line?

title: Aetna to Offer Management Of Institutional Investments
description: The formation of an investmeet management service for institutional investors, such as pension plans, foundations and endowment funds, was announced yesterday by Aetna Life and Casualty Company of Hartford.

title: Hanoi May Release P.O.W.'s Saturday
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 7 The first United States prisoners of war May be released on Saturday In Hanoi, the chairman of the International Commission of Control and Supervision said yesterday.

title: Rockefeller Sees Billions Saved By Plan for Uniform Pensions
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6  Governor Rockefeller urged the Legislature today to approve a uniform retirement plan for new public employes that has been proposed by a state pension commission.

title: D.A.'s Assail Rockefeller Drug Penalties
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The New York State District Attorneys Association today opposed Governor Rockefeller's proposed penalties for traffickers in hard drugs and proposed its own plan to crack down on narcotics pushers.

title: Much Ado of TV Dooms Stage Version
description: Much Ado About Nothing, the brash modernist adaptation of Shakespeare's comely hailed recently as a sign of new life on Broadway, will close Sunday, partly because its critically acclaimed production on television has caused a boxoffice slump.

title: Winged Fairway, $11.40, Wins By Head in Liberty Bell Finale
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6The 67day fallwinter meeting at Liberty Bell race track ended on a winning note today for Joseph E. Cranmer's Winged Fairway as he raced to a head victory in the featured $15,000 Tollgate Purse.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: Neva Summary and Index, Page 41

title: 2 PRIMARY DATES ARE SET FOR CITY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6New York City voters will go to the polls in two primaries this springon May 31 to vote for candidates for Mayor, City Council President and Controller and on June 28 to vote for other local and some state officials, and in any runoff contests resulting from the first primary.

title: BONN BUYS AGAIN TO ASSIST DOLLAR
description: BONN, Feb. 6Another wave of dollars struck the West German foreignexchange markets today, compelling the Bundesbank in Frankfurt to intercede with purchases of $1.3billion of United States currency.

title: 6 MEN ARE ARRESTED IN I.R.S. BRIBE CASES
description: A lawyer, two certified public accountants and three corporate officers were arrested yesterday on charges of having bribed Internal Revenue Service agents in three separate incidents with payments totaling $16,500.

title: MAILER CLARIFIES HIS: FIFTH ESTATE
description: Norman Mailer clarified yesterday what he meant by The Fifth Estate, an organization whose formation he had announced at his 50thbirthday party Monday night.

title: MRS. GEORGE HAYWARD
description: HOBE SOUND, Fla., Feb. 6Mrs. Jane Haggerson Hayward, daughter of the late Fred H. Haggerson, former president and chairman of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, died apparently of a stroke at her home here yesterday. She was 56 years old and lived also in Wytheville, Va.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Acting Gov. Alfred N. Beadleston asked yesterday for Federal aid from the Small Business Administration for flooddamaged homes and business in Bergen, Mercer, Morris and Passaic Counties. Mr. Beadleston said in a telegrani to the S.B.A. office in Newark that torrential rains in parts of central and nothern New Jersey on Feb. 2 caused extensive damage to 400 to 500 residences and business establishments.

title: THE NEW YORK TIMES, WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1973
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6They are of the same generation and both are professionals, one a soldier, the other a lawyer, and for two days now they have been at each other as fiercely as two men wrestling in a pit. Only the pit is a courtroom.

title: Cairo: Chance for an Accord To Reopen Suez Judged Nil
description: CAIRO, Feb. 6  Seen from Cairo the outlook for the diplomatic season is grim. It may be summed up like this:

title: I.B.M. Computer Memory Employs Bubble Technique
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday demonstrated a new computer memory based on magnetic bubble technology.

title: Nixon Assures Hussein of Continued U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 President Nixon assured King. Hussein of Jordan today of continuing economic and military aid as the two leaders reviewed efforts to achieve a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: RECEIVERSHIP ASKED FOR CONTROLS CORP.
description: A petition for receivership was filed here yesterday in United States District Court on behalf of the International Controls Corporation, a New Jersey electronics company controlled by Robert L. Vesco, its former board chairman. A hearing on the petition is scheduled for today.

title: F.T.C. Nominee Supported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee approved unanimously today President Nixon's nomination of Lewis A. Engman to the new head of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Sassy, 61Foot Sloop, Favored In Southern Ocean Race Today
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 6Sassy, the overall winner of the first event in the Southern Ocean Racing Conferenefrom St. Petersburg to Venice, Fla.became the yacht to beat as the second of the sixrace series was set to begin tomorrow.

title: Bright A.B.C. Show for Children
description: The American Broadcasting Company's monthly Afterschool series for youngsters has another bright package today at 4:30 P.M. Here again is tasty, sturdy homeviewing for children. Adults could do much worse.

title: Corona Parole Hearing In 7 Years a Possibility
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) Juan V. Corona, convicted in the nation's biggest mass murder case, can be considered for parole after seven years even though he has been sentenced to 25 consecutive life terms in prison, state officials said today.

title: Fyodor Lopukhov, Who Guided Russian Ballet's Growth, Dies
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6Fyodor V. Lopukhov, one of the foremost figures in Russian ballet, died last week in Leningrad, it was announced today. He was 86 years old.

title: Education Aide Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Joseph P. Cosand has submitted his resignation as Deputy Commissioner for Higher Education, the Office of Education announced today. Mr. Cosand, whose resignation becomes effective Feb. 16, said he was leaving for personal and professional reasons.

title: BALANCE OF TRADE FOR ITALY IN RED
description: ROME, Feb. 6Italy's trade balance is still in the red, almost exclusively because of a staggering domestic demand for imports of food, especially meat.

title: The Peace Conference
description: Eight years to the day after the United States opened its devastating bombardment of North Vietnam, the warring parties have announced agreement to convene the Vietnam peace conference. Starting Feb. 26 in Paris, diplomats of the Soviet Union, China and the United States will sit down with representatives of the Vietnamese combatants, plus Britain, France and the four nations supervising the ceasefire. This diplomatic assemblage will stand as the first test of greatpower responsibility in the postVietnam war era.

title: JULIUS WEINER
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N. Y., Feb. 6Julius Weiner, a lawyer and former owner of the White Roe Lake Hotel here and the Plymouth Hotel in Miami Beach, Fla., died today apparently of a heart attack, in the Liberty Community General Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived here.

title: ME IS FACING A MIDNIGHT STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The troubled Penn Central Railroad is faced with the likelihood of a new strike starting at 12:01 A.M. Thursday, officials of the company, the union and Government warned today.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED FOR WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spat primary prices for the week ended Jan. 30.

title: Bridget Loves Bernie Attacked by Jewish Groups
description: Bridget Loves Bernie, the runaway new show hit of the current television season, has come under heavy fire from some Jewish groups, who charge it mocks the teachings of Judaism and presents intermarriage between Jews and Christians as a desirable end.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SET RECORD PRICE
description: Eager speculators pushed prices of soybean futures to another record yesterday, again up the 10centaday limit per bushel.

title: GAMBLING INQUIRY COSTS COACH JOB
description: NORMAN, Okla., Feb. 6 (UPI) The University of Oklahoma announced today it had requested and received the resignation of an assistant football coach, Joe Granato, because of Granato's association with a Federal gambling investigation.

title: MANDATE ADDED TO NOFAULT BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The Republican majority's modified no fault insurance bill was repprted out of committee this evening after sponsors aimed to shore it against criticism by requiring that all premiums be reduced.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor four triangles to none.)

title: SAINTS TRIUMFH OVER RAIDERS, 54
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 6 (AP)Bill Klatt and Wayne Connelly fired in two goals apiece as the Minnesota Fighting. Saints nipped the New York Raiders, 54, in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

title: Austin Returns to Redskins As Assistant Coach to Allen
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UN) George Allen today hired Bill Austin, the man he replaced two years ago as head coach of the Washington Redskins, to be an assistant in charge of the offensive line.

title: Advertising: N.A.R.B. Challenge
description: Benny L. Kass, the public interest lawyer who is fast becoming the gadflymember of the National Advertising Review Board, is asking that guidelines be established regarding the business relationships of its public members.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Under its new chairman, Matthew J. Troy Jr. the City Council's Finance Committee served notice on the Lindsay administration and the Board of Estimate yesterday that it would take the lead in the budgetmaking process.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Vietnam's Joy in Victory
description: WASHINGTONRecently I met with Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh. My only disappointment was that every American could not share in the joy of Vietnam's victory. By any standards, it is incredible.

title: Sassy, 61Foot Sloop, Favored In Southern Ocean Race Today
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 6Sassy, the overall winner of the first event in the Southern Ocean Racing Conferenefrom St. Petersburg to Venice, Fla.became the yacht to beat as the second of the sixrace series was set to begin tomorrow.

title: Berry, Parker and Schmidt Honored
description: Two of the Baltimore Colts' brightest stars, Raymond Berry and Jim Parker, plus Detroit's angry linebacker, Joe Schmidt, were named yesterday to pro football's Hall of Fame.

title: Safeway Stores Posts Net and Sales High
Guest's Calling Card Might Be a Pot of Soup
description: DARIEN, Conn.  You feel funny the first time you come to someone's home carrying part of the meal in your hands, said Robert Emerson, who moved here from Manhattan eight months ago.

title: Downgrading Science
description: Many of the major problems President Nixon faces dailyon matters of defense, environmental pollution, medical policy and the likehave important scientific and technical components. The extent to which expertise in technology is indispensable to governmental decisionmaking in these fields makes it surprising that the President now has chosen to lessen the role of science and scientists in his Administration. He has abolished the Office of Science and Technology and moved chief responsibility to a secondlevel agency, the National Science Foundation.

title: Theater: Shelter, Musical, Arrives
description: SHELTER, a musical. Book and lyrics by Gretchen Cryer; music by Nancy Ford; settings, costumes and prolectiens by Tony Walton; lighting and projections by Richard Pilbrow; orchestrations and electronic arrangements by Thomas Pierson; music direction and vocal arrangements by Kirk Nurock; musical staging by Sammy Bayes; directed by Austin Pendleton; production manager, John Actman. Presented by Richard Fields and Peter Flood; associate producer, Julie Hughes. At the John Golden Theater, 252 West 45 Street.

title: 2 PRIMARY DATES ARE SET FOR CITY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6New York City voters will go to the polls in two primaries this springon May 31 to vote for candidates for Mayor, City Council President and Controller and on June 28 to vote for other local and some state officials, and in any runoff contests resulting from the first primary.

title: JAZZ SERIES PILOT LIFTS FANS' HOPES
description: A projected series of monthly jazz concerts at the Theater de Lys got off to a promising start Monday night before friendly, attentive audience that more than filled the small theater.

title: Barry Bingham Honored
description: LAWRENCE, Kan., Feb. 6 (AP)The William Allen White Foundation of the University of Kansas announced the selection today of Barry Bingham of The Louisville (Ky.) CourierJournal and Times to receive its 1973 medallion here Saturday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 6 (UPI)National Collegiate collegedivision football teams have set up a national plaxoff system for 1973. But a spokesman said he did, not envision any pressure on major colleges to follow suit. I have a hunch they'd like to run their programs and let us run ours, said Ed Sherman, the N.C.A,A. spokesman.

title: Posthumous Tale: A Man Who Cared
description: Arthur Rubinow, who died a public death last Saturday evening when he was shot on a subway platform by a man he had admonished for bothering a woman passenger, was mourned yesterday, quietly and privately, the way he had lived.

title: A.M.A. CRITICIZED ON DRUGS POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6  A former chairman of the American Medical Association's Council on Drugs told a Senate subcommittee today that the council was disbanded last fall to appease the drug industry.

title: Blue Bell Sets Changes To Utilize Younger Men
description: Blue Bell, Inc., one of the country's largest makers of sports and Western wear, yesterday realigned its top management in an effort to begin an orderly transfer of duties to younger men. L. Kimsey Mann, executive vice president, was named president, to succeed Roger S. LeMatty, who becomes vicechairman.

title: Oppenheimer Will Enter Insurance Field
description: Oppenheimer & Co. disclosed yesterday that it would enter the life insurance business.

title: One Reported Dead, Many Hurt in Fire In Boston Subway
description: BOSTON, Feb. 6 (AP)One man died and 94 persons were injured today in a flash fire that broke out in a fourcar subway train crowded with commuters bound for home.

title: 3 BANKS RESCIND LOANRATE RISES UNDER PRESSURE
description: Under heavy pressure, from the Administration, three major banks reduced yesterday their prime lending rates to 6 per cent, thus rescinding the quarterpoint increases they posted on Monday.

title: A Debt Of Honor
description: After the return of the prisoners from Vietnam, after all the consoling ceremonies at the White House, and the family reunions and tears on television, the reality for the prisoners coining home at last will begin in private. When they come home from Vietnam, what will they find?

title: Picketing Is Planned At the White House By Peace Coalition
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The National Peace Action Coalition announced today plans to picket the White House on Feb. 24 in protest of what they called continued United States involvement in Southeast Asia.

title: Washington: Some Optimism But No Plan for an Initiative
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Nixon Administration officials believe that the prospects for resolving the current nowar nopeace situation in the Middle East have improved with the Vietnam ceasefire agreement, but for the moment they plan no major new initiative to bring the Arabs and Israelis closer together. As King Hussein of Jordan begins his visit to Washington, officials say that although President Nixon has declared that the Middle. East will get a very high priority this year, the White Housepreoccupied with Indochinahas not yet had time to focus its full attention on that part of the world.

title: 72,000 COMMUTERS FACE TIEUP HERE
description: A strike against the Penn Central Railroad, scheduled for 12:01 A.M. tomorrow, would strand 72,000 commuters in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, and cause new inconveniences for 90,000 Long Island Rail Road riders because the strike would close. Penn Station.

title: South African Blacks Held
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Feb. 6 (Reuters)Policemen carrying nightsticks charged a group of black strikers today in the first direct response by authorities to mounting industrial strikes and demonstrations by blacks. Dozens of policemen arrested some 200 blacks who had marched in a demonstration for higher wages.

title: White House Aide Termed A LiddySegretti Contact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6At least one White House official knew of and initially aided the political intelligence operations led by G. Gordon Liddy and E. Howard Hunt Jr. as early as February, 1972, four months before the Watergate arrests, according to Government sources.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
description: Cloudy to partly cloudy skies are expected over the Northeast today; light snow or flurries may develop in portions of New England. Snow is forecast from the middle Mississippi Valley to the Rockies, changing or mixing with rain over Kansas and Missouri. Sunny skies will spread from the South Atlantic States to Texas, and from the northern plateau region and great basin to the coast of the Pacific Northwest. Scattered showers will cover the central Pacific Coast. Colder weather will occur from the upper Mississippi Valley to the central Rockies, while elsewhere, no major temperature changes are anticipated.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: WOE MULTIPLYING FOR XRATED FILM
description: PATERSON, Feb. 6  Under fire from the Passaic County Prosecutor's office and under investigation by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey, the Xrated film Deep Sleep has also run afoul of the F.B.I. in Oklahoma and the Oklahoma City police vice squad.

title: Bibb Takes Buying Option
description: The Bibb Company, textile manufacturer, has taken a twoyear option to purchase Inwood Knitting Mills, a maker of doublcknit fabrics owned since 1969 by the National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. Bibb, which will purchase Inwood at National's book value at the time of exercising the option, will in the interim assume management of Inwood.

title: CAIRO, ILL., FOUND BADLY POLARIZED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The United States Civil Rights Commission has found widespread discrimination against blacks in Cairo, Ill., and a breakdown of law and justice.

title: MAILER CLARIFIES HIS FIFTH ESTATE
description: Norman Mailer clarified yesterday what he meant by The Fifth Estate, an organization whose formation he had announced at his 50thbirthday party Monday night.

title: NICHOLAS P. FIERRO
description: PATERSON, N. J., Feb. 6 (UPI)Nicholas P. Fierro, the newly appointed director of the city's Civil Defense disaster control unit, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack yesterday. He was 55 years old.

title: Japan Communists Assailed
description: TOKYO, Feb. 6The leader of Japan's Socialist party deivered a sharp attack on the Japanese Communist party as the Socialists opened their annual convention today in Tokyo. Tomomi Narita, chairman of the Socialist party, the largest opposition group, said that the Communists were making slanderous accusations against his party.

title: Connecticut Police Arrest Mother of Unattended Child
description: WESTBROOK, Conn., Feb. (UPI)The state police arrested a Hartford mother after they said they had found her 18monthold son unattended in an auto early today.

title: Businessman Indicted in Sales to PX's
description: A businessman who had sales of $140million a year to military post exchanges was indicted here yesterday on charge of conspiracy to defraud the United States of $50,000 on a contract in Saigon.

title: 25,000 Welfare Families In Projects Get Rent Cuts
description: Rents for more than 25,000 welfare families living in public housing here will be reduced by an average of $40 a month beginning June 1 because of new Federal subsidy payments to the city's Housing Authority.

title: GLAMOUR STOCKS LEAD A RECOVERY
description: A bounce in the glamour issues and a gain in the popular averages finally showed up yesterday on Wall Street, breaking a dreary string of market declines.

title: Garment Leaders Sign Contract At City Hall as Mayor Applauds
description: Pilferage, which has long plagued the garment industry, hai been cut sharply by the program of greater security worked out by the industry and the Police Department, that included more policemen, more volunteers and better street lighting.

title: White House Aide Termed A LiddySegretti Contact
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6At least one White House official knew of and initially aided the political intelligence operations led by G. Gordon Liddy and E. Howard Hunt Jr. as early as February, 1972, four months before the Watergate arrests, according to Government sources.

title: People and Business
description: Two Cabinet officials in the first Nixon Administration took assignments yesterday in the aviation industry, one with a carrier and the other with a manufacturer.

title: BELFAST BRACES FOR STRIKE TODAY
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 6  With violence continuing, Belfast braced itself for a strike tomorrow called by militant Protestant organizations in protest over the first use of emergency powers against suspected Protestant terrorists.

title: Democratic Delegation Elects Delaney as Head
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 Democratic Representatives from New York filled their leadership vacuum in an amicable manner today by naming Representative James J. Delaney of Queens general chairman of the delegation and giving leadership roles to other members.

title: New U.S. Atomic Energy Chief
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 The new chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission is a 58yearold marine biologist, Dixy Lee Ray, who brings two dogs to the office every day, is an honorary member of an Indian tribe, lives in a mobile home and is the first woman to head the cornmission. Dr. Ray, a short woman with short gray hair, a ready smile and determinedor stubbornconvictions, is the third woman to head a Federal regulatory agency.

title: 4 ON WRITING STAFF PROMOTED BY NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6President Nixon is upgrading the jobs of four members of his research and writing staff and changing the name of their office to the White House Editorial Department.

title: 25,000 Welfare Families In Projects Get Rent Cuts
description: Rents for more than 25,000 welfare families living in public housing here will be reduced by an average of $40 a month beginning June 1 because of new Federal subsidy payments to the city's Housing Authority.

title: Cambodian Says Army Is Modernizing but Still Needs U.S. Help
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 4Cambodia's Chief of Staff, who is charged with the task of reorganizing the nation's armed forces, predicts that by the end of the year we can say we are going to have a modern army.

title: VICTOR ROSEN, 61, PSYCHIATRIST, DIES
description: Dr. Victor H. Rosen, clinical professor of psychiatry at. Yale University and a past president of the American Psychoanalytic Association, died Monday at his home on Cedar Swamp Road, Deep River, Conn., where he had been ill with pneumonia and phlebitis. He was 61 years old.

title: Waldheim, in India, Is Hopeful Of Settlement on Subcontinent
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations said here today, on the eve of his departure for Pakistan after his talks with Indian leaders, that there was a lgood chance of achieving peace in the subcontinent.

title: KAHANE, 3 OTHERS INDICTED BY ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 6  Rabbi Meir Kahane, leader of the Jewish Defense League, and three others were indicted here today in connection with an alleged attempt to smuggle arms abroad for an antiArab guerrilla campaign.

title: Scientists, Citing Hazards, Urge Cut in Reactor Operating Levels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Federation of American Scientists, warning that an accident at a nuclear power station could mean death to tens of thousands of people, urged the Government today to require cutbacks in the reactors' operating levels.

title: Kenny Is Paroled; Ill Health Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 John V. Kenny, a former mayor of Jersey City and Democratic leader of Hudson County who was sentenced to prison last May for Federal income tax evasion, was granted parole today after serving less than half of his 18month sentence.

title: Cleveland Quartet Fulfilling Promise Of Its Beginnings
description: If happy marriages are made in heaven, on what transcendental plane must successful string quartets be manufactured? A higher one, certainly, considering the doubled problems in bringing and keeping together a compatible foursome of gifted, trained and sensitive musicians. No wonder 99 per cent of quartet alliances (that's a rough estimate) end in divorce or trail off into dull routine.

title: NEW SOVIET MOVE MADE IN VIENNA
description: VIENNA, Feb. 6With EastA Test talks on force reductions n Central Europe still stalled sere, the Soviet Union introluced a new issue today by proposing that Hungary's paricipation be restricted to that if a nonvoting member.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PLAYBACK The Performers Committee for Twentieth Century Music convened first in 1967, determined to introduce the public to contemporary music. It has worked out a retrospective formatone performance to one composerwith each concert to give a working profile of what the composer accomplished.

title: Patricia Kendall, 72, Dies; Writer on Customs of India
description: Mrs. Patricia Kendall Hurd, widow of George F. Hurd, a lawyer here, died Saturday at her home, 67 Park Avenue. She was 72 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Pension Reform Bill: A Sham

title: U.S. STEPPING UP ATTEMPT TO GAIN LAOS CEASEFIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The White House today announced a further effort to achieve ceasefire in Laos and plans for an international conference that will try to solidify last month's Vietnam ceasefire.

title: Deal on Israeli Steel Plant Includes American Group
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 6 (AP)Two West German concerns and an American investment group have bought a half interest in Steel City, a plant that produces 40 per cent of Israel's building rods and bars, Koor Industries reported today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Nixon Aide Opposes Tax Reform to Raise Revenue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6A high official of the Nixon Administration told Congress today that the Administration opposed using tax reform or loopholeclosing as a means of raising revenue to permit the continuance of domestic programs reduced or eliminated in the President's budget.

title: Music: The Clevelanders
description: THE CLEVELAND ORCHESTRA, Rudolf Serkin, piano. Conducted by Claudio Abbado. At Carnegie Hall.

title: Official Upholds Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The new Deputy Attorney General, Joseph T. Sneed, told members of Congress today that President Nixon had an implied constitutional right to refuse to spend money as Congress directed.

title: Bronx Youth Held in Rape Of a Girl in Clinton High
description: A 16yearold youth was arrested yesterday on charges of having raped an 18yearold college girl whom he allegedly forced into DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

title: A Drive in Congress Links Trade to Soviet Exit Tax
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Representative Wilbur D. Mills has decided to use his power as Chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee to block any liberalization of trade with the Soviet Union unless Moscow rescinds it exit fees and freely allows Jews and others to emigrate, a Congressional source said today.

title: Nixon Aides Press Bill to Harness Land Development
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The Nixon Administration urged quick passage today of a bill to harness runaway land development and thus deal with the number one environmental priority facing the nation.

title: People in Sports: Jet Coach Goes
description: The New York Jets lost a coach yesterday when Ken Meyer, who headed the receivers' unit, said he was joining the Los Angeles Rams as offensive coordinator. Meyer, who spent four years with the Jets, will renew a working relationship with Chuck Knox, the new head coach of the Rams, that began 15 years ago at Wake Forest.

title: A NearRun Thing In France
description: Next month's French elections are enormously important to Western Europe and, conceivably, to that vital area's relationships with the United States. France, after all, is at the geographical heart of the region joined in a Common Market and allied with North America.

title: ST. JOE MINERALS RAISES LEAD PRICE
description: Faced with strong demand and limited smelting capacity, the St. Joe Minerals Corporation announced yesterday that it had increased its quoted lead price by half a cent to 15.5 cents a pound.

title: WHITE HOUSE GOT TIP ON WATERGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The White House was alerted within hours of the Watergate burglary to links between one of its consultants and two of the men arrested in the June 17 breakin, it was disclosed today.

title: MANDATE ADDED TO NOFAULT BILL
description: ALBANY, Feb. 6The Republican majority's modified ?? fault insurance bill was reported out of committee the evening after sponsors aimed to shore it against criticism by requiring that all premiums be reduced.

title: Madison Mall Test Put Off Till July (After Primaries) I
description: The oftdelayed and controversial test of a trafficfree Madison Avenue Mall between 44th and 57th Streets has been postponed once more by Mayor Lindsay, and some proponents fear that the longplanned project is dead.

title: Korea Bus Accidents Kill 11
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 6 (UPI) At least 11 persons were killed in two separate bus accidents today. A bus with about 80 persons aboard plunged into a valley from a narrow countryside road about 65 miles south of Seoul, The police reported that seven persons were confirmed killed and 59 injured, many seriously. In the other accident, four persons were killed and 16 injured when a bus careened off the road near Taegu, about 150 mile southeast of Seoul.

title: Rampal Partnered By VeyronLacroix In Delightful Music
description: More than a century ago, Niccolo Paganini had to publish a letter in the newspapers to prove that his violinistic perfection was not due to his being the devil's offspring. Had JeanPierre Rampal lived in those days, his ad would probably have been in the next edition.

title: STENNIS WEAKER AFTER OPERATION
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, underwent emergency surgery early today for internal injuries suffered in a shooting during a holdup in front of his home here a week ago. Doctors said that his prospects for recovery had deteriorated.

title: U.S STEPPING UP ATTEMPT TO GAIN LAOS CEASEFIRE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The White House today announced a further effort to achieve a ceasefire in Laos and plans for an international conference that will try to solidify last month's Vietnam ceasefire.

title: MRS. GANDHI HITS U.S. POLICY IN ASIA
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 6Prime Minister Indira Gandhi bitterly attacked American policy in Asia today, despite quiet diplomatic efforts in recent weeks to soothe the strained and chilly relations between India and the United States.

title: FASHION TALK
description: It was a throwback to a more gracious era. Pretty clothes on the runway (Arnold Scaasi's spring madetoorder collection). Pleasant lunch Ichicken crepes and popovers, with blue, white and yellow chrysanthemums centered on the yellow tablelinen). And more than 400 casually but carefully dressed women to enjoy it all for $20 a ticket.

title: Official Upholds Nixon By JAMES M. NAUGHTON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The new Deputy Attorney General, Joseph T. Sneed, told members of Congress today that Presidention, had an implied constittifnal right to refuse to spend money as Congress directed.

title: Nixon's Effort to Cut Spending Is Defended by Rockefeller Here
description: Governor Rockefeller defended President Nixon's efforts to cut spending yesterday, declaring he's got to live within his means, and suggested all elected candidates had overpromised and underdelivered.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT MAPLE LEAPS, 42
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 6The New York Islanders rewarded Earl Ingarfield, their coach of one week, with his first victory tonight by beating the Toronto Maple Leafs, 42, in the Nassau Coliseum.

title: CM Cheng Reel Quits Too Many Hurdles
description: CLAREMONT, Calif., Feb. 6 (UPI)Mrs. Chi Cheng Reel, who planned to enter her first hurdles race since a major operation last year, withdrew today from the 14th annual Times indoor track meet at the Forum Friday night because of criticism by another hurdler.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 41

title: Hogan Will Press Only 5 of 77 Charges Against Last 2 Indicted in Tombs Riot
description: Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said yesterday that only five of 77, charges would be brought against the two remaining defendants accaged as ringleaders in the 1970 rebellion at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men.

title: Records
description: Curtis Mayfield is at present one of the hottest properties. He wrote the musical score for one of the most successful black action films, Superfly, and sales from the soundtrack album recorded by Mr. Mayfield are approaching two million around the world. Mr. Mayfield also had a hit single recording, Freddie's Dead, from the film.

title: Premier in Hanoi Insists on the Ultimate Reunification of Vietnam
description: The following dispatch, distributed by The. Associated Press, 4 by Louise Hickman Lione of The Philadelphia Inquirer, who has just completed a visit to Hanoi. Transmission was delayed bedtime of review by the North Vietnamese.

title: Kerner Acquittal Denied
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)Federal District Judge Robert L. Taylor declined today to order a jury to acquit Otto Kerner and Theodore J. Isaacs of charges in connection with racetrack stock transactions while Mr. Kerner was Governor of Illinois from 1960 to 1968.

title: Boycott at 5 Schools In Newark Goes On
description: NEWARK, Feb. 6  A boycott of Vailsburg High. School and four grammar schools by white students entered its second day today as the Board of Education and the City Council sought to cool tempers in a racially tense situation.

title: Dominican Patrol Battles Guerrillas; 4 Killed in Fighting
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Feb. 6 (UPI)An army patrol today spotted the guerrilla band that landed Sunday in the Dominican Republic and in an exchange of gunfire one of the group and three soldiers were killed.

title: Liquor Prices to Rise 8c a Fifth on March 1
description: Consumers in New York State will have to pay about 8 cents more for a fifth of whisky beginning March 1.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Local precinct commanders have been empowered to allow auxiliary police units to resume patrolling in uniform. The police department order, which took effect last night, rescinded an earlier directive requiring auxiliary policemen to wear civilian clothes to keep the unarmed patrols from becoming ambush targets.

title: Fire Opens the Way for Donohue
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6It took a $150,000 fire to resolve the hassle, but the net effect is that Mark Donohue is out of the Sports Car Club of America's L&M Championship for 1973, clearing the way for him to race anywhere on the championship circuit of the United States Auto Club. This will be good news for Pocono International Raceway in Pennsylvania, because for a while over the weekend it was evident that Donohue would not be permitted to run in USAC's 500mile race there on July 11 The prohibition at Pocono and other USAC tracks was the result of the rivalry between USAC and the S.C.C.A. for Donohue appearances.

title: Monetary Crisis Reflects World's Economic Splits
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, Feb. 6 The new monetary crisis involving heavy selling of the dollar reflects the fractured state of world economic relations. The major Western nations are trying to rebuild a monetary system that collapsed on Aug. 15; 1971, when President Nixon suspended the dollar's convertibility into gold. The huge American balanceofpayments and trading deficits and the relucof other countries take measures that would reduce their surpluses are among the destabilizing, forces at work. Surpluses mean jobs because exports provide work.

title: The Proceedings in the U. N. Today
Jerusalem: Deadlock Is Expected to Continue At Least Until Nixon and Brezhnev Confer
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 6In the opinion of Israeli Government officials, the current military and political deadlock in the Middle East is likely to continue essentially unchanged, at least until President Nixon and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party chief, confer in Washington later this year.

title: F.T.C. Nominee Supported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (UPI) The Senate Commerce Committee approved unanimously today President Nixon's nomination of Lewis A. Engman to the new head of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Insurance Chief Urges Buyers to Shop For Lowest Auto Coverage Premiums
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6  State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough said today that there were wide variations in rates being charged under the wageprotection provisions of nofault automobile insurance and offered this bit of advice to costconscious motorists: Shop around.

title: FiscalData Bill Loses in Committee Vote
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6Efforts to get a controversial bill on disclosing political campaign finances out of the Assembly Judiciary Committee failed by one vote this evening.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: Since Jan. 1, ten New York City policemen have been wounded and one has been killed. In most of these incidents, including the murder of Patrolman Stephen R. Gilroy, our men have been shot by people using highcaliber automatic rifles, or automatic pistols.

title: Canada's Total of Idle Is Up But Rate Shift Spurs Hope
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 6 (UPI)Canada's unemployment total climbed to its highest level in nearly 12 years in January, but statistics issued today indicated that the jobless trend actually showed an improvement.

title: Kansas State Five Victor
description: MANHATTAN, Kan., Feb, 6 (UPI)Ernie Kusnyer's layup and two free throws in the last 30 seconds carried Kansas State to a 7874 victory over Iowa State tonight in a hardfought Big Eight Conference game. The victory left the highranked Wildcats tied with Colorado for the conference lead with 51 records, The teams meet Saturday in Boulder.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 7, 1973

title: Books of The Times
description: THE TAKING OF PELHAM ONE TWO THREE. By John Godey. 316 pages. Putnam. $6.95.

title: Market Place: Retail Broker In 2d Career
description: Glance into the office of a retail brokerage office and note the relatively low level of activity. The sparse crowds and the lackadaisical attitude that prevail reflect a continuing lack of interest on the part of the individual investor.

title: State Inquiry Started On Prison Psychiatrist
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6Commissioner Robert L. Clifford and top officials of the State Department of Institutions and Agencies began an investigation here today into the circumstances surrounding the employment of Dr. William King, the staff psychiatrist at the state prison charged with plotting three murders.

title: BYRNE TAKES LEAD IN CHESS PLAYOFFS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)Robert Byrne scored the first victory in the threeway United States chess championship playoffs last night when Samuel Reshevsky, eight times the United States champion, resigned after 40 moves.

title: The Coast Guard at Work: A Day in the Life of an Icebreaker Crew on the Great Lakes
description: ABOARD THE ICEBREAKER MACKINAWFor Charles Faircloth, a father of three boys who lives in Cheboygan, Mich., it all began as another typical work day. He ate breakfast and left home in time for work at 8 A.M. But then the weather grew colder. And Micheline Faircloth, along with the wives of dozens of other Cheboygan men, began to suspect that their families would not be together for dinner that night. And perhaps for some time to come.

title: Laos Premier Confident Of Truce Within a Week
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 6Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, expressed confidence in an interview today that a ceasefire would be concluded here within one weekat the latest by Feb. 15despite the onset of a general Communist military offensive and an evident hardening of the Communist negotiating position.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: '73 Newport Fete to Be Bigger, Bolder
description: The first notes of anticipation for the 1973 Newport Jazz Festival in New York were sounded yesterday by George Wein, the festival's promoter, and they were big and bold and brassy.

title: CITY PAPERS BEGIN TALKS WITH UNION
description: The city's three major daily newspapers and Mailers Union No. 6 began formal negotiations yesterday for a new con tract to replace one scheduled to expire at midnight March 30.

title: Negro Ensemble Finds Hit Play Poses Problem
description: The Negro Ensemble Company is faced with a problem that is rare in the theaterwhat to do with a hit show.

title: WILLIAM ENGLISH JR. OF PRESBYTERY HERE
description: William H. English Jr., a former member of the executive committee of the Presbytery of New York City, who was president in 1933 and 1934 of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, died Monday In the Princeton (N. J.) Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived at 116 Hunt Drive in Princeton.

title: 3 BANKS RESCIND LOANRATE RISES UNDER PRESSURE
description: Under heavy pressure from the Administration, three major banks reduced yesterday their prime lending rates to 6 per cent, thus rescinding the quarterpoint increases they posted on Monday.

title: Democratic Chief To Delay Parley Until Late in 1974
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Robert Strauss, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, said today he would do everything he could to minimize the midterm convention planned for next yearprobably by postponing it until December, 1974, after key Congressional races and contests for Governor are over.

title: 2 Accused of Smuggling Saws to Tombs Escapers
description: The escape of seven prisoners from the Tombs last Octoberthe first successful breakout since the Manhattan House of Detention was built in 1941 was made possible by two women who smuggled hacksaw blades to an inmate, according to an indictment filed yesterday.

title: Stennis Has Surgery
description: Senator John C. Stennis, who was shot a week ago in a holdup, underwent emergency surgery, yesterday for internal complications. His condition was described as grave at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Page 44.

title: Amex Prices Fall as the Volume Risen
description: Increased selling in the last hour of trading caused prices yesterday to close mixed in the overthecounter market and slightly lower on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Record Earnings And Sales Posted By Goodyear Tire
description: Record earnings and sales for the fourth quarter and year ended Dec. 31 were reported yesterday by the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company.

title: Heart Month Proclaimed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) President Nixon yesterday proclaimed February as American Heart Month and called on al citizens to support programs to conquer cardiovascular diseases.

title: Meskill's New Budget Calls for Tax Cut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 6Gov. Thomas J. Meskill presented to the General Assembly tonight a $1.26billion budget that would require tax reform, reduced taxes and a more moderate increase in spending than in recent years.

title: New Books
description: Bertolt Brecht, Collected Plays: Volume 9, Adaptations, The Tutor, Coriolanus, The Trial of Joan of Arc at Rouen, 1431, Don Juan, Trumpets and Drums, edited by Ralph Manhelm and John Willett (Pantheon Books, $10).

title: Highs and Lows
description: TUESDAY, FEB. 6, 1973

title: 7 CHILDREN KILLED IN BUS HIT BY TRAIN
description: LITTLEFIELD, Tex., Feb. 6 (UPI)A freight train smashed into a rural school bus at a marked crossing today, killing seven children.

title: PENNSY IS FACING A MIDNIGHT STRIKE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6The troubled Penn Central Railroad is faced with the likelihood of a new strike starting at 12:01 A.M. Thursday, officials of the company, the union and Government warned today.

title: Hearing on Energy Crisis Stirs Environmental Rift
description: TRENTON, Feb. 6  Spokesmen for environmental interests and for the fuel industries lashed here today in placing the blame and offering solutions for the socalled national energy crisis.

title: U.S. Forces Leaving At Rate of 400 a Day
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 6 (UPI)  American troops are leaving South Vietnam at a rate of more than 400 a day, the United States command said today. There were 19,500 in the country as of Sunday, the lowest number since September, 1964.

title: Australia to Begin Negotiations To Establish Ties With Hanoi
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 6Prime Minister Gough Whitlam announced today that Australia plans to begin negotiations for establishment of diplomatic relations with North Vietnam next week.

title: Neckties for Russian Men Mean Sacrifice for Women
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 6Men's neckties lately have been getting priority over women's undergarments from economic planners and Komsomolskaya Pravda is worried about it.

title: New Dollar Crisis
description: What at first seemed a minor flurry over the weakness of the Italian lira blew up into a fullfledged monetary storm yesterday, as waves of selling buffeted the dollar.

title: Navy Adds to Contract
description: The General Dynamics Corporation received a $40million addition to a previously awarded Navy contract for design work on Trident missilefiring submarines, it was announced yesterday.

title: Some Air Force P.O.W.'s Will Receive $25,000 to $100,000 in Savings Accounts
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Many of the prisoners of war, upon their release, will find several thousand dollars awaiting them in pay, savings and bonuses that accumulated while they were in captivity.

title: SEAMANS CONCEDES ADVICE ON OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. said today that he had received some advice from the White House before terminating the employment of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a managemerit analyst, three years ago.

title: Airport Guards Deployed Despite Delay Set by Court
description: Scores of cities across the country deployed armed policemen at their airports yesterday to help screen passengers, despite a court order signed Monday that prevented the Federal Government from requiring such guards.

title: Drought in India Causes Power Shortage and Spurs Trend to Recession
description: JOG, India, Jan. 30The Gersoppa Falls, or Jog Falls cataract, on the Sharavati River here has dried up.

title: Kenny Is Paroled; Ill Health Is Cited
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 John V. Kenny, a former mayor of Jersey City and Democratic leader of Hudson County who was sentenced to prison last May for Federal income tax evasion, was granted parole today after serving less than half of his 18month sentence.

title: Former Policeman Sentenced to Jail For Having Drugs
description: A Brooklyn State Supreme Court justice, terming outrageous a probation department recommendation of parole, yesterday sentenced a 36yearold former patrolman to serve from eight years and, four months to 25 years in prison on a drug conviction.

title: Kerner Acquittal Denied
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 6 (AP)Federal District Judge Robert L. Taylor declined today to order a jury to acquit Otto Kerner and Theodore J. Isaacs of charges in connection with racetrack stock transactions while Mr. Kerner was Governor of Illinois from 1960 to 1968.

title: Freedom or Hypocrisy
description: It is too early to detect any trends resulting from New York State's recent revision of the law governing care of the mentally ill. But since it is designed specifically to strengthen the existing policy of voluntary hospitalization and easy discharge, it must necessarily intensify the problem which that policy has already createda problem that deserves far more attention than it has so far received from lawmakers and civil libertarians alike.

title: Sun Oil Plans Retail Cutback in Midwest
description: The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from retail marketing in all or part of eight states, mostly in the Midwest, because the company is losing money on the areas affected.

title: Syracuse Holds Off Fordham, 73 to 71
description: Syracuse held off a late Fordham rally last night and handed the Rams their fourth straight loss, 7371, at the Rose Hill gym.

title: SLAYING SUSPECT SEIZED IN MANHUNT
description: A 19yearold New Jersey youth was captured in a countryside manhunt last night seven hours after he allegedly killed his sister's fianc and gravely wounded his own brother and another teenager with shotgun blasts at his home in a semirural section of Morris County.

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yester. day was:
The Making of a Jersey A.B.A. Franchise
description: New Jersey has an American Basketball Association franchise in name only.

title: Dr. Clairette P. Armstrong, Research Psychologist, 86
description: Dr. Clairette P. Armstrong, a clinical and research psychologist, died here Monday at her home, 925 Park Avenue. She was 86 years old.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: TV: New America '73
description: As the Corporation for Public Broadcasting continues to do battle with national news and publicaffairs programing on public T, the admirably undaunted National Public Affairs Center for Television (NPACT) officially started a new weekly series last night. Called America '73, it will be offered on Wednesday nights for about 20 weeks on WNET/Channel 13.

title: JapanRed China Trade At Peak $1.1Billion in '72
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 (AP)Japan's twoway trade with Communist China totaled a record $1.1billion in 1972, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: Bridge: Opening Bid of OneDiamond Can Cover Various Hands
description: All the systems based on a strong artificial oneclub bid, from Vanderbilt in the twenties to Blue Team, Schenken and Precision in the last two decades, have had difficulty with hands containing a long club suit.

title: 3 AT BROWN'S TRIAL DESCRIBE '71 HOLDUP
description: Three more prosecution witinesses yesterday corroborated earlier courtroom description of the holdup of a West Side bar in which H. Rap Brown and three codefendants are charged with armed robbery and the attempted murder of several policemen.

title: Interest in Hunting Led To a Long Show Career
description: Sixty years ago Fred Hunt was given a beagle. It started him on a career in the dogshow world, in which he still is very active. I havent bred a dog for eight or nine years, he said, but I keep busy judging. I accept 20 shows a year and turn down more than twice that number.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The New Jersey chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that it would ask the United States Supreme Court to stay an election of the West Orange Board of Education until the name of a 16yearold high school sophomore was included on the ballot.

title: 'Carry on Doctor,' British Import, Continues Trend in Humorous Vein
description: I can't wholly resist a movie comedy that comes billed as "the greatest medical discovery since laughing gas," or one that has characters with names like Doctor Tinkle and Mavis Winkle, or that takes the plunge into sexual innuendo with exchanges like:"I dreamt about you last night, nurse.""Did you?""No, you wouldn't let me!"This isn't' to say that "Carry on Doctor," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, isn't pretty resistible. It is rather a matter of how you happen to feel today about the tradition of noisily overstated British humor to which it belongs. Today, I feel unresistant."Carry on Doctor" is one of a series of British comedies ("Carry on Camping" was the last I saw here) directed by Gerald Thomas and featuring more or less a single cast playing different roles from film to film but occupying, if you will, the same existential situations.Thus Kenneth Williams (Dr. Tinkle) is forever the oily villain aided by the enormous Hattie Jacques (The Matron) who at some point will let her hair down and slip into something more comfortable and, much to her leader's disgust, declare her love for him.The appetites and irritations of Frankie Howerd and Sidney James (here, a couple of hospital patients) will remain unchanged no matter what their ages, as immutable as the uplift to Barbara Windsor's (Nurse Sandra May's) bosom.In the hospital their manner is no different from anywhere else. And their comic acting stylea kind of fast burn twice repeatedloses no emphasis and gains no subtleties. Of course the hospital's chief surgeon has St. Vitus's dance, and of course the principal items of medical equipment are the bedpan and the urine bottle.There is nothing in the arsenal of mere movie criticism to combat this, and any mere movie critic would be an idiot to try. Furthermore, I find I rather like the plucky attachment of Nurse Clark to the resident Dr. Kilmore, and the clumsy middle-aged romance across the wards between Ken Biddle and Mavis Winkle.

title: Flu Vaccine May Fight Strains of Future
description: Researchers at the Pasteur Institute in Paris have produced an influenza vaccine that they believe will be effective against strains of the disease yet to evolve.

title: Profits Climb at A.M.C.
description: DETROIT, Feb. 7  The Chrysler Corporation and the American Motors Corporation, companies that two years ago were fighting for survival, issued financial reports today that showed not only recovery but also vigorous health.

title: Civic Leaders Discussing TV Town Meeting Plans
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7New Jersey religious and civic leaders met today to discuss a pioneer effort to solve twentiethcentury programs through a series of electronically inspired town meetings.

title: Newark Council Urges a State Inquiry on School Board
