description: NEWARK, Feb. 7The white majority on the City Council today called for a state investigation of the city school board's performance in response to the threedayold boycott by white students at Vailsburg High School and four elementary schools.

title: Sales Reach Record Levels For Private Plane Makers
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The nation's builders of corporation aircraft and private planes shipped $56,248,000 worth of flying machines to dealers and potential customers in January.

title: Navy Jet Hits Apartment in California
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Thursday, Feb. 8 (AP)A United States Navy jet fighter exploded in flames last night as it slammed into an apartment building with an estimated 80 persons inside. The building, across the bay from San Francisco, was reduced to rubble.

title: BRIBERY WITNESS NAMES EX MAYOR
description: CAMDEN, N. J., Feb. 7 (AP) Former Mayor William T. Somers of Atlantic City was named in Federal Court here today as the recipient of a $5,000 bribe to approve the licensing of a jam joint on the city's Boardwalk ill 1969.

title: H.R.A. AIDES FIGHT WORKRULE SHIP
description: More than 2,000 employes the Human Resources Admin istration jammed the block front of the agency's offices 250 Church Street yesterday protest a shift in administrative procedures designed to increas productivity and curb latenes and absenteeism.

title: Hussein Says U.S. Agrees to Supply 2 Squadrons of Aircraft
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7King Hussein of Jordan said today that the United States had agreed to supply his country with two squadrons of F5E jet fighter planes to help modernize his air force.

title: State Labor Scores G.O.P. Bill On NoFault Auto Insurance
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7The statewide A.F.L.C.I.O. today denounced the Republican legislative leadership's modified nofault auto insurance bill as a fake and a hoax.

title: Impounding And Implying
description: In the political and constitutional struggle now developing between Congress and President Nixon on the question of his right to refuse to spend appropriated funds, the danger is that the President is largely right on the issue and may therefore seem to be right on the principle.

title: A Senator's Idea of a Woman's Place
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 There was Senator Mark Hatfield of Oregon, addressing the Republican Congressional wives' first luncheon meeting of the 93d Congress and trying to tread the narrow, sensitive line between the women's liberation movement and a women's traditional place in the kitchen.

title: NIXON DECLARES PHASE 3 HAS TEETH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 President Nixon and the new director of the Cost of Living Council promised today to swing a very big stick in dealing with those who fail to observe voluntarily the Phase 3 wage and price guidelines.

title: N.B.A. in Merger Bill Dilemma
description: Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, is at work on a bill that will permit the, American and National Basketball Associations to merge at the expense of traditional reserveclause limitations on players.

title: Paul Revere, Circa '73: One If by Land, 2 by Ski
description: In view of the great rise in crosscountry interest in the last two years, it comes as no surprise that Gov. Francis W. Sargent of Massachusetts has proclaimed next Sunday as a statewide Ski Touring Day.

title: Chase Acquisition Approved
description: The New York State Banking Board, acting on the recommendation of Harry W. Albright, Jr., the State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday the proposed acquisition by the Chase Manhattan Corporation of a new bank to be organized in Albany, and also of the $11million Lincoln National Bank of Buffalo. The applications must still be approved by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Bruges Begins Combating Pollution By Cleaning Up Its Odorous Canals
description: BRUGES, Belgium, Feb. 7The main subject of conversation in Bruges this winter is the color of the water in de reien, the canals that wind past the city's wellpreserved medieval buildings.

title: RESTRAINT URGED ON SOVIET EXIT TAX
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The State Department said today that although it took very seriously Congressional threats to block trade concessions to the Soviet Union, it believed that quiet diplomacy would be more effective than a public confrontation in getting Moscow to rescind the tax on Jews and other emigrants.

title: Nixon Visits Stennis and Says, I Think He's Going to Make It
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)President Nixon visited Senator John C. Stennis, fighting, for his life at Walter Reed Army Medical Center; for 10 minutes today and said, I think he's going to make it.

title: MARCH SOYBEANS CLOSE AT RECORD
description: In what traders called a wild session, prices of soybean futures gyrated yesterday over range of 20 cents a bushel in some nearby contracts on the Chicago Board of Trade. The nearby March delivery closed at a new high.

title: Catholic Funeral Cortege Raked by Ulster Gunmen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 7Northern Ireland erupted in widespread violence today after gunmen fired into a procession of hundreds of Roman Catholics following the coffins of three members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army who were killed over the weekend by British troops.

title: MISUSE OF FUNDS LAID TO SCHOOLS
description: Charging widespread misuse of public funds by district school boards City Councilman Michael DeMarco called yesterday for an intensive audit of the city's 31 boards by city, state and Federal agencies.

title: U.S. CANCELS SALE OF HOUSING HERE
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that It would suspend its planned sale of more than 100 vacant slumarea homes in Bmoklyn.

title: Illinois Abotiion Law Void
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI)A judge ruled today that the Illinois abortion law was unConstitutional and dismissed charges against a woman accused of performing an abortion 2 years ago. Judge Marvin E. Aspen of Cook County Circuit Court relied in his ruling on a United States Supreme Court decision of Jan. 23, which struck ddwn abortion laws in Georgia and Texas similar to the Illinois law. He threw out charges against Mary Beth Kain, 50 years old.

title: HOUSE VOTES BILL TO REQUIRE NIXON TO RELEASE FUND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The House of Representatives voted today, in defiance of President Nixon, to require the Department of Agriculture to spend $210million that the Administration had refused to release for the Rural Environmental Assistance Program.

title: The Sidetracked Research Project
description: From a theoretical point of view, it seemed to be a sound idea. Unfortunately, this research project just didn't work out along the precise lines that had been planned for it. The Madison Square Garden laboratory was booming at its usual full decibel content the night before last for this purportedly penetrating study of the New York Knicks in general and their Willis ReedJerry Lucas center tandem in particular. But before any measuring, weighing or analyzing, could even begin, the experimental scientific probe lost all validity. It became distorted because Walt Frazier, the superstar of the Knicks, was unable to play as the result of a damaged heel. This automatically destroyed the delicate balance that had given so intriguing a quality to this game between the Knicks, strongest defensive team in pro basketball, and the Los Angeles Lakers, the strongest attacking unit as well as the defending champions.

title: Dayton School Board Gets Desegregation Plan Order
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. (AP)The Dayton School Board was ordered today to prepare a desegregation plan within 60 days.

title: Hearings to Start Feb 27 On New Farm Support Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI) The Senate Agriculture Comemittee announced today that would start hearings on a major new farm support bill on Feb 27.

title: Judge in Camden 28 Case Bars. Talks With Newsmen
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 7  Federal Judge Clarkson S. Fisher today ordered all defendants, witnesses and lawyers in the Camden 28 case to refrain from commenting to newsmen on any aspect of the case throughout the trial.

title: ALBERT S. FULLING
description: EAST ORANGE, N.J., Feb. 7 Albert S. Fulling, director of public information for the New Jersey Department of Institutions and Agencies, died yesterday of a stroke in East Orange General Hospital. He was 57 years old and lived here.

title: City Medicaid to Undergo Audit and Survey by State
description: The State Department of Social Services said yesterday it would make a survey and audit of the Medicaid program in the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation as the first such review of hospital providers in the quality control program it has set up.

title: Notes on People
description: The British Defense Ministry admitted, in effect, that the cover had been blown for the man who heads Britain's Secret Service (M.I.6). Stern, the West German magazine, disclosed that the head of British overseas intelligence is Sir John Rennie. The department also said that since Stern had disclosed Sir John's identity, British publications could not be prevented from revealing it. The disclosure came in connection with reports that Sir John (hitherto unidentified) would resign because his son, Charles, was facing narcotics charges in London. British officials would not comment on the possible resignation.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: U. S. WILL MODIFY OIL IMPORT QUOTAS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7  The Nixon Administration signaled today that despite widespread demands for an end to restrictions on oil imports it would keep the mandatory quotas and change the way they are administered.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Pentagon sources said yesterday that Communist forces in South Vietnam would release 27 American prisoners of war on Sunday. [Page 1, Column 1.]

title: U.S. REPORTS RAIDS IN LAOS STILL GO ON
description: HONOLULU, Feb. 7 (UPI)The United States Pacific forces command reported today that American aircraft conducted bombing missions over Laos for the 11th straight day since the start of the Vietnam ceasefire.

title: State Denies Wide Drug Abuse Exists Among Leesburg Inmates
description: TRENTON, Feb. 7State officials denied today that drug abuse was widespread among the inmates at Leesburg State Prison. They contended, in fact, that any drug traffic problem there was minimal.

title: Books of The Times
description: SAMUEL JOHNSON: HIS FRIENDS AND ENEMIES. By Peter Quennell. 272 pages. Illustrated. American Heritage Press. $12.95.

title: Personal Finance: U. S. Savings Bonds
description: There are 500 million or so Series E Government Savings Bonds outstanding, worth about $50billion, and threequarters of them are held by coowners, perhaps parents and children, grandparents and grandchildren or husbands and wives.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Soviet Mat Team Defeats U.S.; Jerseyan Wins Despite Injury
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 7 (AP)Dave Pruzansky of Passaic, N. J., recovered from an early injury to defeat Batal dadjiyey in freestyle wresting today but the Soviet Union outpointed the United States national team, 5 to 4, Tass, the Soviet pfess agency, reported.

title: Senate Votes Inquiry on Espionage Against Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Senate voted today, 70 to 0, to undertake a fullscale investigation of the Watergatel bugging case and of reported efforts to sabotage the campaigns of Democratic Presidential candidates last spring.

title: Sister of P.O.W. Thinks He Will Face a Shock
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., Feb, 7 When Lieut. Comdr. Everett Alvarez went away to war, he believed in his country, and the battles it was fighting in Southeast Asia. Soon he will be coming home, home to a family, and to many countrymen, who feel that his sacrifice of eight and onehalf years in a North Vietnamese prison camp was a waste of time.

title: A HEALTH SERVICE PROPOSED BY ITALY
description: ROME, Feb. 7  Premier Giulio Andreotti announced program today to stimulate the sluggish economy and to improve socialwelfare, programs, principally by creating a national health service.

title: People and Business
description: Dempsey J. Travis, president of the United Mortgage Bankers of America, yesterday opened the midwinter conference of the minority mortgage bankers group with a stinging attack on the recently imposed 18month freeze on Federal housing subsidies.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Overfishing Depletes Cod
description: Although attempts to protect the cod from overfishing began as far back as the mid16th century, the species is being seriously depleted, Albert C. Jensen writes in the January issue of the Natural History magazine.

title: U.S. Executive Faces Trial in Hungary
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 7 An American business representative is, expected to face a court here early next month accused of running a flambouant commercial operation involving alleged bribery, gifts of new cars, bank accounts abroad for Hungarian accomplices, blackmarket currency dealings and. violation of of??icial secrets.

title: MARKET PLUNGES AFTER EARLY RISE
description: The stock market changed rapidly yesterday from a modest winner in the morning to a big loser in the afternoon.

title: Cosmetics Industry Backs Ingredient Lists on Labels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (UPI)  The cosmetics industry is willing to comply with a Government proposal for ingredient labeling of all its products but the cost may be passed on to the consumer, the Food and Drug Administration said today.

title: Yablonski Trial Panel Set
description: ERIE, Pa., Feb. 7 (AP) A special panel of 250 prospective jurors was chosen today in Erie County Court for the trial of a United Mine Workers official charged with murder in the Yablonski slayings. The new panel, replacing 175 prospective jurors picked last November, was ordered for the March 5 trial of William Prater, 53 years old, a former U.M.W. organizer from LaFollette, Tenn.

title: CELTICS OVERCOME LAKEN BY 113112
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)John Havlicek's turnaround jump shot with two seconds left in overtime gave the Boston Celtics a 113112 victory over Los Angeles tonight, snapping the Lakers' 11game National Basketball Association winning streak.

title: PROBLEMS BESET CHURCH IN BRAZE
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 7Brazil's bishops are meeting this week in their biennial general assembly amid reports of a growing crisis in the Roman Catholic Church in the world's largest Catholic country.

title: VANDEN HEUVEL ENTERS D.A. RACE
description: Stressing the time for a change theme, William J. vanden Heuvel announced yesterday his candidacy for Manhattan District Attorney, the oflice held by Frank S. Hogan since 1942.

title: $40,000 Aid From City Keeps Black Library Alive in Queens
description: A Queens community that created its own library to specialize in black cultureand kept it alive with its own contributions after Federal funds were cut offwas rewarded yesterday for its tenacity with a city grant of $40,000. The money will let the center operate at least until July 1.

title: Sassy Presses Equation
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7Sassy, who had one Southern Ocean Racing Conference victory already under her belt, came out of the pack today to halt what had threatened to become a runaway in the St. Petersburg  Fort Lauderdale yacht race.

title: Waldheim, in Pakistan, Is Urged to Help Free P. O.W.'s
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 7As Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived in Rawalpindi today for a twoday visit to Pakistan, the issue of the Pakistani prisoners of war held in India was raised with him immediately at the airport and again in a meeting with President Zulfikar All Bhutto.

title: Chess: Another Fine Game Founders On the Bank and Shoal of Time
description: CHICAGO Why are so many important games decided by timepressure blunders? Hours of fine, sophisticated play degenerate into a crude catchascatchcan meles presided over by a clock flag whose sudden drop registers a time forfeit.

title: Emergency Service Ready To Help Stranded Riders
description: Commuters and transportation authorities began preparing last night to ease the plight of 103,000 Penn Central riders affected by the dispute between the line and the United Transportation Union.

title: Albert on Radio Sunday To Rebut Nixon Budget
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The four major radio networks have allotted Speaker Carl Albert free time next Sunday to reply to President Nixon's budget speech of Jan. 28.

title: Diet Pill Swindle Charged
description: NEWARK, Feb. 7 (AP)A Federal grand jury indicted the operators of an East Orange company today on charges they sold $1.1million in phony diet pills in a fraudulent mail order operation. Charged with mail fraud were George Maisonet, 23 years old, of the Bronx; Edward Axel, 45, of Livingston; Dolly F. Bradwell, 35, of Newark, and Vincent Lynch, 69, of Brooklyn.

title: Brahms and Le Sacre
description: Claudio Abbado, in the mood to slay dragons, faced up to two of the repertory's most fearsome monsters at Tuesday night's Cleveland Orchestra concert in, Carnegie Hall. Mr. Abbado had some stout help; besides the orchestra: As soloist in the Brahms Piano Concerto No. 2 in B flat, Maurizio Pollini did not command the magisterial style one associates with this immensely strenuous score, but he delivered a lovely performance of another sort, one that searched for all the lyricism, glitter and grace that the concerto contains.

title: 500 Police Told to Write Name Signed on DrugTheft Vouchers
description: About 500 policemen have been ordered to write out 10 times the signature of a dead detective who has been connected with the disappearance of narcotics from the Police Department's property clerk's office.

title: Services for Commuters
description: Following is a list of alternative means of reaching the city during the Penn Central strike:

title: Shanker Seeks a Seat on A.F.L.C.I.O. Council
description: Albert Shanker, president of the state and local teachers' organizations, is seeking a seat on the executive council of the American Federation of LaborCongress of Industrial Organizations.

title: Flu Vaccine May Fight Strains of Future
description: Researchers at the Pasteur Institute in Paris have produced an influenza vaccine that they believe will be effective against strains of the disease yet to evolve.

title: North Central Airlines Sues
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (UPI)North Central Airlines filed an $11million damage suit yesterday against the Collins Radio Company, saying the company had designed a faulty auto pilot system that caused the 1968 crash of a North Central Convair 580 at O'Hare Airport.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: What is especially disturbing about President Nixon's special counsel Charles Colson's Jan. 30 OpEd article, The Georgetown Blacking Factory, is not the importance of the charges it makesfor they are as absurd as those Mr. Colson claims were made by his adversariesbut the care with which, he sought to set the record straight on a matter of colossal unimportance, except for propaganda purposes. President Nixon has gathered around him a large group of P. R. men to get the record straight who can only be described as amateur Josef Goebbelses.

title: Catholic Funeral Cortege Raked by Ulster Gunmen
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb.7Northern Ireland erupted in widespread violence today after gunmen fired into a procession of hundreds of Roman Catholics following the coffins of three members of the Provisional wing of the Irish Republican Army who were killed over the weekend by British troops.

title: Haunting or Suave, Fine Tone Yielded By Stern's Clarinet
description: David Stern, clarinetist, won a debut recital from the Concert Artists Guild last season. The guild felt he was worth a return engagement, and he was back in Carnegie Recital Hall on Tuesday night with a new program. The encore seemed justified. Mr. Stern, who is barely out of his teens, prodaces a beautiful tone, sometimes haunting, sometimes suave. The playing was, for the most part, as deft as could be, and the phrasing indicated a musician as instinctive as he is well trained.

title: Lyle Punches the Bag and Pounds Out Answers for Young Spectators
description: Ron Lyle sparred with the questions of curious New York schoolchildren for more than an hour in the Felt Forurn yesterday, a task considerably easier than his scheduled 12round heavyweight fight with Jerry Quarry tomorrow night in Madison Square Garden.

title: 14 in City Region Finalists In Science Talent Search
description: Fourteen high school seniors from the metropolitan area, including 10 from New York City, were named yesterday among 40 student finanlists in the 32d annual nationwide Westinghouse Science Talent Search.

title: Jackson Plans to Introduce Energy Conservation Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Senator Henry M. Jackson, chairman of the Senate Interior Committee, announced today that he would introduce legislation designed to conserve America's consumption of energy and free the economy from depending on foteign fuel sources.

title: 500 Police Told to Write Name Signed on DrugTheft Vouchers
description: About 500 policemen have been ordered to write out 10 times the signature of a dead detective who has been connected with the disappearance of narcotics from the Police Department's property clerk's office.

I think that Mr. Gregory is one of the most interesting and innovative direc tors in the world. Others disagree. One of my respected colleagues, for example, apparently told Mr. Gregory's press agent, regarding his latest production, Endgame, that he intended to Use his review to expose Gregory for the fraud he is. Strong words. Especially when spoken by a critic who had net yet seen the production in question.

title: Custer, S.D., Fears New PoliceIndian Battle

title: 'Black Caesar' Cues on Crime Lord:The Cast
description: "I'm trying to break into the business at the top," a smiling assured Fred Williamson says before becoming the "Black Caesar," who crashed into the Cinerama and other theaters yesterday. Despite the fact that he reaches the top temporarily and given the film's lip-service to social injustices, this "Black Caesar" is essentially black bad guys against white bad guys in gory warfare that evolves more as exploitation than as clear, convincing exposition of man's inhumanity to man.One can't avoid the feeling that Larry Cohen, the writer-director-producer, has stacked his melodrama largely for black machismo and constant carnage. As a youngster, our hero is already working for Harlem gangsters and venial white cops, one of whom maims him. So, before you can utter one of the many pithy epithets used in the script, he is grown up, wise in the ways of the white underworld and blasting away at the Mafia-like type on his way to the top.Our man, of course, snatches the books of the syndicate, which gives him the power he needs. And, of course, there's blighted romance with Gloria Hendry, a sultry nightclub singer, and confrontations with his heartsick mother (Minnie Gentry) as her estranged husband (Julius W. Harris) before the mob starts striking back.Mr. Williamson, who led the slave revolt in the recent "The Legend of Nigger Charley," this time is equally imposing, tough and unflappableif not as dignifiedas the "Black Caesar," who seems to be subject to some of the shocks as well as the fate of the original Caesar. And the performances are as obvious as the program blurb which proclaims him "the cat with the 45 caliber claws.He's plagued, for example, by Art Lund, as the blatantly bad cop who gave him his first traumas and now, as the Commissioner and still gangland's pal, plots his downfall. Miss Hendry, as his girl, falls in love with his best friend (Michael Jeffrey) and is forced to set him up for the kill. And, as noted, Mama and Papa don't like him either.Mr. Williamson, in short, can't be blamed for the plot contrivances that hinge mostly on action and bloodshed. "Black Caesar" may have been shot in fine colors in Harlem and elsewhere but its bullet-filled contents are unrelievedly black and white.

title: Screen: 'Train Robbers':Burt Kennedy Western Keeps It Traditional The Casts
description: If tone and attitude were enough to sustain a movie, then Burt Kennedy's "The Train Robbers," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, would rank among the best-sustained movies in recent months. Except for a bitter, unnecessary, and rather stupid plot twist at the end, it is so full of understanding, fellowship and reconciliation, that the air of good feeling pervading it almost seems sufficient reason for its being.I don't think that tone and attitude are quite enough to sustain a movie, or that an air of good feeling can take the place of meaningful dramatic action. But as an exercise in pleasantness, "The Train Robbers" is an interesting addition to the late history of the traditional unpretentious Western.At this stage, at least in the Burt Kennedy films ("Hannie Caulder" is a recent, also very interesting, example), the Western takes place in the Westnot a place really, but a few buildings and much countryside occupying a state of mind.John Wayne and some long-time buddiesnotably Ben Johnson and Rod Taylorband together to help Ann-Margret, a voluptuous, hard-drinking but virtuous widow, recover the half-million dollars worth of gold that her husband, a burglar, long ago stole and then hid in some Mexican desert. Only she knows where. The object isn't the gold; it's the $50,000 reward money and also a chance that Ann-Margret's little son can preserve his honor among his playmates in grammar school.You may begin to see what I mean by good feeling. The feeling is enhanced by the companionship, the growing intimacy and trust within the little band. And it is intensified from without by a menacing group of hard-riding horsemen, also after the gold, and by a mysterious stranger (Ricardo Montalban) who observes everything from the sidelines, like a nonsensical ironic fate.The turns of the story are mostly predictable and not very important. But the turns of conversation among the friends around the campfire are full of good memory and decent conviction, and it is for this that "The Train Robbers" seems to exist.The cast is for the most part quite lovely, led by a gentle Wayne, too old for romance but not for regrets, and well supported, most happily for me, in fine restrained performances by Ben Johnson and Rod Taylor.

Massachusetts, Connecticut, Florida, New Jersey and Michigan now have good nofault laws. New York needs one.

The plaintiffs say the project would damage the area's environment, reduce the value of municipal property and its tax revenues and destroy the area's beauty and recreational facilities. They name as defendant the Federal Highway Administration.

description: Mayor Lindsay signed contracts yesterday releasing $250,000 in poverty funds to aid the city's Jewish poor.

title: Alaska Jury Declares Boggs Died on Flight
description: ANCHORAGE, Feb. 7District Court Judge Dorothy A. Tyner signed today a presumptive death certificate for Representative Hale Boggs, Democrat of Louisiana, moments after a sixmember jury declared that the House majority leader died while on a plane flying from Anchorage to Juneau last Oct. 16.

title: NO NEW TALKS SET
description: WASHINGTON, Thursday, Feb. 8The United Transportation Union struck the Penn Central Railroad at 12:01 this morning in a dispute over a unilateral management decision to cut the size of train crews. The strike halted all freight and passenger service on the nation's biggest rail system.

title: STATE TO STUDY MEDICAID FRAUD
description: ALBANY, Feb. 7The State Welfare Inspector General, George Berlinger, disclosed plans today to investigate fraud and waste in the Medicaid systern, which he said accounted for about half of the $1billion wasted annually in payments to the indigent in the state.Some Queens legislators indicated today that they would press for the creation of a new district in the predominantly black area of South Jamaica.

title: Two Guards Rob Bank
description: HOLYOKE, Mass., Feb. Two men dressed as Brink's security guards held up the Holyoke National Bank today and escaped with $297,350. The bank is around a corner from the police station. The police said that the men, one white and one black, had apparently used two getaway cars, both reported stolen from Palmer last night.

title: Boca Raton Classes Off
description: BOCA BATON, Fla., Feb. 7 (UPI)Boca Raton High School canceled classes for the third eimseutiye day today when confrontation between blacks and whites threatened to flare into violence.

title: Administration Is Stung By Mrs. Gandhi's Charge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7The Nixon Administration respond. ed today with a combination of hock and irritation at stateents by Prime Minister Indira andhl of India yesterday that ere sharply critical of the United States.

title: Says Upward Direction Should Not Cause Undue Increase in Profits
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Dr. Arthur F. Burns gave more details today on his jawboning policy for checking the rise in lending rates, saying the basic principle was that upward adjustments in lending rates should be so ordered that profits margins do not rise appreciably.

title: Oilers' General Manager Will Coach W.H.A. Team
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, Feb. 7 (AP)Bill Hunter, general manager of the Alberta Oilers, took over today as coach of the World Hockey Association team, replacing Ray Kinasewich.

title: DOLLAR OFF AGAIN; BONN CURBS BANKS
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, Feb. 7The dollar weakened again today against the world's other major currencies and West Germany's central bank sharply reduced the lending rapacity of the nation's banks in an effort to curb the inflationary effects of the flood of dollars that has been pouring into the country since last week.

title: Jet Hits Apartments
description: A Navy jet fighter slammed into the roof of a wooden apartment building in Alameda, Calif., in a ball of flames last night, touching off a fire that engulfed the building and spread to two adjacent ones. Witnesses feared that few of the estimated 80 tenants could have survived. Details on Page 85.

title: A Retreat Where French Chefs Try Each Other's Home Cooking
description: It is 2 in the morning, Sunday morning, and the lights have finally gone out in the kitchen at Lutce. The owner and chef, Andre Soltner, can at last Lang up his toque blanche and take a day off from running what certainly one of the best French restaurants outside France.

title: Sassy Presses Equation In Southern Ocean Race
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 7Sassy, who had one Southern Ocean Racing Conference victory already under her belt, came out of the pack today to halt what had threatened to become a runaway in the St. Petersburg  Fort Lauderdale yacht race.

title: All Divisions Improve
description: The Anaconda Company, which formerly derived about half of its profits from the now nationalized copper properties in Chile, showed substantially improved results in the quarter and year ended Dec. 31, according to the annual report issued yesterday. This reflected improved earnings in all divisions, increased income from equity in affiliated companies, reduced interest costs and a lack of work stoppages.

title: Lindsay Reassures Residents of Wueens on Crime
description: Mayor Lindsay and top police commanders held a hearttoheart session last night with more than 120 Forest Hills and other Queens residents on how to make life better in the streets, homes and schools.

title: The Making of a Jersey. A.B.A. Franchise
description: New Jersey has an American Basketball Association franchise in name only.

title: 'Baron Blood' Here From Austria
description: There's more to Austria than gemtlichkeit and Mozart. There's also "Baron Blood," one of the dual horror entries that alit at local houses yesterday to illustrate that a flight to Austria isn't absolutely necessary.The "Baron," in short, is a dastard who'd been cursed into haunting his Devil's Castle by a witch he immolated 300 years before. And when resurrected, somewhat witlessly by his handsome, contemporary descendant, Antonio Cantafora, with the reluctant aid of the local, gorgeous castle expert, Elke Sommer, the ghostly hob he raises is mostly ersatz.The revived "Baron" seems to be suffering from terminal leprosy and bleeding and is good for a mild shock or two. But when he appears in the guise of a seemingly crippled tycoon who buys the castle, he's only a bland, avuncular villain as played by Joseph Cotten.Under Mario Bava's pedestrian direction, the concocted creaking, screaming, gory murders and Miss Sommer's frightened racing through dark passageways largely add up to spectral schlock.

title: Cola Plants Opened Abroad
description: Royal Crown Cola Company announced yesterday that it has opened bottling operations in Amman, Jordan and the Republic of Singapore, expanding its operations into 38 countries outside the United States.

title: F.T.C. Rejects Bid by Pepsico, Inc., on Complaint
description: The Federal Trade Commission yesterday rejected an attempt by Pepsico, Inc., to settle a complaint against its proposed acquisition of Rheingold, Inc., and began questioning the legality of the GeorgiaPacific Corporation's proposed acquisition of the timberland assets of the Boise Cascade Corporation. After turning down the modified proposal by Pepsico to permit it to acquire Rheingold by a threetotwo decision, the F.T.C. returned the case to adjudication. The F.T.C. did not give any details concerning the Pepsico pro. posai.

title: Culebra Pullout Urged
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 7 (AP)The Puerto Rican House of Representatives has unanimously adopted a resolution demanding immediate withdrawal by the United States Navy from Culebra and Vieques, two small offshore islands used by the Navy for gunnery and amphibious training. A similar measure was adopted last week by the CornI monwealth Senate.

title: Fete at Lambs Features A WellRoasted Mackell
description: District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell of Queens sat through an hour of insults and wellintentioned harassment last night as a volunteer fall guy for the satirical revue staged monthly by the Lambs, the theatrical club.

title: Banking Analyst Charges the Federal Reserve With Intimidation
description: A leading analyst of the banking industry charged yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had, in effect, intimidated bankers in order to block criticismand, more recently, to roll back interest charges.

title: Lindsay to Head Speakers At Forum for Candidates
description: In what appeared to be the strongest hint that he might run for reelection, Mayor Lindsay will be the first of a series of speakers at a mayoral candidate forum sponsored by the New York City Democratic Committee next month.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Stressing the time for a change theme, William J. vanden Heuvel announced yesterday he would run for Manhattan District Attorney, the office held by Frank S. Hogan since 1942. While insisting he would not attack Mr. Hogan personally, Mr. vanden Heuvel linked him with the bankruptcy of the criminaljustice system.

title: R. J. Jacobs Weds Fay I. Rubenstein
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Miss Fay Irene Rubenstein of New York and Robert Jared Jacobs of Washington were married here this afternoon in the American University Chapel by Rabbi Harold S. White.

title: BENJAMIN F. SMALL OF INSURANCE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7Benjamin F. Small, executive vice president of the American Life Insurance Association, died yesterday of a stroke. He was 53 years old and had moved recently to Potomac Falls, Md., from Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Irvin Named to Hall of Fame In Special Vote for Blacks
description: Monte Irvin was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday with the reflection that I wasted my best years in the Negro leagues before the sport was integrated.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: 3 Sailors Injured in Blaze On Destroyer Off San Olego
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 7 (AP)Three sailors were injured today in an engineroom fire aboard the destroyer U.S.S. Agerholm, a sister ship of the U.S.S. Basilone, which was damaged by a boiler expolsion that killed four sailors and injured seven during a training exercise in the Atlantic two days ago.

title: KENNETH BATES
description: MYSTIC, Conn., Feb. 7Kenneth Bates, known for his paintings and pastels of local scenes, died Monday at his home, 15 Grove Avenue. He was 77 years old.

title: Volume Reaches Record At Fanny May Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The Federal National Mortgage Association said today it received $100,926,000 in offers in its conventional mortgage free market system auction Tuesday, the highest volume since it entered the conventional mortgage field.

title: Corona Attorney Released
description: FAIRFIELD, Calif., Feb. (Reuters)Richard Hawks, attorney for Juan Corona, the convicted mass murderer, was released from jail last night after spending 26 hours behind bars, pending action on a motion contending that his 54day jail term for contempt of court is unlawful.

title: Irvin Named to Hall of Fame In Special Vote for Blacks
description: Monte Irvin was elected to baseball's Hall of Fame yesterday with the reflection that I wasted my best years in the Negro leagues before the sport was integrated.

title: Alabama Blast Kills Three
description: ADAMSVILLE, Ala., Feb. 7 (AP)Three persons were killed and two injured today in an explosion and fire at a grocery store in this small town about 10 miles northwest of Birmingham, the police said. The names of the victims and details of the explosion were not immediately available. A police spokesman said the explosion was apparently a result of natural gas leak.

title: Strike on the Pennsy
description: The strike that has shut down the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad is new evidence of the high price the public pays for the absence of a compulsory arbitration law to head off transportation strike emergencies.

title: Doctors Again Question Deodorant Toilet Soaps
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) The panel that recommended the virtual ban on hexachlorphene in overthecounter prodcuts now says that existing evidence does not show that chemical substitutes for hexachlorophene in deodorant toilet soaps are safe.

title: ExHead of C.I.A. Backs Its Training Of Domestic Police
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 The former director of the Central Intelligence Agency, Richard Helms, told the Senate Foreign, Relations Committee today tat it was perfectly legitimate for the agency to provide training to domestic police forces.

title: Stage: The Unwanted People of Hot L Baltimore
description: In his new play, The Hot L Baltimore, Lanford Wilson writes with understanding and sensitivity about unwanted people. His characters are locked in interior worlds, clinging to solitary, futile dreamsand stubborn about not being defeated.

title: School Contracts Voted Despite Waste Charges
description: The Board of Education awarded schoolprogram evaluation contracts totaling $614,144 to a number of private research concerns yesterday despite charges from a board member that the present evaluation system was an outrageous waste of public funds.

title: ELLSBERG JUDGE BARS HE CHARGE
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 7The judge in the Pentagon papers case took action today that will result in the dismissal of one of the espionage charges against Daniel Ellsberg.

title: Tanaka Bars Shift For Yen as Eberle Denies Urging Step
description: TOKYO, Feb. 7 (Reuters)Japan's Premier, Kakuei Tanaka, flatly ruled out today the possibility of another revaluation of the yen at this stage.

title: Tear Gas Disperses Zulu Strikers Near Durban
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Feb. 7Policemen fired tear gas today at a crowd of about 200 blacks at Hammarsdale, an industrial area about 25 miles from Durban that has been closed down by strikes.

title: Many Homeless, at Least Briefly, as Clashes Continue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 7The small, widely scattered battles that have continued since the ceasefire have driven some 200,000 people from their homes at least briefly, officials here said today.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP

title: Providence Five Turns Back St. Joseph's, 81 to 75
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 7 (AP)  Providence, with the help of Ernie Di Gregorio's sharpshooting, held off St. Joseph's, 8175, tonight in a game between two of the East's top college basketball teama.

title: Campaign Spending Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) A Senate subcommittee will hold hearings March 7, 8 and 9 on legislation to limit spending in all Federal election campalgns.

title: Emergency Service Ready To Help Stranded. Riders
description: Commuters and transportation authorities began preparing last night to ease the plight of 103,000 Penn Central riders affected by the dispute between the line and the United Transportation Union.

title: U Conn Five Stopped
description: BOSTON, Feb. 7 (AP)Boston University's basketball team snapped Connecticut's sixgame, winning streak and handed the Huskies their first Yankee Conference loss, 10799, tonight. A freshman, Al Weston, making his first start for Connecticut, scored 43 points.

title: State Senator Padavan Is Guilty Of Ethics Breach in Sale to City
description: The city's Board of Ethics found State Senator Frank Padavan guilty yesterday of a conflict of interest while Serving as a deputy commissioner of the Department of Buildings between 1969 and Dec. 31, 1972.

title: Cabinet to Meet Today
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP) President Nixon summoned his Cabinet today for a breakfast meeting tomorrow and a major discussion on his budget proposals. The meeting will be followed by a midmorning conference with the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana.

title: PASSAGE IS SWIFT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8Congress adopted late today a resolution ordering a halt for at least 90 days in a strike that had stopped all passenger and freight service on the Penn Central Railroad, the nation's largest rail system.

title: Phone Deposits Found Too High
description: Hundreds of thousands of New York Telephone Company customers have been forced to pay excessive security deposits, a Public Service Commission staff report said yesterday.

title: FASHION TALK For Summer, Halsion Doesn't Let His Friends Down
description: Well, he's certainly right on the track, someone observed at Halston's summer showing on Seventh Avenue yesterday.

title: No Indictment Voted Against Patrolman In Killing in Jersey
description: BERNARDSVILLE, N. J., Feb. 8A Somerset County grand jury reported today that it had found no ground for criminal action against a white policeman who shot and killed young black resident here outside a tavern last Jan. 13.

title: Berlin Doctor Says NewFound Skeleton Is That of Bormann
description: BERLIN, Feb. 8 (AP)The director of the Institute for Forensic Medicine here said today that a human skeleton recently unearthed in West Berlin was without doubt that of Martin Bormann, the longsought Hitler aide.

title: Journey Into Peace
description: The current Asian journey of Henry Kissinger will lay the groundwork for the future role of the United States in Indochina and its relations with the emerging powers across the Pacific. In signaling just how low will be the American profile in postwar Asia, Mr. Kissinger's nuances will be as important as his overviewand his hosts in Hanoi, Vientiane and Peking are not exactly novices in sensing nuance.

title: MARCH COST DEAD; BRITISH NOVELIST
description: March Cost, the British novelist, died Wednesday in London. She was believed to have been in her sixties, and for two decades and more she had made her home in Tunbridge Wells, Kent.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
Book Reports Chou Offered to Assist Whitlam in Voting
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 8A new book on last December's campaign asserts that Premier Chou Enlai of China offered to cancel a $76.2million order for Australian wheat last year if it would help the Labor party win the national election.

title: Village View: It Is Only a CeaseFire
description: LONG DINH, South Vietnam, Feb. 8Mrs, Tran Thi Anh was harvesting her rice here today, winnowing the dry brown stalks to separate the grain, when the first artillery rounds began landing near her field.

title: Drugs Found Missing, Warehouse Is Blamed
description: The South Bronx wholesale outlet of the McKesson & Robbins Drug Company has been charged with allowing addictive drugs to be diverted to illicit markets.

title: AMEX AND OTC SHOW DECLINES
description: Prices continued to decline yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market in moderate trading.

title: Volpe Sworn as envoy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) John A. Volpe was sworn in today as the new United States Ambassador to Italy. The former Massachusetts Governor and former Secretary of Transportation is the first American of Italian extraction to hold that post.

title: Letters to the Editor The President vs. Congress: Power of the Purse
description: To the Editor: In his press conference on Jan. 31, President Nixon was so incautious as to cite Harry Truman'S impounding of the funds appropriated for a 70group Air Force, of which Truman had decided that a 48group of war planes was adequate. As such; Mr. Nixon underlined inescapably the most decisive issue around which his impounding of funds and budgetary cuts for protection of the environment, for health, education; housing and welfare in favor of a $4.2billion, budget increase for the military will be vehemently opposed, especially in the fate of the end of the Vietnam war.

title: Vesco's Letter Identifies Potential Buyers of Stock
description: The buyer negotiating for nearly a million shares of International Controls Corporation stock, now held by Robert L. Vesco, the company's former chairman, was identified yesterday as a group headed by Norton W. Mailman and Elmer A. Sticco.

title: Intruder Holds Up 2 Teachers In Front of Classes in Brooklyn
description: A man with Ma knife robbed two women teachers of $58 in front of their classes in a Brookfront elementary school yesterday afternoon. The intruder fled as children in a secondgrade class began to cry.

title: Lyle Arrives at Vanishing Point Tonight
description: In a 12round bout enhanced by George Foreman's recent coronation as the world heavyweight champion, Jerry Quarry will test Ron Lyle's credibility as a potential challenger tonight at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Kitchen Offers A Program of Musk By Elias Tanenbaurn
description: The Kitchen, the newmusic concert space at the Mercer Arts Center, is open to everybody, but most of the composers who have appeared there have been young. It was thus a particular pleasure on Tuesday to see Elias Tanenbaum, who runs the Electronic Laboratory at the Manhattan School of Music, make his way downtown for an evening of his music. The pleasure was augmented by the fact that Mr. Tanenbaum's work turned out to be very good.

title: Congress Buys Time
description: Congress, eager to get off on a weeklong holiday weekend, has done a rush repeat of a familiar scriptpassage of an emergency backtowork law to halt a paralyzing railroad strike.

title: Black Board Member, 18, Assailed on School Clash
description: NEWARK, Feb. 8  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson, breaking his silence on a weeklong racial controversy in five of Newark's schools, sharply criticized tonight an 18yearold black youth he had appointed to the Board of Education.

title: Dominican Invasion
description: Unless President Balaguer's Government is holding back significant information, there is no reason to get too excited about the invasion of the Dominican Republic by a small band of guerrillas said to have come from Cuba. What must be taken seriously, however, is the possibility that the military will use the incident as a pretext for trying to destroy former President Juan Bosch and his Dominican Revolutionary Party (P.R.D.).

title: A DERAILMENT HALTS THIRD AVENUE TRAIN
description: Service on the Third Avenue Elevated line in the Bronx was suspended for nearly four hours beginning in the evening rush hour yesterday following a derailment north of the 156th Street station.

title: Hutcherson Gains Pole
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb, 8 (UPI)Ron Hutcherson of Keokuk, Iowa, won the pole position today for Sunday's position 300 stock car race with a lap speed of 181.269 miles an hour over the Daytona International oval. Next to Hutcherson's 1971 Mercury will be 1972 Ford driven by Red Farmer of Hueytown, Ala., who qualified in 177.493 M.P.H.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 37

title: Black South African Strikers Returning to Municipal Jobs
description: DURBAN, South Africa, Feb 8Black municipal workers, who recently joined other black workers on strike in this east coast port city, began reporting for work today after city ultimatum to return by tomorrow or be discharged.

title: FAIRFIELD RIDERS FIND TRANSPORT
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 8Despite the Penn Central strike, Fairfield County commuters go to work today without undue discomfort.

title: GATT Head Urges Effort to Eliminate Industrial Tariffs
description: GENEVA, Feb. 8A leading international trade official urged the industrialized nations today to be ambitious when they attack tariffs at the world trade negotiations that are scheduled to start in September.

title: Balloon Flights Delayed
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Feb. 8 (AP)Winds of 20 to 30 miles an hour, light snow and heavy overcast forced cancellation today of the second day of competition in the United States eliminations for the first world hot air balloon championships.

title: RAIDERS DEFEAT NATIONALS, 3 TO 2
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 8 (AP)Gene Peacosh's 27th goal of the season, with less than six minutes remaining in the game, lifted the New York Raiders to a 32 World Hockey Association victory over the Ottawa Nationals tonight.

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Film

title: Freight Train Crew, Ending Routine Run, Bitter About Change
description: MORRISVILLE, N. J., Feb. 8 Freight train No. EG2 from Harrisburg rolled into the Morrisville terminal at 9 o'clock last night, on time despite some track trouble down the line and a threat of the strike three hours hence.

title: Police Chief Found Guilty of Corruption In Newburgh Raids
description: WHITE PLAINS, Feb. 8Humbert M. Cappelli, suspended Police Chief of Newburgh, was found guilty today of 12 of 14 charges of corruption, including the planting of narcotics at the scene of police drug raids and the stealing of money uncovered during the raids.

title: Princeton Fencers Snap N.Y.U.'s Streak at 37
description: With an overtime victory in the final bout, Princeton's fencing team snapped New York University's 37meet victory string, 1413, at N.Y.U.'s School of Education gymnasium on Wednesday night.

title: TV: Tasty Vaudeville
description: The great Ziegfeld probably would have relished N.B.C. Follies, a fast, funny, festive revue hour that went down last night like the tastiest of hot dogs. Here, for once, was a televised vaudeville program  brisk songanddance, hilarious oldtime burlesque sketches and Ziegfeldtype girls in feathers and spanglesthat swatted out good, ribald entertainment, with no fiddling around.

title: Soybeans Rise by Limit Fifth Day in Row
description: The soybean price spiral continued upwards yesterday with another 10 cents a bushel limit rise for the March delivery. It closed at a historic record high of $5.48 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade, compared with $5.38 on Wednesday.

title: Psychiatrists Review Stand on Homosexuals
description: A committee of the American Psychiatric Association yesterday began deliberating whether homosexuality should be considered a form of mental illness and whether it ought to he stricken from the association's official catalog of mental disorders.

title: Boca Raton Decides to Stop Growing
description: BOCA RATON, Fla., Feb. 8 Boca Raton has more polo fields (four) than it has bowling alleys (one), a costofliving index higher (122.0) than New York City's (117.5), and a growth rate (nearly 600 per cent in the last dozen years) greater than Jack's beanstalk.

title: FrameUp Plot Laid To a Jersey Senator
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8  State, Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of having conspired to frame a Gloucester County Democratic Assemblyman by having narcotics planted in his house.

title: A BLACK IS URGED AS SCHOOL CHIEF
description: The appointment of a black as the next Chancellor of the city schools was urged yesterday by a group of black leaders.

title: Weinberger Is Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8But 10 Senate Democrats voted against the confirmation in an angry gesture of protest against the Administration's spending priorities. The vote on the nomination was 61 to 10.

title: Admirable Playing Of Bostonians Lifts Strauss's Quixote
description: The Richard Strauss program in which William Steinberg led the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night began with one of the composer's less often played works, the Suite from Le bourgeois gentilhomme. For all its rarity on the local concert scene, it turned out to be the least interesting part of the evening.

title: Doctor's Arrests Were Known To Prison When It Hired Him
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8New Jersey prison officials today admitted knowing that Dr. William R. King had been arrested twice in 1966 when they hired him as staff psychiatrist at Trenton State Prison in November, 1971.

title: CAVALIERS DOWN HAWKS BY 136132
Rozelle Puts New Man In Hot Seat Officially
description: Officiating in the National Football League, exposed by the cruel eye of television as less than perfect last season, now becomes the responsibility of Art McNally, a retired referee. McNally has been promoted by the commissioner, Pete Rozelle, to supervisor of the N.F.L.'s 84 officials, succeeding Mark Duncan, who resigned to join the Los Angeles Rams as director of personnel.

title: LEGAL
PRESS IS DISPUTED AT HOUSE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  A University of Michigan law professor who has surveyed more than 1,200 newsmen contended today that, contrary to what the press has been saying, reporters need only partial immunity from forced testimony to prevent their confidential sources from drying up.

title: Campaign to Harm News Media Cited By Chief of N.B.C.
description: Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Company, warned last night that some Federal Government officials are waging a continuing campaign aimed at intimidating and discrediting the news media, and the public has expressed very little concern.

title: INA Posts a 12.5% Increase in Earnings
Nixon Said to Seek Authority to Impose Imports Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Nixon Administration is understood to have decided to include in its proposed trade legislation authority to impose an acrosstheboard import surcharge when the nation's balance of international payments is in deficit and parallel authority for a uniform cut in tariffs when the balance, of payments is in surplus.

title: RICHARD GIIINO, SCULPTOR, IS DEAD
description: PARIS, Feb. 8 (AP)Richard Guino, a sculptor, died Feb. 2 at the age of 83. He was buried privately in the town of Antony, just south of Paris.

title: Spring Camps Delayed
description: Baseball training camps, which were scheduled to open next week, were declared off limits by the club owners until agreement is reached in their labor dispute with the players. The owners said they had offered to arbitrate individual salary disputes. Details, Page 17.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Winterweary New Yorkers would do well, if their interests are so oriented, to consider the special programs offered by the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Billy Conigliaro Wantsto Play
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 8 (AP)Billy Conigliaro has asked to be removed from the Milwaukee Brewers' voluntarily retired list, apparently so he can sign with the world champion Oakland (A's. Jim Wilson, the Brewers' general manager, confirmed that the outfielder, who jumped the club June 25, had applied for reinstatement.

title: McGovern Looks Homeward for Votes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8After losing his home state of South Dakota in the Presidential election last November, Senator George McGovern now presents the profile of a national politician struggling to local.

title: The D.A.'s Prescription
description: The New York State District Attorneys Association, group with specialized knowledge about law enforcement, has responded calmly and sensibly to Governor Rockefeller's demagogic call for a crackdown on drugs. With the skill of practiced lawyers, members of the association zeroed in on the unworkable elements the Rockefeller proposals, which fail to distinguish either among kinds of drugs or among kinds of drug pushers.

title: Local School Unit Contract Questioned
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt has raised pointed questions of propriety over $383,500 in contracts awarded to a computerservice company by a Bronx school district whose superintendent was the sister of the company's president.

title: STOCKS ARE HIT BY RAIL WALKOUT
description: The stock market added another worrythe Penn Central Railroad striketo its carload of woes yesterday. As a result, stock prices moved through bumpy session and finished moderately lower.

title: All 64 W.C.T. Stars to Play In $100,000 Tourney in '74
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8A $100,000 indoor tournament, with all 64 World Championship Tennis players, will be played next year at the Spectrum.

title: Stony Brook Freshman, 18, Is Killed in Fall Into Steam Manhole
description: STONY BROOK, L.I., Feb. 8 An 18yearold freshman at the State University of New York campus here plunged 25 feet through an open manhole to his death in live steam late last night.

title: Purvis Leaving F.B.I.; Served for 32 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)  Joseph D. Purvis, assistant director of the F.B.I. in charge of the identification division, announced today his retirement after 32 years of service.

title: Records: Charlie Brown
description: You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown, the musical based on Charles M. Schulz's Peanuts comic strip that brightened the 1967 OffBroadway season and several seasons after, was, in its way, as much of a landmark for the musical theater as My Fair Lady had been a decade earlier. Much as Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe retained the essence of Shaw's, Pygmalion and, in some respects, gave it an added dimension in transferring it to the musical stage, Clark Gesner managed the even more remarkable feat of moving a group of very familiar comicstrip characters from their established twodimensional world to three dimensions plus music without losing the unique flavor that Mr. Schulz had built up over a period of years.

title: F.C.C. PLEA LOST BY BLACK CAUCUS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 The Federal Communications Commission, by a 5to2 vote, has rejected sweeping demands by the Congressional Black Caucus for free television time similar to that granted to the President.

title: Miss Darre's Skill Makes Piano Sing
description: JEANNEMARIE DARRE, piano. At Tulty. Hall.

title: Witness Tells of 10% Kickbacks To Three Atlantic City Officials
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 8 (AP) Three present and former Atlantic City officials were named in Federal Court testimony here today as having received 10 per cent kickbacks on trucks sold to the city by two motor dealers.

title: Cold Weather Warming Hearts of Ski Operators
description: Well aware that two consecutive holiday weekends were approaching, ski enthusiasts yesterday were heartened by the report that winter had returned and seemed prepared to linger. Snow was reported falling yesterday at ski areas throughout the Northeast. And, to brighten News the picture, forecasters expected of that subfreezing Skiing temperatures would prevail at least until next Monday.

title: Texaco Offers Fuel Data
description: BOSTON, Feb. 8 (UPI)Texaco Inc., threatened with a $25,000 a day fine and a oneyear jail term for the company president, has agreed to produce requested information to the United States Environmental Protection Agency relative to a shortage of low sulphur fuel in New England.

title: U.S. FIVE LOSES IN 3 LANGUAGES
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Feb. 8 (AP)  The executive board of the International Olympic Committee has rejected another appeal by the United States to reverse the result of the controversial Olympic basketball title game at Munich last September. The Soviet Union defeated the United States 5150, the first time the United States ever lost an Olympic basketball game.

title: JOSEPH L. BAUMAN
description: Joseph L. Bauman, a former trustee and Police Commissioner of Port Chester, N. Y., died Wednesday in Hallandale, Fla., where he had lived for the last two years. He was 71 years old.

title: Postal Overcharge

Those giants were not doomed solely by the staggering rise secondclass mailing rates, but that was a grim and important factor. Even more vulnerable to extinction through higher postal charges are those prestigious but financially precarious journals that feed and reflect the whole gamut of American public opinion.

title: Screen: Not for Tourists:Jamaica's Other Face in 'Harder They Come'
description: Reported to be the first feature filmed by Jamaicans in Jamaica, "The Harder They Come," which landed at the Embassy yesterday, is striking proof that a good many of the natives are far removed from the carefree vacationer's sun, surf and daiquiris. If it isn't particularly polished in its acting or melodrama, this focus on an aspiring young black singer's short, unhappy life seems as honest as its depiction of the seamier practices of some of the islanders. The authentic settings in Kingston and its environs have been captured in the vivid colors dear to visitors.Perry Henzell, the 36-year-old, white producer-director-co-scenarist and a professional in the commercial and documentary film fields, has achieved a sort of cinma vrit approach to his story. The film deals with a country boy who is hurt by the minister he works for, the producer of his first and only hit record and the marijuana traffickers who hustle him until, in desperation, he becomes a gunslinger who ends up as a martyred folk hero.It must be stressed that the film is not all that grim. The heavily accented dialogue, while technically English, is, on most occasions, tough to follow, and Mr. Henzell and company helpfully have provided copious English subtitles, which amusingly makes this one of the rare, if not the first of English-language films with English subtitles.Jimmy Cliff, a noted exponent of the native rocklike Reggae music, is natural and energetic in his movie debut as the ill-starred singer-gunman. And, naturally, he makes good use of his talents with the titular song, as do others with the supersyncopated Jamaican rhythms and spirituals of the film's score.Credit for equally unvarnished portrayals should go to Janet Berkley, as a minister's ward who loves him; Ras Daniel Hartman and Carl Bradshaw, as marijuana dealers; Bobby Charlton, as the graspingly tough record tycoon, and Winston Stona, as a detective in cahoots with the "grass" traders.The largely amateur cast of black performers and their producer-director may be involved in basically simple action fare in "The Harder They Come," but they also leave a slightly disturbing, documentary impression of the darker side of the sunny Jamaica.

title: BRITISH TESTING ARTHRITIS DRUG
description: A cooperative study at five medical centers in Britain has indicated that penicillamine, a cousin to the antibiotic penicillin, is effective in treating severe cases of rheumatoid arthritis, a painful and crippling chronic disease that afflicts about five million Americans.

title: Screen: Mike Hodges's 'Pulp' Opens:A Private Eye Parody Is Parody of Itself
description: I know I'm wrong, but it feels as if every week for the last six months at least one new imitation private-eye movie has opened in New York City. They all haven't been awful. But I don't see what the profit is (except for the profit from salable nostalgia) in parodying a genre that more or less lived by grace of self-parody even in the classical noon of its warmest heyday.There is certainly not much profit, even at this stage of the nostalgia business, in making an actor up like Humphrey Bogart and giving him a bit movie role in which he must ask what that bird is ("It's a Maltese Falcon"). And yet that is typical of what happens in Michael Hodges's "Pulp," which opened yesterday at the First Avenue Screening Room."Pulp" pits Mickey King (a bit up from Sam Spade?), writer of dirty novels, against a determined band of rich sportsmen who will stop at nothing, even murder, to keep him from ghost-writing the incriminating autobiography of one Preston Gilbert, former movie star, ex-Mafia man, currently living in raucous seclusion with his mother, his mistress and his bodyguard on the island of Malta.The plot, which is somewhat better than the movie it occupies, is full of incredible complications and clever conceitslike an international hired gunman who between hits teaches literature at Berkeley. But it is also a plot that is painfully aware of its origins, all its origins, perhaps on the assumption that anything is better if you can guess where it came from.You can guess where most everything comes from: the castMickey Rooney, Lionel Slander, Lizabeth Scott  partly out of the nineteen-thirties and forties; the characters  imitation Bogart, Cagney, and the likeout of those pop-culture objects now made icons; the moods and tensions, out of the collective depths of the film noir. But all this is better recollected, or revived, not reworked. And "Pulp" has no very interesting passions to match its ideas or its several dozen memories. For all its intricacy, intrigue and physical action, it is a curiously detachedalmost somnolentmovie.There is nothing really in the performance of Michael Caine, as Mickey King, to dispel the drowsiness, and nothing much in the deliberate, often intentionally gimmicky, direction of Hodges. I suspect that this is a very personal project for Hodges (previously responsible for "Get Carter"), but his personality seems to have been engaged only in disparate parts.Much of the soundtrack for "Pulp" is given over to King's interior monologue, full of color of the "He had eyes like bloodshot oysters" variety. But by some cruel trick of electronic reproduction, all the other voices are weak, unresonant, difficult to hearas if picked up by a soundman working across the street, on somebody else's movie.

title: Rise in Building Costs Plagues Hirshhorn Museum
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 6What goes up seldom comes down is axiom in the nation's capital concerning the construction costs of Government projects. The controversial Joseph Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden, now under construction on the Mall, is no exception.

title: F.D.I.C. Director Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) The resignation of Irvine H. Sprague as director of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporaion was accepted with regret today by President Nixon. Mr. Sprague had served on the F.D.I.C. board since September, 1968. His resignation is effective next Thursday. A successor has not been named.

title: Delay Caied in Spring Training
description: The major league baseball clubs directed their 960 players yesterday not to report for spring training until agreement was reached in their dispute on working conditions.

title: Advertising: Ogilvy Turnabout
description: When the Popular Democrats lost power in Puerto Rico in 1968, Ogilvy & Mather, which had been doing spectacular advertising, lost the tourism and rum advertising business it had been doing for the Commonwealth.

title: STOCKTON DOWNS SOLOMON, 63, 62
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8In Dickie Stockton's mind, the secret now is not learning how to play tennis, but learning how to win.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Notes on People Mrs. Nixon Quits DayCare Unit
description: The Day Care and Child Development Council of America, a nonGovernment agency, disclosed in Washington that Mrs. Richard M. Nixon had resigned as its honorary chairman. A spokesman for the Council said Mrs. Nixon resigned Nov. 28, about a year after President Nixon vetoed daycare legislation that was supported by the council. The spokesman said the Council had asked Mrs. Nixon to discuss the veto with its executive committee and received the resignation in reply. The spokesman also said Mrs. Nixon's work for the council in the four years the was honorary chairman was restricted to having her photograph taken several times at daycare centers. The White House said Mrs. Nixon resigned because she did not have enough time to devote to the council, and noted that she held, many honorary positions.

title: Pollution Tax Bill Offered
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  Representative Henry P. Smith, Republican of upstate New York, introduced today a bill to levy a 3 per cent Federal income tax surcharge, to finance the program to control water pollution. The revenue would go directly into a pollution control trust fund and could be spent only for pollution control.

title: Bridge: World Team Championship Is Back in Brazil This Year
description: The world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl, played in Rio de Janeiro in 1969, returns to Brazil this year. Play is scheduled to begin May 15 in Sao Paulo.

title: CONGRESS ACTED TO AVERT IMPACT
description: The threat of massive disruptions throughout American industry was apparently averted, or at least postponed, last night when President Nixon an nounced his intention to sign a bill Congress passed during the day to halt the strike of the Penn Central Railroad until May 9.

title: Auburn and PinkLilac Men
description: SAINT GALLEN, SwitzerlandIt is hard to say whether man was one of nature's mistakes from the outstart, or whether he has by degrees developed into being the only known beast that enjoys killing its own kin. Some scholars think that man's warlike instincts were implanted in him from the beginning as some sort of precautionary apparatus, lest he multiply too easily for the species to sustain itself.

title: Reserve. Data Show Growth Is Slowing in Money Supply
description: Business loans are continuing to increase abnormally as growth in the money supply has slowed to the lowest rate in two months, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday in its weekly distribution of banking data.

title: Nixon Said to Seek Authority to Impose Imports Surcharge
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Nixon Administration is understood to have decided to include in its proposed trade legislation authority to impose an acrosstheboard import surcharge when the nation's balance of international payments is in deficit and parallel authority for a uniform cut in tariffs when the balance of payments is in surplus.

title: ELEANOR H. HOGG
description: COCONUT GROVE, Fla., Feb. 8Eleanor H. Hogg, a trustee of the Coconut Grove Library Association, died in her home here today. She was 64 years old.

title: Government Says Accords On Pricing Stay in Effect
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  Pricing rules contained in agreements made with the Government in the second phase of the wageprice controls program are in effect until they expire, the Cost of Living Council said today.

title: Bowman to Undergo Surgery
description: GREEN BAY, Wis., Feb. 8 (AP)The Green Bay Packers said today that Ken Bowman, a center, would undergo ankle surgery.

title: Shift to Monthly Medicaid Cards Recommended by State for City
description: ALBANY, Feb. 8State Department of Health officials said today that they had recommended that Medicaid eligibility cards in New York City be issued on a monthly basis and allow for two visits to a doctor to cut down on fraud and a misuse of the cards.

title: Nixon Aide Opposes Rise In Milk Price Supports
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)  The Nixon Administration criticized today a bill that would raise milk price supports, and suggested that any step by Congress to compel a sharp increase could prompt enough consumer backlash to kill the program.

title: 2 MORE STATES BACK RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 8 (AP)Minnesota became the 26th state today to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment to the Constitution. The measure won final passage in the Senate, 48 to 18, following House approval earlier.

title: CONGRESS HALTS RAILROAD STRIKE, BARRING A WALKOUT FOR 90 DAYS; COMMUTER TRAINS RESUME TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, Feb. 9Congress adopted late yesterday a resolution ordering a halt for at least 90 days in a strike that had stopped all passenger and freight service on the Penn Central Railroad, the nation's largest rail system.

title: Books of The Times
description: A WOMAN NAMED SOLITUDE. By Andre SchwarzBart. Translated Front the French by Ralph Manheim. 178 pages. Atheneum. $5.95.

title: BELFAST VIOLENCE IS REPORTED DOWN
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 8Youths stoned soldiers in three Roman Catholic areas of Belfast today and a woman was slightly injured in crossfire. But the city was generally quiet after the violence yesterday in which five men were allied.

title: Dismay Spreads in Some Cairo Circles as Regime Presses Purge
description: CAIRO, Feb. 8  The mood in Cairo universities and newspaper offices is one of uncertainty arid dismay as the Government of President Anwar elSadat presses its purge of political dissidents, mostly journalists and intellectuals with leftist ideas of various kinds.

title: Johnson Tribute Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (UPI) Congress has sent President Nixon a resolution that would rename the manned space center in Houston the Lyndon B. Johnson Manned Space Center. The House completed Congressional action on the measure yesterday. It was approved Tuesday by the Senate.

title: Makarios, Unopposed, Gets a New Term
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 8 Archbishop Makarios, with no candidate to oppose him, was proclaimed before a crowd of 100,000 cheering people today as President of Cyprus for another fiveyear term.

title: SQUIRES TOP NETS AS ERVING HITS 58
description: NORFOLK, Va., Feb. 8 Julius (Dr. J.) Erving totaled a career high of 58 points to lead the Virginia Squires to a 123108 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Store Sales Increase 13%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales last week were an estimated $665million, up 13 per cent from the yearearlier $591million. Total retail store sales were an estimated $8.78billion, up 12 per cent from last year's $7.378billion.

title: Boston College Six Scores
description: HANOVER, N. H., Feli. 8 (AP) Ed Keay scored his second goal of the game at 9:34 of the period tonight to snap a 55. tic and give Boston Colloege a 65 hockey victory over Dartmouth. Richie Smith also had two goals for the winners. The victory gave Boston College a 54 wonlost mark.

title: Binder Memorial March 3
description: A memorial service for Joseph Binder, an artist and graphic designer, will be held in the Roman Catholic Chapel of SS. Faith, Hope and Charity, 487 Park Avenue, March 3 at 11 A.M. Mr. Binder died June 26 in Vienna at the age of 75.

title: FrameUp Plot Laid To a Jersey Senator
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8  State Senator James M. Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, was indicted by a state grand jury today on charges of having conspired to frame a Gloucester County Democratic Assemblyman by having narcotics planted in his house.

title: Soul Music
description: With cab fare and a certain amount of stamina it was possible Wednesday evening to examine the full spectrum of black soul music. Uptown at Carnegie Hall was Stevie Wonder, supported by three women singers, eight musicians and casually being called the Genius onstage, transmuting the dross of ballads such as For Once in My Life into emotional soul food.

description: A surgeon at the Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn has successfully reattached the left hand of a punch press operator that had been severed at the wrist in an industrial accident, a spokesman for the medical center reported yesterday.

description: PARIS, Feb. 8  President Pompidou tonight set as his theme for the coming French elections the endorsement or rejection of all that has been done in the 15 years of Gaullist rule.

title: ERIC BARKER
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Feb. 8 (UPI) Eric Barker, poet, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here today. He was 67 years old.

description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., Feb. 8 (AP) Three yachtsmen stranded aboard a 41foot ketch that ran aground on the southern tip of Baja California were rescued by helicopter after the vessel's, owner walked for two days to reach help, the Coast Guard said.

title: Cited for Contribution to Island's Cultural Growth
