Net proceeds of the offering will be applied to reduction of outstanding commercial paper used for construction needs. The company's stock closed at 20& down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Bill Banning Blockbusting Sent to Cahill for Signing
description: TRENTON, Feb. 8The State Senate gave final legislative passage today to a bill outlawing blockbusting  the use of fear tactics by unscrupulous realestate agents to induce home owners to sell their, homes.

title: New Mexico State. Lifts Suspension of 2 Players
description: LAS CRUCES, N. M., Feb. 8 (AP)Two New Mexico State University basketball players, John Williamson and Roland (Tree) Grant, have been reinstated on the team, the university announced today.

title: LA PLATA QUARTET IS INTRODUCED HERE
description: The La Plata String Quartet from Argentina was introduced to New York at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night by the Center for InterAmerican Relations. The essemble is attached to the National University at La Plata, and if it is typical of groups to be found at academic centers in Argentina, the musical standards maintained on campuses there must be of good quality.

title: Editor Becomes Publisher
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 8 (AP)John Seigenthaler, editor of The Tennessean here since 11962, has been promoted to publisher of the morning newspaper, succeeding Amon Carter Evans, who was named president of Tennessean Newspapers, Inc.

title: FORMAT CHANGED IN N.B.A. PLAYOFFS
description: A little more money and a little more complication will mark the National Basketball Association playoffs this season, according to plans officially approved yesterday by the league's board of governors.

title: Gen. William M. Dunn, 86, ExMilitary Attache, Dies
description: Brig. Gen. William Mckee Dunn, U.S.A. retired, a veteran of both World Wars, died Wednesday at his home in Hot Springs, Va. He was 86 years old.

title: Maryland Beats Fordham, Fairleigh Bows at Garden
description: Better days have been promised for Fordham's basketball program, but for this season the schedule is too tough and too physical for the undermanned Rams. Maryland, ranked among the nation's top 10 teams, battered Fordham, 8372, last night in the second game of a college doubleheader at Madison Square Garden. It was Fordham's fifth straight loss and its ninth in 20 games.

title: Bill to Slow Postal Rate Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP)Senators Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, joined today in introducing a bill to ease the impact of higher postal rates on magazines and newspapers. The Postal Service plans to increase the secondclass postal rate for these publications an average of 127 per cent over five years. The bill found extend the increase over 10 years. It also provides that publications with a circulation of less than 250,000 be given a reduced rate.

title: Rail TonMileage Showed Rise of 16.3% for Week
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16.6 billion tonmiles, 16.3 per cent above the corresponding week last year. Carloadings totaled 528,641, up 13.5 per cent from the same period last year.

title: RHODE ISLAND'S BAN ON ABORTIONS UPSET
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 8 (AP)A threejudge Federal court declared Rhode Island's strict antiabortion law unconstitutional today.

description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 138.5 from the 136 last week.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8  Although reports were sketchy, it appeared late toInight that Equation, the early pacesetter in the Southern, Ocean Racing Conference's race from St. Petersburg to Foal Lauderdale, was holding her lead.

description: BOMBAY, Feb. 8 (Reuters)Keith Fletcher and Tony Greig's fifthwicket partnership of 254 runs carried England to 333 for five wickets today on the third day of the fifth cricket test against India.

description: The Newspaper Deliverers Union and negotiators for the city's three major dailies met yesterday for preliminary discussions on a new contract to replace the one expiring at midnight March 30.

title: Dollars And Sense

title: New Jersey Briefs

The Democratic chief of North Haledon, Anthony J. Perrotta, who played a bit part the film; Detective Louis Funk of the Prosecutor's office, and a third person, who was not identified by John Niccollai, the first assistant prosecutor heading the investigation, were called as witnesses.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 8  A B52 pilot who refused to fly more bombing raids in Vietnam after 175 missions has been granted a discharge from the Air Force, his civilian lawyer said today.

title: A Genius, a Giant and a Dragon
description: Raymond Berry, Jim Parker and Joe Schmidt were tapped for the professional football Hall of Fame the other day, proving that the ingredients of immortality are manifold. In a single election, the panel of sports writers that enthrones deities for veneration in Canton, Ohio, chose a genius, a giant and a dragon.

title: PBW FILES A SUIT OH S. E. C. ORDER
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 (AP]  The PBW Stock Exchange filed suit in the 3rd Circuit Court of Appeals here today against the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to overturn the S.E.C.'s recent order restricting institutional investor membership on stock exchanges.

title: Snowball Express' A Family Film
description: What could be more squareor welcomeat the moment than a pleasant Disney movie, the old-fashioned, family kind? "Snowball Express" fills the bill very nicely. What it lacks in wit it has in wholesome, hearty chuckles. Add to this some nice, snowy backgrounds and slope activity in the Colorado ski country.Last but not least, it has a genuinely winning little family front and center, including Dean Jones, Nancy Olson (as Papa and Mama), Kathleen Cody and little Johnny Whitaker. They're New Yorkers who pull up stakes, head west and turn an old Gothic mansion that they inherited into a bustling ski lodge.There are few surprises, including maintenance problems, a helpful old miner (Harry Morgan), a wily banker (Keenan Wynn) and plenty of broad, pratfall gags involving the business of skiing (obviously using experts).There is a picturesque climax of a snowmobile race that would have been more impressive minus the cliff-hanging gags. But the pacing is generally easy, under Norman Tokar's direction, and the playing is genial. That old darling, Mary Wickes, finally comes to the rescue of the Baxter family like the cavalry.As for the four charming Baxters themselves, you can't beat a family like this. The new picture, which opened Wednesday in neighborhood theaters, is double-billed with a revival of the animated "Lady and the Tramp," an old Disney delight. Anybody interested in family entertainment?

title: Screen: 'Emitai,' a Tragic Vignette From Senegal:The Program
description: All the feature films of Ousmane Sembene have opened locally, generally to quite favorable reviews, and yet I doubt that he is known to more than a handful of the most devoted and adventurous moviegoers. The reason isn't far to seek. Sembene50 years old and a novelist as well as a film makeris Senegalese, and Senegal is his subject. You look for Senegal in the National Geographic, not in a movie theater. Or if you do look for it in a movie theater, you expect danger, ritual sacrifice, tom-toms, faces hidden in the treetopsthe traditional matter of darkest Africa."Emitai," Sembene's latest movie, has all that  the ritual sacrifice, the tom-toms, the dangerbut with the difference that it approaches everything from the point of view of the faces hidden in the treetops. At one point in "Emitai," native warriors ambush a small detachment of French colonial troops (also natives), and the absolute ineffectualness of massed spears against a few well-placed rifles should lay to rest the memories of a goof many delicious terrors during Saturday afternoons at the movies.The film takes place near the beginning of World War II, and the troops have been sent to seize 50 tons of harvested rice in a little village from which they have already impressed the able-bodied young mento serve in the army of Marshal Petain.The villagers don't exactly need the rice; it is to be used in religious ceremonies, not for sustenance. And the French don't really need it either. Halfway through the movie, deGaulle replaces Petain, the above-ground battles are ended, and so is the demand for overseas food. But everyone remains inflexible, and the story of "Emitai" continues to a fatal standoff in its bitter conclusion.I don't mean to suggest that Sembene doesn't take sides; he does, and of course he is not pro-French. But his stronger interest is in the life of the village; in the difficult, slightly hostile, relations between the men (who conduct the ceremonies) and the women (who seem to do the work); and in the relations between the men and the gods, who sometimes appear when summoned and sometimes don't, who generally give their worshipers a hard time, and who generally are given a hard time in return.Just before the village chief diesfrom French rifle wounds  he utterly renounces the gods, wherupon he is gotten up for a marvelous funeral, so he may rest with them in eternity. This juxtaposition is typical of the spirit "Emitai."It is a cool, balanced, proportionate spirit, affectionate but unillusioned, and wonderfully suited to the intricacies (and the idiosyncracies) of the subject matter. Sembene does not grab you; he engages you. Much of the time he photographs his action in the middle distancenot for the sake of distance but for the sake of an inclusiveness that keeps surprising you with its ironic sophistication."Emitai" isn't a very complicated moviein the abstract, little more than a tragic vignette. But for its purposes it is very complete; and considerate of the puzzles faced by its gods, its victims and its killers."Emitai" opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.

description: NEWARK, Feb. 9The contractor for the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project said today that he would move workers and equipment into the construction site Monlay.

title: 374 Drug Arrests in 6 Years Made Among School Personnel
description: A total of 374 Board of Education employes, including 103 teachers, have been arrested in the last six and a half years for the possession or sale of drugs, a board official said yesterday.

title: Distaff TV Production Team That's More Than Tokenism
description: There's quite a bit of buzzing around the control rooms and corridors of the American Broadcasting Company these days. A series of five 90minute dramatic shows, called generically The Classic Ghosts, is being produced to run soon in the Dick. Cavett time slot. Practically everybody involved in the production is a woman.

title: I.R.S. Staff Members Give Tax Advice on Staten Island Ferryboats
description: Seven staff members from the Internal Revenue Service office at 120 Church Street are helping to ease the incometax ordeal for commuters who ride the Staten Island ferryboats during rush hours.

title: Hockey Star Quits College
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Boston University reported today that its sophomore hockey star, Dick Decloe of Mississauga, Ontario, had withdrawn from school to play in the Junior A amateur ranks in Canada. Decloe recently was declared ineligible by the Eastern College Athletic Conference for allegedly accepting educational expenses before enrolling at B.U.

title: PILOT IS PLANNING FIGHT ON DISCHARGE
description: SAIGON, South Vietndin, Feb 9 (AP)Capt. Michael J. Heck, the Young B52 pilot granted discharge from the Air Force for other than, honorable reasons after he had refused to fly A mission over North Vietnam on Dec. 26, said today that he was planning a legal appeal of that type of discharge.

title: Queens Democratic Unit Picks Biaggi in MayoralChoice Poll
description: In the first test of strength of possible Democratic mayoral candidates, Representative Mario Biaggi of the Bronx ran ahead of 13 other Democrats, including Mayor Lindsay, in a poll of the Queens Democratic executive committee.

title: Duhamel Misses in Attempt For Snowmobile Record
description: BOONVILLE, N. Y., Feb. (AP)  Yvon Duhamel of LaSalle, Quebec, beset by customs and mechanical problems, just missed an attempt to improve his world landspeed record for snowmobiles today.

title: REPORT DISPUTED ON PHONE CHARGES
description: A New York Telephone Company lawyer yesterday challenged a Public Service Commission staff report that suggests the phone company is biased against lowincome customers.

title: Books of The Times
description: WHEN EVEN ANGELS WEPT. The Senator Joseph McCarthy AffairA Story Without a Hero. By Lately Thomas. 654 pales. Morrow. $12.50.

title: Max Yasgar Dies; Woodstock Festival Was on His Farm
description: MARATHON, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)Max Yasgur, whose Sullivan County dairy farm was the scene of the tumultuous 1969 Woodstock rock festival, died today at Fishermen's Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: Equity Financing.
description: Middle South Utilities, Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday in connection with an offering of 4 million common shares to be sold at competitive bidding. The company's stock closed at 24, down  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: 30 Rutgers Students Charge Camden Campus Is Slighte
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, Feb. 9Students from the Camden campus of Rutgers, the state university, protested today ?? they said was neglect in financing their campus. They threatened to protest to the Legislature if the situation was not corrected.

title: Power Break Delays Trains
description: A power failure on two of the Penn Central's four tracks in the Woodlawn section of the Bronx caused commutertrain delays of up to an hour last night, affecting mostly the Newt Haven Division, a spokesman for the railroad said. He addect that service should be back to normal by this morning.

title: Utility to Build Plant
description: The Carolina Power & Light Company said yesterday it planned to build a $78million power plant at Hartsville, S. C. The plant will generate 630,000 kilowatts from 11 internal combustion turbinegenerators! burning lowsulphur oil. Construction will begin as soon as regulatory approval is obtained.

title: Policeman in Team Behind Radio Car Is Shot by a Sniper
description: A 26yearold policeman in a backup team behind a radio car was shot by a sniper early this morning in a possible ambush at Central Park West and 106th Street.

title: Money and Politics
description: PARIS, Feb. 9The latest international monetary crisis came as a surprise only in timing and specifics. It was there growing all the time and the basic ques tion has not changedwhat is going to be done about it?

title: Professors As Makers Of Policy
description: CARBONDALE, IllRobert Cutler, architect of the developed National Security Council organization under President Eisenhower, was a Boston banker. Penetrating in understanding and precise in detail, he chaired the security council planning board with care and fairness, seeking agreed recommendations or, if these were not attainable, an exact presentation of diverse views for the benefit of the President. He was a cautious, deliberative man who weighed risks carefully; as bankers should be, he was a prudent man.

title: PRICES OF BONDS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: Bond prices climbed sharply yesterday in brisk trading as the markets continued to benefit from dwindling upward pressure on shortterm interest rates and a strong technical position.

title: Anaconda Unit Elects
description: Herbert M. Weed was named yesterday president and chief executive officer of the Anaconda Sales Company, which is part of the company's primary metals division. He will continue as a vice president of the parent Anaconda Company with responsibilities in sales and industry liaison affairs.

title: KNICKS TO REGAIN FRAZIER TONIGHT
description: Refreshed by three days of rest and strengthened by the return of Walt Frazier, the Knicks will attempt to start a new winning streak at Madison Square Garden tonight against the Detroit Pistons.

title: Combining Elections
description: The New York primary election timetable endorsed by the Republican leadership of the State Legislature promises unnecessary cost and confusion. It would confront voters in New York City with an electoral .obstacle course requiring them to appear at the polls no fewer than three times in the space of as many months. This multielection scheme imposes too great burden on the electorate and thus plays into the hands of organization forces who traditionally thrive on low voter turnouts.

title: Dartmouth Wins Slalom, Gains Carnival Lead
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9The Dartmouth College ski team, with a one, three, seven finish in the slalom and a two, five, six performance in the 15kilometer crosscountry race, gained a narrow lead over the University of Vermont today at the midway point of the 63d annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Political Machine Grinds On in Albany City Hall
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  The fortresslike City Hall in the shadow of the gleaming State Capitol matches the reputation of city government here  antiquated, seedy and grimy.

title: Chiefs of Women's Political Unit Differ on Course
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9Leaders of the political arm of the women's rights movement expressed conflicting views today over the direction they should take.

title: Research Funds and Disease Effects Held Out of Step
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Unpublished Government figures show there is often little correlation between the amount of money spent by the United States to conquer a group of diseases and the amount of disability those diseases cause.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CUBAN  The number of Cubans living in New York probably runs into six figures; they are a recent immigration, but the roots are going down and the cultural trees are flowering. Two and a half months ago, some 50 actors, artists, writers, film makers, and musicians, all from Cuba, formed the Cuban Cultural Center of New York. Starting tomorrow the center will make its initial local splash with the first Cuban Festival of the Arts, at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street (86536001, 3695963).

title: GOLDEN CYCLE IN BID FOR GREYHOUND VAN
description: The Golden Cycle Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Greyhound Van Lines, unit of the Greyhound Corporation, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: L.I. Boy Killed by Car
description: PORT JEFFERSON STATION, L. I. Feb. 9 (UPI)A 9yearold boy riding his bicycle was struck and killed by a car today here, the Suffolk County police reported, They said the boy, Joseph Dotts of 6 Newport Drive here, was crossing Jayne Boulevard when he was struck by a southbound car at about; 5:20 P.M. He died a short time later at Mather Memorial Hospital.

title: 1,200 G.I.'s Leave Vietnam; U.S. Forces Down to 18,600
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9 (UPI)A total of 1,200 American servicemen left South Vietnam this week, reducing United States strength there to 18,600 men, military spokesmen said today.

title: Marlborough Concedes Gain in Met Art Deal
description: The Marlborough Gallery has tacitly acknowledged that in its trade with the Metropolitan Museum of Art last June it got more than it gave.

title: BOUNDARY LINES HINDERING TRUCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 9The chairman of the new International Control Commission asserted today that an effective ceasefire was being delayed because the Saigon Government and the Communists have been unable to agree on clear lines separating the territories they hold.

title: Uruguay Defense Minister Quits Under Army Threat
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 9President Juan Maria Bordaberry accepted the resignation of his Defense Minister tonight, bowing to the demands of the army and air force, which had been in virtual rebellion.

title: 2 Shakespearean Classics To Be Televised by A. B. C.
description: The American Broadcasting Company has contracted with two of Britain's most prestigious theater companies for videotaped threehour productions of two Shakespearean classics to be televised during the 197374 season.

title: 11 SEIZED IN HARLEM AT NARCOTICS MILL
description: An East Harlem narcotics mill that processed an estimated total two kilograms of hard drugs a week, $500,000 worth, was said to have been broken up by a combined Federal, state and local narcotics force.

title: Bridge: Clue Found in Defense Bids May Prove False in Game
description: Once the play begins, any bids made by the defending side are likely to help the declarer in judging the distribution. But if the bid on which he bases his inferences is only a halftruth, he may find that he would have been better off with no clues.

title: Dartmouth Wins Slalom, Gains Carnival Lead
description: HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9The Dartmouth College ski team, with a one, three, seven finish in the slalom and a two, five, six performance in the 15kilometer crosscountry race, gained a narrow lead over the University of Vermont today at the midway point of the 63d annual Dartmouth Winter Carnival.

title: TECHNICAL RALLY PUSHES UP STOCKS
description: A strong technical rally rippled through the stock market yesterday, sending prices ahead for their best gain in more than three months.

title: Microphone Reduces Background Noise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9A directional microphone that was patented this week for Bell Laboratories can minimize background noise and pick up a person's voice, even in a large room with other people talking.

title: Jersey Chief Judge Is Planning to Retire
description: NEWARK, Feb. 9 (AP)Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court said yesterday that he would retire before he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 in five years. But Justice Weintraub, who will be 65 years old on March 5, said he had no firm plans to leave the bench immediately.

title: A Real Float for the Franc
description: NANCY, France, Feb. 9 (Reuters)  The franc floated in Eastern France todayliterally. Firemen here recovered about fifty 100franc notes floating on the river Moselle. They said the notes had been thrown on the water by a woman for reasons unknown.

title: Weintraub Announces Plan to Retire
description: TRENTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub of the New Jersey Supreme Court said today that he would retire before he reached the mandatory retirement age of 70 in five years.

title: HANOI WILL FREE 115 U.S. CAPTIVES TOMORROW NIGHT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Pentagon announced today that North Vietnam planned to release about 115 American prisoners of war in Hanoi sometime Sunday night, Eastern standard time, while 27 more prisoners would be turned over by the Vietcong in South Vietnam.

title: Exchanges to Remain Open
description: Most of the nation's securities exchanges and commodities markets will remain open for business Monday on Lincoln's Birthday. However, the New York Cocoa Exchange, the New York Commodities Exchange, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and all banks will be closed.

title: BAR UNIT REJECTS NOFAULT SYSTEM
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 9 Any possibility that the American Bar Association would relax its opposition and support a national system of nofault automobile insurance all but vanished today.

title: SUBPOENAS ISSUED IN BERGEN INQUIRY
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 9 A Federal grand jury, in what appears to be an investigation of the Bergen County Republican organization, has apparently subpoenaed the records of at least 16 companies that supply goods to the party.

title: Maud Sets Back Laver, Smith Gains Semifinal
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9Refusing to yield to tense tiebreaker pressure, unseeded Rob Maud of South Africa upset topseeded Rod Laver in the quarterfinal round of the United States professional indoor tennis championship tonight.

title: HALASZ'S L.I. CHOIR SINGS MOZART MASS
description: Laszlo Halasz, the dynamic artistic and music director of the New York City Opera from 1943 to 1951, has been busy in recent years, principally conducting in Europe and teaching on Long Island. He has also established the Concert Orchestra and Choir of Long Island, which was brought into Town Hall Thursday night by the Cooper Union Forum for its annual Lincoln Day celebration. It was Mr. Halasz's first appearance here in a dozen years.

title: Longshore Pay Bid Lost
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Cost of Living Council has rejected a request by West Coast longshoremen to reinstate a 3Qcent an hour pay raise turned down by the Pay Board under old wageprice controls. A spokesman said that the council would not release copy of a letter sent to the union and to the companies until they had received it. The letter was sent yesterday.

title: Is It Really Reality?
description: Reality's shortcomings have infected me with a sense of permanent daily disappointmenteven the egg cream which I consume every evening before dinner is now a pale shadow of its former glorious self.

title: Paul Strand Photo Show Opens Here
description: Hilton Kramer reviewed the Paul Strand exhibition in 1971, November, 1971 when it appeared at the Philadelphia Museum of Art. After a national tour, it opens today at the Metropolitan Museum. Following is an excerpt from the original review.

title: To Save a Kangaroo
description: The kangaroo is a unique and fascinating animal, intriguing to adults as it is delightful to the imagination of children the world over who make its acquaintance in their storybooks. But like the dolphin, the whale, the tiger and other highly distinctive members of the animal kingdom, the kangaroo has been taken for granted and frivolously slaughtered to make women's shoes and cat food.

title: Mayor Swears In 3 Judges In Ceremony at City Hall
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday swore in three judges, two of whom are new. The third, who had been filling out an unexpired term, was appointed for a full 10year term.

title: Poetry Ain't Going to Feed Me Always
description: This excerpted interview with Bobby Seale appeared in The Black Scholar, a journal of black studies and research.

title: Ellsberg Trial Told Public Data Could Aid Foreign Intelligence
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9  The major prosecution witness in the Pentagon papers trial said today that, as far as he was concerned, a geography book, public opinion polls and transcripts of Congressional hearingsall public informationcould be helpful to foreign intelligence analysts.

title: WINE TALK
description: First, a bit of timely assistance for men seeking that perfect Valentine's Day gift. Were you considering a big red heart filled with candy? Or a trinket from Cartier? Why not slip her a fifth of the new whisky for women, Lady Like?

title: Concert: Opera Scenes
description: In its annual series of concerts at Carnegie Hall, the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra has been making it a practice to bring us excerpts from operas that have been all but submerged by history. This season's repatriates from the Sargasso Sea include Pfitzner's Pelestrina, presented last December, and Massenet's Cendrillon, which Henry Lewis conducted on Thursday night.

title: TOLL IS SET AT 16 IN COAST JET CRASH
description: ALAMEDA, Calif., Feb. 9 The Alameda County coroner's office estimated tonight that no more than 15 or 16 residents of an apartment house here died when a Navy, fighterbomber crashed into it Wednesday night.

title: Rangers Face Islanders Tonight Seek 10 thin Row
description: Searching for their 10th straight victorysomething no Ranger team has done in 33 years  the Rangers tonight Tam the Islanders at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: POSTAL SERVICE TO GRANT RAISES
description: WASHINGTON; Feb. 9 The United States Postal Service announced today that it would grant scheduled pay increases totaling more than $40.8million to managers and supervisors unless restrained by the Cost of Living Council within one week.

title: PENN FIVE BEATS COLUMBIA, 7459
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9 When Pennsylvania and Columbia went through the first three minutes of their Ivy League game tonight without scoring a point, one woman in the crowd of 6,544 at the Palestra said, That's what happens when you let scholars play the game.

title: HUNT LINKED TO TALK OF SPY ON KENNEDY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP)E. Howard Hunt Jr. tried to recruit a former motel public relations director at Hyannis Port, Mass., to spy on Senator Edward M. Kennedy during the same month that Hunt started working at the White House, The Washington Post reports.

title: Music: Bernstein's Way
description: We have been getting a lot of Haydn at the New York Philharmonic this season, conducted by a variety of conductors. Thursday evening it was Leonard Bernstein's turn, with the Symphony No. 95 in C minor. Haydn sounded different, and the Philharmonic sounded different. Pierre Boulez, who has been concentrating on Haydn, has rather aseptic ideas about the composer. His approach is analytical. Mr. Bernstein's, as always, was warm and rich.

title: Stennis Condition Reported As Gradually Improving
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Physicians attending Senator John C. Stennis, wounded by gunfire Jan. 30, said today they were pleased with his response to treatment and continued gradual improvement.

title: Trading Is Active Here  Fed Does Not Intervene
description: The dollar sank well below its official floor in relation to both the West German mark and the Dutch guilder in active trading yesterday in the New York foreignexchange market.

title: LostDrug bignouts Laid to One Person
description: Preliminary analysis of the signatures on nine vouchers from the Police Department property clerk's office indicates that one person signed the names of both Detective Joseph N. Nunziata and three other policemen when checking out 398 p6unds of nowmissing narcotics, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: It's Cheaper to Walk
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (UPI) Robert Ferrell, a University of California, Los Angeles, football player, was taken in custoday by the police today for ignoring 95 parking tickets carrying fines totaling more than $1,000. There's just no place to park at U.C.L.A., the police quoted Ferrell as saying.

title: Airlines' Bid for Fare Rise Is Dismissed by the C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board dismissed today petitions of the scheduled airlines for a fare increase to cover costs of newly ordered airport security measures.

title: Stankiewicz Sculptures Reveal Striking Authority
description: The exhibition of recent works by the sculptor Richard Stankiewicz now on view at the Zabriskie Gallery, 29 West 57th Street, has all the excitement of a breakthrough. It reveals the artist working at top bent and with striking authority. Mr. Stankiewicz's exhibition last year was in the nature of a comeback; the artist had been absent from the New York scene for seven years and his work, at that time, marked a distinct break from the usually humorous foundobject sculptures on which his reputation was based in the fifties and early sixties.

title: People and Business
description: Dr. Thomas O. Paine, the former head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration and now a vice president of the General Electric Company, said yesterday that the current energy crisis would not exist if certain ccnditions had not preceded it.

title: VARIO CONVICTED OF TAX EVASION
description: A Federal jury deliberated for 90 minutes yesterday and convicted Paul Vario, a 58yearold gambling figure, on all counts of a threecount indictment charging conspiracy to evade Federal income taxes on money from illegal gambling operations.

title: Dr. Henry Bullock, 66, A Noted Black Educator
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 9 (AP) Dr. Henry Allen Bullock, wellknown educator, died yesterday. He was 66 years old.

title: Estate Forgeries Are Charged By Late Senator Long's Family
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 9The Federal Bureau of Investigation is checking into the tangled affairs of the late Senator Edward V. Long, Democrat of Missouri.

title: SURCHARGE ISSUE VEXES EUROPEANS
description: DAVOS, Switzerland, Feb. 9 Reports that the Nixon Administration is considering use of an import surcharge to help correct the American balanceofpayments deficit has drawn a prickly reaction among Europeans concerned with trade.

title: BETHLEHEM STEEL FACES RIGHTS TEST
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 Black workers at the Bethele hem Steel Corporation's plant at Sparrows Point, Md., together with a civil rights group, are planning direct action to end alleged discrimination in jobs there after deciding that recent Government rulings are insufficient.

title: Ohio StateMinnesota: Many Eyes Watching
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 9 (AP)Minnesota and Ohio State meet tomorrow in the renewal of their Big Ten rivalry. A national television audience will be watching the behavior of players and fans as much as the game.

title: The Shotgun Approach
description: Ambush attacks have taken a heavy toll of police officers in New York and other cities across the country. These unprovoked, cowardly assaults are a serious challenge, not only to the police whose lives are on the line, but to the safety of the entire community.

title: Monmouth Swimmers Win
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N. J., Feb. 9The Monmouth College swimmers defeated St. John's, 6251, tonight at the Monmouth pool to remain unbeaten in the Metropolitan College Conference. The loss was the first for St. John's in the conference.

title: Political Machine Grinds On in Albany City Hall
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9  The fortresslike City Hall in the shadow of the gleaming State Capitol matches the reputation of city government here  antiquated, seedy and grimy.

title: Germans and British Meet With French on Dollar
description: PARIS, Feb. 8West German and British finance ministers flew here unexpectedly tonight for urgent talks with France on a European solution to the latest dollar crisis, The ministers met for dinner, in the apartment of French Finance Minister Valery Giscard d'Estaing. British Chancellor of the Exchequer Anthony Barber flew home afterward and German Finance Minister Helmut Schmidt did not reveal his plans.

title: RIZZO LIFTS OFFER IN SCHOOL STRIKE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9This city's bitter 25dayold school strike escalated today with the imposition of prison sentences against two top offidais of the recalcitrant Philadelphia Federation of Teachers, a pledge of support for the striking teachers by some 40 other unions and a promise by Mayor Frank L. Rizzo to provide $10million more to sweetthe offer to the teachers.

title: LAWYERS ASSAIL POLICE ON FILES
description: Lawyers representing a group of political activists in a pending Federal suit aimed at restricting the intelligence activities of the police here said yesterday that the purging of more than a million names from police files was totally misleading.

title: G.I. Escorts Await the Prisoners
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 9A few days ago, Sgt. 1st Cl. Horace Purifoy and Sgt. 1st Cl. Robert L. Cutting of the Army walked over to the base uniform store to polish buttons and other brass belonging to two men they have never met but already know.

title: Soviet Union Said to Bar 10 U.S. Religious Leaders
description: WASHINGTON, (AP) Representative Robert F. Drinan, Democrat of Massachusetts, a Roman Catholic priest, said today that the Soviet Union has barred him and nine other religious leaders seeking to investigate the plight of Soviet Jews.

title: LostDrug Signouts Laid to One Person
description: Preliminary analysis of the signatures on nine vouchers from the Police Department property clerk's office indicates that one person signed the names of both Detective Joseph N. Nunziata and three other policemen when checking out 398 pounds of nowmissing narcotics, according to a source close to the investigation.

title: Liberal Party Fills Post
description: ROCHESTER, Feb. 9 (AP)Mrs. Florence Carpenter was named chairman of the Monroe County Liberay Party Committee today. Mrs. Carpenter, 59yearold widow, succeeds Rafael Martinez, who resigned. No reason was given for his resignation.

title: $2 Turns to Riches
description: ARCADIA, Cali., Feb. 9 (UPI)Turn to Riches won the second race at Santa Anita ltoday, returning $174, $48.80 and $13.40 for $2 across the board.

title: P.O.W.'s Will Get the News, 1965 to 1971
description: BETHESDA, Md., Feld. 9 The first entry is the inauguration of President Johnson in January, 1965; the last, the June, 1971, Supreme Court decision on state aid to nonpublic schools. Packed into the pages between is a cram course in eventsthatwerecurrent in the world outside the prisonerofwar camps in Vietnam.

title: Van Pelt Quits Basketball
description: EAST LANSING, Mich, Feb. (UPI)Brad Van Pelt, Michigan State's star allround athlete who was selected early in this year's professional football and baseball drafts, has quit the University basketball team to concentrate on varsity baseball. The 225pound senior had hoped to be the first Spartan in 20 years to win nine letters. He was drafted by the New York Giants in football and by the St. Louis Cardinals in baseball.

title: SCHOOL AIDE LISTS 374 DRUG ARRESTS
description: A total of 374 Board of Education employes, including 103 teachers, have been arrested in the last six and a half years for the possession or sale of drugs, a board official said yesterday.

title: KATHY WHITWORTH GAINS 3SHOT LEAD
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 9 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, the leading moneywinner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, carded a fourunderpar 68 today and took a threestroke lead after firstround play in the NaplesLely Golf Classic.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Detective Says. Man Confessed to Fire

title: The New Cool
description: In his speech to the Oxford Union, George McGovern said that he'd appealed to our idealism, and that he couldn't understand why sq many of us voted for Richard Nixon, a man we don't like. Mr. McGovern can't understand what happened because he judges idealism and likableness by the obsolete standards of the Old Charisma. The Old HollywoodCamelotstyle Charisma.

title: Owners Wait as Players Study Peace Pitch
description: From Charles O. Finley to Bowie K. Kuhn, which is quite a distance in baseball rapport, the feeling was being voiced yesterday that no shutdown was imminent on the bigleague labor front. Their optimism developed in spite of the directive by the American and National Leagues on Thursday not to open spring training until the club owners and players settled their general dispute. The decision, if it lasts, would delay the start of the early camps for pitchers and catchers next week.

title: New Mexico Court Upsets Portions of Abortion Law
description: SANTA FE, N.M., Feb. 9 (AP) The New Mexico Court of Appeals ruled today that major portions of the state's criminal abortion law were unconstitutional.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In his Statler Hilton hotel room, Ray Satterfield had been watching television.

title: Joseph W. Beach, 84 Dies; Former Mayor of Hartford
description: CHATHAM, Mass., Feb. 9Joseph Watson Beach, Mayor of Hartford from 1933 to 1935 and a former director of the Travelers Insurance Companies died yesterday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: 2 Sailors Die From Burns After Blast on Destroyer
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Feb. (AP)Two sailors being treated for burns they suffered in boiler room explosion aboard the destroyer U.S.S. Basilone died today at the Brooke Army Medical Center here.

title: Shepherd of Rail Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9After World War II service, as a Navy pilot, Harrison Arlington Williams Jr. did a brief stint at a steel mill, but did not like it. He then became a dictationtypist at United Press, but couldn't type. So he became a copy boy at The Washington Post, but decided, as he recalled last year, that deadlines were unimportant stuff. Yesterday, morning, however, it was a different story. The New Jersey Democrat zipped into his office about 9 o'clock, assembled some staff members of the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee, of which he is chairman, made some phone calls, convened a hearing and by late afternoon had secured Congressional passage of a resolution halting for at least 90 days the strike of the Penn Central Railroad that had begun at midnight.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Fell at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Beauty Salon Owner Drops SexBias Fight
description: Mrs. Ila Kraus, owner of the beauty salon in the St. RegisSheraton Hotel, has given up her fiveyear fight against charges that she discriminated against a male hairdresser. After spending nearly a day in jail, she paid a $250 contemptofcourt fine and agreed to rehire the hairdresser, Richard Read.

title: Quarry Wins by a Decision, Giving Lyle First Ring Loss
description: Jerry Quarry called it persistency, but that was about all Ron Lyle showed last night in his heralded debut at Madison Square Garden.

title: Sanderson to Suit Up
description: BOSTON, Feb, 9 (AP)Coach Bep Guidolin of the Boston Bruins said today that Derek Sanderson would be in uniform tomorrow afternoon for a National Hockey League game with the Pittsburgh Penguins.

title: Consent Decree on I.O.S. Signed by James Roosevelt
description: James Roosevelt, eldest son of President Franklin D. Roosevelt, signed a consent decree here yesterday to sever himself from the fraud suit of the Securities and Exchange Commission against Robert L. Vesco and 40 others.

title: GUESS WHO MAKES IT WITH FAITHFUL ROCK
description: Canada takes its rock music a little more seriously than the United Statesthe Canadian Government hands out subsidies, radio insists on a 30 per cent Canadian content ruling and Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau finds an occasional appearance at rock concerts good for an image beef. But for all that, the Canadian dream is still to make it in this country.

title: KAWAIDA BUILDER TO RESUME WORK
description: NEWARK, Feb. 9The contractor for the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project said today that he would, move workers and equipment onto the construction site Monday.

title: St. John's, Fordham, Will Meet on Court Today for 55thTime
description: The record favors St. John's, but emotionalism may be the decisive factor today at Madison Square Garden when the Redmen meet Fordham for the 55th time in a basketball series that began in 1907.

title: Miss Jill C. Werdann Bride of James Bauer
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Feb, 9  Miss Jill C. Werdann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs, John Werdann of Freeport, L.I., was married here this afternoon to James L. Bauer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bauer of Forest Hills, Queens, New York. Justice of the Peace J. Leo Sullivan performed the ceremony in his office.

title: Money and Politics
description: PARIS, Feb. 9The latest international monetary crisis came as a surprise only in timing and specifics. It was there growing all the time and the basic ques tion has not changedwhat is going to be done about it?

title: SOUTH KOREA VOTE ORDERED FOR FEB. 27
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 The South Korean Government decided today to hold national elections on Feb. 27 to elect a new legislature. Under the revised constitution, the voters will choose twothirds of the 219 lawmakers, and President Park Chung Hee will appoint the remaining third.

title: LAWYERS ASSAIL POLICE ON FILES
description: Lawyers representing a group of political activists in a pending Federal suit aimed at restricting the intelligence activities of the police here said yesterday that the purging of more than a million names from police files was totally misleading.

title: No. Carolina State Beats Clemson for 18th Straight
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 9 (AP)David Thompson scored 30 points, 21 in the second half, as he rallied unbeaten North Carolina State to a 6861 Atlantic Conference basketball victory over Clemson tonight in the second game of a doubleheader.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: British Bill Rate Drops
description: LONDON, Feb. 9 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British treasury bills fell to 8.0902 per cent. This week's 60  million offer of 91 days bills met applications of 247,945,000. Applicants for bills dated Monday to Friday at 97.975 received about 17 per cent. Next week 160million bills will be offered, replacing 80million of maturities.

title: RAMMON MULFORD OF OWENSILLINOIS
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 9Raymon H. Mulford, chairman of the board of directors of OwensIllinois, Inc., the glassmaking company, died in his sleep today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: ERICH CAHN
description: Erich Cahn, a seed merchant, died, apparently of a heart attack, at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday. He was 73 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

title: Secret Paris Pact on Laos And Cambodia Disclosed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States and North Vietnam agreed secretly in their negotiations in Paris last month that a ban on foreign military activity in Laos and Cambodia would not take effect immediately, sources in the Nixon Administration reported today.

title: Jewish Leaders to Fight Housing Ruling
description: Jewish community leaders on the Lower East Side met yesterday to plan appeals and other action to fight a Federal Court ruling that found the city had acted illegally in leasing apartments in a new public housing project to a group of families, most of whom are Jewish.

title: Catskill Building Where 8 Died Called a Firetrap by Survivor
description: A teenage survivor of a fire that took the lives of eight young fellow employes of a Catskill Mountain resort hotel told state legislators yesterday that their dormitory had been decrepit and filled with fire hazards long before the fatal blaze.

title: Penn Central Operating Again; Nixon Signs Bill Halting Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Penn Central Railroad resumed virtually full operations this morning as United Transportation Union crewmen began returning to work even before President Nixon signed legislation ending their oneday strike early today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Commissioner of Public Works of the Town of Oyster Bay has been suspended without pay from his $30,000ayear job because of alleged irregularities in the administration of his office.

title: London, Paris Recognize East Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 9Britain and France formally recognized East Germany today, leaving the United States the last of the Big Three Western powers without official ties with the Communist German state.

title: Hawks Beat Flames, 43, With ThirdPeriod Rally
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 9 (AP)Dennis Hull scored two goals in the third period as the Chicago Black Hawks rallied from a 30 deficit to defeat the Atlanta Flames, 43, in a National Hockey League game tonight.

title: U.S., at Request of Laos, Halts Briefings on War
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 9  A United States spokesman announced today that at the request of the Laotian Government American sources here would no longer provide newsmen with information on the military situation. He said the request had been made in view of the current sensitive stage in peace negotiations.

title: KAVALEK DEFEATED BY BYRNE IN CHESS
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 9 (AP) Robert Byrne defeated Lubomir Kavalek here early today in the fifth game of the United States Chess Championship playoffs.

title: Art: Beautiful Sculpture by Nagare
description: Masayuki Nagare's Bachi, an 8foot granite sculpture at the Staernpfli Gallery, 47 East 77th Street, may not be the most beautiful piece of stone on exhibition in New York just nowsince, after all, there are some quite wonderful ones from ancient Greece, the Buddhist Orient, medieval Europe and elsewhere, standing around in, for instance, the Metropolitan Museum. But Bachi deserves a superlative as most beautiful in some less inclusive but far from minor classification.

title: Death Penalty Voted
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 9 (UPI)The Washington State Senate voted today, 40 to 6, to require the death penalty for killing a uniformed policeman or fireman in the performance of his duty. The death penalty would also be mandatory for killing a prison guard, murder committed while resisting arrest or escaping from jail or an institution, and murder committed for hire. The bill was sent to the House.

title: Crime Figure and 7 Indicted in Newark As Drug Smugglers
description: NEWARK, Feb. 9 (UPI)The Government announced today that eight persons including one man identified as a leading figure in organized crime in Montreal, had been indicted on charges related to an alleged multimilliondollar heroin smuggling operation spanning three countries.

title: Legislation Planned To Let State Agency Give Flood Warning
description: ALBANY, Feb. 9As a result of a Senate investigation of state flood warning systems following the tropical storm Agnes last June, a bill will be introduced in the Legislature to extend the authority of the State Civil Defense Commission to cover natural disasters.

title: Lunokhod 2 Is Reactivated After 2Week Lunar Night
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9 (UPI)The Lunokhod 2 moon rover today ended its twoweek mechanical hibernation in the freezing lunar night and resumed exploration of the moon's surface, Tass, the Soviet press agency said.

title: Remedies Sought
Miss Consuelo Hutton Married Here
description: Miss Consuelo Virginia Hutton and Henry White SeherrThoss of New York were married here yesterday afternoon in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More by the pastor, Msgr. James G. Wilders.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Groups Here to Tip Their Top Hits to Astaire at Champagne Party
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 9 Top hat. White gloves. Cane. For the last 40 years, these whitetie accessories have symbolized Fred Astaire, the dancingest man in show business. Some movie stars are remembered for their voices or profiles or measurements. A few are famous for their acting but Fred Astaire transcended the rules for celebrity.

title: Kissinger Flies From Laos to Hanoi
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Saturday, Feb. 10Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser for national security, left here today for Hanoi, saying that he expected his trip would usher in an era of peace for all of Indochina.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: RIGHTS UNIT SAYS NIXON STILL LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States Commission on Civil Rights, for the fourth time in three years, painted today a bleak picture of the Nixon Administration's enforcement of laws and regulations affecting minority groups.

title: SMOOTHER U.S. ROLE WITH E.E.C. IS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI)  President Nixon has been urged to consult with Congress to seek ways of smoothing over the misunderstanding be. tween the United States and European Economic Community on trade and monetary matters.

title: Bridge Traffic Tied Up
description: Manhattanbound traffic on the lower level of the Queensboro Bridge was tied up for nearly an hour around noon yesterday when a van, cut off by another vehicle, struck a girder and overturned, the police reported. The drive escaped injury.

title: $59,375 Paid at Sale For 89 Halpert Prints
description: Eightynine prints from the art collection of the late Edith G. Halpert and the Downtown Gallery, which she owned and directed, were auctioned for $59,375 in a twoday sale that ended yesterday.

title: TV: Stage Version of Peanuts and Duke Ellington
description: You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown still on television. Ditto the Duke, or rather Edward Kennedy Ellington.

title: Groups Here to Tip Their Top Hats to Astaire at Champagne Party
description: HOLLYWOOD, Feb. 9Top hat White gloves. Cane. For the last 40 years, these whitetie accessories have symbolized Fred Astaire, the dancingest man in show business. Some movie stars are remembered for their voices or profiles or measurements. A few are famous for their acting. But rrea Astaire transcended the rules for celebrity.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. 9 (AP)Venice Borkorsor, the World Boxing Council flyweight champion, retained his title tonight by gaining a unanimous decision over Erbito Salavarria of the Philippines in a 15round bout. There were no knockdowns.

title: Penn Central Operating Again; Nixon Signs Bill Halting Strike
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Penn Central Railroad resumed virtually full operations this morning as United Transportation Union crewnen began returning to work even before President Nixon signed legislation ending their oneday strike early today.

title: Cranston's Son Cleared
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 9 (UPI) The 25yearold son of Senafor Alan Cranston, Democrat of California, was found not guilty today of drugging a former Playboy bunny. Robin Cranston haday been charged with giving a grape drink laced with hallucinogen to Joyce Williams, 23, last March.

title: Soviet Seeks to Bar Dissident Periodical
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 9The Soviet secret police, widening their yearold campaign to snuff out the main underground publication of the last four years, today questioned the wife of Andrei Amalrik, a prominent dissident writer who is now finishing a term In a Siberian labor camp, according to unofcial sources.

title: BRANDT SEEKS AID IN MONEY CRISIS; $2BILLION BOUGHT
description: BONN, Feb. 9Chancellor Willy Brandt conferred by telephone today with President Nixon, Prime Minister Heath of Britain and President Pompidou of France and asked their cooperation in the continuing monetary crisis that by day's end had forced. West Germany to buy up two billion more unwanted dollars.

title: The Unmighty Dollar
description: LONDON, Feb. 9Just over a year ago the leading central bankers and finance ministers met at the Smithsonian Institution, Washington, to grapple with an international currency crisis. When they ended on an agreed formula, President Nixon hailed as the most significant monetary achievement in the history of the world.

title: Acidental U.S. Bombing In Thailand Is Reported
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb. (AP)The newspaper Bangkok World said today that United States Air Force jet bombers dropped 20 bombs Tuesday in rice field in Udorn Province, about 250 miles northeast of Bangkok, killing one farmer and destroying two huts.

title: Notes on People
description: Frank Sinatra, the entertainer, billed the House Select Committee on Crime for $18,750 in travel and living expenses for the day he appeared before the committee last July. However, a spokesman for the committee said Mr. Sinatra declined to file an expense voucher after learning that he was entitled to only $20 plug commercial air fare. He had asked tote reimbursed for leasing an aircraft to attend the hearing and $750 in living expenses for the oneday appearance. The committee, which was holding hearings on organized crime's influence in horse racing, wanted to ask Mr. Sinatra about the $55,000 he invested in the now defunct Berkshire Downs racein Mass.

title: Padded Club
description: The first whacks of the Phase 3 club in the closet. have been carefully swathed in velvet, but that has not softened the message the blows were intended to deliver: the Cost of Living Council will allow no walkaway from wage or price limits ordered by its disbanded predecessors, the Pay Board and the Price Commission.

title: Barnes, Providence Center, Pleads Not Guilty to Assault
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 9 (AP)Marvin Barnes, the star center of Providence College and the nation's top rebounder, today pleaded not guilty to a charge of assault with a dangerous weapon.

title: MRS. WALTER DIAMOND
description: Mrs. Jeanette Diamond, the wife of Walter Diamond, a metal merchant here, died Thursday. She was 81 years old and lived at 1060 Fifth Avenue.

title: GOV. CARTER SEES HOAX IN U.S, AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9Gov. Jimmy Carter of Georgia said today that the Federal Government was deteriorating on both sides of the current power struggle herethe executive branch because of what he described as President Nixon's reclusive insensitivity, and Congress by what he viewed as drift and internal secrecy.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Arts Institute Elects Eight

title: Ghost of Liston No Help To Lyle in Garden Ring
description: The ghost of the late Sonny Liston hung over the Madison Square Garden ring last night. But that's all it was a ghost.

title: Antiques: Miniature Furniture and a View of Why It Was Made
description: Nobody knows exactly who handcarvedand for what reasonmost of the miniature furnishings so lionized by today's antiques collectors. But Herbert F. and Peter B. Schiffer have made a strong argument against one traditionally held beliefthat these, for the most part unsigned, Lilliputian lowboys, highboys, desks, chairs and chests were devised as display samples by cabinetmakers, their apprentices or itinerant artisans.

title: Resolving the Crisis
description: Huge waves of selling hit the dollar again yesterday in Frankfurt, Tokyo and other world financial centers. The significance of the crisis is understated by the billions of dollars being exchanged for foreign currencies. For what is at stake is not only the financial stability of the nonCommunist world but also its political solidarity.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Quarter Profit Down
description: American Airlines reported yesterday 1972 earnings of $5.6million, or 20 cents share, on revenues of $1.4billion.

title: New School Bus Standards Expected in Three Weeks
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (UPI) The Government will issue new school bus standards, perhaps by the end of the month, that could force manufacturers to equip new school buses with seat belts, sources said today.

title: N.C.A.A. Lists Violations By S.W. Louisiana Five
description: LAKE CHARLES, La., Feb. 9 (AP)Dwight Lamar, college basketball's leading scorer last season, and Roy Ebron, a 6foot9inch center, were named today among players allegedly paid to play for Southwestern Louisiana.

title: U.S. COURT BLOCKS PERMITS TO BUILD ALASKAN PIPELINE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit blocked today the issuance of Government permits for building a transAlaska oil pipeline.

title: Fronk Rosenblum, 85, Leader Of Clothing Workers, Is Dead
description: Frank Rosenblum, a founder of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, died yesterday at his home in Chicago. He was 85 years old.

title: In English Area of Montreal, a New Breed
description: WESTMOUNT, Quebec, Feb. 8The owner of a red brick house in this most elegant neighborhood of Montreal recently posted a for sale sign that bore this plaintive pitch:

title: Hunt On for Strangler in Jersey Town
description: WESTFIELD, N. J., Feb. 9Detectives of the Union County Prosecutor's office and the Police Department of this quiet residential community have begun the plodding, painstaking task of searching for the strangler of Linda Celeste Sisko, a 25yearold secretary.

title: MORRISONKNUDSEN SETS AFRICAN DEAL
description: The MorrisonKnudsen Company announced yesterday that it had signed a contract to design and build an 1,100mile extrahighvoltage transmission line across the Republic of Zaire in Central Africa.

title: FASHION TALK
description: If anyone wants to buy a dress from the Soviet Union, We'll take her measurements and have one made in Moscow, Yvonne Burbage, the fashion director of Hess's in Allentown, Pa., explained yesterday. She was in New York with four outfits that had arrived for her store this week from Moscow.

title: NUCLEAR TEST SET IN SHALE DEPOSIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The Department of the Interior, in a reversal of its earlier position, said today in a joint announcement with the Atomic Energy Commission that it had decided to go ahead with an expertmental underground nuclear explosion in the oil shale lands of Western Colorado.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHTS GAME

title: 5 Saved in Flooded Mine
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., Feb. 9 (UPI)Five miners were rescued unharmed today after water flooded the deep shaft in which they were working. The five were underground for about four hours. Four other miners escaped from the Ranger Fuel Company mine near Bolt, in southern, West Virginia, minutes after the mine crew accidentally broke into an abandoned shaft that was flooded with water.

title: There's Enough Fuel
description: TRENTON, Feb, 9 (UPI) Barring a long cold spell, supplies of heating fuel appear to be adequate for the rest of the winter in New Jersey, the Cahill administration said today. The Governor's cabinet Committee on Energy decided, however, to ask electric and gas companies to consider shifting from oil to an alternate fuel source.

title: Business Briefs
description: The Federal Court in St. Paul, Minn., yesterday denied the motion of the Telex Corporation to set aside the recent outofcourt settlement of the antitrust suit between the Control Data Corporation and the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Urban Transit Aid Scores Point
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 New York area Representatives who have been pushing without much success for several years to get Federal operating aid for urban masstransit systems scored an unpublicized victory this week when Democrats on the House Banking and Currency Committee voted to create a separate subcommittee to handle masstransit legislation. The Democratic committee members voted, 12 to 10, to create the subcommittee. Representative Joseph G. Minish, a New Jersey Democrat who has sponsored bills to provide Federal operating subsidies for urban masstransit systems, was designated chairman of the new unit.

title: Senator Turns Himself In on Plot Charge
description: TRENTON, Feb. 9  State Senator James Turner, a Gloucester County Republican, gave himself up to the state police near here today after he was ordered arrested on charges that he conspired to incrimirate a Gloucester Democratic Assemblyman by having drugs planted in the Assemblyman's home.

title: SOYBEAN PRICES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Soybeans almost jumped the 10centabushel limit yesterday once again and they did make new historic high price. The new high became $5.57 a bushel, up from Thursday's close, also the former record high of $5.48.

title: Dragnet Is On for the Strangler Of Woman, 25, in Westfield
description: WESTFIELD, Feb. 9Detectives of the Union County prosecutor's office and the Police Department of this quiet residential community have begun the plodding, painstaking task of searching for the strangler of Linda Celest Sisko, a 25yearold secretary.

title: Hockey Star Quits College
description: BOSTON, Feb. 9 (AP)Boston University reported today that its sophomore hockey star, Dick Decloe of Mississauga, Ontario, had withdrawn from school to play in the Junior A amateur ranks in Canada. Decloe recently was declared ineligible by the Eastern College Athletic Conference for allegedly accepting educational expenses before enrolling at B.U.

title: ROBERT M. COATES, WRITER, 75, DEAD
description: Robert M. Coates, novelist, shortstory writer and a staff member of The New Yorker magazine since 1927, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after surgery. He was 75 years old and lived in Old Chatham, N. Y.

title: 2,000 Attend Dinner in Honor of Hoffa
description: CHERRY HILL, N. J., Feb. Two thousand friends and supporters of James R. Hoffa turned out tonight to honor the former president of the teamsters union and, some suggested, to begin a movement to restore him eventually to the top post in the twomillion member union.

title: FRANK O'CRAVEN, 71, NIGHTCLUB PIANIST
description: Frank O'Craven, who as Knuckles O'Craven played nostalgic piano melodies nightly at Bill's Gay Nineties at 57 East 54th Street, died Thursday at his home in the Henry Hudson Hotel, 353 West 57th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: Flu and Pneumonia Deaths Continue to Rise in Nation
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 9 (AP) Deaths from influenza and pneumonia continue to rise in the United States, although most regions report a decline in the number of cases, the Federal Center for Disease Control reported today.

title: Monetary Developments
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif.The Western White House announced that President Nixon is sending Peter G. Peterson, former Secretary of Commerce, to Europe next week on a factfinding mission. He is expected to convey the President's concern over the monetary crisis.

title: RIGHTS UNIT SAYS NIXON STILL LAGS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 9The United States Commission on Civil Rights, for the fourth time in three years, painted today a bleak picture of the Nixon Administration's enforcement of laws and regulations affecting minority groups.

title: Frank Frisch Breaks Back in Car Crash
description: ELKTON, Md., Feb. 9 (UPI) Frankie Frisch, playermanager of the St. Louis Cardinals' Gas House Gang of four decades ago, was in serious condition today at Union Hospital here after he was hurt in an automobile accident late yesterday.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL BACKS ALIEN DRAGNETS
description: After a review of the investigative operations of the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service here, Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst, has endorsed the periodic roundups of illegal aliens in the city by the agency.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the article To Buy a House Is to Buy a School District [Jan. 28], Myrna Wachsman mentioned specific school systems in northern Westchester along with her reasons for ruling them out. Such unnecessary, thoughtless and negative personal references undoubtedly damaged the reputations of some fine school systems.

title: Dominican Republic
description: MEXICO CITYThe scenario was bizarre. Last Monday, President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic announced that 10 armed guerrillas had landed on the country's southwest coast. For the next few days, radios and newspapers reported that hundreds  perhaps as many as 2,000  Dominican soldiers were chasing the 10 guerrillas through the woods. Tanks and armored cars moved into Santo Domingo, the capital, and took up positions near the university and a key bridge. Police occupied the home of former President Juan Bosch, and the Government claimed that Mr. Bosch was at least partly responsible for the invasion.

title: Today to Be Doggy Here With 20 Special Shows
description: The Chinese Year of the Ox started last Saturday, with appropriate ceremonies here. The Week of the Dog started here yesterday, with four specialties. It continues today with 20 more.

title: Gypsy Moth Spraying Urged
description: If New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation has its way, 40, 000 acres of Long Island woodland, mostly in eastern Suffolk County, will be sprayed from the air in May to eliminate this spring's influx of gypsy moths.

title: Jail a Newsman and You Lock Up the News
description: I AM tempted to reflect today on how tremendously broadcasting has changed and progressed over the span of years we have shared. But there are more pressing matters and one, particularly, would seem to lay special claim to our attention this morning. That subject is the dismaying and very serious assault that has developed, in the courts and elsewhere, against newsmen's rights and the public's right to receive an unrestricted flow of information.

title: Works of Best Artists Are Displayed in Morristown
description: MORRISTOWNWho are New Jersey's most distinguished artists? The New Jersey State Council on the Arts Is currently presenting ?? answer to that question with an exhibition, at the Morris Museum of Arts and Sciences, of 33 paintings, graphics and sculpture by a dozen contributors. The exhibit will continue through March 15.

title: Future Social Events
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: Army Triumphs in Track Over C. W. Post, Rutgers
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., Feb. 10 Army used its depth to score a triangular track meet victory against C. W. Post and Rutgers today. Army had 71 points, Post 60 and Rutgers 16.

title: HUNGARIANS HOPE TO REGAIN CROWN
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 9  More than 28 years ago, as artillery of the advancing Soviet Army rumbled in the distance, a special train, left Budapest, for the Austrian border.

title: Downtown Areas Given New Hope
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  While the central business districts In many of Nassau County's villages have had to contend with a loss of business since the advent of shopping centers in the county in the last 20 years, they may experience a resurgence because of the lack of available developable land in the county.

title: The teachings of Don B.:
description: While doing anthropological field work in Manhattan some years ago I met, on West 11th Street, a male Yankee of indeterminate age whose name, I was told, was Don B. I found him leaning against a building in a profound torporperhaps the profoundest torpor I have ever seen. He was a tallish man with an unconvincing beard and was dressed, in the fashion of the Village, in jeans and a blue work shirt. After we had been introduced, by a mutual acquaintance, I explained to him that I had been told he knew the secrets of certain hallucinogenic substances peculiar to Yankee culture and in which I was professionally interested. I expressed a wish to learn what he knew and asked if I might talk with him about the subject. He simply stared at me without replying, and then said, No. However, taking note of the dismay which must have been plain on my face, he said that I might return, if I wished, in two years. In the meantime, he would think about my proposal. Then he closed his again, and I left him.

title: 10 Dogs Found Poisoned
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 10 (UPI)Ten dogs were found dead in one city block late yesterday, two days after Don Smith, an animal control officer, said he received an irate call from a man who said he was going to spread poison in the area. Mr. Smith said the 10 dogs were obviously poisoned,

title: My view, my approach, is probably hat of a Disraeli conservative
description: Asked which British Prime Minister they most admired, both Harold Macmillan and Harold Wilson had no hesitationSir Robert Walpole, who stayed in office for 21 years and left his party in office for nearly a century; a man who mixed consummate wheeling and dealing with such sound policy that he created a monolithic political stability. The same English statesman fascinated President Kennedy. Other British and American politicians have opted for Chatham and Pitt, a few for Peel and Gladstone as their heroes. But Disraeli? Not, one would have thought, a politician's politician, even less a statesman's statesman. But first Henry Kissinger referred to himself as being a Disraelian conservative in domestic matters and then Daniel P. Moynihan, having read Robert Blake's Disraeli, passed it on to President Nixon, who, it seems; was fascinated by this curious, exotic politician who flitted like a tropical butterfly down the corridors of power, dazzling in color, light in substance, unpredictable in movement.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: A Bibliomaniac's Collection Is Exhibited
description: Sir Thomas Phillips I (17921872) was the world's greatest collector of booksaselfstyled vellomaniac whose passion for the page kept him for years, despite his wealth, just steps ahead of the debtcollecting bailiff.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  At the beginning of a second term of the. Nixon Administration, it is perhaps useful to reflect upon one particular aspect of government.

title: Luxury Coop Market Pierced By Auction Needle
description: Since the middle and late nineteensixties, when prices were high and apartments hard to come by, the market for luxury cooperatives has been sobered by economic recession.

title: Austrian Gains First Ski Sweep
description: ST. MORITZ, Switzerland, Feb. 10Annemarie Proell of Austria completed a perfect season of downhill skiing today with her eighth victory, and then said she was building for the future.

title: RUTGERS SUBDUES WILLIAM & MARY
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 10Rutgers outscored William and Mary, 154, in the first three minutes of the second half tonight to break open a close game and go on to defeat the Indians, 9778. John Somogyi and Mike Dabney led the Scarlet with 29 and 26 points, respectively. Mike Arizin led William and Mary with 28 points.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The New Jersey Department of Defense announced yesterday that women would be accepted into four National Guard units in New Jersey as officers or enlistees. The units are the 141st Transportation Company, the. National Guard Headquarters Company, the 63d Army Band and the 44th Public Information Detachment.

title: PETERSON WINS POLE IN BRAZIL GRAND PRIX
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 10 (AP)Ronnie Peterson of Sweden won today the pole polition for tomorrow's Brazilian Grand Prix, the second race of the 1973 world drivers championship.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The socalled good guy mutual funds have fallen flat on their face.

title: A comfortable life
description: If uniqueness Is the stuff of biography, the life of Massachusetts's Edward William Brooke 3d is a lode of singularity. The only Republican Senatorial candidate forced to swim against the tide of a McGovern victory in his state in 1972, he is also the most politically adroit president the Boston Opera Company has ever had. He cast his first vote at the age of 30 in 1949, then went on to begin a phenomenally successful political career at 31. A native of the then voteless District of Columbia, he returned there in triumph as a Senator from Massachusetts in 1967.

title: Profits Are Carrots, Juices and Rewards
description: Whether or not, as Liza Minnelli sang in Cabaret, money makes the world go round, businessmen and economic theorists insist that profits are what make the capitalist system spin.

title: Goal by Ghana Starts Soccer Riot in Nigeria
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, Feb. 10 (AP)Troops and police were called tonight to restore order after a riot erupted at the new $20million National Stadium during a soccer match between Nigeria and Ghana.

title: Steven Golann Weds Jan Fullgraf
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 10Miss Jan Laura Fullgraf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Fullgraf, was married here this evening to Steven Warner Golann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin C. Golann of Holliswood, Queens. The Rev. Luther Tucker performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Indian Hill Episcopal and Presbyterian Church, where he was assisted by the Rev. Paul Long, a Presbyterian minister.

title: No Progress Seen as Eberle Ends Japanese Talks
description: TOKYO, Feb. 10William D. Eberle, President Nixon's special representative for trade affairs, finished three days of discussions with Japanese officials and businessmen today without any evidence of prog ress toward a reseltition of United States trade issues with Japan.

title: Hertha Pauli, Author, Is Dead; Wrote Biographies for Young
description: Hertha Pauli, a Viennaborn biographer and writer of historical works and children's books, died Friday at the Southside Hospital in Bay Shore, L.I. She was 63 years old and lived at 102 Woodhull Road, Huntington, L.I.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Terry Robards's incontestably accurate assessment of the mutual fund industry in Mutual Funds and Mediocrity (Jan. 14) unfortunately committed the all too common error of omission in not citing the record of the noload mutual funds.

title: Joanne DuBois, Douglas Judah To Be Married
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., Feb. 10  Miss Joanne Pederson DuBois, who teaches at the Dalton School in New York, and Douglas Fraser Judah, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, plan to be married here on March 24.

title: T. R. Hustedt Marries Amy Clark
description: In the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity here at noon yesterday, Miss Amy Hadden Clark, daughter of Mrs. Joan E. Clark of East Williston, L. I., and Theodore Clark of Cornwall Bridge, Conn., was married to Terrence R. Hustedt, son of Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hustedt of Lake Iroquois, Ill. The Rev. Gary Marshall performed the ceremony.

title: NIXON'S ATTORNEY TIED TO FUND ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 10Herbert W. Kalmbach, president Nixon's personal attorney, has been described in court papers here as essentially the principal fund raiser of Mr. Nixon's 1972 reelection campaign until last February.

title: Shelley's mistress, wife and widow
description: A publisher's blurb calls this a story of love and genius. Her love, his genius. Noel Gerson, whose previous books include Because I Loved Him, the life of Lillie Langtry, and under a pseudonym, The Divine Mistress (Voltaire's), appears to be mining a rather wornout lode. That's a crying shame, because Gerson writes a wellpaced script with a good, clean sentence. With a cast of characters like Percy Bysshe Shelley, Lord Byron, Trelawny, Leigh Hunt and Frankenstein, Mary Shelley and the reader deserve substance.

title: Slugger a Good Hunch Bet
description: BOSTON, Feb. 10 (AP)Seven Slugger won the $7,000 Red Sox Handicap today at Suffolk Downs, covering the 1 116mile distance in 1:46. Seven Slugger paid $4 for $2.

title: Egypt
description: CAIRO  He lets the reins hang loose, and when you least expect it he suddenly cracks the whip. The Cairene was trying to explain President Anwar elSadat's political style. He had in mind the sudden ouster of the Russians last summer, the dismissal of Gen, Mohammed Sadek as CommanderinChief last October, the crackdown on the students last month  and the purge of the intellectuals last week.

title: Husak Woos Washington
description: Word from Prague is that the regime of party boss Gustav Husak is seeking to improve relations with the West, particularly with the United States and West Germany. Some Western correspondents are being permitted to visit Czechoslovakia, Mr. Husak himself received a group of United States Senators who visited Prague late last year, and there are reports that formal United StatesCzechoslovak talks have begun.
