description: New York City Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn announced his availability as a candidate for Controller. However, he said that if the current Controller, Abraham D. Beanie, is running for Controller, I'm not.

title: David Lawrence Dies
description: David Lawrence, founder of U.S. News & World Report magazine and a conservative syndicated columnist for more than half a century, died yesterday at 84 in Sarasota, Fla. His columns appeared in more than 300 newspapers. Details, Page 30.

title: SHERWOOD NORMAN; CORRECTION WORKER
description: Sherwood Norman, who retired in December as director of prevention and youthcortection services of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency, died Saturday in Stanton, Ky., where he was serving as a consultant, from the council to the state government. He was 68 years old and Eyed at 18. Stevenson Street, Piermont, N.Y.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Essex County, N. J., Board of Freeholders was informed yesterday that contrary to what they had assumed, the county does not own the landmark statue of President Lincoln in front of the old district court house in downtown Newark The city does.

title: TRUCE TOMORROW, LAOTIANS ASSERT
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Monday, Feb. 12Laotian Government sources said today that the Governtheit and the proCommunist Pathet Lao would sign a ceasefire agreement tomorrow to halt the fighting in this country on Friday.

title: 2 Bonn Officials Hopeful On MoneyCrisis Solution
description: BONN, Feb. 11  Two toplevel Bonn officials said tonight that an international solution was near in the crisis involving speculation against the value of the dollar.

title: Furs and Pistol Stolen From Mackell's Home
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas 3. Mackell returned front an evening at the movies to find early yesterday that burglars had eluded an alarm system and broken into his Douglaston home.

title: Carol Magil Is Bride of Irving Yoskowitz
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Miss Carol Lynn Magil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Magil of Bethesda, Md., was married this afternoon to Irving Benjamin Yoskowitz. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Yoskowitz of Great Neck, L. I., and Brewster, N. Y.

title: Safety Before Dollars
description: Money has become the only issue in the dispute that is delaying deployment of armed guards at many airport embarkation points. The question is whether the cost of this essential security measure should be defrayed by the local communities, the airlines and the passengers as suggested by the Department of Transportationor by the Federal Government which ordered these precautions. The latter course is proposed in a bill before the Senate.

title: Nation Urged to Respect Privacy of ExP.O.W.'s
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 11 (AP)  President Nixon said today that Americans should respect the privacy of the returning prisoners of war.

title: Amnesty Under Lincoln
description: The war was not yet overindeed, there were hard battles ahead and calls for revenge were in the airwhen President Lincoln began to parole and pardon draft resisters, evaders and even deserters. He found it in his heart to do se while there was a Civil War on, not 10,000 miles away in a foreign jungle but at times only 10,000 yards from the White House.

title: CAMBODIA ABANDONS 4 POSTS IN AN ATTACK
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 11 (AP)  Government troops abandoned four positions on Route 1 about 15 miles east of Phnom Penh last night, leaving behind two 105mm. howitzers that the Cambodian Communists then turned on them, reports from the battle area said today.

title: MONEY MARTS CLOSED TODAY; TALK PRESSED
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 11 Most foreign exchange markets in Western Europe and Japan were ordered closed tomorrow as the major industrial powers entered a phase of intense bargaining over new patterns of currency values.

title: Royal Rogue A Surprise In Miniature
description: Ch. Carolane's Royal Rogue, a miniature schnauzer making his, first appearance in a specialty show, and Ch. Littleway Haranwal Barrister the wire hair wild has won numerous honors, provided the highlights yesterday in the 56th annual Associated Terrier Clubs Show at the 102d Engineers Armory.

title: Mother Mallard's Proves Enjoyable As a Rock Troupe
description: Mother Mallard's Portable Masterpiece Co. has more going for it than just a cute name. The threemember newmusic ensemble appeared Saturday night at the WBAI Free Music Store and managed, despite a rather curious interruption, to present a most enjoyable concert.

title: Espionage Trial of 6 Starts in Israel
description: HAIFA, Israel, Feb. 11The trial of six Israelistwo nativeborn Jews and four Israeli Arabsaccused of spying for Syria opened here today amid elaborate security precautions.

title: MINISTERS APPEAL VIRGINIA DECISION
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 11The Virginia. Supreme Court will be asked to determine whether Universal Life Church ministers may perform marriages in the state.

title: SNAG ON EXCHANGE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 12The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam ceasefire agreement was delayed this morning, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners.

title: Norby Wins Ski jump Tourney at Ishpeming
description: ISHPEMING, Mich., Feb. 11Showing the same great form that he exhibited seven years ago in making the United States Olympic squad, Dave Norby of Madison, Wis., rallied today to capture the talentpacked Paul Bietila memorial ski jumping tournament.

title: Building the Peace
description: In his Inaugural Address, President Nixon declared that the time has passed when America will make every other nation's conflict our own. A determination to refrain from unilateral assertions of our power should have the support of us all. But if the policy is to have any real meaning in a world where conflicts abound, there must be increased efforth to build better multilateral methods for building and keeping the peace. The multilateral half of any effective policy of unilateral restraint is not yet in evidence.

title: AIRLIFT IS BEGUN
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Monday, Feb. 12The repatriation of American prisoners of the Vietnam war began today.

title: BLANTON SCORES IN DAYTONA RACE
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb, 11The racing cars of two classes that generally operate in relative privacy had their day in the sunor whatever sunshine was available on this wintry 39degree dayat Daytone International Speedway.

title: 1,500 SEATS OPEN ON SCHOOL BOARDS
description: Lawrence Kelberg, a 41yearold mechanical engineer who lives in East Brunswick, will be seeking his third term on the board of education in local elections tomorrow. Alicelee Conn, whose four children range in age from 16 to 22, will be running for her first term on the Metuchen board.

title: Suffolk Downs Races Off
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)The ninerace card at Suffolk Downs was canceled today because of an impending snow storm, track officials said.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: DR. NOEL NUTELS, 60, AIDED BRAZIL INDIANS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 11Dr. Noel Nutels, who came to Brazil as an immigrant boy from the Ukraine and distinguished himself by providing medical care for the nation's jungle Indians, died of cancer yesterday. He was 60 years old.

title: FEDERAL INQUIRY ON SEGRETTI IS ON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11The Justice Department has begun an investigation of Donald H. Segretti, the young California lawyer who allegedly directed a political sabotage effort on behalf of the Republican party during last year's. Presidential campaign.

title: Hooked On Histrionics
description: Radical action is needed to cure an escalating problempolitical demagoguery on drugs. It is needed to counteract the politicians who obviously believe that the radical is chic year and that the outrageous is now in vogue.

title: SEOUL SAID TO GET TREATY PROPOSAL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 Informed South Korean sources said today that North Kore had secretly proposed recently that a peace treaty be concluded to end officially the Korean war, which was halted by an armistice in 1953.

title: Opera: 3dAct Cameos
description: A dressy audience that paid premium prices for the privilege heard Leontyne Price, Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Franco Tagliavini, Cornell MacNeil and other stars sing the third acts of three operas in a special performance given at the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night. The event, sponsored by the Metropolitan Opera Guild, was a benefit for the company's production fund.

title: APATHY IS CITED ON SOLID WASTE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11A statewide survey of municipal refuse services and facilities concludes that a negative public attitude is a major obstacle to improvement of solid waste disposal systems.

title: NoFault Passage Tied To Profit Limitation
description: An amendment limiting the profit that insurance companies can make under New York State's nofault auto insurance plan would guarantee passage of the measure, according to the Citizens Union.

title: School Fund  Sharing Disputed
description: President Nixon's proposal to consolidate large parts of the Government's aid to education under a special revenuesharing program has alarmed and outraged some powerful Congressmen and much of the education establishment.

title: David Lawrence, the Columnist, Is Dead
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11David Ilaivrence, columnist arid founder and editor of U.S. News & World Report Magazine, died today at his home in Sarasota, Pla., apparently of a heart attack. He was 84 years old.

title: Cricket Fever Sweeping India as the English Bow
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 11  Youngsters scampered through the markets of New I Delhi tonight shrieking the news. Old men on Connaught Circus, in the center of the city, whispered and broke into grins. Crowds in coffee shops, hovering around transistor radios, clapped excitedly.

title: BRUINS Pill LOSS ON KINGS, 2 TO 0
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Ross Brooks, a 35yearold rookie, goalie, registered his first National Hockey League shutout tonight, a 20 decision over the Los Angeles Kings. It was the third victory in a tow for Boston's new coach, Bep Guidolin.

title: Sailor Faces Trial in Clash
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 11 (UPI)The only white sailor charged in a racial disorder aboard the carrier Kitty Hawk goes before a courtmartial tomorrow. Airman William E. Boone, 20 years old, of Texas City, Tex., is accused of having assaulted a petty officer in the clashes Oct. 12 and 13, in which 46 crewmen were injured. Seaman recruit Robert L. Coleman, 21, of Homestead, Pa., one of 23 black sailors charged, will go on trial tomorrow on two counts of assault.

title: Slide Kills a Worker, Closes Big Sur Road
description: BIG SUR, Calif., Feb. 11 Reuters)  An earth slide dropped tons of mud nearly two hundred yards down a canyon cliff today, cutting away part of scenic Highway 1 and killing one person.

title: Tunnelers Find Din and Danger 700 Feet Under
description: Deepdown rumbles and earth tremors felt on the East Side herald the steady advance of a city project at such an awesome depth it could have been conceived by Jules Verne.

title: Kissinger Talks in Hanoi Called Serious by the White House
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 11 (Reuters)  Henry A. Kissinger met for six hours today with North Vietnamese Government officials for a second round of talks on American postwar relations with North Vietnam, the Western White House said.

title: Oh, Perfidious Columbia
description: LONDON, Feb. 11The British people have adjusted quite painlessly to the loss of empire. They feel no envy as the United. States carries on their former role of world leadership in economic and political affairs. They are content to cultivate their own small garden without the burden of greatness.

title: GOVERNOR OFFERS MENTALAID PLAN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11Governor Rockefeller will submit a bill to the Legislature tomorrow that is designed to enable the state and local communities to jointly plan, deliver and finance all mentalhealth, mentalretardation and alcoholism services in the communities.

title: MONEY MARTS CLOSED TODAY; TALK PRESSED
description: BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 11 Most foreign exchange markets in Western Europe and Japan were ordered closed tomorrow as the major industrial powers entered a phase of intense bargaining over new patterns of currency values.

title: ROBERT M'CONNELL, A RETIRED ADMIRAL
description: ASHEVILLE, N. C., Feb. 11 (AP)Vice Adm. Robert P. McConnell, commander of the aircraft carrier Cowpens in the Pacific during World War II, died yesterday at Oteen Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 77 years old.

title: Miss Devine, Teacher, Bride Of William Epp
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 11In Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Catherine Devine, daughter of Michael Francis Devine of Morristown and the late Mrs. Devine, became the bride of William Epp.

title: MRS. COURT KEEPS HER STREAK ALIVE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 11 (UPI)Mrs. Margaret Court, overcoming, a lobbing attack, defeated her Australian countrywoman, Kerry Melville, 46, 61, 75, in the final of the $30,000 Virginia Slims tennis tournament today.

title: BASKETBALL PILOT AT RUTGERS QUITS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 11Dick Lloyd, basketball coach at Rutgers for the last two seasons, announced his resignation today, effective at the end of the current season.

title: APATHY IS CITED ON SOLID WASTE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11A statewide survey of municipal refuse services and facilities concludes that a negative public attitude is a major obstacle to improvement of solid waste disposal systems.

title: Bluhdorn's Role in A. & P. Drama Disclosed
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company has been the apple of Charles G. Bluhdorn's eye for some time, possibly for a whole year, according to testimony released in United States District. Court in Manhattan Friday.

title: 28 VICTIMS FOUND, 12 STILL MISSING IN S.I. EXPLOSION
description: Grimfaced firemen descended into the fireblackened chasm of a huge, volcanolike gas tank on Statten Island yesterday and labored through the day to recover the bodies of 40 men buried Saturday in an explosion and fire whose cause remained a mystery.

title: Stennis Continues to Make A Satisfactory Recovery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, continned today to make satisfactory progress in recovering from gunshot wounds, a spokesman for Walter Reed Medical Center reported.

title: Bar Association Members Cool to Proposal for New National Appeals Court
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 11Hightlevel discussion of the plan for a new Federal court to screen out less important Supreme Court cases is meeting middlelevel indifference among members of the American Bar Association.

title: ZUKERMAN GIVES LOWKEY CONCERT
description: A violinist of outgoing romantic temperament, Pinches Zukerman appeared to be in an unusually mellow, lowkey mood Saturday night at Hunter College. All the music on the program was restrained, if not actually selfeffacing, and all of it was treated to a sweet, rounded tone and the most fastidious musical care.

title: Bridge: Becker Is Player of Year, Beating Roth in a Recount
description: A recalculation based on 1972 tournament results in New York has now shown that Michael Becker has won the William Lipton Trophy and the title of New York playeroftheyear. Alvin Roth, who was at first thought to have won, placed second.

title: RIZZO WILL FIGHT NEW SHAPP TERM
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 A simmering quarrel between Mayor Frank L. Rizzo and Gov. Milton J. Shapp, over budgetary matters has boiled over into a public exchange of insults and a pledge by the Mayor that he will work to ensure that Mr. Shapp is a oneterm Governor

title: News Summary and Index
description: The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam ceasefire agreement was delayed this morning, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners. The release had been set for 8:30 A.M. Saigon time (7:30 P.M. Sunday, New York Times), but by midmorning it had not been made. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: SNOW BEWILDERS TOWN IN GEORGIA
description: MACON, Ga., Feb. 11 (UPI)Vhen 15 inches of snow, fell on this middle Georgia, city, paralyzing the town and re(rally cutting it off from the rest of the world, officials had little they could offer to aid he bewildered citizenry except warnings against overexertion.

title: Cricket Not Yanks' Cup of Tea
description: Reaction in the United States to India's retention of the world cricket championship by defeating England in the test match yesterday fell far short of hysteria. No bonfire celebrations, tickertape parades or barroom brawls were reported.

title: TEXAN WILL HEAD WOMEN'S CAUCUS
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 11Frances Farenthold, a reformminded Texas Democrat, was elected overwhelmingly today as the first national chairman of the National Women's Political Caucus.

title: RELEASE IN SOUTH RUNS INTO A SNAG
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 12The release of 27 Americans who were scheduled to be the first United States prisoners of war freed under the Vietnam ceasefire agreement was delayed this afternoon, apparently because of a dispute over an exchange of Communist prisoners.

title: Harlem Woman Dies in Fire
description: A 32yearold Harlem woman died last night in a onealarm blaze in her apartment at 163 Edgecombe Avenue, the police reported. She was identified as Betty Blue.

title: BEAUTY TALK
description: Now it's time for the winter wearies, when vitamin pills seem to have lost their efficacy and one's looks go as droopy as the unwatered poinsettia in the window. The siren call of the beauty people never sounded so enticing.

title: Stephen Thompson Dies; Officer in Realty Institute
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11Stephen G. Thompson, executive vice president of the American Institute of Real Estate Appraisers in charge of public relations and publicationi, died yesterday, apparently of thrombosis, in Passavant Hospital. He was 60 years old.

title: Medical Study of State Prisons Finds Psychiatric Care Is Grossly Deficient
description: TRENTON, Feb, 11A survey of medical care in the state prison system by teams of doctors and dentists has found facilities for psychiatric care grossly deficient and drug programs totally inadequate.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Cricket Fever Sweeping India as the English Bow
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 11  Youngsters scampered through the markets of New Delhi tonight shrieking the news. Old men on Connaught Circus, in the center of the city, whispered and broke into grins. Crowds in coffee shops, hovering around transistor radios, clapped excitedly.

title: Survivors Tell of a Brief Warning Hiss
description: John Carroll, a 31yearold crane director who had been standing on the dome of the tank, survived Saturday's explosion on Staten Island because he was in a position to run down the outside of what turned into a burial mound.

title: Tunnelers Finds Din and Danger 700 Feet Under
description: Deepdown rumbles and earth tremors felt on the East Side herald the steady advance of a city project at such an awesome depth it could have been conceived by Jules Verne.

title: Bergen County Republican Leadership Faces Attack From Within and Without
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 11 Bergen County Republican headquarters here is in what used to be a Vic Tanny gymhasium, a location that in some ways symbolizes the kind of political muscle the wellfinanced organization has been able to exercise on both local and national levels.

title: Church Where Ceiling Fell Is Fixed
description: More than three years after part of its ceiling crashed to the floor, Immanuel Lutheran Church has been restored, with some changes.

title: Burns's Dual Rate Role Poses a Conflict
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Last week's open clash between several major banks and Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, brought into sharp focus this question: Is there a conflict between Dr Burns's responsibility as a central banker and his duties as one of the administrators of President Nixon's WagePrice Stabilization campaign?

title: AFRICAN'S PARTY CONTINUES TIGHT
description: CONAKRY, Guinea, Feb. 2Behind the wellguarded doors of this city's state hotel, African guerrilla fighters are planning a proposed declaration of independence for most of the territory in Portuguese Guinea.

title: Lincoln Statue ls Newark's Good Deed
description: NEWARK, Feb. 11The Essex County Board of Freeholders was informed today that, contrary to what it had mistakenly assumed, the county does not own the landmark statue of President Lincoln that stands in front of the old District Courthouse in downtown Newark.

title: John R. Maust Dies at 77; Founder of a Coal Concern
description: John R. Maust, former president and chairman of the board of the Maust Coal and Coke Corporation, which was acquired by Occidental Petroleum Corporation in 1969, died yesterday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and also lived at 49 Hillcrest Drive, Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Gaytonglen Teddy Named Best at Yorkshire Show
description: Ch. Gaytonglen Teddy of Mayfair, who will be 6 years old in July, was named best of 149 Yorkshire terriers in the Gold Ballroom of the Statler Hilton at the national specialty yesterday. He is owned by Ann Seranne and Barbara Wolferman of Newton, N.J.

title: Army Returns Honor To Discharged Black
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 11Dorsie W. Willis was honorably discharged from the United States Army today, 66 years after he was dishonorably discharged from the same Army.

title: SNOW HAMPERS HUNT FOR CLIMBER'S BODY
description: GLENWOOD, Wash., Feb. 11 The glitter of snow crystals in the wind is like the enlightened smile of a prophet, who, like the mountains, knows that he is free.

title: Celtics Overwhelm Bucks As Cowens Stars, 12096
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP)Dave owens and Paul Silas paced a firsthalf scoring spree and the Boston Celtics went on to register a 12096 National Basketball Association victory today over the Milwaukee Bucks.

title: Tax Reform Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (UPI) Herbert Stein, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today that the Administration was working on a bill to reform the Federal Tax Code, but that the shape of the final product was uncertain.

title: AID TO MIGRANTS FOUND DEFICIENT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11Although problems of migran and are expected to grow worse farmworkers are serious now as their employment opportun ities decline, Federal programs designed to help migrant farm workers are underfunded, frag mented and inefficient, the Gen eral Accounting Office has said in a report to Congress.

title: Waldheim in Bangkok Talks
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, Feb, 11 (Reuters)  Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations arrived here today from Calcutta for a threeday visit for talks with Thai leaders on the United Nations role in restoring peace in Indochina and in postwar reconstruction. Mr. Waldheim has just completed visits to India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh.

title: Behagen, a Dream Forward, Again Haunts Ohio State
description: The New York Nets need a big, strong, rebounding forward.

title: STUDY SUPPORTS SULPHUR RULINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 11A study prepared for the Environmental Protection Agency on the health effects of sulphur oxides has concluded that the Federal standards limiting the amount of these pollutants in the atmosphere are not too strict.

title: German Export Profits Cut After Revaluations
description: BONN, Feb. 11One of the most frequently heard sounds in West German export circles is the groaning of businessmen complaining about the negative effect of the upward revaluation of the mark by more than 15 per cent during the last three years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The repatriation of American prisoners in Vietnam began this morning with the ceremonial turnover at Hanoi's Gia Lam airport of three planeloads of men. The first of three Air Force medical jets arrived two hours behind schedule because of early morning rain and ground fog in Hanoi. Prisoners began boarding the plane after a ceremony at the airfield. [Page 1, Colunin 8.]

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Theater

title: Watts Vaults Over Difficulties in Liszt
description: If there were an Olympic piano team, Watts would definitely be winning gold medals for America. Thus runs his recording company's claim for Andre Watts, printed in the program book for the 26yearold pianist's Philharmonic Hall recital Sunday. And who would want to contest it after hearing him vault over difficulties in Liszt's Paganini Etudes?

title: Workers Grimly Remove Bodies
description: All through the biting cold day, in the stark marshland of western Staten Island, the two giant tower cranes swung and dipped into the fireblackened hole that had been a liquefiedgas storage tank.

title: SMITH CAPTURES INDOOR NET FINAL
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11 Stan Smith beat Bob Lutz, his doubles partner and close friend in a stirring threehour, fiveset final today for the $10,000 top prize in the United States professional indoor tennis championship.

title: Canadiens' Rally Ties Rangers, 2 to 2
description: Taking advantage of two golden opportunitieswhich is what firstplace clubs are supposed to dothe patient Montreal Canadiens fought back yesterday and tied the Rangers 22 at Madison Square Garden.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Picketing Resumes Today at Kawaida

title: 10 Scarsdale Women Seek to Join Men's Town Club
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 11 Ten women whose applications to join the Town Club were rejected last month now plan to go to court to gain admission to the 68yearold organization, which describes itself as Scarsdale's Town Meeting for Men.

title: David Lawrence Dies
description: David Lawrence, founder of U. S. News & World Report magazine and a conservative syndicated columnist for more than half a century, died yesterday at 84 in Sarasota, Fla. His columns appeared in more than 300 newspapers. Details, Page 30.

title: Edison Honored at Ceremonies In Edison on 126th Birthday
description: EDISON, Feb. 11  Wreathlaying ceremonies commemorating the 126th birthday of Thomas A. Edison were held in the Menlo Park section of Edison Township today on the site of the inventor's first large research laboratory.

title: AUSTRIANS SWEEP WORLD CUP EVENT
description: ST. MORITZ Switzerland, Feb. 11 Though the names were not quite as familiar, the Austrian men today continued the skiing snowball started yesterday by their countrywomen.

title: Starheir's Aaron Ardee Judged Best Irish Setter
description: Hugh H. Rumbaugh, an inventor from Akron, Ohio, came up with the winning design at the Combined Setter Clubs of America fixture at the Statler Hilton Hotel yesterday when Ch. Starheir's Aaron Ardee was named best of breed at the Eastern Irish Setter Assospecialty.

title: 2 Soized in Harlem Attack
description: Two men were arrested in Harlem early yesterday after one allegedly fired a shot at two plainclothes men riding in an unmarked Police cat Neither policeman was hit.

title: ROME TALKS HELD ON MONEY CRISIS
description: ROME, Feb. 11The United States Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, Paul A. Volcker, paid a 50minute visit to Rome this afternoon and then returned to Paris, taking the Italian Treasury Minister, Giovanni F. Milagodi, and other Italian officials with him.

title: GEORGE W. FOY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 11 (UPI)George W. Foy, a lawyer and former State Assemblyman, died at his home Friday night, He was 70 years old.

title: Fresh Look Is Due In Federal Design
description: WASHINGTON  A highpriority $100,000 program to raise design, standards throughout all Federal agencies without doing a hatchet job on mistakes of the past, has been initiated here at the request of President Nixon.

title: MILTON SIMON
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 11Milton Simon, president of Samuel P. Gross, Inc., a textile jobber, died yesterday in the Albert Einstein Medical Center. He was 57 years old.

title: Car Emission Standards To Cost State Billion More
description: State Environmental Conservation Commissioner Henry L. Diamond said yesterday it would cost the state roughly $1billion additional to met Federal court standards on car emissions by 1975, instead of the 1977 date set previously for New York State.

title: BYRNE BREAKS TIE IN U.S. CHESS TITLE
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 11 (AP)Robert Byrne broke the 10month tie for the United States chess championship last night.

title: Fittipaldi Captures Brazil Grand Prix; Stewart Is Second
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 11 (UPI)Driving an impeccable race, the world Formula One champion, Emerson Fittipaldi of Brazil, roared away from the field today to win the Brazilian Grand Prix before 80,000 of his hometown fans at the. Interlagos circuit, of which his father is director.

title: Palmer's Closing 69 Wigs Hope Golf by Two Shots
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 11  After an 18month spell, Arnold. Palmer won the $160,000 Bob Hope golf tournament by two strokes in rain today.

title: Seoul Said to Bar Treaty With the North Koreans
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 Informed South Korean sources said today that North Korea had secretly proposed recently that a peace treaty be concluded to end officially the Korean war, which was halted by an armistice in 1953.

title: SELLING CHANGES OPPOSED BY FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 The mutual fund industry told the Securities and Exchange Commission today that any material change in the way its shares are sold would mean a return to the chaotic conditions previaling before 1940.

title: Frazier, Unitas and Such Give Extra Attention to Certain Fans
description: Joe Frazier, the former heavyweight champion, and Johnny Unitas, the quarterback, have called them up with personal greetings at Christmaslime. Jerry Lucas, the Knicks's forward, is preparing a magic show for them. Ron Swoboda of the Yankees is going to have them at the Stadium this spring.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Maryland, whose coastal areas offer some of the best Canada gooseshooting in the United States, is considering a regulation that would ban the use of lead shot for waterfowlhunting.

title: Macao Casinos Refuse To Accept U.S. Dollars
description: MACAO, Feb. 12 (AP)The United States dollar, under pressure on world currency markets, was turned back at Macao casinos today.

title: Koch Joins Mayoral Race; Calls Crime Major Issue
description: Representative Edward I. Koch announced his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday and declared that crime was the overriding issue.

title: KerrMcGee Corp. Elects
description: James J. Kelly, executive vice president, will succeed F. C. Love as president of the KerrMcGee Corporation when Mr. Love retires March 1. D. A. McGee will remain as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Kelly formerly was also president and chief executive of the KerrMcGee Chemical Corporation, a subsidiary. W. J. F. Francis, vice president of the subsidiary, will succeed Mr. Mr. Kelly as president of the subsidiary.

title: Firemen Rescue Balloonist
description: BRISTOL, Wis. Feb. 12 (UPI) Roger Heninger, 35 years old, of Morton Grove, Ill., was trying to land his balloon in a field yesterday but missed and wound up in a tree. The Bristol volunteer fire department rescued him. Damage to his $6,000 balloon was estimated at several hundred dollars.

title: Long Wait Is Ended for 27, Set Free in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 13  After 12 hours of debate and anguishing delay, 27 American prisoners of war held in South Vietnam were freed last night by the Vietcong, flown to Saigon and then rushed to Clark Air Base in the Philippines.

title: Arctic Bubble?
description: The recent decision of the United States Court of Appeals blocking once again the proposed Alaska oil pipeline was narrowly basedbut not so much so as to deny a great measure of comfort to those who have long opposed the project.

title: Air Crash Hearing Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board said today that it would open a hearing at Miami Springs, Fla., on March 5 into the airliner crash near Miami last Dec. 29 in which 101 of the 176 persons aboard were killed.

title: TeenAgers Who Help Look After the Elderly
description: It's hard to say who is being benefited more: (1) the old people who are alone, usually existing below the poverty level but often too proud to go on relief, and sometimes with physical handicaps severe enough to keep them from going outside their livingquarters, or (2) the teenagers who are helping to look after them.

title: 7 PowerShort Days Seen in Summer Here
description: Consolidated Edison will probably lack sufficient power reserves on seven warm days next summer, Bertram Schwartz, the utility's vice president in charge of system planning and fuel supply, testified yesterday before the State Public Service Commission.

title: Devaluation Gets Approvd Of Top Economists in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Leading United States economists took a generally favorable view tonight of the Administration's dollar devaluation package.

title: Hijacker, 22, Who Surrendered Gets 30Year Prison Sentence
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 12Francis M. Goodell, 22 years old, of Manassas, Va., Vietnam war veteran who hijacked an airliner with 58 persons aboard last July, was sentenced today to 30 years in prison.

title: Vietcong Say Saigon and U.S. Repeatedly Violate CeaseFire
description: PARIS, Feb. 12 (UPI)  The Vietcong side accused South Vietnam and the United States today of repeated violations of the Vietnam peace agreement and warped that it will not go on tolerating them.

title: FROEHLING OUSTED BY STONE IN TENNIS
description: TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press)Alan Stone of Australia eliminated 12thseeded Frank Freoehling of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., 62, 67, 61, today at the Toronto tennis tournament.

title: Weinberger Is Sworn In, Completing New Cabinet
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)  President Nixon hailed Caspar W. Weinberger, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, as a man of great intelligence and great compassion and really great heart at swearingin ceremonies here today.

title: N.B.C TURNS DOW A. M. A. REBUTTAL
description: The National Broadcasting Company, accused by the American Medical Association of having shown overall bias in a television news special called What Price Health?, yesterday turned down an A.M.A. demand for free, equal air time for a rebuttal.

title: DRUGS SAMPLING SHOWS DEATHS DIP
description: A national sample of 25 key geographical areas shows a 6 per cent drop in narcoticsrelated deaths between 1971 and 1972, the White House's Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention announced yesterday.

title: The Stage
description: Some elements work well in the revival of Thunder Rock, Robert Ardrey's 1939 fantasy of a cynical journalist holed up in a Michigan lighthouse to escape the world.

title: Satellite Gives Scientists a Picture of the Earth
description: GREENBELT, Md.Dr. Nicholas M. Short, a geologist at the Goddard Space Flight Center here, bent over the light table and squinted through an eightpower magnifying glass at a large color transparency of western Nevada.

title: 225 Facing Loss of Jobs At Brookhaven Laboratory
description: UPTON, L.I., Feb. 12 (UPI)A Brookhaven National Laboratory spokesman said today that 225 employes would lose their jobs starting next month because of a budget cut and rising operational costs.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 13, 1973

title: Debris Foils Hunt for S.I. Blast Victims; Cause of Explosion Still Baffles Officials
description: Firemen searching a scorched Staten Island gasstorage tank or 12 more bodies were frustrated yesterday as slabs of fallen concrete blocked their path.

title: Bigger Crane and New Scaffold To Be Used in Recovery Effort
description: A 250ton crane and a newly erected internal scaffolding with rungs will be used today in an attempt to facilitate the recovery efforts of firemen and laborers at the Staten Island gasstorage tank where 40 men were buried in an explosion and fire on Saturday.

title: G.M.A.C.'s 1972 Purchases Of Retail Contracts Rose
description: Retail installment contracts purchased by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation totaled a record $7.8billion in 1972, compared with $7.2billion in 1971, the finance arm of the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: TV Preacher Cited in Securities Suits
description: AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 12 The Securities and Exchange Commission and the State of Ohio filed suits today against the Rev. Rex Humbard and his Cathedral of Tomorrow for alleged violations of state and Federal securities laws.

title: Remote Siberian Oil Field Thrives in SubZero Cold
description: NIZHNEVARTOVSK, U.S.S.R., Jan. 31In this remote corner of Siberia, oildrilling crews are working around the clock in temperatures of 40 and 50 degrees below zero to tap the riches of the Samotlor field, reputedly one of the world's largest underground reservoirs of petroleum.

title: More Apparel Outlets Opened
description: The number of retail apparel outlets opened in January broke a fouryear downslide for that month, the Credit Clearing House, the appareltrades division of Dun & Bradstreet, reported yesterday. January openings rose to 175, compared with 68 in 1972, 94 in 1971 and 119 in 1970.

title: NoFault Auto Insurance Is Passed by Legislature
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12The Republican majority's modified nofault auto insurance plan was approved by the Legislature tonight.

title: Weinberger Is Sworn In; Completing New Cabinet
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 12 (AP)  President Nixon hailed Caspar W. Weinberger, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, as a man of great intelligence and great compassion and really great heart at swearingin ceremonies here today.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: Simplified Rites Are Set For 30 New Cardinals
description: ROME, Feb. 12The Vatican announced today that the forthcoming elevation of 30 churchmen to the rank of Cardinal by Pope Paul VI would take place with a new simplified ritual.

title: COURT AUTHORIZES AIRPORT GUARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  A Federal judge authorized the Nixon Administration today to implement immediately an emergency order requiring the stationing of armed local law enforcement officers for every flight at each of the nation's 531 airports with airline service.

title: Tombs Prisoner Is Killed In Fight With Cellmate
description: An inmate of the Manhattan House of Detention for Men killed his cellmate in a fistfight shortly after 11 o'clock last night, the police reported.

title: Progress Found in Talks
description: PARIS, Feb. 12Progress was reported today as secret consultations continued in several European centers to resolve the men of imported products. But the amount of the increase is uncertain and will depend on pricing decisions by foreign exporters.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHTS GAMES

title: Currency Bloc Remains.
description: PARIS, Tuesday, Feb. 13The Common Market Countries have made an important concession to the United States by permitting the dollar to be devalued by 10 per cent without a downward adjustment of their own currencies.

title: ARTHUR J. MURPHY JR.
description: Arthur J. Murphy Jr., a lawyear with the firm of Sullivan, Donovan, Hanrahan, McGovern & Lane, died of cancer yesterday in Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 41 years old and lived at 315 East 72nd Street.

title: NoFault Auto Insurance Is Passed by Legislature
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12The Republican majority's modified nofault auto insurance plan was approved by the legislature tonight.

title: BRITISH FOOTBALL
description: By Reuters

title: Pennco Seeks N. & W. Change
description: The Pennsylvania Commpany, the investment company subsidiary of the bankrupt, Penn Central Railroad, announced yesterday it would ask the Interstate Commerce Commission to modify or eliminate a 1964 Commission requirement under which it must divest itself of its holdings of Norfolk Western Railway stock.

title: Scholarships for Veterans
description: Twenty scholarships of $1,000 a year each will be offered to Vietnam veterans enrolling next fall in the New York University General Studies program, the school's director of financial aid, Raymond J. Brienza, announced yesterday. Combat veterans will be given priority. The regular tuition fee is $2,700 a year.

title: Statement by Secretary Shultz on Devaluation of the Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Following, is the text of the statement tonight by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz on the devaluation of the dollar:

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: Should We Abolish the Presidency?
description: Owing to the steady accretion of power in the executive over the last forty years, the institution of the Presidency is not now functioning as the Constitution intended, and this malfunction has become perilous to the state. What needs to be abolished, or fundamentally modified, I believe, is not the executive power as such but the executive power as exercised by a single individual.

title: INDIANA DEFEATS ILLINOIS, 87 TO 66
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Feb. 12 (UPI)Steve Downing scored 41 points tonight to lead Indiana to an 8766 victory over Illinois and into first place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: Phelps Has Irish Smiling With Thought of N. I. T. Bid
description: Richard (Digger) Phelps, Notre Dame's coach, was casually informing yesterday's meeting of the Metropolitan basketball writers at the Steer Palace that his team would be staying at one of the fashionable hotels along Central Park South before their Thursday night game against Fordham.

title: Dr. Abraham Braunstein, Thoracic Specialist, Dies
description: Dr. Abraham Braunstein, a specialist in chest diseases, who had practiced in Queens more than 50 years, died Friday in Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived in Brightwaters, L. I. His office was at 3069 36th Street, Astoria, Queens.

title: Bridge:Preemptive Action Leaves Bidder Open to Some Risks
description: Any kind of preemptive action suffers from one major disadvantage: If the opponents survive the barrage and reach their best contract they will have a blueprint for the play of the hand. The declarer will know that the preempter has little but his long, strong suit and will therefore assume that length and strength in the other suits lie on the opposite side of the table.

title: Prices on Big Board Soar As Holiday Trims Volume
description: The stock market steamed ahead on a broad front yesterday, apparently in response to signs of progress toward resolving the current international monetary crisis.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The United States announced last night a devaluation of the dollar of 10 per cent against nearly all of the world's major currencies. The devaluation will be greater than 10 per cent against the Japanese yen, which will float upward in foreignexchange trading for an indefinite period. The announcement was made by Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz. [Page 1, Col. 8.]

title: A PRIEST TO RUN FOR CITY COUNCIL
description: The Rev. Louis R. Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest who has been for some time a vigorous political power in the South Bronx, announced his candidacy yesterday for the City Council.

title: Canada Business Failures Up
description: TORONTO, Feb. 12 (Canadian Press)  Business failures in Canada during December totaled 244, compared with 243 in November, Dun & Bradstreet reported today. This was well ahead of last December's 194 failures and represented the highest December total in 40 years.

title: NEW PHASE BEGIN IN ELLSBERG TRIAL
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12The prosecution moved the Pentagon papers trial into a new phase today by going into the question of the security of classified documents.

title: Happy Hubbub Fills Homes of Returning P.O.W.'s
description: I was so tickled to see my son get off the plane, I just sat at that television like I was glued there.

title: S.E.C. to Lift Trading Ban On Power Conversion, Inc.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (Reuters)  The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it would lift the ban on trading of the stock of Power Conversion, Inc., at midnight Friday.

title: NEWS INDEX
Chess: How Reshevsky Returned From the Brink of Disaster
description: After his thirdround loss to me, in the threeway playoff for the United States championship, Samuel Reshevsky came smashing back into contention by defeating Lubomir Kavalek in a finely contested, closely fought fourthround encounter. Earlier, Reshevsky had to be satisfied with a draw against Kavalek in their roundone game, which ran to 62 moves in the adjournment session.

title: Family of 3 Slain In Suburban Home Near Pennsylvania
description: JAMESTOWN, N. Y., Feb. 12 (AP)A businessman, his wife and 8yearold daughter were found shot to death in their suburban home in the Town of Busti tonight, the state police said.

title: $2.7Million Is Donated Anonymously to Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 12 Cornell University has received a $2.7  million gift from an unnamed alumnus, the University president, Dale It. Corson, announced today.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: OUT THERE The Foundadation for Parasensory Investigation is not an occult undertaking, although it, too, pries into those matters not easily explained by existing scientific knowledge. Some idea of what it is all about can be gained by the three sessions today (9:30 to 1 P.M.; 2:30 to 5:30, 7 to 10:30) that constitute its second Western Hemisphere conference on acupuncture, Kirlian photography and the human aura in Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (5824536). Acupuncture, as is well known, is Chinese pinpointing.

title: Rhodesia Fines Whole Village For Aiding Nationalist Rebels
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 12 (Agence FrancePresse) The Rhodesian Government has imposed the first collective punishment on black tribesmen for sheltering nationalist guerrillas.

title: PILOT FACES INQUIRY IN ONASSIS AIR CRASH
description: ATHENS, Feb. 12  The Athens district attorney ordered a full judicial inquiry today to determine whether Donald McCusker, a 48yearold American pilot, should be charged with manslaughter in the death of Alexander Onassis, son of Aristotle S. Onassis, last month after an air crash at Athens airport.

title: New Road Alters Life in South Korea Town
description: KIMYANGCHANG, South Korea, Feb. 5A new political order and a new road have made their marks on the lives of the 5,000 Koreans in this farm town amid the rice fields now brown with the winter cold.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Ann Klein Enters Race for Nomination As Democratic Candidate for Governor
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12  Ann Klein, a member of the Assembly from Morris County, announced her candidacy here today for the Democratic nomination for Governor in the June primary election.

title: N.B.C. TURNS DOWN A. M. A. REBUTTAI
description: The National Broadcasting Company, accused by the American Medical Association of having shown overall bias in a television news special called What Price Health?, yesterday turned down an A.M.A. demand for free, equa air time for a rebuttal.

title: SHULTZ COMMENTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12The United States announced to night a devaluation of the dollar by 10 per cent agains nearly all of the world's major currencies.

title: Balloon Competition Off
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Feb. 12 (AP)The opening competition of the first World Hot Air Balloon Championships between aeronauts from 14 countries was scrubbed today because of high, gusty winds. The balloons generally cannot fly in winds stronger than eight miles an hour.

title: CONGLOMERATE BIDS TO PURCHASE SHARES
description: Northwest Industries, Inc., which since last October has reacquired 775,000 shares of its convertible preferred and common stocks, has been authorized by its board to purchase up to an additional 500,000 shares, according to Ben W. Heineman, president of the Chicagobased conglomerate.

title: Baseball Owners' Stand Called Lockout Threat
description: Marvin Miller said yesterday that the 24 major league player representatives will meet in New York Friday to discuss the baseball club owners' latest offer, including salary arbitration, but it might take a series of meetings involving all players to determine the Players Association's response.

title: First Prisoner Release Is Completed
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Tuesday, Feb. 13  The first released American prisoners of the Vietnam war were greeted with cheers of welcome and tears of joy here yesterday as they stepped off military evacuation jets. They looked in better physical condition than most onlookers had expected, and the hospital commander here pronounced their general health reasonably good.

title: '71 Charge a Factor
DR. JOEL B. ADLER
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., Feb. 12Dr. Joel B. Adler of Ramapo Hills, Suffern, director of orthopedic surgery at Good Samaritan Hospital here, died suddenly today at the hospital. He was 38 years old.

title: Buenos Aires Halts Trading
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 12 (UPI)The central bank of Argentina today suspended all transactions in foreign currencies other than the dollar for an indefinite period. The official announcement said the measure was a result of the international financial situation that has closed exchanges abroad.

title: Arthur Daley
description: America's finest pole vaulters left their crying towels behind them amid the other dolorous mementos of the Munich Olympics. They had been jobbed and victimized by the politicallymotivated badgewearers from the Iron Curtain countries when the ground rules were suddenly changed on them just before the vaulting competition began.

title: Theater: Richard III
description: BOSTON, Feb. 11It is rare that an actor of Al Pacino's stature, following such an enormous film success as The Godfather, returns immediately to the live theater. Obviously, Pacino wants to expand his talent, and his choice of roles shows his seriousness of purpose and also his courage. Last year he did The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel, and last night he opened in Richard IIIon both occasions with David Wheeler's admirable Theater Company of Boston.

title: Tourists Vexed by Currency Plight
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 (AP)I can't buy any presents or souvenirs, the disgruntled tourist said. I'm going home.

title: Derailment Blocks Penn Central Line
description: YONKERS, Feb. 12  ?? man was killed and all Hudson Division commuter service was blocked today by a Penn Central freight train derailment that left 23 cars crumpled and scattered over all four tracks.

title: Queens Women's Five Loses
description: IMMACULATA, Pa., Feb. 12 The defending women's national intercollegiate basketball champions, Immaculate College, scored a 7156 victory over the defending New York State champions, Queens College, today. Immaculata was led by Theresa Shank, who had 27 points and 13 rebounds.

title: HARRY SWARD
description: MOLINE, Ill., Feb. 12, (UPI) Harry Sward, longtime publisher of The Moline Dispatch until his retirement in 1969, died Monday at his winter home in St. Petersburg, Fla, He was 88 years old.

title: Income at John Hancock Co. Passed $2Billion in 1972
description: BOSTON, Feb. 12 (AP)The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company reported today that its total income exceeded $2billion for the first time in history last year.

title: EVERETT MARSHALL
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., Feb. 12 (AP)Everett Marshal, reognized in Colorado in 1935 as the world professional wrestling champion, died Saturday. He was 67 years old.

title: 3 Shots Are Fired At Patrolman Here; Gunmen Elude Him
description: Shortly before dawn yesterday, Patrolman Dennis Coyle finished a sandwich and coffee at the Cozy Diner in the South Bronx.

title: Legal Services Chief Is Ousted; He Assails Poverty Office Head
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12A new political controversy erupted tonight over the Federal Legal Services Program with the abrupt discharge of its acting director, Ted R. Tetzlaff, following his refusal to resign.

title: Exuberance Makes Up for Some Deficiencies in Choral Premiere
description: PARAMUS, Feb. 12Daniel in the Lion's Den, a choral work by Daniel Pinkham was performed for the first time at Bergen Community College here last night.

title: Notes on People
description: After serving almost four years as an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, Eugene T. Rossides, who is known in New York for football as well as politics, has returned to membership in the law firm of Royall, Koegel & Wells. In the Treasury Department, from which he resigned in December, Mr. Rossides's duties were enforcement, tariff and trade affairs and operations. Before that he was active in a number of Republican national and New York State campaigns. Now 45 years old, Mr. Rossides is also remembered as the Columbia quarterback who on Oct. 25, 1947, completed 18 passes against Army at Baker Field, as Columbia defeated the Cadets 2120, ending West Point's unbeaten record at 32 consecutive games overthree and onehalf seasons.

title: ALBANY IS UNSURE ON VOTING HERE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12The dates for New York City's general primary and for runoff elections for candidates for Mayor, City Council President and Controllerwhich were agreed upon by the Governor's office and Republican legislative leaders last weekcontinued to provoke controversy here today in a situation one official described as flipflopping like crazy.

title: RATE ACTION SCORED BY BANK OF NEW YORK
description: The Bank of New York charged yesterday that the Nixon Administration was impairing the financial soundmess of this, bank and the privatelyowned banking system in trying to hold down bank lending rates in the face of rapidly raising costs for all sources of funds.

title: STATE U. DENIES A TAKEOVER PLAN
description: ALBANY, Feb. 12A State University official told members of the Joint Legislative Committee on Higher Education today that the state had no plans to take over community colleges across the state and that local boards of trustees should retain control of spending and policy.

title: Top Pro Soccer Draftee Has a Goal on His Mind
description: John Matuzsak was an allAmerican at Tampa. He was the first choice in the football draft a few days ago. He is expected to sign a threeyear, nocut contract for about $150,000, including bonuses.

title: Inquiries Open Into Daley Links to Insurance Firm
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 12State and county officials began today to investigate the awarding of $2.9million in city insurance contracts to an Evanston firm with which one of Mayor Richard J. Daley's sons has been associated.

title: Maritime Agency Backing An R. J. Reynolds Merger
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) In a 32 decision, the Federal Maritime Commission today allowed R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., to take over U. S. Lines and operate it in competition with its own line, SeaLand Service.

title: No More Steak & Brews
description: Steak & Brew does not plan to issue any more franchises, Lawrence Ellman, president, said yesterday as he announced that the 40unit restaurant chain had reacquired a franchised restaurant at Madison Avenue and 79th Street. Closed briefly for redecoration, the restaurant has reopened as a companyowned Roast Beef & Brew. It is the fourth Roast Beef & Brew in the city.

title: Another Body Found
description: SANTA CRUZ, Calif., Feb. 12 (UPI)A human skeleton was found in a remote mountain area north of Santa Cruz yesterday, the eighth body to be found in Santa Cruz County since Jan. 1.

title: Home Again
description: They are strong men, as President Nixon said after watching the first planeloads of Vietnam war prisoners return to American hands. In the understated words of Navy Capt. Jeremiah A. Denton, they were called to serve our country under difficult circumstancesindeed, among the most difficult this Republic has demanded of its sons.

title: Concert: Teaming Up
description: The history of attempted collaboration between popular bands and symphony orchestras is fairly long by now (does anyone else remember Fritz Reiner conducting the Chicago Symphony and the SauterFinegan band nearly 20 years ago in Liebermann's Concerto for Jazz Band and Symphony Orchestra?). But very little in that history forced one to think there would be much merit in Sunday night's teaming up at Philharmonic Hall of the Symphony of the New World with the jazzrock group called Mandrill.

title: College, School Results
description: HOCKEY

title: Smith Looks Past Prize Money
description: Stan Smith, the big blond tennis player with the mustache, received $10,000 on Sunday for winning a tournament in Philadelphia and $7,500 here yesterday for being voted the best in the world last year at his game.

title: Floating Post Office to End
description: DETROIT, Feb. 12 (AP)The Federal postal authorities, declaring that they could no longer justify subsidizing Detroit's oneofakind floating post office, have ordered an end to weekly mail delivery service to ships on the Detroit River June 30.

title: $2.7Million Is Donated Anonymously to Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 12 Cornell University has received a $2.7  million gift from an unnamed alumnus, the University president, Dale R. Corson, announced today.

title: Events Today
description: Theater

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Maryland, whose coastal areas offer some of the best Canada gooseshooting in the United States, is considering a regulation that would ban the use of lead shot for waterfowlhunting.

title: Audience Magazine Suspends After Two Years
description: Audience magazine, which began two years ago as a wellwritten, topical bimonthly published between hard covers on highquality paper  and last year won the top award of the Society of Publication Designers  announced last week that its current issue would be its last.

title: Demonstrators Bar Bulldozer And Laborers at Kawaida Site
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12  A group of 200 shouting demonstrators succeeded today in preventing a bulldozer and a crew of laborers from going to work at the site of the Kawaida Towers housing project.

title: Advertising: For Love and Money
description: She was a highly rated professional in direct marketing direct mail mostly, and he was deeply immersed in film, television and cable television, but they got married anyhow.

title: Negotiators in Laos Continue To Haggle Over Truce Details
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 12is Representatives of the Laotian Government in Vientiane and the Communistled Pathet Lao were still haggling over details of an imminent Laotian ceasefire settlement today. It appeared certain that the ceasefire would go into effect before the end of the week, but a Government source said it could take years to reach a political settlement.

title: Release of Prisoners in Hanoi Is Simple and Swift
description: HANOI, North Vietnam, Feb. 12 (Agence FrancePresse)Buses still bearing the camouflage paint of war arrived at the civilian airport at Gia Lam this morning carrying American prisoners of war in their last moments of captivity.

title: Mrs. Knauer Says Business Can Best Solve Grievances
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP)  President Nixon's consumer adviser says business is more effective at resolving consumer grievances than Congress, which tends to become mired in debate and rhetoric.

title: Socialist Warns Pompidou to Heed Vote
description: PARIS, Feb. 12Francois Mitterrand, the Socialist leader of the leftist opposition, warned President Pompidou today that he would be taking a reckless gamble if the Gaullists were beaten in the elections next month and the President refused to name a leftwing premier.

title: Koch Enters Race for Mayor; Declares Crime Is Main Issue
description: Representative Edward I. Koch announced his candidacy for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday and declared that crime was the overriding issue.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Shultz Names Consultant
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (AP) Joseph A. Loftus, special assistant to the Labor Secretary for communications, was named today as special consultant to Treasury Secretary George P. Shultz. He is a former Associated Press newsman and a former member of the Washington bureau of The New York Times.

title: SUBWAY WORKERS DISRUPT HEARING
description: Angry transit workers and union officials took over a public hearing called by the Mayor's Subway Service Watchdog Commission at the Biltmore Hotel last night, preventing testimony by two suspended car inspectors who had filmed what they said was goldbricking at a Bronx subway yards.

title: No Place for Watchdogs
description: The case of A. Ernest Fitzgerald, the former Air Force Deputy Assistant Secretary who was dismissed three years ago after publicly criticizing cost overruns on Lockheed's C52 military transport plane, has become entangled in a web of official doubletalk and highlevel obfuscation.

title: List of the 40 in S.I. Blast
description: The Police Department yesterday issued the list of the men reported missing at the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation disaster on Staten Island:

title: Stenhouse Sails Aura to Victory In Yacht Race to Ft. Lauderdale
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 12A sweetwater sailor from the Great Lakes was declared the winner yesterday of the second race in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference circuit, a 40mile voyage from St. Petersburg to Fort Lauderdale.

title: Industrial Disaster
description: The explosion that killed forty workers in a huge liquefiedgas storage tank on Staten Island last weekend is a reminder of the frequency with which death, disease or crippling injury haunt the job sites where millions of Americans are employed.

title: COURT AUTHORIZES F. A. A. TO REQUIRE AIRPORT GUARDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12  A Federal judge authorized the Nixon Administration today to implement immediately an emergency order requiring the stationing of armed local law enforcement officers for every flight at each of the nation's 531 airports with airline service.

title: Nixon Talks With Colonel; Calls the Release Moving
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Feb. 12President Nixon spoke today by telephone to oneof the released American prisoners of war at Clark Air Base in the Philippines, then through his press secretary described the experience as one of the, most moving he had ever had in the White House.

title: Moynihan Urges Power to Levy Taxes Be Granted to Communities in the City
description: Daniel P. Moynihan says that decentralization, to be feasible in this city, must permit communities to levy some taxes and to control the schools in their areas.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The State Public Service Commission authorized the Brooklyn Union Gas Company yesterday to increase its rates on a temporary basis to obtain $3.609million in additional revenue. The company had sought a temporary rate increase of $5.4million annually, the commission said.

title: U.S. HEADQUARTERS MOVING TO THAILAND
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) The Pentagon announced today that it was setting up a new Southeast Asian headquarters at a base in Thailand to control teams searching for missing United States servicemen and to direct any air activity after March 28.

title: Chemical Debris Is Fouling the Atlantic
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Federal scientists reported today the recent discovery of vast areas of the Atlantic Ocean stretching from Cape Cod to the Caribbean that were befouled by floating oil, tar and plastics.

title: BASEBALL TRANSACTIONS
description: PITSBURGHSigned Charlie Sands, catcher. CINCINNATISigned Mel Balmy, Will McEnaney and Rawly Eastwick, pitchers.

title: Total of Blacks Elected in South At Record 1,144
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 12 (UPI)The number of black elected officials in the South reached a record high of 1,144 this year, with Alabama and Mississippi, once strongholds of segregation, leading nine other states in the region, the Voter Education Project announced today.

title: People and Business
description: For the first time in 100 yearsexcept for a brief period during Prohibition the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company has reached outside the Uihlein family for a president.

title: Top Pro Soccer Draftee Has a Goal on His Mind
description: John Matuzsak was an allAmerican at Tampa. He was the first choice in the football draft a few days ago. He is expected to sign a threeyear, nocut contract for about $150,000, including bonuses.

title: 2 Yippies Charged With Having Bombs Are Freed on Bail
description: Two writers for the Underground Press Syndicate were released on bail here yesterday on charges of possessing fire bombs during the Republican National Convention in Miami Beach last August.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: TONIGHT'S GAMES

title: BILL ON EVIDENCE OPPOSED BY A.B.A.
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 12  The American Bar Association voted narrowly today to oppose legislation pending in Congress that is designed to give trial judges broader discretion in admitting illegally obtained evidence in criminal cases.

title: P.O. W. Became Pawn In a Complex Struggle
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12With the first release today of American prisoners in Vietnam, Washington and Hanoi began the final act of a lengthy drama in which the prisoners became pawns in a political and military struggle.

title: I.T.T. Makes Initial Grant For 60 Exchange Students
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation has made an initial grant of $565,000 to start an I.T.T. International Fellowship Program this fall under which 30 American graduate students will be sent annually for a year's study at foreign universities, principally in the social sciences and the humanities. Thirty foreign students will be selected annually by the Institute of International Education here, administrator of the program, to attend American colleges and universities.

title: Vatican Bank Continues Daily Currency Trading
description: ROME, Feb. 12One of the few financial instiutions in Weestern Europe that carried on foreignexchange operations as usual today was the Vatican's bank. It bought large amounts of United States dollars.

title: Theater: Entertaining Double Bill
description: WELCOME TO ANDROMEDA and VARIETY OBIT, two plays by Ron Whyte; directed by Tom Moore; settings by Peter Harvey; lighting by Roger Morgan; costumes by Bruce Harrow; music by Mel Marvin; words by Ron Whyte and Bob Satuloff; narrator, David Clennon; production stage manager, Robert Keegan. Presented by Ruth Kalksteln and Patricia Gray, associate Producer, Sidney Annis. At the Cherry Lane Theater, 38 Commerce Street.

title: Pants Suits: Trade Mark For Candidate Ann Klein
description: NEWARK, Feb. 12  At this time of year, Ann Klein nornally would be looking forward to a week of snorkeling in the Caribbean, one of the sports she and her husband, Robert, a management consujtant, enjoy.

title: Gold Change Technical
description: At his Washington news conference last night announcing the 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar, George P. Shultz, the Secretary of the Treasury, said that the planned change in the gold price has no practical significance.

title: BENJAMIN FRANKEL; WROTE FILM SCORES
description: LONDON, Feb. 12 (Reuters) Benjamin Frankel, who wrote the scores for more than 100 feature films ranging from the World War II epic Battle of the Bulge to the comedy The Importance of Being Earnest, died here in a hospital last night of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: A Boost for Peron
description: Argentina's military rulers seem suddenly to have lost the deft touch that marked their handling of exPresident Juan Peron's return to the country late last year. As a result they are in danger of restoring some of the aura of martyrdom that cloaked Mr. Peron during seventeen years of exile and of creating insoluble problems for the civilian Government soon to be elected.

title: Services for Lawrence Set In Capital and Princeton
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 Services for David Lawrence, founder and editor of the U.S. News & World Report magazine, who died yesterday, will be held simultaneously in Washington and Princeton, N. J., on Wednesday at 2 P.M.

title: First Prisoner Release Completed
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Tuesday, Feb. 13  The first released American prisoners of the Vietnam war were greeted with cheers of welcome and tears of joy here yesterday as they stepped off military evacuation jets. They looked in better physical condition than most onlookers had expected, and the hospital commander here pronounced their general health reasonably good.

title: Yugoslav Official Begins Trade Talks With U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 (UPI) The Yugoslav vice premier for economic affairs, Dr. Jakov Sirotkovic today began weeklong talks with the Nixon Administration's top economic and political officials aimed at increasing United StatesYugoslav trade and investment.

title: It's Long Road to Winner's Dog Show Circle
description: Outside ring No. 6 yesterday JoJo Nesberg, a 5yearold girl with pigtails, was given the task of babysitting for her sister, Keri, 18 months. They concentrated on sharing a box of popcorn while the Great Pyrenees judging was going on at the Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 12Federal scientists reported today the recent discovery of vast areas of the Atlantic Ocean stretching from Cap Cod to the Caribbean that were befouled by floating oil, tar and plastics.

For the 45yearold professor, research at his laboratory in the Roman suburb must wait: the welfare of his embryonic walnut liqueur comes first.

Eight inches of rain pounded the mountains above the winding road during the weekend.

title: Berlin: A OnceOstracized Author Is Rediscovered
description: BERLINMarielouise Fleisser was 25 in 1926 when her first play was staged here for a single performance. It took some four and a half decades to rediscover her. Those who have promoted the comeback are successful new playwrights and movie makers still in their 20's  Rainer Werner Fassbinder (who dedicated a movie to her) and Franz Xaver Kroetz (who writes bitter Bavarian folk plays). The Fleisser play is about lonely adolescents for whom conventional education and sexual repression drive either to insanity or to conformism. Titled Purgatory in Ingolstadt, the work has been performed recently in Wuppertal, Zurich, West Berlin and Ingolstadt itself, and the author has at last become famous overnight. The prestigious publishers Suhrkamp have just brought out her collected works in three expensive volumes containing longneglected prose piecesoften barely disguised autobiographical narrations  that are perhaps even superior to the play.

title: Rally Sends Prices Of Corporate Bonds Into a Sharp Rise
description: A midafternoon rally sent prices of corporate bonds sharply higher yesterday in relatively brisk trading. Gains in this sector, the only part of the credit market that was open, ran to    point. The advancing prices extended a better performance that began late last week. It was marked by professional covering of short positions and buying by investors who, as one trader put it, missed the bottom of the market. A number of specialists predicted that when the entire market opens today there could be a general surge in prices and a resulting decline in interest rates.

description: Steel production for the week ended last Saturday totaled 2,886,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a gain of 0.4 per cent over the 2,875,000 tons poured the week before.

title: Screen: Horror Pairing:'Creeping Flesh' Joins 'A Reflection of Fear' The Casts
description: With so much celebrated acting talent in front of the camera  Robert Shaw, Mary Ure, Sally Kellerman, Signe Hasso  with Laszlo Kovacs as cinematographer behind the camera, and with a screenplay partly by Lewis John Carlino, one might have expected something good. At the very least, one might have expected a more interesting failure than "A Reflection of Fear," which opened Friday on a double bill in neighborhood theaters."A Reflection of Fear" deals with the horror attendant upon a delicate, rich and strange teen-age girl (Sondra Locke) whose secluded life is upset by the arrival of her estranged father (Mr. Shaw), who wants to divorce her mother (Miss Ure) so he can marry his mistress (Miss Kellerman). Horrible things happen  and if you want to guess why, I'll mention that the girl has a deep-voiced friend, a doll named Aaron. "Life," as somebody remarks, minutes before being done in, "is so full of changes."Sondra Locke has a virtuoso role, and I guess she is impressive, and Sally Kellerman is downright good. But "A Reflection of Fear" has been so ponderously paced and fatally overdecorated (with symbolically "meaningful" decoration) that performances can't count for much. No mere actor is allowed in the way of the crystal or the chinaware. And there is such density of atmospheric haze that half the film looks as if it had been photographed through a jellyfish.Much more fun, and also pretty fancy, is the second half of the double bill, Freddie Francis's, "The Creeping Flesh." Peter Cushing and Christopher Lee play brothers, scientists, both mad, but one is good and the other bad. There is a scary 3,000-year-old skeleton and some spooky lunacy, but the story mainly has to do with evil, which Christopher Lee has located under a microscope, like a disease germ, and for which he means to develop an antidote."The Creeping Flesh" thus belongs to the grand tradition of "Doctor, the serum! Thank God, we didn't use it on a human being!" But the doctor has, of course, just pumped quite a lot of it into the right forearm of his beautiful and virtuous young daughter.

title: People in Sports: Same Old Ali

Ali, now 31 years old, said he planned to fight four or five more years and regain the heavyweight title before retiring. Looking beyond Bugner, he has a scheduled bout with Ken Norton in San Diego on March 31.

title: Neither Fish Nor Fowl
description: SAN JUAN, P. R.The major problem with the commonwealth status of Puerto Rico is that it leaves the island neither fish nor fowl. As an offshore part of the United States without much in the way of natural resources, Puerto Rico needs numerous special provisions in the mainland law; but since its people have no real political voice in mainland affairs, it has none of the usual political means to get the kind of exclusions and preferments that it needs.

title: GOING OUT
description: JAZZ Three years ago a number of young musicians hot for contemporary and avantgarde jazz banded together as Free Life Communication, not a band but a group that would arrange for their music, and the music of likeminded people, to get a hearing. Free Life has since moved into a fifth floor loft of Space for Innovative Development, 344 West 36th Street, that central headquarters for tomorrow's esthetic. There are a score of musicians in Free Life Communication, but perhaps 100 avantgarde musicians play under its aegis each year. Tonight at 8, it is giving a Valentine's Day jazz concert and dance, with music by Frank Tusa and the Barry Miles quartet. Mr. Miles, a specialist in scat, the voiced nonword glossolalia of jazz, will present new music from Scatbird, a recent album. Dancing, as you will. Admission, $2. Information: 9474671, 7573025.
