description: State Welfare Inspector General George F. Berlinger disclosed yesterdayand the city regretfully admitted  that in the city's longheralded program for facetoface recertification of its entire relief case load, only about 0.5 per cent of the cases had thus far been interviewed.

title: FUNDS URGE S.E.C. TO. DROP AD CURB
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The Securities and Exchange Commission heard arguments today by the mutual fund industry that its survival depends on modification of agency rules that now forbid ladvertising a company's performance record of earnings for shareholders.

title: Joseph P. Connor Is Dead at 62; A Copy Desk Chief at The Times
description: Joseph P. Connor, who since 1954 had headed the copy desk at The New York Times that edits cultural, society and obitary news, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He had reentered the hospital last Wednesday with complications after recuperating at home from heart surgery last year. He was 62 years old and lived at 22 Altamount Court in Morristown, N, J., of which he was a lifelong resident.

title: AIRPORTS APPEALING NEW RULES DEADLINE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) The Airport Operators Council International asked the United States Court of Appeals here today to reverse or delay a lower court decision permitting new airport security rules to go into effect at midnight tomorrow.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
Skiing Enthusiast Finds His Hill in Flat Midwest
description: CABLE, Wis., Feb, 14Just 25 years ago Tony Wise returned from an Army stint overseas as a confirmed ski enthusiast. Having seen the sport flourish at GarmischBartenkirchen in the Bavarian Alps, he was determined to open a ski area in the Midwest. I was convinced the sport, would prove popular in our own North country, too, Wise said today. So I began looking for hills to buy. It wasn't easy. Most of the land in this part of America is as flat as a baseball diamond.

title: Six Seized Here on Charge Of Selling Illicit Methadone
description: Six men, including a $13,724ayearcounselor in an East Harlem methadone clinic, were arrested yesterday by undercover narcotics agents and charged with selling illicit methadone tablets for $5 each.

title: STATE'S ECONOMY IS RISINGAT LAST
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14After feeling the recession sooner, more severely and at greater length than the rest of the country, New York State is at last participating in the economic recovery the state's Council of Economic Advisers has concluded.

title: Bessie Brown, Was Singing Where McKinley Was Shot
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 14 (AP) Bessie Greenwood Brown, a soprano who was heard by President McKinley moments before he was assassinated, died in hospital here yesterday. She was 92 years old.

title: Fireman Is Out of Uniform
description: BOTTINGHAM, England (AP) A parttime fireman at Warsop, called out to a fire in the middle of the night, put on his wife's shortie nightdress in mistake for his shirt. He did not discover the mistake until he arrived at the scene of the fire.

title: 175 Released by South Vietnam Returned to the North in Boats
description: QUANG TRI, South Vietnam, Feb. 14 (AP)The Saigon Government freed 175 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners today in 10 fiberglass boats.

title: Screen: 'Save the Tiger':Lemmon Battles Middle Age at Tower East The Cast
description: Harry Stoner (Jack Lemmon), a Los Angeles garment manufacturer, lives in a Tudor mansion in Beverly Hills where, in cold dawns, heated swimming pools steam ominously, like tanning vats. He sends his daughter to a Swiss finishing school, drives a limousine equipped with a telephone and has a wife who suggests that he see a certain Dr. Frankfurter to cure his nightmares. "Hypnosis is the thing," she says.If not hypnosis, Harry is in great need of something, including money. To finance his disintegration into middle age, he juggles the books of Capri Casuals and isn't adverse to acting as a pimp for an important client. "Dammit!" says Harry when the client has a heart attack just before the big fashion show, "we should have gotten the order up front!"In desperation, Harry puts out a contract to burn down one of his factories. The arsonist, a fastidious professional, reassures Harry that he has set 15 major industrial fires in three years and only had five firemen overcome by smoke. "Each received a citation," the arsonist says, adding, "but this is a matter of technology, not morality.""Save The Tiger," written by Steve Shagan and directed by John G. Avildsen ("Joe," "Cry Uncle"), is not a very good movie but it's a rather brave one, a serious-minded examination of some of the least interesting aspects of the failed American dream. It's not really the sort of thing a producer would expect to make $10-million with.Although both Mr. Avildsen and Mr. Shagan are aware of how all the people and places should look and sound, their film is relentlessly unmoving, largely, I think, because life for Harry Stoner is less a series of lost confrontations with conscience which might be moving than an inventory of the small affronts that are the consequences of his failures.Harry feels very badly about all the things he has to do, and people are often quite nasty to him. A parking-lot attendant is rude. Some small boys in the park won't let him play ball with them. He comes to think upon the 1940's as a kind of Golden Age when it was possible to have courage, to affirm moral stances. Harry mourns the oblivion of Lou Gehrig, Joe Penner, Henry Wallace. He loathes monster jets and plastic baseball diamonds.Harry feels so absolutely rotten, in fact, that "Save The Tiger" seems intentionally to sentimentalize his self-pity, as if that would somehow upgrade the feeling into true passion. It doesn't. It results in a film that is, at heart, as soft as Harryand as soft as the sequence in which he spends the night with a sweet Sunset Strip waif who tells Harry, among other poetic things: "I saw this piece in National Geographic, about how lions and tigers always return to places of remembered beauty. . . ."The unfortunate thing is that although people often do talk such nonsense, most solemnly, the movie itself deals in the same kind of sentimentality. In spite of very good performances by Mr. Lemmon, who projects a lightweight bitterness that is a sad fact of homogenized American culture, and by Jack Gilford, who plays Harry Stoner's morally stricken partner, "Save The Tiger" never succeeds in disassociating itself from the self-pity it details. The film opened yesterday at the Tower East.

title: '73 World Cup Golf Listed
description: TOKYO, Feb. 14 (AP)Hsieh Minnan and Lu Lianghuan, winners of the 1972 World Cup golf tournament in Melbourne, Australia, will defend their title in the 1973 championship in Spain Nov. 22 to 25, Fred Corcoran, tournament director, said today.

title: GOVERNMENT BEATEN IN ITALIAN CHAMBER
description: ROME, Feb. 14The centrist Government of Premier Giulio Andreotti suffered a defeat in the Chamber of Deputies last night because of a split in his Christian Democratic party, and there was speculation today that he might be forced to resign before May.

title: STUDENTS FAVOR MEDICINE AND LAY
description: College freshmen are continuing a sixyear trend away from education, engineering and science and toward medicine and the law, according to a major survey by the Ameri can Council on Education.

title: Two HighSpeed Scanners Are Bought by Big Board
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 14 (UPI)A new method of handling stock certificates for clesrance at highspeed employing optical reasding system is being bought by the New York Stock Exchange's central certificate service from SanOptics, Inc., of East Hartford, Conn.

title: Kitty Hawk Sailor Sentenced
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 14 (AP)Seaman Recruit Robert L. Coleman, a 21yearold black from Homestead, Pa., was sentenced yesterday to 90 days restriction and 45 days at hard labor after pleading guilty to assault aboard the aircraft carrier Kitty Hawk at sea. A special courtmartial jury of four white officers deliberated an hour before sentencing him one day after his pleas were entered.

title: The Home Front
description: The 10 per cent devaluation of the United States dollar was indeed a bold action necessitated by the chaos in the international money markets, but it scarcely provides occasion for Mr. Nixon to claim a triumph for the way he has managed the American economy. On the contrary, the Administration's policies have done much to exacerbate a situation that had been in the making for a decadepartly because of the Vietnam war.

title: BIG SIX MAYORS MAKE PILGRIMAGE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 14  The Mayors of the state's six largest cities made their annual futile pilgrimage to the Capitol today to testify at public hearings on the Governor's proposed $8.88billion budget and to ask for millions and millions all of it a bit like going to Lourdes and catching the flu.

title: Soviet Physicist Assailed for 1968 Memo
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 14Andrei D. Sakharov, the nuclear physicist and leading Soviet civil rights advocate, was publicly criticized today for the first time for his 1968 memorandum DR peaceful coexistence and EastWest convergence, published in the West but suppressed here.

title: Cahill Aide Cleared In CoverUp Inquiry
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. was cleared today by the State Commission of Investigation of any inference that he or his staff had covered up information that ultimately led to the extortion conviction of former Secretary of Stale Paul J. Sherwin.

title: Aid and Vietnam Future
description: PARIS, Feb. 14  Although continuing official Vietnam meetings remain focused on the stability of the ceasefire, various talks are getting under way between the rival South Vietnamese factions about their country's political future.

title: Valentine's Cost Is Enough to Break Some Hearts
description: The cost of saying I love you keeps going up, as Valentine's Day observers found out yesterday.

title: Hulan Jack Surrenders To Begin Term in Prison
description: LEWISBURG, Pa., Feb. 14 (AP)Hulan E. Jatk, a former State Assemblyman from New York City, surrendered at the United States marshal's office here today to begin serving a threemonth term for conspiring to violate provisions of the TaftHartley Act.

title: GasTank Fire Theories Offered As 3 More Bodies Are Retrieved
description: Speculation on the cause of the fire last Saturday at the giant liquefiedgas storage tank on Staten Island continued yesterday among scientists and engineers as the official inquiries into the disaster went on.

title: NEW EFFORTS BEGUN TO AID 'FT. WORTH 5
description: New drives were initiated here yesterday to require the Government to free the Fort Worth Five  fiye Irish  born New Yorkers jailed Indefinitely in Texasor explain fully why they are being held so far from their families.

title: Sales Also at Record
Arthur Daley
description: Monte Irvin was the best player on the New York Giants when they were creating their fantasy of 1951, the one historians refer to as the Little Miracle of Coogan's Bluff because much of the action took place at the Polo Grounds, neatly nestled at the foot of a bluff or escarpment owned by the Coogan family. In the final six weeks of that season, unbelievable things were happening as the 13game lead of the Brooklyn Dodgers started evaporating. On the last day of the season, the two ball clubs tied for the pennant and in the last inning of the last game of the playoff series, Bobby Thomson hit his unforgettable home run win it all for the Giants. Although Giant fans were beginning to get excited about the new kid center fielder, Willie Mays, the solid man to them was Irvin. He led the team in hitting with a .312 average. He led the league in runs batted in with 121. He slammed 24 home runs. He fielded with swift precision and had a deadly throwing arm.

title: Voters Reject Tennis Plan
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Feb. 14 A proposal to build five tennis courts at Ridgewood High School for use by pupils and the public was defeated yesterday when 54 per cent of the voters opposed the $65,000 tennis bond issue.

title: RATIO OF WOMEN AMONG AGED IS UP
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 The Census Bureau has reported that, there is a large and growing ratio of women over men among older Americans.

title: Seton Hall Wins, 78 to 75, From St. Francis Quintet
description: John Ramsay scored 30 points to spark Seton Hall to an uphill 7875 victory over St. Francis last night, on the loser's floor. Aiding Ramsay was Bill Kelly, who scored 13 of his 15 points in the second half.

title: Poodle Is Called Outstanding
description: Mrs. Augustus Riggs 4th, only the fourth woman to name the best in show in the 97 years of the Westminster Kennel Club classic, told the Dog Fanciers Club members and guests, at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday, why she chose the white standard poodle, Ch. Acadia Command Performance, on Tuesday night. He is coowned by Mrs. Jo Ann Sering of Portland, Ore., and Edward B. Jenner of Richmond, Ill.

title: The Quality of JusticeII
description: The thing to fear is not the law but the judge, goes an old proverb, to which can be added the method selecting and disciplining judges. The Constitution's only guideline is good behavior on the bench; governors and mayors and voters must take it from there. Respect for the courts and judges has diminished in recent times, partly because both are overwhelmed, partly because the judiciary like other branches of government is disrepute. The calibre of judges must be improved reform of the court structure in New York City and State is to be effective.

title: NIXON BLOCKS CUT IN VETERAN FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 President Nixon ordered today the withdrawing of proposals that would have lowered disability benefits for veterans. He acted after the proposals encountered speedy and strong opposition.

The board set a public hearing for next Wednesday and a final vote on the issue Feb. 28. Revenue bonds would be sold for the stadium.

title: SISTER REGAN, HEAD OF JERSEY HOSPITAL
description: PATTERSON, N. J., Feb. 14Sister Anne Jean Regan, executive director of St. Joseph's Hospital, died yesterday morning at St. Josephs Convent. She was 62 years old.

title: Music: A Song ful Manner
description: In a way the shadow of George Szell lay over the Cleveland Orchestra's Tuesday night concert in Carnegie Hall. Istvan Kertesz conducted a program that would have been very close to the fate Conductor's heart. He was a great Mozartean, and the first piece was Mozart's E flat. Symphony (K. 543). Toward the end of his career, Szell interested? himself in Mahlek, and here were lour of Mahler's Rckert Lieder. And Szell and Dvorak were a familiar combination. Mr. Kertesz conducted. Dvorak's Eighth Symphony, a special Szell favorite.

title: Dr. Laban Rice, Educator, Devised Archeological Hoax
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 14 (AP)Dr. Laban Lacy Rice, former educator, who was a past president of Cumberland (Tenn.) University, died today in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 102 years old and lived here.

title: Bridge: An Undefeated Foursome Stands Tall in Its Victories.
description: If asked which competitive activity has produced the tallest team, most people would guess basketball. But the correct answer is bridge. A team now competing in the New York Double Knockout Championship, and unbeaten to date, can field a foursome with an average height of 6 feet 9 inches.

title: Egyptians Appear Conciliatory In Dealing With Student Unrest
description: CAIRO, Feb. 14  Egyptian authorities appeared to be trying today to end two months of unrest at Cairo universities by consulting with moderate student factions and giving them at least partial satisfaction.

title: CATHOLICS WARNED TO AVOID ABORTIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Roman Catholics have been warned by church leaders that they face excommunication if they undergo or perform an abortion.

title: Age for Beer Put at 19
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The Judiciary Committee of, the Oklahoma House voted, 76, yesterday to set the minimum age for buying beer at 19 years, instead of the current limit of 18 for girls and 21 for boys.

title: DR. HENRY REICH
description: ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 14Dr. Henry Reich, who had medical offices in Newark and Irvington, died today at St. Michael's Hospital in Newark. He was 72 years old.

title: 76ERS BEAT BUCKS TO BREAK SLUMP
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP)  The Philadelphia 76ers snapped a 20game losing streak, longest in the history of the National Basketball Association, as they edged the Milwaukee Bucks, 106104, tonight on a goaltending basket with 16 seconds to play.

title: Rap Brown Judge to Tell Police To Produce Robert Daley Files
description: The judge in H. Rap Brown's armed robberyattempted murder trial said yesterday that he would order the Police Department to produce relevant personnel records of Robert Daley, former deputy commissioner for public affairs.

title: VICTIM RESISTING HOLDUP IS SLAIN
description: A 41yearold stock clerk for Macy's was fatally stabbed early yesterday morning on a street corner in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Poodle Is Called Outstanding
description: Mrs. Augustus Riggs 4th, only the fourth woman to name the best in show in the 97 years of the Westminster Kennel Club classic, told the Dog Fanciers Club members and guests, at a luncheon in the Hotel McAlpin yesterday, why she chose the white standard poodle, Ch. Acadia Command News Performance, on of Tuesday night. He is coowned Dogs by Mrs. Jo Ann Sering of Portland, Ore., and Edward B. Jenner of Richmond, Ill.

title: Billboards in Six Counties Mark the Vietnam Peace
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 12More than 75 outdoor billboards in six northern New Jersey counties are displaying posters that commemorate the Vietnam peace.

title: Rams Sign Free Agents
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 14 (AP) The Los Angeles Rams announced the signing today of nine free agents, including two defensive backs with National (Football League experienceLeroy Howar who played for Houston in 1971, and Larry Shears, waived by Atlanta last summer after playing in nine games in 1971.

title: DOLLAR WEAKENS IN TRADING HERE
description: The dollar weakened further in relation to major foreign currencies yesterday in a market atmosphere that traders described as nervous and uncertain.

title: Pounding a Housing Beat
description: The housing patrolman walking his beat looks remarkably like the solitary neighborhood cop in a bygone New York.

title: TRIO WORKS LED BY LEOPOLD SIPE
description: The Leopold Sipe Trio, composed of three able musicians who have not yet managed to meld their talents into an ensemble of noteworthy strength. or individuality, gave a wellprepared, conscientiously played concert at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night. Not that anything went seriously wrong in the program Of trios by Martinu, Beethoven, Francis Thorne and Ravel; but a prevailingly bland approach to tempos, dynamics and expression deprived the performances of intensity and conviction.

title: Syracuse Ends St. John's String, 8070
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 14Syracuse neatly lost control of a large early lead but held on in a thrilling finith to teat St. John's, 8070, tonight, snapping the Redmenrs 14game winning streak.

title: CHARISMA LEADS IN OCEAN RACING
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 14  Charisma, a sleek, blue 56foot sloop from the Great Lakes and the unlikely hailing port of Dayton, Ohio, held a thin 7point lead in the 125boat Southern Ocean Racing Conference today after two races.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Personal Finance
description: There's a nest egg of $22billion awaiting some taxpayers at Internal Revenue Service offices, but there seems to be no rush so far to get the money.

title: Chess:
description: How much is it worth to have the white pieces  to have the first move? Match players usually respect White's advantage, playing for a victory only when they have the first move, and playing for only a draw with Black. But in last summer's world championship match in Reykjavik, Bobby Fischer, after falling behind 02 to Boris Spassky as a result of blundering away Game 1 and forfeiting Game 2 for nonappearance, came roaring back with brilliant victories in Games 3 and 5in both of which he had Black.

title: Pacific Gas Sets Plans For Hydroelectric Plant
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said yesterday it had presented plans to the Fresno, Calif., County Board of Supervisors for a pumped storage hydroelectric plant costing more than $150million. It would use two existing reservoirs and have a capacity of one million kilowatts of electricity, peak demand periods.

title: An Investment Advisory Service Is Introduced by the Chase Bank
description: An investment advisory serviice for individuals and organizations with cash or securities of $10,000 or more was introduced yesterday by the Chase Manhattan Bank.

title: Flames Trade Gratton
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 14 (AP)The Atlanta Flames of the National Hockey League traded a right wing, Norm Gratton, to the Buffalo Sabres today for a left wing, Butch Deadmarsh. It was the Flames' second trade in two days. The Flames traded a forward, Ernie Rieke, to the New York Islanders for a defenseman, Arnie Brown, yesterday.

title: Inexorably, a Copper Mine Is Eating A way Butte, Mont.
description: BUTTE, Mont.  About noon most days here the Anaconda Company blasts loose another chunk of Butte, bringing the rim of the largest openpit copper mine in the country closer to the center of what was once Montana's largest city. Pieces of Butte are literally going down the hole. Anaconda's enormous Berkeley pitthe yawning, spirally terraced excavation into the worl'd's richest hill is a mile and a quarter long, a mile wide and 1,000 feet deephas already swallowed up the saloons and sporting houses of the Meaderville section of Butte and half of McQueen.

title: MISS OELSNER WINS PRESS AWARD FOR '73
description: The Woman's Press Club of New York City announced yesterday that Lesley Oelsner, a reporter for The New York Times, had been named the winner of. the 1973 Newspaper Award of Merit for her articles, on disparities in sentencing in New York State and city courts.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
North India Music Brings Out Subtlety Of Sitar and Tabla
description: America's pop fad for Indian music has run its course, which on balance is probably all to the good. If fewer Indian artists are appearing here, these days, at least they can play now in smaller, more appropriate balls and be heard by audiences more attuned to the complexity and subtlety of their ancient tradition.

title: Advertising: Thompson Aide Presents His Case for TV
description: It was a little bite like one of those Army training films on Know Your Enemy, when Joseph Brouillard, a vice president of J. Walter Thompson, showed up yesteraay to tell the advertising and marketing staff of Time magazine about what a swell medium for corporate advertising television is.

title: U. S.North Vietnamese Communique
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) Following is the text of the United StatesNorth Vietnamese communiqu issued today after Henry A. Kissinger's visit to Hanoi.

title: Uruguay Pressing Drive on Corruption as Crisis Appears Over
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Feb. 14  The emergehcy is over, a spokesman for Uruguay's armed forces declared today, a week after the military defied civilian authority and demanded a greater role in this country's administration.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N. J., Feb. 14  When word came out of Englewood Cliffs College list yeaOhat the school had a basketball player named Jan, who was averaging more than 38 points a game, some Bergen County residents may have been confused.

title: Dollar Above New Parity In Heavy Foreign Selling
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 Heavy selling of the United States dollar hit the world's foreign exchange markets today, but the prices were strong and well above the dollar's new devalued parities with such currencies as the West German mark, the French franc and the Dutch guilder.

title: U.S. AND CUBATO SIGN HIJACK PACT TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Secretary of State William P. Rogers plans to sign an antihijacking agreement with Cuba at the State Department tomorrow while a Cuban Foreign Ministry official will do the same in Havana, a high Administration official said tonight.

title: HANS DANIEL JENSEN
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Feb. 14 (UPI)Prof. Dr. Hans Daniel Jansen, winner of the 1963 Nobel Prize for Physics, died Sunday at the age of 65, the Max Planck Institute announced today.

title: FORD RECALLING CARS TO CHECK ON BRAKES
description: DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) The Ford Motor Company has announced it is recalling 82,000 standardsize 1973model automobiles to check for possible faultily placed brake lines.

title: NETS LOSE, 11790; MELCHIONNI HURT
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 14 (AP)Cincy Powell left the bench and scored 23 points to lead the Utah Stars to a 11790 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.

title: Gunman, 13, Robs Bank In Buffalo
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 14A 13yearold gunman took $701 from a branch of the Marine Midland bank here today, according to the police, who described him as perhaps the youngest bank robber on record.

title: Guide
description: VEILED THREATS When Richard Strauss's Salome opened in Dresden in 1905, the Kaiser went but found the opera a bit of a shocker it would hurt the composer's reputation, he thought. When it opened at the Met in New York two years later, the realestate company that owned the premises did not let it run into a second performance  it didn't get back to the Met for 27 years. Its early reviews featured such adjectives as monstrous, pestilential, mephitic, abhorrent, loathsome and a similar run of vocabulary difficult to find in the press clipping book. Salome does not measure up to a Last Tango nowadays, but it is still a lively piece. It opens for the first time this season at 8 tonight at the Met, 63d Street and Broadway (7993100, or, for credit cards, 79944201, with Karl Bhm conducting (he turns 80 next year and Austria will honor its native with of concerts). Ursula Schroeder has the title role, her first in the opera. Other firsts in Salome are Ragnar Ulfung as Herod and James Morris as the soldier. Tickets, $4 to $17.50; standing room upstairs, $1.75, and downstairs, $2.85.

title: RIESSEN DEFEATS BARTHES IN 3 SETS
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, FeB. 14 (UPI)  Topseeded Marty Riessen of Evanston Ill., survived a number of doublefaults and missed volleys today to squeeze past Pierre Barthes of France 46, 63, 63, and gain the quarterfinals of the $50,000. World Championship Tennis circuit tournament.

title: Notes on People
description: In Tokyo, former Premier Eisaku Sato disclosed what Mrs. Richard M. Nixon whispered to him after her husband's inauguration last month. I enjoyed that magnificent party at the White House, the 71yearold former Premier said, particularly the remark Mrs. Nixon made about me while dancing with her as my partner at the party. Mrs. Nixon whispered to me complimentarily that I looked 10 years younger. I was very pleased with her remark. I have never learned to dance. I left Mrs. Nixon to lead me. All I did was pay heed not to step on her toes. I enjoyed the dance immensely. What I now regret very much was I had no sense of sniffing what kind of perfume she used.

title: Saigon and Vietcong Aides Hold 4th Meeting in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 (APDelegates from South Vietnam and the Vietcong held their fourth meeting today to work out procedural details for political negotiations in Saigon.

title: Embezzlement of $17,750 Laid to ExDayCare Aide
description: A 36yearold beauty parlor operator who was named a $10,000ayear director of a Brooklyn daycare center in 1971 was charged yesterday with embezzling $17,750 from the center. He was arrested and charged with grand larceny.

title: Austin Bailey, a Developer Of TransAtlantic Phones
description: MILLBURN, N. J., Feb. 14Dr, Austin Bailey, a physicist who was a pioneer in the development of transAtlantic radiotelephones with American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died Friday at his home, 193 Sagamore Road. He was 79 years old.

title: Excerpts From Stern's and Kugler's Testimony a State Inquiry
description: Following are excerpts from testimony by Herbert J. Stern, United. States Attorney for New Jersey, and George F. Kugler Jr., the State Attorney General, describing their recollections of their initial meeting on the Sherwin case. Among those involved in the testimony are David A. Biederman, then a deputy attorney general; Bruce Goldstein, assistant United States attorney; Pierre P. Garven, Governor Cahill's counsel; John C. Kohl, Commissioner of Transportation; John F. McCarthy Jr., chairman of the investigation commission, and John J. Francis, former justice of State Supreme Court, who was special counsel to the commission.

title: Dance Magazine Offers Data on Funding Panels
description: An expanded edition of Dance magazine's annual directory, containing previously published information on the advisory panels that disburse public funds on the national and state level, has just come out.

title: MiniOperas Ready to Take Met Role
description: Stop! Alvin Ailey shouted above the orchestra and the massed chorus, whose members were dressed in brightly colored satin simulations of medieval monks habits. The ministage of the Forum Theater at Lincoln Center's Vivian Beaumont fell eerily quiet.

title: Protesting Greek Students And Police Clash in Athens
description: ATHENS, Feb, 14Disorders broke out at the national technical university here today when policemen raided the downtown campus and, used force to disperse a meeting of student strikers. At least 45 students were arrested.

title: The Magic of Comic Strip
description: What were the playwrights trying to do? Did they succeed in doing it? Was it worth doing? The classic questions of criticism. The playwrights are Bury St. Edmund (a likely name) and Stuart Gordon. What they are trying to do is to bring the magic of Marvel Comics into the living theater.

title: Construction Accord Bars Jurisdictional Disputes
description: MIAMI BEACH, Feb. 14 (AP) Officials from the bulk of the nation's $100 billionayear construction industry and 16 A.F.L.C.I.O. unions have reached an agreement designed to eliminate jurisdictional disputes, sources here report.

title: Rockefeller on Vacation
description: Governor Rockefeller left yesterday morning for a brief working vacation in the Caribbean. His office said the Governor was expected to return early next week.

title: Son's Safe Return Gives Ill Mother a Will to Live
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 14Mrs. Anita Woods, near death in the intensive care unit of Coronado Hospital, told her doctor in frail whisper today that the [bravery of my son and his safe return have given me a new determination to live.

title: Nixon's Plan Spurs Amex In Foreign Listing Effort
description: The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it was undertaking a major program to attract more listings of corporate securities from Europe and Japan. The exchange indicated that the program had been accelerated by the Nixon Administration's proposal Monday to abolish the 10yearold interest equalization tax on foreign securities bought here.

title: Knicks Lose to Bulls, 100 to 98, As Late Rally Fails at Garden
description: The Chicago Bulls outplayed the New York Knicks in the second half at Madison Square Garden last night, and in one sense their 10098 victory was as simple as that. But a lot of things happened in the last few seconds that require explanation, even to the 19,694 customers who constituted the 22d capacity crowd of the Knick season.

title: FERDINAND MENEFEE
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 14 (UPI)  Ferdinand Menefee, professor emeritus of engineering mechanics at the University of Michigan for 40 years and a pioneer of the St. Lawrence Seaway, died Monday. He was 87 years old.

title: 30YEARSENTENCE FOR DRUGS UPSET
description: In a unanimous decision, an appellate court has ordered a new trial for a 24yearold narcotics addict who was sentenced last year to a 30year term for the sale of oneseventythird of an ounce of heroin.

title: Fire Union Head Disputes Department Fatality Data
description: The head of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association accused the Fire Department yesterday of falsifying figures on how Many civilians had died in fires in January in an effort to justify what he asserted was a decrease in fire protection.

title: AMEX AND OTC DECLINE SHARPLY
CLARK BASE GETS THANKS OF P.O.W.'S
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Thursday, Feb. 15Twenty freed American prisoners departed for the United States yesterday on a United States Air Force medical evacuation plane, and two planes, each carrying 20 freed prisoners, departed today.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: U.S. Minesweepers Clear Anchorage for Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)American minesweepers have cleared an anchorage in the Gulf of Tonkin for the naval force that will clear the mines from North Vietnamese waters, the Defense Department said today.

title: 3 More Banks in Britain Raise Loan Costs to 9%
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (Reuters)All four of Britain's major clearing banks have now fallen into line on setting their base rates at the record 9 per cent level, taking the cost of borrowing for their corporate and private customers to between 10 and 15 per cent.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SURGE TO RECORD
description: Soybean futures again surged to a new historic high price, yesterday, rising the daily permissible limit of 10 cents a bushel. The new high price on the Chicago Board of Trade became $5.83 a bushel. The beans closed at the new high.

title: TV: Of Ghosts and Ads
description: The opening hour of And the Bones Came Together, a suspense teaser on television tonight, is pretty good. The final 30 minutes run downhill. And the entire 90minute program, starting at 11:30 in the A.B.C. Wide World of Entertainment slot, runs for its life in a torrent of commercials.

title: Teacher Robbed in Class, 5th Recent School Holdup
description: A teacher in an East Harlem elementary school was held up and robbed of $11 in her classroom yesterday as her 25 thirdgraders were enjoying a Valentine's Day party.

title: Postal Service on Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (UPI) The United States Postal Service announced today that it would operate on a holiday schedule on Washington's Birthday, Feb. Limited window services and special delivery will be available, but there will be no residential or business area deliveries. Mail will be collected from mail boxes designated with one or two white stars as late in the day as possible.

title: Brooklyn College Five Beats Baruch on Late Rally, 8676
description: Brooklyn College continued its quest last night for a postseason smallcollege tournament berth with an 8676 triumph over Baruch College. Baruch rallied to take the lead, 6564, with six minutes to play after Brooklyn had led throughout the game. But Brooklyn scored 8 consecutive points to assure the victory. Brooklyn now has won 15 games in 22 starts, while Baruch is 9 and 4.

description: LONDON, Feb. 14  Heavy selling of the United States dollar hit the world's foreign exchange markets today, but the prices were strong and well above the dollar's new devalued parities with such currencies as the West German mark, the French franc and the Dutch guilder.

title: Chileans, Anxious Over Change, Flock to Psychiatrists
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 14Psychiatrists and private psychiatric clinics here report a dramatic increase in middleclass and upperclass patients suffering from anxieties provoked by the social and economic upheavals of two years of Marxist government.

title: Nixon Aides Said to Draft, Weaker StripMining Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 Advocates within the Nixon Administration of stiff regulation of strip mining have suffered nearly total defeat in their efforts to draft a strong control bill.

title: ELLSBERG RULING AIDS PROSECUTION
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb, 14The prosecution in the Penta gon papers trial scored a ?? victory today when the ?? admitted into evidence a man ual that governs the ?? arrangements between the Defense Department and ?? companies doing business with the armed forces.

title: RUSSELL T. BRANCH
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 14  Russell T. Branch, who retired in 1957 as chairman of the Stone & Webster Engineering Corporation, died Monday in Manhasset Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived at 10 Birchdale Lane.

description: The stock market broke sharply yesterday in its most massive decline in nearly 20 months, only one session after the dollar devaluation had set off an explosive rally.

description: Lieut. Col. Terry Lee. Born, Oct. 19, 1934. Scheduled to die, Feb. 25, 1973.

description: To the Editor:

description: BASKETBALL

title: Books of The Times
description: Contrary, to the recent news, the Cold War is still very much with usat least it is in these two espionage thrillersthe one an intermittently diverting entertainment; the other a perfect little gem of thriller.

title: Henle Memorial Tomorrow
description: A memorial meeting in honor of James Henle, president of Vanguard Press from 1928 to 1952, will be held tomorrow at 3 P.M. at Freedom House, 20 West 40th Street. Mr. Henle died in Washington Jan. 9 at the age of 81. Speakers will include William V. Shannon of the editorial board of The New York Times and James T. Farrell, whose Studs Lonigan trilogy was published by Mr. Henle.

title: Red Carpets And Other Hypocrisies
description: The American prisoners of war are coming home from captivity, some of them after as long as seven years, all 592 of them to heroes' welcome. President Nixon has remarked upon the good character required to withstand imprisonment, and has sought to insure the privacy of their family reunions. At Honolulu, a red carpet was spread for them. Each will be able to use a new Ford automobile for a year without cost. Official mourning for Presidents Truman and Johnson has been replaced by flags at full staff, representing official pleasure in the prisoners' return. The Pentagon reports that it has persuaded the nation's biggest employers to find jobs for former P.O.W.'s who choose to leave military service. Television and the newspapers breathlessly cover every stage of the return.

title: U.S. Sets Credit Plan On Grain for Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Feb. 14 (UPI)  The United States today signed an agreement providing Indonesia with a 40year credit of $76.3million with which to buy American wheat, cotton and bulgur.

title: Tea Testing: Search For a Perfect Blend
description: ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J.  Noble Toby Fleming, suave and pinstripqd, looks very much the president of an international business until you notice the tiny little black leaves clinging to his nose. Also, he keeps three chromeplated brass rolling cuspidors outside his office  and uses them constantly. Mr. Fleming, despite appearances, is no eccentric. He is a teataster.

title: MIGUEL A. FALLA
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 14 Miguel A. Falla, former president of the Cuban Atlantic Sugar Company, the largest sugar company in Cuba, died last Thursday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old.

title: Alleged FireBomb Thrower Shot After Chase by Police
description: A 21yearold man who was wearing a skullcap of the kind used by a militant group the police said was involved in attempted shakedowns of Harlem merchants was shot and seriously wounded early yesterday after he allegedly hurled a fire bomb at a gasoline station on upper Park Avenue.

title: FED ACTS TO EASE RATE PRESSURES
EVERGLADES WON BY RESTLESS JET
description: MIAMI, Feb. 14The other horse win was the cry that went up when Restless Jet of the Elkwcod Farms won the $30,950 Everglades at Hialeah today.

title: The City Hall Rotunda, a Political Crossroads
description: Don't push. ... Take your time. ... Do you know what happened to those people who were here before?

title: Pullman Unit Gets Order For Urea Plants in China
description: AMSTERDAN, The Netherlands, Feb. 14 (Reuters)Kellogg Continental, which is controlled by Pullman, Inc., said today it won a $34million order from China for three urea fertilizer plants.

title: Returning P.O.W.'s Are Flooded With Offers of Gifts and Other Benefits
description: ??ning prisoners of war are coming home with little public fanfare, but many of them will find an unexpected flood of homecoming gift offers from generousand, some fear, selfservingdonors.

title: Editor Chokes to Death
description: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Feb. 14 (UPI)Joseph G. Majersky, editorial page editor of The Jefferson City PostTribune and CapitalNews, choked to death last night while attending a Jefferson City Chamber of Commerce awards banquet. Mr. Majersky, 55 years old, choked on food caught in his throat and was dead before he could be helped.

title: PHILIPPINES COURT MEETS ON CHARTER
description: MANILA, Feb. 14The Philippine Supreme Court donned their black robes this week and, through daylong sessions in their crimsondraped hall, heard a panel of lawyers plead with them to save the republic from the stark reality of a dictatorship.

title: Meetings of Atomic Panel Will Be Opened to Public
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14The Atomic Energy Commission has decided to open to the public the meetings of its key Advisory Committee on Reactor Safeguards.

title: NIXON TO PROPOSE A PLAN TO ASSURE ENERGY SUPPLIES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 President Nixon said today in a radio address that he would propose a plan to assure the nation adequate supplies of energy at acceptable economic arid environmental costs.

title: Transcript of the President's Radio Address Resources and the Environment
description: Following is the transcript of a nationwide radio address by President Nixon yesterday on resources and the environment, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Freed P.O.W. Asserts He Upheld U.S. Policy
description: CLARK AIR BASE, Philippines, Thursday, Feb. 15 (AP) An American pilot reported to have made antiwar statements while a prisoner of war in North Vietnam said in a news conference today that at no time during my imprisonment have I failed to support my President and my country and my President's policy.

title: Article 3  No Title
New Jersey Briefs
description: Judge Mitchell H. Cohen denied defense motions yesterday in United States District Court in Camden for acquittals and for dropping of certain counts in the extortionconspiracy trial of four present and former Atlantic City officials.

title: Rivalry in Blue: Housing Police vs. City Police
description: In the early hOurs of 12, Detectives Leroy Ruffin and Phillip Stubbs of the Housing Authority Police, while offduty, were wounded outside a Brooklyn bar after they had moved to search two men carrying concealed weapons.

title: Brooklyn Man Is Charged With Harassment of Women
description: An unemployed Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday afternoon on charges of having harassed several women in the Park Slope section by walking up to them on the street, throwing them to the ground and fleeing without further molestation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A State Supreme Court justice ivied in Mineola, L. I., yesterday that a prospective witness would be permitted to testify in a court proceeding through the use of a videotape recording.

title: Political Contributions Held Cancer in Report
description: TRENTON, Feb. 14The report by the State Commission on Investigation in the Paul J. Sherwin case described some political contributions as malignant cancer.

title: Laos Talks Continue
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 14Discussions on how to end the ??ighting in Laos continued here ??oday, but the accord that Government sources had prelicted might go into effect by he end of this week remained but of reach.

title: U.S. AUTO MAKERS POSE SALES RISES
PLANT IN CLIFTON WILL CLOSE TODAY
description: CLIFTON, Feb. 14  Ordinarily the talk during,the lunch hour at Gus's Tavern opposite the rail car division of the Fruehauf Corporation here is spiced with easy raillery over who lost how much on the trotters and the thousand reasons why Muhammad All no longer floats like a butterfly or stings like a bee.

title: British Scrap Hovertrain
description: LONDON, Feb. 14 (AP)Britain's experimental Hovertrain, designed to run on an elevated track at speeds of up to 300 miles an hour, is being scrapped, Aerospace Minister Michael Heseltine announced today.

title: An Ice Rink in Their Own Backyard
description: Call me Dumbo, 3yearold Jennifer Goodnow insisted as she stepped out on the ice on her new doublerunner skates. She extended her arms and, as she glided along, she wriggled her fingers in a child's classic simulation of a bird in flight.

title: Court Weighs U.S. Complaint On I. B. M. Destruction of Index
description: Federal Judge David N. Edelstein yesterday reserved decision on a Justice Department motion that the destruction of Control Data Corporation's computerized document index as part of C.D.C.'s settlement of its antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation constituted a violation of a court order in the Government's separate antitrust action against I.B.M.

title: John Brown's Song Stirs Writer to a New Biography
description: A song first heard more than 60 years ago from the lips of an aging Civil War veteran has sparked a widely acclaimed biography. The song was The John Brown Song, known now as John Brown's Body. The lad who heard it, from his grandfather who fought with the 9th Pennsylvania Cavalry, was Richard O. Boyer. And his book is The Legend of John Brown: A Biography and a History, just published by Alfred A. Knopf.

title: OWNERS, PLAYERS MAY NEED UMPIRE
description: The baseball club owners' proposal for salary arbitration was described yesterday as innovative but in need of further negotiation to make it workable.

title: MRS. SOLOMON KUNIS
description: Mrs. Gloria Schneider Kunis,. a guidance counselor at Adlai E. Stevenson High School in the Bronx and a writer on problems of the retarded, died Monday of cancer in Mount Sinai Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 2055 Center Avenue, Fort Lee, N. J. Her husband. Solomon Kunis, is director of the graphics division of United Business Publications.

title: O.E.C.D. Report on Norway Points to Cloudy Outlook
description: PARIS, Feb. 14 (Reuters)The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development today said the shortterm outlook for a better balance in the norwegian economy remained cloudy.

title: Canadiens Rout Rangers With 4 Early Goals, 63
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 14The hockey game that fans and players considered the clutch one so far this National League season was captured tonight in exuberant style by the Canadiens, who trounced the Rangers by 63.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The card, flower and candy shops did their usual land office business on Valentine's Day, even though prices for these romantic staples have crept upward in the last three years.

title: Shanghai Tops Tokyo and New York As the World's Most Populous City
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 14Shanghai has moved, into first place as the world's most populous city, oustripping Tokyo and New York.

title: Joe Masiell, in Nightclub Debut, Takes PostBrel Fling at Songs
description: Joe Masiell, one of the most impressive of a long list of singers who passed through Jacques Brel Is Alive and Well and Living In Paris during its fiv4year run, is, like many others in that long list, taking a postBrel fling in nightclubs. Mr. Masiells nightclub debut at Walter's Apartment, Second Avenue at 56th Street, coincides with the debut of an entertainment policy in this intimate restaurant and bar which was once known simply as The Apartment.

title: UnionCompany Accord Spurs Computerized Typesetting Here
description: Representatives of the printing industry and the typographical union demonstrated a new computerized typesetting systern yesterday that is now in operation at Pandick Press here.

title: Pioneer 10 Pierces Asteroid Belt Safely
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Pioneer 10 emerged unscathed today from its sevenmonth, 270millionmile passage through the asteroid belt, which it found to be less of an obstacle course than scientists had feared.

title: UNION FRAUD LAID TO RETIRED JUDGE
description: A retired acting justice of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the chief clerk of the court's criminal term and 28 officers and trustees of an independent union were all charged yesterday with using the union's funds for living and entertainment expenses.

title: Battista, Fino and R. F. Wagner Jr, in Council Races
description: The battle for seats on the City Council in this year's election widened yesterday with the entry of Robert F. Wagner Jr., Assemblyman Vito P. Battista and former Supreme Court Justice Paul A. Fino in the campaign.

title: States and Doctors Wary On Eased Abortion Ruling
description: State governments and the American medical profession have thus far moved with extreme caution in implementing the Supreme Court's ruling of 25 days ago giving women the right to obtain abortions.

title: OpenMarket Committee Widens Growth Range of Money Supply
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee adopted an innovation in its conduct of monetary policy at its meeting in December, it was disclosed today in a summary of the meeting.

title: KERNER JURY TOED PROOF IS LACKING
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15The attorney for former. Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois contended today that the Federal Government had failed to prove that Mr. Kerner, in accepting a chance to buy lucrative horse racing stock while he was Governor, had been offered a bribe or had accepted one.

title: Book of The Times
description: CARO: THE FATAL PASSION. By Henry Blyth. 260 pages. Illustrated. Coward, McCann and Geoghegan. $8.95.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 39

title: TEXAS OIL QUOTAS ARE KEPT AT 100%
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 15Gasoline shortages will be the next item on the energycrisis agenda, Jim C. Langdon, chairman of the Texas Railroad Commission, said today as Texas kept its oil wells at wide open production rates for another month.

title: ROCKEFELLER FEELS A TAX CUT IS OUT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15Governor Rockefeller said today that projections of the state's fiscal condition over the next five years clearly demonstrate the perils of commitments to tax reduction or to greater spending than the state can reasonably finance over the long term.

title: COUGAR RALLY TOPS COLONELS,120 TO 108
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., Feb. 15 (AP)Billy Cunningham scored 28 points and Carolina got strong support from its reserves as the Cougars charged from behind tonight to beat Kentucky, 120108, in an American Basketball Association game.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: WEDNESDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Woman, 19, Gets 6Year Term And Man 25 Years in Rape of 2
description: A 19yearold woman convicted of rape was sentenced yesterday to six years in prison by Supreme Court Justice James Leff. Her male companion was sentenced to 25 years.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Gains; Truck Tonnage Up 14.5%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads last week totaled an estimated 15,7 billion tonmiles, 12 per cent above the corresponding week a year ago. Carloadings in the same week totaled 484,239 cars, up 8.1 per cent over last year.

title: Morton Hints Congress Bid To Clear Alaskan Pipeline
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (UPI)  Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton said today the Administration might have to ask Congress to change the law so construction could proceed on the controversial Alaskan oil pipeline.

title: SecondGeneration Environmental Issues
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15The socalled energy crisis has made many people aware that a second generation of environmental problems is closing in President Nixon, in his third environmental message to Congress today, took partial note of this. But he indicated that there were some things he preferred to worry about later. To wit: a population policy and a resource policy above and beyond the matter of fuels. Environmental problems divide roughly into two categories. One is the various kinds of pollution, with which the nation has been preoccupied up to now and whose solution is estechnical.

title: Ford Official Urges a Major Loosening of Emission
description: The Ford Motor Company, saying that the automobile industry has been backed to the cliff edge of desperation, pro; posed yesterday a major loos, ening of the Federal Clean Air Act to avert a complete, shut down of the United States auto industry.

title: BIDS CONGRESS ACT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 President Nixon proposed today that Congress gradually eliminate direct payments to farmers to subsidize their crops, ending a system that has cost the Government more than $48billion under three Presidents.

title: Documentaries About and by Women Are Shown
description: A New Consciousness, which opened yesterday at the Whitney Museum, is a program of three mediumlength documentaries by and about young women actively concerned with the quality of their lives in their families, their homes, their professionswhich are by and large the arts. One of the three movies, Susan Kleckner's Birth Film, wasn't available for my screening, (I am assured it will he in the show), but Judith Dancoff's Judy Chi. cago and the California Girls is interesting, and Joyce Chopra's and Claudia, Weill's Joyce at 34 is lovely enough to justify anybody's program of documentary films.

title: Sabres Down Rangers, 41; Crozier Outstanding in Goal
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 15Normally the most composed of all National Hockey League teams, the Rangers tonight again looked like players who had met only minutes before game time and they dropped a 41 decision to the Sabres.

title: Hand GunMaking Barred Under Bill Voted by Council
description: The City Council yesterday unanimously approved a bill designed to outlaw the manufacture or assembly here of cheap hand guns commonly known as Saturday night specials.

title: Thomas Shevlin, 58, Dies; Led Group to Save Animals
description: Thomas H. Shevlin, a sportsman and vice president of Louwana, a world organization for the preservation of animal life, died Wednesday of cancer at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 58 years old.

title: BOND PRICES POST MODERATE GAINS
description: Bond prices moved moderately higher yesterday, reflecting massive market operations by the Federal Reserve and the strong nearterm fundamentals of supply and demand.

title: Amer. Basketball. Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAME

title: Squash Racquets Tourney Begins at Princeton Today
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 15 (AP)The men's squash racquets national singles tournament gets under way at Princeton University tomorrow. It will be the first time in 62 years that it has not been played in an urban area.

title: HAROLD J. TRUE
description: DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP)Harold J. True, a retired Detroit newscaster whose career included 10 years as the announcer for the Lone Ranger radio program, died yesterday. He was 81 years old.

title: DH Role Not for Him, Frank Robinson Says
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 15 (AP)Frank Robinson returned to his home here today after managing Santurce in the Puerto Rican League and said he was pleased at the trade that sent him from the Dodgers to the Angels, where Harry Dalton knows what I can do.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES CONTINUE TO RISE
description: Soybean futures again jumped the 10centsAbushel daily limit, yesterday, reaching a, histgric high of $5.93 bushel in terms, the March delivery on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: PRESIDENT CALLS FOR PHASING OUT OF FARM SUBSIDY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Presdent Nixon proposed today that Congress gradually eliminate direct payments to farmers to subsidize their crops, ending a system that has cost the Government more than $48billion under three Presidents.

title: Representative Riegle Said To Plan Shift to Democrats
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Representative Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Republican who has consistently opposed the Nixon Administration on a wide range of issues, is planning to become a Democrat, according to informed sources in the House.

title: Golden Gate Track Drops Double and Adds an Exacta
description: ALBANY, Calif., Feb. 15 (AP) The traditional daily double will be missing when Golden Gate Fields opens its 87day racing season tomorrow.

title: Institutional Dirty Tricks
description: WASHINGTON  Most people believe that the function of the Central Intelligence Agency is to collect intelligence. In fact, however, as many as onethird of its 18,000 employes are occupied with political operations. The Bay of Pigs, the Iranian and Guatemalan coups, the effort to overthrow the Albanian Government in 1949, the secret war in Laos and other lesser known operations have been run by the C.I.A.'s Directorate of Plans.

title: MRS. MARY J. ODEGAARD
description: Mrs. Mary J. Odegaard, a telephone communications supervisor for The New York Times, died, apparently of a heart attack, Wednesday. She was 48 years old and lived at 5419 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: Felix Slavik, the Mayor of Vienna, visited the Mayor of Jersey City yesterday and said the outlook for urban centers throughout the world was improving.

title: Crisis in Uruguay
description: Uruguay has emerged from its worst political crisis in four decades with heavy damage to the democratic system that was once the pride and envy of the Americas. President Juan Bordaberry has remained in office only by ceding a large measure of his constitutional power to military leaders who assert the right to select key Cabinet members as well as to chart drastic reforms to cope with corruption, Inflation, unemployment and an outdated landtenure system.

title: Prosecutors at Odds
description: TRENTON, Feb. 15Federal and state lawenforcement authorities in New Jersey have long maintained that a consolidated campaign against organized crime and official corruption could not succeed without public confidence and mutual gust and cooperation between the two principal prosecutors in the state  the United States Attorney for New Jersey and the State Attorney General.

title: Dropout Wives Their Number Is Growing
description: The number of wives running away from home, or walking away from marriage, has risen dramatically over the last 10 years.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 3.9 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and in dustrial materials rose to 142,4 from 138.5 last week.

title: Williams Is Signed by Cubs; Pay Estimated at $150,000
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Billy Williams, the 1972 major league batting champion and runnerup in the voting for the National League's Most Valuable Player award, signed his Chicago Cubs contract today for an estimated $150,000 salary.

title: Spots of Blight Mar Queens Stability
description: City housing officials went the Flushing section of Queens yesterday for a close look pockets of decay that threaten the middleclass stability that surrounds them.

title: Woman Will Counsel Women Employes at C.B.S.
description: Kay Wight Boyers has been appointed the first woman counselor at the Columbia Broadcasting System, in an accelerated company program aimed at employing and advancing more women in the corporate structure.

description: BASKETBALL

title: The Cabinet Big Three
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The focus of American foreign policy is now obviously moving away from the war in Vietnam to the great economic questions now troubling the nations, and this is bringing new men and new problems to the fore in Washington.

title: 2,290 Chevrolets Recalled
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  The General Motors Corporation is recaling 2,290 Chevrolets, mostly station wagons, to modify their exhaust control devices. The modifications were ordered by the Environmental Protection Agency after it learned that General Motors had incorrectly listed vehicle weights, which determine the amount of pollutants allowed. G.M. said the mistake had been inadvertent and owners would not be charged for the modifications.

title: HijackGuard Rule Takes Effect But Is Eased for Some Airports
description: A Government regulation requiring that all airports with airline flights provide armed local policemen to help intercept potential hijackers finally went into effect today. But a Federal court greatly cushioned the impact on the many airports that have complained that they would have trouble complying.

title: Men's Apparel Retailers Prepared to Pay More
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15Men's apparel retailers are resigned to paying from 5 to 20 per cent more for their merchandise this year and are just as resigned to increasing their selling prices by the same percentages.

title: Red Smith
description: In the stratosphere of big, big, big business, the president of, say, I.B.M. Corporation, doesn't just pick up the phone and ring his friend, the chairman of the board General Motors. Calls like that go through channels manned by operators, secretaries, expediters and maybe junior vice president or two. This tickled the public ultilities magnate, Christopher T. Chenery, as far back as 1950 when he had Hill Prince, the 2yearold champion of 1949 who was destined to be Horse of the Year at 3. That spring, when Hill Prince was coming up to the Kentucky Derby, there would be a deal of buzzing, ringing and scurrying until at last the president of Standard Oil would be connected with the board chairman of Southern Natural Gas. Hello, Chris? an urgent voice would say. How's the horse?

title: Saigon Threatening to Hold Up Release of Communist Prisoners
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15South Vietnam threatened today to hold up the release of Communist prisoners of war if the Communists continued to delay the return of prisoners they hold.

title: An Ambitious North Italian Menu That Fulfills Its Promise
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (Tour triangles to none).

title: HOUSING PLANNED ON SCARSDALE SITE
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 15  A Westchester County chapter of the ethical culture movement has applied for a zoning change to build 30 low  and moderateincome apartments on two acres of wooded land it owns here.

title: VoteSeekers in Chile Court the Housewife
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 15 The column of women pressing into a small food shop in Santiago's middleand workingclass Nufioa district stretched around the block and ended a few steps before a drab, gray, 19thcentury church.

description: There are hundreds of such situations around in the stock market. The stocks represent companies promising excellent earnings growth but, no glamour and thus no appeal for the institutional investor.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 (UPI) The State Senate approved a proposal today to ban sex films on outdoor movie screens visible outside the theater.

title: Nixon Aides Seeking to Cut State Social Programs by $800Million
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 The Nixon Administration] moved today to narrow such state social programs as day care and health and employment services and cut Federal outlays for them by $800million in the fiscal year 1974.

title: WHITLAM DRAWS FIRE IN AUSTRALIA
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 15 Prime Minister Gough Whitlam has come under heavy fire from many sides today for exposing Australian intelligent activities in Singapore in a supposedly off the record press briefing this week.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15Richard G. Waldhaus, 60 American prisoner who remained in Vietnam after his release by the Vietcong Monday, left today for home, the United States Embassy reported.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Secretary of State William P. Rogers, today signed the agreement with Cuba: intended to curb hijacking betaven the two countries, but said the accord did not foreshadow any improvement in Washingtonapos;s relations with Premier Fidel Castro's Government.

description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Feb. 15Scientists at the State University of New York here have discovered that the orange soil found on the moon during the Apollo 17 explorations is billions of years older than was first thought.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 15One of Governor Cahill's favored legislative proposalsa yearly $12 million urbanaid package earmarked for safe and clean neighborhoodswas approved by a 69to2 vote today in the State Assembly.

title: HARVESTER'S PROFIT CLIMBED IN QUARTER
description: The International Harvester Company, one of the nation's largest industrial enterprises, and maker of farm machinery, motor trucks and industrial tractors, engines and other products, realized a 37 per cent increase in first fiscal quarter sales and sharply higher earnings over the depressed period a yea rearlier.

title: Tim Holt, Western Film Star Who Made 149 Pictures, Dead
description: SHAWNEE, Okla., Feb. 15 (AP)Tim Holt, a popular star in Western movies before and after World War II, died today at the Shawnee Medical Center Clinic. He was 54 years old.

title: Music: Evening of Heavy Monotony
description: The Evenings for New Music that are presented each season at Carnegie Recital. Hall by the Center of the Creative and Performing Arts, State University of New York at Buffalo, have provided lively moments in the past. But Wednesday night's program seemed designed to set records for heavy monotony.

title: A FUND SHIFT LAID TO ARMS MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15By temporarily holding back payments of Government money into company retirement funds, at least five major defense contractors have, in effect, received millions of dollars in interestfree Federal loans, Senator William. Proxmire said today.

description: The newspaper headline was tacked to a wall in Steve Smith's Huntington Beach, Calif., apartment. It read:

description: Miriam Makeba, giving her first New York concert in three years, sang to an enthusiastic audience that filled Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday evening.

title: 6Year Losing Streak Ends for High School
description: FRIENDSVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 15 (AP)  Tiny Friendsville Academy ende dits 138game losing streak in high school basketball tonight, beating St. Camillus Academy of Corbin, Ky., 6243.

title: Italy Lifts Last Tango Ban
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  A Bologna court ruled today that the controversial film Last Tango in Paris, starring Marlon Brando, could immediately be shown in Italy. The film was seized last December on the orders of the Rome Public Prosecutor because of allegations that it was obscene.

title: Value of Yen Still Rising As Pace of Trading Slows
description: TOKYO, Feb. 15  The Tokyo foreign exchange market canned down a bit today but the value of the dollar continued to slide.

title: 6 Reputed Mafiosi Accused of an Extortion Plot
description: Six reputed Mafia figures were indicted here yesterday as a result of an alleged extortion conspiracy to recover $100,000 that had been lost in a stock investment.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)The United States recorded its largest steeltrade deficit ever last year, despite a slight decline in imports from 1971's record, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported today.

title: Trial On in SchoolBus Tragedy With 2 Sides Disputing Cause
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Feb. 15The trial of the driver of the school bus involved in a fatal collision with a freight train in nearby Congers opened here today with attorneys for the two sides presenting contradictory accounts of the final moments before the crash.

title: Prices on Amex and Counter Off 2d Day in Row
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market finished lower yesterday for the second consecutive session in moderate trading.

title: Cambodia, Mired in War, Looks to U.S. as Only Help
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 13 Cambodia, the last country of Indochina to be engulfed by the war, watches dejectedly as peace continues to elude her.

title: 2 Armed With a Shotgun Seized By Patrolmen in Brownsville
description: Two men, one armed with a sawedoff shotgun, were arrested in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn last night by three plainclothesmen on patrol in a cab.

title: MRS. JAMES ZILBOORG
description: Mrs. Eugenia Helfman Zilboorg, widow of James M. Zilboorg, an executive engineer with the Ebasco International Corporation, died yesterday at St. Charles Hospital in Port Jefferson, L. I, She was 79 years old and lived in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: U.S. Copter Assigned To Truce Unit Downed
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 16 (UPI)  An unarmed United States CH47 supply helicopter assigned to the fourpower Joint Military Commission was shot down today and crashed in flames while returning from An Loc, according to reports from the field.

title: Dollar Advances Abroad As Turnover Moderates
description: LONDON, Feb. 15The devalued dollar moved upward against many of the world's currencies today in trading that dealers on the major European exchanges said was returning to normal turnover levels after three weeks of monetary turmoil.

title: 4 RAIL LINES ASKED FOR WESTERN U. S.

title: Issues Have Moved to the Right for 7 Candidates for Maryor
description: Crime community control and the delirvery of city sere ices are the in issues, and the middle class the in voter bloc for seven Democrats already campaigning feverishly for their party's mayoral nomination.

title: Plaques Mark the Oldest Town House in New York
description: Two bronze plaquesone in English and the other in Chinesewere unveiled yesterday on the oldest remaining town house in New York City, a threestory building dating back to Revolutionary War days. The structure is at 18 Bowery, on the southeast corner of Pell Street, in the heart of Chinatown.

title: BAKER AND MARLIN DAYTONA WINNERS
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15A pair of 125mile qualifying races, closely contested with as many as seven cars running in bumpertobumper formations at 175180 miles an hour, completed the 40car field today for next Sunday's Daytona 500, this country's most prestigious stockcar race.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 14. (Reuters)Top honors in the CapetownRio ocean sailing race will go to the grand old man of the seas, Kees Bruynzeel, when the prizes are handed out on tomorrow.

title: Pentagon Says Strikes This Week Increased by About 100 Daily
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Pentagon today announced a significant increase in United States air strikes against North Vietnamese and Pathet La?? troop and munitions movements in Laos.

title: Israeli and Egyptian Jets Clash at Suez; Artillery Is Fired at a Golan Settlement
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 15  Israin and Egyptian planes fought a brief air battle over the Gulf of Suez today, breaking eight months of silence along the Suez Canal front.

title: Opera
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 14 Everybody thought the Spring Opera Theater of San Francisco had gone out of its collective mind when it decided to open its current season with a dramatized performance of Bach's Passion According to St. Matthew, But Spring Opera was right, and we with the raised eyebrows were wrong. The Passion According to St. Matthew, staged by Gerald Freedman, with settings by Ming Cho Lee and Abraham Kaplan conducting, was an emphatic success, artistically and popularly, and it left one wondering why nobody had ever attempted to stage this work in America before.

title: JULIA RUBENSTEIN
description: Julia Rubenstein, an assistant director of public relations at Yeshiva University, died yesterday at her home after a brief illness. She was 64 years old and lived at 150 West End Avenue.

title: Final F.T.C. Rules Issued to Correct Mail Sales Abuses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 15 The Federal Trade Commission today issued the final version of a regulation designed to correct alleged abuses in negative option plans used widely to sell books, records and other merchandise by mail.

title: HAROLD BRIGHTMAN, RETAIL EXECUTIVE
description: Harold W. Brightman, a retired demtniexitstore executive who over the years had been with Filene's, Bamberger's, Abraham & Straus and Gim hers, among others, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital after a brief illness. He was 83 years old and lived in Manasquan, N. J.

title: Reporter Freed in IndianData Case
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15A Federal grand jury refused to day to indict a Washington newsman and two Indian acti vists on charges of illegal pos session of stolen Govemmen documents.

title: Equity Financing
description: Champion International yesterday announced that directors have authorized the company, subject to Securities and Exchange Commission approval, to purchase up to one million shares of its common stock and/or its $1.20 convertible preference stock for its treasury. The company said purchases would be made over an indefinite period of time in order to minimize impact on the market price of the issues. The company's stock closed at 17, up  on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Wally Cox, TV Mr. Peepers, Dies at 48
description: AWL AIR, Calif., Feb. 15Wally Cox, the bespectacled lowkey comic known to teleVision viewers as the meek Mr. Peepers since 1953, was found dead this morning in the bedroom of his home in this Los Angeles suburb. He was 48 Years old.

title: CHESTER N. FRAZIER, DERMATOLOGIST, 81

title: 133 YACHTS BEGIN RACE TO LUCAYA
description: MIAMI, Feb. 15Fair winds and calm seas assured a fast passage for today's start of the Southern. Ocean Racing Conference Miami to Lucaya race.

title: Devaluation Stirs Anxiety and Dismay in Europe

title: Issues Dividing 2 Sides Appear to HardenAmericans Faulted

description: Stock prices continued to tumble yesterday as Wall Street surveyed the aftermath of Monday night's dollar devaluation with misgivings and concern.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)  The Government National Mortgage Association today sold at auction $92.4million of mortgages at an average yield of 7.57 per cent.

description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 15 When Mrs. Helen Brunstrom was unpacking her husband's duffle bag last night, she found a pair of worn sandals and a small cup and spoon, the only utensils he had used during almost seven years in a North Vietnamese prison camp.

title: VIETCONG GUESTS BLOCKED IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15  The South Vietnamese military police today barred a group of foreign newsmen and several senior members of the international peacekeeping commission from attending a reception given by the Vietcong.

description: PORTSMOUTH, Va., Feb. 15 For three of the first group of prisoners of war to return home, life here is an overflowing bowl of cherries, replete with champagne, Tbone steaks and lobster.

title: Wholesale Prices Increase Sharply; Rise Led by Food
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Wholesale prices rose sharply again in January, though not as much as in December, the Labor Department reported today.

description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 Ninetynine striking teachers were handcuffed and led away from a school entrance here today for violating an antipicketing injunction.

Taylor will meet Brian Fairlie of New Zealand, who ousted Erik Van Dillen of, San Mateo, Calif., 36, 76, 64.

title: Most Farm Groups Score Plan For Phasing Out U.S. Subsidies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The reaction today from most farm organizations and some influential members of Congressional agriculture committees to President Nixon's proposal to phase out farm subsidy payments ranged from mildly negative to explosively opposed.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: During an hour of solemn pageantry, Cardinal Cooke offered a mass of the resurrection and traditional prayers in a packed Staten Island parish house for the 40 victims of last week's gas tank collapse. Mayor Lindsay, Borough President Robert T. Connor and nearly 1,000 people joined the widows and children in the Church of Our Lady of Mount CarmelSt. Benedicta in the West New Brighton section for traditional services, with a dozen priests participating. Five children of the victims brought bread and wine forward in the solemn offertory procession.

title: GAS STRIKE HURTING IN WINTRY BRITAIN

title: New Jersey Sports

title: TV's Pufnstufs Spark a Stage Show
description: Some stage entertainments, frankly cashing in on children's television series and luring family audiences, have been downright crummy. Not so The H. R. Pufnstuf Show, now playing at the Felt Forum through Feb. 25. One adult addict of the Late, Late Show recently creaped into the. Forum for an earlymorning matinee with a small army of children and generally had a fine old time of it.

title: Aid and Politics
description: The first of the institutions for shaping the United States role in the Asia of the 1970's has now emerged from the rubble of the Vietnam war. Creation of a United StatesNorth Vietnam Joint Economic Commisskon for planning postwar reconstruction is a modest startand a welcome sign that the Nixon Administration and North Vietnamese Politburo are willing to continue regarding each other in the spirit of goodwill that led to the ceasefire.

title: Arms Cache Is Seized in Brooklyn as 4 More Are Linked to Attacks on Police
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy announced yesterday that four additional suspects had been added to the list of six persons sought in the recent shootings of policemen in Brooklyn and Queens.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 16, 1973;

title: Overseas Net Up 55% At National City Corp.
description: The First National City Corporation reported yesterday that its overseas earnings in 1972 rose 55 per cent to $110million and represented 54 per cent of its aftertax net operating earnings.

title: George Welsh Is Named Football Coach at Navy
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 15 (UPI)  George Welsh, who quarterbacked the 1954 Navy team to a Sugar Bowl victory over Mississippi, was named head football coach at the United States Naval Academy today. He has been an assistant to Joe Paterno at Penn State.

title: Wholesale Prices Increase Sharply; Rise Led by Food
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Wholesale prices, rose sharply again in January, though not as much as in December, the. Labor Department reported today.
