description: The police continued yesterday their minute search for clues inside the house and door to door around the Forest Hills neighborhood where a doctor's young wife was found murdered on Tuesday.

title: Advertising: Business Press Woe
description: Less than 30 per cent of the trade, technical and professional magazines in this country belong to the American Business Press and collectively nonmembers carry a lot more advertising than members.

title: After 22 Years in Coma, A Woman of SO Is Dead
description: POLK, Pa., Feb. 15 (AP)After spending nearly half her life in world devoid of awareness, 50yearold Janet Shouse died this week. On April 23, 1951, when she was critically injured after falling from a moving car, the 28yearold woman fell into a coma.

title: Cardinal Lienart, Who Backed WorkerPriest Movement, Dies
description: LILLE, France, Feb. 15Achille Cardinal Linart, the Bishop of Lille for 40 years and a forceful champion of progressive Roman Catholic Church movements, died at his home here today after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: New Approaches
description: WASHINGTONNow that the monetary crisiswhich particularly affected U.S.Japanese relations has at least momentarily been solved, it may be considered almost certain that Emperor Hirohito and President Nixon will exchange official visits this year. The likelihood is Hirohito will come here first and the President will fly to Japan not too long afterward as part of the process of healing a friendship wounded by the Nixon shocks on China and economics.

title: ROCKEFELLER FEELS A TAX CUT IS OUT
description: ALBANY, Feb. 15Governor Rockefeller said today that projections of the state's fiscal condition over the next five years clearly demonstrate the perils of commitments to tax reduction or to greater spending than the state can reasonably finance over the long term.

title: HARASSMENT LAID TO U.S. ATTORNEY
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 15 (AP)The United States Attorney's office in New Jersey was accused in Federal Court here today of harassing and intimidating officials of a company that allegedly made kickbacks to present and former Atlantic City officials who are on trial on extortion and conspiracy charges.

title: HENRY D. LINDSLEY JR.,
description: DALLAS, Feb. 15Henry D. Lindsley Jr., an independent lumberman with interests in Texas, Oklahoma and New Mexico, died here Wednesday at the age of 77.

title: Trial On in SchoolBus Tragedy With 2 Sides Disputing Cause
description: NEW CITY, N. Y., Feb. 15The trial of the driver of the school bus involved in a fatal collision with a freight train in nearby Congers opened here today with attorneys for the two sides presenting contradictory accounts of the final moments before the crash.

title: Suit Against A.&P. Seeks $11Million Over Meat Labeling
description: A classaction lawsuit seeking $11million in damages from the Great Atlantic and. Pacific Tea Company for alleged mislabeling of ground meat in its A. & P. supermarkets was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Elliot Richardson preaches that we should keep it local (OpEd Jan. 31) and . . . give states, cities and citizens the power and authority they need to make decisions affecting their existence. These are unexceptionable. sentiments but, they mask what seems to be a deliberate campaign to destroy New York and other Urge cities and preserve, deep poverty as an American way of living.

title: P. O. W. SAYS ALL UPHELD WAR AIMS
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 15  A senior American war prisoner, released in Hanoi three days ago, said here today that to his knowledge not one of his fellow prisoners of war held in North Vietnam was against President Nixon's Vietnam war policies.

title: 900 on S. I. Hear Cooke Offer Mass for Tank Victims
description: More than 900 people packed a Staten Island church yesterday for the solemn pageantry of a traditional Roman Catholic mass of the resurrection for the 40 men killed in the explosion last Saturday of a huge gas storage tank.

title: KISSINGER IS MET BY CHINESE AIDES
description: PEKING, Feb. 15Henry A. Kissinger arrived here by air today from Hong Kong for consultations with Chinese leaders.

title: 50,000 Gallons of Deadly Fluid Baffle Utility
description: FORKED RIVER, Feb. 15 The Jersey Central, Power and Light Company has 50,000 gallons of poisoned water that it is not sure what to do with.

title: Notes on People
description: President Nixon has named W. J. Usery Jr. Director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. Mr. Usery, who has been Assistant Secretary of Labor for labormanagement relations, will succeed Curtis Counts in the mediation post. The 50yearold. Mr. Usery has been the Administration's chief troubleshooter in labormanagement relations. He joined the Labor Department in 1969. Before that, Mr. Usery (his name is Willie Julian, but he prefers to be called Bill) was a grand lodge representative or the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers.

title: DEMOCRATIC CLUB FAVORS BADILLO
description: In the first test of the strength of mayoral candidates in the liberal New Democratic Coalition, six delegates favorable to the candidacy of Representative Herman Badillo were selected by the Lexington Democratic Club on Manhattan's East Side early yesterday.

title: Film: 'Wattstax,' Record of Watts Festival Concert
description: "Wattstax" is the 102-minute filmed record of the seven-hour concert sponsored in Los Angeles last August by the Stax Organization, a black recording company based in Memphis, and the Schlitz Brewing Company, the (I assume) mostly white manufacturers of the beer that made Milwaukee famous. The concert was the climax of the seventh annual Watts Summer Festival, which marks the Watts riots of 1965.The proceeds from the $1-a-person ticket sales went to the Sickle Cell Anemia Foundation, the Martin Luther King Hospital in Watts and the budgets of future Watts summer festivals. All of the performers at the concert were Stax employes.I mention these fascinating details because they explain something about the look and feel of the film, which are those of a slick souvenir program rather than of a motion-picture documentary on the order of "Woodstock," a film that assumed the shape of the event recorded. "Wattstax" seems to have evolved the other way around.I don't mean that the film is in any way fake; it just has the air of something too carefully laid out in advance. It's so busy being glossy and optimistic that it doesn't even allow its performers time to create on screen a measure of the excitement they might have created in person.More than two dozen solo performers and groups appear on the bandstand in the middle of the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum, but few of their turns are allowed to build to any sort of emotional climax. Instead, the flim keeps cross-cutting to less-than-incisive interviews with various Watts residents, survivors of the riots and architects of its future, who discuss, among other things, blues (one man says he can get them over his car).It may be because of this film context that the concert appears to have been a good deal less than exciting, though a number of good performers turn up, including Carla Thomas, the Staple Singers, Johnnie Taylor and Isaac Hayes.The only moments worth noting are provided by Richard Pryor, the actor ("Lady Sings the Blues") and comedian who, apparently, never got near the concert. He is seen in a casual, very funny interview, seemingly shot in a nightclub, talking about his childhood and doing bits and pieces of routines that are both witty and sad, such as the one about the ex-con who fails to get unemployment insurance just because he can't find a job as a license-plate presser.The rest of the film is prefab. It opened yesterday at the Criterion, Orpheum and Columbia I Theaters.

title: SHULTZ SAYS U.S. SEEKS NEW DROP IN DOLLAR VALUE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz said today that the Administration was seeking further depreciation of the dollar in world currency markets.

title: WARMTH PERVADES CLEVELANDERS' TONE
description: The concert Daniel Barenboim and Jacqueline de Pr gave Wednesday night at Carnegie Hall with the Cleveland Orchestra provided the kind of mixed bag of pleasures and frustrations one has come to expect with those two artists. It also provided a reaffirmation of the Cleveland ensemble's continued excellence: such warmth and brilliance of tone and both individual and sectional virtuosity is surely unsurpassed in the world today.

title: People and Business
description: Elmer A. Sticco yesterday, was named president, acting chief executive and a director of the International Controls Corporation, possibly laying the groundwork for him to succeed Robert L. Vesco, who severed his remaining links with the company last week.

title: Smith's Confidence Rises For Pole Vault at Garden
description: That's the price you pay, Smith said the other day. Every time I step on the runway now, people are disappointed if I don't clear 18.

title: Foreman Ali Bout Long Way Off
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., Feb. 15  Curiously, but perhaps wisely, Muhammad All has not been agitating to challenge George Foreman for the world heavyweight title. But he might be merely saving his breath. Their showdown appeared today to be at least 18 months away, perhaps two years.

title: Pentagon Says Strikes This Week Increased by About 100 Daily
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The Pentagon today announced a significant increase in United States air strikes against North Vietnamese and Pathet Lao troop and munitions movements in Laos.

title: Holdings by Reserve of U.S. Securities Rise to Record Level
description: Credit conditions became tighter than ever in the week ended Wednesday, data released by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York showed yesterday. Business loans continued to grow.

title: ROGERS SAYS U.S. IS FIRM ON CUBA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 Secretary of State William P. Rogers today signed the agreement with Cuba intended to curb hijacking between the two countries, but said the accord did not foreshadow any im provement in Washington's relations with Premier Fidel Castro's Government.

title: Text of Accord With Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (UPI)Following is the text of the United StatesCuban agreement signed today Washington and Havana, called memorandum of understanding on hijacking of aircraft and vessels and other offenses:

title: Time Seeks Timber Unit; Posts Lower 1972 Profit
description: Time Inc. announced yesterday it was planning to broaden its forestproducts business and had signed a memorandum of intent to buy Texasbased Temple Industries, Inc., through a taxfree exchange of stock.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and decor (four triangles to none.)

description: Twentyfour major league player representatives meet in New York today to discuss the owners' latest proposal in negotiations for a new basic. agreement.

title: Weather Reports and Forecast
Monitoring the Truce in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 15  The machinery to provide international supervision of the Vietnam ceasefire is not working, and a speedy solution to the problems is not in sight.

title: Theater: Handke's Kaspar Is Staged in Brooklyn
description: The more I see and read of Peter Handke the more and more ready I am to accept the common European view that he is one of the most important young playwrights of our time. This was reinforced by seeing the Chelsea Theater Center of Brooklyn's new production of Kaspar, which officially opened at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night.

title: Fordham Registers Upset Over Notre Dame, 7069
description: Darryl Brown scored what he called, the 2 most important points of my life, last nighta short jumper with 12 seconds remaining that gave Fordham a 7069 upset victory over Notre Dame at Madison Square Garden.

title: Device for Bugging Discovered in Room Of House Committee
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15The chairman of the House Foreign Affairs Committee said today that a tiny, sophisticated listening device had been found in the committee's main hearing room.

title: The Baltic States
description: Free Lithuanians everywhereand an unknown number of Lithuanians in the Soviet Union as wellwill mark today the 55th anniversary of the modern Republic of Lithuania. It was on Feb. 16, 1918, that the Lietuvos taryba or Council of Lithuania met in Vilnius and declared the existence of an independent state free of ties to all other sovereignties.

title: Arms Cache Stirs Shock, Yet Residents Understand
description: The people on Saratoga Avenue gasped when the police carried the guns down yesterday. Even the toughest of the men, who have been on the streets a long time, crowded around the police car that carried the rifles and the bazooka.

title: Cambodia, Mired in War, Looks to U. S. as Only Help
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 13 Cambodia, the last country of Indochina to be engulfed by the war, watches dejectedly as peace continues to elude her.

title: Mrs. Norell Wed to Ian Strasfogel
description: Mrs. Judith Norell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sandor S. Hirsch of 10 East 70th Street, was married at her parents' home yesterday afternoon to Ian Strasfogel, opera stage director, and general director of the Opera Society of Washington. He is the son of Ignace Strasfogel, associate conductor of the Metropolitan Opera, and Mrs. Strasfogel, also of New York.

title: El Paso Gas Lists Gains for Earnings And Revenue in '72
description: The El Paso Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in 1972, operating revenues and net income. Howard Boyd, chairman, placed operating revenues at $1.1billion against $1.04billion a year earlier. Net income rose to $63.9million, or $2.05 a share, from $50.3million, or $1.62 a share, in 1971. Net for 1971 is after an extraordinary charge of $7.1million, or 26 cents a share, from the writedown of a phosphate, fertilizer plant.

title: Bhutto Discharges 2 Opposition Aides As Province Chiefs
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 15 President Zulfikar All Bhutto today ordered the dissolution of the provincial government of Baluchistan, in a move to strengthen his hold over unruly areas of the country.

title: Bidder Is Back for Coups in Met. Sale
description: Julius H. Weitzner came back to town this week to see his tax adviser and shop the latest sale of museum art, yesterday's auction of paintings from the Metropolitan at Sotneby Parke Bernet. The two functions are related, for Mr. Weitzner has made fortunes by trading with museums.

title: ShakeUp of Top Echelon In Park Agency Completed
description: A shakeup of the top echelon of the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administration has been carried out and will continue down to middlelevel management.

title: A Chalk Talk
description: WASHINGTONThe New York Jets have a new head coach, soninlaw to the one retiring, and a reasonable observer might infer that Weeb Ewbank exercised some slight degree of influence in the selection of his successor. Meanwhile, 215 miles down the Jetstream as the shuttle flies, questions concerning a different kind of succession are filling the air like fifty yard spirals on one of Joe Namath's better days: Questions like:

title: CRAMPTON POSTS 67 TO SHARE LEAD WITH KITE, IRWIN
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Bruce Crampton of Australia, gunning for his third victory of the year, shot a fiveunderpar 67 today to tie Tom Kite and Hale Irwin for the firstround lead in the rainplagued $170,000 San Diego open golf tournament.

title: CAHILL PRESSES FOR DISCLOSURES
description: TRENTON, Feb, 15Governor Cahill stepped into the legislative fight over a campaigndisclosure bill today, reminding the legislators that he wanted a strong law enacted in time for this year's gubernatorial and legislative election campaigns.

The game to be played at 8 P.M. will be the Newcomers Pairs instead of as in the past, the Novice Pairs, a name, that has a faintly insulting flavor.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Mrs. Rodin Is Wed To Philip D. Pakula
description: Mrs. Barbara Zuckerman Rodin and Philip D. Pakula were married here yesterday afternoon at 1025 Park Aveneu, the home of Mr. and Mrs. Paul M. Yuder, friends of the bride. Rabbi Raphael Ostrovsky performed the ceremony.

title: Those Economy Flights of Fancy Are Fast on Way Out
description: Two years after they appeared at 40,000 feet, economyclass lounges in jet airlinerswith their bars, balladeers, pianos, magicians and group singalongsare flying into oblivion. Airlines say they need the space devoted to the lounges because business has picked up.

title: Lindsay Proposes Intensified Drive On Drug Pushers

title: WESTBETH LOSING KAPLAN FUND AID
description: Mrs. Joan K. Davidson resigned yesterday as a trustee and president of Westbeth, the controversial artists' housing community on the Lower West Side, and at the same time announced the election of a new board of directors for the experimental project.

description: BIEN HOA, South Vietnam, Feb. 15  The South Vietnamese sergeant almost growled as he talked about how life had been in the Communist prisonerofwar camps.

title: 2 Area Families Greet Ex P.0 W.'s
description: Outside the whiteshingled colonial home on Plymouth Stieet in Montclair, N.J., an Americana flag flew yesterday. Inside the atmosphere was filled with anticipation.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: PALEOLITHIC Murray the K is celebrating his 20th anniversary in New York radio, a fair enough milestone in the quickly changing world of broadcasting, in which he was a disk jockey famed for bringing in the new (now old) rock. Nowadays Mr. Kaufman (his checksigning name) works for WNBCAM radio on weekends, presiding over rock, with pop and some folk, too, but in a format that does not involve sweating out top 10's and 20's.

title: Only Minor Faults
description: The nofault automobile insurance bill passed by an overwhelming vote in the State Legislature and immediately signed into law by Governor Rockefeller, its chief sponsor, is a good bill which promises' significant benefits to all motorists. It paves the way for fairer, swifter, surer and cheaper automobile insurance. Those sustaining medical and other economic losses as a result of automobile accidents will be able to recover from their own insurance companies without the need for lengthy, costly court trials to determine who may have caused the accident.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The City Council yesterday approved the first increase in towtruck rates in 25 years. It raised the rate for the first mile from $4 to $10, and the rate for each additional mile or fraction of a mile from $1 to $1.50. It also set a storage charge not to exceed $2 for each. 24 hours.

title: TAYLOR, RIESSEN, ROSSWALL SCORE
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Feb. 15 (AP)  Roger Taylor upset thirdseeded Mark Cox, 34, 67, 76 today in an allBritish quarterfinal match in a World Championship Tennis circuit tournament. Taylor will meet Brian Fairlie of New Zealand, who ousted Erik Van Dillen of San Mateo, Calif., 36, 76, 64.

title: 146 Metropolitan Works In Parke Bernet Auction
description: It was a clearance sale yesterday at Sotheby Parke Bernet as 146 paintings from the storage caverns of the Metropolitan Museum of Art bargains to buyers and, in many cases, dogs to others  chalked up the resounding total of $467,875, nearly twice the prsale estimate.

description: PORTLAND, Me., Feb. 15 Archibald M. Knowles, corporate vice president and general counsel of the Maine Central Railroad, died yesterday in the Maine Medical Center here. He was 63 years old and lived in nearby Falmouth.

description: While the trotters who will race in it relax as yearlings, the 1975 Hambletonian Stake is being pursued by a wellorganized group of bidders from the Capital District of upstate New York.

description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)The United States trade deficit in 1973 should inctease, possibly by as much as $2billion, from last year's $6.4billion deficit, even with the effects of the 10 per cent dollar devaluation, the United StatesJapan Trade Council predicted.

title: AirTraffic Issue Is Unresolved, Says the Mayor of West Berlin
description: BERLIN, Feb. 15  Mayor Klaus Schtz of West Berlin is dissatisfied with what he regards as the neglect by the Big For powers of problems left unresolved by their accord of last year on the future of his isolated city.

description: TRENTON, Feb. 15 (AP) State Insurance Commissioner Richard C. McDonough announced today that he had ordered Blue Shield of New sey to lower rates for about one million subscribers.

description: CHICAGO, Feb. 15 (UPI)Billy Williams, the 1972 major league batting champion and runnerup in the voting for the National League's Most Valuable Player award, signed his Chicago Cubs contract today for an estimated $150,000 salary.

title: Providence Closes Strong Routing Holy Cross, 9475
description: WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 15 (UPI)Providence College's nationally ranked basketball team overcame stubborn Holy Cross tonight in rolling to a 9475 triumph.

Mathias, Republican of Maryland, and Adlai Stevenson, Democrat of Illinois, introduced a resolution today to open virtually all Senate committee sessions to the public. Excluded from public scrutiny would be matters involving national security, individual privacy and business secrets.

Enjoying a lead of a dozen lengths at one time during the 1mile race for fillies and mares, Joe Wetterich's 4yearold managed to last long enough to win by a neck.

title: Rogers Appeals for Unity And a Little Pride in U.S.

title: FrenchCanadians Reign In Harness Drivers' List

Of course, Herve Filion, with five consecutive National trotting championships heads the list. However, the energetic man from Angers, Quebec, who had 605 victories in 1971, has not been burning up the track with winners so far in the winter meeting at Yonkers Raceway.

title: STUDENTS BEATEN BY ATHENS POLICE
description: ATHENS, Feb. 16University students clashed with the police in downtown Athens today in a widening of the conflict between the militarybacked Government and what it regards as student agitators.

title: Soviet ABlast Recorded
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, Feb. 16 (AP)A strong nuclear explosion in a series of Soviet underground tests in Siberia was registered by the Seismological institution here this morning. The strength was estimated at 5.8 on the Richter scale.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: MISS ROMACK'S 69 LEADS BY STROKE
description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP)Barbara Romack of Atlantic Beach, Fla., who hasn't won a tournament in 10 years, posted a threeunderpar 69 to day to lead the first round of the $36,000 Pompano Beach Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Shotguns and Race and Cops
description: To the Editor:

title: TWO PLEAD GUILTY IN GAMBINO KIDNAP
description: Two men pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday to charges that they conspired to extort $350,000 as ransom in the kidnapping of Emanuel Gambino, the 29yearold nephew of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia boss.

title: Blue Cross Rates to Rise 7.4 % for 1.5 Million Here
description: Blue Cross of Greater, New York has been granted an average increase of 7.4 per cent in hospitalinsurance rates for more than a third of its subscribdrs in the five boroughs and 12 other counties, the State Insurance Department announced yesterday.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesBobby Chacon, 127 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Tury Pineda, 127, Mexico, 5 rounds.

title: DOLLAR UP AGAIN IN TRADES ABROAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 16As the European exchange markets closed out a week of heavy trading today, the devalued American dollar was moving tip against many currencies and pushing toward its ceiling against the West German mark.

title: WINE TALK
description: In stories written immediately after the 10 per cent devaluation of the dollar on Monday, liquor dealers were quoted as saying they would have to raise prices on foreign wines after their present stocks ran outin about four days.

title: Court Official Says Governor's Drug Plan Won't Work
description: The State Administrator of the Courts said yesterday it was completely unfeasible to rely on 100 new temporary judges to implement Government Rockefeller's proposal for a mandatory life penalty for drug sellers.

title: Persico Ordered to a New Prison
description: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Carmine Persica Jr. transarred from a detention cell on West Street to the maximumsecurity prison in Marion, Ill., as the Federal prosecutor and the reputed Mafia leader had been accorded special privileges here.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: A Beatle Sues Record Companies

title: In Need of Advice, Hungarians Dial a Psychologist
description: BUDAPEST, Hungary  In Budapest, after the sun goes down, anyone feeling troubledmentally, physically or sexuallycan dial 1719 25 and hear friendly, hearttoheart advice in a soothing, bedside tone that Hungary's overworkec c occur, o??er lack time for in clinics and hospitals.

title: N. CAROLINA PLAYS FLA. STATE TODAY
description: Coaches Dean Smith of North Carolina and Hugh Durham of Florida State were chatting last March after Durham's. Seminoles had eliminted the Tar Heels, 1975, in the semifinal round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament.

title: Multispectral Aerial Photo System Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16A system of multispectral aerial photography that was patented this week has been used to study the color of the moon, to explore for precious minerals in Africa, and to detect crop and forest diseases and ocean pollution in many parts of the world. Patent 3,715,962 was granted to Edward F. Yost Yr., a professor of Engineering at Long Island University in Greenvale. It is assigned to Spectral Data Corporation, Syosset, L.I.

title: Noted Heart Surgeon Convicted Of Income Tax Evasion Charges
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 16Dr. C. Walton Lillehel of New York, who pioneered in openheart surgery at the University of Minnesota in the nineteenfifties, was convicted today of five charges of income tax evasion.

title: 5 Are Injured in Gas Explosion At a Steak House on East Side
description: Five persons were injured last night when an apparent gas explosion blew out a kitchen wall of McCarthy's Famous Steak House at Second Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Flier lack, Thanks Mr. and Mrs. America
description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Feb. 16 (AP)  A new wave of flights brought home today 60 more freed American prisoners of war, including Lieut. Comdr. Everett Alvarez, the first American flier shot down in the Vietnam war.

title: Godard's Tout Va Bien Opens at Two Theaters
description: Tout Va Bien, which opened yesterday at the New Yorker Theater and the Fifth Avenue Cinema, was shown at the 10th New York Film Festival. The following excerpt is front Roger Greenspun's review, which appeared Oct. I1, 1972, in The New York Times.

title: Plan to Dismantle O.E O. Devised to Foil Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The Administration has devised a detailed plan that calls for dismantling the Office Economy Opportunity before Congress can come to its rescue, according to a paper prepared by the antipoverty agency's technical staff.

title: Security Guard, 73, Kills Robber in Harlem Building
description: A 73yearold security guard shot and killed a holdup man in the hallway of a Harlem apartment building yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Housing Policeman Accused Of Looting an Apartment
description: A Housing Authority patrolman was arrested late Thursday night and charged with looting a Bronx apartment after posing as a narcotics detective to gain entrance.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Baseball Signings
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: The New Dr. Pangloss
description: The almighty dollar is not as mighty as it was before the two Nixon devaluations, but its apostles are still cheerily chirping: All is for the best in this best of all possible worlds.

title: Banker Is Not Pleased With Mistaken XRating
description: ELMWOOD PARK, N.J., Feb. 16 (AP)Joseph Rose, a banker, is being confused with Joseph Rose, a movie star, and he's not happy about it.

title: A Chronology of Monetary Crises
description: Among the major monetary crises of recent years were the following:

title: 2 Law Firms Push FeminismWith All  Women Staffs
description: The last thing any of them wants to be called is Portia, but nine young women lawyers are about to face professional life in two new allwomen law firms that they describe as feminist collectives.

title: Progress '73: Ersatz Caviar
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 16 (AP)The Russians reported today that they have developed a technique to mass produce an artificial caviar. The breakthrough was credited to research at a Moscow organization dedicated to creation of substitute foodstuffs.

title: No Gain Toward Truce in Laos Is Reported Alter Day's Talks
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 16Despite meetings lasting most of the day between Vientiane Government and Pathet Lao negotiators and a special CabMet session, no progress was reported today toward a ceasefire agreement in Laos.

title: SOYBEANS CLIMB BY FUTURES LIMIT
description: Sixdollarabushel soybeans became a reality today as March soybean futures climbed the 10centabushel limit to close at $6.031, another new historic high.

title: An Antibusing Amendment
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) Senator Herman E. Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, introduced a proposed amendment to the Constitution yesterday to prohibit forced school busing. He said Congress should let the American people be heard on this issue.

title: Noted Heart Surgeon Convicted Of Income Tax Evasion Charges
description: ST. PAUL, Feb. 16Dr. C. Walton Lillehei of New York, who pioneered in openheart surgery at the University of Minnesota in the nineteenfifties, was convicted today of five charges of income tax evasion.

title: LATE SURGE EARNS VICTORY NO. 1,000 FOR KNICKS, 10298
description: BUFFALO, Feb. 16It happened quickly but surely for the Knicks tonight as they discovered their lost skills in the closing minutes to defeat the Buffalo Braves, 10298.

title: MILLS PROPOSES 15% ADDED TARIFF
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Representative Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, called today for an immediate imposition of a 15 per cent tariff surcharge on all imports as a means of overcoming a foreign lack of confidence in the future value of the dollar.

title: Milburn Ties. World Mark; Smith Fails to Set Another
description: Rod Milburn looked as unbeatable as ever, Herb. Washington went underground but still came out on top and Beaufort Brown issued a new challenge to track and field's Chairman of the Boards, Martin McGrady.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: LONG BRANCH, N. J., Feb. 16A biting wind nips at the face and freezing temperatures numb the fingers. An angry sea spits its froth into the chilling, night air, adding dampness to the bitter atmosphere, and waves lashing the beaches interrupt the cold silence.

title: TANK BLAZE LAID TO LINING REPAIR
description: The city's chief fire marshal, Edwin Steppard, said yesterday that the blaze that killed 40 workmen at a giant Staten Island liquefiedgas tank broke out when normal repair techniques were applied to the innovative tank's unuusual insulation.

title: Factory Output Rises
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the nation's industrial production rose by fivetenths of 1 per cent in January. In another report, the Commerce Department said housing starts continued in January at the record  breaking pace of 1972. Details, Page 41.

title: Crash Victims Identified
description: BRUNSWICK, Ga., Fab. 16 (AP)The Navy identified today two aviators killed in a crash of a twinengine S2 aircraft yesterday. The victims were Lieut. Comdr. Frederick G. Butler and Lieut. Gabriel Hernandez. The plane crashed on an approach to the runway at Glynco Naval Air Station, here.

title: PROSECUTOR DENIES PLAN TO GET KERNER
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16 (AP)A federal prosecutor denied in his closing argument today that he was out to get federal Judge Otto Kerner, who is being tried on charges including accepting a bribe when he was governor of Illinois.

title: An End to Farm Subsidy?
description: Four decades have passed since the Depression days of 1933 when President Roosevelt inaugurated the basic system of farm subsidies that is still the law of the land. In that era prices of food and fiber had plummeted such disastrously low levels that an epidemic of bankruptcies swept this country's rural areas. So desperate was the situation in the spring of 1933 that a Government campaign urging farmers to plow under the cotton they had planted and to kill baby pigs was widely applauded. It made sense then to rescue American agriculture by instituting an elaborate mechanism of agricultural subsidies combined with limitations on production through restrictions on the acreage each farmer planted to specific crops.

title: Stony Brook Builders Are Told To Meet Safety Rules or Leave
description: STONY BROOK, L. I., Feb. 16 The president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook warned campus construction contractors today that he would order them physically barred from the university if they failed to meet the university's reasonable safety standards.

title: Tax Ruling on Credit Cards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service ruled today that finance charges on oil company credit cards are taxdeductible. The ruling was issued after roughly 12 million taxpayers had filed 1972 Federal income tax returns.

title: TRUCE COMMISSION URGES BOTH SIDES TO HALT FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 17The chiefs of the fourparty Joint Military Commission today made what they called an urgent appeal to the Communist and Saigon commands to promptly issue orders to halt any further fighting in South Vietnam.

title: NET RALLY BEATS COUGARS, 112104
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 16The New York Nets, trailing by as many as 14 points in the first half, put on a rousing rally after the intermission to defeat the Carolina Cougart, the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division leaders, 112104, tonight. The Nets snapped a fivegame losing streak and ended a Cougar home winning skein that had stretched to 15 games.

title: Business Briefs
description: Railroads Are Denied 2% Rate Rises

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Missile Shots in Soviet Asia Reported
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 Nixon Administration officials report that the Soviet Union, in an unusual development, has fired nine intercontinental ballistic missiles over its Asian territory north of China within about two weeks.

title: Mary Doe Has Abortion
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 16 (UPI)  Mary Doe, the 23yearold woman who filed a successful suit against Ohio's abortion law, had an abortion in a hospital yesterday, one day after a Federal judge ruled that the law was unconstitutional. She has had the abortion and is doing fine, said Leonard Schwartz, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union of Ohio, which initiated the court challenge.

title: A Brooklyn P.O.W. Meets New Niece an Nephew
description: PHOENIXVILLE, Pa., Feb. 16 Pvt. Ferdinand Rodriguez of Brooklyn, a prisoner of war in Vietnam for the last five years, ate lunch with his family at Valley Forge General Hospital today and met his niece and nephew for the first time.

title: Opera: Montezuma Is Sung in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 15This city has been a reliable source of newsworthy opera activity for a long time now, the news being made by the Opera Company of Boston and its inimitable director, Sarah Caldwell.

title: Art: Salvator Rosa Etchings Shown
description: Rosa's Dutch contempoTary, Rembrandt, revolutionized etching during their lifetimes, releasing its potentials for spectacular effects that would have delighted the Italian, but Rosa never explored that area. Hence the exhibition of his etchings at the Finch College Museum, 62 East 78th Streetheld to observe the tercentenary of Rosa's deathmay not be the greatest Rosa show in the world, but no Rosa fan will want to miss it.

title: CONSENT ORDER ISSUED BY F.T.C.
description: The Federal Trade Commission yesterday announced a consent order requiring Illinois Central Industries, Inc., to create an independent manufacturer of automotive brake friction Imaterials. The order would settle a Commission complaint that Illinois Central's acquisition of the Midas International Coporation, automobile muffler and parts maker, would create a monopoly in the manufacture and sale of brake friction materials. Illinois Central's Abex Corporation, a subsidiary, produces such materials and Midas buys such materials as a major franchiser of autorepair shops. Last year, Illinois Central acquired Midas for stock valued at about $75.2million.

title: TRUE KNIGHT PICK IN RICH WIDENER
description: MIAMI, Feb. 16The Hialeah program tomorrow will feature the Widener Handicap, the first of the $100,000 events that mark the major league competition at the course. The largest crowd of the season is expected to watch the 1mile race, which has attracted a field of 10, making for a gross value of $131,400.

title: Javits Sees Sour Grapes In A10 Contract Criticism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16New York members of Congress are getting upset by efforts of Connecticut's two Senators to cast doubt on the Air Force's decision last month to give a contract for a new fighter  bomber to Fairchild Industries' Republic Division at Farmingdale, L. I. Sour grapes, said Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York. Petulant, parochial pettyfogging, said Representatives Angelo D. Roncallo and James R. Grover Jr., Republicans of Long Island.

title: 3 M'KENZIE GOALS SINK RAIDERS, 92
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (UPI)John McKenzie collected three goals tonight as the Philadelphia Blazers did all their scoring in the last two periods to defeat the New York Raiders, 92, in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Lehman Triumphs, 7473
description: Nick McNickle hit two four shots with eight seconds to play to clinch a 7473 victory for Lehman over Baruch last night. Stan Brown led the winners with 22 points, McNickle had 20. Lehman has won 16 and lost 4.

title: COUNTER STOCKS CLOSE DAY MIXED
description: The overthecounter market did slightly better than the American Stock Exchange yesterday, closing mixed while the Amex finished lower.

title: S.E.C. Takes Action On 3 Broker Firmi
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday public administrative proceedings involving three brokerage firms and several of their officers and directors in connection with new issues transactions.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOOTWORKERS A choreographic troika takes over the stage of Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (5824536), tomorrow night at 8 for the second of four Sunday programs designed to let audiences get the word of mouth directly from the backstagers responsible for putting shows on. The three choreographers are Valerie Bettis (As I Lay Dying, Ulysses in Nighttown and a dance treatment of A Streetcar Named Desire), Patricia Birch (Grease, The Me Nobody Knows, You're A Good Man, Charlie Brown, A Little Night Music) and Donald Saddler (No, No, Nanette, From Berlin to Broadway, Much Ado About Nothing).

title: LOUIS E. JACOBI
description: MERIDEN, Conn., Feb. 16Louis E. Jacobi, who retired in 1962 as a products engineer for the General Motors overseas operations division, died today at the Westfield Manor Convalescent Home. He was 76 years old and lived here.

title: Lufthansa Says It May Drop Option to Buy 3 Concordes
description: BONN, Feb. 16  A member of the executive board of Lufthansa said today in Hamburg that the West German airline may renounce its option on the purchase of three BritishFrench Concordes.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16.Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: JUDGE BIDS H.E.W. FORCE 17 STATES TO DESEGREGATE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16  A Federal district judge ordered the Nixon Administration to day to start enforcement proceedings against allegedly segregated public colleges and school districts in 17 states. The action could lead to a cutoff of Federal funds.

title: Calley Conviction Upheld By Army's Review Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The United States Army Court of Military Review upheld today the murder conviction of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. for his role in the My Lai killings and approved his sentence of 20 years' confinement at hard labor.

title: Board Cuts the Capacity Of Unfinished High School
description: The Board of Education announced yesterday that it was reducing the capacity of the new North Central High School in Brooklyn, which is nearly a third completed, from 4,000 to 2,500 students.

title: Airport Boarding Guards Put In a Quiet First Day
description: At the HollywoodBurbank Airport in California, a passenger being screened by a Federal antihijacking guard before boarding a Las Vegas flight said he was carrying a hand grenade and a 45caliber pistol.

title: Flat Grants for Welfare Rents Urged
description: The city has submitted to the state a plan for a twostage transition over the next five years to a system of flat grants for welfare clients' rents, to meet a Federal call for a statewide welfare rent plan.

title: When the Sergeant Cooks, Local Children Rush Into His Horne
description: When the seven MCGiiite children and their steady stream of ffiends start talking about pizzas as they Iounge around the comfortable house in the

title: New Submarines to Be Based in West
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 The Navy announced today the selection of Bangor, Wash., as the base for the Trident misile submarine.

title: U.S. Says Algeria May Also Want a Hijacking Accord
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The State Department said today that Algeria, which has provided a haven to some American hijackers, has shown interest lately in concluding an antihijadking agreement with the United States, perhaps sirnliar to the one signed in Washington and Havana yesterday.

title: Left's Unity Seems Shaky In Turbulent Marseilles
description: MARSEILLES, Feb. 13Although the leaders of the French leftists have pledged unswerving loyalty to the new electoral alliance of Socialists and Communists, the traditional feud between the two groups continues at the grass roots.

title: Gray Reported Chosen to Head F.B.I. as Permanent Director
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16L. Patrick Gray 3d will soon be nominated to the post of permanent director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Steinberg's Surprises Mark Two Shows
description: An artist who is copious, amusing, facile, inventive, surprising and irreverent, yet both commercially successful afid deeply ironicalironical, of all things, about art itselfis, in some respects, a great irritation. We prefer our artists either modest or suffering, either hooked on a narrow specialization or suitably distraught before the mysteries of experience. When they are neitherwhen they display a positive appetite for the comedy of life and a highly original gift for transforming its absurdities into unexpected forms and irresistible imageswe hardly know what to do with them.

title: Kissinger Has Talks With Chou And Other Leaders in Peking
description: PEKING, Feb. 16 (Reuters)Henry A. Kissinger today had his first round of substantive talks with Chinese leaders, including Premier Chou Enlai.

title: 2 Law Firms Push Feminism With AllWomen Staffs
description: The last thing any of them wants to be called is Portia, but nine young women lawyers are about to face professional life in two new allwomen law firms that they describe as feminist collectives.

title: Soviet Ballerina Who Fell From Ship in Japan Dies
description: YOKOHOMA, Japan, Feb. 16 (AP)  Alexandra Lichniayskaia, a Soviet ballerina, who was seriously injured Wednesday in a fall from a ship's deck to a dock, died ih a hospital here today of a fractured skull. She was 24 years old.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Query Vesco, Leaving Criminal Issue Open
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an unusual step in a civil suit, asked the United States Court of Appeals here yesterday for the right to take pretrial testimony from Robert L. Vesco without granting him immunity from criminal prosection by the Department of Justice.

title: Marijuana Part of Religion At Commune in Tennessee
description: SUMMERTOWN, Tenn. More than 200 young people sat bundled up on the floor of the chilly barn on pillows, sleeping bags and bales of hay.

title: Meskill Signs Bill For Gasoline Tax To Aid Bus Lines
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 16Gov. Thomas J. Meskill signed into law today a bill enabling transit districts in Connecticut to collect a pennyagallon tax on gasoline to cover deficits in public bus services.

title: GREMLINS FINISH 1, 2 IN CITRUS 200
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16A pair of Gremlins, a modern marque descended from the Nash of a generation ago, led the way home today in the Citrus 200, a road race for subcompact sedans over the 3.81mile circuit of Daytona International Speedway.

title: BANKS SUPPORTED ON INVESTING ROLE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16The American Telephone & Telegraph Company, disclosing comprehensive data, has concluded that the investment ability of banks is competitive with other professional managers of pension funds and that their skills seem to be improving.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1973

title: Antiques: Porcelain Sale
description: The Worcester, Delft, Svres and Meissen porcelains were certainly not, with some notable exceptions, the choicest ever auctioned at Sotheby Parke Bernet. But the twopart sale, which ended yesterday, included such a variety of ware from more than 55 makers, in it range of quality from fair to fine, that the assemblage did represent the broad spectrum of what people collect.

title: Out in the Country
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.When Moms apple pie is made by Mom's Apple Pie, Inc., what then is as American as apple pie? When small farmers must sell out to realestate developers, when rural factories are bought out by efficiency  minded, faceless conglomerates, when the old local craftsmen, the cooper, blacksmith, wheelwright, sawyer, tinker and miller are replaced not by practitioners of more modern arts but by products made somewhere else by no one in particular, far more has been lost than homemade apple pie.

title: Industrial Output Rises Again
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16Industrial production rose a further fivetenths of one per cent in January, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Regional Truce Teams Unable to Act
description: MY THO, South Vietnam, Feb. 16The two commissions to carry out and supervise the Vietnam ceasefire maintain regional headquarters in this Mekong Delta town 40 miles south of Saigon, but they are inactive and almost invisible.

title: Belfast Explosion Injures 6; 10Second Warning Given
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 16 (AP)  A telephoned bomb warning today to a Belfast tavern frequented by Romaa Catholics gave the patrons 10 seconds to clear out. The explosion wounded six persons as they dashed for the door.

title: Village Puts Tax Liens On 2 Biggest Employers
description: PIERMONT, N.Y., Feb. 16This little village is putting the property of its two biggest employers up for public auction in three weeks because they have not paid their village property taxes.

title: Georg Duckwitz, German Aide Who Helped Danish Jews, Dies
description: BONN, Feb. 16Georg Ferdinand Duckwitz, a German career diplomat who defied Nazi orders in 1943 to, provide the warnings that allowed more than 5,000 Danish Jews to escape to Sweden, died today in his native Bremen. He was 68 years old.

title: STUDENTS BEATEN BY ATHENS POLICE
description: ATHENS, Feb. 16University students clashed with the police in downtown Athens today in a widening of the conflict between the militarybacked Government and what it regards as student agitators.

title: 76ers Turn Back Pistons; Winning String Reaches 2
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP) Fred Carter, Tom Van Arsdale and Jeff Hallburton led the Philadelphia 76ers to a 119106 National Basketball Association victory over the Detroit Pistons tonight, the second victory in a row after 20 straight losses.

title: Ewing Township Fined $800 In Incinerator Violations
description: TRENTON, Feb. 16 (AP)The State Department of Environmental Protection announced today an $800 fine against Ewing Township for continued airpollution violations caused by its incinerator. The department said the municipality had paid a total of $700 for three previous similar violations.

title: MaterialHandling Group To Drop Its Boycott Policy
description: WASHINGTON  Feb. 16 (Reuters)The Material Handling Institute, Inc., a group of more than 200 companies that make and sell materialhandling equipment, agreed to drop its policy of boycotting foreignmade equipment.

title: Thursday's Fights
description: Los AngelesBobby Chacon, 127 pounds, Los Angeles, knocked out Tury Pineda, 127, Mexico, 5 rounds.

title: Taylor and Riessen Gain Tennis Final
description: COPENHAGEN, Feb. 16 (AP)  Unseeded Roger Taylor of Britain scored another upset today by defeating secondseeded Brian Fairlie of New Zealand 64, 64, and reaching the final of a World Championship Tennis Bgroup tournament.

title: HUNGARY OFFERS FAMILY BENEFITS
description: BUDAPEST, Feb. 9  The women of Hungary are so beautiful, but the birth rate is so low. It makes one wonder.

title: Bridge: Bidding Clues Point the Way To a Successful Defense
description: More often than one would suppose a shrewd defender can gauge the declarer's precise distribution after one or two tricks have been played, making full use of the bidding clues available to him. This will certainly improve his chances of uncovering the best defense.

title: Wood Beats Over40 Foe In Squash Racquets Opener
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 16Peter Wood of New York City defeated Dan Boorman of Montclair,. N. J., 1510, 155, 1115, 1512, in the opening round of veterans' singles play as the 62d United States squash racquets championships opened tonight in Princeton University's Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: Soames Sees White House As Eager About Trade Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16The European Common Market's Commissioner for Extenal Affairs said today following talks with President Nixon and nuerous high Government officials that there was a definite desire in the Administration to try to get a trade bill through Congress in time to open international negotiations on schedule in September.

title: G. M. WILL SPEND $1BILLION IN 73
description: The General Motors Corporation will spend well over $1billion in capital expenditures in 1973, compared with $940million in 1972, the annual report released yesterday disclosed.

title: CITY IS ADAMANT ON LIMITING LEAD
description: Ten, major oil companies that had said it would be, an economic hardship to comply with the city's strict new limits on lead in gasoline were denied a request for a variance yesterday.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York Cuts School's Capacity

title: COL. ANSON ROBINSON
description: Col. Anson F. Robinson,; who had been a commandee of the Military Order of Foreign Wars, died Thursday in a nursing home in Queens. He was 92 years old and lived at 315 East 68th Street.

title: No Asphalt on the C. & O.
description: WASHINGTONThe construction of the C. & O. Canal was started under John Quincy Adams and its operations ended in the regime of Calvin Coolidge. For some seventy years its canal boats brought coal down from Cumberland, Md., to tidewater at Georgetown, then a suburb of Washington, D. C., and took merchandise inland on the return trip. It was acquired by the Federal Government from the B. & O. Railroad in the thirties.

title: Domestic Gold Output Falls
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (Reuters)Domestic gold production fell 8 per cent in November to 110,900 ounces from October's 120,733 ounces, the Interior Department said today. Output for the first 11 months of the year totaled 1.32 million ounces, compared with 1.36 million ounces produced for the same period of 1971.

title: Jets Send Philbin to Chiefs For Adamle, Draft Pick
description: The wish to be traded that Gerry Philbin first gave voice to last fall came true yesterday when the New York Jets dealt their 6foot2inch, 245pound, nineyear defensive end to Kansas City in exchange for Mike Adamle, a running back, plus an undisclosed draft choice.

title: Cyprus Truce Means Clam but Not Peace
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 13  The Green Line, along which United Nations peacekeeping forces stand between the armed Greek and Turkish sectors of this divided capltal, means safety for many and coexistence for some but no real peace.

title: Brazil Imposes Sweeping Press Curbs and Installs Censors in Newsrooms of the Few Papers That Resist
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Feb. 10 Every night around 11, a censor from the Brazilian federal police goes into the newsroom of O Estado de Sao Paulo, the county's most influential newspaper, reads all the proofs and cuts any material that deals with taboo subjects or appears inconvenient.

title: Factory Output Rises
description: The Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that the nation's industrial production rose by fivetenths of 1 per cent in January. In another report, the commerce Department said housing starts continued in January at the record  breaking pace of 1972. Details, Page 41.

title: BISHOP ELWELL
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 16 (UPI)Bishop Clarence Elwell, head of the Columbus Diocese since 1968, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in the rectory of St. Joseph's Cathedral. He was 69 years old.

title: Sound Measure
description: Good news for riders of the Staten Island ferry that they may from now on expect to contemplate New York Harbor in peace and quiet. Charles G. Leedham, the city's Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, is pledged to take reprisals against those traveling nuisances who inflict the outpourings of their radios, phonographs and tape recorders on the nervous systems of those whose only recourse until now has been to jump into the polluted waters of the bay.

title: STATE IS WARNED ON TRIAL DELAYS
description: New York's highest court told the other branches of government yesterday that it would begin a wholesale release of defendants from jail unless the courts received adequate finaning to provide those defendants with speedy trials.

title: Lag Seen in Devaluation Impact
description: One of the chief architects a this week's devaluation of the dollar warned yesterday that would take more than two years for the full effects a the action to be apparent, and that, initially, its results would likely be perverse.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Nixon and Congress to Clash on Hospital Act
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 16The Nixon Administration has embarked on a collision course with Congressmen of both parties by seeking to end one of the most politically popular Federal programs ever voted, the HillBurton Act, which in 25 years has spent almost $4billion upgrading the nation's hospitals.

title: EXPILOT OF B52 FIRM ON DECISION

title: Poverty Agency Chief Howard Jay Phillips

Mr. Phillips has been selected by the White House to direct the dismantling of the Office of Economic. Opportunity, the antipoverty agency, with some parts of it to be abolished and others to be assigned to other agencies. His job is much like that of a referee in bankruptcy but he approaches it with fervor and the toughness of which he boasts. It was disclosed today that an internal O.E.O. memorandum called for swift dismantling of the agency before acted to it.

title: 'I Love You Rosa' Arrives From Israel:The Cast
description: Although it is inspired by Old Testament law, "I Love You Rosa," the Israeli-made nominee for an Oscar that arrived at the Little Carnegie yesterday, happily doesn't exude the mustiness of a period piece. Despite a slow, measured pace and a soap opera note or two, this gentle but perceptive examination of a decidedly unusual affair that happens to be set in Jerusalem of the eighteen-eighties is as sentimental as genuine love and as up to date as the women's liberation movement.In dealing largely with an 11-year-old Jewish boy's love for his young, widowed sister-in-law, Moshe Mizrahi, writer-director, sticks to his theme and avoids religious or distaff proseletyzing. He is a refreshingly professional craftsman who allows a viewer his own judgments.His story, unfolded mostly through a flashback, derives from the tenets in Deuteronomy on the duty of a man to marry his brother's widow as well as those involving the widow's rights if she's refused. Mr. Mizrahi's sentimentality may be obvious but his deft use of his material and his principals is sensitive and multifaceted.His hero, even under ancient law, is too young to marry, but he jumps at the chance to live with the sister-in-law he adores despite the opposition of his family and the taunts and attacks of friends and neighbors. And, as the drama's strongest character, the resolute widow is maternally understanding in her affection, even in the face of the community's heated criticism. When he does make love to her as a young man, a love she obviously reciprocates, she nevertheless rejects him as a husband. Eventually, he unselfishly releases her from her religious commitment. Women's liberation? She, in turn, in a somewhat sudsy finale, does choose to marry him.Michal Bat-Adam, a dark-eyed, brunette beauty (she also appears as a shriveled grandmother in the opening and closing sequence), is markedly persuasive as the stalwart Rosa who adamantly waits and achieves her rights and desires. Gabi Otterman is diffidently natural as the boy confused by love, sexuality and unbending religious requirements. And competent supporting players, among them Avner Chezkiyahu, as a compassionate rabbi, and Yosef Shiloah as the widow's suitor and the boy's employer, help enhance the bittersweet romance.Color cameras have vividly captured ancient Jerusalem, and English subtitles make the Hebrew dialogue lucidly plain. "I Love You Rosa" may have evolved as naive, mawkish folklore but Mr. Mizrahi's polished handling of his cast and subject makes them come alive in a simple, subdued and knowledgeable portrait.

title: Some Plants Should Not Be Eaten

The ingestion of a plant part can have a different effect on different people. It may cause a mild stomach upset in one person, severe abdominal pain in another, or perhaps death in a third, depending on the quantity ingested, its mode of intoxication, and individual susceptibility.

title: Talleyrand
description: TACIT but wellestablished law among publishers of history would have it that the more a subject has been treated, the more likely it is to be treated again. In other words, the more useless a book, the easier to publish. Thus, like the Beaujolais grapes which ripen each year on the gentle slopes of Burgundy, the traditional harvest of Napoleons, Victorias and Lincolns appears annually on bookstore shelves. Not far behind these grands crus, follow the Talleyrands, a sure bet whose consumption never fails to satisfy publishers and authors. This year's vintage is Americanonly just, perhaps, since the hero of the tale spent some time in the United States.
