description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Feb. 17Miss Deborah Evans Dillenbeck plans to be married March 17 to Charles Kirkland Duncan, who expects to be commissioned a second lieutenant in the Army at his graduation next month from the Officers Candidate School at Fort Benning, Ga.

title: CORNELL TROUNCES HARVARD SIX BY 94
description: ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 17 Cornell virtually assured itself of an eighth Ivy League hockey championship today with a 94 victory over Harvard before a standing room crowd at Lynah Rink. The Big Red now has an 181 wonlost record in Ivy play and 173 over all, while Harvard is 521 in the league and 1331 over all.

title: BILL SEEKS EXAMS TO AID VETERAN??
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik said yesterday that he had introduced a bill in the City Council to compel th?? Civil Service Commission to provide special examinations for Vietnam veterans who missed them because they were in the service.

title: $300,000 Humphrey Donor Denies Taking Big Loan
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Feb. 17 (AP)Walter Thomas Duncan has denied receiving $200,000 that the National Bank of Washington says he borrowed about the time he was to have contributed a like sum to Senator Hubert H. Humphrey's presidential campaign.

title: Greek Police Revise Toll
description: MEGARA, Greece, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The police said today that four persons died and 36 were injured when a passenger train jumped the rails near here last night. Earlier, the police put the toll at 10 dead and 17 injured.

title: Hall Sets Olympic Invitation Meet Mark of 683 in Weight Throw
description: Al Hall, a fourtime United States Olympian, set a meet record yesterday of 68 feet 3 inches for the 35pouted weight throw at the United States Olympic Invitational indoor track meet.

title: Leaders of American Legion, in a Major Shift, Seeking Friendly Dialogue With Soviet War Veterans
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 17Since its organization 54 years ago the American Lesion has yielded to no one in the militancy of its opposition to the Soviet Union and Communism, but now its leaders have decided on a new tack.

title: COSMOS ACQUIRE RIGHTS TO MESSING
description: The New York Cosmos, the defending North American Soccer League champions, announced yesterday that they had traded a future draft consideration and cash to Montreal for the right to negotiate a contract with Shep Messing, the controversial goalie of the 1972 United States Olympic team.

title: A place where the wind blows clean
description: This warm, joyous and often hilarious firstperson chronicle of a young animal doctor, beginning his career in the magnificent Yorkshire countryside nearly 40 years ago, shines with love of life. It is not surprising that James Herriot still ministers to his charges in the same location, for the reader soon feels that the man and his work should never be separated from Yorkshire and its people.

title: Diver at Home In Ocean Depth
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.  Linda and Edward Betts of Rosetdale, Queens, lead a happy and busy life operating divingequipment shops in Freeport and Huntington, but Mrs. Betts sometimes complains about her competition. The ocean is Ed's mistress, she said at the Long Island Boat Show in the Nassau Coliseum, where their Is41and Dive. Shops exhibit is larger than some boatdealer displays. Her husband said he counterattacked by belooming a skilled diver.

title: OSWALD MAY GET NEW STATE POST
description: ALBANY, Feb. 17Legislative sources said this week that a bill just passed by the Senate increasing the number of members on the Crime Victims Compensation Board was an attempt to find a new niche in state government for Correction Commissioner Russell G. Oswald.

title: INQUIRY INTO FUND NEAR CONCLUSION
description: The office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan said last week that a Manhattan grand jury was expected to complete by the end of February its investigation of alleged irregularities in Mayor Lindsay's Office of Neighborhood Government.

title: Boat Show Opens in Na.ssau Coliseum
description: UNIONDALE, L.I.  Boat shows were never like this  at least on Long Islandand the Long Island Boat Show, which opened last Friday night at Nassau Coliseum has officials hoping they will be turning away spectators as they have been exhibitors.

title: De Groot Inquiry Brings to Limelight Benefactor of Metropolitan Museum
description: Courted, won and soon forgotten, Adelaide Milton de Groot is back in the limelight.

title: A Hand for Errant Youths
description: ELIZABETH  Every week, on Elizabeth businessman and a teenage boy meet for coffee in a local restaurant. They chat about school, sports, family and friends, but the meeting is more than a social visit. The boy is on probation after a burglary attempt, and the businessman is his volunteer probation counselor.

title: Kilometers and Miles On Ohio Road Signs
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 17 (AP)Two pairs of the signs along Interstate Highway 71 in Ohio show the distance to Columbus, Cleveland and Cincinnati in kilometers as well as miles.

title: Voluntary World Power
description: WASHINGTONPentagon studies have persuaded the White House that ending the draft and shifting this year to armed forces based only on volunteer enlistments will but slightly diminish the overall size of this country's military establishment. Therefore this will neither weaken the U.S. defense role at home or abroad nor affect its role as a major factor in achieving foreign policy goals.

title: MRS. SIDNEY E. FRANK
description: PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 Mrs. Louise Rosenstiel Frank, a collector of impressionist and threedimensional art, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at the age of 50. She lived here, in New Rochelle, N. Y., and in Antigua, West Indies.

title: Youths Get Close Look At Politics In Matawan
description: MATAWAN  Ten Matawan teenagers are getting a close look at municipal government this year through a new program that gives them seats on the Township Council and four other official boards and commissions.

title: Episcopal Clerics Rejoice at a Pentecostal Parley
description: DALLAS, Feb. 17Episcopal clergymen, rejoicing what they called receipt of gifts of the Holy Spirit, gathered at St. Matthew's Cathedral here this week for the first National Episcopal Charismatic Conference.

title: Deborah Beinecke Is Married Here
description: In the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church here yesterday evening, Miss Deborah Beinecke, daughter of Mrs. George Edmund Dickinson of Cos Cob, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass., and Walter Beinecke Jr. of Williamstown, Mass., and Nantucket, became the bride of Willaim Archibald Kinsella 3d.

title: Columbia Medical School Plans 20Million Facility
description: Columbia University's preliminary plans for the major educational facility and library for its Medical School in Wishfngton Heights calls for the construction of a 10story tower with provision for the addition of 20 floors.

title: Miss Katharine Ann Rohrer Betrothed to Thomas Haight
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 17  Mr. and Mrs. William Matthew Rohrer of Bronxville and Pocono Lake Preserve, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Ann Rohrer, to Thomas Griffith Haight, son of Mrs. David Crater Haight of Glenside, Pa., and the late Mr. Haight. A September wedding is planned.

title: GIBSON PRESSES BID ON A NEWARK PAPER
description: PARAMUS, N. J., Feb. 17 (UPl)Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark said today that he had asked 80 publishers across the country to start a second newspaper in New Jersey's largest city, but had received almost no favorable response.

title: A Classical Harpist Gives Folk Concert Troubador's Touch
description: On previous occasions here, Gerald Goodman has shown his expertise as a classical harp soloist and chamber player. At Carnegie Recital Hall on Friday night, he added a troubadour's feather to his tonal cap, and with the assistance of Susan Reed and Joseph B, Brady, a pipe major, put on as winsome a folk concert as we've had since the last visits of Richard DyerBennet.

title: U.S. GIVES YESHIVA GRANT OF $878,000
description: The United States Office of Education has made two grants totaling about $878,000 to Yeshiva University for research and curriculumdevelopment for the education of the mentally retarded and for worldwide study of exemplary highschool bilingual programs.

title: Stamps
description: LOOKING with hope beyond a world of strife, carpet bombing and balanced nuclear terror, the United Nations is once again returning to the quest for disarmament as it puts out its first stamps of 1973.

title: Edison Letter Describes Himself as Poor and Needy
description: MARIETTA, Ohio, Feb. 17 (UPI)Marietta College officials have celebrated the anniversary of Thomas Edison's birthday with the release of letter the inventor wrote saying he was poor and needy.

title: The Key Lesson: Cooperation Is Vital
description: LONDONRealism is often said to be the beginning of wisdom in international relations, as elsewhere. It is on that basis that the latest devaluation of the dollar, and the way it was done, have been widely welcomed outside the United States.

title: Laos Some Day We'll Have Peace
description: VIENTIANE A highranking Laotian Government official was asked last week how he felt about a forthcoming ceasefire agreement that would end the war in his country. He paused for a moment, shrugged, and replied: It's not our war.

title: Landslide Kills 2 in Italy
description: NAPLES, Italy, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Firemen recovered two bodies from wreckage of two houses buried by a landslide near here last night, but there was no sign of eight persons who were reported missing. Rescuers worked all night to clear tons of earth that swept down a hillside onto the houses on the edge of the town of Termini.

title: Olegna Fuschi Displays Musicianship at Piano
description: Every piece was superlatively played by Olegna Fuschi in her Tully Hall recital last Monday night. The pianist unraveled the snarled webs of Scriabin's B minor Fantasy and Godowsky's Piedermaus paraphrase with admirable clarity, easily sustaining the surface tension and highlighting the salient musical, points with graceful finesse and ebullient virtuosity.

title: NIXON PICKS GRAY AS HEAD OF F.B.I.
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 17 President Nixon today nominated L. Patrick Gray 3d to be director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in a move that could touch off a confrontation between the Senate and the White House.

title: Susan B. Anthony Honored
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb, 17 (UPI)  The Texas Legislature held special services Thursday in tribute to Susan B. Anthony, a campaigner for women's liheratism at the turn of the century.

title: L.I. Professor Is Honored
description: STONY BROOK, L.I. Science and humanism, which often operate on such different wave lengths that never the twain shall meet, have met in the person and teaching goals of Elof Axel Carlson, professor of biological sciences at the State University Center at Stony Brook, who has been selected by the Danforth Foundation as a recipient of a 1972 E: Harris Harbison Award for gifted teaching, worth $10,000.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: She thought Byron was mad, bad and dangerous to know
description: VERY silly woman was what The British Critic, a contemporary literary journal, called the heroine of Lady Caroline Lamb's Glenarvon, published in 1816, in which she told all about her muchpublicized affair with Lord Byron. Henry Blyth, who has had access to the large collection of her diaries, letters and sketches now the possesion of Lady Salmond, has retold her sorry story with (he hopes) compassion. He has come to another conclusion: that the central characters in this drama behaved as they did because they remained basically very immature ... We are really dealing with children, not adults. They are spoilt children. He goes on to explain that he uses their fatal passion to illustrate his two central themes: that a permissive society is not necessarily mature and that such a society can be surprisingly unworldly.

title: VERMONT DEBTOR IN PRISON 5 YEARS
description: WINDSOR, Vt., Feb. 17Although there are no debtor's prisons in Vermont, George J. Chicoine has been imprisoned at the maximum security State Prison here since Oct. 30, 1967, because he owes $2,550 in support payments to his estranged wife.

title: Bessie
description: By Chris Albertson. Illustrated. 253 pp. New York: Stein & Day. $7.95.

title: Freddi Gingold Fiancee Of Robert Greenberg
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., Feb. 17 Miss Freddi Jane Gingold and Robert E. Greenberg have made plans to be married in June. Their engagement has been announced by Miss Gingold's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Gingold. The prospective bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pascal A. Greenberg also of Great Neck.

title: Blomqvist, Driving a Saab, Takes Swedish Auto Rate
description: KARLSTAD, Sweden, Feb. 17 (AP)Stig Blomqvist of Sweden, driving a Saab, gained his third straight victory by winning the 24th Swedish Royal Automobile Club's KAK Classic winter rally today despite carbouretor trouble that cost him 600 points and 10 minutes, during the first leg yesterday.

title: Miss O'Shea Has Nuptials
description: Miss Elizabeth Marie O'Shea, daughter of Mrs. Charles Joseph O'Shea of Point Lookout, L. I., and the late Mr. O'Shea, was married here yesterday morning to James Mathis Pfohl, son of Louis H. Pfohl of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Dubuque, Iowa, and the late Mrs. Pfohl.

title: Mrs. Wohl Married to John C. Hilly
description: Mrs. Mae Kreshover Wohl of New York and Hilo, Hawaii, was married here last evening to John C. Hilly of Atlantis, Fla., a former assistant United States attorney for the Southern District of New York. Lieut. Comdr. Donald B. Reese of the Navy Chaplains Corps performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the Friar's Chapel of the Church of St. Vincent Ferrer.

title: Myschool Offers Novel Education
description: MORRISTOWN  Three certified teachers, all despairing of the heavy reliance, on rote in the public school system, have founded their own school. Called Myschool, it is currently attended by 24 children between the ages of 5 and 10.

title: R. K. Weiser to Wed Miss Susan B. Gorel
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. Myron S. Gorel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Beth Gorel, to Robert Kane Weiser, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth D. Weiser. Both families live in Scarsdale.

title: Future Social Events
description: Feb. 21Gian Carlo Menotti started the Spoleto Festival of Two Worlds 16 years ago to give opportunities to young people in the arts. The festival is seeking to enlarge its circle of American friends, whose $100 annual membership fee insures American participation. The first step in the drive will begin at 6:15 P.M. on Bloomingdale's third floor with a program of modes and music. After cocktails and antipasto, a classic shortcut to the start of new acquaintanceships, Ottavio and Rosita Missoni will present their spring collection of fashions for women and men. Then the New York Pro Musica, which will be a part of this summer's festival, will give a brief Bach program. One Hundred dollars permits your viewing of this cultural gallimaufry and is your passport to American Friendship. Mrs. Donald

title: AROUND THE
description: Seed can now be patented. Gardeners paging through seed catalogues and thumbing through seed sales racks in stores will find evidence of this, In most catalogues, a tiny circle with a small letter P in it will appear after the variety listing to designate that protection has been applied for under the U.S. Plant Variety Protection Act. Seed packets will also have the same designation if the particular variety is under patent application.

title: The Mutual Fund Trap
description: Not so long ago, a partner in a distinguished investment banking and brokerage firm was talking about a corporation whose common stock had gone from nowhere to 36 and then down to 5. Nobody got hurt, the man said. Huh? He explained that the commercial banks were more than adequately covered on their loans to the company and that there was still enough money coming in to enable it to pay interest and preferred dividends. But what about the little people who were told it was a hot stock at maybe 30 and were still holding at 5? They shouldn't be in the stock market, was his reply.

title: Politicized Dollar
description: Devaluation of the dollar has become a handy instrument for exporting the political consequences of mismanaged domestic economic policy. Necessary as was the Administration's decision to cut the exchange price of United States currency for the second time in fourteen months, it would be a mistake to pretend that this represents a painless corrective for the economy's present ills or, for the future, that the country can dance through an endless series of such devaluations without disrupting the fabric of international relationspolitical as well as commercial and financial.

title: Tigers Kill 151 Indians In Forest in Five Years
description: CALCUTTA, India, Feb. 17  Tigers have killed 151 people in five years in a forest north of Calcutta, the Government reported this week.

title: NIXON WILL VISIT CAROLINA CAPITOL
description: COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 17President Nixon will address the South Carolina Legislature Tuesday, and the hastily arranged visit is being viewed by some Democrats as what one termed the opening salvo of the 1974 Governor's race.

title: How an American moved
description: In 1928, Doris Humphrey (age 32) presented a highlypraised New York concert consisting amost entirely of dances she had choreographed. She wrote home to her mother in Oak Park, Ill., And now that I've smelled blood God help anybody who stands between me and my meat! No one would have dared toat least not with much conviction: not her colleagues in this nascent period of American Modem Dance; not her husband, a sailor, who often found that his days on shore coincided with her most strenuous rehearsals; not her son, who was used to roller skating from grammar school to the HumphreyWeidman studio or meeting his mother at a restaurant for a hasty dinner.

title: The Challenging Mountains: Men Attempt 46
description: IN the late spring of 1972 in Lake Placid, N. Y., two young men begin planning a mountaineering expedi tion. It was not the kind of expe dition on which climbers, using tope and ice axes, cross glaciers and scale pre. cipitous rock faces in the thin air of great altitudes. The two men would challenge the calendar and the clock on the forested and often wild slopes of the Adirondack Mountains in upstate New York.

title: Dustin's a Rabbi Now
description: WE always knew Dustin Hoffman would be going places, but we never knew one of those places would be a synagogue. Nevertheless, the exgraduate Benjamin Braddock, exhustler Ratzo Rizzo, exrock composer Harry Kellerman has definitely made up his mind to play man of God in the film version of Harry Kemelman's novel, Friday the Rabbi Slept Late. The project will be a joint production of First Artists and Wagner/International Productions, which is headed by Raymond Wagner and John Damore. Ulu Grosbard, who guided Hoffman through the 1971 comedydrama Who Is Harry Kellerman and Why Is He Saying Those Terrible Things About Me?, will also direct Rabbi. Shooting will begin later this year, in New England, after Hoffman has completed his costarring assignment with Steve McQueen in Papillon.

title: Poet as victim and victimizer
description: FOR those who recognize that it is nations and not individuals that make war, Robert Bly's new book may be the best examination of our motives during the debacle in Vietnam. Sleepers Joining Hands looks at the dominion of chaos and death over recent American life and tries to discern its whole meaning, as if at last we have got far enough into it or beyond it to understand what happened, and as if we will not be devastated again by any more surprises.

title: The Erotic Mountains One Woman Finds Joy in a Flower Guide
description: IN my Seattle youth I'd known some real mountains, but never intimately. Too young, too ouch of a clean wholesome Girl Scout. James Dickey's ecopornplogical adventure yarn Deliverance aged me. Dickey's cliffhanging description of cliff climbingat the place where Ed is scaling up from the river with his suburban bow and arrows to kill the killer of his buddy Drew  was absolutely galvanizing: Then I would begin to try to inch upward again, moving with the most intimate motions of my body, motions I had never dared use with Martha, or any other human woman. Fear and a kind of enormous moonblazing sexuality lifted me, millimeter by millimeter.

title: Miss Wilson Plans Bridal
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17Miss Louise Lard Wilson and Timothy Floyd Lewis plan to be married here March 3 in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Mother of Good Counsel.

title: Activist Says. He Is Scapegoat In Slaying of 3 Black Students
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 17Cleveland L. Sellers Jr., a black activist, surrendered last night for imprisonment by the South Carolina Department of Corretdons. He said he viewed himself as a scapegoat in the slaying of three black students at Orangeburg more than five years ago.

title: Julia Kalikman Wed
description: WELLESLEY, Mass., Feb. 17  Miss Julia Kalikman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kalikman of Haddonfield, N.J., and Peter L. Masnik, a iawyer of Worcester and member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives, were married here this evening at the Wellesley College Club by Rabbi Ira Youdovin, associate rabbi of Temple Emanuel in Worcester. The bridegroom is a son of Michael G. Masnik of Worcester and the late Mrs. Rose L. Masnik.

title: CATRIGGED KETCH IS SAILING VICTOR
The World's Next Monetary System
description: President Nixon has hailed the advent of the generation of peace, and all Americans fervently hope that his prophecy will be realized. Yet the world faces Simultaneously the real threat of an end to the generation of economic peace that has contributed greatly to the stability and prosperity of the postwar period, and which has distinguished it so radically from its interwar predecessor.

title: Mrs. Walters Is Bride Of Edward Wallace
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17Mrs. Genevieve M. Walters of Manalapan, Fla., widow of John W. Walters, was married here this morning to Edward Corbett Wallace of Greenwich, Conn., and New York by Msgr. Edward N. Ferger, a retired Roman Catholic priest, in his private chapel. A reception was held at the Everglades Club in Palm Beach.

title: Ellen Jacoby Engaged
description: PLEASANTVILLE, N. Y., Feb. 17Mrs. Earl E. Jacoby has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ellen Orleans Jacoby, to Oliver Woodman Stalter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver R. B. Stalter of Springfield, Vt.

title: Bridge
description: The Irish novelist George Moore was probably not thinking of bridge when he wrote that The wrong way always seems the more reasonable, but many card players would find his dictum appropriate. The obvious, routine, commonsense play often seems reasonable but turns out badly, and the player never discovers that an exotic and apparently unreasonable play, breaking all traditional rules of thumb, would have been indicated by less superficial reasoning, and would have succeeded.

title: Good Guys
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Sunrise Mall Damning In Nassau Next August
description: Stuirise Mall, the regional shopping center along Sunrise Highway in Massapequa, is scheduled to open next August. But the concept of an enclosed mall at this prime retail location has been bandied about for more than a decade.

title: Denver Wonders When Its Transit Project Will Start
description: DENVER, Feb. 17The Federal Government with some fanfare announced last October a decision to start a demonstration of a new urban public transit technology in Denver. Four months later, Denver officials are wondering when, and whether, the project will start moving.

title: Bicentennial Panel Changed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 16, (AP)  Representative Gerry E. Studds, Democrat of Massachusetts, has been appointed to the American Revolution Bicentennial Commission. He repines Representative James A. Burke, also a Massachusetts Democrat, who asked to be replaced because of his work on the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: They Remember Ted
description: Fifteen years after having switched from the mutuels to the mutuals, T. Frederic Atkinson was driving recently through midtown traffic here when a huge garbage truck lumbered alongside the little man's little car.

title: Dismissal of Char es Against Senator Is Studied
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 17At the request of a group of Phoenix lawyers, the Phoenix City Council has ordered an examination of the circumstances surrounding the Dec. 22 dismissal of drunken driving charges against United States Senator Paul J. Fannin, a Republican.

title: The Last Word
description: The nose of a mob is its imagination, said Edgar Allan Poe; By this, at any time, it can be quietly led.

title: Princeton Battlefield Will Be Expanded
description: TRENTON  Plans to enlarge and improve historic Princeton Battlefield State Park got a boost last week.

title: Hillsdale, Now in 75th Year, Recalls Past
description: HILLSDALE  The Indians came here first, then the Dutch and the English. It was the LeniLenape tribe of the Algonquin Nation that named the little brook Musquapsink and the path that crossed it Wierimus Lane.

title: Robin Moore, the Author, Weds Mary Olga Troshkin, a Model
description: WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 17Miss Mary Olga Troshkin was married here this afternoon to Robert Lowell Moore Jr., known as Robin Moore, author of such best sellers as The Green Berets and The French Connection. The ceremony at the bridegroom's home was performed by Judge Robert Anstett of the Westport Probate Court.

title: Calendar of Horse Show Events
description: TodayNimrod Farm, Route 57, Weston, Conn. Maiden, novice, children's and regular working hunters; equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: CORRUPTION STUDY IN FLORIDA MOVED
description: MIAMI, Feb. 17An inquiry into alleged corruption in Dade County's judiciary and local government has been transferred to the jurisdiction of a grand jury in Volusia County (Daytona Beach).

title: 72 Invited to Masters; No Blacks Are on List
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., Feb. 16 (AP)  Two fourtime winners, Jack Nicklaus and Arnold Palmer, head a list of 72 American golfers who have been extended invitations to participate in the 38th Masters golf tournament at Augusta National Golf Club in April.

title: U.S. Wins in Water Polo
description: CUPERTINO, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)The United States national water polo teed defeated the Soviet Union's Olympic championship squad today, 54. It was the final of the Russians' sixgame tour here and their only loss.

title: Few Taxpayers Completing Form for Political Gift
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) Based on early returns, the new system of allowing Americans to contribute part of their Federal income tax to the national political parties is a dismal failure.

title: Old Rail Depots Are Being Put to New Use as Art Galleries
description: HARRINGTON PARK  The number of railroad commuters in North Jersey may be down to a comparative trickle these days, but many of the stations that once served themand served them wellare still in business and going strong.

title: U.S. BARGE IS SUNK ON MEKONG RIVER
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb, 17 (UPI)  AntiGovernment units along the Mekong River sank an American barge carrying napalm bombs and badly damaged two other cargo ships carrying supplies to the Cambodian capital, the ships' owners said today.

title: Letters: Atlantic Steam
description: To the Editor: In his letter to the editor in the Travel Section of Jan. 21, Gregory Battcock suggested that the maintenance of yearround transAtlantic steamship service should be a worthwhile subject for Government subsidy. I heartily agree, particularly since the liner United States is available; it is one of the finest ships in the world and still holds the blue ribbon for crossing the Atlantic.

title: Natural Resources
description: WASHINGTON  President Nixon sent shock waves through rural America last week. In a message to Congress, he called for an end to major Governmentaid programs that are based on a philosophy that has, benefited farmers for nearly four decades.

title: Canadiens Toppled by Flyers, 76
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 17 (UPI)Bobby. Clarke had the first threegoal game of his National Hockey League career tonight, scoring the winning goal with less than four minutes to play as the Philadelphia Flyers overcame the Montreal Canadiens, 76, in a wild, penaltyfilled contest.

title: The economy: To tame the monster
description: How times do change! It seems only yesterday that Walter W. Heller, fresh from his triumphant tour of duty as chairman of the KennedyJohnson Council of Economic Advisers, began his 1966 Godkin lectures at Harvard with this proud claim for the economists:

title: Smith Indicts Prison System
description: Edgar Smith, who spent 14 years and nine months in New Jersey's Death Row before his release 14 months ago, does not regard the state's prison system highly. He maintains that prisoners who are rehabilitated accomplish it despite prison, not because of it.

title: Melba? She's the Toast of the Town
description: SHE is a new kind of celebritya television superstar reporterbred by television and its peculiar kind of intimacy which brings her into the living rooms or bedrooms or kitchens of almost a million viewers every night on WABC's Eyewitness News, covering fires, funerals, raids by the D.A.'s office, or sick baby whales. She is a household word just like the products pushed in the commercials. The viewers have bought her, in a way, and to many she is their sweetheart. When they see her on the street, they act as if they own her.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The article on racial change in the Wynnefield section of Philadelphia [Racial Change Slashes Valuesand Produces Bargains, Jan. 21] mentioned that areas of New Rochelle have had a similar experience.

title: Pupil Tests on Race and Sex Bias Arouse Montclair Parents
description: MONTCLAIRIn a community already divided by educational strife, a series of tests given recently to 4,200 public school children in grades 2 through 8 have added to the discord.

title: Saving Legal Services
description: The Office of Economic Opportunity is dying but its Legal Services program deserves to live. Under both a Democratic and Republican President, the storefront lawyers for the poor have brought a fuller meaning to the idea of equal justice under law. Its 2,500 federally funded attorneys in 900 neighborhood offices have represented the indigent in city slums, on Indian reservations, in oldage homes, in landlordandtenant cases and a variety of other civil matters. This public service law has attracted some of the best young men and women in the country and they have changed attitudes and courtrooms for the better while helping to restore faith in the legal system.

title: Letters
description: When pishtush just won't do

title: Pacts Signed for Japanese To Purchase U.S. Uranium
description: TOKYO, Feb. 17 (Reuters)Japanese electric power companies have announced the signing of formal contracts with the United States Atomic Energy commission to import 10,000 rims of enriched uranium worth $320million.

title: Libyan, in AntiAtheist Move Bars Portraits of Leaders
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, Feb. 17 (Reuters)The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, says he has banned the display of portraits of leaders to keep people from possibly honoring Communist atheists.

title: An American Family
description: Elie Wiesel sat in his chair refusing to follow the other dinnerparty guests into the TV room where they were watching Lance Loud and his mother, Pat, on WNET's new series, An American Family. One written sentence is worth 800 hours of film, said Mr. Wiesel, poet, purist, artist. On the other hand, Margaret Mead has termed the series as important a moment in the history of human thought as the invention of the novel. Probably she exaggerates, but it's no wonder writers are defensive.

title: Junior Band Head Honored
description: VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Feb. 17 (UPI)Donald W. Hurrelbrink, 63 years old, leader of the Warren (Ohio) Junior Military Band for 43 years, was named winner today of the 1972 George Washington Award, the highest individual honor of the Freedoms Foundation of Valley Forge. Mr. Hurrelbrink, retired music director of the Austintown, Ohio, Fitch High School Band, will receive the award and $5,000 along with 42 other recipients of awards on Monday at the Valley Forge Military Academy.

title: U.S. ENVOY TO LAOS MAY SUCCEED GREEN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17G. McMurtrie Godley, the United States Ambassador to Laos, was reported today as the likely successor to Marshall Green as the State Department's chief official in charge of Asian affairs.

title: Fire at OilStorage Tank
description: A fire of undetermined origin caused slight damage yesterday to the outside of an oilstorage tank at a Consolidated Edison plant at Hudson Avenue and John Street in Brooklyn, near the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, a company spokesman reported. He said the blaze broke outabout 8:30 A.M. at a partially buried tank containing about two millions gallons of No. 6 oil. No injuries were reported.

title: the traveler's world
description: HERE is a vision being polished and groomed in the New York City Department of Marine and Aviation: it shows the present small and inadequate heliport at the foot of East 34th Street transformed into a major terminal designed for the occasional use of the President and other officials and available for use by all of us common people the rest of the tune. More important, it is, in the vision, the prototype of possibly a halfdozen air and water transportation interfaces ringing Manhattan Island.

title: Golf Foundation Plans To Add Scholarships
description: Spurred by the success of its tournament, Day with the AllAmericans, the AllAmerican Collegiate Golf Foundation has announced plans to broaden its scholarship program and possibly move the event to other cities.

title: Blockbusting Curb Upheld By Federal Appeals Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (AP)  The antiblockbusting provision in the Fair Housing Act is a legal attempt by Congress to disprove the belief held by many that the nation made a promise it could not keep when it abolished slavery, a Federal court here has ruled.

title: U.S. AIDE ENTERS BELL CO. DISPUTE
description: Virginia H. Knauer, the White House adviser on consumer affairs, has entered a longstanding dispute between the hearing aid industry and the Bell Telephone System. The dispute is over which industry should be responsible for the fact that about half the hearing aids that Americans now use do not work with a new type of telephone earphone being installed across the country.

title: He honored the Presidency merely by seeking the office
description: WHEN a foreign policy has culminated in such a disaster as Vietnam, there is an irresistible temptation to contemplate what might have been. The obvious focus of such speculation is Adlai Stevenson, who, I believe, brought more honor to the Presidency in seeking the office than any who have since held it.

title: Hong Kong Drops All Curbs On Liquor Sale and Drinking
description: HONG KONG, Feb. 17 (UPI) All restrictions on drinking in this British colony were abolished this week.

title: Headliners
description: Auxiliaries and craft. That was the unassuming title of an item in the Budget submitted to Congress by President Nixon three weeks ago. But tucked away therein, according to Representative Les Aspin, was an unheralded $192million appropriation request for Litton Industries and its contract to build amphibious assault ships. Litton has been pushing for a $300million price increase in the Navy contractto a chorus of Congressional critics who accuse the company of mismanagement and the military of bailing out a corporation that's big enough to take care of itself. Mr. Aspin, an erstwhile Pentagon economist, last week claimed the Government had been deceptive in the presentation of the Budget item, a claim denied by the Navy. In blunt terms, said Mr. Aspin, calling upon Defense Secretary Elliot L. Richardson to cut out the item, the Navy has been taken to the cleaners by Litton Industries.

title: Music
description: FOR years Rudolf Bing had been talking about the desirability of the Metropolitan Opera operating a smaller house. The idea would be to present a different kind of repertoryintimate opera, new opera, works that would not fit the big stage of the Lincoln Center house. Held as a model was the Piccola Scala, an appendage to the great Scala in Milan, which was founded in 1955 and has presented operas such as Paisiello's Barber, Pergolesi's La serva padrona and so on through 20thcentury items. But nothing came of Bing's idea. There was no appropriate house to stage operas, and there was no money build a house.

title: Mexican Workers Pressing for a FiveDay Week
description: MEXICO CITY, Feb. 17 To the workers it is a dream that may come true, to touristhotel operators it could be more money in the till and to sociologists it poses the possibility of new studies on how Mexicans spend their spare time. But to many Mexican businessmen, it is flirting with fiscal irresponsibility.

title: The Past Emerges, Daily, At Aphrodisias
description: MOST Americans probably have at best a hazy notion that Homer's ancient Troy is in Turkey, but it is doubtful that they would know even that much about Sardis, Pergamum and Aphrodisias. Matters more important than a deficiency in Turkish geography are involved: Most Americans, also incorrectly subcribe to the theory that western civilization incubated solely west of the Bosporus, while actually it developed on both sides of that historic gateway between the eastern and the western worlds, and with a surprising amount of interaction.

title: Uruguay
description: MONTEVIDEO  In the end, many people wondered if there had been military coup or not.

title: Reversing The Blame
description: It is an ironic fact that those who call attention to a problem and insist that it be dealt with often end by being considered the problem themselves. Thus, the war in Vietnam might never have been halted had it not been for the political opposition of Americans who insisted to two Presidents that it was an unnecessary, unwinnable and immoral war; but in the end it was those same Americans who were consistently accused of having been the stumbling blocks on the way to peace with honor.

title: Trudeau, His Liberal Party's Ranks Thinned Is More Conservative in Manner but Not in Mind
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 17With the ranks of the Liberal party thinned by election reverses, Prime Minister Pierre Elliot Trudeau is a sobered, subdued leader in the House of Commons these days.

title: Officer to Marry Carolyn J. Conte
description: BALDWIN, L. I., Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. Paul F. Conte have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Jean Conte, to Chief Warrant Officer/2 Brian B. Sheehy, an Army helicopter pilot who returned recently from Vietnam. He is the son of James J. Sheehy of Rockville Centre and the late Mrs. Frances K. Sheehy.

title: Photography
POINT OF VIEW
description: We are now in the midst of an economic boom that probably cannot be sustained for long. Late this year, or no later than early 1974, the real rate of economic growth may be only a small fraction of the current high rate and a complete lack of real growth for a short time span cannot be entirely ruled out.

title: Minimansion in Manhattan By Norma Skurka
description: The corridors of apartment buildings usually look monotonously alike, but behind the anonymous doors, individualism reigns. There are classic modern interiors, comfortably dowdy ones, and then there are sumptuous minimansions like this penthouse on Central Park South. When their children were grown, the Leonard Kahns decided to leave the suburbs and indulge themselves with a compact pied terre in the center of Manhattan's cultural world. They found a small penthouse with a large living room and told gesigner Hariet Eckstein of Rouridtree Inc that they wanted an elegant look, but nothing stiff or overformal. She used rich pattern and color, a few stunning antiques and a number of reproductions for everyday hard use to achieve a countrified elegance. With its enclosed greenhouseterrace overlooking the park, the penthouse comes close to being a country house high in the sky.

title: What rice Amtrak?
description: The mystique of rail travel in America is gone.

title: The New Plays
description: FINISHING TOUCHES, a comedy by Jean Kerr, got four favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Watts, Post; Wallach, Newsday; Raidy, Newhouse Newspapers), three mixed (Glover, AP; Gaver, UPI; Sanders, ABCTV) and five negative reviews (Watt, News; Gottfried, Women's Wear; Harris, CBSTV; Klein, WNEWTV; Bookspan, WPIXTV).

title: Woman Pilots Boat Show
description: EAST MEADOW, L. I., Feb. 17At a time when most of today's women's liberation supporters were in their rompers, a young woman was breaking the allmale domain of the boating industy by selling magazines behind a counter of the National Boat Show.

title: EGYPTIAN TO VISIT U.S. TO GIVE VIEW
description: CAIRO, Feb. 17The Egyptian Government today decided to send Hafez Ismail, President Anwar elSadat's adviser on national security affairs, to Washington to impress on President Nixon the need for diplomatic action in the Middle East, highplaced diplomatic sources, said tonight.

title: Nixon Farm Proposals Stir Old Democratic Fears
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Most Congressmen were out of town when President Nixon sent to the Capitol this week his message calling for the elimination of the central features of a farm program that has a largely Democratic past.

title: Jane Blalock on Tour: Hot or Cool Receptions
description: NAPLES, Fla., Feb. 17 (AP) Cold shoulders and warm hearts greet Jane Blalock on the pro golf tournament trail.

title: Huntington Groups Protest School Plans
description: HUNTINGTON VILLAGE  Rallies, demands and appeals have been sweeping the Huntington area with increasing intensity since Jan. 11, when the Board of Education of Huntington's District No. 3 announced its redistricting plan, developed in response to State Education Commissioner Ewald B. Nyquist's integration order of last August.

title: G.M.'s New Deal for Women Workers
description: DETROIT  When Anne Zaragoza graduated from high school with a strong interest in mathematics and science, she did not want to teachthe usual career open to a woman in that field.

title: Ann C. Sullivan Engaged to John Olson
description: WAYNE, Pa., Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. George Francis Sullivan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Catharine Sullivan, to John Karl Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Gunnar Olson of Weymouth, Mass.

title: Air Passenger Boom at Kennedy Topped 20 Million Mark in '72
description: Stimulated by the nation's resurgent economy following a threeyear slump, and a continuing boom in travel abroad by middleclass AmerJeans, passenger arriving at or departing from Kennedy International Airport exceeded 20 million for the first time last year.

title: Interfaith Effort Fights Social Ills
description: EAST ORANGEAn interfaith drive to recruit those community leaders who can pinpoint and act upon major social problems is under way in Bergen, Essex, Union, Morris, Hudson, Sussex and Passaic Counties.

title: Art
description: IT will be a year next weekthe date was Sunday, Feb. 27since the exposure of the first episode of what has turned out to be the running scandal of the Metropolitan Museum's wheelingdealing, secrecy, evasions, deceptions, and flat denials of demonstrable truths in the sales and swaps of paintings from its collections. It has been a tempestuous year for the museum and a tragic one for its public image.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Dogs Aid in Search for Bodies on S.I.

title: M.B.A. Program Aids Women
description: GREENVALE, L. I.Women  including those in middle life whose family responsibilities have lessenedare moving in the traditionally male domain of the american graduate business school with the aid of an unusual scholarship program at C. W. Post Center of Long Island University.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: United Parcel Service has leased almost the entire New York Motor Truck Terminal for 25 years at an aggergate rent of $15,816,000.

title: Not to be married or single
description: MOST Americans grow up in a nuclear family, the basic social unit of mother, father and children living together without relatives or dependents. Starting in late adolescence they may live outside the family for up to 10 years; then they marry, thus founding the nuclear families of the next generation. But rarely, nowadays, do they seem to live happily ever after. The muchpublicized deficiencies of the nuclear family are closely related to its small size and, especially in the United States, its isolation from other social institutions and activities. Hardly ever in previous history has man lived in such a confined domestic setting; and many young people, wary of the concentrated tensions of such a way of life, don't wish to perpetuate it themselves.

title: Ballplayers To Accept 3 Proposals
description: The executive board of the Players' Association has accepted the baseball club owners' proposals on a waiver limit, a later spring training Start and daily meal money, but continued to differ with the owners on, salary arbitration, minimum salary, minimum. World Series shares, the right to reject trades and the reserve clause.

title: House of Dolls in Nassau
description: WESTBURY  More than 1,000 residents crowd the quiet, whiteframe home of the Marcus family here but only four of them are people. Dolls of, every period and nationality line the walls, cabinets, even the kitchen shelves of the twostory home on Lace Lane.

title: Writers Will Present Golf Prizes Tomorrow
description: Ben Hogan, in a rare public appearance, Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Byron Nelson will be among those honored at tomorrow night's National Golf Awards dinner at the Hotel Americana.

title: Pop
description: EVEN though every pop vocalist who carries an acoustic guitar is commonly referred, to as a folksinger, there is very little real folk music currently reaching a mass audience. In America, the tendency has always been to absorb our young folk culture into the pop media in a smooth, continual process of updating that forbids the establishment of tradition. Our songwriters are turning to other sources for their material and inspiration: commercial country music, 50's rock and roll, 30's pop ballads, art songs. Even the nostalgia craze has not brought about a revival of the late 50's folk boom, maybe because the communal hootenanny spirit now seems so inappropriate to our fragmented, Excedrin  ridden lives.

title: Minnesota Defeats Indiana
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 17 (UPI) Clyde Turner topped Minnesota's balanced attack tonight as the fourthranked Gophers defeated 10thranked Indiana, 8275, and moved loser to first place in the Big Ten.

title: World News Briefs
description: ATHENS, Feb. 17 (UPI)Medical students at Athens University, a day after more than 100 other students there had clashed with the police when they demonstrated against Government measures, joined today with law school and Polytechnic colleagues in boycotting classes until the Government repeals legislation aimed at curbing student agitation.

title: Horsemen's Association on L.I. Opposes Planned Bridge to Rye
description: The Nassau Suffolk Horsemen's Association has gone on record as oppsing the proposed bridge connecting Rye, N. Y., with the North Shore of Long Island.

title: MRS. JAMES J. DRISCOLL
description: Mrs. Gertrude Quinn Driscoll, the widow of James J. Driscoll, who had been assistant controller of St. Mary's Hospital in Brooklyn and executive vice president of the George W. Luft Company of Long Island City, died yesterday at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Queens. She was 67 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens, and in Mattituck, L. I.

title: Home Improvement
description: In an effort to catch up on the backlog of unanswered questions, the entire Home Improvement column this week is being devoted to Questions and Answers. Many of these pose questions that are similar to those asked by other readers whose actual letters may not be published here, but who, nevertheless, will find their answers below. Readers sending in questions about home repair problems should address them to: Home Improvement Pepartment, The New York Times, Times Square, New York, N.Y. 10036. Only those questions of general interest will be answered on this page.

title: Nine Arrested in Jersey In Police Gambling Raids
description: EDISON, N. J., Feb. 16 (AP) Nine persons were arrested today on various gambling charges after State Police conducted simultaneous raids on 26 locations in Middlesex, Monmouth, Union and Mercer Counties.

title: Witchtown First at Lincoln
description: LINCOLN, R. I., Feb. 17 (AP)  Witchtown registered his fourth consecutive victory today in taking the $7,500 America Handicap before a crowd of 7,537 at Lincoln Downs. He returned $12 for $2 after running the seven furlongs in 1:28.

title: WILLIAM. DEKNATEL, CHICAGO ARCHITECT
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 17William Ferguson Deknatel, an architect and city planner, died yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
New Political Front Is Formed by Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 17  The Government announced today the formation of a national political body to oppose the National Liberation Front in the coining political struggle in South Vietnam.

title: Water Studies Roil East End Officials
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. Eight months before Suffolk County proposed a comprehensive study of the water resources of the South Fork that would cost close to $1million, the United StatesGeological Survey offered to do a comparable job for $300,000.

title: Artie Shaw at 62: Still the Romantic
description: Happiness, I've found, isn't a state you arrive in, like Rhode Island or Verniont.Artie Shaw

title: Goodall and chimpanzees at Yale
description: The large auditorium of Yale's Sterling Law School was darkened; a film on chimpanzee behavior in the wild was in progress. Off to one side of the movie screen, her fair hair and green dress illumined by the glow, the noted animal behavorist Jane Goodall narrated: Of course we do know that the chimpanzee is man's nearest living relative, that anatomically and biochemically he resembles us more closely than does any other primate species. We know that the circuitry of his brain is remarkably similar to that of our brains. And yet, she observed, her voice quiet, her accent proper and very much that of the English girls' boarding school, when one views the very striking similarities between certain chimp and human behaviors, one simply is astonished. There is something rather funny about it; it seems like caricature. One has the feeling that one is looking, not so much at animals living in their natural habitatone is looking at one's longlost cousins.

title: Eastern Hockey League
description: FRIDAY NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Anyone for Scottish Haggis?
description: KEARNY The Cameron brothers, Bill and Frank, estimate that about 60 per cent of Kearny's population consists of first and secondgeneration Scottish and Irish.

title: Village Community Board Votes Again to Oust DogRun to Build a Play Area
description: A Greenwich Village comminity board refused once more last week to allow a novel comanunityoperated dogrun to continue to operate on a vacant rubblestrewn lot on West Houston Street.

title: U.S. Modifying Passaic FloodPlain Plan
description: The Army Corps of Engineers, which last year unveiled a controversial $750million plan to control floods and develop water resources on the Passaic River, is modifying its proposal as a result of local criticism.

title: Researchers Urge Nation to Cut Use of Raw Materials
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) A report from researchers and businessmen says the United States must reduce its consumption of certain raw materials and help avert a global crisis in natural resources.

title: U.S. Airman Killed in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (UPI) The first American, serviceman has been listed by the Pentagon as killed in action in Laos since the Vietnam ceasefirewhich does not cover Laoswent into effect three weeks ago. He was First Lieut. Robert E. Bernhardt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry A. Bernhatdt of Richmond, Va., an Air. Force crewman in an EC47 electronic intelligence plane shot down Feb. 5 in southern Laos. Seven other crew members are missing.

title: Immigrant Families Are Being Taught at Home
description: Teachers from John Jay High School in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn are leaving their classrooms and are going into homes in the area to teach reading not only to the schoolage children, but also to the whole family.

title: U.S. Killer Reported Hired In a Plot Against Marcos
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines, believes that last fall, shortly before he imposed martial law, he was the target of a rightwing assassination plot involving a hired killer from the United. States, according to information supplied to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: Admiral Hadden to Retire
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., Feb. 17 (AP)Rear Adm. Mayo A. Hadden Jr., commander of fleet air wings of the United States Atlantic Fleet, announced yesterday that he would retire from he Navy on July 1.

title: Mr. Nixon's Reforms
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Senator George McGovern based his disastrous Presidential campaign on the assumption that the American people were ready for radical reform, and now President Nixon seems to be interpreting his spectacular victory as a mandate for dramatic conservative reform.

title: Evans Leads Connecticut To Yankee Track Crown
description: DURHAM, N. H., Feb., 17 (AP)Ron Evans, the Natinal Collegiate decathlon champion, won three events in leading Connecticut to victory in the 10th annual Yankee Conference indoor track meet today.

title: The Theater: A Look at the Fifties Evokes an Era
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17AI Carmines's new musical, which has just opened at the Washington Arena. Stage, is set very precisely and carefully in 1956. But it is the 1956 of President Dwight D. Eisenhower rather than of Elvis Presley. It is called A Look at the Fiftes, and, much more than Grease or any of the other recent nostalgic evocations, it does suecoed in evoking a time and a place. It was a time for innocenceperhaps the last time.

title: A 72 Slowdown In Renovations That Require Eviction Reported
description: The gut rehab business' appears to have slowed In the city last year.

title: W. J. Heron Jr. Weds Toni. Tornai
description: GLEN ROCK, N. J., Feb. 17 In St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Toni Tomei, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James V. Tomei Jr. of Ridgewood, became the bride of William Julian Heron Jr. Ho is the son of Mrs. Stephen Corrigall of Estepona, Spain, and Mr. Heron of Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: Anne Kennedy Is Wed
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 17 Miss Anne Bernadette Kennedy was married here this evening to Joseph A. Gargano Jr. The Rev. Blaise Gintoli performed the ceremony in the Our Lady of the Assumption Roman Catholic Church. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Kennedy of Fairfield. Mr. and Mrs. Gargano of Trumbull are the parents of the bridegroom. The bride's grandfather, the late Martin J. Kennedy of New York, served as a Democrat State Senator and member of the United States House of Representatives.

title: Susan's Girl Gives Pincay 5th of 6 Winners on Coast
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 17 (AP)Laff it Pincay Jr. scored his fifth triumph of the afternoon today by winning the $55,400 Santa Maria Handicap aboard Susan's Girl.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: LADY CAROLINE LAMB, directed and written by Robert Bolt and starring Sarah Miles, Jon Finch and Richard Chamberlain, got 3 favorable reviews (Wanda Hale, News; Rex Reed, News; Arthur Knight, Saturday Review), 5 mixed (Archer Winsten, Post; Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Paul D. Zimmerman, Newsweek) and 8 negative (Roger Greenspun, Times; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Jeffrey Lyons, WPIXTV; John Simon, New Leader; Judith Crist, New York; Pauline Kael, New Yorker; William Wolf, Cue; Time).

title: High Schools Add A Course in Jazz
description: VERONA  An extraordinary program of instruction in jazz improvisation will begin tomorrow in 36 New Jersey high schools. The threemonth program, which will involve four wellknown jazz musicians as instructors, 500 students and a music teacher from each of the 36 schools, is being funded by the National Endowment for the Arts and the New Jersey Council on the Arts.

title: Employes Bitter Over Schlitz Closing in Brooklyn
description: Schlitz, the beer that made Milwaukee famous, is leaving a bitter taste in the mouths of more than 300 workers who will be laid off when the company closes its Brooklyn plant next month.

title: Nixon Signs Highway Bill
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 17 (UPI)President Nixon signed into law today a bill extending the life of the Commission on Highway Beautification until Dec. 31. The legislation provides an authorization for $250,000 to continue the study of implementation of the Highway Beautification Act of 1965.

title: The Growth of Lessness
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 17Ecstasies of diminishment are suddenly the Washington commonplace. Headlines toll the daily shrinkage with that toneless unmusicality which would make the Second Coming sound humdrum.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Cameras, television sets, radios, automobiles, motorcycles and textile goods have long marked the substantial  and by now familiar presence of Japanese manufacturers in United States consumer markets.

title: An Assemblyman As a Prosecutor
description: ALBANYIt was Jan. 3, the opening day of the Legislature, and Governor Rockefeller had just started a joint meeting of the Senate and the Assembly by telling them he wanted mandatory life sentences for narcotics pushers with no chance for plea bargaining or for parole.

title: Careful, devastating, enjoyable, witty, illuminating, Pauline Kael should write a book
description: RIGHT now, movie criticism in America seems livelier, more pungent than literary criticism. People who read any sort of criticism at all are more likely to care about Pauline Kael's opinion of a movie than what anyone in these pages says about a book; movies have recently carried a sharper air of excitement than have books; and some people have begun to develop, or fumble toward, a film esthetic.

description: Tickets for the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 17  Five minutes after the match begins, the two players are soaked in sweat.

title: SAIGON'S FORCES RECEIVE ORDERS TO STOP FIGHTING
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Feb., 18  A Saigon military spokesman said yesterday that Government troops had been ordered to stop fighting in compliance with an urgent appeal issued earlier in the day by the FourParty Joint Military Commission.

title: Auto Pollution
description: DETROITIn the fall of 1971 and the spring of 1972, Ford Motor Company engineers were testing engines for 1973 cars to see if they could meet the standards of the Federal Clean Air Act. The standards were tough and some of the engineers had a Better Idea about how to pass them: They tampered with the engines and didn't report the changes to the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: DR. WALLACE CAKE, RUBBER CHEMIST, 76
description: Dr. Wallace E. Cake, who retired in 1962 as vice president in charge of research and development of the United States Rubber Company, now Uniroyal, Inc., died Friday night in the Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Cervantes
description: The Man and the Genius. By Francisco Navarro Ledesma. Translated and Revised by Don and Gabriela Bliss. 294 pp. New York: Charterhouse Books. $9.95.

title: Catholics Number 659 Million, Says Vatican Yearbook
description: VATICAN CITY, Feb. 17 (UPI)The Vatican's new statistical yearbook, on sale today, estimates that there are 659 million Roman Catholics in the world.

title: THE COLDEST DAY OF WINTER CHILLS CITY TO 7 DEGREES
description: The coldest weather of the winter.  a nosereddening, cheeknumbing 7 degrees at midmorning  clasped the metropolitan area in an Arctic embrace yesterday.

title: NONSMOKERS GET CAR PREMIUM CUT
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 17 The Farmers Insurance Company, Inc., has been authorized by the Iowa Insurance Depart ment to offer reduced auto in surance rates to nonsmoking lowans.

title: The House That Jean Built...
description: JEAN KERR'S Finishing Touches is an entirely affable and, in its own way, a thoroughly honest comedy.

description: A baffling maze of conduits, wires, cables and other utility equipment has been slowing work crews excavating for the first section of the Second Avenue Subway, between 98th and 105th Streets.

title: ALBERT C. YORK
description: Capt. Albert C. York of the Merchant Marine, retired, who was decorated for his service in the Dunkirk invasion and in the Pacific in World War II, died Friday in Columbus Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at. 201 East 19th Streets.

title: Old Bank Reports Call Young Truman Bright
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 17 (UPI)Harry S. Truman, at the age of 19 years, was ranked as an exceptionally bright young man who might have made a good career in banking if he had not decided to change professions, old bank records show.

title: FRED BOHEN, 77, HEAD OF A MAGAZINE FIRM
description: DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 17Fred Bohen, board chairman of the Meredith Corporation, which publishes Better Homes and Gardens and other magazines, died today in Good Samaritan Hospital, Phoenix, Ariz., after a long illness. He was 77 years old.

title: Barbara Roggen to Wed
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., Feb. 17Mr. and Mrs. Harold Roggen have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Lynn Roggen, to William Karetny, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Karetny of Manhasset Hills. Miss Roggen and her fianc attend New York University.

title: Rosemary Keough Is Married To Paul J. Redmond in Boston
description: BOSTON, Feb. 17  Miss Rosemary Keough, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Keough of Aldan, Pa., and Ocean City, N.J., was married here this evening to Paul Joseph Redmond, son of Mrs. Ambrose J. Redmond of Belmont and the late Mr. Redmond. The Rev. Earl Heywood of the Wesley United Methodist Church in Medford performed the ceremony in the Massachusetts Room of the Harvard Club. The Rev. James Kenney, a Roman Catholic priest, gave the blessing.

title: 30CenturyOld Village Found in Southern Italy
description: FOGGIA, Italy, Feb.17 (AP  Archeologists excavating in an area near this southern Italian city have unearthed parts of a village dating from the Iron Age.

title: Miss Rothamel Engaged to K. C. Fichter
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., Feb. 17Miss Margaret. Jean Rothamel and Kenneth Charles Fitcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Fichter of Tenafly, N. J., plan to be married on June 23 in the chapel at Fort Hamilton in Brooklyn.

title: FOUR BODIES FOUD IN LEANTO ON COAST
description: FELTON, Calif, Feb. 17 (UPI) Sheriff's deputies found the bodies of four men today inside a crudely fashionedleantoshelter off Highway 9 in a forested area where a series of multiple killings have occurred.

title: Atlantic in Peril
description: The great gray Atlantic, so majestic and powerful its fury, so awesome in its sweep, is sickening and dying. Its enemies are dirty thick clumps of petroleum waste, indissoluble plastic, and deadly chemicals.

title: A Slowing of Mail Delivery Conceded by Postal Chief
description: A letter deposited last month at the Grand Central Post Office got to Carol Brownell15 blocks away11 days later. In Greenwich, Conn., Edward W. Barrett received two letters one recent dayone letter 12 days en route from Columbia University in Manhattan, the other 12 days from Peking.

title: Chapin Picks Nix Who's Nix?
description: A GOOD many people are involved in Opera at the Forum, whose inaugural season is discussed at length elsewhere on this page. Yet under the guidance of the Met's acting general manager, Schuyler G. Chapin, it is administered by only three people: Richard Dufallo, principal conductor and artistic adviser; William Nix, special administrative coordinator, and Carmen Kovens, his assistant. As performer and spokesman, Dufallo is a wellknown quantity, but a lot of people might ask, Who is Nix?

title: We Sought a Vacation Hideaway in Paris And Found Apartments Start at Small And Become Smaller
description: Last spring my wife and I purchased a pied  terre in Paris. The total living space is approximately 17 square meters about the equivalent of a 9 by 12 rug but there is compensation in the fact that we are around the corner from the beautiful Champ de Mars and only a few blocks from the Eiffel Tower.

title: Abortion
description: Since the establishment of American Roman Catholic Hierarcl in 1789, the bishops have been virtu apostles of respect for civil lai Thus, the action the bishops took abortion last week was without pre edent in American Catholic history.

title: Pub Turned Into a Vineyard
description: Folksong, wine and cheese, a proper plebian parlay, have been used to turn a failing steak pub into a flourishing wine and cheese pub in the Sheepshed Bay area of Brooklyn.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE DOLLAR WAS DEVALUED by 10 per cent against major currencies. The Japanese yen, now floating, was up about 16 per cent against the dollar.... Reaction was generally favorable to the second devaluation of the dollar in 14 months.

title: Coach Hit in Hammer Throw

title: Family Roots Grow Through a Train Window

Slowly I make my way along the streets, fighting a fierce wind and a chilling downpour. A staggering dizziness plagues me a dizziness brought oh by insomnia and the previous day's flight from New York that passed through too many time zones. Although my shoes are filling with water, I am otherwise wellprotected by a workingclass cap pulled tight, an extra shirt and even an extra coat. My Bowery, best.

title: Paul Goodman, Outsider Looking In
description: The time Paul Goodman died at 60 last August, he had moved through what for most people would have been several careers: poet, novelist, urban planner, psychotherapist, social, literary and educational critic. As he noted many times himself, specialists in each of the fields he touched complained that he spread himself too thin. But almost everything he did was worth attending to, and his career has the coherence of a life lived both passionately and intelligently. He trained himself to live as an outsider looking in, and apparently he could not be seduced by the kinds of rewards his talents might have earned him though his moving journal, Five Years (1966), makes clear how deeply he longed for an audience. But even after the success of Growing Up Absurd in 1960, when he began to seem a kind of guru for the young who were dropping out or turning left, he retained his power both to be engaged and to criticize. And in the years just before his death, he was describing himself as a neolithic conservative, almost as if to ensure that he might remain outside all parties.

title: Delicious conversation piece
description: Mostly, chickens are stuffed in their cavities. This more dramatic Mediterranean method, taught in Viviana Schetky's local cooking school, involves a spinach and cheese stuffing that goes under the skin of the breast. The result is a very buxom bird with unusually moist white meat. The stuffing protects the bird where it is most vulnerable to drying out from oven heat. This recipe was used originally with chickens that still had their necks attached. Such chickens are available at live poultry markets in the city. But aluminum foil or bread will seal in the stuffing just as well. The only difficult part of the job is creating a pouch of loose skin across the breast. This is not nearly so troublesome as it may seem at first glance. The method is ingenious and requires no elaborate boning. All you do, really, is to snip out the backbone with poultry scissors in order to make it possible to flatten the whole chicken slightly and pull the breast skin away from the meat to make a capacious pouch, open at the neck end and naturally sealed at the other end by the skin adhering to the legs. It doesn't even matter if you make a hole or two in the skin while stuffing. These can be easily sealed off. The various herbs add a vigorous Provencal taste. And when you serve the chicken, it will look as though you had perfected an abstruse technique.

Well, RCA has deemed these oftplayed, scores worthy of fresh versions, both performed by the Philadelphia Orchestra under Eugene Ormandy with Artur Rubinstein as soloist in the concerto. title: A Shot in the Arm for Realism?
description: IN this season of realist revival, Jack Beal's current show at the Allan Frumkin Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, must be judged something of a bombshell. Here is revival with a vengeance. There are only three new paintings in the show, along with several pastel and charcoal drawings, but its spectacular skill and ambitiousness have an impact that Is dimly and rather stunning. And this would be true if the show comprised a single canvas  Beal's new version of the Danae myth. I hesitate to call his Dame a masterpiece only because it seems so obviously calculated to be one; its grandiosity awakens a resistance that its beauties do not immediately overcome. But it is, at the very least, a remarkable painting.

title: Doings in Earthsea
description: LAKE said that the making of a flower was the labor of ages. The writing of new myths for children runs it a close second. It is easy enough to provide tired or unoriginal stuff, of course, and we see it on every side; but to create something of sufficient imaginative strength to touch those archetypal depths where children feel at home, while maintaining a narrative simplicity which young minds will be able to follow, is not easy.

title: Immunity
description: When she was three years old, Tomi Willis's right arm was ripped off by a bear at High Point State Park, New Jersey. Her parents sued the state for not taking proper precautions to protect visitors to the zooand found themselves bucking the, doctrine of sovereign immunity, a legal concept, that dates back to early English law. It decrees that the state, as sovereign, cannot be sued for damages without its consent. The only recourse: a private bill passed by the Legislature to recompense an injured citizen.

title: Fun in Sun, Baseball or No Baseball

title: Numismatics
