description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 18Yale scored three goals in the third period last night and defeated Princeon, 52, in hockey, avenging a 42 loss to the Tigers 10 days earlier.

title: ELWOOD MOFFET, 64, A UNION LEADER, DIES
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP)Elwood Stewart Moffett, who took his 180,000member District 50, Allied and Technical Workers union out of the independent United Mine Workers and later joined it with the United Steel Workers, A.F.L.C.I.O., died here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Hunter Five Beats Queens In Conference Game, 6861
description: Hunter College knocked Queens out of a fourway tie for first place in the Knickerbocker Conference by posting a 6861 basketball victory over the Knights yesterday. John Bradley was high scorer for the Hawks with 20 points. Darney Gripper led Queens with 16.

description: DEVENTER, The Nether lands, Feb. 18 (AP)  ?? Claesson of Sweden won thr 1973 world speed skating championship today with a victory in the 10,000meter race and a sixthplace finish in the 1,500.

title: Gunman in Belfast Kills Two Mailmen In Catholic Section
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 18Two mailmen were killed today and another injured by a gunman in the Roman Catholic Falls district of Belfast.

description: POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18 (UPI)Sandra Palmer sank a fivefoot putt for a birdie on the first hole in a playoff and defeated Betty Burfeindt in the $35,000 Pompano Beach golf tournament today.

title: Ali to Fight Dutchman
description: ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Rudi Lubbers, the Dutch heavyweight boxing champion, is to fight the former world titleholder, Muhammad Ali, in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta in May,. Lubbers's manager, Henk Ruhling, said tonight. Ruhling said the contract would be signed Tuesday in the presence of representatives of the Indonesian government and the Asian Boxing Board.

description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 18  Twenty American prisoners of war arrived here tonight from Hanoi, looking healthy, saluting the flag, and waving and smiling at a crowd of more than thousand wellwishers.

title: U.S. FINDS FEWER HOME IN DAYTIME
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18People don't stay home as much any more, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Swiss Take World 4Man Bobsled Title
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 18  A recordbreaking plunge in this morning's third heat, during which Rene Stadler reached speeds in excess of 80 miles an hour, set up victory for Switzerland today in the world fourman bobsledding championship.

title: Average Cost of a Year At Princeton Is $5,400
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 The average undergraduate at Princeton University will pay $5,400 for his education in the 197374 school year, an increase of $300 over 197273,

title: Norwegian Skiing Victor
description: SYRACUSE, Feb. 18 (AP)Two members of Norway's Olympic silver  medal crosscountry skiing relay team, Oddvar Braa and Maple Myrao, finished first and second, respectively, today in the final race of the Samsonite Nordic series. Braa won the 10kilometer (about 6.2 miles) race in 33 minutes 44 seconds. Mike Gallagher of Killington, Vt., was third.

title: Striking Teachers in St. Louis Vote to Accept Raise of $1,000
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 18 (UPI)Striking teachers voted today to accept a proposed contract agreement calling for a $1,000 salary increase over the next 18 months, apparently ending a strike that had kept 103,000 students out of classes since Jan. 24.

title: Murray the K, Rock n Roll D.J., Presents a Blast From the Past
description: Murray Kaufman is a survivor of 20 years working in the rough, highcasualty area, of rock n roll radio where he is known respeitfully as Murray the K. And Mr. Kaufman celebrated those two decides on Friday night, when be introduced, extolled and generally kept moving The Murray the K Show at the Academy of Music on East 14th Street.

title: Paris: Behind the Scenes at Louvre
description: PARISThey may be partners now, but their policies are still an ocean apart. While the Metropolitan Museum has been deaccessioning and demoting on a scale reminiscent of medieval mass confessions, the Louvre has been quietly accessioning and promoting. The most spectacular of its recent acquisitions was the portrait of Monsieur De Julienne by Watteau, purchased a few hours before it was to go on public auction. The sitter's identity is doubtful, but the painter's is sure: The Louvre now owns the only known portrait by the Mozart of painting. Perhaps this triumph will console its curators for the trouble they got into by promoting Olympos et Marsyas. They had bought the picture, a year ago, at a public auction. Described by the auctioneer's expert as School of Caracci and sold for an accordingly low price, it was promptly hailed and displayed by the Louvre's specialists as a genuine  and therefore highly valuable  Poussin. Estimating that he had been deceived, the former owner of Olympos sued, asking that the sale be voided. He has just won his case. The Louvre is appealing. Should the decision be maintained, it is likely to make the study of works of art whose attribution poses problems an extremely risky enterprise.

title: Urgent Conferences Set On GasTank Regulations
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18  Assemblyman John J. Fay Jr. has scheduled urgent meetings this week with state environmental officials and leaders in the Legislature on his proposed legislation to regulate the construction of tanks for storing liquefied natural gas and combinations of natural and synthetic gas.

title: Washington Farewell Echoes in Congress
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A Presidential message warning of real despotism if one branch of the Federal Government assumes the powers of another, cautioning against an overgrown military establishment and recommending a stop to alliances with other nations will be read to Congress tomorrow.

title: Miss Farber Has Nuptials
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 18Miss Laura Ann Farber, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Farber of Upper Nyack, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Peter Allen Segall. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mac Segall of Freeport, L.I.

title: Advertising: 2 Airlines Differ on Spending
description: United Air Lines and Trans World Airlines, both of which have advertising budgets of more than $20million for 1973, have very different ideas about where to spend it.

title: Parade Today
description: A parade by the Knights of Columbus marking George Washington's birthday is to begin today at 9:45 A.M. at 35th Street and Fifth Avenue and go up the avenue to St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: Imagery Abounds in Nikolais's Grotto
description: Alwin Nikolais, who has just staged an electronic spectacle at the Hamburg Opera House in Germany, is not neglecting the folks back home. Saturday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, he gave us the premiere of Grotto, by his own Nikolais Dance Theater, which is sharing the program with the Murray Louis Dance Theater.

title: U.S. and Soviet Scientists Exchange Studies on Space
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 18 (AP)American and Soviet scientists have exchanged results of studies on the use of space for peaceful purposes, a joint statement reported today.

title: Mrs. Marion Hays Potter; Aided Humanitarian Causes
description: GREENWICH, Conn., Fed. 18 Mrs. Marion Hays Potter, a writer and founder of the Greenwich Committee for the United Nations, who had been active in nany humanitarian causes, diets yesterday at her home here. She was 82 years old and had also lived in West Townshend, Vt.

description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: London Orchestra to China
description: PEKING, Feb. 18The London Philharmonic Orchestra will give five concerts in Peking, Canton and Shanghai between March 17 and 26, an informed source said today. The visit is regarded as a major cultural breakthrough because Western classical music has not been performed in China since the Cultural Revolution began in 1966.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Heat returned yesterday to more than 800 homes in Washington Township and surrounding Gloucester County communities after a breakdown of electric and gas lines left the homes heatless for most of Saturday.

title: Paris Police Ban Conference Of U.S. Exiles for Amnesty
description: PARIS, Feb. 18  The Paris police have banned a conference of a group called Exiles for Amnesty scheduled here Tuesday and Wednesday by American war resisters.

title: CYPRUS ECONOMY GAINS VIGOROUSLY
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Feb. 13Despite 13 years of intercommunal strife, this sunny eastern Mediterranean island's economy is prospering, particularly for the Greek majority.

description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 (AP)Norman D. Tilles, the national commander of the Jewish War Veterans, has suggested that President Nixon appoint a commission to consider amnesty for draft evaders.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Feb. 19.  The recent upsurge in fighting showed no signs of abating yesterday despite an urgent appeal by the FourParty Joint Military Commission for an immediate end to hostilities.

description: CLAREMONT, Calif., Feb. 18Hard on the heels of the latest international monetary crisis, some of the world's leading economists met here this week to try to figure out how to reform the world monetary system to make it less crisisprone and more durable.

title: BOBBY GORDON
description: Bobby Gordon, a vaudeville actor in the dance team of Gordon, Reed and King in the nineteentwenties and thirties and more recently a comedy and travel writer, died Saturday at his apartment in the Great Northern Hotel. He was 69 years old.

title: A False Middle Way
description: In his brief radio address on Tuesday and again, in the more detailed message he sent to Congress, President Nixon made this astonishing assertion: I can report that America is well on the way to winning the war against environmental degradation; well on the way to making our peace with nature.

title: Careerist
description: Lin Piao was a traitor, said a highranking official to me in Peking. He spoke with rare vehemence. Lin Piao plotted against Chairman Mao's life; he was exposed and fled. He died in the accidental crash of his plane. The manner of Lin Piao's death was cited as at once his own indictment, the evidence and the sentence for his crimes.

title: Plotter
description: STANFORD, Calif.In August, 1972, Chiang Ch'ing, leader of the revolutionization of the performing arts in China, member of the Central Committee of the Political Bureau of the Communist party, and wife of Mao Tsetung, spoke to me for some sixty hours.

description: ROME, Feb. 18Last fall Thomas P. F. Hoving, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, announced the acquisition of a 2,500yearold Greek vase signed by its creators, the painter Euphronios and the potter Euxitheos, that he said was of such high quality that the histories of art will have to be rewritten.

title: Charles S. Mott, Who Helped Shape G M., Dies at 97
description: FLINT, Mich., Feb. 18 (AP) Charles Stewart Mott, who helped guide the General Motors Corporation to its place as the world's largest industrial organization, died early today at St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 97 years old.

title: REPORT SHOWS G.I.'S FIND ARMY RACISM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (UPI) A recent Pentagonfunded study shows that both black and white soldiers tend increasingly to believe as they go through Army training that the other race Is getting favored treatment.

title: West Indies Battles Back
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Rohan Kanai's 60 and a 69 not out from Maurice Foster raised the West Indies to 300 runs for four wickets before rain stopped play on the third day of the first test against Australia today, Jamaica needs only 128 runs to reach Australia's firstinnings total of 428 for seven declared.

title: A Potpourri of Antiques Puts Nostalgia in Garden
description: A law passed a few years ago gave antique status to objects 100 years old and more. This created some disdain among purists and still does, but, under the edict, there are thousands of antiques at the National Antiques Show now in progress at Madison Square Garden. Or near antiques.

title: Japan Air Lines Flying High on National Loyalty
description: TOKYOJapan Air Lines, perhaps more than any other national flag carrier, plays on its nationality to distinguish it from other airlines. In its advertising abroad, it emphasizes the mystery of the Orient and asserts that the passenger is in Japan as soon as he steps aboard a J.A.L. airliner.

title: FULBRIGHT FAVORS INDIRECT HANOI AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that he would support President Nixon's proposal to rebuild North Vietnam if the President would agree to cut back on military spending abroad.

title: An Ebb in U.S.Japanese Relations
description: TOKYO, Feb. 18  When Henry A. Kissinger arrives here tomorrow to meet with Premier Kakuei Tanaka, he will find American relations with Japan at their lowest point 1960, when riots forced Tokyo to cancel a visit by President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: S.I. BLAST IS LAID TO TRAPPED GAS
description: Fire Chief John T. O'Hagan said yesterday that natural gas entrapped somewhere behind the polyurethane liningignited by fire was probably the cause of the explosion in the liquefied gas storage tank in Staten Island that took 40 lives last week.

title: 120MILLION PLANT SET IN YUGOSLAVIA
description: A $120million nuclear power plant is expected to be built in Yugoslavia by American interests, according to Jakov Sirotkovic, a Yugoslavian Deputy Premier. He said that proposals by the General Electric Company and the Westinghouse Corporation were under active consideration.

title: Student Sends to the Neediest The Holiday Money Given Him
description: A student at Amherst College in Massachusetts summed up the philosophy of The Newt York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the other day when he contributed $75 in the hope that someone, somewhere will be a little happier and a little more comfortable.

title: Dickson Wins by 3 Shots In Golf as 4 Tie for 2d
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 18. (UPI) Bob Dickson, former United States and British amateur champion, won his second pro golf title in five years today, beating Bruce Crampton in duel for the top prize in the $170,000 Andy Williams  San Diego open. The margin was three strokes.

title: Head of CrimeData Bank Reassigned in State Shift
description: ALBANY, Feb. 18  The New York City police official and crimedata ekpert who developed and ran the state's computerized criminal identification system here for all of its eight years has been quietly reassigned amid a major reorganization of the state's criminal justice agencies.

title: Holiday Inns Lifts Profit
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 16Holiday Inn, Inc., reported today revenues of $775.21million for the year ended Dec. 29, 1972, up from $707.88million for 1971. Operating profits before taxes amounted to $78.1million in 1972 compared with $73.64million in 1971. Operating earnings per share rose to $1.38 in 1972 from $1.36 in 1971.

title: Sandman Sees a Disaster In Cahill's Renomination
description: TRENTON, Feb. 18Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. charged today that the renomination of Governor Cahill would destroy the Republican party in New Jersey and assure its loss of both houses of the State Legislature to the Democrats in the November election.

title: Editor Urges Shield Law, Calls for Government Noninterference
description: An editor who said his newspaper opposed privileges for newspapers, such as mail subsidies and antitrust and wagepricecontrol exemptions, said yesterday that he had been driven to believe in the need of a Federal shield law to protect newsmen's confidential sources.

title: Leave It to Beaver Takes Hunter Title At Show in Weston
description: WESTON, Conn., Feb. 18Jessica Fleischmann's Leave It to Beaver made his first start and won the regular working hunter championship today at the Nimrod Farms horse show.

title: U.S. Calls On Truce Commission To Investigate Loss of Copter
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 18The head of the American delegation to the FourParty Joint Military Commission today asked the International Commission of Control and Supervision to investigate an incident last week in which an American helicopter was shot down and five crewmen were injured.

title: Soviet Economic Report
description: The Soviet economic report for last year shows an even more lackluster performance than had originally been suggested. It was hardly a secret that Soviet agriculture suffered a debacle and that the goal for growth of national income had been missed by a wide margin. What the new report added to this gloomy record was that industry as well as agriculture suffered malaise last year. Not only did industrial output fail to reach its growth target, but there was a shortfall in the expected increase of labor productivity Production of some key consumer goods lagged, and much that was turned out was of poor quality and not varied: enough to satisfy consumer taste. Mr. Brezhnev's dream of saturating the market with consumer goods appears far from realization.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: COSSUTTA SHINES IN NORMA AT MET
description: Carlo Cossutta had been scheduled to make his debut at the Metropolitan Opera last Monday night, as Pollione in the season's first Norma. Illness prevented that, however, and his actual debut came Saturday afternoon, in the same role.

title: BRUBECK FAMILY IN JAZZ CONCERT
description: There was such a proliferation of Brubecks on stage at Philharmonic Hall on Friday evening that the program's title, Two Generations of Brubeck, sometimes seemed like an underestimate. On hand were Dave Brubeck, the founding father, and three of his sons (Darius, Chris and Danny); three Brubeckled groups (Dave's, Darius's and Chris's), and key figures in two generations of the Dave Brubeck QuartetPaul Desmond, the saxophonist in the original quartet, and Gerry Mulligan, saxophonist in the current quartet.

title: Planning Changeover
description: With Donald H. Elliott leaving as chairman of the City Planning Commission and John E. Zuccotti taking over the job, the changed role of the Planning Commission and Department comes sharply into focus. Mr. Elliott has shepherded the agency through six crucial years during which it has become a pivotal factor in the city's future. Planning standards have been raised and plan, ping power increased, and a determination demonstrated to come to grips with the city's longterm development in environmental terms.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Officials in Ocean Township, N. J., reported the second fish kill in three clays in Oyster Creek yesterday, and said they would bring complaints against a nearby nuclear generating plant to the State Legislature.

title: NIEDERHOFFER GAINS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18Vic Niederhoffer, the defending titleholder from New York, and the Rev. Bob Hetherington of Buffalo won two matches apiece in reaching the final of the 62d United States squash racquets championship today in Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium. They meet tomorrow at 11 A.M.

title: U.S. to Dispose of Huge Medical Supplies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18The Federal Government is planning, to get rid of more than $100million worth of medical equipment and supplies, enough to put into trornediate operation 800 or more fullsized emergency hospitals.

title: Waldheim Back From Asia
description: Secretary General Waldheim of the United Nations returned here yesterday from a twoandahalfweek trip to Asia where he conferred with official of halfadozen countries. At Kennedy Airport, Mr. Waldheim said that the highlight of his trip was a dicussion of the IndianPakistani situation, and that he was cautiously optimistic about a resolution of the differences between the countries.

title: Ali to Fight Dutchman
description: ROTTERDAM, The Netherlands, Feb. 18 (Reuters)Rudi Lubbers, the Dutch heavyweight boxing champion, is to fight the former world titleholder, Muhammad Ali, in the Indonesian capital of Jakarta in May, Lubbers's manager, Henk Ruhling, said tonight. Ruhling said the contract would be signed Tuesday in the presence of representatives of the Indonesian government and the Asian Boxing Board.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: CRANFORD, N. J., Feb. 18Everything was rosy at Union College until Jan. 17. The school's basketball team had won nine of its 10 games and an invitation to the state tournament was a possibility. But then the roof fell in.

title: Amer. Hockey League
description: SATURDAY'S GAMES

title: Sports News Briefs
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18 (AP)  Graham McRae of New Zealand, his car packed in dry ice to combat temperatures of more than 100 degrees, clinched his third Tasman Cup championship, today by winning the nexttolast race of the eightrace series. McRae, in a fiveliter STP McRae, won the 52lap, 111.36mile race in 55 minutes 32.3 seconds, an average speed of 108.45 miles an hour.

title: Catskill to Hear Proposal For VillageTown Merger
description: CATSKILL N. Y., Feb. 18A proposal to merge the village and town of Catskill to achieve economies in operation and possibily a 50 per cent reduction in taxes for some residents will be presented to the public tomorrow night.

title: New Head of Retailers' Group Urges Forceful Role on Inflation
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 16The new president of the Menswear Retailers of Americathe trade association for the country's 4,000 men's clothing storescalled today for a more assertive role by merchants to combate inflationary increases in the cost of their merchandise.

title: Island Show Attracts 18,087 for Weekend
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 18 More than 18,000 persons, twice the usual number of guests, visited this weekend the Long Island Boat Show, held for the first time in its 16year history at the Nassau Coliseum.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: He Nourishes His Mews With Solitude, And His Guests With Gingerbread Cake
description: AMHERST, Mass.Guests were coming, and a light meal sat on a shelf under the kitchen window. Beyond the window of the tiny white frame cottage, Robert Francis could see the winter woods. Civilized woods, with wide spaces between the trees.

title: Kissinger and Chou Talk for Five Hours
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 18Henry A. Kissinger met for five hours today with Premier Chou Enlai on the fourth day of his visit to Peking, the White House announced here.

title: Catholic Congress Opens in Melbourne
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 18The 40th Eucharistic Congress, a major event of the Roman Catholic world that is held every four years, opened here today.

title: A SkiLift Failure Kills Brooklyn Man And Hurts 2 Others
description: WARWICK, N. Y., Feb. 18One New York City man was killed and another was injured at the Mt. Peter Skiing Center near here this afternoon when the skilift chair they were in broke loose from the lift cable and dropped them 45 feet to the ground.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: Lawyers Call Police Aid Agency Potential Threat to Civil Rights
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18A group of civil rights lawyers has accused the Nixon Administration's principal agency for reducing crime in the streets of fostering a potential threat to civil liberties by encouraging the increased use of sophisticated law enforcement technology in state and local police forces.

title: Break 11 Tie in Last PeriodPark Hurt
description: Playing poorly enough to lose to any club in the National Hockey Leagueexcept the Islandersthe Rangers last night salvaged a 32 decision over their Nassau County rivals.

title: Memos Show New Plans To Narrow U.S. Legal Aid
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Critics produced documentary evidence today that the Nixon Administration was exploring new ways to stamp out controversial aspects of the Federal program of legal aid to the poor.

title: Swiss Take World 4Man Bobsled Title
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 18  A recordbreaking plunge in this morning's third heat, during which Rene Stadler reached speeds in excess of 80 miles an hour, set up victory for Switzerland today in the world fourman bobsledding championship.

title: Official Secrets
description: LONDON, Feb. 18Alan Grimwood, a postal clerk in Chingford, Essex, wrote to the local paper the other day to explain that slow service in the town post office was caused by a shortage of help. When his letter was published, he was accused of violating the Official Secrets Act.

title: Princeton Raising Tuition Again, And It. Sees No End to Increases
description: PRINCETON, Feb. 18Princeton University is raising tuition and room charges for undergraduate and graduate students next fall. And it expects further increases in 1974 and 1975, with no guarantees of holding the line after that.

title: Questions and Answers On Devaluation Arithmetic
description: The arithmetic of devaluation, like acrostic puzzles, is not something that interests everyone. But if a Sony TV is likely to cost more, it may be useful to look at the numbers that tell why. Here are some questions and answers for the mathematically inclined.

title: Biaggi and 5 Other Democrats Seek Queens ReformUnit Vote
description: Representative Mario Biaggi talked to the liberally oriented New Democratic Coalition in Queens yesterday, smiling tightly through a quickly hushed moment of heckling, leaving to polite applause and then standing easily in a nearby corridor to chat with youngsters who seemed somewhat intrigued by this rare plant in a liberal garden.

title: Philadelphia School Typifies Urban Ills
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18Overbrook High School in northwest Philadelphia stands as a monument to the glory days of American public education.

title: Lawsuits Threaten Millionaire Promoter of Pyramid Sales
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18 The world is closing in on William Penn Patrick, a North Carolina farm boy who turned a fertile imagination and a persuasive manner into millions Of dollars.

title: A Convicted Judge
description: Until the verdict was announced in Federal District Court in Chicago yesterday, Otto Kerner had been unusual in the roughandtumble world of Illinois Democratic politicsa product of the Cook County machine whose name had never been touched with scandal. The suave, patricianFederal judge and former Governor had sailed through, a 25year career with some criticism of his aloofness and mild manner but with no word except impeccable for his honesty.

title: Met Remembers Caruso, Whose Voice Few Can Forget
description: It is a name that still brings a flush of excitement to those who heard the voice, more than half a century after his death at the age of 48. Beloved by millions who never heard the voice except on recordings, it is a name that also brings a flash of recognition from many who have not even heard the recordings. Like Babe Ruth, Chaplin or Nijinsky, it is a name that lives and grows in popular mythology.

title: Drug Failures
description: Mayor Lindsay has now formally proposed an altemative to Governor Rockefeller's lawandorder, crackdown response to the state's persistent drug problem. It is, in general, a more moderate, more reasonable and more comprehensive alternative, more likely to win legislative approval and holding greater promise for the achievement of positive results.

title: NETS ROUT CHAPS; TAYLOR IS INJURED
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19The New York Nets checked into the Nassau Coliseum long enough this afternoon to trounce the Dallas Chaparrals, 12899.

title: Opera: Minimet Bows
description: Officially it's named Opera at the Forum, as presented by the Metropolitan Opera. But everybody already is calling it the Minimet, and it came on stream last night at the Forum Theater with two minioperasMaurice Ohana's Syllabaire pour Phdre and Henry Purcell's Dido and Aeneas.

title: Buckley on Amnesty
description: Senator James L. Buckley of New York, seeking to share the publicity being given returning Vietnam P.O.W.'s, toured St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens the other day and used the occasion to issue a pronouncement against the granting of amnesty for draft resisters. To Mr. Buckley, general amnesty would be morally objectionable and historically unprecedented. He is wrong on both counts.

title: POINSETTIA TAKEN BY NOBLE SPLASH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 19  Noble Splash, owned, by Mrs. L. E. Thomas, made history of a sor?? at Hialeah today. Under the direction of John Mallano, Noble Splash won the first running of the Poinsettia Handicap, a seven furlong event for older fillies and mares. The winner, a 5year old mare, carried 108 pounds the lightest in the field of eight and covered the distance in 1:23 4/5.

title: Head of O.E.O. Disputes Study On Community Action by Agency
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19The new head of the Office of Economic Opportunity today disputed the findings of an agency study of the Community Action Program that termed the project highly constructive in meeting Nixon Administration goals.

title: Mrs. Nancy Amory Woodland Is Married to Harris Metcalf
description: SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Feb. 19  Mrs. Nancy Amory Woodland, daughter of Mrs. Harcourt Amory of New York and Southampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Amory, an investment banker, was married here this evening to Harris Metcalf of Providence, R.I. He is the son of Mrs. Ernest T. H. Metcalf of Providence and the late Mr. Metcalf, a stockbroker.

title: Minnesota Tops Illinois, Leads Big 10
description: CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Feb. 19 (AP)Minnesota, sparked by Ron Behagen's gamehigh 26 points, battled hack from a halftime deficit and defeated Illimois 8273, tonight. The victory along with Purdue's defek put the Gophers in first place in the Big Ten Conference.

title: Jules D. Holzberg, Psychologist Who Led Wesleyan Unit, Is Dead
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Feb. 19Prof. Jules D. Holzberg, chairman of the psychology department at Wesleyan University, died of a heart attack last night at his home. He was 57 years old.

title: RENTCURB DRIVES GROW IN SUBURBS
description: The recent lifting of all Federal controls on rents, after a year and a half of price regulation, has brought tenants in many of the metropolitan area's suburbs to a new level of militancy and has intensified political pressures for alternative forms of rent control.

title: British Football Results
description: ENGLISH F.A. CUP Fourth Round (Second Replay)

title: THOMAS H. KOERNER
description: Thomas H. Koerner, a retired principal of Haskins & Sells, international accountants, died Sunday at his home in West Norwalk, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Ambitious plans formulated by the directors of the newly created Striped Bass Fund may result in a muchneeded management and protection program for the species.

title: Houston Space Center Is Named for Johnson
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI)  President Nixon signed into law today a bill designating the Manned Spacecraft Center in Houston as the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Flushing Town Hall, which has been registered as a national landmark, has been endorsed by Donald R. Manes Queens Borough President, as the future home of the MuSewn of Man of the New York Institute of Anthropology, which occupies the building.

title: U.S. COURT TO REAR SUIT ON CONTRACT
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit has ordered a Philadelphia Federal court to hear a civil suit contesting the award of a $78million Government contract for office space.

title: DR. SILAS MOORMAN 2D
description: Dr. Silas Mercer Moorman 2d, associate surgeon at the Medical Arts Center Hospital and an honorary policesurgeon, died Friday of cancer in New York Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 345 East 57th Street. His office was at 157 East 72d Street.

title: Ballet: Pennsylvania Troupe Opens
description: PHILADELPHIAThe new program of the Pennsylvania Ballet, which opened at the Walnut Street Theater last weekend and runs through next Saturday, is not only interesting in itself but also a useful yardstick to the company's recent progress. It consisted of two world premieres and a new production of Benjamin Harkarvy's Madrigalesco, which opened the program.

title: Nixon Sees Food Prices Easing After a Brief Rise
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 President Nixon told union leaders today that rises in food prices would continue for at least several months, then tend to level off, his official spokesman disclosed after the President's private meeting with the leaders.

title: Advertising: Gametime With Flip
description: Flip Wilson is joining the highpriced talent that promotes Aurora toys and games on television.

title: Books of The Times
description: NOBODY EVER DIED OF OLD AGE. By Sharon R. Curtin. 228 pages. Atlantic Monthly. Press  Little, Brown. $6.95.

title: Patrolman Puts Psychology Ph. D. to Use
description: The way Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy tells the story, he was looking at computer printouts about police personnel one day when he came across the name of a patrolman in the Traffic Division with a Ph.D. in psychology.

title: Kutsher's in Catskills Is Damaged by Blaze
description: MONTICELLO, N. Y., Feb. 19Fire destroyed a building containing the nightclub and coffee shop of Kutsher's Country Club, a popular Catskills resort, early this evening.

title: SAIGON REPORTS A SHARP DECLINE IN FIGHTING LEVEL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 20Fighting in South Vietnam declined substantially during the last 24 hours, the Saigon military authorities reported today, leading to the belief that an urgent appeal by the FourParty Joint Military Commission to end all hostilities might be having some effect at last.

title: Pope Calls a Synod of Bishops; '74 Parley May Weigh Celibacy.
description: ROME, Feb. 19The Vatican announced today that Pope Paul VI had decided to convene the Roman Catholic Church's fourth Synod of Bishops in October, 1974, to discuss the evangelization of the contemporary world.

title: WeightWatcher Coach Staying Close to Bruins
description: Does Armand (Bep) Guidolin have a secret for leading the tempestuous Boston Bruins to six victories in the seven games he has coached them? Certainly. Explains Guidolin: I shower with the players. That's where I can watch their weight. The Bruin's have as big a reputation around the National Hockey. League for their stomachs' as their Hoc willingness to fight. After an AllStar game, the Rangers' Brad. Park remarked on showering with half a dozen Bostonians, I've never seen so beer bellies.

title: KISSINGER MEETS JAPAN'S PREMIER
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 20Henry A. Kissinger arrived hen from China yesterday to confer with Premier Kakuei Tanaka about reconstruction in Indo china and policy toward Peking.

title: World Monetary Reform
description: The suddenness and tremendous force of the latest dollar crisis reemphasizes the urgency of reforming the international monetary system. The series of crises that has racked the world since early 1968 has been prevented from shattering world trade and prosperity by number of ingenious moves, but those necessary maneuvers have not begun to reform the basic faults of a monetary system that itself is generating periodic crises. The most basic of these faults is lack of any means of requiring countries running balanceofpayments deficits or surpluses to take the actions necessary to restore equilibrium to their accounts.

title: Ford to Lease Cars in Test Of Antipollution Devices
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) The Ford Motor Company announced today plans for extensive testing of catalytic converter emission control systems on 450 cars leased to three California companies.

title: TAYLOR IS INJURED NETS ROUT CHAPS;
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 19The New York Nets checked into the Nassau Coliseum long enough this afternoon to trounce the Dallas Chaparrals, 12899.

title: A Convicted Judge Otto Kerner
description: Until the verdict was announced in Federal District Court in Chicago yesterday, Otto Kerner had been unusual in the roughandtumble world of Illinois Democratic politicsa product of the Cook County machine whose name had never been touched with scandal. The suave, patrician Federal judge and former Governor had sailed through a 25year career with some criticism of his aloofness and mild manner but with no word except impeccable for his honesty.

title: BODY DISCOVERED OUTSIDE BELFAST
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 19  The body of a man that lay buried under snow for five days was found by British soldiers today at Ligoniel, in the northern suburbs of Belfast.

title: Major Remodeling of National zoo to Begin Soon
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18When the National Zoo is remodeled, the baboon family will cavort in an old rock quarry that was last used by the zoo guards for a firing range, the lions and tiger will lounge on a radiantheated hillside, and Ham, the space chimpanzee, will finally have enough room to invite a mate to move in with him.

title: Telex Charges I.B.M. Impedes Progress in Its Antitrust Action
description: The Telex Corporation charged in a motion filed in Federal District Court in Tulsa that it had information leading it to believe that I.B.M., its agents and attorneys, are engaged in a concerted effort to induce Telex's independent witnesses to refuse to testify and thus impede the progress of pretrial preparation and materially hinder the ability of Telex to present its case at the trial.

title: WILLIAM HODOKINSON JR.
description: William Hodgkinson Jr., who retired in 1965 as a statistician specializing in census studies for the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, died here Sunday. He was 72 yeaks old and lived at 601 East 20th Street.

title: Doubling From 1963 Level Is Expected
description: American business is on the threshold of the first $100billion capital spending spree in history. Corporations are expected to lay out more than twice as much money for new plant and equipment this year as they did a decade ago.

title: Chess: RookandPawn End Games Test Technique and Ingenuity
description: Rookandpawn end games are the bane of the average player. A pawn ahead, he very often can find no way to make it tell; a pawn behind, he may be equally baffled in his search for the saving defense.

title: Colon's 4:03.1 Mile Paces Manhattan to Track Crown
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19 Tony Colon recorded his fastest indoor mile, 4 minutes 3.1 seconds, and Manhattan ran away wtih its third consecutive Metropolitan Intercollegiate track and field title today.

title: Alberta Oil Output Drops
description: CALGARY, Alberta, Feb. 19 (Canadian Press)Liquid petroleum production in Alberta averaged 1,683,934 barrels a day during the week ended Feb. 8, the Alberta Energy Resources Conservation Board said in a report today.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:
description: Tickets matching The numbers win $2,500. Tickets, with the five numbets reverse win $225. Tickets with the first or last four numbers In order win $225. Tickets with the first, middle or last three numbers In sequence win 525. Tickets with all five numbers scrambled win $25. Tickets matching the first and second digits, the second and third, the third and fourth or the fourth and fifth win $2.50.

title: Managing the P.O.W.'s
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 19  The first 163 American prisoners freed by the Communists in. Vietnam have come home to the theme of God bless America, and many officers at this base clearly believe that the returners' conduct has set the stage for restoration of unchallenged patriotism and of the status of the military man to his honored place. If so it will have been no accident but a result of careful military planning.

title: E. W. BOYER
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Feb. 19 (AP)E. W. (Bill) Boyer, vice president of the Minnesota Vikings, died tonight while vacationing in Palm. Springs, Calif. He was 67 years old.

title: The Absolutist
description: WASHINGTONRichard 2d has assumed some of the superficial aspects of a king. The White House today has the air of a court; the President controls the Treasury as though it were a privy purse; and as Commander in Chief his armies wage war at his pleasure. Within four more years the Supreme Court will be dispensing the king's justice. Mr. Nixon does not claim divine right like Shekespeare's Richard 2d (The breath of worldly men cannot dispose, the deputy elected by the Lord) but he makes a similar claim for the deputy elected by the new American majority.

title: Yonkers Youth Found Dead
description: PUTNEY, Vt., Feb. 19 (AP)The body of Daniel Robert Alweis, 18 years old, of Yonkers, was found yesterday near a dormitory at Windham College, where he was a student. The authorities said death was due to exposure and ordered an autopsy although they said there was no indication of foul play.

title: YOUTH DIES, 3 HURT FORT DIX RANGE
description: FORT DIX, N. J., Feb. 19 (UPI)One teenager was killed and three others were injured today in an explosion at a Fort Dix grenade range, officials said.

title: GOAL IS SURPASSED BY BIRD WATCHERS
description: Bird watchers, taking an idea from Wall Street investors, now have their own system for measuring one of the successes of their annual Christmas bird count.

title: Golf's Greats Pause for National Plaudits
description: Champions young and old and a thousand golf fans gathered at the Americana Hotel for the national awards dinner last night to learn more about the game and its personalities. Some of the highlights were:

title: Jamaica Devalues Dollar
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, Feb. 19 (Reuters)The Jamaican Government tonight devalued the Jamaican dollar to retain its parity with the United States dollar. The rate had been fixed earlier this year when Jamaica cut its monetary ties with sterling and linked its currency to the American dollar.

title: 8 Greek Students Get Suspended Terms; Doctor and ExOfficer Tried in Bombings
description: ATHENS, Feb. 19Eight university students who were arrested during a demonstration last Wednesday were sentenced today to 8 to 11 months in prison on charges of having insulted the police.

title: MRS. SIDNEY GREENFELD
description: Mrs. Terry McNellis Greenfeld, a former Democratic committeewoman on the Lower East Side and the wife of Sidney Greenfeld, president of several parking garages, died Sunday in Beth Israel Hospital. She was 45 years old and lived at 457 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive.

title: Weight Watcher Coach Staying Close to Bruins
description: Does Armand (Bep) Guidolin have a secret for leading the tempestuous Boston Bruins to six victories in the seven games he has coached them? Certainly. Explains, Guidolin: I shower with the players. That's where I can watch their weight. The Bruins have as big a reputation around the National Hockey League for their stomachs as their willingness to fight. After an AllStar game, the Rangers' Brad Park remarked on showering with half a dozen Bostonians, I've never seen so beer bellies.

title: RURALAID CUTOFF ASSAILED IN HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) A spokesman for Midwestern farmers and a rural water authority testified today that the Administration's cutoff of rural water and waste disposal grants would impair the quality of life outside the cities.

title: 2 Inquiries Begun
description: ROME, Feb. 19  Italian authorities arc conducting two separate investigations to determine if the 2,500yearold Greek vase acquired last year by New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art was smuggled out of Italy.

title: Youth Found Shot Dead On Stairway in Bronx
description: A 17yearold youth was found shot to death on a stairway landing in a fivestory tenement building at 906 Simpson Street, near 163d Street, in the Morrisania section of the Bronx shortly before last midnight.

title: MOTORCADE ON S.I. HONORS 40 DEAD
description: A 40car motorcade wound through the shopping districts of southern and western shore communities of Staten Island yesterday in a silent memorial to 40 men killed last Saturday in the explosion in liquefied, naturalgas storage tank.

title: CITY LEGAL SETUP STUDIED BY STATE
description: Reinforced with 10 additional staff members, the State Cornmission of Investigation has, begun examining some of the most complex problems of the police, prosecutors and judges of New York City.

title: Garden Flirts for College Crowd
description: Madison Square Garden is expected to make another at tempt to improve sagging college basketball attendance by scheduling some Saturday night doubleheaders next season. Saturday night regular season doubleheaders have not been played in the Garden for more than a decade.

title: U.S. Force in Vietnam At Lowest in a Decade
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 19 (AP)  The United States command announced today the withdrawal of 1,564 more American soldiers from Vietnam, reducing the United States force to 14,180 men, the lowest in a decade.

title: President Plans to Seek Options in Trade Talks
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 President Nixon told a cordially attentive A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council today that he would ask Congress for broad discretionary powers to negotiate a safeguard system of trade agreements in the national interest.

title: Markets Observe Holiday
description: All securities and commodities markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Washington's birthday. Banks in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were also closed.

title: 13 FOOD PLACES FAIL HEALTH INSPECTION
description: The Health Services Administration announced yesterday the names of 13 foodprocessing establishments it said had violated the city's Health Code.

title: Link to Armenians
description: Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan Museum's curator of Greek and Roman art, said yesterday that Robert E. Hecht, who sold and delivered the Euphronios vase to the museum, had acted on behalf of an Armenian collector.

title: Pravda Warns of Ousters in TurnIn of Party Cards, Due Soon, but Says a Major Purge Is Not Planned
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 19The authoritative Communist party daily Pravda today warned the 14.5 million party members that a turnin and replacement or party cards due to begin in 10 days could bring expulsion for anyone guilty of unworthy behavior.

title: Autobiography, Tuqui II Destroyed After Mishaps
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb, 19 (AP)Two accidents on the final turn at Santa Anita today cost the lives of two top handicap horses and caused injuries to Eddie Belmonte, the jtickey, during the $67,000 San Luis' Obispo Handicap.

title: Lord & Taylor's Expands
description: The first of Lord & Taylor's five projected stores in Chicago was opened yesterday in Oakbrook Center outside the city. The 100,000squarefoot, threelevel store will be followed by 1977 by four more stores in the area, one in downtown Chicago and three more in the major suburban shopping malls.

title: Israel Is Quietly Building A Highway on West Bank
description: AQRABA, IsraeliOccupied Jordan, Feb. 19  Israel has quietly begun work on a new highway along the occupied West Bank that could ultimated ly linlc Jerusalem with the upper Jordan Valley.

title: MOYNIHAN ARRIVES IN INDIA AS ENVOY
description: NEW DELHI, Tuesday, Feb. 20Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the new American Ambassador to India, arrived here at dawn saying that the United States and India were linked by a community of interest.

title: Only Few Memorable Moments Enliven Pattern of Tedium at the Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 No matter how important the trial, no matter how many farreaching constitutional issues are buried in its daily thicket of technicalities, a pattern of tedium develops in the courtroom as days of testimony grow into weeks and even perhaps months.

title: Scarsdale in Communes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19In Armed Love (Bantam, $1.25) Elia Katz tours a number of experiments in group living and gives us a picture of commune life that is memorable and sad. If this is the alternative to the bourgeois humdrum of nuclear family life in the birthcontrolled age, what is left for American romantics to pine for? That group joke of so many a trendy youthmarket movie, the affluent family in Scarsdale, seemed merely to be reproducing itself in most of the communes. Popular romance has held the communal urge of the young is revolutionary, promising a shattering of old values and a birth of new ones. Katz's book exposes this feat as empty.

title: Mayor to Join Black Group Fighting Cuts in City Aid
description: ALBANY, Feb. 19Mayor Linhsay told a black audience tonight that he would join a black coalition of state and Federal legislators to fight plans of the Nixon Administration to cut funds for poverty and other programs vital to cities.

title: Link to Armenians
description: Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan Museum's curator of Greek and Roman art, said yesterday that Robert E. Hecht, who sold and delivered the Euphronios vase to the museum, had acted on behalf of an Armenian collector.

title: STOUFFER'S RECALLS FOUR FROZEN FOODS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration and the Stouffer's Food company of Solon, Ohio, jointly announced tonight the recall of four frozen food products that may contain mushrooms with botulism.

title: Adoption Costs Soar as Births Decline
description: Childless New York couples, made desperate by the current shortage of healthy white infants, are turning to the legal but often expensive field of private adoption.

title: MRS. CHELLIS CHASMAN
description: Mr. Dorothy Kohn Chasman, president of the New York School of Mechanical Dentistry, which she and her late husband, Chellis I. Chasman, founded in 1920, died Saturday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She lived at 1100 Park Avenue.

title: Connors, Mayer Lead Advance Of Americans in Indoor Tennis
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 19 (UPI)  All four of America's seeded players advanced in the national indoor open tennis championships today by beating foreign competitors.

title: Primaries Promise Fireworks
description: TRENTON, Feb. 19If the first two months of this gubernatorial and legislative election year are any indication, New Jersey is about to witness primary election that could wrench the state's political fabric and shatter many political traditions.

title: FOOD TALK
description: Turtle soup Is a delicacy in parts of Maryland, Pennsylvania and New Jersey, and the canned soup is readily available in specialty stores. But when it comes to steak  turtle steak  there has been no retail availability for years.

title: Pavarotti Displays Big Lyric Tenor in Recital Debut
description: Luciano Pavarotti is, by any measure, one of the big singers of our day. At 300plus pounds, the Italian tenor makes a strong impression on the eye, and his bright, forward lyric voice fills the ear with immense pleasure, too. His debut recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night also filled the house, and then some. About 150 overflow customers had to be seated onstage.

title: Rabbi and 2 Others to Run For Council in. Manhattan
description: Rabbi Julius G. Neumann, who resigned from the City Commission on Human Rights in 1967 for its alleged neglect of discrimination against Jews, announced yesterday he would seek the Democratic nomination for City Council in the new Third District covering lower Manhattan.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: New Jersey Sports
description: MERCERVILLE, N. J., Feb. 19Howie Landa, the most successful junior college basketball coach in the East over the past decade, sees the junior college program threatened just as it is getting good in the Garden State. Meanwhile, his Mercer County Community College, with a 243 wonlost record, is the envy of many teams around the country.

title: Irish Football Cup
description: By Reuters

title: It's All in the Feet, Bowler Says
description: By 12:30 P.M., the rumble of bowling balls and the clopping of bruised pins had begun drowning the sound of pipedin string music.

title: How Cuts in R.E.A. Subsidy Affect 2 Families in Arkansas
description: BEN HUR, Ark., Feb. 16In the ragged heart of the Ozark Mountains, 80 miles northwest of Little Rock and nine miles from the last blacktop, the settlement of Ben Hur crouches and survives.

title: Body of Ptain Stolen From Island Grave Off France
description: PARIS, Feb. 19An oak coffin containing the body of Marshal Philippe Main, the most controversial figure of 20thcentury France, has been stolen from a tomb on the windblown Ile d'Yeu off the French Atlantic coast, an official investigating group discovered today.

title: 3 Children and Landlord Killed in 2 Newark Fires
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19Fire swept through four Ahreestory residential buildings near Springfield Avenue on the west side of this city at dawn today, killing three young girls in family and making 68 persons homeless.

title: Multimedia Concert At Kitchen Proves Less Than Success
description: The most successful pieces in Sunday's multimedia concert at the Kitchen were those that demanded least of the audience; whether the failures represented a deficiency in the artists or the audience would be hard to say. This was the third of four such Sundaynight concerts at the Kitchen this month being presented by Charlotte Moorman, Nam June Paik and Yoshi Wada.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: CLEAN SLEIGHT What started out as a class in juggling has evolved into a circus at Trinity. Church's downstairs arts and leisure hall, 74 Below, at 74 Trinity Place, just clown the hill and across the street at the rear of the churchyard.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (AP)  Lou (Machine Gun) Butera converted five impossible shots and went on to. defeat the sixtime champion, Irving Crane, 150130, last night in a playoff for the world pocket billiards championship.

title: Football Transactions
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: TV: B.B.C. Point Counter Point Provides Satire
description: As the latest import from the British Broadcasting Corporation for public television's Masterpiece theater, Point Counter Point has its flaws. But, in a fivepart dramatization by Simon Raven, enough of the Aldous Huxley satire is retained to provide, if not a completely satisfying whole, an impressive number of deliciously wicked parts. It opened Sunday on WNET!13 and will continue weekly.

title: Parley Set on Relations Between U.S. and Mart
description: LONDON, Feb. 19Plans for a conference to discuss the developing relationship between the enlarged. Common Market and the United States were announced here today.

title: Worst Drought in Decade Perils India's Food Supply
description: NEW DELHI, Feb, 19India, struck by the worst drought in a decade, is facing severe food shortages and rising prices, and criticism of the Government is growing.

title: TV: Brand New Life Proves a Compliment to A.B.C. Viewers
description: Most madeforTV movies emerge like assemblyline lard, but A Brand New Life is a joy. Intelligent adults or young people, or even bright children, who watch the 90minute Tuesday Movie of the Week tonight at 8:30 over the American Broadcasting Company network can almost take it as a compliment.

title: The Romantics
description: Anyone who wonders if May and June will surely come should watch the squirrels. On bitter cold days they have enough sense to stay under cover, even to sleep around the clock a time or two; but when the weather moderates, out they come to inspect their world, to stretch their muscles, to look for something tasty to eat. And before the month is out some of the gray squirrels will be dashing from tree to tree, leaping from limb to limb, acting coy and eager. They will be mating.

title: Levitt Criticizes City Truancy Handling
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt has found that the city Board of Education's procedures for dealing with truants and school dropouts are not being effectively administered.

title: Quake Jars Nevada Desert
description: RENO, Feb. 19 (UPI)  A moderate earthquake and several aftershocks jarred the southern Nevada Dsert today, but there was no damage.

title: OTB Says Its Numbers Payoff Would Top Organized Crime's
description: The Offtrack Betting Corporation plan to enter the numbers business would involve payoffs to winners at much higher rates than the current 600to1 in the illegal numbers game, Howard Samuels, chairman of the agency, said yesterday.

title: CENTROWITZ SETS MILE RUN RECORD
description: Matt Centrowitz made his first individual mile of the season a recordbreaking one yeserday while leading Power Memorial to the indoor track champinship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association's New York Diocese.

title: Toll in Soviet Crash At Prague Put at 77
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 19  A threeengine Soviet jetliner burst into flames and broke apart today while attempting to land at Prague International Airport. Western airline sources there reported that 77 of the 99 persons aboard had died.

title: TENNESSEE BEATS FLORIDA, 87 TO 83
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., Feb. 19 (UPI)Eddie Voelker scored a layup on a steal with 8 seconds remaining tonight and Tennessee's Volunteers defeated Southeastern Conference rival, Florida, 8783.

title: FRANK COSTELLO QUIETLY MOURNED
description: About 125 relatives, friends and acquaintances quietly paid final respects last night to Frank Costello, once considered the overlord of the national crime syndicate. He died Sunday night at the age of 82.

title: DEMOCRATIC CHIEFS SPLIT ON F.B.L HEAD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (UPI) Disagreeing with his deputy, Senator Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate Democratic leader, said today he was Inclined to support the confirmation of L. Patrick Gray 3d as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Prison Visitation Plan Helps Reform Program
description: The Rev. Charles H. Straut Jr. scribbled something in his small black notebook and moved on to the next cell.

title: GERMANY SELLING SOME OF DOLLARS
description: BONN, Feb. 19West Germany's central bank began selling some of its horde of United States dollars at the new ceiling rate of 2.9656 marks to the dollar today, just one week after the new international alignment of currencies was agreed upon.

title: Escorts Planned for Kawaida Workers
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19  The black sponsors of the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project have indicated that they ire prepared to escort workers ind equipment onto the project ite if white demonstrators continue to block the project.

title: U.S. Agency Investigates Mail Service
description: Representative Lester L. Wolff said yesterday, that a major investigation of Postal Service operations had been started by the General Accounting Office, including the service's efforts to promote airmail in what Mr. Wolff charged was misleading advertising.

title: Dean of Market Letters Stresses Long Term
description: Lucien O. Hooper, who grew up on a Maine farm and went on to Harvard, is a practitioner of that form of Wall Street literature known as the market letter.

title: RENTCURB DRIVES GROW IN SUBURBS
description: The recent lifting of all Federal controls on rents, after a year and a half of price regulation, has brought tenants in many of the metropolitan area's suburbs to a new level of militancy and has intensified political pressures for alternative forms of rent control.

title: Flag Has a Banner Day On Washington Bridge
description: A 90by60foot American flag flew from the George Washington Bridge yesterday, the first time in the memory of Port Authority employes that the weather permitted this on a Washington's birthday.

title: A School Offcial Calls for Curb On NonCivil Service Job Titles
description: A member of the Board of Education has called for a halt in the increase within the school system of special nonCivil Service job titles that are being filled by unlicensed personnel.

title: Speculators in Currency: Who and Why
description: PARIS, Feb. 19The banks say the winners were the multinational companies. The multinational companies cite the banks. Everyone mentions the oil sheiks, and some talk of those institutionalized individuals  men like Jean Paul Getty, Aristotle Onassis and Stavros Niarchoswhose very capable financial advisers have been advising for months to be long on marks and yen and short on dollars.

title: Women's Group Vows Poverty Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 19The National Organization for Women voted today to condemn the policies of the Nixon Administration as not being in the interest of minorities and to make 1973 the organization's action year against poverty.

title: REV. TYLER T. THOMAS
description: ELIZABETH, N. J., Feb. 19  The Rev. Tyler T. Thomas, pastor of the Liberty Baptist Church, which he founded in 1926, died after preaching his Sunday sermon. He was 79 years old and lived at 256 Second Street.

title: Scholars' Group Decries Auctions of Met's Coins
description: Scholars from 14 institutions appealed yesterday to trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art to halt further sales of its coin collections, being auctioned largely to finance the purchase of the calyx krater.

title: ROCCO LOFARO
description: Rocco Lofaro, a retired traffic patrolman in the Times Square area, who later was treasurer of the Ambassador and St. James Theaters and more recently was in charge of reserved seats at Roosevelt and Yonkers Raceway, died Friday in Bronx Lebanon Hospital. He was 60 years Old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: CarSmashing Derby and Cyclist's Jump Attract Throng on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 Around a centerpiece of wrecked automobiles, a Cadillac Eldorado bearing a red sign: See Parnelli Jones destroy this car, a Rolls Royce Silver Shadow, a Lincoln Continentals Mark IV and some $50,000 worth of other latemodel cars bashed each other into ??nk here yesterday.

title: 179 Pakistani Prisoners Are Returned by Indians
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, Feb. 19 India returned 179 sick and wounded Pakistani prisoners of war today at a border post near Lahore, the capital of Punjab Province.

title: Morton Will Enter Hospital For Prostate Malignancy
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Secretary of the Interior Rogers C.B. Morton announced today that he would enter a hospital for treatment of a prostate malignancy discovered during a routine physical.

title: Committee Formed to Aid Consumes
description: Eighteen prominent corporation executives have joined to form a Committee for Constructive Consumerism, which will work through the Better Business Bureau movement to provide improved customer satisfaction for products and services.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: City Gets a Grant To Develop Parks

title: Red Mud Dumped at Sea Off Italy Enrages Corsicans
description: SCARLINO, Italy, Feb. 16This village near the Tuscan coast is the source of a red mud that is soiling the blue Tyrrhenian Sea, vexing fishermen, worrying ecologists in France and Italy and enraging the islanders of Corsica.

title: N.Y.U. Teaches Race Betting and Bartending (No Credit, of Course)
description: More than 700 New York University students and members of the staff and faculty have signed up this term to take extra, noncredit courses on such topics as the art of horse betting, the mixing of drinks, repairing bicycles and saving on taxes.

title: Baseball Talks Drag For 3d Straight Day
description: Representatives of baseball's club owners and players met for the third straight day yesterday with no indications that they were closer to an agreement.

title: 3 Children and Landlord Killed in 2 Newark Fires
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19  Fire Swept through four threestory residential buildings near Springfield Avenue on the west side of the city at dawn today, killing three young girls in family and making 68 persons homeless.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Mrs. Gandhi and the U.S.

title: The Fallacy Of Getting Tough
description: Thomas F. McCoy, the chief administrator of New York state courts, has dealt a staggering blow to Governor Rockefeller's proposal that drug pushers should receive life sentences, without possibility of parole, or of a bargain for a lesser sentence in return for a guilty plea. In doing so, Mr. McCoy implicity questioned  although he did not discussthe whole idea that improving law enforcement is a matter of encouraging hardnosed police, prosecutors and judges to get tough with offenders.

title: Priest's Plan to Wed Is Backed by Parish
description: MOUNT PLEASANT, Mich., Feb. 19 (UPI)Parishioners conducted an aroundtheclock prayer vigil today in a college Roman Catholic church that was ordered shut down after its copastor announced plans to get married.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: BAR GROUP URGES DISCIPLINARY UNIT
description: NEWARK, Feb. 19The State Bar Association, responding to mounting criticism of the ways judges and lawyers are disciplined, has taken steps to deal more effectively with judges found incompetent, corrupt or unfit and with lawyers who violate their professional canons of ethics.

title: Business Briefs
description: PARIS, Feb. 19 (UPI)Peter G. Peterson, President Nixon's special trade emissary, opened a round of talks with French business and Government representatives today on future relations between the United States and Europe.

title: NIXON FORECASTS FOODPRICE EASING
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 President Nixon told union leaders today that rises in food prices would continue for at least several months, then tend to level off, this official spokesman disclosed after the President's private meeting with the leaders.

title: Bridge: Aldenderfer and Williams Win Life Master Pair Event
description: Two littleknown young experts, Sam Aldenderfer and Ray Williams of New York, topped a strong field in the life master pair championship at the New York Hilton Sunday.

title: Stettheimer Paintings Are Revived
description: The American painter Florine Stettheimer died in 1944 at the age of 73. Her work, though considered somewhat eccentric in its day, was sufficiently respected and admired to merit, two years after her death, a full retrospective exhibition at the Musewn of Modern Art. She was, perhaps, best known for the highly original sets and costumes she designed for the original production, in 1934, of the Virgil ThomsonGertrude Stein opera, Four Saints in Three Acts.

title: STATE SAYS CITY IMPROPERLY CUT TAX ASSESSMENTS
description: The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that the city's Tax Commission had improperly reduced realestate tax assessments by millions of dollars by blindly acting on incomplete, irregular and sometimes patently false applications by owners of large properties.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: EDWARD WILSON OF ARMOUR DEAD
description: Edward W. Wilson, retired president and director of Armour & Co., meatpackers, died Saturday in Vero Beach, Fla., where he had a winter home. He was 74 years old and lived in River Forest, Ill.

title: How Worldwide Marketer Prepares for Devaluation
description: The Brother International Corporation, an American company that sells Japanese products in the United States and elsewhere, began preparing for last week's dollar devaluation 14 months ago when the Smithsonian agreement restored calm to the international monetary system.

title: Met Camp Goes Underground in Mud
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 19  The underground camp bf the New York Mets opened today on a muddy public playground four miles from the team's shutdown training base.

title: Kerner Guilty on Charges Based on Racetrack Bribe
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19Former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois was found guilty today of conspiracy and accepting a bribe, and of income tax evasion, mail fraud and perjury.

title: SAMUEL RUTTENBERG
description: Samuel Ruttenberg, president of the Amperite Company in Union City, N.J., makers of electronic devices, died Sunday in Roosevelt Hospital, He was 75 years old and lived at 16 West 77th Street.

title: The Facts on Exiles
description: WASHINGTONOn Dec. 14, 1971, introducing his Amnesty Act of 1972, Senator Robert Taft of Ohio observed, ... estimates of the number of young Americans living in exile range as high as 70,000. Therein lies a tale.

title: PALMER HAYDEN
description: Palmer Hayden, a painter of AfroAmerican life and culture, died Sunday in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan. He was 83 years old and lived at 127 West 56th Street.

title: S.E.C. and Funds Seen Far Apart on Views of Industry Woes
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 18Nearing the end of its public investigation of the $60billion mutual fund industry, the Securities and Exchange Commission agrees with most indutsry spokesmen that this once profitable form of public investment needs a shot in the arm.

title: FASHION TALK
description: They haven't been out of sight too long, really, but for summer, knees are back. Nobody's calling those new short dresses minis, It's too soon for that. But they're around once again, in some of the very best fashion collections.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 20, 1973

title: 6Lane Ring Road Through Old London Areas Backed
description: LONDON, Feb. 19The British Government approved in principle today the construction of a sixlane ring road in a fivemile radius around central London.

description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: FRANCIS BEMOANS RANGER INJURIES
description: It was not the first time in his extraordinary career as coachgeneral manager of the Rangers that Emile Francis had been confronted with major injuries at a key point in the National Hockey League season.

description: News Summary and Index, Page 35

title: MYTH AND SONGS BY GEORGE BURNS
description: George Burns's show at Philharmonic Hall on Sunday followed the same general pattern as one given months earlier at Carnegie Hall by another veteran comedian, Groucho Marx.

title: Worst Drought in Decade Perils India's Food Supply
description: NEW DELHI, Feb. 19India, struck by the worst drought in a decade, is facing severe food shortages and rising prices, and criticism of the Government is growing.

title: Struck, El Al Cuts Flights
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 19 (UPI)A strike of maintenance workers for higher wages forced El Al Israel Airlines to cancel all outbound flights today, and the Government warned that it might stop operating the line if the walkout did not end in 24 hours. An El Al spokesman said that 800 passengers with tickets for the United States and Europe had been transferred to other carriers.

title: U.S. Allots $4.7Million For Harbor. Work Here
description: Federal funds earmarked for New York Harbor improvement projects under President Nixon's recent budget proposals for the 1974 fiscal year, beginning July 1, total slightly less than $5million.

title: Lufthansa Is Skeptical On Buying Concorde
description: BREMEN, West Germany, Feb. 19 (UPI)A Lufthansa executive said today the West German national airline had had second thoughts about buying the Concorde supersonic jet airliner.

title: Failure of a Bolt Believed the Cause In SkiLift Mishap
description: First reports by State Labor Department inspectors and the state police yesterday indicated that failure of a bolt may have caused Sunday's accident On the Mount Peter skirun chairlift at Warwick N.Y.

title: CHADIAN BUDGET INCLUDES TAX CUT
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 19The Government proposed tonight budget marked by tax cuts, business incentives and pension increases designed to reduce unemployment and encourage faster growth.

title: Music: New Curriculum
description: Composers used to be such marvelously direct fellows. If a man wrote a piece and called it, say, Rage Over the Lost Penny, the listener was justified in looking in the music for a lot of noisy banging and other allusions to the mood suggested. But that was long ago. Now, when a composer such as Friedrich Cerha entitles his piece Curriculum, it is safest to presume the meaning is terribly arcane, terribly private or nonexistent.

title: Adoption Costs Soar as Births Decline
description: Childless New York couples, made desperate by the current shortage of healthy white infants, are turning to the legal but often expensive field of private adoption.

title: Beanie. Hits S.&P.'s Top RatingOf Agency Bonds That Defaulted
description: Controller Abraham D. Beame yesterday charged the Standard and Poor's Corporation with using slipshod and arbitrary methods in evaluating state and municipal bonds.

title: Soviet Starting Production In Largest Blast Furnace
description: MOSCOWThe Soviet Union announced this month the start of production at its largest blast furnace, situated in the iron and steel center of Lipetsk in the heart of European Russia.

title: Cosmos List 11 Contests On Home Soccer Schedule
description: The New York Cosmos, the North American Soccer League champions, yesterday announced their 11game home scheduled, which will be highlighted by a game against Vera Cruz of Mexico Sunday, June 24.

title: MORDECAI GROSSMAN, EDUCATOR, DIES AT 74
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19Dr. Mordecai Grossman, author and educator, died today of cancer at his suburban Maryland home. He was 74 years old.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Yearround daylight savings time would reduce street crime, automobile accidents and fuel consumption, says Representative Stewart B. McKinney, a Republican of Fairfield, Conn. Mr. McKinney and Representative Craig Hosmer, Republican of California, are cosponsoring a bill to make daylight savings fulltime.

title: Body of Ptain Stolen From Island Grave Off France
description: PARIS, Feb. 19An oak coffin containing the body of Marshal Philippe Main, the most controversial figure of 20thcentury France, has been stolen from a tomb on the windblown Ile d'Yeu off the French Atlantic coast, an official investigating group discovered today.

title: Victimless Crimes Plan
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 19 (UPI) Gambling, prostitution and marijuana possession are victimless crimes and society could cut its crime rate in half by, abolishing penalties against them, Dr. Thomas Gitchoff, criminologist, told a weekend seminar.

title: Notes on People
description: The new chief officer of the American National Red Cross will be Dr. Frank Stanton, former president of the Columbia Broadcasting System and now vice chairman of the network. The White House staff at Key Biscayne, Fla., said President Nixon would appoint Dr. Stanton to the Red Cross post to succeed E. Roland Harriman, who is resigning next month. Dr. Stanton, who was president of C.B.S. from 1946 to 1971, will serve concurrently as a board member of the Red Cross and as its chief officer.

title: National Advertising Aide Is Appointed by The Times
description: William Shuck has been appointed assistant national advertising manager of The New York Times, effective March 1. Now assistant financial advertising manager, he will continue to supervise the financial advertising department in his new post.

title: FRANK COSTELLO QUIETLY MOURNED
description: 125 Attend Gangster's Wake at Campbell's Chapel

title: KAWAIDA BACKERS FORM TASK FORCE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 10The black sponsors of the embattled Kawaida Towers housing project have indicated that they are prepared to escort workers and equipment onto the project site if white demonstrators continue to block the project.

title: Lindenwold Is Called A Model Transit Line
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 The Lindenwold Rapid Transit Line linking Camden and its suburbs with Philadelphia is a model for the nation, a University of Pennsylvania study has found.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary aid Index, Page 35

title: CREDIT MARKETS EXPECT RATE RISE
description: Now that credit market analysts have had more time to evaluate last week's news, they generally conclude that devaluation will push interest rates moderately higher than they otherwise would have gone.

title: New Books
description: And the Hills Shouted for Joy: The Day Israel Was Born, by Bernard Postal and Henry W. Levy (McKay, $8.95).
