title: Stars Vanquish Q's, 9989, As Wise Scores 43 Points
description: SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 19 (AP)  The Utah Stars, with Willie Wise scoring 43 points, defeated the San Diego Conquistadors, 9989, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.Wise scored 20 points in the first half as the Stars ran up 14point lead at one point. However, the advantage dropped it) 4 points at the half, 4541.??

title: 4 KILLED AS PLANE CRASHES IN STREET
description: BROOKFIELD, Wis., Feb, 19 (UPI)  A twinengine private plane with no sound coming from its engines crashed in suburban street filled with morning rushhour traffic today, killing four persons aboard the plane.

title: Two Authors, One Israeli, Get B'nai B'rith Awards
description: Two authors, one an American, the other an Israeli, were honored yesterday with cash awards by B'nai B'rith's Commission on Adult Jewish Education for their literary works dealing with Jewish life.

title: President Plans to Seek Options in Trade Talks
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 19 President Nixon told a cordially attentive A.F.L.C.I.O. Executive Council today that he would ask Congress for broad discretionary powers to negotiate a safeguard system of trade agreements in the national interest.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
2 Inquiries Begun
description: ROME, Feb. 19  Italian authorities are conducting two separate investigations to determine if the 2,500yearold Greek vase acquired last year by New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art was smuggled out of Italy.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The Clark Police Department has begun carrying a lowpowered shotgun that shoots small bags of pellets to knock a person down without any permanent damage. The weapon, called the stinger stick because it resembles the conventional nightstick, is for use in situations that are dangerous, but not dangerous enough to warrant the use of a pistol, according to Lieut. Robert F. Bartkus.

title: Walter B. White, Banker And Fencing Enthusiast, 72
description: Walter B. White, who retired in 1955 from the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, where he was president of the Guaranty Mutual Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday at his apartment in Hampshire House. He was 72 years old and had homes also in Scarsdale, N. Y., and Dunellen, N. J.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: SUNDAY'S GAMES

title: EVELYN F. BURKEY, 62, WRITERS GUILD AIDE
description: Evelyn F. Burkey, who retired last June as executive director of the Writers Guild of America, East, died Sunday in Eastern Long Island Hospital, Greenport. She was 62 years old and had been living in Greenport since her retirement.

title: Tree Planted to Honor P.O.W.'s, Missing Men
description: In a ceremony at City Hall Park yesterday a crab apple tree was planted and dedicated by members of Viva (Voices in Vital America) as a tribute to prisoners of war and men missing in action.

title: TRUCE PROPOSED BY LAOTIAN REDS
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, Feb. 20 Prince Souphanouvong, leader of the Conimunistled Pathet Lao, has proposed a de facto ceasefire in Laos without a formal settlement. A ceasefire of this kind could go into effect within hours, reliable sources reported.

title: SPATE SAYS CITY IMPROPERLY CUT TAX ASSESSMENTS
description: The State Commission of Investigation charged yesterday that the city's Tax Commission had improperly reduced realestate tax assessments by millions of dollars by blindly acting on incomplete, irregular and sometimes patently false applications by owners of large properties.

title: NIEDERHOFFER WINS IN SQUASH RACQUETS
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 19Vic Niederhoffer of New York won the United States Squash racquets championship for the second successive year by beating the Rev. Robert Hetherington of Buffalo, 157, 159, 1511, in the final at Princeton's Jadwin Gymnasium today.

title: 6 Freed Prisoners Tell A Little of Hove It Was
description: CLARK AIR BASE, the Philippines, Feb. 19  Six American war prisoners, freed yesterday in Hanoi, talked to newsmen here today about their thoughts in captivity, how they felt about being released, and their plans.

title: A Senate Subcommittee Reports Its Findings in 18Month Study
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP)  The Senate securities subcommittee today recommended legislation preventing members of stock exchanges from acting as both broker and money manger for the same institutional investors.

title: 383 IN PHILADELPHIA CHARGED ON STRIKE
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 (AP) For, the first time in three days of mass roundups, pickets arrested outside strikebound city schools here were charged with criminal contempt.

title: SAIGON REPORTS A SHARP DECLINE IN FIGHTING LEVEL
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 20Fighting in South Vietnam declined substantially during the last 24 hours, the Saigon military authorities reported today, leading to the belief that an urgent appeal by the FourParty Joint Military Commission to end all hostilities might be having some effect at last.

title: Toll in Soviet Crash At Prague Put at 77
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 19  A threeengine Soviet jetliner burst into flames and broke apart today while attempting to land at Prague International Airport. Western airline sources there reported that 77 of the 99 persons aboard had died.

title: People in Sports: Sitting It Out
description: Since Kevin Loughery replaced Roy Rubin as coach of the Philadelphia 76ers last month, he has not had available the playing talents of one of the few active players to score more than 10,000 points in the National Basketball AssociationKevin Loughery.

title: Forty Horses Die in Fire At a Track in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 19 (UPI)Thirtyeight race horses and two ponies died early today in a stable fire that witnesses said had been set off by a series of explosions.

title: Parley Studies Highs Of Addicts and Mystics
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 19A group of scientists and scholars gathered here over the weekend for objective discussions on getting high.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The world's fastest human has now improved to such an extent that it requires photo finishes to beat him. It took the camera to split apart Valery Borzov of the Soviet Union from the two sprinters who hit the wire with him in a virtual dead heat at San Diego last Friday. He was third in excellent time and was satisfied. He should be. A week earlier, in his American debut, he dragged anchor all the way and was eliminated in his qualifying heat.

title: DR. HAROLD S. BURR
description: LYME, Conn., Feb. 19Dr. Harold Saxton Burr, E. K. Hunt Professor of Anatomy at Yale University from 1933 until his retirement in 1958, died Saturday at his home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Kerner Guilty on Charges Based on Racetrack Bribe
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 19Former Gov. Otto Kerner of Illinois was found guilty today of conspiracy and accepting a bribe, and of income tax evasion, mail fraud and perjury.

title: People and Business
description: U.S. Industries, Inc., the freight car manufacturer founded by Diamond Jim Brady in 1899 that has become one of the nation's largest conglomerates, has revamped its top management team.

title: POST FIVE GETS BERTH IN TOURNEY
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association today chose eight more teams for its collegsdivision basketball shampionship and sites for two retonal tournaments.

title: REJTO'S CELLO IDEAS WORK EFFECTIVELY
description: Most people tend to think of the cello only as the luscious, extrovertedly romantic instrument par excellence. Peter Rejto a 23yearold cellist from the West Coast, has other ideas, and he put them to work most effectively in his New York debut recital Monday night at Hunter's Young Concert Artists Series.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The varsity basketball coach at South River High School was suspended yesterday because of his arrest Saturday by the state police on gambling charges. Joseph Feuhrer, who has held the coaching job since 1970, was among nine persons arrested in South River and in four nearby towns by raiding parties directed by Capt. Peter Dunn of the state police. The defendants were araigned on charges of bookmaking and maintaining a disorderly place and released on their own recognizance or in bail ranging from $1,000 to $3,000.

title: People in Sports: Halas Leaves Hospital
description: George Halas, the 78yearold owner of the Chicago Bears, was released from Passavant Hospital in Chicago yesterday where he underwent successful intestinal surgery on Feb. 7. Halas was operated on for the removal of stones from the common duct leading from the liver to the intestine. A hospital spokesman said Halas was in good condition and had fully recovered from the operation.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: BLACKOUT STRIKES BROOKLYN AND S.I. MILLION AFFECTED
description: Almost half of Brooklyn and parts of Staten Island were without electricity for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon in a blackout apparently caused by a fire in a Consolidated Edison transformer.

title: Robinson to Resign Post
description: CLINTON, S. C., Veb. 20 (UPI) Herb Robinson, head basketball coach and physical education coordinator at Presbyterian College for five years, announced today he was resigning at the end of the school year.

title: Excerpts From President Nixon's Address to the Legislature of South Carolina
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Following are excerpts from the White House transcript of President Nixon's speech today before a Joint session of the South Carolina Legislature in Columbia:

title: Strapless 40's Return in Style To Suit the 70's
description: It burst, upon the world to the late 1930's. It flourishid through the 1940's as le dernier cri for promgoers, and it survived into the 1950's. It was boned all around so it would stay up. The strapless dress.

title: Vietnam Fighting Rises Sharply After a Day's Drop
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Feb. 21After a oneday decline in action, the level of fighting has risen sharply again, to around its highest point since the ceasefire began on Jan. 28, Saigon military authorities reported this morning.

title: You Have Become Someone Else
description: COOLANGATTA, AustraliaAmerica, what has happened to thee? Once you were morally impeccable and stanchly proud; a model republic with your citizens having unbounded power; a symbol of freedom, the hope of the downtrodden and a shelter for the world's poor and oppressed; one nation under God where free men lived in equality, peace and justice; a country not divided by hate and weakened by your citizens apathy: Your streets were safe and rivers clean and the, sky over you was pure and blue; and your mighty Constitution was a document that protected your citizens and served as a torch that illuminated bigotry and slavery in the world's dark lands.

title: Coffee Demands a Grand Jury Inquiry Into Kugler's Role in the Sherwin Case
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20Richard J. Coffee, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor, demanded today a grand jury investigation to determine whether the Cahill administration had whitewashed charges that the State Attorney General had tried to cover up a kickback conspiracy involving the New Jersey Secretary of State.

title: Abortion Law Linked in Study To 19,000Birth Drop in City
description: Legal abortions performed on New York City women during the first two years under a liberalized abortion law led to a decline of about 19,000 births beyond what would have otherwise occurred, a statistical analysis has indicated.

title: A RADICAL TURN URGED FOR WOMEN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Wilma Scott Heide, the newly reelected president of the National Organization for. Women, said today that the women's movement needs to become more radical.

title: London Police Kill 2 Attacking Embassy
description: LONDON, Feb. 20  The police shot and killed two masked Asian youths brandishing imitation guns who invaded and terrorized the Indian High Commissioner's office in central London near the Strand today.

title: Some Heartbreaks Are Relined
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20Some days you eat the bear, Bobby Allison was saying, and some days the bear eats you. The Daytona 500 had been completed and now everyone was participating in the postmortems. It was all therethe rehashing of that final pit stop that helped Richard Petty in a Dodge to beat Buddy Baker in another Dodge, the secondguessing, the conjectures based on if we had. Petty was basking in the warmth of his fourth winning of the Daytona 500 (no other driver has won it more than once) and elsewhere around the track, heartbreak and cruel disappointment showed through the stoicism.

title: PRAGUE CRASH LAID TO CONTROL FAILURE
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 20 (UPI) The captain of a Soviet passenger jet that crashed in flames yesterday told investigators that the plane's stabilizer, horizontal tail surfaces, jammed as he came in to land at Prague Airport, Western airline officials said today.

title: Trudeau Budget Wins Backing, Averting Threat to Leadership
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 20The New Democratic party, which holds the balance of power in Parliament, threw its support today behind the budget proposed last night by the minority Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT RAID IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Feb. 21Israeli troops struck into Lebanon last night to raid what Israel said were two Arab guerrilla bases north of the coastal town of Tripoli. An Israeli military spokesman said that scores of defenders had been killed and that dozens of buildings had been blown up.

title: Joseph Szigeti, Violinist, Dead; Exponent of Classical Tradition
description: Joseph Szigeti, one of the titans of the violin in this century, died Monday night at a clinic in Lucerne, Switzerland. The Hungarianborn musician, pioneer of contemporary music and a jealous guardian of the classic tradition, was 80 years old. He had been living in Montreux, Switzerland, since his retirement in 1960.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT RAID IN LEBANON
description: TEL AVIV, Wednesday, Feb. 21Israeli troops struck into Lebanon last night to raid what Israel said were two training bases for Arab, guerrillas north of the coastal town of Tripoli. An Israeli military spokesman said that scores of defenders had been killed and that dozens of buildings had been blown up.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, Feb. 20, 1973 SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 20 (UPI)  The widow of Roberto Clemente announced today a 602acre site had been chosen for construction of the Roberto Clemente Sports City, which Clemente had dreamed of building to provide sports facilities for underprivileged youths. Mrs. Vera Clemente said the sports city would take about 2 years to build at a cost estimated at $12 to $14 million.

title: Benjamin Freeman, Tailor For Nixon and Eisenhower
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP)  Benjamin H. Freeman, retired board chairman of the clothing concern here that has tailored President Nixon's wardrobe for the last 20 years, died Sunday at Pennsylvania Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Stagehands' Local Pickets Juilliard Over Recognition
description: Local 1 of the Stagehands' Union is continuing to picket the Juilliard School in Lincoln Center in an effort to gain recognition as bargaining agent for its members.

title: Advertising: Paying the Media
description: Broadcasters and publishers who insist on changing the ad agencies' traditional responsibility for media payment could cause more harm to the industry than they are bargaining for.

title: FLYERS SINK BLUES AS FLETT STARS, 53
description: ST. LOUIS, Feb. 20 (AP)Bill Flett tallied his 33d goal at 2 minutes 18 seconds of the final period in helping the Philadelphia Flyers gain a 53 victory over the St. Louis Blues in a National Hockey League tonight.

title: Sports News in Brief
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 20 (UPI)  The widow Roberto Clemente announced today a 602acre site had been chosen for construction of the Roberto Clemente Sports City, which Clemente had dreamed of building to provide sports facilities for underprivileged youths. Mrs. Vera Clemente said the sports city would take about 2I/2 years to build at a cost estimated at $12 to $14 million.

title: Bridge: BoardaMatch Team Play, Now a Rarity, Is Held Here
description: Boardamatch team contests, which a decade ago were an automatic feature of every local tournament program, are now a rarity. The Swiss Team, scored by international match points and therefore closer in spirit to the dabber bridge game, has takes over.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH OVER SUNS, 10797
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)The Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, Paul Silas and Dave Cowens, gained their seventh consecutive victory today, a 10797 triumph over the Phoenix Suns.

title: NIXON DECISION SEEN SLOWING TRADE GAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) Wilbur D. Mills, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that an improvement in the United States trade deficit would be delayed by President Nixon's decision to seek new trade Igislation rather than hnpose an import surcharge.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: $135,000 Bank Loss Here Disclosed in Court Action
description: The disappearance of $135,000 last October from a vault of the Bankers Trust Company was disclosed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan when Justice Vincent A. Lupiano ordered the State Department of Labor to justify a subpoena of bank records.

title: MRS. FERDINAND KRAMER
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 20Mrs. Stephanie Shambaugh Kramer, a landscape architect here and the wife of Ferdinand Kramer, a mortgage banker here who served on President Kennedy's Committee on Equal Opportunity in Housing, died here today. She was 64 years old.

title: CANADA ACCUSED OF INGOT DUMPING
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The Treasury Dbpartment accused Canada today of selling aluminum ingots at illegally low prices in the United States. This accusation sets off one of the largest dumping cases in History.

title: PENGUINS DEFEAT ISLANDERS BY 40
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., Feb. 20 All the little mistakes that losing teams call bad luck plagued the Islanders tonight as they bowed for the 50th time this season, a plateau that had laden reached only four times in National Hockey League play.

title: Score Still 00 in Baseball Talks
description: Negotiators in the baseball talks met for the fourth straight day yesterday and emerged with the same results none. They'll meet again today, but more significant is another meeting scheduled for today and one that may be set for later in the week.

title: TV: Slack Suspense
description: And No One Could Save Her certainly fits as a title for the A.B.C. Wednesday Movie of the Week, starting at 8:30 tonight and stumbling along for 90 minutes, with poor Lee Remick being mysteriously driven crazy in Dublin.

title: PATERSON PROGRAM IS DENIED SUPPORT
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)The State Community Affairs Department withdrew its support today from a Paterson economicdevelopment program. It said the Community Economic Development Corporation of Greater Paterson was doing nothing to help businesses in the poor neighborhoods.

title: CHRYSLER AND G.M. RECALLING VEHICLES
description: DETROIT, Feb. 20(UPI)Gasoline leaking from defective fuel pumps has caused fires on at least 57 Chrysler Corporation cars, and the company annouriced today that it was recalling 149,056 vehicles to replace the fuel pumps.

title: Canadian Output Index Up
description: OTTAWA, Feb. 20 (Reuters) Canada's seasonally adjusted index of industrial production rose 0.5 per cent in December to 203.3 from 202.3 in November, with 1961 as the base year at 100. Manufacturing increased for the fourth consecutive month. Both mining and utilities showed a decline. Electric power, gas and water index declined 0.2 per cent to 239.2 in December from 239.6 in November.

title: Where Were You When Lights Went Out Again?
description: Fluorescent lights flickered on Brooklyn subway platforms, then went dark. Only the old incandescent lamps burned on.

title: HOWELL E. JACKSON OF RACING DEAD
description: MIDDLEBURG, Va., Feb. 20 Howell E. Jackson, an owner and breeder of race horses whose maroon silks are reportedly the oldest in the United States, died Saturday. He was 76 years old.

title: Court Lets Stand Ruling Protecting Jobs of Political Appointees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Supreme Court made a move today toward eventual abolition A the timehonored system of political patronage.

title: POST FIVE GETS BERTH IN TOURNEY
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 20 (AP) The National Collegiate Athletic Association today chose eight more teams for its collegedivision basketball championship and sites for two regional tournaments.

title: BURNS VOWS END TO DEVALUATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that, as far as I am concerned, this is the last devaluation of the dollar.

title: COUGARS SUBDUE NETS, 123 TO 106
description: GREENSBORO, N. C., Feb. 20  The Carolina Cougars stretched their lead in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division to 4 games by defeating the New York Nets, 123106, tonight.

title: Joseph Szigeti, Violinist, Dead; Exponent of Classical Tradition
description: Joseph Szigeti, one of the titans of the violin in this century, died Monday night at a clinic in Lucerne, Switzerland. The Hungarianborn musician, a pioneer of contemporary music and a jealous guardian, of the classic tradition, was 80 years old. He had been living in Montreux, Switzerland, since his retirement in 1960.

title: Night Music Postponed
description: The Broadway opening of A Little Night Music, the Stephen Sondheim and Hugh Wheeler musical, has been postponed from Feb. 25 to either March 4 or March 5 because of the illness of Glynis Johns, one of the show's leading performers. Miss Johns is under treatment for her illness at New York University Hospital. Her understudy, Barbara Lang, is temporarily appearing in the musical, which began a series of previews Feb. 14 at the Shubert Theater.

title: FOOD COST SURGED 2%3% IN JANUARY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that the cost of food rose between 2 and 3 per cent in January, the largest monthly rise in 20 or 25 years.

title: Judge Questions Four Charges Against Deep Sleep Producer
description: PATERSON, Feb. 20 Judge Ervan F. Kushner of Municipal Court questioned today the validity of four of the nine criminal charges that have been levied against Alfred Sole because of the sexual content of his Xrated movie Deep Sleep.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Citizens Budget Commission and the Commerce and Industry Association Accused yesterday the Lindsay administration of excessive expenditures. The statement came at the first day of hearings on the Mayor's budget before a joint session of the Board of Estimate and the Finance Committee of the City Council.

title: Consumer Harassment Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UN) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, introduced today a bill that would prevent consumers from being harassed by creditors while billing disputes are being resol ed. One of the bill's provisions would require creditors to acknowledge customer billing inquiries within 30 days and to resolve such inquiries within 90 days.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Carrier Airman Convicted In Race Rioting in October
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 20 (UPI)Airman Apprentice Lawrence Wommack was convicted today of a single count of rioting in connection with a racial disturbance aboard the aircraft carrier. Kitty Hawk.

title: Moslems in Dearborn Fight For Survival of Community
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 20 Aside from the modest gold dome atop the mosque at the corner of Verno Highway and Dix Avenue, there are only sketchy hintsArabic script here and there, restaurant signs advertising shish kebab that Dearborn's South End houses what is said to be the largest commonity of Arab Moslems in North America. The gigantic River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor, Company, not much more than a stone's throw away, sets the exterior tone of the area. These frigid days, plumes from the plant's giant smokestacks congeal in the 20degree air into billowing cloudcastles that lend the neighborhood a certain muscular, industrial picturesqueness. But for the most part it is a stark and inhospitable scene.

title: Yesterday's Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Two Utilities in Kansas Set NuclearPower Plant
description: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company and the Kansas City Power and Light Company announced plans yesterday to build a nuclearpower plant set for service beginning early as 1981.

title: Frisch Remains Critical
description: WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 20 (AP)Frankie Frisch remained in critical condition at Wilmington Medical Center tonight, a spokesman said.

title: $200,000 Ransom Frees Banker Son; Dallas Man Seize??
description: DALLAS, Feb. 20 (AP) ?? banker's 12yearold son wa?? released unharmed tonight aft er the family reportedly paid a $200,000 ransom. A 30yearold Dallas man was later seized by F.B.I. agents in connection with the kidnapping.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: ARTICLE CORRECTED ON INVESTING DATA
description: An article in Saturday's editions of The New York Times that described proceedings at a seminar at the Wharton School at the University of Pennsylvania contained a number of errors. In citing several conclusions that were presented to the seminar, the article should have said:

title: Secrets of Freedom
description: Democratic governments are puz zled by contradictions between the desire to inform their populations freely and completely while preserving from public disclosure legitimate secrets deemed essential to national security in a nuclearmissile world.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Support for Public TV Grows As More Viewers Pledge Aid
description: Public television, faced with curtailed government financial aid and uncertain funding from foundations, appears to be winning unprecedented viewer support in several cities.

title: ARABS IN EL AL CASE IN ITALY ARE MISSING
description: ROME, Feb. 20The status and whereabouts of two Arabs arrested here last August on charges of plotting to bomb an El Al Israel Airlines jet were the subject of controversy today.

title: Volcano Erupts Again
description: REYKJAVIK, Iceland, Feb. 20 (Reuters)A new stream of molten lava burst today from the western side of Helgafell volcano on Heimaey, an island 10 miles off Iceland's south coast, and began to engulf houses in the town of Vestmannaejyar. The new eruption came four weeks after the volcano became active.

title: KING'S BISHOP, $5, WINS AT HIALEAH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 20King's Bishop and Iron Anthony engaged in a tingling stretch duel in the feature event at Hialeah today, with King's Bishop winning by half a length.

title: Jersey Environment Aide Sees No Energy Crisis
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20  The State Commissioner of Environmental Protection said today that while New Jersey did not yet have an energy crisis, it did have an energy problem that, to a considerable extent, industry had allowed to develop.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao today signed a peace agreement that ends 20 years of war and establishes an interim coalition government made up of equal numbers from both sides. The accord also creates two commissions to deal with military and political, questions and provides for the exchange of prisoners within sixty days. A ceasefire is to go into effect at noon tomorrow. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: Gross Indicted as Taker Of $41,400 in Kickbacks
description: Ted Gross, former Commistimer of the City Youth Services Agency, was indicted by a Manhattan grand jury yesterday on charges of having accepted $41,400 in kickbacks during his 16 months in office.

title: TAX CHIEF DENIES ANY ABUSES HERE
description: Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, yesterday denounced as a grubby politicial gambit state investigation report charging irregularities in realestate tax assessments here.

title: Philadelphia School Head Quits As Picketing by Teachers Ends
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) Mass picketing at Philadelphia schools halted today after the arrest of 790 teachers, but most of the 13,000 teachers, out since Jan. 8, remained defiant in support of bigger salaries and smaller classes.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Blazers Triumph Over Whalers, 42; Take Third Place
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 20 (AP) The Philadelphia Blazers, getting thirdperiod goals from John McKenzie and Michael Plante, beat the New England Whalers, 42, tonight to move into third place in the East.

title: Failure to Protect Public Is Charged Against S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission was accused today of abrogating its responsibilities to the public in order to protect the private cartel on Wall Street.

title: LABOR BODY SAYS NIXON ENDANGERS SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20  The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O., which received President Nixon warmly yesterday, sharply assailed today the Administration's domestic policies, particularly what it said was the dismantling of the nation's social programs.

title: LABOR BODY SAYS NIXON ENDANGERS SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 20 The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.LO., which received President Nixon warmly yesterday, sharply assailed today the Administration's domestic policies, particularly What it said was the dismantling of the nation's, social programs.

title: Manufacturing Investment In U.S. Made by Mitsubishi
description: The impact of new currency values manifested itself in trade and business yesterday with price changes and the apparent start of a large flow of Japanese investment to the United States.

title: Manassas Rejoims Stills, Its Leader, Blues and Rod
description: It takes a special kind of confidence to tell the paying customer that you have not seen your band for three months and that he should consider the evening's performance not a concert but a rehearsal. This is exactly what Stephen Stills did Monday evening introducing his band, Manassas, at the Academy of Music.

title: Ted Gross Indicted
description: The city's former Youth Services Commissioner, Ted Gross, was indicted yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of having accepted $41,400 in kickbacks during his 16 months in the post. Page 49.

title: CAPITOL PROTEST SCORES FUND CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Thousands of demonstrators moved through the halls of the Capitol today in an attempt to rally support for the social welfare programs that have been sharply cut back by President Nixon's proposed 1974 budget.

title: PACT TO END WAR IN LAOS, INCLUDING POLITICAL PLAN, IS SIGNED BY THE 2 SIDES
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Feb. 21The Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao signed a peace agreement today, ending 26 years of war and establishing an interim coalition government to be made up of equal numbers from both sides.

title: Meatless Day Is Called A Way to Beat. Prices
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (Reuters)  Americans might improve their health and their wallets if they ate less meat, Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today.

title: Metropolitan Briefs.
description: Despite an early morning protest demonstration and a threat of further court action, crews under contracts to the State Department of Transportation began chopping down several dozen trees yesterday along a narrow, winding section of Route 9W in Rockland County. The treechopping is part of a $2million project to widen a 3.4mile stretch of the twolane road just south of the Tappan Zee Bridge.

title: Theater: No Sex Please We're British Arrives
description: There is a peculiar theatrical genre known as British sex comedy. While it is admittedly always British it is never sexy or comic. At its best it can achieve a few innuendos and a certain farcical gusto. It is vastly popular in Britain, except with the critics. The form might prove vastly popular here, but unfortunately the critics tend to be more of a stumbling block. British audiences who like this kind of thingand they are legion, and sometimes even foreign legionare too sensible to be put off by the jaded views of critics.

title: GLAMOUR ISSUES LEAD STOCK RISE
description: The stock market moved moderatey higher yesterday, paced by several bigname, glamour and steel issues.

title: Government Drops Prosecution of Couple in StripMining Fight
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 The Justice Department disclosed today that it had dropped all further prosecution of Alan and. Margaret McSure, ly, young radicals who have been at the center of a fiveandahalfyear controversy over their efforts to organize the Appalachian poor against strip mining in the eastern Kentucky mountains.

title: BRAZILIAN LEADERVISITS VENEZUELA
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20The presidents of Brazil and Venezuela met today in a move to ease tension that has been rising between the two countries ever since President Nixon publicly singled out Brazil as the natural leader of Latin America over a year ago.

title: Red Cross Renames Campaign Chairman
description: Fred D. Thompson, president of Family Circle magazine, will serve for the second year as general chairman of the campaign for members and funds for the American Red Cross in Greater New York.

title: HORSES & EQUIPMENT
description: Well Bred Yearlings Fillies$2500 each, $4500 the pair. Offer good till March 1. GOHAGAN FARM, Route 70 & 73, Mariton N.J. 6099830324

title: Riessen Struggles To Down Borowida Ashe Wins, 62, 63
description: COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 21 (AP)  Topseeded Marty Riessen of Evanston, 41, scored a 76, 16, 64, triumph over Jeff Borowiak of Berkeley, Calif., today and advanced to the second round of the $50,000 Cologne tournament on the World Championship Tennis tour.

title: NIXON NOMINATES AGRICULTURE AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 President Nixon sent to the Senate today the nomination of Robert W. Long, a San Francisco banker, to be Assistant Secretary of Agriculture. The action was surrounded by, controversy.

title: Segovia, at 80 Looks Disdainfully at Trends in Music
description: Andres Segoia is just an ordinary man, in the Henri, Higgins sense, so why shouldn't he show an ordinary man's pride in what he has wrought? The grandee of the classic guitarwhose Philharmonic Hall recital today, the first of two there this season, will coincidewith his 80th birthday all but twangs and vibrates, with pleasure these days at tion of his son, Carlos Andrs, a musically gifted young fellow.

title: Counterfeit $100 Bills Wagered at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, Feb. 20  At least $3,400 in counterfeit money, all in bills of $100 denomination, was among the $2,892,241 wagered by last night's surprisingly large crowd of 23,752 at Yonkers Raceway. One seller was amazed by the expertise of the counterfeiters.

title: Liguori Risking 1.3Race Garden Streak
description: Marty Liguori, overjoyed at his current running success, will have more on his mind than a subfourminute mile Friday night during the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships at Madison Square Garden.

title: KAWAIDA PICKETS CUT 50% BY JUDGE
description: NEWARK, Feb. 20Superior Court Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman today reduced by half the number of pickets allowed to march in front of the Kawaida Towers construction site, but he refused a request by the contractor to move the picket line to a side street.

title: Seller of the Greek Vase Is Named by Met Curator
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's curator of Greek and Roman art yesterday identified Dikran A. Sarrafian, a Lebanese dealer and collector, as the seller of the ancient vase bought by the museum for approximately $1million last September.

title: In Marxist Chile, the Wealthy Who Remained Still Find Beef and Scotch
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 20  On a recent evening a small group of neighbors gathered for dinner on the open veranda of a large Spanish, colonial house in the affluent district of Las Coudes.

title: 250 Protesters Disrupt PhoneRise Hearing
description: A raucous Public Service Commission hearing on the New York Telephone Company's latest request for a rate increase was interrupted yesterday when 250 angry residents of Coop City swarmed into the hearing room in the World Trade Center.

title: Utility Names Rutgers Dean
description: NEWARK, Feb. 20 (AP)Margery Somers Foster, dean of Douglass College at Rutgers University, was elected today to the board of directors of the Public Service Electric & Gas Co., becoming the first woman to serve on the board.

title: Old Futures of Soybeans Rise By New Daily Permissible Limit
description: The old soybean futures crop took advantage of the new daily permissible trading limit of 15 cents a bushel yesterday, rind the futures jumped that amount on the Chicago Board of Trade at the opening. The rule raising the limit from 10 cents to 15 cents became effective yesterday.

title: The Road to a Bank Robbery Charge  at 13
description: A 13  year  old boy, whose povertyridden parents are deaf and unable to speak, will go on trial in Buffalo tomorrow on charges involving a $700 armed robbery of a bank there last Wednesday.

title: HIGH COURT REJECTS APPEAL BY RATTENNI
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) The Supreme Court let stand today the 1971 convictions of Nicholas. A. A. Rattenni and two other reputed organizedcrime figures found guilty Of taking part in a bribery plot to protect illicit gambling in Westchester County.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  The Supreme Court today rejected a bid by Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, to reopen the International Telephone and TelegraphHartford Insurance Company, antitrust case that raised furor over alleged political influence last year.

title: CUSTOMS OFFICIAL PINS DOWN DRUGS
description: Customs Inspector Lewis Bacigalupo played a hunch yesterday and scored a strike.

title: Sally MacDougall Dead at 97; Feature Wrider for The World
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 20Sally MacDougall, a feature writer who began with The World of New York in 1919 and continued with its successor newspapers until her retirement in 1959, died yesterday in, a nursing home here. She was 97 years old and had lived in Manhattan's Greenwich Vilage until two years ago.

title: Guess What State's Initials Are N.J.?
description: PHILLIPSBURG, N. J.New Jersey is a small state on the eastern seaboard halfway between Honest John Lindsay and the Liberty Bell. It is best known for its Turnpike, Atlantic City, Imamu Baraku, Newark Airport and the Morro Castle disaster. Most of its leaders are in jail for stealing money.

title: Equity Financing
Music and Theater Offered at Kitchen Ina 3Part Concert
description: Monday's concert of new music and theater at the Kitchen was in three parts, and if interest declined steadily during, the course of the evening, even the last part still had something to offer.

title: Number One Priority
description: Among the few hopeful aspects of the President's environmental message was his renewed support of a landuse bill with teeth in it. A measure of the urgency with which the country's undeveloped lands need protection is the staggering estimate that at the present rate of sprawl each of the next three decades will see new urban expansion equal in area to the entire state of New Jersey.

title: Levy's Rise to Power: Totally Political Animal
description: Norman A. Levy's earlier remembered visit to City Hall occurred when he was 2, years old, and he sat on Fiorello H. La Guardia's lap.

title: Unsworn Statement Law Dies in Georgia Legislature
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 20 (UPI)Georgia's unsworn statement law was wiped from the books yesterday by members of both houses who demanded that the public must be protected.

description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art's curator of Greek and Roman art yesterday identified Dikran A. Sarrafian, a Lebanese dealer and collector, as the seller of the ancient vase bought by the museum for approximately $1million last September.

title: Ervin Modifies Press Shield Bill; Sees Opposition to Full Immunity
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee's Subcommittee on Constitutional Rights, said today that a bill giving newsmen absolute Immunity from forced testimony had no chance of getting through Congress.

title: BLACKOUT STRIKES BROOKLYN AND S.I.; MILLION AFFECTED
description: Almost half of Brooklyn and parts of Staten laland were without electricity for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon in a blackout apparently, caused by a fire in a Consolidated Edison transformer.

title: G.I. Arraigned in Murder Tied to Drug Traf ficking
description: SOMERVILLE, Feb. 20  A 24yearold private was arraigned here today on charges of having murdered a fellow soldier in a case that the County Prosecutor said he believed was related to marijuana trafficking at Fort Monmouth.

title: Vietnam War Monument
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Senate approved yesterday a resolution calling for a monument to the Vietnam war dead of the First Infantry Division.

title: Moslems in Dearborn Fight For Survival of Community
description: DEARBORN, Mich., Feb. 20 Aside from the modest gold dome atop the mosque at the corner of Verno Highway and Dix Avenue, there are only sketchy hintsArabic script here and there, restaurant signs advertising shish kebab that Dearborn's South End houses what is said to be the largest community of Arab Moslems in North America. The gigentle River Rouge plant of the Ford Motor Company, not much more than a stone's throw away, sets the exterior tone of the area. These frigid days, plumes from the plant's giant smokestacks congeal in the 20degree air into billowing cloudcastles that lend the neighborhood a certain muscular, industrial picturesqueness. But for the most part it is a stark and inhospitable scene.

title: Dijon, Usually a French Bellwether, Is Worried Over Prices and Leftists
description: DIJON, France, Feb. 17If one can find a middle France or a silent majority anywhere in this country, it is here in Dijon, a town of 180,000 in the eastcentral region.

title: A Patrolman Is Suspended On Charges of Misconduct
description: A 27yearold patrolman was suspended yesterday for allegedly threatening several persons with his revolver after he was in an accident with couple on a motorcycle.

title: Breakfast Special: Take 7 Musicians...
description: Seven members of the local floating pool of musicians who customarily play country music, bluegrass, oldtime music, blues and street rock and perform miscellaneous backup functions, have formed a group called Breakfast Special. It made an appropriate miscellaneous debut Monday evening at the Washington Square Methodist Church, 135 West Fourth Street.

title: Scott Calls Choice of Site For U.S. Offices Proper
description: Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader, described yesterday the selection of a new building in Philadelphia to house the regional headquarters of Federal socioeconomic agencies as the appropriate and proper result of lengthy public scrutiny and recommendations from civic leaders and government agencies.

title: A. Relocation Company Agrees Not to Use Harassment Tactics
description: A leading tenantrelocation company here has agreed in court not to engage in any harassment tactics designed to force tenants to vacate their apartments, Attorney. General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.

title: FOOD COST SURGED 2%3% IN JANUARY
description: WASHHINGTON, Feb. 20Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz said today that the cost of food rose between 2 and 3 per cent in January, the largest monthly rise in, 20 of 25 years.

title: Truck Carrying Knitwear. Is Hijacked by 4 in Bronx
description: Four masked men yesterday stole a truck carrying $100,000 worth of men's and women's knitwear in a manner remniscent of Prohibitionera liquor hijacking.

title: A C.I.A. Analyst Disputes General in Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20An affidavit by an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, disputing a general's testimony, has emerged in the Pentagon papers trial and led today to a defense demand that the chief prosecutor be removed from the case for misconduct.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 45

title: Mr. Nixon Wins First Round
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20After all the shouting on Capitol Hill about the need to reduce the President's power, it looks as if the Congress will actually increase Mr. Nixon's authority in the opening skirmish over trade and tariff policy.

title: Is World Central Bank Needed?
description: In 1866 the failure of the great banking house of Overend, Gurney & Co. in the City of London touched off a severe financial crisis. The crisis was not particularly different from many othets that had swept England and other countries. But it is Memorable in that it forced. Walter Bagehot, banker, economist, literary critic, political theorist and editor of The Economist, to invent the modern theory of central banking. Bagehot's revolution in monetary thinking finally comprehended and put into practice by governments and central banks  is the basic reason why domestic financial crises and panics have almost vanished.

title: G.I. Arraigned in Murder Tied to Drug Trafficking
description: SOMERVILLE, Feb. 20  A 24yearold private was arraigned here today on charges of having murdered a fellow soldier in a case that the county prosecutor said he believed was related to marijuana trafficking at Fort Monmouth.

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: Revenue Sharing Assailed As Going to Wrong Places
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Some local officials who greeted the first influx of Federal revenuesharing funds with enthusiasm are now complaining that the money is going to the wrong places.

title: Brooklyn Woman Accused Of Killing Husband and Child
description: A 27yearold mother of five was charged with homicide yesterday after her husband and a 6yearold daughter were shot to death in their Brooklyn apartment. An infant son was also wounded, the police said. Like the others, he was shot once in the chest.

title: EXMAYOR DENIES TAKING ANY BRIBE
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 20 (AP) William Somers, a former Mayor of Atlantic City, denied in Federal court here today that he had taken a $5,000 payoff to approve a mercantile license for an Atlantic City auctiontype of business known as a jam joint.

title: Ted Gross Indicted
description: The city's former Youth Services Cominissioner, Ted Gross, was indicted yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury on charges of having accepted $41,400 in kickbacks during his 16 months in the post. Page 49.

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: E C.A.C. to Fight From Inside
description: The Eastern College Athletic Conference voted yesterday to maintain its membership on the United States Olympic Committee but, at the same time, elected to join the newly organized Committee for a Better Olympics, a group hoping to dispose of the present U.S.O.C.

title: Kretchmer, Seeking Mayoralty, Aims His First Blast at Lindsay
description: Jerome Kretchmer formally announced his candidacy for Mayor yesterday and charged that Mayor Lindsay, his former boss, has tolerated corruption.

title: 3 Children Killed in Crash
description: SUMMERVILLE, S.C., Feb. 20 (AP)  Three, young children were killed today when a van taking them to a day care center ran off a highway and struck a clump of pine trees, the authorities said. The driver and 30 other children were injured.

title: Some Heartbreaks Are Relined
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20Some days you eat the bear, Bobby Allison was saying, and some days the bear eats you. The Daytona 500 had been completed and now everyone was participating in the postmortems. It was all therethe rehashing of that final pit stop that helped Richard Petty in a Dodge to beat Buddy Baker in another Dodge, the secondguessing, the conjectures based on if we had. Petty was basking in the warmth of his fourth winning of the Daytona 500 (no other driver has won it more than once) and elsewhere around the track, heartbreak and cruel disappointment showed through the stoicism.

title: A Summary of Actions Taken Yesterday by the United States Supreme Court
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: TV SPECIAL NETS SEAGREN $39,700
description: ROTONDA, Fla., Feb. 20Bob Seagren, the 26year  old pole vaulter from California, entered the world of the pros today with a flourish and a bankroll when he defeated nine professional athletes in a miniOlympics among the palm trees of Florida's Gulf Coast.

title: Who Is Coopting Whom?
description: The proudest boast of American labor has been its freedom from any institutional ties to government. Even when labor's patron saint, Franklin D. Roosevelt, was in the White House the line between unionism and government was kept distincta separation necessary for the integrity of both.

title: SAFETY UNIT URGES SEAT BELTS IN BUSES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI) The Government proposed today tough, new safety standardsincluding possible use of beltsfor seats on buses.

title: Firestone Lifts Its Net to a Peak
Levy's Rise to Power: Totally Political Animal
description: Norman A. Levy's earliest remembered visit to City Hall occurred when he was 2 years old, and he sat on Fiorello H. La Guardia's lap.

title: Monopoly Charge Is Denied by I.B.M.
description: TULSA, Feb. 20 (AP)An attorney for the International Business Machines Corporation denied today an assertion by the Telex Corporation that I.B.M. had monopolized the computer field.

title: Dean at Drew Believes One Assailant a Student
description: MADISON, Feb. 20The dean of the College of Liberal Arts at Drew University said today that she believed that one of two masked men who assaulted her last week was a student.

title: 18 More P.O.W.'s Land in U.S After. Doing a Little Sightseeing
description: TRAVIS AIR FORCE BASE, Feb. 20 (UPI)Eighteen former prisoners of war came home 20 minutes late today because they did a little sightseeing over the Golden Gate Bridgetheir first sight of the United States mainland in more than five years.

title: Books of The Times
description: CALIFORNIA. The Vanishing Dream. By Michael Davie. 272 pages. Illustrated. Dodd, Mead. $7.95.

title: 7 U.S. Servicemen Get Guided Tour of Haiphong
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP)  Seven United States Navy men and marines were taken Sunday on a closely guided tour of Haiphong, North Vietnam's principal port, the Pentagon said today.

title: RATES UP BROADLY IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Interest rates rose across the board yesterday, reflecting continued negative appraisals of the devaluation of the dollar and the very rapid pace of business expansion. Trading activity was light. Treasury securities registered the sharpest price decline, with many bills spurting 10 to 17 basis points in rate and coupon securities falling by as much as  point. Bills suffered from reports that West Germany had begun to sell its accumulated dollars, reversing the recent pattern that had acted to depress bill rates, substantially.

title: Two Soldiers Killed in Belfast By Gunmen in a Catholic Area
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 20 Two British soldiers were shot dead tonight and another seriously wounded in a guerrilla ambush. Their jeep patrol was fired on in the Catholic Lower Falls area by at least four gunmen suspected of being members of the outlawed Irish Republican Army.

title: Records: Rock Revival
description: A heartening development In the rock 'n roll world of late has been the appreciation of things past. In a now industry that embraces controlled obsolescence with a passion, there has been over the last few years a real growth in rock revival.

title: Gross Once a Key Figure On Mayor's Street Team
description: In the days when cooling the neighborhoods was a major boast of the Lindsay administration, Ted Gross joined the tough, streetwise crew of fliply personable young men who served interchangeably as the Mayor's political advance team and the city's neighborhoodcrisis team.

title: Notes on People
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama is expected to be released from a Birmingham hospital this week, nearly a month after surgery to remove his prostate gland. Mr. Wallace will be returning home to Montgomery amid speculation that he is physically unable to function as Governor and still somewhat depressed about his condition.

title: Tanaka Regrets Float; Moves to Spur Imports
description: TOKYO, Feb. 20 (Reuters)Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan said today that his. Government gravely regretted floating the yen, but that it accepted full responsibility for the decision.

title: Two Citizens' Units Assail Mayor at Budget Hearings
description: The Citizens Budget Commission and the Commerce and Industry Association assailed the Lindsay administration yesterday for excessive, expenditures.

title: Some Gauges Show Easing For U.S. Economic Boom
description: The nation's booming economy may not be growing quite so rapidly as many analysts have been assuming, two key Government reports published yesterday indicated.

title: STEEL PRODUCTION FELL 0.1% IN WEEK
description: Steel production for the week ended last Saturday totaled 2,883,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a drop of 0.1 per cent from the 2,886,000 tons poured during the preceding week.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastem Standard Time

title: Segovia, at 80, Looks Disdainfully at Trends in Music
description: Andres Segovia is just an ordinary man, in the Henry Higgins sense, so why shopldn't he show an ordinary man's pride in what he has wrought? The grandee of the classic guitarwhose Philharmonic Hall recital today, the first of two there this season, will coincide with his 80th, birthdayall but twangs and vibrates with pleasure these days it mention of his son, Carlos Andres, a musically gifted young fellow.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: TITUSVILLE, N. J., Feb. 20A funny thing happened to Hilary Noden on her way to winning the New Jersey schoolgirl crosscountry title last fallshe almost was barred from the race.

title: Philosopher of Violin
description: In a way, Joseph Szigeti was the Schnabel of the violin. He came up in a day when the majority of celebrated violinists were of the Russian school, interested mostly in making beautiful sounds and titillating an audience with virtuoso or encore pieces. Szigeti would have none of this. It was indicative that among his earliest records were complete Bach partitas for unaccompanied violin and equally nonsalon music. He represented sobriety, musicianship, the sublimation of the man into music that he admitted was greater than he was.

title: Britain and France Defer JAL Option on Concorde
description: TOKYO, Feb. 20 (Reuters)Britain an France have deferred the deadline for Japan Air Lines to take up its option to purchase three Concorde supersonic airliners probably until the end of this year, a Japanese Government spokesman announced today.

title: Vishniac's Photos Shown at Fair Lawn
description: FAIR LAWN, Feb. 20The twin worlds of Dr. Roman Vishniac, scientist and humanist, are being shown at the Free Public Library here in a twopart exhibition of his work as an internationally known photographer.

title: A C.I.A. Analyst Dispute General in Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 20An affidavit by an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency, disputing a general's testimony, has emerged in the Pentagon paper's trial and led today to a defense demand that the chief prosecutor be removed from the case for misconduct.

title: Brandt Gets Plan to Restructure States
description: BONN, Feb. 20Chancellor Willy Brandt received a comprehensive proposal today for revision of West Germany's federal structure that would rediice the number of states from the present 10 to 5 or 6.

title: CAMBODIA PLANS A UNITED FRONT
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 20 (Reuters) President Lon Nol's Government and its nonCommunist opponents moved closer today to a united front for contacts with the Communists.

title: Mrs. Frisch, Boutique Owner, Is Married to Stanley Cohen
description: Mrs. Darcy M. Frisch, daughter of Mrs. Maurice Miller of New York and the late Mr. Miller, and Stanley Cohen of Johannesburg, South Africa, were married yesterday afternoon by Eric J. Braatvedt, Senior Magistrate of the District of Johannesburg Court.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: C.W. POST STREAK SNAPPED BY L. I. U.
description: Long Island University snapped C. W. Post College's 18game winning streak with a 6968 victory last night on the winner's court in Brooklyn.

title: VIETCONG AIDE URGES NEUTRAL TALKS SITE
description: PARIS, Feb. 20 (UPI)  A leading Vietcong official proposed today that highlevel talks to decide the political future of South Vietnam be held in a neutral zone in South Vietnam or in Paris.

title: Mets Will Open Training Camp To Eight NonRoster Players
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20The Mets will open their spring training camp to eight nonroster players Thursday, General Manager Bob Scheffing said today.

title: Adjusting City Taxes
description: The report of the State Commission of Investigation on the city's real estate tax assessment procedures touohes two separate but closely related issues.

title: SIX IN BRONX LINKED TO A CIGARETTE RING
description: Six men and 20,000 cartons of untaxed cigarettes were seized in a raid yesterday in a warehouse in the Bronx.

title: Music: Bruckner's Ninth
description: Fashions in music can be useful forces, however annoying they may seem from time to time. Buffeted by experiments and excesses, artists occasionally are driven onto a sensible course. Not too many years ago, when the Bruckner revival was beginning to attract young musicians, his symphonies often received square and almost brutal treatment. To many listeners, as a result, Bruckner seemed a thickskulled, clumsy Mahler, a kind of idiot savant of the symphony.

title: Relief Workers From City Area Find Their Trek Is Frustrating
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Lucy Cortez, the chairman of the board of directors of the Martin Luther King Health Center in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, was here for the second time in two weeks today trying to save the center, which is financed by the Office of Economic Opportunity and which, she said, will run out of money at the end of this month.

title: NUCLEAR PARLEY HITS SOVIET SNAG
description: GENEVA, Feb. 20The Soviet Union called today for the participation of China and France in negotiations on an accord to end all nuclear weapon testing.

title: BURNS VOWS END TO DEVALUATIONS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that, as far as I am concerned, this is the last devaluation of the dollar.

title: ADS ON CAB ROOFS BACKED BY LAZAR
description: Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, proposed legislation to the City Council yesterday to permit advertising on the outside of taxicabs.

title: Knicks Down Blazers, 110106
description: Dean Meminger and Jerry Lucas picked up the Knicks in vital spots last night to make up for a general team letdown and the very specific absence of Willis Reed, pacing a 110106 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers before a crowd of 19,558 at Madison Square Garden.

title: Kunstler Subpoenas Magazine Over Article on the Brown Case
description: William M. Kunstler, lawyer for H. Rap Brown, the black militant, in his trial on charges of armed robbery and attempted murder, subpoenaed New York magazine yesterday.

title: JERSEY AIDE SEES NO ENERGY CRISIS
description: TRENTON, Feb. 20The State Commissioner of Environmental Protection said today that while New Jersey did not yet have an energy crisis, it did have an energy problem that, to a considerable extent, industry had allowed to develop.

title: Downfall of a Judge
description: It is tragic enough that for the second time in history a judge of the United States Court of Appeals should be found guilty of felony. That the judge in question should be Otto Kerner is doubly tragic, since his reputation had appeared unassailable not only on the bench but in the considerably less rarefied world of Illinois politics.

title: Red Smith
description: Because he once rode a glass swizzle stick to an altitude of 18 feet 5 inches, people identify Robert Lloyd Seagren as a pole vaulter, but the fact is Slugger Seagren is a $39,700 beauty as a batsman, weight lifter, halfmiler and bicyclist. It just goes to show what a boy can do once he breaks away from Avery Brundage and starts taking his pay in broad daylight. It's fun with all that money up there, Seagren just got through saying on the phone. Really exciting. The world champion vaulter was talking from Rotonda West, Fla., a newborn town north of Fort Myers that is still wet behind the wallboard. He was one of 10 athletes from 10 different games engaged in a kinky promotion designed to push the sale of building lots in Rotonda West and make a television, show for the American Broadcasting Company. The show is called The Superstars and A.B.C. will put it on the air from 2 to 4 P.M. Sunday. Seagren's opponents were Joe Frazier, former heavyweight champion of the world; Johnny Bench, catcher for the Cincinnati Reds; Elvin Hayes of the National Basketball Association's Baltimore Bullets; Rod Laver, the tennis player; JeanClaude Killy, the skier; Johnny Unitas, a quarterback hovering midway between the Atlantic and the Pacific; Rod Gilbert, who skates with the New York Rangers; Peter Revson, auto racer, and Jim Stefanich, bowler.

title: C.&O. Acts to Broaden System And Form a Holding Company
description: The Chesapeake & Ohio Railway moved yesterday to broaden its transportation system and also to form a parent holding company, Chessie System, Inc., through which it could more fully develop its nonrailroad assets.

title: Whitehead Reiterates TV Policies
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Under intense questioning, Clay T. Whitehead today stuck by his proposal that broadcasters be made responsible for the content of network newscasts, but said he should have explained it better and used less colorful language in first presenting it.

title: PACT TO END WAR IN LAOS, INCLUDING POLITICAL PLAN, IS INITIALED BY TWO SIDES
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Wednesday, Feb. 21The Laotian Government and the Communistled Pathet Lao reached agreement this evening to end the war that has torn this country apart for the last decade.

title: Paradox in Brazil
description: Brazil, riding the crest of remarkable economic development, continues to be a country of paradox. The more it advances economically the more its military rulers feel compelled to resort to repression and censorship. As a recent dispatch to The Times has pointed out, Goveminent pressures have been steadily increasing against newspapers that stoutly refuse to impose selfcensorship on the basis of official guidelines.

title: Funds Allocated in Albany For Added Expenditures
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20The Legislature today approved a $210.7million deficiency budget authorizing additional expenditures for the current fiscal year that were not anticipated when the 197273 budget was approved last April 1.

title: Scott Calls Choice of Site For U. S. Offices Proper
description: Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Senate minority leader, described yesterday the selection of a new building in Philadelphia to house the regional headquarters of Federal socioeconomic agencies as the appropriate and proper result of lengthy public scrutiny and recommendations from civic leaders and government agencies.

title: Nixon Says Paris Accord Can Bring Lasting Peace
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 20President Nixon appealed today, in a 25minute address here, for public understanding of the motives for the settlement in Vietnam and its potential benefits.

title: A BELGIAN PHYSICIAN FREE PENDING TRIAL
description: BRUSSELS, Feb. 20A Belgian gynecologyst whose arrest Jan. 17 on charges of performin over 200 abortions touched off a wide debate on strict abortion laws here was released from prison today by a court.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n LAST NIGHTS GAMES
description: Carolina 123, New York 106. Dallas 119, Indiana 112. Memphis 107, Virginia 103.

title: IVAN SANDERSON, NATURALIST, DIES
description: COLUMBIA, N.J., Feb. 20 (AP)Ivan Sanderson, the author and naturalist, died yesterday of cancer. He was 62 years old and lived on a farm here.

title: EQUIT ABLE LIFE UNIT LEAVING OVER POWER
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society discolsed yesterday that it was moving half of its $25million computer operations out of the city because it could not depend on Consolidated Edison and the New York Telephone Company to meet future demends.

title: Rhodesia Seizes White Journalist at His Home
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 20 (Reuters)A freelance journalist, Peter Niesewand, today became the first Rhodesian white to be detained under the country's emergency laws since the former Prime Minister Garfield Todd and his daughter were taken into custody in January, 1972.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: SEASONED The New York City Opera comes back for; its 57th season tonight at 7 with Rosenkavalier, at the New York State Theater, 63d Street and Broadway (TR 74700). The company, which performs just across the Lincoln Center patio from the Met, is scheduling 21 operas (23, if you count the doublebill operas separately) for the 10 weeks through April 19.

title: City's Tax Chief Denies State Charge of Abuses
description: Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, yesterday denounced as a grubby political gambit a state investigation report charging irregularities in realestate tax assessments here.

title: PRICES DROP A BIT ON HEX AND OTC
description: A moderate early advance in prices of stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange and in the overthecounter market yesterday dissipated in the afternoon and prices finished slightly lower in moderate trading.

title: Nixon Says Paris Accord Can Bring Lasting Peace
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Feb. 20President Nixon appealed today, in a 25minute address here, for public understanding of the motives for the settlement in Vietnam and its potential benefits.

description: To the Editor:

title: GREECE FINDS 2 GUILTY AS REBELS
description: ATHENS, Feb. 20A Greek war hero and a wellknown physician were sentenced to prison terms today on charges of planting bombs in protest against the Greek Government.

title: EXCESS DOLLARS LEAVING GERMANY
description: LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP)West Germany today began unloading some of the billions of dollars that poured in during the monetary crisis ended last week with the devaluation of the United States currency.

title: Senators Urge Delay in Debate On Hanoi Aid Till Pullout Ends
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20Senate leiders of both parties urged today that debate on American aid to North Vietnam be put off until United States troops and prisoners were safely out of Indochina.

title: Two Girls Drowned in Fall Through Ice in Connecticut
description: TRUMBULL, Conn., Feb. 20 (UPI)  Two young girls drowned yesterday when they apparently fell through thin Ice on a duck pond here, the police reported.

title: KISSINGER REPORTS TO NIXON ON TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (UPI)  Henry A. Kissinger returned to the United States today and went directly to the White House to report to President Nixon on his twoweek trip to North Vietnam, China and Japan.

title: PACE AT YONKERS TO HAIL TO ROMEO
description: YONKERS, Feb. 20  An excellent drive by Carmine Abbatiello, who had his mount pacing behind cover through most of the mile, helped Hail to Romeo, a New Yorkbred chestnut 4yearold, to register a victory over Diarac in tonight's featured claiming allowance pace for a gross purse of $8,000.

title: Instead of Potato Chips, the Children Tried Bananas Dipped in Wheat Germ
description: Three and fouryear olds at the Henry Street Settlement Day Care Center were fixing refreshments to serve at an, open house for their parents on a recent morning, but not a cookie, cupcake, soda or potato chip was in sight.

title: Verdun Cemetery Guarded in Search For Petain's Coffin
description: PARIS, Feb. 20 (Reuters)The police sealed off the Douaumont military cemetery at Verdun today on the theory that those who stole the coffin of Philippe Ptain might try to rebury the hero  turned  traitor. among France's honored war dead.

title: Assembly Votes, Primary June 4 and Runoff June 26
description: ALBANY, Feb. 20After complaints from some upstate legislators, as well as from Republicans from Nassau County, Brooklyn and Queens, the Assembly passed a bill today providing for a statewide primary on June 4 and a runoff in New York City on June 26 if it is needed in the races for Mayor, Controller and City Council President.

title: 2 Chief Gangs in Japan Merge; Police Act to Curb New Efforts
description: TOKYO, Feb. 20 (AP)The two principal rival gangs in Japan's underworld have merged and are trying to infiltrate legitimate business, and the police have begun a drive to stop them.

description: Page

title: $6Million Suit Filed in Suffolk Over Sale of Tiana Beach Land
description: RIVERHEAD, L.I., Feb. 20A $6million civil damage suit was filed today by a Suffolk County taxpayer in connection with the county's purchase of 295 acres of land at Tiana Beach in Hampton Bays in which three public officials and a realestate broker are under indictment.

title: New Books
description: GENERALA Land of Our Own: An Oral Autobiography by Golda Meir, edited by Marie Syrkin (Putnam, $6.95).

title: Track With Gold Cargo Stolen in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, Feb. 20Soon after Louis Oulette pulled off the Connecticut Turnpike near Milford this morning for a cup of coffee, he set off a statewide police alarm by announcing that someone had driven off with his truck load of gold and other precious metals.

title: Litton Gets Navy GoAhead to Purchase $182Million Worth of Components for Seven More Destroyers
description: After a month's delay, the Navy announced yesterday that it had authorized Litton Industries to start buying $182milIon worth of components for seven more DD963class destroyers to be built at its controversial automated shipyard in Pascagoula, Miss.

title: CELTICS TRIUMPH OVER SUNS, 10797
description: BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP)The Boston Celtics, led by John Havlicek, Paul Silas and Dave Cowens, gained their seventh consecutive Victory today, a 10797 triumph over the Phoenix Suns.

title: Senate Approves More Aid for Elderly
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 20The Senate, over the opposition of the Nixon Administration passed legislation today that would provide additional social services and employment as sistance to the elderly.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Orders to End Vietnam Fighting Reportedly Not Sent to Military
description: PLEIKU, South Vietnam, Feb. 21American and South Vietnamese officers said today that no one in the crucial central provinces of South Viennam had been ordered to stop fighting.

title: A NEW METHOD PUTS MEDICINE INTO BRAIN
description: Psychiatric researchers are developing a new technique to implant medicine directly in a specific area of the brain, a psychiatrist reported yesterday.

description: FIRST GAME7 P.M.

title: Pershing Missiles Fired
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 21 (UPI)  Pershing missile troops from the Army returned home after a 10year asbsence and fired four rockets to Atlantic Ocean target areas today in a successful test of their combat readiness. The 35foot, needlenosed missiles were blasted from mobile launchers flown here last week with 120 soldiers from the seventh Army in Heilbronn, Germany.

title: CITY SUES TO REGAIN SALE SCHEME FUNDS
description: The city's Consumer Affairs Department filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court to recover $3.5million allegedly lost by investors in a pyramid sales scheme promoted by a West Coast concern.

title: 200 Are Feared Dead as a Ferry Sinks After Collision at Rangoon
description: RANGOON, Burma, Thursday, Feb. 22 (Reuters)More than 200 people are feared dead following a collision in the Rangoon River between crowded ferry and a Japanese freighter last night.

title: City Halts Camp Plan For Youths
description: A citysponsored winter camping program for underpriviliged children has been suspended after the death of an 11yearold. South Bronx girl who struck a tree stump while sliding down a ski slope in a saucer sled.

title: Equity Financing
description: A public offering of cue million shares of beneficial interest of First Commerce Realy Investors was sold yesterday at $25 a share by group led by Goldman, Sachs & Co. and Kohlmeyer & Co. First Commerce Realty is a New Orleans real estate investment trust sponsored by the First Commerce Corporation, bank holding company Louisiana.

title: Only One Side Rejoices
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Thursday, Feb. 22While the peace accord signed in Laos yesterday hears a strong family resemblance to the accord signed on Vietnam last month, the Communist side here seems to have won the lion's share of the bargain.

title: '72 Revenues Up 2.8%
description: The Penn Central Transportation Company yesterday announced a net loss of $222,829,250 for 1972. The size of the loss was somewhat of moral victory for the nation's largest railroad, which had net loss of $560,152,752 in 1971.

title: An Illegal Fur Ring Broken Up Here by U.S.
description: Federal authorities said yesterday that half the illegal trade by Americans in the pelts of endangered wild animals had been disrupted with the breaking up of a ring of skin traffickers.

title: Two Wail St. Firms Undergo Changes
description: Two old names in the securities industry underwent major changes yesterday.

title: Senate Passes Bills, Opposed by President, for Power Loans and Airport Guards
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Senate continued today to pass by wide margins politically, popular legislative programs that the Nixon Administration believes are too costly and unwise.

title: Antitrust Suit Challenges Mutual Fund Sales Setup
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Justice Department filed an antitrust suit today charging conspiracy and challenging the legal right of the mutual fund industry to sell its shares solely in the way that it traditionally has done.

title: Over Dares Scores at Yonkers With Filion as Substitute Driver
description: YONKERS, Feb. 21Offtrack bettors took the worst of it tonight, when Herve Filion, the North American harnessdriving champion over the last five years, was named to drive Over Dares in the third race at Yonkers Raceway.

title: How 20 Pounds of Meat and Bones Becomes 2 Quarts of Sauce
description: Cooking, the most conservative of the arts, has recently been going through a revolutionary period in France. A group of young chefs have redefined and purified the traditions of classic cooking, but the cookbooks have not yet caught up with them.

title: Morning After Contraceptive To Get Approval in Some Cases
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21The Food and Drug Administration will approve the use of diethylstilbestrol, or DES, as a morning after contraceptive pill for women in emergency situatons such as rape, Commissioner Charles C. Edwards disclosed today.

title: New Books
description: A History of Pottery, by Emmanuel Cooper (St. Martin's Press, $12.95).

title: 16 Charged With Beating Bar Patron in Argument
description: Sixteen persons were arrested early yesterday morning and charged with beating a man at the New World Bar, at 150 West 47th Street.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Marcel Marceau is returning to New York's City Center of Music and Drama for a threeweek engagement starting April 17. The French pantomimist, now on a fivemonth tour that includes performances in 65 cities in the United States and Canada, will offer several new pieces, among the A Sunday Walk, Tango, Small Cafe and The Dream.

title: Senate Approves Kyl Post
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) The Senate approved yesterday the White House's nomination of John H. Kyl, a former Republican Representative from Iowa who was defeated for reelection last November, as Assistant Secretary of the Interior.

title: Stern Says Legislation Can't Wipe Out Kickbacks
description: TRENTON, Feb. 21Herber J. Stern, United States Attorney for New Jersey, said today the no competitive bidding law could eliminate contract kick backs or corruption among local officials, but he proposed the the contract  letting procedure be strengthened and that pen alties for violators be increased.

description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon, Feb. 21An Israeli attack by amphibious and airborne forces early today seriously damaged commando offices, warehouses and schools at two Palestinian refugee camps near here.

title: GOLD PRICE SOARS TO ALMOST $80
description: PARIS, Feb. 21The price of gold soared by almost $3 to nearly $80 an ounce today, setting yet another record as it continued the spectacular advance started Feb. 13 when the dollar was devalued for the second time in 14 months.

title: HIGH COURT EASES DISTRICTING RUIN FOR LEGISLATURES
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 The Supreme Court said today that its oneman onevote mandate need not be applied so strictly to state legislative districts as to Congressional reapportionment.

title: Washington and Slavery
description: The record in relation to George. Washington is a conspicuous demonstration of how black history has been neglected. One example: the twovolume index to the thirtynine volume set of Washington's Writings specifies almost everything except the names of slaves.

title: PROF. ELSA EHRENSTEIN
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 21Prof. Elsa Meyer Ehrenstein, a retired member of the department of pharmacy at the Philadelphia College of Pharmacy and Science, and the widow of Dr. Maximilian Ehrenstein, professor of biochemistry there, died here Friday. She was 71 years old.
