title: TV Industry Adopts Strictures Limiting Commercials on Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) Television industry leaders today announced strong and sweeping rules regulating the television advertising of nonprescription medications, effective Sept. 1.

title: Federal Aide Seeks to End Philadelphia School Strike
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 (UPt)Assistant Secretary of Labor William J. Usery Jr. stepped into the seventhweekold strike of teachers today, caring for fall parties concerned to halt public announcements about the walkout.

title: Across the Sand, Debris of Disaster
description: IN THE SINAI DESERT, Near the Suez Canal, Feb. 22 At 2 P.M. today, weary Israeli soldiers finished the gruesome job of extricating 100 dead passengers and crewmen from the Libyan airliner shot down by Israeli jets here yesterday.

title: Supplier Denies Atlantic City Kickbacks
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 22 (AP) A heavyequipment supplier testified in Federal Court here today that his company sold about $50,000 worth of equipment annually to Atlantic City, and that to his knowledge city officials had never demanded or received 10 per cent kickbacks on the contracts.

title: Mackell Called to Testify Today by Nadjari Jurors
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell has been subpoenaed by a special state grand jury investigating the way his office handled a case in which some of his staff members were involved.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Bridge: Charity Tournament to Have ThreeSession Pair Contest
description: One of the most ambitious charity bridge tournaments ever held in New York City will be played this weekend in aid of the Muscular Dystrophy Associations.

title: STATE BATTLE DUE FOR CHIEF JUDGE
description: The first political, party battle since 1916 for the post of chief judge of the State Court of Appeals began yesterday with the announcement by State Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein that he was seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: Reputed Mafia Chieftain and 5 Others Are Held in U.S. LoanSharking Case
description: Frank Tied, the reputed acting boss of one of New York's five Mafia families, was arrested yesterday with five alleged associates on loansharking charges.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Up at 12Month Sale
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Music
description: Although Charles Wuorinen is still afew months short of being 3.5 years old, the Pulitzer prizewinning composer has been so prolific that a new work by him might not seem particularly newsworthy. But Speculum, Speculi, the piece given its first New York performance by Speculum Musicae at Carnegie Recital Hall on Wednesday night, made so forceful an impression that it could hardly be ignored even by those who do not care for contemporary music.

title: BUCKS DEFEAT KINGS In OVERTIME, 116113
description: OMAHA, Feb. 22 (AP)Jon McGlocklin hit two straight baskets from the baseline in a 13second span to lift the Milwaukee Bucks to a 116113 overtime victory over the Kansas CityOmaha Kings tonight in a National Basketball Association game.

title: Belfast I. R. A. Leader Escapes For the 2d Time in 14 Months
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 22 (Reuters)A leading member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army made a break from prison here today, his second in 14 months.

title: Sporadic Art Dealer
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 When Dikran A. Sarrafian's two children married, he asked them not to name any sons they might have after him as is the Armenian custom. There is nothing about me worth perpetuating, he said candidly over straight Scotch today at the St. Georges Hotel bar. I wasted most of my life with whores and archeologists. Mr. Sarrafian, whose recounted experiences sound like those of a character in a Lawrence Durrell novel, has been a center of attention in the art world in both Europe and the United States during the last, three day.

title: Obscene Magazines Draw $3,500 Fine
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 22 (UPI)Liberty National Distributors, Inc., of Astoria. Queens, was fined $3,500 in Nassau County Court today for supplying more than 100 varieties of obscene magazines to stores in Nassau county.

title: Petain's Coffin Reburied on Prison Isle in Atlantic
description: PARIS, Feb. 22The remains of Philippe Main, who died 22 yeah ago at the age of 95, were returned to their grave today after the police had recovered them from political kidnappers.

title: 'Charlotte's Web' Opens at Music Hall
description: Some years ago when it was announced that henceforth all children's records would be made of unbreakable plastic, a friend of minea father with a special hatred for the nursery rhyme orchestrated and sungpredicted madness for parents and illiteracy for children."I could always count on the kids breaking the records faster than we could buy them," he said. "Now they'll accumulate . . . by the roomfuls. Imagine entire collections of Mother Goose! They'll forget how to read."I always remember how parents and children survived that technological breakthrough when I see a film like "Charlotte's Web," Hanna-Barbera's animated feature based on the funny, sad, lean novel that E. B. White wrote for childrenand for anyone else interested in the elements of style in the English language. Parents will survive it, and so will their children."Charlotte's Web" is not really bad in the way that the archy and mehitabel film was bad. It's not a distortion. It's just a big, bland-looking cartoon feature with a musical score by Richard M. Sherman and Robert B. Sherman that sounds like any number of other Sherman scores ("Mary Poppins," "Chitty-Chitty Bang Bang").The music and the pictorial style, which seems to be a blend of early Grant Wood and late Max Fleischer, are exceedingly uninteresting, but though they blunt the precise effects of Mr. White's prose, they don't obliterate them. Probably enough of the original feeling is left to prompt the child of elegant taste to look into the book for himself, to read pure White and to look at the scratchy, rather harried, utterly charming Garth Williams illustrations.Earl Hamner Jr., who wrote the screen play, has followed the original so closely that it's still possible to be moved by the story of Charlotte, the spider who devotes her entire life (one spring, summer and fall) to saving the life of Wilbur, the stout-hearted pig who would otherwise have been turned into ham, bacon and pork chops.Charlotte's method is the word. As Wilbur preens on the ground below, Charlotte calls attention to him by weaving "SOME PIG" into her web above. Later she writes "TERRIFIC," then "RADIANT," though she's not convinced that Wilbur's action is as radiant as that of the detergent whose box supplied the inspiration."Charlotte's Web" is about friendship, vanity, love, birth and death, all of the things, in fact, that make life worth living, even in a barnyard. While the film version is told principally in terms of syrupy songs and pictures, enough of the text remains to occassionally please the curmudgeon.There is, for example, the healthy cynicism of old Templeton, the rat (whose personality is perfectly projected in the voice of Paul Lynde). "Play? Play?" Templeton screams in answer to Wilbur's invitation. "I'm a glutton but not a merrymaker!"The one sequence in which music, pictures and original property come to some kind of happy accord is the one in which we follow Templeton's night-long debauch on soggy spun sugar, old franks, watermelon and corn cobs at the county fair.For most of the rest of the time, we have to compromise. Fern, the little girl who adopts Wilbur when he is first born, has apparently been drawn to look like the adult Julie Andrews with very short arms and legs. The animals are somewhat more attractive, though styleless, and Charlotte has remarkably blue eyes for a movie spider. The major voices are supplied by Debbie Reynolds (Charlotte), Henry Gibson (Wilbur) and Agnes Moorehead (The Goose)."Charlotte's Web" opened yesterday at Radio City Music Hall. I have very mixed feelings about most of it, but not its ending, which are the closing lines of Mr. White's book: "She was in a class by herself. It's not often that someone comes along who is a true friend and a good writer. Charlotte was both." It's difficult to hate anything with such style, even if it's borrowed.

title: McGovernDrive Leader Joins Coffee's Campaign
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22Anne C. Martindell, the titular leader of the forces that supported Senator George McGovern in New Jersey for the Presidency, announced today that she was taking leave as vice chairman of the Democratic State Committee to support former State Senator Richard J. coffee's campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: Arab Nations Outraged; Soviet Denounces Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Arab capitals expressed horror and outrage at the downing yesterday of a Libyan airliner intercepted by Israeli fighter planes.

title: Gulf Oil to Buy 10 Million Of Its Shares at $26 Each
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation's directors yesterday authorized the purchase of 10 million shares, or almost 5 per cent, of its outstanding common stock through tenders at $26 a share. The tender offer, the company said, will be made as soon as practicable and will remain open for about 20 days. Gulf Oil shares, which closed on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday at $26, up 75 cents a share, had a book value as of Sept. 30, 1972, of $25.47 a share.

title: IRENE BARLOW
description: Irene Barlow, who served in 1961 as a United States delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Wednesday of cancer in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.

title: PLAYERS, OWNERS ARE NEAR ACCORD
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners and players went their separate ways after their meeting yesterday, but they were closer together than at any time since they began talking last September.

title: Kugler, in Turnabout, Describes His Link to Stern as Excellent
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr., in an apparent contradiction of his earlier testimony to the State Commission of Investigation, said today that he had an excellent working relationship with Herbert J. Stern, the United States Attorney for New Jersey.

title: Orders in January For Durable Goods Rose to Peak Level
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 New orders for durable goods rose sharply in January after a small dip in December, the Commerce Department reported on the basis of preliminary figures.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FAMILY STYLE The Romeros, guitarpluckers extraordinaire, are back in town for the first time in almost two years. The quartet, father and three sons, are playing at 8 tonight in Philharmonic Hall, 65th Street and Broadway (TR 42424). One of the virtuosi's virtues is their ability to perform both classical and flamenco guitar, which they will do today in a program consisting of Bach, Scarlatti and such classicists plus a menu of traditional flamenco, folk and modern music. The Spanish guitarists, who now have headquarters on the West Coast, first met the American public a decade ago. They have since performed with symphonies and on television and records. This New York engagement is at the midpoint of their annual coasttocoast tour, which calls for 75 appearances either in recitals or with symphony orchestras. Admission, $3 to $6. Sunday, at 8:30, the Roineros cross the East River to perform at Queens College's Colden Auditorium, Kissena Bouleyard and Long Island Expressway (4457676). Admission $3.50, $4, $4.50. Free parking.

title: One Killed and 3 Injured In a Plane Crash Upstate
description: PALENVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 22 (UPI)One person was killed, but three others with injuries walked away from the crash of their singleengine plane in the Catskill Mountains near this Greene County community, the state police said today.

title: ExStockbroker And Yachtsman Dies of Gunsh
description: CENTER ISLAND, L.WI., F 22The body of John Park son Jr., a retired stockbrol and yachtsman, was found t?? morning in the den of his room mansion here.

title: Mayor Washington Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP)  President Nixon presided over the swearingin today of Mayor Walter Washington for a third term as the chief executive of the nation's capital. In the ceremonies in the Oval Office, Mr. Nixon said that Mayor Washington's leadership has become indispensable.

title: MEMBERS OF AFTRA ACCEPT NEW PACTS
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists announced yesterday that its membership had ratified, by overwhelming votes, new singleyear contracts with the three major TVradio networks and new threeyear pacts covering TV commercials and radio transcriptions.

title: Business Briefs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)Interest costs on eenventional home mortgages rose slightly in January on average to 7.68 per centon new singlefamily homes and 7.60 per cent on previously occupied homes, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Israeli Deplores Tragedy
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 22Defense Minister Moshe Dayan today described the loss of life in the downing yesterday of a Libyan airliner over the Sinai desert as a tragedy, but he said that the blame lay with the pilot because he ignored repeated instructions to land.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Thieu Fears Supply Flow Despite the Laos Truce
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Feb. 23  President Nguyen Thieu said yesterday that he welcomed the truce in neighboring Laos.as complementary to the ceasefire in Vietnam.

title: Amex Issues at 14Month Low; Shares on OTC Decline Again
description: With prices closing at their lowest level in more than 14 months, turnover on the American Stock Exchange was relatively light again yesterday.

title: Kissinger TV Interview Due
description: The National Broadcasting Company will film an exclusive interview with Henry A. Kissinger at the White House today, for televising Sunday at 10:30 P.M. Interviewing the Presidential aide will be Barbara Walters, who said she planned, to question Mr. Kissinger not only about his recent journey to Hanoi, Peking and Tokyo but also about his personal plans for the future.

title: DESALES HARRISON
description: CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 22 (AP)DeSales Harrison, a farmer board chairman of the CocaCola Butting Company (Thomas), died yesterday at his Lookout Mountain home. He was 72 years old.

title: Fingerprints Found on Papers, Witness Tells Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 Deemer E. Hippensteel, a retired Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, testified today that he had found the fingerprints of Daniel Ellsberg, Anthony J. Russo Jr., Lynda Sinay, Resnick and Dr. Ellsberg's son, Robert, then 13 years old, on the Pentagon papers that were removed from the Rand Corporation.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Federal judge gave sixmonth prison sentences yesterday to two towtruck operators who had done ur lercover work for the Knapp Commission, saying that he could not suspend sentence because perjury goes to the very heart of the judicial process. The defendants, who were convicted Jan. 11 in their second trial, were George C. Burkert, 25 years old, of 3362 10th Street, and Vincent Wright, 24, of 3811 33d Street, both Long Island City and employed by an auto body shop there.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The New York Pro Musica, the chamber music group, played Bach, a change from their usual emphasis on medieval and Renaissance music. Then the amplifiers were plugged in and the sound switched to rock. The harpsichord and music stands were swept away and aloe stage was filled with rhythmically gyrating figures in clothes that vibrated with color.

title: Kuwait Denies Any Speculation Against Dollar During Crisis
description: Salim S. Al Sabah, Kuwait's Atnbassador to the United States, said yesterday that his country. did not speculate. against the, dollar during the recent monetary crisis that resulted in the devaluation of the dollar.

title: Net Fund Redemptions Declined During January
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (Reuters)  Redemptions of mutualfund shares topped sales by $130.6million in January, compared with $170.1million in December, the Investment Company Institute reported today.

title: Robyn Smith Is Unhurt In Spill at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP)Rohyn Smith, 28yearold jockey who says she's never been hurt in a spill, escaped injury today when she fell from her stumbling mount in the third race at Santa Anita Park.

title: Kennedy Puts in Gun Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, proposed today the licensing of every civilianowned gun in the country. In a Senate speech introducing his Personal Safety Firearms Act of 1973, he said that he would require all gun owners to pass stringent quailtying procedures for a license and ban domestic manufacture of hand guns not designed for sporting purposes.

title: Battle Set for State Chief Judge, First for This Post Since 1916
description: The first political party battie since 1916 for the post of chief judge of the State Court of Appeals began yesterday with the announcement by State Supreme Court Justice Irwin R. Brownstein that he was seeking the Democratic nomination.

title: Camden Mayor Decides Not to Seek ReElection
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 22 (UPI)Citing the pressures of the job, Mayor Joseph M. Nardi Jr. announced today that he would not seek election to another fouryear term next May 8.

title: U.S. Still Hopes for ArabIsraeli Dialogue
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 On the eve of an important round of EgyptianAmerican talks, the Nixon Administration sought today to keep alive the possibility of starting an IsraeliArab dialogue toward peace despite the heightened tensions caused by Israel's downing of a Libyan airliner yesterday.

title: Winthrop Rockefeller Is Dead at 60
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Feb. 22Winthrop Rockefeller, former Governor of Arkansas and a grandson of the oilman John D. Rockefeller, died this morning at Desert Hospital in this Southern California resort community, where he had a winter home. His age was 60.

title: Classic European Food at a Brazilian Resturant
description: Restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: ELIZABBTH BOWEN, NOVELIST, DEAD
description: LONDON, Feb. 22Elizabeth Bowen, the novelist, died today in a London hospital. She was 73 years old.

title: Red Smith
description: Whatever gains are achieved, or damage done, in the current contract dispute between the baseball players and the men who own them, there has already been at least one result. Any misconceptions about the role of the commissioner that may haye lingered in the minds of fans have been eliminated. On two or three occasions since the haggling began, Bowie Kuhn has abandoned the pretense of neutrality and has issued press releases presenting the owners' side to the public. No longer can there be any illusion that the commissioner's office is a court of last appeal or its occupant an impartial magistrate or a house dick riding herd on the bosses to protect the players from exploitation. From here out everyone must accept Kuhn for what he has been ever since he was hiredhis employers' mouthpiece, a front man, a figurehead.

title: ROSEN PERFORMS MUSIC BY BOULEZ
description: The Contemporary Music Series at the New. York Cultural Center made it possible on Wednesday night to hear Charles Rosen in one of his rare New York recitals. The pianist had carved, out an illuminating and rewarding program. Between the Trope and Constellation sections of Pierre Boulez's Third Sonata, he played Sehbenberg's Six Little Pieces (Op, 19). After that came Three Etudes of Bartk, and Elliott Carter's Sonata rightfully had the second half of the evening to itself.

title: 7% PRICE RISE SET FOR VOLKSMAGEN
description: A 7 per cent average increase of prices on Volkswagen cars was announced yesterday along with indications that the prices of Japanese and other imported cars would soon be raised.

title: Stock Market Declines As Trading Volume Dips
description: A few negative news items helped send stock prices lower yesterday for the second consecutive session. Trading was slow.

title: LILLY CAMPBELL
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22 (AP)  Lilly Campbell, a major league catcher for the Chicago Cubs, Cincinnati Reds and Brooklyn Dodgers, died yesterday in a hospital here. He was 65 years old.

title: Notes on People
description: The issue of the advantages or disadvantages of being a Kennedy emerged again in San Francisco and Washington, In, San Francisco, a city supervisor questioned the hiring by the health department of 20yearold. Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, the son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy. The supervisor, John L. Molinari, said, I'm wondering as to why this particular person was hired. There may be other people who are better qualified.

title: A Warning to Dental Patients Issued by Pennsylvania Official
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 22 (AP)Pennsylvania's insurance commissioner has warned dental patients against having their teeth capped just so the teeth look like Chiclets.

title: Panama Pot
description: MEXICO CITYHaving broken the back of its Indochina war entanglement the United States clearly hoped to focus foreign policy attentions on relations with Western Europe and Japan this year because of the com plex trade, monetary and defense problems existing with those vital areas.

title: HEAD OF NEGRO FUND SAID TO FACE OUSTER
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Arthur A. Fletcher, executive. director of the United Negro College Fund, has been asked to resign by the, board of directors, sources close to the fund said here today.

title: Agency Sets Gas Drilling as Condition of Price Rises for Producer
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22  A divided Federal Power Commission has approved higher prices for a Texas natural gas producer on the condition the producer drill exploratory wells. It was the first time the agency allowed a producer to raise prices as an incentive to explore.

title: Advice on Asia
description: WASHINGTONHaving exerted their influence in Asia for the last 27 years, American forces are, in the name of the Nixon Doctrine, gradually withdrawing from Asia, thereby leaving behind the domino tendency of military dictatorship. The proud history of American democracy may not record this act kindly but also will in time inflict pain on the conscience of the American people; for with power comes responsibility. In the moment of hopelessness and of unfulfilled dreams, freedomloving Asians will reflect on the valued friendship with America with bitterness.

title: Jersey City State Defeats Montclair for League
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 22Jersey State captured its first New Jersey State lege Conference basketball championship in eight years night by trouncing Monteclair Slate, 8762. The Gothics pleted the conference with 82 wonlost mark and 159 for the season.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: PRICES OF BONDS SAKE A REBOUND
description: The bond market staged a modest rebound yesterday following several sessions of skidding prices. Activity remained light, however, and there were few in Wall Street who maintained that any basic change, had occurred to attract inflationconscious investors. They money markets also were subdued, with rates Credit on Treasury bills moving slightly Markets lower and Federal, funds  overnight, loans between banks of uncommitted reserves traded relatively comfortably at 6.6.

title: 4 Harlem Students Urge Funds For School for Disadvantaged
description: Four East Harlem teenagers pleaded yesterday for funds for Park East High School, an experimental pilot school serving some 300 disadvantaged youngsters.

title: Students in Athens End SitIn After Professors Pledge Help
description: ATHENS, Feb. 22 Two thousand students gave up their occupation of the law school of Athens University tonight after professors had agreed to take their demands to officials of the armybacked regime.

title: Man Jailed 22 Years in Smashing of a Window Sues Pennsylvania
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22 Armando Beltrante is 44 years old but seems much younger, almost boyish. He is plump and gregarious and talks almost incessantly, using phrases like deprivation of civil rights that sound oddly out of place in his fractured discourse.

title: Advertising: General Mills Shift
description: General Mills has moved most of its business (estimated at between $6million and $10million in billings) out of Knox Reeves Advertising  and spread it among three of its other agenciesWells, Rich, Green, New York, Needham, Harper & Steers, Chicago, and CampbellMithun, Minneapolis.

title: Price Index Is Up Sharply On Record Grocery Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Propelled by the largest onemonth increase in grocery prices on record, the Consumer Price Index rose sharply in January, the Labor Department reported today.

title: J.D.L. Ends SitIn After Promise By Churches to Study Demands
description: Ten members of the Jewish Defense League yesterday ended a sitin of more than 24 hours at, offices of the Mork] Council of Churches at 475 Riverside Drive after a council official said serious disussion would take place soon between Christian and Jewish leaders in the city on issues raised by the group.

title: IRENE BARLOW
description: Irene Barlow, who served in 1961 as a United States delegate to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Wednesday of cancer in the Harkness Pavilion of the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 59 years old and lived at 530 East 23d Street.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: Stage: Penthouse Legend, a Courtroom Drama
description: A man falls to his death from a Manhattan penthouse. Did he jump, or was he pushed? Was he, indeed, the body the police thought he was? A man can get awfully mussed up on the long fall to the sidewalk.

title: FIRE RUINS OFFICE OF COLLEGE HEAD
description: POMONA, Feb. 22A fire of suspicious origin virtually destroyed the log cabin office building of the president of Stockton State College late last night.

title: Bowie Entries
description: BOWIE, MD.

title: Ovations Greet Segovia at 80th Birthday Recital
description: Andres Segovia's 80th birthday recital at Philharmonic Hall on Wednesday night began with long, affectionate ovations before the Spanish guitarist had even touched finger to string. At the end of the scheduled program, a female voice called out, Happy birthday, and the greeting was taken up all the soldout hall.

title: William McNicol, 86, Dies; A Former Bank Officer
description: William J. McNicol, who retired in 1952 as a trust officer of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died Wednesday at the age of 86. He lived on Beardsley Lane in Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I.

title: Brewer, Fezler Share Lead in Golf With 67's
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 22Gay Brewer scored a fiveunderpar 67 today to share the firstround lead in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary golf tournament with Forrest Fezler, a 23yearold nonwinner on the pro tour.

title: EVEN THE HEATS LOOK OLYMPIAN
description: If quality entries are a per formance yardstick, tonight's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships may be the finest track and field meet since the Munich Olympics.

title: State Questions Levy Further In Inquiry on Tax Assessments
description: The State Commission of Investigation yesterday called in Norman A. Levy, the president of the city's Tax Commission, and questioned him further in connection with what it has portrayed as widespread irregularities and inequities in the city's realestate tax asstssments.

title: News Summay and Index
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Nixon Economic Message Defends Social Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22President Nixon, in his economic state of the union message, told Congress today that his budget spending soared in the last fair years in programs aiding the poor, the sick, the aged and the hungry, with increases ranging from 66 to 242 per cent in those areas.

title: The Western Hat Is Starting to Ride High in These Parts, Too
description: Virtue may flourish in an old cravat. But man and nature scorn the shocking hat.

title: DEATH PENALTY SET BY GEORGIA SENATE
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 22 (UPI)The State Senate voted 47 to 7 today to restore capital punishment in Georgia.

title: Nat'l Hockey League
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: Carlton Cigarettes Rated Low by F.T.C. In Tar and Nicotine
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) The Federal Trade Commission said today that the tar content of 134 varieties of domestic cigarettes tested in January ranged from 1 to 34 milligrams.

title: People in Sports: Yanks Sign Old and New Faces
description: Ron Blomberg, who batted .268 and hit 14 homers in 107 games last season, and Ron Swoboda, who hit .248 and one homer in 63 games, signed their Yankee contracts yesterday. Blomberg, who produced 49 runs batted in, will be getting paid close to $30,000 for his firstbase chores. Swoboda signed for about $45,000 as one of Ralph Houk's platoon of designated pinchhitters. The Yankees also signed two rookies from their West Haven, Conn., farm of the Eastern League. They are Rick Earle, a righthanded pitcher who won 11 and lost 5 in 1972, and George Zeber, a second baseman, who hit .267.

title: A.P. President Cites Greater Difficulties In Reporting News
description: News reporting became more difficult last year than at any time since World War II because of censorship, harassment of reporters and a spreading cloak of secrecy, the president of The Associated Press charged yesterday.

title: LAOTIAN REPORTS COMMUNIST DRIVE
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 23 Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier of Laos, charged this morning that Communist forces had launched a general offensive throughouf his country following yesterday's ceasefire, and that if the Communist attack continued he would ask for renewed American bombing.

title: SHAPIRO TO RETIRE 14YEAROLD MARE
description: YONKERS, Feb. 22It is not often that a 15yearold pacer or trotter is turned from racing to serving as a broodmare. Too many years of competition, it appears, take too much out of a mare and too many that have tried have proved to be barren.

title: Cairo's Tape of Pilot Heard
description: CAIRO, Feb. 22The French pilot of the Libyan airliner that was shot down by Israeli fighters yesterday over Sinai had lost his way as, a result of instrument failure and thought he was over Egyptian territory and was being followed by Egyptian MIG's, according to a tape recording of his exchanges with the Cairo control tower.

title: Curtis Awarded Daughter
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif., Feb. 22 (AP)Tony Curtis, the actor, has been awarded the custody of a teenage daughter from his first wife, Janet Leigh, the actress.

title: New Supper Club in Greenwich Village Swims Against the Tide
description: Ten years ago, when they were sophomores at Columbia, Lewis Friedman and his roommate, Eliot Hubbard, used to do a lot of their field research in Contemporary Civilization at a Greenwich Village supper club called the Bon Soir.

title: BUTZ'S AIDES HUNT DATA TO BACK HIM
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 22After a day's search, aides of Secrete!? of Agriculture Earl L. Butz have been able to supply the names of only two newspapers to support his charges that reporting of foodprice increases in the urban press has been misleading.

title: House, Despite Threat of Veto, Votes DisasterAid Loans at 1%
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Disregarding the threat of another Presidential veto, the House voted today to reinstate for a limited period a lowinterest emergency loan prograin that President Nixon abruptly terminated in late December as too costly.

title: Rockefeller Favors Proposals of Nixon On Domestic Outlay
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Governor Rockefeller bloke today with the nation's bigcity Mayors and supported the Nixon Administration's domestic budget plans down the line.

title: JOHN H. TENNENT
description: John H. Tennent, who retired 10 years ago as manager of real estate for the mortgage division of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Wednesday at the North Shore Hospital in Manhasset, L. I. He was 76 years old and lived in Douglaston, Queens, and in Wainscott, L.I.

title: STATE TAKEOVER OF BUSES IS SEEN
description: TRENTON, Feb. 22  Bus transportation in New Jersey has declined so drastically in efficiency, patronage and profitability that a state takeover may be necessary, according to a study released today by the State Department of Transportation.

title: Meany Says Pay Restraint Hinges on Control of Food
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb, 22George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, called today for direct Government controls on food and agricultural products. Ile warned that workers would require substantial wage increases this year if food price increases were not halted.

title: Robinson Remembers City College in His Will
description: Edward G. Robinson, who gave up law for an acting career while attending City College, left a share of his estate to his alma mater, the school announced yesterday.

title: EVEN THE HEATS LOOK OLYMPIA
description: If quality entries are a per formance yardstick, tonight's National Amateur Athletic Union indoor championships may be the finest track and field meet since the Munich Olympics.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Prague Declares Amnesty for 1968 Refugees as Brezhnev Arrive
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 22President Ludvik Svoboda of Czechoslovakia announced an amnesty today for citizens who had fled abroad, most of them in 1968 after troops of the Soviet Union and other Warsaw Pact countries entered the country.

title: Quebec Man Is Acquitted in Murder of Official
description: MONTREAL, Feb. 22 (AP)Jacques Rose was acquitted today of a charge of having murdered Quebec's Labor Minister, Pierre Laporte, more than two years ago.

title: The Last Devaluation
description: The restoration of monetary order requires not only a steppedup pace of international negotiations but concerted national effort by this country to restore faith in the stability of the dollar, now shaken by the two large devaluations of the past fourteen months. But confidence in the dollar cannot be restored by rhetoric, however impassioned, nor by allegations of commitmentnot backed up by adequate monetary reservesnever to devalue the dollar again.

title: 100 at Essex House Driven From Rooms by Smoky Fire
description: A smoky fire last night on the 17th floor of the Marriott Essex House at 160 Central Park South forced the evacuation of some 100 residents and guests, four of whom were treated in the lobby with oxygen for smoke inhalation.

title: Widow, 84, Found Stabbed to Death In 92d St. Project
description: An 84yearold widow was found stabbed to death yesterday in her eighthfloor apartment in the John Haynes Holmes Towers, a publichousing project at 405 East 92d Street.

title: Events Today
description: Films

title: Index of Commodity Prices Climbed to 144.6 in Week
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 144.6 from 142.4 last week.

title: Soviet Rebuffs West in Vienna Talks
description: VIENNA, Feb. 22Sovietbloc powers today rejected a Western compromise proposal for settling a dispute over who is to participate in negotiations on the reduction of military forces in Central Europe:

title: MARCH 21 MEETING PLANNED BY SWIFT
description: Swift & Co. told shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Houston yesterday that it would seek to hold a special meeting in Chicago on March 2i to get approval for a major reorganization plan.

title: Rules F.P.C. Regulation Cannot Be Claimed to Avoid Prosecution
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 The Supreme Court decided today that private power companies could not escape antitrust prosecution for monopoly by claiming they could only be regulated by the Federal Power Commission.

title: Head of Energy Study Criticized By Advisers for Consumer Talk
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The advisory board of a $3.5million research project on energy policy, financed by the Ford Foundtion, has criticized the project's director, S. David Freeman, for a widely publicized speech in which he took a strongly proconsumer view of energy issues and attacked President Nixon.

title: Brooklyn Mill to Expand Rather Than Leave City
description: The Mayor's Economic Development Administration announced yesterday that Brooklyn knitting mill had not only decided to spurn offers to relocate outside the city but also had made plans to expand its facilities and double its work force.

title: WashingtonPeking Pact Seen As Null and Void by Taiwanese
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 22The Chinese Nationalist Government maintained today that the agreement between the United States and Communist China to open governmental liaison offlees in Washington and Peking contravenes the wishes of the Chinese people.

title: Price Index Is Up Sharply On Record Grocery Rise
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22Propelled by the largest onemonth increase in grocery vices on record, the Consumer ?rice Index rose sharply in January, the Labor Department eported today.

title: EXPERT ON CANCER WARY OF NEW PILL
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The Government's approval of the emergency use of DES (diethylstilbestrol) as a morning after birth control pill was termed unfortunate today by a New York health official, who predicted that the action would encourage wider use of the controversial drug.

title: ASHE AND TANNER BEATEN AT TENNIS
description: COLOGNE, Germany, Feb. 22 (UN)  Unseeded Ismail El Shafei of Egypt advanced to the quarterfinals of the Cologne qualifying tournament of the world tennis championship tournament today by beating Arthur Ashe of Gum Spring, Va., 67, 62, 63.
