description: ACROSS

title: Miss McKay Bride of Henry D. Talbot 2d
description: Miss Christine Mary McCay, daughter of Mrs. James Henry McKay of Fresh Meadows, Queens, and the late Mr. McKay, was married here last evening to Henry David Talbot 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Talbot of Short Hills, N. J. The Rev. Malcolm Gordon performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church.

title: P.O.W.'s Maintained Discipline but Had Some Quarrels
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22The American prisoners of war in North Vietnam maintained strong overall discipline and rapport, sources close to the prisoners report, but daytoday camp life also included many serious personality disputes and some bitter divisions over the Vietnam war.

title: G.O.P. PICKS COUNSEL FOR WATER GATE UNIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (UPI)  Fred D. Thompson, 30 years old, a former United States Attorney, was named today Republican counsel for the Senate committee investigating the Watergate affair.

title: Notre Dame at Coliseum; Garden Stars Marquette
WINE TALK
description: Christian Willm sports a traditionally Gallic beard, but it does little to hide the fact that he is only 23 years old.

title: Queens Woman Guilty In Drug Factory Case
description: Doliree Mapp, a defendant in a major United States Supreme Court case of the nineteensixties has been convisted of running a Queens heroin factory.

title: Bulls, 26 Behind, Top Knicks, 8483
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23  Neither a 24point lead at halftime nor a 3point lead with 26 seconds to play was enough to save the New York Knicks tonight as they lost to the Chicago Bulls, 8483, on Bob Love's rebound basket with eight seconds to play.

title: People and Business
description: Two of the bestknown corporate bond traders on Wall Street and two of their associates at Halsey, Stuart & Co., Inc., are leaving the investment firm on Wednesday to join other houses, According to Wall Street sources, they resigned from Halsey Stuart following a disagreement over compensation for their effortswhich were understood to have produced a substantial portion of the firm's total profits last year.

title: 4 HighLevel C.I.A. Men Reportedly Being Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Four key officials of the Central Intelligence Agency are planning to retire within weeks in what some highlevel officials believe is the first round in a major shakeup of the agency under its new director, James R. Schlesinger.

title: Geoffrey Bell And Joan Abel Wed in London
description: LONDON, Feb. 23Miss Joan Abel, a vice president of WorldWide Business Centers, and Geoffrey Bell, an assistant director of J. Henry Schroder Wagg & Co., Ltd., merchant bankers, were married today at the Kensington Registry Office.

title: Muzzled P.O.W.'s...
description: Democratic nations have never hesitated to let their heroes speak freely for themselves, whether in triumph or adversity. No public relations expert translated Vinegar Joe Stillwell's hell of a licking into a phrase more acceptable to the Government's delicate phrasemakers. The brave but beaten British soldiers returning from the beaches of Dunkirk did not have to run the gantlet of His Majesty's professional communicators, nor did those who emerged at the end of the war after four or five years' incarceration in prison camps. We do not recall that American prisoners coming home after any previous wars were told what they could and could not discuss even with their hometown press.

title: Libyans Ask Vengeance, but Government Keeps Silent
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, Feb. 23 (Reuters)  Libyans called for vengeance today for 106 persons killed when Israeli jets forced a Libyan airliner to crashland in the Sinai Deserts on Wednesday. But Libyan officials continued to maintain silence on the matter.

title: 4 Generations Live TogetherBut in 3 Separate Apartments
description: The generation gaps in the family of Mrs. Marjorie B. Traube is easily bridgedby elevator. Mrs. Traube has simply to go from her eighthfloor apartment up six flights to the residence of her 83yearold mother, Mrs. Rachel Bec, or down two floors to the apartment of her daughter, Mrs. Madeleine Berman, and grandchildren, Lisa Berman, 14, and Eric, 13.

title: Western Union Rate Rise Is Postponed Until March 1
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Federal Communications Commission today suspended until March 1 proposed rate increases and other changes filed by the Western Union Telegraph Company for the Telex and TWX service.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Defense Department announced that American B52 bombers had struck Communist troop positions in Laos less than 24 hours after a ceasefire had formally gone into effect. The announcement said that the raids were made at the request of the Royal Laotian Government. [Page 1, Column 8.]

title: BOARD HOLDS OFF ON CANARSIE PLAN
description: In a move apparently aimed it forestalling a new Canarsie school boycott, the central Board of Education yesterday withheld action, at least temporarily, on Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner's new zoning plan for District 18 in Brooklyn.

title: Stocks Recovered on Bus
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP)A package containing $375,000 in negotiable stocks and bonds was left on a Chicago bus by a bank messenger today. It was recovered by a Chicago Transit Authority supervisor. The messenger notified the authority when he realized he had left the stocks on his seat on the bus. A supervisor at a bus terminal checked two buses returning to the depot and found the envelope on the second seat of the second bus.

title: Parkinson Rites Today
description: CENTER ISLAND, L. i., Feb. 23A funeral service for John Parkinson Jr., a retired stockbroker and yachtsman, will be held tomorrow at 11 A. M. at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley. Mr. Parkinson, who was 67 years old, died accidentally yesterday.

title: Screen: Show of Shows
description: Even the picture quality adds to the effect. Low contrast, a little distortion at the edges, 16mm. kinescopes blown up for the theater screenand looking like old movie history or a message from Marshall McLuhan. It isn't movies; in the early nineteenfifties it was a way of avoiding movies, of staying home Saturday nights to have your mind eroded by television for a change. Probably you were watching Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca in Your Show of Shows, and probably you knew how lucky you were.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23Royce Flippin, the former singlewing tailback from Montclair who terrorized the Ivy League and particularly Yale during the middle nineteenfifties, is back making headlines again at Princeton University.

title: A.S P.C.A. Shift Heartens Critics
description: In a major policy shift, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is requiring that all dogs and cats adopted from its shelters be spayed or neutered in the hope that this will curb the steadily rising number of unwanted pets that are continuously being dumped onto the streets and left to roam wild throughout the city.

title: The Insidious Diatribe of Halldor Laxness
description: To the Editor: Halldor Laxness (OpEd Page, Feb. 9), Nobel Prize winner, must have won it as a fiction writer.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: CINCINNATISigned Pat Zachary, Mike Ruddell, pitchers, and Arturo DeFreltes, Infielderoutfielder,

title: British Football
description: ENGLISH LEAGUE

title: FINN TAKES JUMP IN NORDIC SKIING
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb, 23 (AP) Scandinavian, German and Soviet ski jumpers and racers shared top honors today in the 25th Swedish Nordic competition, a prelude to next year's world championships.

title: KAWAIDA FACTIONS ARE KEPT APART
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23  The police set up separate sidewall areas for opponents and supporters of the Kawaida Towen housing project today to avoid a repetition of yesterday's brief outbreak of fighting between blacks and whites.

title: PISTONS DEFEAT BULLETS, 107105
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23 (AP)Bob Lanier's 10foot hook shot with 10 seconds left enabled the Detroit Pistons to edge the Baltimore Bullets, 107105, and move out of last place in the Midwest Division for the first time since Nov. 4.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los Angeles  Roberto Duran, 137 Pounds, Panama City, knocked out Juan Medina, 135, Mexico, 7 rounds, nontitle.

title: Dollar Recovers Abroad As Selling Wave Is Halted
description: PARIS, Feb. 23Half a dozen central banks of Europe supported the dollar today to halt a selling wave that threatened to reach panic proportions in the morning hours as the price of gold soared at one point to $95 an ounce.

title: Antiques: RollTop Desks Return to Favor and U.S.
description: The rolltop desk, revived when that forest of golden oak furniture sprouted in Greenwich Village shops well over a decade ago, is so much in demand these days that the American desks, exported to Europe when they were new, are now being shipped back by the boatload.

title: A Second Work by Master of Vase Comes to Light
description: Dietrich von Bothmer, the Metropolitan's curator of Greek and Roman Art, said yesterday he had recently shown scholars a photograph of a hitherto unknown cup by Euphronios, the master who painted the recently acquired calyx krater at the museum.

title: Woods Sets Indoor Mark In ShotPut With 699
description: Under conditions described by the chief field judge as rinky dink, George Woods recorded the best indoor performance ever in the shotput yesterday during the 85th National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships.

title: Feb. 1120 Car Sales Rose By 40.9% to Record Level
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23  The United States automobile industry sold a record 272,784 cars in the Feb. 1120 period, up 40.9 per cent from the 193,667 cars sold in the yearearlier span.

title: Oh, the Things They're Debating at Cambridge
description: Germaine Greer, author of The Female Eunuch, and William F. Buckley Jr., editor of National Review, debated before the Cambridge Union in England. These excerpts are from the program produced by the Southern Educational Communications Association for the Public Broadcasting Service.

title: Photographs by Tice and Hine at Witkin
description: The double bill at the Witkin Gallery, 243 East 60th Street, brings together two remarkably straightforward photographic talentsthe 34yearold George A. Tice and the late Lewis W. Hineboth nononsense practitioners and both committed to the human equation in its social context.

title: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS
description: SOUTHERN DISTRICT

title: NASTASE IS FINED BY PLAYERS' UNIT
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 23 (AP)Ilie Nastase of Rumania was fined $500 and reprimanded by the Independent Players Association tonight after failing to go all out while losing in the quarterfinals of the United States indoor open tennis tournament.

title: Art: Margaret Israel's Sculpture
description: The art of Margaret Israel is a highly individual esthetic phenomenon. Only an artist of acute sculptural sensibility could produce it, yet it somehow falls outside the boundaries of sculpture as they are usually defined even today, when such definitions are loose indeed. Nor is it, despite a good deal of engaging pictorial embellishment exactly a pictorial art either. And to consign it to the limbo of mixed media is also not quite right, for this term has come in recent years to signify everything Mrs. Israel's art is notan art based on complex technological means.

title: FINN TAKES JUMP IN NORDIC SKIING
description: FALUN, Sweden, Feb. 23 (AP) Scandinavian, German and Soviet ski jumpers and racers shared top honors today in the 25th Swedish Nordic competition, a prelude to next year's world championships.

title: U.S. IS ASSAILED BY NATIONALISTS
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, Feb. 23 America Blunders Once Again was the headline on the editorial in today's United Daily News. The contents termed the Nixon Administration's agreement with Communist China to open governmental liaison offices in Washington and Peking an unfriendly act and warned that the exchange of officials would simply give Communist agents access to American society for purposes of subversion.

title: Whalers Defeat Oilers, 42; Webster Gets Two Goals
description: BOSTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)Tom Webster scored two goals tonight to lead the New England Whalers to a 42 victory over the Alberta Oilers in a World Hockey Association game. The victory lifted the Whalers within 2 points of the Cleveland Crusaders, who lead the East Division. Webster's goals gave him 43 for the season.

title: Mental Health Official Cautions Senate Panel on Psychosurgery
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Government's top mental health officer said today that scientists do not yet know enough about the brain to justify most attempts to alter human behavior by brain surgery.

title: Antiques: RollTop Desks Return to Favor and U.S.
description: The rolltop desk, revived when that forest of golden oak furniture sprouted in Greenwich Village shops well over a decade ago, is so much in demand these days that the American desks, exported to Europe when they were new, are now being shipped back by the boatload.

title: Tougher Policy Is Indicated on Enforcement
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The new chairmandesignate of the Securities and Exchange Commission disclosed today that the commission intends to issue a new set of guidelines for proper and improper conduct in the sensitive area of inside information in securities trading, and will be tougher in enforcing the rules once they are laid down.

title: Dollar Recovers Abroad As Selling Wave Is Halted
description: PARIS, Feb, 23Half a dozen central banks of Europe supported the dollar today to halt a selling wave that threatened to reach panic proportions in the morning hours as the price or gold soarea at one point to $95 an ounce.

title: Judge Denies Magazine's Plea And Again Orders Brown Data
description: The judge in the trial of H. Rap Brown refused to quash subpoena yesterday and directed New York magazine to produce unpublished portions of controversial article it ran about the case.

title: N.C.A.A. PUTS BAN ON SOVIET SERIES
description: Al McGuire, coach of the fifthranked Marquette University basketball team, has been told he could not coach the United States team in a series against the Soviet Union team, thus reopening the word war between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Labor Quietly Moving Back Into Democratic Party
description: BAL, HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 1At a reception for A.F.L.C.I.O. labor leaders given by Robert S. Strauss, the new chairman of the Democratic National Commitee, the crowd of union leaders and party functionaries was thick and convivial.

title: Price Questioned
description: Museum officials, archeologists and academic scholars throughout the country yesterday questioned the price paid by the Metropolitan Museum for its Greek vase and also censured the secrecy surrounding its purchase. The museum paid approximately $1million for the 2,500yearold krater last September.

title: Ellsberg Lawyers Ask for Acquittal
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (UPI)  The defense asked the judge in the Pentagon papers case today to order a directed verdict of acquittal on all charges, arguing that the Government had not proved espionage, theft or conspiracy.

title: LIBYA AND EGYPT CALL FOR INQUIRY
description: The Governments of Libya and Egypt urged the International Civil Aviation Organization yesterday to investigate the downing of a Libyan airliner on Wednesday by Israeli fighter planes.

title: MRS. WALTER BECKET
description: Katherine Smith Becket, a school principal who spent some 43 years in the city's school system, died Wednesday at the Richmond Memorial Hospital, S. I. She was 68 years old and lived at 6 Shore Road, Tottenville, S. I.

title: B52'S BOMB LAOS LESS THAN A DAY AFTER THE TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Defense Department annonnced today that American B52 bombers had struck Communist troop positions in Laos less than 24 hours after a ceasefire formally went into effect there.

title: K. A. Siegel Weds Miss McEnerny
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 Miss Mary Clare McEnerny, daughter of Mrs. Will G. McEnerny and the late Mr. McEnerny, was married here this afternoon to Kenneth Alan Siegel, personnel manager of National Shoes, Inc., in New York, of which his father is board chairman. The Rev. Louis Poch performed the ceremony in Thomas Hall of Loyola University.

title: WALTER A. ROACH JR.
description: Walter A. Roach Jr., who had served in supervisory positions in the composing room of The New York Times over a period of 48 years, died Thursday at the age of 64. He lived at 137 Gordonhurst Avenue in Upper Montclair, N. J.

title: PENN FIVE UPSET BY. BROWN, 5351
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 23Eddie Morris hit a 15foot jump shot with two seconds left to give Brown a 5351 upset victory tonight over Penn, the defending Ivy League basketball champion.

title: BASEBALL ACCORD IS POSSIBLE TODAY
description: After five months of offand on negotiatingmore off than on until, the past weekrepresentatives of baseball's 24 club owners could reach an agreement with their players today and call for spring training to start Monday.

title: Contractor Testifies in Extortion Trial He Carried $50,000 in Cash to Kenny
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23A former Mayor of North Bergen testified today that he had carried two envelopes purportedly containing $50,000 in cash to the office of John.J. Kenny, when Mr. Kenny was a Hudson County Freeholder.

title: Quick End Seen in Strike Of Philadelphia Teachers
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23 (AP) Under Secretary of Labor William J. Usery Jr. predicted today that the sevenweekold strike by Philadelphia teachers would be settled within days.

title: Defiance in Greece
description: Strikes and demonstrations by thousands of university students have generated one of the most serious challenges to Greece's military dictatorship since it overthrew the legal government nearly six years ago. Democratic political leaders and professors have given outspoken support to student demands for restoration of academic freedom and university autonomy and for a stronger student voice in academic policy.

title: RailTon Mileage Up
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 16 billion tonmiles, up 10.2 per cent from the yearearlier week. Carloadings in the same week totaled 505,792, up 6.8 per cent from a year tarlier.

title: TV Newsman Dismissed in P.O.W. Tape Sale Deal
description: DETROIT, Feb. 23 (UPI) A television news producer was dismissed yesterday for allegedly trying to sell videotaped television news broadcasts for $75 each to the families of Vietnam prisoners of war.

title: Thousands of Mourners
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23The bodies of 100 of the 106 people killed on Wednesday when a Libyan airliner was shot down by Israeli fighters over Sinai arrived here tonight. Israel had turned them over to Egypt earlier in the day at the Suez Canal.

title: Brezhnev, in Prague, Hails Gain in Party Rule There
description: PRAGUE, Feb. 23Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist leader, expressed high praise today for the consolidation of Communist party pdwer in Czechoslovakia since the liberal upheaval in 1968, but he left unanswered questions whether the situation was consolidated enough to permit the withdrawal of 70,000 Soviet troops.

title: PATRICK M'GINNIS, A RAIL EXECUTIVE
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 23 (UPI) Patrick McGinnis, a retired New York businessman and railroad executive, died Tuesday at his home in suburban Glendale. He was 68 years old.

title: Bridge: A Loss of 24 Match Points Can Be Rewon in Other Deals
description: The purpose of the international matchpoint scale, now the standard procedure for scoring team events, is to reduce the impact of a large turnover of points on a single deal.

title: MICHAEL J. MAHONEY sinew to The New York Times
description: TEANECK, N. J., Feb. 23Michael J. Mahoney, a New York lawyer who retired in 1967 after 40 years in practice, died yesterday in Holy Name Hospital. He lived at 115 Sherman Avenue.

title: Sales for January Up 12.6% at Chains And Mail Concerns
description: The country's leading chainstore and mailorder companies achieved a gain in sales of 12.6 per cent in January compared with volume the year before, a survey by The New York Times showed yesterday.

title: ALVIN E. CORMENY
description: Alvin E. Cormeny, a lawyer and educator who had been president of Worcester (Mass.) Polytechnic Institute, died of coronary attack Thursday at his home in East Setauket, L. I. He was 60 years old.

title: A Third Candidate Makes English ByElection Special
description: LINCOLN, England, Feb. 22The labor Party Club, painted green and decorated an what the older members disparagingly call swinging socialist, stands at the bottom of Newland Street. The women, wearing hats, stuff envelopes for the byelection next week and an elderly committeeman steps across from the bar and puts Carol of the Drumsin castanets and massed bagpipeson the jukebox.

title: Theft Trial Looms By PAUL HOFMANN
description: ROME, Feb. 23The Deputy Prosecutor who is charged here with the judicial investigation of the case of the Greek vase recently acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York today formally advised four unidentified persons to retain defense counsel.

title: Nat'l Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: E.C.A.C. Basketball
description: TVCHANNEL 4, 1:30 P.M. PENNSYLVANIA YALE

title: PRESIDENT APPOINTS ENERGY CONSULTANT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) 1President Nixon has appointed Charles J. DiBona as his special consultant on energy, the White House announced today.

title: MEANY ADVOCATES PAY RISES OF 7.5%
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 23 George Meany, the president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today that he would prefer to have no guidelines at all for Phase 3 of the economic stabilization program, but that if there was a wage limit it should allow increases of 7.5 per cent rather than the current 5.5 per cent.

title: TV: Film of Albee Virginia Woolf Is Adult Earful
description: Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf? Not television. The scalding, powerful 1966 movie, costarring glizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton and derived from Edward Albee's famed play, not only survived the home screen Thursday night. It also projcted.

title: NATHAN EHRENWORTH
description: Nathan Ehrenworth, president of Imperia Foods, Inc., an importer and processor of cheese and bread crumbs, died Thursday, apparently of a heart attack, in Miami Beach, where he had been on a business trip. He was 79 years old and lived at 521 Commonwealth Avenue, the Bronx.

title: I.T.T. SETS ACCORD ON PUTNAM'S DEAL
description: G. P. Putnam's Sons, a 135yearold general book publishing company, announced yesterday that an agreement had been signed with the International Telephone & Telegraph Corporation whereby I.T.T. would acquire the company.

title: Death of a Couple In EastSide Home Laid to Argument
description: A 42yearold stock trader and his wife were found shot to death in their East Side apartment early yesterday. The police said the woman had apparently killed her husband, then herself, after an argument.

title: PENN STATE LEADING EASTERN WRESTLING
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 (AP) Pins by Tom Teagarden, Dan Brenneman and Charlie Getty widened Penn State's lead tonight in the Eastern Intercollegiate Wrestling Association tournament.

title: Discount Rate Increased To 5% by the Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Federal Reserve Board raised its discount rate from 5 to 5 per cent tonight while the Committee on Interest and Dividends simultaneously gave tacit green light for the nation's banks to raise their prime rates from 6 to 6 per cent.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The Murasan Gallery at 122 Christopher Street is ablaze with the rich tones of handpainted silks in an array of pillows, scarves, screen panels and all kinds of clothing.

title: DR. JOHN J. BROOKS, EDUCATOR, 61, DEAD
description: Dr. John Julian Brooks, former director of the New Lincoln School, founder of International Schools and professor of foreign languages and international education at New York University, died Thursday of a heart attack at his home in Nyack, N. Y. He was 61 years old.

title: Greece Is Firm on Draft for Protesters
description: ATHENS, Feb. 23The Greek Government refused today to yield to student demands for the repeal of the controversial decree ending draft deferments for students it considers troublesome.

title: Wallace to Attend Benefit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 23 (UPI)An aide to Gov. George C. Wallace said today that the Alabama Governor planed to attend a fundraising benefit in Dallas March 25 to help pay off debts from his 1972 Presidential campaign. Charles S. Snider, director of the campaign, said that the debt was down to about $190,000 from a $250,000 total after the Democratic national convention.

title: Dr. Eugene A. Rothschild, Professor of Dentistry, 59
description: Dr. Eugene A. Rothschild professor of fixed prosthodontics at the New York City College of Dentistry, died at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center on Thursday. He was 59 years old and lived at 120 East 81st Street.

title: Business Briefs
description: Price increases for paper pulp, sulphuric acid, copper and copper products were announced yesterday.

title: Dump Operations Assailed On a Tour of Meadowlands
description: LYNDHURST, Feb. 23State Assemblyman Byron M. Baer walked gingerly along the garhigestrewn banks of a drainage canal between the Meadowland landfill operations run by Bergen County and the Intercity Service Company today and pointed to what he termed vioations of the state's Sanitary Code.

title: C. ALLAN STEW ART, ENVOY TO CARACAS
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 23 (AP)C. Allan Stewart, a former United States Ambassador to Venezuela, died yesterday. He was 66 years old and had lived here several years after retiring from the Foreign Service.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: In a packed ceremony in the Blue Room at City Hall, Herbert Elish was sworn in by Mayor Lindsay as the new Environmental Protection Administrator. Mr. Elish, who is 39 years old, has been Sanitation Commissioner for the last three years, a past he will continue to hold. His new salary will be $41,000.

title: Discount Rate Increctsed To 5% by the Reserve
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Federal Reserve Beard relied its discount rate from 5 to 5 per cent tonight while the Committee on Interest and Dividends simultaneously gave a tacit green light for the nation's banks to raise their prime rate from 6 to 6 cent.

title: Peace Protest Planned
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)  Antiwar activists, unconvinced that the Vietnam ceasefire means the end of the war, said today they would picket the White House tomorrow demanding complete American withdrawal from Southeast Asia. The picket line, to be composed of members of the steering committee of the National Peace Action Coalition and local Washington peace groups, will be the first antiwar demonstration in Washington since the Vietnam accords were signed Jan. 27.

title: Joan W. Thompson Is Bride in Capital
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Miss Joan Webb Thompson, whose father is vice president of The Washington Evening StarNews, was married here this afternoon to Lawrence Wiley Secrest 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Secrest 2d of Alexandria, Va. Canon Kenneth J. Sharp performed the ceremony in the Bethlehem Chapel of the Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul.

title: Charges Against ExP.O.W. Dropped
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI) The Army dropped courtmartial charges today in the case of a 23yearold soldier who was captured by the Vietcong while his trial was pending in 1970 and was not released until Feb. 5.

title: Favors to Wall St. Charged in Report
description: State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday charged unidentified officials of the Levitz Furniture Company, as well as unidentified stock brokerage firms, securities analysts, mutual funds and hedge funds and other institutional investors, with having engaged in securities dealings in Levitz stock that were contrary to the interests of the general public.

title: V.A. DENIES LETTER ON G. I. INSURANCE
description: A letter of unknown origin has reappeared throughout the country telling veterans of World War II that they are entitled to a G.I. insurance dividend if they merely ask for it.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: Former United States Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher was suspended by the State Supreme Court yesterday from practicing law because of his plea of guilty to evading $74,045 in income taxes in 1966. In a fourparagraph order by Chief Justice Joseph Weintraub, the court said the suspension of the Bayonne Democrat would continue until ethics charges pending against him because of his plea were resolved. Lawyers who are convicted of or plead guilty to serious crimes must also face charges of, violating their professional ethics. No sentencing date was set.

title: Amer. Basketball Ass'n
description: LAST NIGHT'S GAMES

title: ExP.O.W.'s Say Ordeal Was Not in Vain
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 23In a series of news conferences around the country, farmer American prisoners of war insisted today that the Vietnam war had succeeded and that their years in captivity had not been in vain.

title: AMEX SEEKS DATA ON OPTION TRADING
description: The American Stock Exchange has begun an inquiry into the trading of options, or outs and calls, by its member firns to determine whether any abnormal activity has occurred in the option business.

title: W. C. Hutchins Marries Mrs. Joan Bush
description: LONDON, Feb. 23Mrs. Joan Morthland Bush of New York and Oyster Bay, L.I., and Warren C. Hutchins of New York and London were married in the Chelsea Registry Office this morning.

title: Trenton Girl Killed by Train
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 (AP)Laura Lee Adams, 7 years old, of Trenton was killed by a northbound train today after she ran onto the Penn Central tracks after a dog, the police said.

title: Football Transactions
description: DENVERSigned. Oliver Ross, Alabama A. and M. running back, and Marvin Frazier, wide receiverdefensive back, free agent.

title: Clashes Persisting After Trace in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Saturday, Feb. 24  Two days after a ceasefire technically went into effect in Laos, widespread fighting continued today with each side accusing the other of violations but with some progress toward setting up peacekeeping machinery.

title: Shift on Rights Delayed
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 23 (UPI)A Nebraska legislative committee has put off action on a move to rescind the state's ratification of the equal rights amendment to the United States Constitution, citing the large amount of evidence presented by both sides. Debate on the resolution, sponsored by Senafor Richard Proud of Omaha, has generated more controversy in the 1973 session than any other issue.

title: Trenton State Is Leader In Metropolitan Wrestling
description: UPPER MONTCLAIR, Feb. 23  Montclair State, Trenton State and C. W. Post are locked in a threeway battle for team honors in the 15th annual Metropolitan intercollegiate wrestling tournament at Montclair State.

title: Horticulturists Get Washington's Farm
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (UPI)  George Washington's river front farm, once a part of his Mount Vernon estate along the Potomac River south of Washington, was officially transferred today to the American Horticultural Society to be used as a national horticultural center.

title: FRENCH DISBAND MEN'S SKI TEAM
description: LA FOUX D'ALLOS, France (AP)The French Ski Federation; reacting to a mutiny, disbanded the national men's ski team today and canceled French participation in the remaining World Cup ski events in the United States, Canada and Japan.

title: Quebec Club Is 96 Victor Over Hershey in Curling
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 23The Bale d'Urfe (Quebec) Curling Club rink skipped by George Flemming, the 1971 champion, led the way today through the first round of the 18th annual St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: Pawn Or Legislator?
description: LINCOLN, EnglandAs the London train approaches, passengers gazing across the fields see one of the magnificent sights of England: the Norman Gothic cathedral towering over Lincoln. It was built on a hill, starting just 900 years ago, and the city grew around and below it. Recent building is the usual undistinguished mixture, but the cathedral still makes Lincoln a rarely beautiful city.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: FOR STRINGS The strings that Franz Haydn wrote Philemon and Baucis for In 1773 were the ones that operated marionettes; the work was one of the puppet operas the composer created while serving as a sort of social director at Esterhaz, the palace built in Hungary by his bosses, the Esterhazy family.

title: MARKET PLUNGES; AVERAGE OFF 11.89
description: Stock prices plunged on Wall Street yesterday, reacting to, monetary jitters abroad and an indicated rise in the inflation rate at home.

title: Awards Are Issued For Gallant Conduct In, Brooklyn Siege
description: Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy presented citations of gallantry yesterday to policemen and civilians who participated in the siege at the Brooklyn sporting goods store last month.

title: Thursday's Fight
description: Los Angeles  Roberto Duran, 137 pounds, Panama City, knocked out Juan Medina, 135, Mexico, 7 rounds, nontitle.

title: Ben Black Elk Is Dead; Fifth Rushmore Face
description: PINE RIDGE, S. D., Feb. 23 (AP)Ben Black Elk, widely known as the most photographed Indian in the world and often referred to as The Fifth Face on Mount Rushmore died yesterday at the age of 74. He was photographed on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation. He was the sixth in line to carry the name Black Elk. His father and Chief Crazy Horse were first cousins, and both participated in the battle of the Little Big Horn.

title: Music: Harris Symphony
description: Roy Harris struck the mother lode in 1938 with his Symphony No. 3, a craggily handsome work that became one of the more frequently performed American scores of its day. After 35 years it keeps a toehold in the repertory, though its appeal has diminished somewhat of late, so Leonard Bernstein's performance of the onemovement piece with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday night was more than an act of homage and statesmanship.

title: Search On for Gas Leak
description: COOPERSBURG, Pa. Feb. 23 (AP)Workmen began a search today for a leak in an 8inch gas line at the site of an explosion and fire that took five lives Wednesday. The blast leveled a threestory apartment building in this eastern Pennsylvania town. A second apartment was destroyed by the fire.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Soviet Favoritism in Industry Found
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 23  Not only Soviet consumers but also the workers who try to serve them  mostly women  suffer from the persistent bias of Soviet economic planners in favor of heavy industry.

title: Keystone Pat Wins 2:02 Pace; Fastest Mile of Yonkers Season
description: YONKERS, Feb. 23  John Hayes Jr. did tonight what his father was unable to do last week and kept Keystone Pat in front for the entire mile in a $21,000 handicap pace before 19,358 fans at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Estelle Marr Married to Internist
description: Mrs. Estelle Flaherty Maher, widow of John J. Maher, was married here yesterday morning to Dr. George W. Melcher Jr., an internist and president of Group Health, Inc. The bride, known professionally as Estelle Marr, is a vice president with Trigre, Inc., fashion concern.

title: Gulf Announces Tender
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation said yesterday that its previously announced tender offer would, become effective Monday and would terminate Thursday, March 15 at 5 P.M. Eastern Standard Time unless extended. The company's directors have authorized the purchase of 10 million shares by public tenders at $26 a share.

title: F.B.I. HEAD TERMED IN POST ILLEGALLY
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Senator William Proxmire charged today that L. Patrick Gray 3d, acting director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, violated Federal law by remaining in his post more than 30 days without Senate confirmation. He called upon Mr. Gray to stand aside at once.

title: BRITON WOUNDED BY ULSTER BOMB
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 23 (UPI)A British soldier was seriously injured today when a bomb was hurled into his Londonderry sentry post and exploded as he tried to throw it away.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Pagel Gains Quarterfinals In Princeton Indoor Tennis
description: PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 23Rick Fagel of Columbia, the top seeded player, won a berth today in the quarterfinal round of the Princeton invitation indoor intercollegiate tennis tournament.

title: VERMONT IS LEADER AT WINTER CARNIVAL
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt., Feb. 23The University of Vermont, with solid performances in both the downhill and crosscountry events, took a 3,5point lead at the halfway mark today in the Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association championships at the Middlebury College Winter Carnival. Vermont scored a total of 196.67 points. Middlebury is second at 193.14

title: NIXON AND ROGERS SEE A CAIRO AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The United States, said today that several hours of highlevel talks with a key Egyptian official had produced a good rapport between the two countries and that further discussions on a possible Middle East settlement would be held in the future.

title: D.A. Won't Decide use Of InjuredDog Funds
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 23 (UPI)  Nassau County District Attorney William Calm decided today that his office was not the agency to rule on the disposal of more than $4,600 in donations for the surgery and hospitalization of an injured stray dog.

title: Tracy Smith Sets ThreeMile Mark
description: Tracy Smith, whose depression as an ailing distance runner once sent nim into a physical withdrawal, established a world indoor record in the threemile run last night at the National Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships.

title: Columbia U. Seeks to Combine Humanities and Career Studies
description: Columbia University undergraduates would get more technical careeroriented courses and graduate students would get more humanities studies under a plan made public yesterday.

title: JOHN J. PONCE
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., Feb. 23John J. Ponce, a retired superintendent of buildings at Grand Central Terminal, died yesterday in the Freehold Area Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 29B Plaza de Las Flores here.

title: KAWAIDA GROUPS ARE KEPT APART
description: NEWARK, Feb. 23  The police set up separate sidewalk areas for opponents and supporters of the Kawaida Towers housing project today to avoid a repetition of yesterday's brief outbreak of fighting between blacks and whites.

title: The Public Side of Nixon's Life Pleases Crowd at Theater
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 The President went to the theater last night, and saw a bouncy, bubbly musical that even his Secret Service agents could love.

title: ... Muzzled Teachers
description: The city's education authorities, Iike any bureaucracy, have never been overly friendly to criticism. When the central Board of Education was still fully in charge, prior to decentralization, principals of local schools occasionally tried to hide behind obscure directives as a means of barring potential critics from visiting classes.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: FUTURES SPECIALIST CRITICIZES RULING
description: Goldstein, Samuelson, Inc., of Beverly Hills, Calif., which specializes in commodity options, yesterday deplored the action taken by the California Corporations Commissioner requiring the registration of such firms.

title: COMMUNISTS CUT CAMBODIAN ROADS
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 23 (Reuters)Communist troops attacking outside Phnom Penh advanced today to within three miles of the outer suburbs, military sources reported.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and Index, Page 31

title: CHAUNCEY B. CARVER, EXPERT ON BANK LAW
description: Chauncey Brewster Garver, a senior member of the law firm of Sherman & Sterling, died Wednesday at his home in Oyster Bay, L. I. He was 86 years old and lived also at 720 Park Avenue.

title: Atlantic City's Solicitor Testifies on Shakedowns
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 23 (AP) Murray Frederick's, the city solicitor of Atlantic City, testified today that he maintained private law offices and that a number of merchants who did business with the city were his clients.

title: N.C.A.A. PUTS BAN ON SOVIET SERIES
description: Al McGuire, coach of the fifthranked Marquette University basketball team, has been told he could not coach the United States team in a series against the Soviet Union team, thus reopening the word war between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and the Amateur Athletic Union.

title: Rockefeller Body Cremated; Arkansas Memorial Planned
description: SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI)The body of Winthrop Rockefeller, a grandson of John D. Rockefeller and twoterm Governor of Arkansas, was cremated today at a funeral home here.

title: Bridge: A Loss of 24 Match Points Can Be Rewon in Other Deals
description: The purpose of the international matchpoint scale, now the standard procedure for scoring team events, is to reduce the impact of a large turnover of points on a single deal.

title: CarExhaust Rule Widened
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 (UPI)California's air resources board ruled yesterday that all small foreign used cars, as well as American vehicles, built between 1966 and 1970 must have exhaust control devices installed before they are sold in southern California.

title: Hesburgh Is Pessimistic On Civil Rights Outlook
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.After 15 years on the United States Civil Rights Commission, the Rev. Theodore M. Hesburgh has come back fulltime as president of the University of Notre Dame, his oncehigh hopes for equality for minorities turned to pessimism.

title: NIXON AND ROGERS SEE A CAIRO AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 23The United States said today that several hours of highleveltalks with a key Egyptian official had produced a good rapport between the two countries and that further, diacussions on a Possible Middle East settlement would be held in the future.

title: A 2D U.S. FATALITY IN TRUCE REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)The United States command today reported the second American peacetime fatality in Vietnam. The victim, the flight engineer of an unarmed helicopter shot down near An Loc a week ago, died today at a hospital on Okinawa.

title: Auto Emission Hearings Set
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) A public hearing on automobile manufacturers' requests for suspension of the effective date of 1975 autoemission standards will begin here March 12, the Environmental Protection Agency announced yesterday. The hearings were ordered after a suit by General Motors, Ford, Chrysler and International Harvester.

title: Thieu Says Hanoi Plans to Send Many People to Vote in South
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Feb. 24President Nguyen Van Thieu asserted yesterday that North Vietnam planned to infiltrate millions of people into South Vietnam to shift the power balance in the elections called for in the Paris peace accords.

title: SpeedUp Urged by Mills To Solve Money Problem
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 Representative Wilbur D. Mills said today that his proposal for a 15 per cent import surcharge, made a week ago, was designed to provide a needed impetus to serious action on world monetary reform and correction of the deficit in the United States balance of international payments.

title: News Summary and Index
description: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1973

title: IndoorOutdoor Tennis Apparatus Devised
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Huntington Hartford, the New Yorker who is best known as heir to a Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company fortune, was granted a patent this week for an indooroutdoor tennis apparatus that he calls DoubleUp. As described in Patent 3,717,343, the equipment consists of two tables, each constituting a playing court, with a flat net stretched between them to serve as a ball deflector. From two to four persons can play.

title: Amex and OT C Are Depressed By Dollar and Inflation Concern
description: Investors' concern over inflaLion and the weakness in the dollar abroad continued to depress prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and on the overthecounter market.

title: Columbia U. Seeks to Combine Humanities and Career Studies Studies
description: Columbia University undergraduates would get more technical careeroriented courses and graduate students would get more humanities studies under a plan made public yesterday.

title: Israel Confirms Cairo Data
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Feb. 24Israel announced early today that the pilots of the Libyan airliner downed Wednesday over the Sinai desert apparently believed that they were within Egyptian airspace and that the Israeli fighter planes intercepting them were Egyptian.

title: B52'S BOMB LAOS LESS THAN A DAY AFTER THE TRUCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The Defense Department announced today that American B52 bombers had struck Communist troop positions in Laos less than 24 hours after a ceasefire formally went into effect there.

title: FRENCH DISBAND MEN'S SKI TEAM
description: LA FOUX D'ALLOS, France (AP)The French Ski Federation, reacting to a mutiny, disbanded the national men's ski team today and canceled French participation in the remaining World Cup ski events in the United States, Canada and Japan.

title: IRVING SANDERS
description: Irving Sanders, founder and former chief executive of the Sanders Meat Company of Newark, a wholesale meat concern, died yesterday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center following recent surgery. He was 78 years old and lived at 77 West 55th Street.

title: 4 Workmen Are Injured In Saratoga Springs Blast
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y. Feb. 23 (AP)Four persons were injured in this resort city today when a gas main exploded at a construction site, shooting flames skyward.

title: Reid and Stratton Are Being Viewed As Potential State Candidates in '74
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23While most of the political attention is being focused on the widening field of candidates running this year for Mayor of New York, the first soundings are being taken for next year's statewide election campaign in New York.

title: Minnan Leads at Manila
description: MANILA, Feb. 23 (AP)Hsieh Minnan of Taiwan scored oneunderpar 71 today for a 140 and a threestroke lead at the halfway mark of the Philippine open golf championship.

title: Citizenship Fair Focuses on Minorities
description: The BrotherhoodinAction Building was turned into a microcosm of the political life of New York's minority communities yesterday for the opening of a twoday citizenship education fair billed as Mission Awareness.

title: Prejudice and Perjury Charged In Investigation of Carrier Riot
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 23 (AP)A prosecutor was accused of racial prejudice and a Navy witness was accused of perjury in a Federal court suit filed today on behalf of 17 black sailors charged in a disturbance at sea.

title: Thousands of Mourners
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23The bodies of 100, of the 106 people killed on Wednesday when a Libyan airliner was shot down by Israeli fighters over Sinai arrived here tonight. Israel had turned them over to Egypt earlier in the day at the Suez Canal.

title: U.S. SHIPS WILL BEGIN MINE CLEARING SOON
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP) United States Navy ships and heicopters arrived off Haiphong harbor today to begin clearing thousands of underwater mines from North Vietnamese waters. Pentagon officials said that the clearing operations would get under way in a few days, probably on Monday.

title: CORDERO ABOARD 4 HIALEAH FIRSTS
description: MIAMI, Feb. 23Angel Cordero Jr., the leading jockey at the Hialeah meeting, brought home four winners on today's card. His most important triumph occurred in the feature race, a 1 1/16mile turf event for fillies and mares, witnessed by 13,586 fans.

title: ExP.O.W.'s Say Ordeal Was Not in Vain
description: SAN DIEGO, Feb. 23In a series of news conferences around the country, former American prisoners of war insisted today that the Vietnam war had succeeded and that their years in captivity had not been in vain.

title: Suspension in Tax Case
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 (AP)The New Jersey Supreme Court today suspended Henry M. Spritzer, a New Brunswick lawyer who had pleaded guilty to failure to file an income tax return in 1968. The court ordered the suspension pending final ethics proceedings based on his conviction. The suspension will take effect March 12.

title: Seals Top Rangers, 53
description: OAKLAND, Calif., Feb. 23Gilles Meloche was prepared to spend tomorrow's predawn hours in restless halfsleep following tonight's game against the Rangers.

title: Dave Anderson
description: It's like I tell my ballplayers, Al McGuire was saying. If you want to go uptown, that's my way of saying if you want to be successful, you got to go together.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Up was still the key word that applied to many important commodities yesterday in futures trading.

title: THE YUGOSLAV PARTY EXPELS FILM MAKER
description: BELGIUM Feb. 23 (UPI)A film maker has been expelled from the Communist party for insulting Yugoslav war veterans, party officials said today.

title: Contractor Testifies He Carried $50,000 in Cash to J. J. Kenny
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23A former Mayor of North Bergen testified today that he had carried two envelopes purportedly containing $50,000 in cash to the office of John J. Kenny, when Mr. Kenny was a Hudson County Freeholder.

title: Agnew Terms Rifts With Press Healthy, Defends Its Rights
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 23 (AP) Vice President Agnew tonight described differences between the Nixon Administration and the press as healthy. calling them repetitions of similar differences in previous administrations.

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: A WARD OF STATE HAS RICH FAMILY
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., Feb. 23 (AP)A 15yearold girl with a rich father, a mother from a wealthy family and a cattle rancher uncle worth $7million is costing Rhode Island $59 a day as a ward of the state.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: Senator Turner Pleads Not Guilty
description: TRENTON, Feb. 23 (AP)State Senator James M. Turner, Republican of Gloucester County, pleaded not guilty today to charges he conspired to plant drugs in the home of Assemblyman Kenneth A. Gewertz, Democrat of Gloucester.

title: Charges of Widespread Doping in Illinois Racing Called Incredible
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 23 (AP)A national harness racing official branded as incredible and irresponsible remarks today by the new Illinois Racing Board chairman that half the winning horses in the state last year were found to have had some form of medication in their system.

title: Office Workers Strike State Employes' Union
description: ALBANY, Feb. 13 (AP)The Civil Service Employes Association, the state's largest publicemploye union, had a labor problem of its own today.

title: Albany's Dirty Dozen
description: After sifting legislative records in Washington, an environmental protection group last year compiled a list of Congressmen who most often voted wrong from an environmental point of view. An even dozen representatives were selected as having the worst records of allthe Dirty Dozen. This is a term that the Citizens Union of New York City has now picked up and used in a slightly modified meaning. The goodgovernment group points to an even dozen areas of public concern needing state legislative attention this year.

title: Wallace to Attend Benefit
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., Feb. 23 (UP1)An aide to Gov. George C. Wallace said today that the Alabama Governor planned to attend a fundraising benefit in Dallas March 25 to help pay off debts from his 1972 Presidential campaign. Charles S. Snider, director of the campaign, said that the debt was down to about $190,000 from a $250,000 total after the Democratic national convention.

title: Litton Industries Lists Sharp Gains In Sales and Profit
WCBS Introduces Portable Camera For Live Coverage
description: Station WCBSTV last night introduced the portable, lightweight colortelevision camera called a minicam for live, onscene coverage of news events, as part of its two evening news programs. The station is the first in New York and the second in the country to begin using the minicam regularly.

title: U.S. Troop Withdrawals Leave 13,234 in Vietnam
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23 (UPI)United States troop strength in Vietnam dropped to 13,234 men today, the lowest figure in a decade.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: ANTISECRECY BILLS OFFERED IN HOUSE
description: The chairman of the House Foreign Operations and Government Information Subcommittee said yesterday that he would push for two pieces of legislation this session that are designed to give the public access to certain government secrets.

title: MICROFILM OFFERED ON JEWISH HISTORY
description: The oral history collection of Hebrew University's Institute of Contemporary Jewry in Jerusalem, one of the world's largest, and most important, will be bade available on microform by the Microfilming Corporation of America, it was announced yesterday.

title: Price Questioned
description: Museum officials, archeologists and academic scholars throughout the country yesterday questioned the price paid by the Metropolitan Museum for its Greek vase and also censured the secrecy surrounding its purchase. The museum paid approximately $1million for the 2,500yearold krater last September.

title: Mackell's Financial Data Asked After Grand Jury Appearance
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell was questioned for, almost three hours yesterday before a special grand jury investigating his office and then was ordered to fill out a 10page questionnaire about his personal finances, for the last three years.

title: Fezler Gains TwoStroke Lead With 136
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 23  Forrest Fezler, a 23yearold Californian who had to qualify here last Monday to gain a place in the field, became the leader today after 36 holes in the Jackie Gleason Inverrary National Airlines open.

title: New Books
description: A Maigret Trio: Maigret's Failure, Maigret in Society and Maigret and the Lazy Burglar, by Georges Simenon, translated by Daphne Woodward and Robert Eglesfield (Helen & Kurt Wolff Book: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95). Detective stories.

title: ClosedEnd Funds
description: February 23, 1973

title: ExP.O.W. Explains Broadcasts for Foe
description: DENVER, Feb. 23 (UPI)Chief Warrant Officer 2d cl. Daniel F. Maslowski, 23 years old, his face thin after more than two years in jungle prison camps, said today that he had agreed to make radio broadcasts for his captors to let his family know he was alive and to help end the war.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: INSURANCE CALLED CONSUMER FRAUD
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23Consumer advocates charged in testimony before a Senate subcommittee today that many life insurance companies were selling to a gullible public policies that were confusing, overpriced and deceptive.

title: The Third Lie
description: With his usual acumen, Mark Twain once remarked that there are three kinds of lies: ordinary lies, damn lies and statistics. A case in point is provided by the newly issued United Nations Demographic Yearbook. In the hands of specialists who know the weaknesses and the qualifications of the data, it is undoubtedly useful. But woe betide the innocent who approaches this volume's serried ranks of numbers with their seeming authority and exactness.

title: Chavez's Brother Held
description: EL CENTRO, Calif. Feb. 23 (UPI)Manuel Chavez, brother of Cesar Chavez, head of the United Farm Workers union, was arrested for trespassing yesterday. Mr. Chavez and another union organizer, Marshall Gans, were arrested in a lettuce field at the Sam Andrews Company ranch, attempting to recruit 35 field hands. The ranch has a contract with the Teamster's union. The U.F.W.'s rival in a struggle for control of farm labor.

title: D.A. Won't Decide Use Of InjuredDog Funds
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 23 (UPI)  Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn decided today that his office was not the agency to rule on the disposal of more than $4,600 in donations for the surgery and hospitalization of an injured stray dog.

title: Books of The Times
description: GEORGE C. MARSHALL. Organizer of Victory, 194345. By Forrest C. Pogue. 683 pages. Viking. $15.

title: POLITICAL TALKS ON VIETNAM SET
description: PARIS, Feb. 23The Foreign Ministers of the Saigon Government and of the South Vietnamese Communists met alone today for the first time and finally agreed on when and where to start political talks between their regimes.

title: The Chilean Military Sets Forth Its Position on March Elections
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 23A high military source said yesterday that the high command of the Chilean armed forces would not consider a simple majority victory by the Opposition in the upcoming legislative elections as an expression by the country against the Government or against its Marxist progam.

title: COUGARS PIN LOSS ON NETS
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., Feb. 23Billy Cunningham, with a dislocated finger, and Joe Caldwell, just recovered from a dislocated toe, helped the Carolina Cougars to a 10793 victory over the New York Nets tonight before a crowd of 7,243 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Sheriff Says Lien Sales Of Homes Seem Unclean
description: MINEOLA, L. L., Feb. 23Sheriff Michael Seniuk of Nassau County told a state commission here today that he felt unclean when auctioning homes to satisfy judgments against their owners.

title: Knicks' LineUp
description: AT GARDEN8 P.M.

title: Rites for Albert Rudolph
description: A funeral service for Albert Rudolph, a 45yearold art dealer who lived at 88 East 10th Street, will he held tomorrow at 1 P.M. at the Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam Avenue at 76th Street. Mr. Rudolph was killed in a plane accident in the Catskills Wednesday evening.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Page

title: Skylab Test Delayed Again
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Feb. 23 (UPI)  Completion of an important test of the Skylab space station was delayed another 24 hours today because of the spillage of several pints of coolant down the side of the booster rocket. A space agency spokesman said the test was now scheduled to end late tomorrow. He said the delay, the second in two days, would not affect the Skylab launching schedule, tentatively set for midMay.

title: Notes on People
description: The Mayor and Public Health Director of San Francisco said they would stand firm behind the hiring by the city health department of 20yearold Joseph P. Kennedy 3d, the son of the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy. Mayor Joseph Alioto and Dr. Francis Curry, the health director, said they hoped Mr. Kennedy would continue to work in the city's health programs. Mr. Kennedy is being paid $748 a month as a coordinator of federally funded programs, mostly in poor black neighborhoods, to control tuberculosis and venereal disease.

title: Theft Trial Looms
description: ROME, Feb. 23The Deputy Prosecutor who is charged here with the judicial investigation of the case of the Greek vaserecently acquired by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York today formally advised four unidentified persons to retain defense counsel.

title: Legislators Seek a Compromise On Governor's Drug Penalties
description: As a monthlong series of public hearings nears an end, members of the codes committees of the Legislature are indicating that they favor a tough new state law for narcotics pushers, but one less stringent than the bill recommended by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Contaminated Lettuce Sent East But U.S Aide Rules Out Harm
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration disclosed today that three shipments of lettuce contaminated with a pesticide in the nerve gas family apparently reached East Coast consumers before the Federal agency could destroy the lettuce.

title: Table for High Tide for Waters Adjacent to New York
Equity Financing
description: American Electric Power Company filed yesterday a rights offering to shareholders of 6.5 million shares to be sold at competitive bidding. It will offer rights for one share for each 10 held March 28.

title: Israel Confirms Cairo Data
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, Feb. 24Israel announced early today that the pilots of the Libyan airliner downed Wednesday over the Sinai desert apparently believed that they were within Egyptian airspace and that the Israeli fighter planes intercepting them were Egyptian.

title: Ski Group Scrapes Up a Hill for Jumping Today
description: Yankee ingenuity  and selfadmitted stubbornness will enable members of the Salisbury (Conn.) Winter Sports Association to stage their annual ski jumping tournaments as rescheduled this afternoon and tomorrowon snow trucked to their 60meter Satre Hill.

title: Clashes Persisting After Truce in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Saturday. Feb. 24  Two days after a ceasefire technically went into effect in Laos, widespread fighting continued today with each side accusing the other of violations but with some progress toward setting up peacekeeping machinery.

title: People in Sports: Allen Aide Joins Cards
description: Joe Sullivan, who has worked with George Allen for the last 14 years in various capacities with the Chicago Bears, Los Angeles Rams and Washington Redskins, was named yesterday as director of operations for the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: M. JOEL FREEDMAN, CHILDREN'S DENTIST
description: Dr. M. Joel Freedman, a specialist in children's dentistry and orthodontia, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 101 Central Park West.

title: Dr. Dickinson Richards Dead; '56 Nobel Laureate in Medicine
description: Dr. Dickinson W. Richards, 1956 Nobel laureate in medicine and physiology, whose work in cardiac physiology helped lead the way to openheart surgery, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Lakeville, Conn. He was 77 years old.

title: A Critic of Insurance Herbert Sidney Denenberg
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23To hear his many friends and enemies tell it, Herbert Sidney Denenberg is an exploding, searing, flashing, loved, hated, outrage of a man. Since he was appointed Pennsylvania Insurance Commissioner two years ago, he has shocked the staid world of fine print contracts. A few months after his appointment by Gov. Milton J. Shapp, Mr. Denenberg unloosed what one insurance publication called a salvo of explosive critcism devastating enough to stir memories of the saturation bombing of World War II.

title: Notre Dame at Coliseum; Garden Stars Marquette
description: The last of five college basketball programs at the Nassau Coliseum this season will be the new arena's first financially successful one, even though the doubleheader this afternoon is to be staged at the same time that Madison Square Garden is conducting one of its own.

title: TEN FOUND GUILTY OF HEROIN CHARGE
description: Seven men and three women were found guilty here yesterday of participation in an extensive conspiracy that distributed $5million a year in heroin at the wholesale level in Harlem, the Bronx and Westchester County.

title: The Public Side of Nixon's Life Pleases Crowd at Theater
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23The President went to the theater last night and saw a bouncy, bubbly musical that even his Secret Service agents could love.

title: CourtMartial in Hair Feud
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., Feb. 23 (UPI)An Air Force sergeant who wears his hair in tight braids has been convicted by a courtmartial of refusing to obey an officer's orders in a dispute about his hair. The same courtmartial found Sgt. Charles C. Miller, not guilty of violating military hair grooming standards, He is stationed at McClelland Air Force Base.

title: Allison Fastest at Richmond
description: RICHMOND, Va., Feb. 23 (UPI)Bobby Allison, in a 1973 Chevelle, won the pole position for Sunday's Richmond 500 with a speed of 90.952 miles per hour in qualifying trials here today.

title: Opera: Minimet's Play ful Four Saints
description: It was Virgil Thomson's Four Saints in Three Acts at the Forum on Thursday night, as the second Minimet bill. St. Therese I and St. Therese II made their innocent appearances; Betty Allen, the Commere, sang and acted with a mean twinkle in her eye, and St. Ignatius Loyola finally got around to Pigeons on the grass, alas, to the vast enjoyment of the audience in the little theater.

title: A.S.P.C.A. Shift Heartens Critics
description: In a major policy shift, the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals is, requiring that all dogs and cats adopted from its shelters be spayed or neutered in the hope that this will curb the steadily rising number of unwanted pets that are continuously being dumped onto the streets and left; to roam wild throughout the city.

title: TWO SLATES VIE IN N.A.A.C.P. VOTE
description: Of course, I'm going to win, Carl Lawrence said. I'd be awfully ashamed if I don't win by 4 to 5to1.

title: The Vietnam Fighting: Many Flare  Ups Fuel the Fire
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 23Why do ceasefire violations continue to take place so frequently almost a month after the fighting in Vietnam was supposed to stop? The traveler around South Vietnam finds many reasons, none of which will appear in communiqus or press conferences.

title: Comsat Forms Subsidiary To Handle U.S. Programs
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP)  The Communications Satellite Corporation today announced a new subsidiary, the Comsat General Corporation.

title: Removal of Dealer Allowances Has Raised Gas Prices Up to 20%
description: The nation's major gasoline producers in recent weeks have quietly raised the price of automobile fuel across most of the nationas much as 20 per cent in some casesby eliminating special allowances to dealers.

title: 2 NEWSMEN TOLD TO RECALL ATTICA
description: An upstate panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court ordered two television newsmen yesterday to tell a special grand jury what they saw inside Attica prison during the inmate rebellion in September, 1971.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: New York State's Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, said yesterday that his agency had begun an exhaustive investigation of the Medicaid program as it is operated by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation. Mr. Lavine told members of the Temporary State Commission to Revise the Social Service Law at a public hearing that the investigation would consist of a comprehensive audit of the operations of the corporation, which accounts for more than $300million in Medicaid hospital care each year.

title: STATE IS STUDYING MEDICAID IN CITY
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23The State's Social Services Commissioner, Abe Lavine, said today that his agency had begun an exhaustive investigation of the Medicaid program as it is operated by the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: DATA ON FINANCES ASKED OF MACKELL
description: Queens District Attorney Thomas. Mackell was questioned for almost three hours yesterday before a special grand jury investigating his office and then was ordered to fill out a 10page questionnaire about his personal finances for the last three years.

title: Dining Out in Jersey
description: Restaurants are rated for their food (four stars to none) and for their atmosphere, service and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: Court Refuses to Act On Elk's Expulsion
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., Feb. 23 (AP)A Superior Court judge refused to intervene, today in the expulsion of a member of the Ridgewood Elks who tried to integrate the organization.

title: Prisoner Hangs Himself in a Brooklyn Jail Cel
description: A heroin addict awaiting a hearing on a robbery charge hanged himself in his cell in the Brooklyn House of Detention while his cell mate was preoccupied with writing a letter, officials of the city's Department of Correction said yesterday.

title: Financial Report Cites Gain For Niagara Frontier Unit
description: ALBANY, Feb. 23 (AP) State Controller Arthur Levitt's office issued a financial analysis today of the Niagara Frontier Transportation Authority showing that the public corporation registered a substantial rise in earnings in fiscal 1972.

title: Toulouse Takes Tight Election Race Calmly
description: TOULOUSE, France, Feb. 20 The major race here in the coming French elections is a cliffhanger involving three nationally prominent figures. But two weeks before the first ballot even the politicians took a full weekend off.

title: Mrs. Marian Hamilton Is Wed To Rawson Lyman Wood Jr.
description: Mrs. Marian Meredith Young Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John M. Young of New York and Bedford, N. Y., was married last Sunday to Rawson Lyman Wood jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of New York and Squam Lake, N. H. The Rev. James Goody performed the ceremony in Tucson, Ariz.

title: Chess: Poker Players and Sphinxes Are Not Models for Geller
description: Spectators at tournaments rarely get a line on what's going on by studying the players' faces. The cool frown of concentration, whether posed or a genuine expression, is virtually de rigeur in formal events.

title: Suffolk Planning Trauma Units
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I.  A countywide system of trauma centerds patterned on the methods in Use for the last year in Illinois with dramatic results, is being planned as the alternative to a county medical center for Suffolk County, it was learned last week.

title: L. C. Wood Jr. to Wed Anne Sunderrnan
description: SCOTCH PLAINS, N. J., Feb. 24Mr. and Mrs. Irwin G. Sunderman of Scotch Plains and Whitefield, N. H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Davis Sunderman, to Leighton Christopher Wood Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wood of New Canaan, Conn., and Jamaica, Vt. A May wedding is planned.

title: Nuns Assisi YearRound Migrants
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I.The section of Montauk Highway that constitutes Main Street of this Colonial village has recently taken on the look of a community that cares.

title: Caesarserving professors and theorizing politicians
description: Formerly, Ambassadors and Senators wrote memoirs and professors wrote theories of international relations. Today, professors often serve Caesar, while diplomats and politicians become theoreticians of power.

title: Miss NancyJane Sievert Married
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 24Miss NancyJane Sievert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Sievert of Waldwick, N. J., and Capt. Joseph A. Lawless, U.S.A.F., son of Mr, and Mrs. Joseph Lawless of Clinton, Md., were married here this afternoon in the chapel of Langley Air Force Base by the Rev. Paul Kapphahn, a Roman Catholic priest. A reception was given in the Langley Officers Club.
