title: Photography
Flaw in RevenueSharing Formula Discovered
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24A flaw in the formula used to distribute general revenuesharing funds to local governments has been discovered, and it could affect the amount of money due some 450 local governments, including New York City.

title: Harvard Six Routs Yale, 91
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24 Bob McManama and Bill Corkery each scored two goals to lead Harvard's hockey team to a 91 rout of Yale tonight at Harvard's Watson rink.

title: Jody Runyon Is Engaged
description: BEDMINSTER, N. J., Feb. 24The engagement of Miss Jody Runyon and Douglas Levinson, students at the University of Arizona, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John E. Runyon. Mr. Levinson is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levinson of Bernardsville, N. J.

title: F.S. Gilligan Weds Miss Kellogg
description: Miss Fernanda Wanamaker Munn Kellogg, daughter of Mrs. Munn Kellogg of Palm Beach, Fla; and New York, and Francis L. Kellogg of Washington and Bedford Village, N.Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Francis S. Gilligan of New York. He is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George A. Gilligan of Worcester, Mass.

title: Cousteau Derides Plan to Use Water of Icebergs
description: LOS ANGELES, Calif., Feb. 24Capt. Jacques Cousteau, the oceangrapher, has described as nonsense a federally funded effort to determine the feasibility of towing icebergs from Antarctica to the United States West Coast as a source of fresh water.

title: Morrison of Giants To Coach College
description: CHATTANOOGA, Feb. 24 Joe Morrison, the New York Giants' 14year veteran, has been named head coach of the University of TennesseeChattanooga football team, school officials said today.

title: Met College Hockey
description: STANDING OF THE TEAMS

title: New Help for Alcoholics
description: MONTCLAIRSince 1966, Mrs. Mary Ryan, a World War II veteran of the Army Nurse Corps, has devoted just about every minute of her time to the battle against alcoholism. And now relief columns are moving up to help share the burden.

title: Powells Cove Site For School Fought
description: Residents of the northcentral section of Queens voiced optimism last week that $1.2million in planning funds for a 2,000seat high school in their vicinity would be deleted from the city's 197374 capital budget.

title: Step Back
description: JERUSALEMThe violence and mutual mistrust that have long made the Middle East the most volatile and unpredictable of the world's trouble spots erupted again last week. The result was renewed fighting, confusion and a tragedy that harmed both sides.

title: Study Finds Community Activity Is Good Business
description: A spot check of the 27,000 industries in New Jersey shows that community involvement is simply good business, according to Scott McGlasson of the State Department of Labor and Industry.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: An eminent scientist dedicated a book to William O. Baker, as a man who understands science and technology and people. Another colleague commented that he could think of no better description.

title: CAIRO AIDE AFFIRMS U.N. MIDEAST ROLE
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Feb. 24 (AP)Hafez Ismail, a special envoy of President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, said here today that the United Nations bore a prime responsbility for peace in the Middle East and would play a very important role in promoting it.

title: Fezler Widens Margin To 3 Strokes With 204
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 24 Forrest Fezler didn't allow his golf game to fizzle today. The 23yearold Californian, who started the day with a twostroke lead over Lee Trevino in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary. National Airlines open, increased his advantage to three shots with a 68. He has a 54hole total of 204, 12 under par.

title: N.A.A.C.P. SHIFTS IN SCHOOL FIGHT
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 24The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in a major departure, consented this week to a desegregation plan for Atlantas public schools that accepts a minimum of integrated classrooms in exchange for a maximum of integrated administrative positions.

title: REUBEN HARKNESS, CHURCH HISTORIAN
description: NEW LONDON, N. H., Feb. 24 Dr. Reuben E. E. Harkness, who held the Griffith Chair of the History of Christianity at the Crozer Theological Seminary, Chester, Pa., from 1937 until his retirement in 1950, died on Feb. 16. He was 88 years old.

title: VERNON S. COOPER
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 24Vernon S. Cooper, general manager of the constructionmaterials division of the General Electric Company, died Thursday at his home here.

title: Center Crosses Ethnic Lines
description: Italian, Yiddish and English filled the room. Knishes were placed next to Italian pork sausages. A Roman Catholic priest delivered the invocation and a Hasidic rabbi delivered the benediction.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: AFTER reading Vincent Canby's review of Last Tango in Paris in the Sunday Times, I wonder if the cleanup of Times Square is simply a matter of sweeping the dirt and filth across town to the East Side.

title: Gay Franklin, Hollins Alumna, Married to Brian Barter Best
description: NOROTON, Conn., Feb. 24  Miss Gay Lloyd Franklin, greatgranddaughter of the late Right Rev. Arthur Seldon Lloyd, Suffragan Bishop of New York, was married here this afternoon to Brian Barter Best, a social worker living among Canadian Indians in High Level, Alberta.

title: Virginia F. Harrison's Wedding To Kirk Knight Held in South
description: HOBE SOUND, Fla:, Feb. 24  Miss Virginia Foster Harrison, daughter of Mr. and, Mrs. H. Stuart Harrison of Shaker Heights, Ohio, was married here this afternoon to Kirk L. Knight, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry W. Knight of Darien, Conn., and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Holdup Suspect Accused of Murder in '72 Case
description: A 20yearold Bronx man, free on bail in the shooting an offduty police lieutenant and another man in a bar robbery in Washington Heights, was arrested again yesterdaythis time on charges of murder and firstdegree robbery in an earlier holdup in the Bronx.

title: Jazz: Vital Creativity by Stamm Group
description: Marvin Stamm, a trumpet and flgelhom played, who has been with Stan Kenton, Woody Herman and the Thad JonesMel Lewis band and is very active in studio work, paused the other night between numbers by his quartet at Sam's Jazz Upstairs, Second Avenue at 64th Street, and told his listeners, In 21 years of playing music, this is the best group of musicians I've ever been with.

title: ADVERTISING POINT OF VIEW
description: What can an advertiser do who's pressed to provide substantiating facts for a claim and knows he hasn't any? If he can argue convincingly that the claim is only puffery, regulatory tradition says he'll be excused.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor: With regard to Fox Butterfield's article, Who was this enemy? (Feb. 4), it should be mentioned that the lack of this kind of personalization of the enemy in the American press has made it difficult for the average American to see the individual realities behind the generalizations and abstractions concerning the Indochina conflict.

title: Kawaida Sponsors Planning To Stay at Site Every Day
description: NEWARK, Feb. 24Imamu Amiri Baraka, the primary developer of the controversial Kawaida Towers housing project here, said today that members of the Temple of Kawaida, the sponsors, would be at the site every day next week to see that workers get in.

title: Mayhem in Paris Subway
description: PARIS, Feb. 24 (UPI)  A group of councilmen informed the City Council this week that a record 50 holdups and muggings by young hoodlums occurred in subway corridors in January menacing millions of peaceful Parisians.

title: The voice of the shepherd
description: Archbishop Anthony Bloom, representative of the Patriarch of Moscow and All Russia in Western Europe, has become a familiar figure in the religious life and ecumenical activity of England during the past few years. He has had an unusual career.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The city has stopped issuing permits for the construettcin of bulk oil and gas storage tanks until it has completed an investigation of the Staten Island gastank fire that killed 40 persons two weeks ago, it was announced yesterday.

title: Looking for a Good Drawing Show? Try Providence
description: IT has been apparent for some time, yet keeps coming as a surprise, that the more specialized the subject of an exhibition, the less likely it is to have originated in New York or to be cording here after originating elsewhere. The latest show of this kind is Drawings and Prints of the First Maniere, at the Art Museum of the Rhode Island school of Design, in Providence, concerned with a single phase of activity during a period of a mere twenty year (between 1515 and 1535) in a single city, Rome. It is of course a phase and a double decade and a city to make drawing buffs lust for a trip to the Rhode Island capital.

title: BOSTWICK DEFEATS ANGUS IN SEMIFINAL
description: TUXEDO PARK, N. Y., Feb. 24Pete Bostwick of New York defeated Howard Angus of England, 36, 62, 64, in the semifinals of the 71st Tuxedo. Gold Racquets court tennis tournament today. Angus is the British open and amateur court tennis champion.

title: Design Award
description: Hawks/Garment Associates of White Plains has won first prize in a design competition for an apartment complex for the aged in Utica. The competition was sponsored by the New York State Association of Architects.

title: N. S. King to Marry Miss Klarnet
description: Mrs. Philip Klarnet of New York and Quogue, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Kartharine Klarnet, to Nicholas Stahl King, son of Mr. and Mrs. Parker King of Behtlehem, Pa.

title: the traveler's world
description: THIS year is, without official recognition or ceremony, the 25th anniversary of the rebirth in 1948 of the international pleasure travel market. In 1946, the first full year after the ?? stepped, Europe was still bleeding and hungry, and in 1947 her concern was reconstruction rather than the business of tourism. Valid statistics are hard to find for 1946, but in 1947 the ship lines had converted enough troop ships back to liners to carry 140,485 Americans to Europe, and the airlines had bought enough surplus war planes to fly 75,000 there. Not until 1948 did Europe have the time and heart to start rebuilding what is now the world's largest single industrytourism. Asia started even later.

title: U.S. Leads Canadian Team In Speed Skating Meet
description: MILWAUKEE, Feb. 24 (AP)The United States and Canada each took two first places today in the United StatesCanada teams speed skating meet, but greater United States balance put the Americans ahead, 5136.

title: Pop
description: IN Peter Medak's antic film version of The Ruling Class, a befogged Peter O'Toole not only believes that he is Jesus Christ but also finds time to lead a chorus of other mad zanies through a swaggering version of The Varsity Drag. As familiar and sentimental as ever, this breath of the English music hall, when placed in the bizarre context of a raging comedy of the avantgarde, suddenly possessed unexpected vividness. The most creative of the contemporary pop song writers have always been aware of this clever use of contrasts. Didn't John Lennon and Paul McCartney wedge the vaudeville rock number When I'm SixtyFour between the then fashionable ambiguities of Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band?

title: Blast in a Power Complex Cripples Pacific Air Base
description: HICKAM AIR FORCE BASE, Hawaii, Feb. 24 (UPI)An explosion, followed by two fireballs and flames, knocked out a power complex today, crippling this air base, which is the headquarters for the Air Force in the Pacific.

title: In 1910 It Was Torture
description: THIS is musical barbarism  simply a cruel torture to the ear! He is sacrificing art to brutal sincerity. The dreadful meaning of the text finds intensified expression in his score. These invectives were hurled at a young and comparatively unknown composer and his opera by. Parisian critics after a premiere at the OperaComique on Nov. 30, 1910. The opera was a new version of Shakespeare's Macbeth, and the composErnest Bloch.

title: Money
description: The nagging crisis over the dollar and other paper currencies became a gold rush last week.

title: Euphronios Cup Is Reportedly Offered for Sale to the Metropolitan
description: An ancient Greek cup by the same painter who created the vase recently purchased by the Metropolitan Museum of Art has been offered for sale to the museum by Robert E. Hecht Jr., The Observer of London reports in today's issue.

title: Hadfield Back With Rangers Tonight Despite Broken Finger
description: When Vic Hadfield returns to the Rangers tonight after missing five games with a broken thumb, he will bring along something new  a broken pinkie.

title: 12 Indian Air Force Officers Caught in Smuggling Effort
description: BOMBAY, Feb. 24 (Canadian Press)  Twelve Indian Air Force officers have been punished for trying to smuggle in luxury articles from Britain and other countries, according to the Indian press.

description: THE TENOR

title: Richard B. Levene To Wed Miss. Neri
description: CROTON  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 24Mrs. John S. Neri has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Cornelia Neri, to Richard Bruce Levene, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Levene of Scarsdale. A June 3 wedding is planned.

title: PRAGUE AMNESTY MAY AFFECT FEW
description: WARSAW, Feb. 24An uncommonly gracious baggage porter at the Prague airport provided an ironic sidelight this week to the amnesty offered by Czechoslovak authorities for those who had been aboard illegally since the 1968 invasion of this country by Warsaw Pact forces.

title: Carol Halsey Has Nuptials
description: BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 Miss Carol Anne Halsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George McLean Halsey of Ruxton, was married here this evening to Edward Warner Minetree, son of Mrs. James Lawrence Minetree Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., and the late Mr. Minetree. The Rev. Roderick Doig Sinclair, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of St. Michael and All Angels.

title: MAGAZINE MAKES CATSKILLS DEBUT
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 24 A new quarterly magazine called The Catskills made its debut here last week, pledged to the twin purposes of preservation and development of the Catskill Mountains region.

title: POLYTECHNIC NAMES AN ACTING PRESIDENT
description: Norman P. Auburn, president emeritus of the University of Akron has been named acting president of the Polytechnic Institutc of Brooklyn.

title: The New York Times Book Review
description: Not every great man is at his best in his correspondence, and it will be a matter of satisfaction to the admirers of C.G. Jung to find that he triumphantly survives the test of having his letters collected and published. All the familiar Rings are here: the knotty, sometimes pedantic reasoner and empiric; the daring speculator about parapsychology and the occult; the dangerous swordanddagger polemicist; the persuasive medical politician, advancing the cause first of psychoanalysis and later of his own analytical psychology at considerable personal sacrifice and occasional risk.

title: High Court Upsets a State's Trial Rules
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24In a decision that could have a broad national impact on the criminal justice system, the Supreme Court has ordered a new trial for a Mississippi black convicted of murdering a policeman.

title: U.S BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Statewide banking, a phrase that has so far generated little stir among depositors or even borrowers, is currently the subject of much attention within the commercial banking fraternity and assorted State Houses, as well as Federal and state regulatory agencies.

description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

description: Leon Hart, former allAmerica end and Heisman Trophywinner from Notre Dame, heads a list of 11 players named yesterday to the College Football Hall of Fame.

title: 8 Old Men Keep Eyes on the Court
description: MINEOLA, L. I.  Eight elderly men meet regularly here in the Nassau County Courthouse. They are neither lawyers, judges nor actively involved in the court proceedings, but as steady observers of the judicial system, their opinion is sought by prosecutors and judges alike.

title: In OnceSpirited Seoul, People Are Now Afraid of Political Talk
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Feb. 9 Something has gone out of the life of this oncevibrant city. A touch of the verve, part of the fervor has died.

title: Kenya to Adopt Swahili As Her National Language
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, Feb. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Swahili is to become Kenya's national language, but English will continue to be used by the international communications media,, Robert Matano, Minister for Information and Broadcasting, has announced.

description: Tickets to the following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated:

title: It's a Bit Quiet South of the Border, Up Montvale Way
description: MONTVALEIn the northern tip of Bergen County, at the New York State line, communities are more rural than suburban, with curbs and sidewalks a rarity and the luxuries of nature still plentiful. One such community is Montvale, whose population has grown to 7,600 in the last decade and which abounds in modern industrial plants that abut the Garden State Parkway, at the western end of the borough.

title: Tired of February?
description: So you've got the midwinter blahs and have decided to take off for points south? You'd like to freshen up the resort wardrobe? Here are some sunseason clothes that are in the stores now. And they'll look just as good in the Hamptons come July.

title: QUESTIONS
description: If you have a question, or know the answer to a question asked in these columns, please send it to Garden News, The New York Times, Times Square, N.Y. 10036. We will publish questions of general interest and the practical solutions. Please enclose a stamped, selfaddressed envelope.

title: Kentucky Hires Black Coach
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., Feb. 24 (UPI)The University of Kentucky today hired its first black assistant football coach, Fletcher Carr, a former center and N.C.A.A. champion wrestler at the University of Tampa. Carr is also believed to be the first black assistant football coach in the Southeastern Conference. He is 23 years old.

title: Dave Anderson
description: In their labor dispute, the baseball players don't expect sympathy. But they deserve some understanding.

title: Correspondent's Choice: Eating as the Natives Do All Over the World
description: Gerofinikas. Wrapped around the think of the ancient palm tree that gives it is name, this is the restaurant I like best in all of Athens. It's the kind of place where every hors d'oeuvre is a masterpiece.

title: M'CUNE TAKES FINAL IN BOWLING SERIES
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., Feb. 24 (AP)Don McCune of Munster, Ind., broke a jinx dating back to last winter when he won the $90,000 WinstonSalem bowling tournament today.

title: PANEL SEES PRESS IN VARIED ROLES
description: The press was portrayed yesterday as the noble adversary, the corrupted arm, the indispensable analyst and the sensational distorter of government.

title: Curran May Leave N.M.U. With a Million in Benefits
description: Joseph Curran, the $85,00ayear president of the National Maritime Union, who has indicated that he does not intend to seek reelection, will be able to retire with nearly a million dollars in severance pay and lumpsum pension benefits, according to union sources.

title: Massachusetts Revenue Up
description: BOSTON, Feb. 24 (AP)Massachusetts tax collections through January, despite a reportedly high unemployment rate, ran $223.77million, ahead of the corresponding seven months in the previous fiscal year, state officials reported this week.

title: 12 REPORTED KILLED BY SHELLS IN DELTA
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 24 (AP)  Reports from the field said today that 12 South Vietnamese were killed and 10 were wounded when three shells were fired by Communist gunners into Tri Ton, a district capital in the Mekong Delta 125 miles southwest of Saigon. FourParty Joint Military Commission during the morning. A second shell hit a building being renovated for use by the International Commission of Control and Supervision. Later in the afternoon, another shell hit the district tactical operations center.

title: Ellsberg Trial
description: LOS ANGELES  To all intents and purposes, the Government has now rested its case against Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. in the Pentagon Papers trial. There has been testimony from generals and bureaucrats and from people from the insulated world of the Rand Corp. think tank, even from one former girl friend of each of the defendants.

title: Travel Notes: The Continuing Saga of Eurailpass
description: SINCE the railroad administrations of the 13 continental Western European countries first collaborated in issuing the Eurailpass in 1959, it has been used by hundreds of thousands American travelers. The pass, which must be purchased outside of Europe, is on sale not only in the United States but almost everywhere else, including Canada, Japan, Australia, Africa and South America. It permits the holder unlimited firstclass rail travel at any time, on virtually every train, in the 13 countries for a period of 21 days to three months, depending on his preference.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: The American ideal of an economic meritocracy  an arrangement where people are rewarded unequally according to their relative abilities and performance  is not a demonstrably unfair system.

title: Food & The Economy
description: WASHINGTON  The performance was mostly upbeat. The President, in his economic message to the Congress last week, accented the positive: reduced unemployment; accelerated economic growth; stable tax rates. In general, he contended, things look very bright for prosperity with only a moderate amount of inflation.

title: Yes, This Is Handke, But Very Good Handke
description: FOR Kaspar, now being performed at the Chelsea Theater Center in Brooklyn, Austrian dramatist Peter Handke has taken the celebrated case of a wild child discovered in Nuremberg in 1828the child had all the potential of an adult but could neither walk nor talkand turned it into a clownshow.

title: Television
description: IN 1966, Felipe Luciano got out of jail after serving two years of a fiveyear sentence. In 1968, he began writing poetry and became part of a group called The Last Poets. In 1969, he became a leader of the Young Lords, a New York group of rebel Puerto Ricans involved in social reforms and the antiwar movement. Today, at the advanced age of 25, he is a disk jockey on WRVRFM in Manhattan's Riverside Church.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: World Hockey Ass'n
description: YESTERDAY'S GAMES

title: News Summary and Index
The New York Times Book Review
description: SLEEPERS JOINING HANDS, by Robert Bly. (Harper, $5.95.) Poems that seek to discern the whole meaning of the dominion of life and death over America.

title: Shorter Reviews
description: The first issue came out in 1952 and was called EC's Mad Dog. Soon the name was shortened to Mad, and the magazine was churning out pictorial satire of movies, advertising, celebrities and other contemporary phenomenato the delight of a largely teenage audience. Frank Jacobs, a Mad contributor since 1957, never explains the Mad phenomenon; instead he offers a lighthearted history of the magazine and its improbable publisher William M. Gaines. Gaines had inherited a comicbook empire from his father and made it into a huge success, specializing in horror comics. When the Comics Code banned these bloodthirsty goingson, Gaines turned to Mad and has specialized in it ever since (he doesn't edit the magazine but laughs at it more than anyone). The book is studded with examples of the Madcap doings of Gaines and his staffers. Some of the humor is on the introoffice side, but the book entertains, and Mad.

title: Bridge
description: Individual rank in many activities is in direct proportion to the amount of worrying that has to be done. In a Napoleonic campaign the Emperor would worry ceaselessly for 20 hours out of 24, thereby destroying more complacent generals who did not find it necessary to concern themselves with such details as strategy, tactics and supplies. Least concerned of all is the private soldier, who in a later age sang: What's the use of worrying, it never was worthwhile.

title: HAMLET REJECTS BECOMING VILLAGE
description: HAMPTON BAYS, L. I., Feb. 24The hamlet of Hampton Bays voted today not to transform itself into a fullfledged villagea distinction that may appear unimportant to outsiders, but that to the 7,000 people here in this seaside resort community is far from academic.

title: Legislation Elsewhere
description: Those skiers and ski area developers who are ready to abandon Vermont as overcrowded and overregulated will have to hurry in their search for a substitute. Other states are acting as well.

title: MIDDLEBURY GETS LEAD IN CARNIVAL
Some Draft Evaders to Go Unpunished in Prosecution Breakdown
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 24Despite President Nixon's pledge that there will be no amnesty for draft resisters, a number of young Americans who fled to Canada and Europe to avoid military service during the Vietnam war will go unpunished because of breakdowns in the method of prosecuting them.

title: The bloody pressure on 22 million Americans
description: Of all the rituals, that mark the routine physical examination, the measurement of blood pressure has always suffered for want of glamour. The simple twofigure readings based upon the quick adjustments of the inflatable cuff, the asthmatic pumping of the rubber ball, the jerky climb and precipitous fall of the thin mercury line, seem primitive compared to the complex ciphers that represent the fracturing of a drop of blood into calcium, phosphorus, glucose, proteins and, of course, the various assortments of arteryplugging fats carried by the blood stream.

title: LIPTON CUP TAKEN BY CASCADE, KETCH
description: MIAMI, Feb. 24Heavy air that turned to light, a number of protests and a computerdefying number of yachts kept a figureweary race committee up late tonight trying to find a winner of the Lipton Cup, the fourth race in the Southern Ocean Racing Conference.

title: How to be healthy, wealthy and wiseeconomically
description: It is harder than it looks to write good popular economics. First of all, you have to be charged up on an issuenobody but a professional would read economics for pleasure or for mere understanding. Second, you have to write well. And third, you have to get it right, at least if you care what the brothers back in the university will think. Peter Passell and Leonard Ross respectively pass these tests with high marks, including the third, which is by far the hardest. The main problem with their book is that it is just a little too sensible because, unfortunately, the fourth rule about writing popular economics is that baloney outsells meat and potatoes.

title: Aid to Hanoi
description: WASHINGTONWith Secretary of State William P. Rogers sitting at the witness table of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal began wondering aloud.

title: Miss Young Wins at 500 Meters in Title Skating
description: STROMSUND, Sweden, Feb. 24 (AP)Sheila Young of Detroit, the world sprint champion, won the 500 meters today in the women's world speed skating championships, but Mrs. Antje KeulenDeelstra of the Netherlands, the defending champion, took the overall lead.

title: Upgrading Under Way in Central Park South Hotels
description: New York's dowager hotels along Central Park South are undergoing facelifts.

title: An Eastern European Diary
description: My associates and I had been planning this trip for more than six months, but we could never have hoped for a more auspicious start. The very day we landed in Budapest and entered Eastern Europe the Vietnam peace settlement was signed. On this most positive note began a fascinating, rewarding and exhausting visit to Hungary, Yugoslavia, Rumania and Poland.. In less than nine days we were to have some 50 meetings with officials of these four countries.

title: ISLANDERS BREAK LOSS STREAK AT 8

title: AROUND THE

Beautifully illustrated as in all the series, this one is packed with solid information on howto grow. There is an additional section on herbs and fruittree spraying. The books are $6.95 each and distributed through Little, Brown, available in major bookstores.

title: Bergen Center Helps Troubled Children Ease Tensions

But at the Holley ChildCare and Development Center, the blocks, picture hooks and tiny pots and pans serve a more serious purpose. They make up the therapeutic milieu for 25 emotionally disturbed 3to5yearolds, all of whom spend five hours at the center every weekday.

title: Many Japanese Quit Smoking
description: TOKYO, Feb. 24 (AP)More than 9.8 million Japanese, or 30 per cent of the country's smokers, stopped smoking in 1972, the Government tobacco monopoly has estimated. The Japan Monopoly Corporation estimated that more than 19 million men and four million women still were smoking at the end of 1972.

title: France

But the melodramatic theft last week of the remains of the man who is a great hero to many Frenchmenand a great traitor to many othersrubbed away for a moment the salve of forgetfulness under which the psychological wounds of World War II lie unhealed.

He also arbitrates domestic strife within the National Football League. That is painful.

The key enables voters to comply with legal requirements that they cast a vote, but at the same time allows them to abstain from voting for anyone.

title: Apportionment

title: He and She and Godard

Work backward from Vladimir and Rosa, through Wind From the East, One A.M., Le Gai Savoir, La Chinoise, Two or Three Things I Know About Her and Vivre Sa Vie, all the way to Breathless, using the original French titles or their English translations, and it would be difficult to tell exactly when Godard became converted by the Radical Left, when he elected to make only revolutionary teaching films for audiences of an ever dwindling number of supporters.
