title: Sappho Was a RightOn Woman
description: If we assume that the current feminist movement does indeed constitute a grave threat to capitalist white male supremacy, what must we discern as an effective powerretaining strategy by the powerholders? Runofthe mill redbaiting must be phased out in an era when President Nixon goes to Peking, and in a situation as unstructured as current feminism. (They can't have forgotten how the House UnAmerican Activities Committee stubbed its toes on the Women's Strike for Peace.) It appears, on the other hand, that lesbianism just might be the ideal fuller's earth to sop up feminism as a widescale rankandfile universal revolution, and to neatly dispose of it as an elitist, sectarian and exotic bypath.

title: Slightly revolutionary
description: New York has a concentration of working artists not to be matched elsewhere. The city draws artists from all over the world just as Paris did a generation or so ago. Artists have traditionally been considered antisocial, antiestablishment, and antihome. It's time to change that image. With the advent of loftliving in SoHo (Manhattan's south Houston Street area) many artists have acquired an enormous living space that has to be furnished and equipped. And they want the same amenities for themselves and their families as other city residents. The way artists achieve this, though, is decidedly different from the way most people do. What happens when the artist designs for the home? The results can be as brilliantly elementary as the table leg devised by Francois Arnal. It functions just like a carpenter's Cclamp. Four legs, can be clamped to any kind of top to make a table. Seating? Artist George McClancy, a SoHo painter from Philadelphia, who also teaches art at City University, takes the hardedge approach with his designs for a sofa, table and chair made with knockdown parts that fit together with handsome wooden dowels and can be shipped in flat cartons. Richard Moore, a graphics artist, takes the softedge approach with his duffle chair, three idendeal cushions filled with polyester pellets held together with canvas straps. (When the cushions get dirty, you unbelt the straps, remove the zippered covers and throw them in the washing machine.) Hedi Kyle, a SoHo refugee from California, has designed a line of table linens in brightly colored folkart motifs on natural muslin. Other artists inject a touch of wit or social concern into the design of their objects. Both sculptor Caspar Henselmann and Arman designed ashtrays to discourage smoking. Henselmann's is a fleshpink mockup of the human heart (the cigarette rests on the indentation of the aorta) while Arman's elegant metal rectangle spells out the word cancer. The diversity of these products and the freewheeling approach to design reflects the openmindedness of The Maplewalnut Studio, a new firm started by Ariane Brener and Graziella Lobo. The studio is geared to market and produce the work of American artists though they do have a working arrangement with Atelier A in Paris to exchange ideas and artistic talent. At first, the artists were very reluctant to work with us, says Ariane, because they don't want to be associated with anything commercial. We finally convinced each one that we aren't selling products, but a concept. And that concept is to involve artists in the needs of society and to put some love back into the making and selling of objects. Design, they argue, has become too much of a big business. The artist and artisan give their heart, they maintain, and we hope that the public will find the same joy in buying that we have found in making the items. Actually production hasn't always been a joy. Manufacturers are hesitant to produce items in small quantities, especially when the items don't conform to their idea of a commercial product. Mass production methods do not favor the small, experimental designer. Finding sympathetic manufacturers has not been easy. The set of table legs, for instance, called The Tablemaker, will be produced by Milgo Art Systems in Brooklyn, a fabricator of architectural metal work. Milgo got involved with artists and art by a fluke in the nineteensixties. After executing a design for artist Michael Steiner, it became a major fabricator of large scale art works for Claes Oldenburg, Richard Serra, Alexander Lieberman, Bernard Rosenthal and graphics designer Ivan Chermayeff. We do it for the love, explains Bruce Gitlin, son of Milgo's owner, we actually lose money at it. For the table linens designed by Hedi Kyle, the studio looked as far afield as India for a producer in an attempt to keep the retail prices in line with what people can afford. They hope to be able to sell them at $3 a napkin and $4 a place mat, since a major goal of Maplewalnut is to keep prices down. But that's not its only goal. We are really an open house, a forum, for ideas. We've started with objects for the home, but eventually we hope to move into many other areas, such as music and even communications. The aim, of course, is to give artists and other creative individuals, who seem left out of the mainstream, a voice in today's supercommercial society. Whether such a concept can succeed or not, Maplewalnut attempts to fill a void that many have felt for a long time.

title: Listening to March
description: Any morning now, you may hear March coming over the hill and up the valley, and some bright, calm mornings you can almost hear April. You probably mistake it for a cardinal whistling, but that is because you haven't heard a cardinal whistle just that way since last May or June. So you call it a cardinal, not daring to tempt the weather gods by even mentioning April. You heard a cardinal, you say, and isn't it wonderful to hear the cardinals whistling again?

title: Antioch Proposes An Exchange Plan With the Chinese
description: YELLOW SPRINGS, Ohio, Feb. 24Antioch College has proposed an educational exchange program with China, hoping that its reputation as a progressive college will persuade the Chinese to let a selected group of Antioch students and faculty members study language and Chinese society at a Chinese university next year.

title: Science
description: The City that waits to die, was the title of a television program in New York recently. It was about San Francisco and the high probability of a major earthquake there. Last week a moderate quake that shook Oxnard, farther south along the coast, was one more reminder of the constant crustal motion that seems to make such a quake inevitable.

title: Alert Environmentalists Preserve San Francisco Bay
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Feb. 24Norman Babkirk, who has been hunting, fishing and walking along the shore of San Francisco Bay for most of his 68 years, observed several trucks last summer dumping dirt in a lagoon where rails and other waterfowl ride out storms. He called a friend who notified the United States Army Corps of Engineers, which ordered the filling halted.

title: NETS ARE BEATEN BY TAMS, 10897
description: MEMPHIS, Feb. 24 The Memphis Tams defeated the New York Nets, 10897, tonight to climb within two games of the Nets in the battle for fourth place and a berth in the American Basketball Association's Eastern Division playoffs.

title: Venanzis Have Son
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., Feb. 24A son was born Feb. 12 to Mr. and Mrs. Eugene T. Venanzi of Southport and Rome in the Bridgeport Hospital. Mrs. Venanzi is the former Anna Maria Clambriello of Undina, Italy.

title: MARYLAND AVENGES LOSS, ROUTING DUKE
description: COLLEGE PARK, Md., Feb. 24 (UPI)John Lucas, a freshman, sparked ninthranked Maryland to a 9668 victory over Duke today, avenging an 8581 loss to the Blue Devils three weeks ago.

title: Man and Woman Boy and Girl
description: Of the intellectual problems which men have worried about since civilization began, one of the most persistently trying has been variously expressed as: free will vs. determinism, nature vs. nurture, heredity vs. environment and, most recently, genetics vs. culture. Are people born murderous or loving, heterosexual or homosexual, male or female, or do they learn to be that way from the world around them?

title: A Country Club That Excludes the Married
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y.A sign tacked to the sauna bath at the Chateau D'Vie country club here informs members:

title: RATIO FOR MALES IN COLLEGE FALLS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The college attendance rate among young men has fallen sharply to its lowest level in eight years, according to new Census Bureau findings issued today.

title: Three Auto Race Tracks Are Back in the Running
description: Things are looking up for three major race tracksRoad Atlanta, Phoenix and Poconobut a fourth one, Ontario Motor Speedway, has suffered still another setback.

title: Caracas Allows Null Vote
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, Feb. 24Venezuela's electoral council has approved a null key on voting machines in next December's presidential elections. The key enables voters to comply with legal requirements that they cast a vote, but at the same time allows them to abstain from voting for anyone.

title: City U. Tuition Asked
description: A special commission on higher education appointed by Governor Rockefeller last fall will recommend an end to the 128yearold free tuition policy at the City University of New York, commission sources said. Page 33.

title: Kennedy Road Defeats Crusading by Nose at Santa Anita
description: ARCADIA, Calif. (AP)Kennedy Road, the Canadian champion, spoiled the Cinderella effort of the $1 American horse, Crusading; when he won the $83,150 San Antonio Stakes today by a nose in a tremendous stretch drive at Santa Anita.

title: The business of buying
description: Consumerism seldom tops anyone's list of urgent public issues. Yet it involves all of us. From shoeshine boys to Presidents, we have marketplace disappointments. There is a big public out there waiting for the author who offers consolation and hope.

title: MATTHEW H. FOX
description: Matthew H. Fox, a member of the staff of the Twentieth Century Fund, died Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital, apparently of a heart attack. He was 26 years old and lived at 51 West 87th Street and in Verbank, N. Y.

title: Why My Sons Watch The Waltons
description: SAFETY is what is stressed. Outside, it is dark and cold. There are bears on the mountain, and the night is full of howling. Inside the house, there is light and warmth and coffee on the stoveA blue enamel coffeepot grasped with the edges of a faded cotton apron.

title: CONSERVANCY GROUP GIVES LAND TO U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24The Interior Department has accepted a part of what will eventually be the largest single land donation ever made to the Federal Government for wildlife conservation.

title: The Dance
description: The story of Adam and Eve would seem to have exhausted all possible interpretations by now. But it is a subject that has held particular fascination for choreographers in the last 15 years, and certainly John Butler's treatment of it in After Eden is one of the most successful and theatrical. The ballet, danced with great power by Starr Danias and Dennis Wayne, was given Thursday night by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the City Center.

title: Where a TwoHorse Race Is Bilingual
description: FROM the starting gate spring two beautiful quarter horses, whipped on by tiny, helmeted jockeys. The horses charge down the track, creating a muted but growing crescendo filtered through dust, their eyes bulging and bright. There is no grandstand, and a hundred or so spectators press against the fence of the inside lane.

title: WILLIAM BERGH KIP
description: SARASOTA, Fla., Feb. 24 William Bergh Kip, a member of one of New York's oldest families, died today at his home here. He was 68 years old.

title: PENN STATE GAINS WRESTLING TITLE
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (AP) A victory by Charlie Getty in the last match of the semifinal consolation round clinched the team title today for Penn State at the Eastern Collegiate Wrestling Association tournament.

title: SAIGON AIDE SEES MEETING IN PARIS EASING U.S. ROLE
description: PARIS, Feb. 24  Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam of South Vietnam said today that the unstated but real purpose of the international conference on Vietnam opening here Monday was to deAmericanize the peace.

title: Record Crowd Watches Cougars Top Crusaders
description: CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (AP)The Chicago Cougars scored two finalperiod goals to insure a 52 victory over the Cleveland Crusaders tonight in a World Hockey Association game.

title: Capital Will Test System Giving Buses Green Light
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (Reuters)City buses are being fitted with electronic devices designed to give buses a clear path of green traffic lights at the flick of the driver's switch.

title: The sickness is colonialism, the cure is revolution
description: In 1956, while stationed at an outpost of the Free World, I read in the Stars and Stripes one morning that a young Negro woman named Autherine Lucy had been admitted to the University of Alabama, at the point of a court order and bayonets. That news item was also read by two other residents of our barracks, a couple of rather elemental white Southerners whom I shall call Julius and Flem. Julius threw the paper aside with an expression of mixed disgust and anger and said, By God, Flem, ah reekon it's about time to go home an' git the ol' shotgun off the wall an' shoot us up some of that nigger meat.

title: City Council Hearings Scheduled This Week
description: Following are public hearings scheduled this week by City Council committees in the City Council Room at City Hall:

title: New & Novel
description: The Distance And the Dark

title: Arboretums Are for Seeing and Learning
description: THE best place to learn trees is at a about tree museum which is called an arboretum, taken from the Latin, arbor, for tree.

title: The Region
description: It was straight out of Eric Ambler: a flawless Euphronios krater, flashing into the limelight after more than two millennia in oblivion, a million dollars changing hands, an American art dealer flying from Rome to meet an Armenian in Beirut and then vanishing.

title: Arthur Daley
description: The letter was, written more in sorrow than in anger. Qr was it? If indignation lurked beneath all the polite phrases, such asperity rated justification. At least I think so, because I agree fully with the unassailable position taken by the letter writer, Art Modell, the president of the Cleveland Browns:

title: Miss Virginia A. Ewart Plans Bridal in England
description: Miss Virginia Anne Ewart and Peter Constable Maxwell who is a greatgrandson of the late Marmaduke Constable Maxwell, 10th Lord Heries; a greatnephew of Simon Fraser, 15th Lord Lovat, and a cousin of the Duke of Norfolk, plan to be married this summer at Old Arlesford, Hampshire, England.

title: Dr. Bob Smith Becomes Fiance Of Miss Adams
description: Capt. Allen B. Adams Jr., U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Adams of New York and Old. Lyme, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Taylor Adams, to Dr. Bob Lorin Smith, son of Lieut. Col. Robert Q. Smith Jr., U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Smith of Dallas.

title: Busy Conservatives Pick Beaver as Party Symbol
description: New York State's Conservative party has been bewailing political privation for lack of a symbol such as the Democrats' donkey and Republicans' elephant, which offer endless variations to imaginative editorial cartoonists.

title: Miss Elias Fiancee Of Stephen P. Snell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Pierce Elias of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter. Miss Wallis Faye Elias, to Stephen Paul Snell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Snell of Passaic, N. J. The wedding is planned for June 3.

title: Seafood Store Offers a Taste of Culture
description: BELLEVILLEOld bronze chandeliers from a church, antique ceramic seafood plates and original oil paintings are not normally the decor of a seafood market. But it's all there, and more, in Sal's Sea Food, Inc., at 10 Bloomfield Avenue.

title: Colleges
description: We know we have a courtship. We hope to have a love affair, but we haven't yet started to talk of marriage.

title: Theodore Southgate to Marry Christina A. Graves on June 26
description: GROSSE POINTE PARK, Mich., Feb. 24Miss Christina Adrienne Graves plans to be married June 26 to Theodore John Southgate, a candidate for a Ph.D. in mathematics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

title: A very live issue
description: Death, like sex, is an old taboo subject that is taboo no longer. And David Hendin has made use of the new freedom he feels to write frankly and clinically about the dead and dying, which, of course, includes all of us. Death isn't as much fun as sex, but it is just as fascinating.

title: Tim speaks in rhyme, not all the time
description: Nissesor rather nisserare a cross between the German Rumpelstiltskin and an Arabian genie, except that they live in Denmark. When treated with care and respect they can, like the shoemaker's elves, bring you great good fortune; but Tim, the nisse who lived on the Timsgaard estate, was not being treated with care and respect until Sorn, a robust and clever young farmhand, came along. Then between the two of them the estateand Sornbegan to prosper.

title: Wedding Held For Linda Lane
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., Feb. 24Miss Linda Jeanne Lane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Cummings Lane of Westfield, Weekapaug, R. I., and Peru, Vt., was married here this afternoon to Merrit Heminway Merriman, 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Heminway Merriman of Watertown, Conn., and Weekapaug. Canon William M. Hale assisted by the Rev. Jackson Foley, performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of the Atonement.

title: Sally B. Castleman Is Betrothed
description: Miss Sally Boone Castleman plans to be married to James Angus Currie Jr, June 9 in St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: Coast ExP.O.W.'s Find We're a Whole Family Again
description: CORONADO, Calif., Feb. 24  Kirk Jenkins weeds gardens to make extra spending money, and he has been saving up for something special.

title: DOG SHOW AWARD TO YAN 'N YELLY
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., Feb. 24A Yorkshire terrier with silken tresses flowing tot he ground was named best of 1,592 dogs at the 64th Providence Kennel Club show today. She was Ch. Mayfair Barban Yan 'N Yelly, owned by Philip Lanard and his mother, Mrs. Gertrude Lanard. It was a popular victory for the 5pound toy, who is a local dog, coming from Warwick, R. I.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: PROVIDENCE, Feb. 24 (AP) Marvin Barnes the nation's top college rebounder, pulled in 23 rebounds and scored 20 points today in leading seventhranked Providence College to an 8765 basketball victory over Seton Hall.

title: NO BLACKS SEEN IN MAYORAL RUE
description: The city's top black leaders have virtually given up on the possibility of running a black candidate for Mayor.

title: Ballet: Arpino Jackpot
description: Gerald Arpino seems to have a special liking for rather gimmicky duets. A few seasons back he gave us Valentine, and now, Friday night at the City Center 55th Street Theater, the City Center Joffrey Ballet offered the New York premiere of his. Jackpot.

title: Mother and Child Are Killed in Leap In Brooklyn Fire
description: A mother and, her 2yearold daughter were killed early yesterday when the woman, holding the child, jumped from the fourth floor during a tenement fire in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Another woman lost her life in a Harlem fire, and a man living alone died in a fire in his East Side apartment.

title: Is Cahill's Popularity Slipping?
description: TRENTON  The Legislature certainly has not been Governor Cahill's best friend over the last year.

title: Meredith Baird a Bride
description: PARK RIDGE, N. J., Feb. 24Miss Meredith Lu Baird and Frederick Tyrone Murphy were married here this afternoon in Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church.

title: State Program Aiding Ambulance Crews
description: TRENTON  The state's Department of Health has undertaken a new and rapidly expanding program to train and accredit ambulance volunteers.

title: Art is in order to cope
description: Anthony Storr belongs to group of English psychiatrists who have become critical of psychoanalysis but have maintained Freud's commitment to broad, philosophical enquiry; this group eschews narrow medical analysis on the one hand and liberation psychiatry on the other. Storr shares with such colleagues as Charles Rycroft, Geoffrey Corer and Peter Lomas a clear, jargonfree approach to psychological issues; his work is distinctive, however, because of his interest in ethology. He believes a psychology of man can be derived from comparing men to other advanced primates. Storr is himself more sophisticated in this endeavor than B. F. Skinner, however; in Human Aggression for example, Storr wants to know what appears unique about man when he is compared to other primates as well as what appears to be merely animal.

title: Night Cream for Everybody Over 30
description: He isn't exactly claiming he's found the fountain of youth, but Charles Revson, the head of Revlon, is indicating that he's come close. He speaks of an advancement, a breakthrough. If pressed, he says, Everybody over 30 should be inter. ested.

title: Drug Users Are Given Hope in Queens
description: Young people at loose ends, dabbling in soft drugs are walking through an unpromising looking storefront ere to find the promise of fresh aims through psycho?? help, personal development and vocational training.

title: The Ageless Ruins of Italy Are In Danger of Finally Dying
description: EARLY last summer an American woman emerging with a party of fellow tourists from an exhausting morning spent tramping about the ancient Roman forums was heard to remark that in some places the grass grew so tall that it reminded her of a safari she once took through the African bush. I could have sworn I saw a lion, she said.

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE PRICE OF GOLD soared to an unprecedented high of $95 an ounce in the London market before dropping to $85 at the weekend ... Declines in clothing, home furnishings, housing and usedcar prices failed to offset a 2.3 per cent rise in food prices during January and the consumer price index registered a 0.3 per cent rise for the month ... Prices of foreign cars in the United States are rising because of the revaluation of the dollar. Volkswagen raised prices about 7 per cent and similar or larger increases were predicted for Toyota.

title: Shadow Over Banks in London
description: LONDONIn 1940, the London branch of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company was destroyed by enemy action. The bank did not consider it worth rebuilding an office in London until 1956. Even then it allowed its lease in Lombard Street to lapse, because of the volume of prospective business was not expected to justify such a prime site.

title: Paul M. Elkin Fiance of Leila M. Joseph
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., Feb. 24Dr. and Mrs. Edward D. Joseph of Scarsdale have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leila Muriel Joseph, to Paul M. Elkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Elkin of Larchmont.

title: SOMERVILLE TAKES JERSEY TRACK TITLE
description: JERSEY CITY, Feb. 24Reggie Blackshear of Metuchen set a meet record of 7.1 seconds in the 60yard high hurdles to highlight the New Jersey state interscholastic track and field championships today at the Jersey. City Armory.

title: Manhattan Sets Back Fairfield On Strong Rebounding, 6955
description: Postseason tournament hopes Manhattan College kept its alive with a 69.55 victory over FAIRFIELD, Conn., Feb. 24Fairfield. The Jaspers were led by two sophomores, Bill Campion and George Bucci.

title: Andrea Strongin To Be Wed in May
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L. I. Feb. 24Mr. and Mrs. Martin Strongin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Andrea Robin Strongin to James Robert Abraham, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Abraham of New York. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Scientists Find Value In Dead Whale Here
description: The Smithsonian Institution in Washington has confirmed that a young injured whale that had washed ashore in Beach Haven, N.J.and was removed to the New York Aquarium in Coney Island shortly afterward, where it died despite an allout effort to keep it alivewas a male of the rare species known as Blainsville's beaked whale, or Mesoplodon densirostris.

title: Plan Held Boating Peril
description: BAYVILLE, L. I.The dirtiest word in a Long Island Sound sailor's vocabulary these days is bridge. When used with the phrase, proposed from Rye to Oyster Bay, it can create instant rage in a yachtsman, environmentalist, fisherman or commercial skipper.

title: Walter Reade Jr., Who Headed Theater Chain, Is Killed Skiing
description: Walter Reade Jr., president and board chairman of the Walter Reade theater chain, died late yesterday during a skiing accident near St. Moritz, Switzerland. He was 56 years old and had lived in Sea Bright, N. J.

title: Grade Schools
description: A visitor to the firstgrade classroom In Public School 77 in the Bronx senses at once that something unusual is happening: Most of the children, seated at four tables in different parts of the room, are quietly talking, as if to themselves, as they pore over their workbooks. Each youngster has a small pile of tokens in front of him, and as the teachers make the rounds and look at each pupil's work, they keep dealing out more chips, always with an approving word or a smile.

title: Music:
description: Josef Suk, the Czech violinist, and Joerg Demo, the Viennese pianist, have demonstrated their chamber expertise on a number of separate occasions, and a firm sense of ensemble tapportmarked their debut here as a team. Their program at the Metropolitan Museum Friday night was unusually constructed  sonatas by Brahms, Mozart, Janacek and Mozart again, in that order but the pacing seemed appropriate.

title: Hearing Is Planned on Controversial WaterPollution Bill
description: TRENTON  The chairman of the Assembly Committee on Air and Water Pollution and Public Health has announced that he will hold a public hearing on a proposal to levy effluent fees against water polluters.

title: Medical Society Faces Discipline Issues
description: Officials of the New York County Medical Society, one of the largest and most prestigious in the country, are making a bread reassessment of the 167yearold organization's regulatory policy as they try to come to grips with the issues raised by the case of Dr. Max Jacobson.

title: Pats Sign Johnson, Booras
description: FOXBORO, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP)The New England Patriots today signed Daryl Johnsbn, a cornerback, and Steve Booras, a defensive end who starred for the Montreal Alouettes in 1970, for the 1973 National Football League season.

title: Zisk Signs Pirate Pact
description: PITTSBURGH, Feb. 24 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Pirates signed today an outfielder, Richie Zisk, to a 1973 contract, leaving only a third baseman, Richie Hebner, unsigned. Zisk hit .311 last year with the Pirates AAA farm club, the Charleston Charlies, and led the International League with 26 home runs.

title: GELDING SCORES BY HEAD IN PACE
description: YONKERS, FEB. 24Only 21,420 harnessracing fans turned out at Yonkers Raceway tonight for the final Saturday card of the meeting, which will end on Thursday do the corresponding date two years ago, the attendance was 29,756.

title: Cowboys, Rams Play Aug. 3
description: DALLAS, Feb. 24 (UPI)With confirmation of a game with the Los Angeles Rams Aug. 3, the Dallas Cowboys today completed their 1973 preseason football schedule.

title: SuccessOr Extinction?
description: A world conference is now proceeding in Washington which can, if it achieves the purpose of its American hosts, do more than any action yet taken to save the endangered animals of this world from extinction. That objective is an international agreement to support the conservation efforts of individual countries that are now made all but meaningless by the readiness of other countries to provide markets for the poacher and the illicit trader.

title: Architecture
description: IT COULD almost be called a hotbed of preservation around Astor Place and Lafayette and East Fourth Streetswith the Old Merchants' House finally being restored under the tender loving care of architect Joe Roberto and the Decorators' Club with some long overdue, grants, Joe Papp's New York Shakespeare Public Festival Theater setting cultural, architectural and urban standards in the old Astor Library, and Cooper Union now embarking on the renovation of its 114year old Foundation Building.

title: MAGAZINE MAKES CATSKILLS DEBUT
description: PRATTSVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 24 A new quarterly magazine called The Catskills made its debut here last week, pledged to the twin purposes of preservation and development of the Catskill Mountains region.

title: Coop Rises On 89th St.
description: Peter Sharp & Co., Inc., has begun construction of a 31  story  and  penthouse cooperative apartment building at 50 East 89th Street that will include four townhouses at street level.

title: For Business, Urban Renewal Can Be Lethal
description: Gershon Mamlak is spitting tacks, a fact that has nothingand everything to do with his upholstery and interior decorating business.

title: The obsessiveness of the
description: TAOS, N. M. When a man's work, freely chosen, consists in running the distance of 26 miles and 385 yards as quickly as possible, he has to expect an occasional question about his masochism. But Frank Shorter, who is just now the finest distance runner in the worldthe United States recordholder at 2 miles (indoors) and 10,000 meters (outdoors) and the first American to win the Olympic marathon since 1908not only denies his masochism, he considers its postulation romantic. I know this one guy says the marathon is like cutting yourself over and over with a razor blade. That's cocktailparty talk. There's pain, sure, but it's not so bad. I don't believe anyone can stand that sort of pain so long.

title: Carpenter Joins Oilers
description: HOUSTON, Feb. 24 (AP)The Houston Oilers announced today the hiring of Lew Carpenter as a receiver coach.

title: Bombs Yesterday, Aid Today
description: At least since President Johnson's speech at Johns Hopkins University in April, 1965, the United States has been committed to the economic reconstruction of Indochina, including North Vietnam, after the end of the war. Now it begins to appear that the Nixon Administration has a bear by the tail in its desire to fulfill this commitment.

title: Bachelors Are Turning to Shared Lives in Rental Homes
description: WOODCLIFF LAKEWith increasing frequency, young bachelors are banding together in familysize groups to share the rental of homes.

title: Financiers Beat a Path to Tokyo's. Door
description: TOKYO  William H. Moore, chairman of the Bankers Trust Company, stretched his legs out from under his chair in the Hotel Okura here one day last month and said: Tokyo is a money center now. With further liberalization, it will be even more of a money center. We wanted to be here on time, and we're looking forward to a much more dynamic market.

title: Music
description: THIS is part of being the star of stars: You get to your dressing room two hours before the performance. You speak in whispers; the voice cannot be strained. You put your head into a French inhaler that contains glycerine and Dobell solution, and you breathe this for 15 minutes. Not until then is the throat clean. Perhaps then you might try a few light scales and arpeggios. This is followed by a touch of Swedish snuff to clear the nostrils. During all this, you have been getting into costume. You then gargle with warm water and salt. Finally you take a sip of diluted Scotch. You are ready. Presently the assistant stage manager appears. May we begin, Mr.

title: Samuel Scoggins Fiance of Miss Naylor
description: CINCINNATI, Feb. 24Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Hawley Naylor have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Emerson Naylor, to Samuel McWhirter Scoggins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Samuel Scoggins of Bethesda, Md. The wedding is planned for August.

title: Green on King Injury List
description: KANSAS CITY, Feb. 24 (AP) The Kansas CityOmaha Kings announced today that Johnny Green has been placed on the injury list and a rookie, Frank Schade from EauClaire State, has been activated. Green injured a knee Thursday.

title: The Sputnik Rapist
description: As novel, The Sputnik Rapist is something of an oyster; it rewards more for occasional digressions than for its natural business. Carl Jonas has a drawling, broad wit that's best when caught young and unawares. Fed into the unwieldy plot contraptiona thing for which you properly need maps, miner's lamp and a trail of croutons behindwit can degenerate to slapstick or, worse, sentimentality.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Since Congress has shown itself so incapable of giving we the people indirect control over foreign policy, a spate of commentary has suggested that the time has come for serious reconsideration of the entire foreign policy mechanism in a democracy. The framers of the Constitution feared giving us complete direct control over national policy, in that representatives the Senate were appointed ed by the legislatures, and not elected. Eventually that flaw in our democracy was corrected.

title: New Dressage Group To Work With A.H.S.A.
description: A new organization, the United States Dressage Federation, has been founded as a result of a meeting of 65 delegates representing 19 regional dressage groups last weekend in Lincoln, Neb. The federation has the blessing of the American Horse Shows Association. In fact, Jack Fritz, the A.H.S.A. representative on the scene, conducted the meetings. John Winnett of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., chairman of the A.H.S.A. dressage committee, dispatched Fritz to the meeting to outline the functions and aims of the parent organization to the delegates.

title: Analysts See Bumpy Credit Road in 1973
description: Nothing is more vital to the functioning of our economic system than the proess by which money is raised from savers and investors and channeled to consumers, business and government.

title: News of the Camera World
description: AN UNUSUALLY compact little photoelectric slave tripper that can be used to convert almost any electronic flash to a slave light has just been introduced by Honeywell Photographic Products, Inc., Box 1010, Littleton, Col. 80120. Called the FotoEye II and priced at $14.95, this unit, when plugged into an existing electronic flash, will automatically fire it when another flash in the same room is firedthus enabling the photographer to fire two (or more) flash units simultaneously without intercorrecting wires and without cutting down on the power of any of the individual lights.

title: A Universe Bound By a Malevolent Fate
description: THERE are exhibitions almost as interesting in their timing as they are in their contents. The Prints of Edvard Munch, now resplendently installed in the firstfloor galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, is certainly a case in point. Munch is one of the most powerful artists of the modern period, yet his work stands at so great a distance from the art of our day that it seems at times to belong to another civilization. That it doesn'tthat still speaks to something central our livesis readily enough apparent if we compare it, not to the painting or scuipture or printmaking that makes the most Imperative claims on our attention nowadays but to work in other mediums, to films, poetry, fiction, autobiography and even still photography. Between Munch's characteristic image's and the majority of the works, say, in the current Whitney Biennial, there are no common impulses. They inhabit different worlds and address theinselves to different sensibilities. But place these same images beside the films, of Ingmar Bergman or the work of a great many contemporary poets, and Munch quickly and unmistakably reeniefges as our contemporary quote from a poem called In the Room, by Harvey Shapiro, in the current number of The Hudson Review:

title: Stamps
description: WITH the Apollo program and its tremendous achievements already receding into history, a history that on the philatelic side unfortunately includes the trafficking of space covers by astronauts, the stage of space is awaiting the cue for the Skylab II manned space flight.

title: What's Opened At the Movies?
description: SAVE THE TIGER, directed by John G. Avildsen, got 7 favorable reviews (Howard Kissel, Women's Wear; Rex Reed, News; Molly Haskell, Village Voice; Leonard Harris, WCBSTV; Jeffrey Lyons, WP1XTV; Judith Crist, New York; Arthur Knight, Saturday Review), 9 mixed (Vincent Canby, Times; Kathleen Carroll, News; Archer Winsten, Post; Frances Taylor, Newhouse Newspapers; Joseph Gelmis, Newsday; Bernard Drew, Gannett News Service; Gene Shalit, NBC; Stanley Kauffmann, New Republic; Paul D. Zimmerman, Netvsweek) and 3 negative (Pauline Kael, New Yorker; Donald 3. Mayerson, Cue; Jay Cocks, Time).

title: Red cabbage and chestnuts
description: You don't have to eat pork with applesauce. In Limoges, the French accompany pork with red cabbage and chestnuts. While the roast is roasting, New Yorkers who want to go just one step further can throw together a piquant sauce. All of this makes hefty eating, elegant but hardly effete.

title: Arms
description: WASHINGTONEver since Senator Gerald Nye's investigating committee turned the spotlight in the 1930's on the merchants of death  the world's munitions makersthe United States has vacillated on whether it should provide arms to foreign countries.

title: Laos Reports Drop in Truce Violations and Calls Situation Clearly Improved
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Feb. 24The Laotian command said today that ceasefire violations by Communist forces had declined sharply during the last 24 hours, and that the situation was clearly improved.

title: Rutgers Intensifies Its Fight On Crime
description: NEW BRUNSWICK  Acting in response to an increase in violent crime last autumn, Rutgers University has Installed, at a cost of $5,000, 20 emergency security telephones on its Rutgers, Douglass and Livingston College campuses.

title: Criminals At Large
description: A trio from France  and a trio within the trio: GREEN, LIGHT, RED CATCH, by Francis Ryck, translated by Gordon Latta (Stein & Day, $5.95); THE CAT'S EYE, by Claude Aveline, translated by Peter Green (Doubleday, $5.95); and A MAIGRET TRIO by Georges Simenon, translated by Daphne Woodward and Robert Eglesfield (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $6.95).

title: It is Now Four Days to Post Time at Aqueduct, but Who's Counting?
description: Rescued by an $8million pat on the back from the State Tax Commission, New York's 249day thoroughbred racing season will come out of the starting gate on schedule next Thursday at Aqueduct.

title: QUEENS PRISONER IS SUICIDE IN CELL
description: A 27yearold prisoner who had been pronounced nonsuicidal by a psychiatrist hanged himself yesterday morning in his cell in the Queens House of Detention.

title: Maybe There's Even an Oscar for You
description: LISTEN to this, my wife said, poking an indignant head above her paper one morning recently; ever since Women's Lib, my wife's been the breakfast table reader at our place. Here's a film which claims it has been nominated for 12 Academy Awards. Why, there aren't even 12 categories!

title: Budget Unit Is Assailed For Killing School Plan
description: Members of the Board of Estimate and the City Counell's Finance Committee reacted angrily last week to the disclosure that the City's Bureau of the Budget had rescinded plans, previously approved, for the construction of Intermediate School 44 in the Rockaways.

title: Joys Fella, $17.80, Wins Stake At Bowie
description: BOWIE, Md., Feb. 24Edward P. Shamy's Joys Fella, ridden by Carlos Jiminez, won by a halflength today in the $28,000 Native Dancer Handicap at Bowie.

title: Letters To the Editor
description: To the Editor: George Abbott White, coeditor with Charles Newman of the collection of essays titled Literature in Revolution, dedicated the book to the late F. O. Matthiessen without consulting many of the contributors. We did not know we were celebrating Matthiessen's vision. Permit me to object.

title: That Train and Route 22
description: KENILWORTHTwo toots and we're going!

title: Paydays Start for Chris Evert
description: Starting tomorrow, Chris Evert will be getting paid for bashing tennis balls.

title: Movies
description: LUIS BUNUEL'S The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie presents me with a critical poser. Here is a film that has received rave notices from all reviewers, top to bottom, and is doing well with local audiences; yet I consider it absolutely worthless. Why?

title: NAVY'S TRACKMEN WIN HEPTAGONALS
description: ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 24Navy scored an overwhelming victory in the Heptagonal indoor track championships tonight, ending the twoyear domination of the meet by Pennsylvania. It was the Midshipmen's first team title in the 26year history of the Heps, in which Army, Navy and the Ivy League colleges compete.

title: 300 Years of New York at Interpex
description: NEW YORK as it looked when it was still New Amsterdam, and the towering metropolis as it appears today, it shown on two stamps from San Marino being issued on March 9 in conjunction with the opening of the International Stamp Exhibition, INTERPEX, taking place for three days at the Americana Hotel.

title: QUEENS PRISONER IS SUICIDE IN CELL
description: A 27yearold prisoner who had been pronounced nonsulcidal by a psychiatrist hanged himself yesterday morning in his cell in the Queens House of Detention.

title: Miss Susan Hallett, Designer, Fiancee of Nathaniel Kwit Jr.
description: BANGOR, Pa., Feb. 24 Miss Susan Trenery Hallett, a descendant of Sir Nicholas Bacon, Lord Keeper of the Great Seal for. Queen Elizabeth I, plans to be married in June to Nathaniel Troy Kwit Jr.

title: Suga Beet Growers Cultivate Controversy
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D. Sugar beet farmers are spreading out from their farms and moving into the sugar refining business as well. Their grasp has reached as far as taking over a refiner whose stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Life at Princeton Challenge to Minorities
description: PRINCETON  After more than two centuries as a bastion of education for the affluent white male, Princeton University is feeling the shock waves of recent efforts to increase the representation of women and minority groups in its student body.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  Last December a high official of the Office of Management and Budget, who already had a good idea of the extraordinary array of program cutbacks and terminations that would be in President Nixon's forthcoming budget, privately confided what troubled him.

title: Food Dating Is Found to Please Customers and Reduce Losses
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24Stamping uncoded dates on perishable food not only pleases supermarket patrons but also can reduce the management's overhead costs, according to a study recently published by the Department of Agriculture.

title: 67 Employes Disciplined by City In Investigation of Hiring Plan
description: Deputy Mayor Edward K. Hamilton announced yesterday that dismissals, suspensions and other administrative actions had been taken against 67 city employes as a result of an investigation into the falsification of home addresses to qualify for a federally financed emergency hiring program.

title: The Heart Is an Impetuous Traveler
description: THERE was nothing ordinary about the Protestant funeral that blistering August day of 1881, even for Damascus, where a few years before the streets had run with the blood of 7,600 Christians, massacred in a Druse uprising. The Englishwoman had survived that slaughter to die a more conventional death from dysentery at the age of 74, but if her death was conventional, her life was not.

title: St. Paul and Ardsley Rinks Gain Final in Mixed Bonspiel
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 24The St. Paul, Curling Club rink, skipped by Barney Arnold, and the Ardsley (N. Y.) C. C., skipped by Robert Whitman, won the semifinal matches tonight in the 18th annual St. Andrew's international mixed bonspiel at St. Andrew's Golf Club.

title: C. I. A. & F. B. I.
description: Things have beenstewing recently at the top in two key Washington agencies  the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency, and last week there were some fresh jets of steam.

title: The Man Who Loved Birds But Shot Them
description: HENDERSON, Ky. John James Audubon, the ornithologist famed for his drawings and paintings of American birds, was born in Haiti but lived most of his life in the United States, settling in wilderness areas where birds were abundant and he could sketch them easily. One of the places he chose was this town beside the Ohio River.

title: Contempt Trial of Lansky Set Tomorrow in Miami
description: MIAMI, Feb. 24 (UPI)Meyer Lansky, a reputed financial leader of the underworld, was ordered today to stand trial Monday on charge of contempt for failing to appear when ordered before a Fedetal grand jury, the Justice Department said.

title: Great Lakes Shore Towns Await Flood of the Century
description: PORT CLINTON, Ohio, Feb. 24The 7,200 people of this normally relaxed fishing and resort town on the southwestern shore of Lake Erie are waiting for disaster to strike.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: AS a veteran film buff, I was figuratively knocked out when I picked up a recent issue of The Times. There, instead of the customary advertisement for a Chaplin film, was the Lincoln Art Theater's announcement of a complete change in policy.

title: Miss Guadalupe Wed
description: In the Universalist Church of New York City, 4 West 76th Street, yesterday afternoon, Miss Patricia Rosa Guadalupe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Guadalupe of Trenton, N. J., became the bride of Douglas Edward Sibole Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sibole of Neptune, N. J.

title: Tremblay Paces Nordiques In 5.3 Victory Over Sharks
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 24 (AP) J. C. Tremblay, a defenseman, had three assists, giving him 61 for the season, and the. Quebec Nordiques defeated the Los Angeles Sharks, 53, in a World Hockey Association game, today.

title: Sandra R. Schusheim Engaged to Neil Bress
description: WOODSBURGH, L.I., Feb. 24The engagement of Miss Sandra Rae Schusheim to Neil Bress has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Sol M. Schusheim. Mr. Bress is the son of Mrs. Donald Gordon of Long Beach and of Leonard Bress of Brooklyn.

title: TUITION AT CITY U. WILL BE PROPOSED
description: ALBANY, Feb. 24A special commission on higher education appointed by Governor Rockefeller last fall will recommend an end to the 126yearold free tuition policy at the City University of New York, commission sources said today.

title: Limit Asked in Hospital Fees
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 The Health Research Group, one of Ralph Nader's consumer organizations, asked the Cost of Living Council today to impose a ceiling of 6 per cent on increase in individual fees for hospital services, including the basic daily rate for a bed. In a petition, the research group said that the present formula for calculating increases on an aggregated basis had led to an 11.6 per cent rise in daily bed rates in hospitals last year.

title: Religious Freedom in Charter Said to Stir Syrian Disorders
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, Feb. 24The circulation of a proposed new Syrian constitution that specifies freedom of religion has produced serious disorders led by Islamic traditionalists, according to travelers arriving here from Damascus.

title: More Room at the Top
description: CUERNAVACA, MexicoThe eccentric spoils system which sees to it that generous American contributors to the campaign chests of winning Presidential candidates are rewarded by being named ambassadors abroad is now running into trouble. Soon there won't be enough foreign countries to handle the mob.

title: Poor, Backward and Adamantly White in a Black World
description: THROUGHOUT the British West Indies the bottom rung of the socioeconomic ladder is reserved for groups of poor, backward and Isolated whites known generally as Redlegs. They are the descendants of men, women and children shipped to the Caribbean islands from Britain from the mid1600's to the mid1800's to shore up the labor supply on the Aprofitable sugar plantations. Some came as slaves: losers in ProtestantCatholic conflicts, debtors and other convicts or kidnapping victims, Others came as indentured servants, some willingly, some not. Seventy years ago a Caribbean tourist described their progeny as mean whites, not colonists fallen upon evil days but colonists by compulsion who for centuries have enjoyed nothing but a heritage of woe.

title: SHOP TALK
description: BERNARDSVILLE  It's not always true that you can't go home again.

title: Book Shows How to Cook by Numbers
description: The Cookbook That Counts, compiled by a committee of parents of the Lawrence Country Day School, is selling as fast as book stores in Nassau County can stock it, and the neat, spiralbound volume will goon be offered across the country by Doubleday stores.

title: Greece
description: ATHENS  They emerged in small groups, looking somewhat nervous but elated. Finally, all 2,000 students who occupied the law school of Athens University moved on to the city's darkened streets, past ominous police cordons.

title: Australians Raise Cattle on Polyunsaturated Feed to Reduce Cholesterol Level
description: Polyunsaturated cattle have been suggested by an Australian research team as one solution to the current worldwide epidemic of heart disease.

title: Hilaire O'Malley to Wed Frances Dixon Burden
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Feb. 24  Isaiah Townsend Burden has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Frances Dixon Burden, to Hilaire J. O'Malley of Villanova, Pa., son of Mrs. W. Gresham O'Malley Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. O'Malley. Plans are being made for a spring wedding.

title: Detente With China
description: A good deal of the remaining ice in ChineseAmerican relations evidently melted during Henry A. Kissinger's successful visit to Peking. The central agreement was a decision on what amounts to an exchange of ambassadors and other diplomatic personnel. The communiguts speaks of setting up mutual liaison offices. That sounds like establishment of quasidiplomatic relations, which would probably be fully realized except for the still delicate problem of Taiwan.

title: Studies In Animal Behavior
description: Although I personally was all for Project Pushcart, a rally of about 100 authors who sold their books from a pushcart on Fifth Avenue couple of days before Christmas to protest publishers' antiquated distribution methods, I have to confess that denouncing publishers for their inefficiency in getting hardcover books into the stores struck me as naive.

title: Forget Your Troubles, Come On, Get Debbie!
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. SOMEBODY told me there's an informer in the company, sighs Debbie Reynolds, like a Girl Scout whose cookies have crumbled. But I don't even want to think about that.

title: Miami U. Beats Kent State For MidAmerican Crown
description: KENT, Ohio, Feb. 24 (AP)Miami University, paced by Rich Hampton, clinched the MidAmerican Conference basketball title today with a 7566 victory over Kent State. Hampton had 21 points to lead all scorers.

title: News Summary and Index
description: Defense Minister Moshe. Dayan said yesterday that Israel had made an error of judgment last Wednesday, in the downing of a Libyan airliner over the Sinai desert. Mr. Dayan's comments were the first acknowledgment by an Israeli leader that Israel was even partly responsible for the incident. [Page 1, Columns 12.] In Cairo, relatives began burying the victims. There were some shouts of War and Punish Israel, but the most of the thousands of mourners grieved silently [3:56.]

title: LINDSAY STRATEGY HIT BY ROSENBAUM
description: The new chairman of the state Republican party yesterday called Mayor Lindsay the unchallenged master of doublethink and the doublestandard and said he was one of the angriest and most intemperate commentators in American politics today.

title: World News Briefs
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 24 (UPI)The British Army said that an exploding land mine injured four soldiers on patrol today in an armored car near the border with the Republic of Ireland.

title: Opera: Jersey Butterfly
description: TRENTON, Feb. 24Dorothy Kirsten sang the title role in Puccini's Madama Butterfly at the War Memorial Auditorium here, last night, and it was a portrayal that elicited genuine respect.

title: Struggle to Save Open Space Is On In Guilford, Conn.
description: GUILFORD, Conn.City people take it for granted that beyond the suburbs there is countryside. Yet here in Guilford, almost halfway between New York and Boston, the countryside is wavering.

title: SOVIET CRITICISM OF CHINA LESSENS
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 24  The Soviet Union has sharply toned down its denunciations of China in the last two weeks, evidently in preparation for Monday's international conference on Vietnam in Paris.

title: Ski Touring Has US and Downs
description: One of the most enthusiastic ski touring devotees in the United States has to be Ron MacKenzie, Lake Placid's retired postmaster. Although he is now 70 years old, MacKenzie, a burly 210pounder, manages to go touring about four times a week.

title: Dance
Mailbox
description: To the Editor: I noticed that Arnold Palmer, new to wearing glasses while playing, chided some of his colleagues for allowing their pride to forestall optical assistance in their games. And he is right! Have you noticed some of their putting efforts in recent televised tournaments? Arnold Palmer, happily, put pride aside and set an example.

title: Paper Recycling Urged
description: What will happen to this newspaper after you're through reading it? If you stack it with others and take them to a recycling collection from the streets, you save the city sanitationmen some work and you even help to give the newspaper a new form.

title: Through Freudcolored glasses
description: If psychoanalysis were anything approaching an exact science, this book might have been worth reading. In fact, as even some analysts are aware, it is an esoteric art, whose successful practice requires a blend of empathy, imagination, humor, humility and common sense not often encountered either inside or outside the profession. I speak here of direct analysis (from which have myself benefited), where the analysand is personally and intimately known to his therapist. When it comes to indirect analysis, in which the patient? (usually a historic figure) is inaccessible and generally dead, the practitioner must add to the virtues listed above a degree of omniscience not often encountered in mortalsdefinitely not in the author of this book.

title: Yale Law School Gets Aid For Interdisciplinary Plan
description: NEW HAVEN, Feb. 24The Yale Law School has received a $530,000 grant front the Commonwealth Fund to begin an interdisciplinary teaching and research program in law, science and medicine. The grant will run for four academic years, beginning in the fall.

title: Air Guard Gaining Stature for Defense
description: McGUIRE AIR FORCE BASEBecause the activeduty Air Force is being leduced, more responsibility is being put on the reserve forces, including the New Jersey Air National Guard.

title: Recordings
description: HE was born a century ago today in a Neapolitan slum. His international career extended for only two decades, and he died more than fifty years ago. Yet his name remains virtually synonymous with Italian opera; no one has ever replaced him in the public mind as The Tenor, or escaped the inevitable comparison.

title: Repertory was the improbable dream
description: For nine long years the idea of drama at Lincoln Center has been driven by an ambitious dream: the establishment of a permanent repertory company that would represent the American theater at its finest. Is it possible that we've been dreaming the wrong dream the whole time?

title: Shopping in Tokyo for Gallery in Great Neck
description: TOKYO  I'm looking for things which people are generally not interested in now, but will be later, said Mrs. Jean Wardell as she sat in her threeroom apartment here, packed with art and antiques. We are trying to keep the gallery as in art gallery and not as an antique shop.

title: Uganda. Will Ban Imports Of Some Consumer Goods
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, Feb. 24 (Agence FrancePresse)Uganda will ban import of such consumer, goods as radio sets, phonographs, passenger cars, matches, refrigerators, enamelware, blankets, shirts, nylon socks and suiting material.

title: Soviet's Bandy Team Captures World Title
description: The Soviet Union won the world bandy championship yesterday at Moscow, according to a report from Tass, the official Soviet press agency. Bandy is a sport similar to field hockey,

title: BASEBALL TALKS NEAR AGREEMENT
description: After meeting for slightly more than three hours yesterday, representatives of baseball's club owners and players left each other in a jovial mood but still without an agreement that would enable spring training to begin.

title: Slocum's Time Sets Pace In Laconia Sled Dog Derby
description: LACONIA, N. H., Feb. 24The defending world champion, 38yearold Lloyd Slocum of Gorham State College in Gorham, Me., turned in the fastest time today with a team of 10 huskies on the second day of the world championship sled dog derby.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 24 (AP)Bols Sherwin's 35foot jump shot with four seconds left provided Army with a 5756 basketball victory over Navy today.

title: Child to Mrs. Sommerfield
description: A daughter was born Feb. 7 to Mr. and Mrs. Barrie Sommerfield at the New York LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named Emily Hope. Mrs. Sommerfield is the former Miss Faith Gimbel Solinger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Solinger of New York and Greenwich, Conn., and granddaughter of Mrs. Bernard F. Gimbel of New York. The child's father is a vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue.

title: South Vietnam to Expel An American Newsman
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 123 (AP)  Ronald Nessen, newsman for the National Broadcasting Company, was informed today that his visa would not be renewed and that he would be denied any future entry visa to South Vietnam.

title: Massive Changes Are in Course in Asia
description: In his speech to the South Carolina Legislature last week, President Nixon said that with the end of the American involvement in Vietnam, The critical question is: How do we end a war and then go on from there to build a peace?

title: Correspondent's Choice: Eating as the Natives Do, And Where They Do, All Over the World
description: It isn't easy, for traveling Americans to do as the Romans do, no matter what country's Romans are doing it. Indigenous customs often no longer exist in the places tourists frequent or have become greatly distorted by their presence.

title: R. M. Lightfoot to Wed Miss Valerie Carabba
description: Dr. and Mrs. Victor Carabba have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Valerie Florinda rabba to Robert Morgan Lightfoot, son of Mr., and Mrs. Lee Gano Lightfoot of Paris, Tex.

title: Brooklyn Man and Wo man Held On Charge of Having Explosives
description: A man and a woman were arrested yesterday in Brooklyn after the police allegedly found a gun, explosive powders and liquids and Black Liberation Army stickers in a car in which they were riding.

title: Miss Lynn M. Wallack Is Fiancee
Article 1  No Title
description: The winning New Jersey daily lottery number yesterday was:

title: Miss Spruance Advances To Squash Racquets Final
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24 (AP) Gretchen Spruance of Greenville, Del., and Goldie Edwards of Chicago advanced to the final of the 41st national women's squash racquets singles championship.

title: Patricia Rogosin Fiancee of F. C. Gelb
description: DIX HILLS, L. I., Feb. 24The engagement of Miss Patricia Belle Rogosin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. George Rogosin of Dix Hills, to Frederick Clinton Gelb, son of Mrs. Francis Heller of New York and the late Sidney Gelb, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

title: Linda White Bride Of Jeffrey Thresher
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24Miss Linda White and Jeffrey Gillet Thresher, graduates of Bethany (W. Va.) College, were married here this afternoon in the First Unitarian Church by the Rev. Ralf N. Helverson.

title: Pro Track Unit at Odds With Stars Over Money
description: Martin McGrady was listed on the official entry sheets of the National Amateur Athletic Union indoor track and field championships Friday at Madison Square Garden.

title: CONCORDIA SINGERS HAVE MELLOW TOUCH
description: The Concordia Choir of Concordia College in Moorhead, Minn., is a superbly trained, highprecision group. Striding briskly on and off Carnegie Hall's stage, singing unaccompanied and from memory, the Concordians are an impressive example of how much technical discipline can be achieved with a chorus of young, untrained voices.

title: Joan Berault Married to John J. Lavoie
description: SUDBURY, Mass., Feb. 24 In the MarthaMary Chapel here this afternoon, Miss Joan Cheryl Berault of Brookline became the bride of John Joseph Lavoie of Waltham. The Rev. Robert Senghas, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Wayside Inn here.

title: T. M. Pickering, Roxana Carnes Plan Marriage
description: RYE, N. Y., Feb. 24Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Yates Carnes have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roxana Beecher Carnes, to Timothy Murdock Pickering, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Butterfield Pickering of Rye. An August wedding is planned.

title: The New Plays
description: KASPAR, a play by Peter Handke, translated by Michael Roloff, got two favorable reviews (Barnes, Times; Gottfried, Women's Wear), two mixed (Watt, News; Cambell, AP) and two negative reviews (Tamer, Post; Wallach, Newsday).

title: JESUIT UNIVERSITY OUSTS PROFESSOR
description: ROME, Feb. 24The dismissal of a nonconformist Spanish professor from the Roman Catholic Church's leading institution of higher learning this week has reawakened latent dissent within the faculty and student body of the Pontifical Gregorian University.

title: Henry Farnum to Wed Priscilla Kroll
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., Feb. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kroll have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Priscilla Dwinnell Kroll, to Henry Whipple Farnum, son of Mrs. Henry W. Farnum of Ardmore, Pa. and the late Mr. Farnum.

title: Air Fares Deadline Looms
description: Confusion, a recurrent condition in the pricing of transAtlantic travel, has hit the airlines this year in more dizzying fashion than ever before.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: ROSCOE, N. Y.Although snow was deep on the hills and ice clogged the slower waters of the Willowemoc River, a constant parade of anglers visited the home of Harry Darbee throughout the day.

title: NAVY PAIR TAKES BOBSLED CROWN
description: LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Feb. 24 A team of Navy men whipped down the 17curve mile of Mount van Hovenburg today to win the North American twoman bobsled championship.

title: CAMBODIAN TOWN REPORTED IN PERIL
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Feb. 24 (Reuters)Communist forces today stepped up their attacks south of Phnom Penh, where they have badly mauled isolated Government battalions and now threaten a provincial capital, military sources here said.

title: Here We Go Again
description: The fatuousness of Administration assurances that wageprice controls would remain firm under Phase 3 has become unmistakable even before President Nixon's labormanagement committee issues its first policy statement.

title: Pay and Time at Work Bitterly Fought Issues in Philadelphia School Strike
description: We find it hard to accept the premise that teachers already spending so little time teachingand for only 180 school days, or 36 weeks, a year  are overworked. Teachers' pay demands ... must be evaluated in terms of how much time the teachers are willing to devote to what they are paid to do: teach. Editorial, The Philadelphia Inquirer

title: Vietnam
description: SAIGONPerhaps it was too much to hope that after a quarter century of carnage the Vietnamese foes would break clean like prizefighters and return to their corners to await the bell for the next round.

title: Pampers and Profits at P. & G.
description: This is the story of Pampers and how they grew.

title: The One, The Only, The Great Caruso
description: Today is the 100th anniversary of the birth of Enrico Caruso, widely regarded as the greatest tenor in operatic history. Here, a celebrated soprano recalls Caruso and the years in which she sang with him.

title: Margaret M. C. Kennedy Betrothed
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., Feb. 24  Mr. and Mrs. Patrick James Kennedy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Mary Courtney Kennedy, to Robert Emmet Curry Jr., on of Mr. and Mrs. Curry of New York. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: How 01 (and 07 and 02) and some other narcs busted Tom, Dick and Harry
description: Drug pushers call them narcsand worse; watchers of old television serials call them Tmen, which they haven't been since 1967 when the Bureau of Narcotics was transferred out of the Treasury Department and merged with the Bureau of Drug Abuse Control (formerly of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare) into the Department of Justice. They call themselves special agents of the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs. Whatever you want to call them, they are growing breed of young, ambitious men (and one or two women) in what is all too obviouslyand tragicallya major American growth industry: narcotics law enforcement. The size of the Federal antidrug force in New York has more than tripled over the past five years, and early this month, to climax this growth, the bureau moved to a new headquarters in a recently completed modernistic office building at 555 W. 57th St. Sixteen of the 21 street groups assigned to New York work out of the 18th and 19th floors there today. This report on one of these groups was compiled just before the bureau moved uptown from the crowded old Federal building at 90 Church St., a squat, blocksquare edifice the bureau shared with miscellaneous offices of the Post Office Department, the Internal Revenue Service, the Secret Service and the Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms unit of the Treasury Department.

title: The Alimentary Progress of Ed Verb
description: Whomever else it may have startled, the proliferation of cookery books (313 new titles in 1972 and even more projected for 1973) came as no surprise to Claude LviStrauss and his canny lingual crowd of structural anthropologists, who have been telling us for years that words and food are prehistorically wedded, that Let's Cook Grandma Right was painted in pictorial form on the walls of caves in the Dordogne eons before Adelle Davis ate a vitamin pill. No, lingo and chow, chatter and grub, letters and lettuce, parsing and parsley, grammar and gourmandise are inseparable, and we have more cookbooks on our shelves than Bibles. Cogito Eggo Sum.

title: On original sin and conservatives
description: Philosophers carry few precincts. Nevertheless they are not without value to men of power. Programs and policies gain added legitimacy if they appear as expressions of more enduring principles. At the same time, those talented in establishing these connections lean mainly to the left. The very epithet intellectual conjures up at least a McGovern supporter, if not more radical affinities. Moreover, when Richard Nixon expounds his views of selfreliance or abortion, the arguments seem not simply shallow but untouched by academic influence.

title: MEILER, CONNORS GAIN TENNIS FINAL
description: SALISBURY, Md., Feb. 24 (AP) Karl Meiler of West Germany advanced to the title round of the troubleplagued United States National indoor open tennis championships today when Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., had to withdraw from the semifinal match because of illness.

title: Weber State Triumphs
description: BOZEMAN, Mont., Feb. 24 (AP)  Dan Dion scored 15 points to spark Weber State to a 6657 Big Sky Conference victory over Montana State tonight. Weber State, which has a 131 mark, clinched the league title last week.

title: The life of a decadent voluptuary, in Technicolor
description: It was not pure capriciousness which once led Henry James to say of Gabriele d'Annunzio: Ostensibly, transcendentally, his is the most developed taste in the world. ... Beauty at any price is an old story to him; art and form and style as the aim of the superior life style are a matter of course. This poetphilan dererpseudo politician concealed from no one the secular belief that his was the inherited role of the superman. Only Lord Byron can be compared to him, Philippe Jullian tells us. And he proceeds to trace, in considerable detail, the Technicolor charade that was to become the life of this decadent voluptuary.

title: Assessments
description: Should a man who has actively solicited political campaign contributions for the Mayor of New York preside over the assessment of the city's $38billion in taxable real estate?

title: On Grand Canary: A New Season
description: The people are the selfsufficient Spaniards of the Mogan Valley on Grand Canary Island, most populous of the Canary Islands; their rainy season will end soon and most of them will return to the fields.

title: Home Improvement
description: REAL marble is a luxurious looking and colorful natural material that is moistureproof, easy to clean and quite durable under normal usebut it is not as impervious to staining and discoloration as many people think.

title: The World and Doomsday Fads
description: The human race; to which so many of my readers belong, wrote G. K. Chesterton at the beginning of one of his novels, has been playing since the beginning of time at the game of Cheat the Prophet It has been playing it with particular vivacity since the end of World War II. Every few years since then there has been a great outcry among the most distinguished decisioninfluencing people that the world is heading for grave and permanent shortage of some particular things. The shortterm result has almost always been a glut within about ten years of those very things.

title: $452,070 Granted for Arts on L.I.
description: The New York State Council on the Arts distributed $452,070 among 69 cultural organizations in Nassau and Suffolk Counties this year, it was announced today.

title: KODES DEFEATS COX, GAINS TENNIS FINAL

title: The Energy Crisis
description: Of the seemingly endless series of crises about which we are continuously exhorted to become aroused, the energy crisis is garnering perhaps the largest share of headlines. Yet unlike the airpollution crisis, and others whose effects are manifest, the energy crisis, except for an occasional brownout, lurks unseen, the product mainly of slide rule extrapolations. There is thus much confusion not, only over just what the energy crisis is but whether, in fact, it exists at all. Both books under review, in highly divergent ways, shed light on this confusion.

title: Gardens
description: If you name six trees correctly, you receive high honors in winter woodsmanship; four or five, excellent; three, very good. Less than that means you need to sharpen your eyes to observe more in the outdoors and learn the characteristic silhouettes of trees in winter. 1. The horsechestnut is easy to spot, for the ends of the lower branches droop and turn upward. The tall crown is somewhat rounded. 2. Sugar maple is a symmetrical grower with a short, heavy lower trunk widening into a lighter framework of wellspaced branches. 3. Pin oak typically droops, the lower branhes often touch the ground. The maintrunk pushes straight to a pyramid crown. 4. White oak is a massivelooking tree with heavy lower branching in a low crown outline. The older the tree, the broader it grows. 5. Tulip tree traditionally is difficult to see in full outline except at some distance' as it is a very tall, straightup grower in deep woodlands. The crown has many shorter twiggy branches than the broad armlike lower branches. 6. White ash usually grows alone into an enormous tree from a high heavy trunk supporting straight symmetrical upward branching, which is opposite as in maple. While looking at trees, don't forget to study the fascinating buds and feel the texture of the bark, how rough, how smooth.

title: Women's Movement

title: Headliners
description: The little town of Cierna Nad Tisou in Czechoslovakia achieved a moment of fame in July, 1968, when Soviet leaders, headed by Leonid Brezhnev, confronted the reformist Czech leadership, under Alexander Dubcek, in the prelude to the Russian invasion that ousted the Czech liberals. Last week Mr. Brezhnev returned briefly to Cierna, on a train that was carrying him to Prague for celebrations marking the 25th anniversary of Communist rule in Czechoslovakia. There was no ceremony in Cierna but in flagbedecked Prague several thousand Czechs were at the station to applaud the Russian leader. And to mark the occasion, President Ludvik Svoboda gave Mr. Brezhnev a medal and announced an amnesty for some minor criminals who had fled abroad during the events of 1968. Only those accused of subversion, violation of state secrets or publishing damaging material abroad were excepted.

title: Screen: 'Priest and Girl':'66 Film From Brazil Is at Quad Cinema
description: Taken as a modern parable, the Brazilian drama "The Priest and the Girl," which arrived at the Quad Cinema recently, is as mildly disturbing and fascinating as a faintly remembered legend. But it is a good deal more effective in its sharp focus on a distant but picturesque area and its depressed, little-known simple people than in its thematic clashes between sacred and profane love, temptation and native mores.Joaquim Pedro de Andrade, the writer-director represented here last year by the picaresque adventure "Macunaima," is recounting in "The Priest and the Girl," which he made in 1966, a moody saga of a dedicated young country padre drawn into an affair with a pretty, apparently nubile girl and the dour, brooding villagers who harass them in their sad liaison.The film was reportedly controversial in Brazil. But an American viewer finds it difficult to relate to the tragedy except on its obvious terms. One can see that the priest, played in properly anguished style by Paulo Jose, is torn between his churchly mission to love all mankind and the physical love literally thrust upon him. But the affection demanded by the girl, portrayed feelingly, if naively, by Helena Ignez, is only vaguely realized.She has been, it turns out, "the woman" of her jealous, elderly, domineering stepfather, portrayed laconically by Mario Lago, who has been keeping the moribund mining village alive as its major shopkeeper and buyer of the few diamonds panned. And she has also been adored by the Milquetoast druggist, Fauzi Arap, who bleats intimations of her intimacies with the village's previous priest, now dead.One is inclined to wonder at the truth of her plea for love and protection when she sobbingly says to the confused young priest, "I love only you." Their ensuing flight from the village, her seduction of the priest (artistically underplayed), their return home and their expulsion and pursuit by the villagers are, one supposes, meant to be meaningful, but the impact is only slight.Mario Carneiro's stark photography etches, in memorably beautiful blacks and whites, the sparse village and the rolling hills and the streams of the Minas Gerais mining country. But the implied commentary on the trials of a priest under the strictures of the church, natural passions and primitive morality is only dimly, if fervently, projected.

title: Red Smith
description: John M. Gayer, who trains horses for Greentree Stable, once gave it as his considered opinion that if the public could be convinced that racing was 100 per, cent honest and every race was contested strictly on its merits, nobody would go to the track. This was before Hot Horse Harry Samuels came along to urge horseplayers to stay away from the track and give their business to his Offtrack Betting Corporation. John Gayer believed, perhaps correctly, that racing's most faithful customers were optimists who kept coming back in the hope that one day they would crack the code and gain access to the information that would make them rich. About the same time Joe Palmer, in his column in The New York Herald Tribune, offered to bet that he could walk through the Belmont stable area wearing prison stripes and carrying a bucket plainly labeled Heroin without attracting anybody's attention. Joe was a large man, easy to see on a clear morning, which tells us something about security measures on the backstretch.

Became consultant and adviser on labor relations for the Major League, Baseball Players Association Committee in August, 1967 .... For three years before that was president of the Publishers Association of Nev York City, representing news papers in their labor problemswith unions.... Born in Nevin York in 1914, attended Pratt, Institute, worked for the Federal Bureau of Investigatim as a clerk, for the Pennsylvania Railroad as an assistant stationmaster, then entered the labor relations. field with the Long Island Rail Road, the New Haven Railroad, American Airlines and eventually became chairman of the labor relations committee of the Eastern Railroads, dealing sometimes with as many as 32 unions over work rules.... title: Aunt of Johnson Dies

title: Trevino Wins as Fezler Falters
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Feb. 25 As Lee Trevino watched from close to the 18th green today, Forrest Fezler, the 23yearold Californian who had led by two strokes until the 15th hole, missed a putt. Had the ball dropped into the cup it would have brought about a tie and a playoff in the $260,000 Jackie Gleason Inverrary National Airlines classic.

title: Senate Panel Gets Secret Data on Colonel Who Says He Had to Retire for Citing War Crimes in Vietnam
description: The Senate Armed Services Committee has received classified documents that Lieut. Col. Anthony B. Herbert says prove his contention that the Army was determined to oust him after he spoke out about alleged atrocities in Vietnam.

But I mean that in the very best sense of the word, the 32yearold, private school official added quickly. He did not mean, he said, dropping out and blowing things up, but rather preparing youngsters to become Independent thinkers who will be able to assume leadership and effect change.
