title: George the Indestructible
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla.Never one to let modesty inhibit full enjoyment of his own successes, George Meany is savoring as an earned personal tribute the bipartisan deference currently being accorded him in the marshmallowandgilt spa he has temporarily converted into America's midwinter political capital spicuously no sale is on the President's determination to cut back drastically on social programs. Balancing the budget is not a good argument when it is being balanced against the human needs of millions of people, says Mr. Meany. How much muscle the federation will put into lobbying for bigger social appropriations remains unclear, but it probably will be considerable, though widespread worker resentment over high taxes is sure to deter zeal on this front by unions.

title: For the Players
description: Since Marvin Miller became the first fulltime executive director of the Major League Baseball. Players Association on July 1, 1966, he has represented players in dealings with owners ... Known as a meticulous worker and abargainer of integrity.... His firm stand on pension agreement and other matters delayed opening of spring training in 1969 and cut into the regular schedule last season. ... Born 55 years ago in Manhattan, father a salesman in the garment district and his mother a teacher.... Hung around Ebbets Field to watch the Dodgers and played street gaines like stickball and stoopball as a child.... Studied economics at Miami (Ohio) and at New, York University.... Became associate director of research for the United Steelworkers in 1950 and was promoted 10 years later to assist David McDonald, the president.... On recommendation of Judge Robert Cannon, who had represented players on a parttime basis, he became executive director of Players Association in 1966.... Players approved him, 489136. ... Earns $75,000 a year in job.

title: 'Childhood II' Looks at Encounter Group
description: The released tensions of adults, psychological and sexual, that are recorded in a group-encounter feature, "Childhood II," are the primary value and appeal of this documentary, even though the revelations aren't especially surprising. The new picture at the First Avenue Screening Room is one of the better group-encounter movies of about six released so far, ranging in quality from fair to very good indeed.This first offering from a new company, headed by Martin J. Spinelli, the director, and Richard M. Gibson, the producer, is marked by care, dignity and purpose. Some of the film's flaws would seem to stem partly from the therapy itself. The session participants and their director, photographed during a weekend experience at Mays Landing, N. J., are totally nude.Nudity may be considered essential to loosening tongues and inhibitions, as the group director initially reminds the clustered adults, but some discreet body posturing does indicate a slightly self-conscious awareness of the camera. Furthermore, with the group shifting to an indoor pool for more self-revelations, the photography indulges in some obtuse, psychedelic effects. Add some jivey music. The film doesn't need a note.The homestretch is best, back on the parlor carpet, as one stricken young woman discloses a father-rejection obsession hinging on a sexual incident from early childhood. This affords genuinely fine, stimulating viewing. So do the candid, clear-eyed utterances of an interracial couple called Angela and Jim.Although it does cover fairly familiar terrain in trailing other sessions on films, this is a worthy movie that may do good where such therapy is needed.

description: To be radically new would be suicide in men's clothes, Hardy Amies, the British designer, remarked as he presented his men's fashions for next year in the informal setting of the midtown apartment he maintains here.

title: It's Politics as Usual
description: TRENTON, Feb 25Despite changes and reforms in the Democratic party over the last decade, this year's gubernatorial primary indicated little change in New Jersey politics.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 33

title: Mrs. Spruance Takes Title
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 25 (AP)Topseeded Mrs. Gretchen Spruance of Greenville, Del., defeated secondseeded Goldie Edwards of Chicago, 1510, 1512, 1847, today to win the 41st national women's squash racquet title. She succeeds her sister, Mrs. Nina Moyer, who did not compete this year.

title: GARELIK ENTERING MAYOR RACE TODAY
description: City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, a former policeman who apparently feels safe on the law and order theme that is dominating New York City politics this year, will formally enter the race for the Democratic nomination for Mayor today with a statement stressing his political ecumenism.

title: Urban and Rural Jersey Face Unwanted Changes
description: In West New York, New Jersey's most congested town, there are 45,000 people to a square mile. In Pahaquarry Township in Warren County, the least congested, there are four people to a square mile. In West New York, schools are just blocks away from any home; there are 17 churches, and doctors' shingles hang in virtually every street. In Pahaquarry there are no schools. There are no children, either. People go to other towns to worship, or to be treated for illness. Obviously, life is different in these place's; but an examination shows many similarities, too.

title: ARNOTT IS RIDER OF SHOW WINNERS
description: NORTH SALEM, N. Y., Feb. 25Jim Arnott scored a double at the closing session of the twoday; The Hill horse show today by riding Platitude to the regular working hunter championship and Liquid Crystal to the green fox chaser title.

title: Court Tennis Match Today
description: Play starts today in the court tennis challenge match between England and the United States at the New York Racquet and Tennis Club. Tomorrow the national amateur court tennis title tournament will open on the same courts.

title: CARMELA ALTAMURA GIVES ARIA CONCERT
description: Carmela Bucceri Altamura, Sicilianborn soprano, gave an aria recital, with orchestral acconipaniment, at Alice Tully Hill Sunday afternoon. The program, dedicated to the late conductor Umberto Vedovelli, was also a benefit for the Bologna University Medical Alumni Association.

title: Nixon and Congressmen At White House Service
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 UPI)President Nixon participated in a prayer of thanks at a White House worship service today to observe the first time in nine years the United States is at peace.

title: VERMONT WINS FIRST EASTERN SKI CROWN
description: HANCOCK, Vt., Feb. 25 Sweeping three of the top 10 places in the jump today, the University of Vermont overcame a 4point Middlebury College lead to win, its first Eastern Intercollegiate Ski Association title and its first Middlebury Winter Carnival Cup since 1945.

title: A TOWMAN IS SHOT; MOTORIST ACCUSED
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., Feb. 25 A towtruck operator was shot in the leg here last night by a man whose car had been removed from an apartmenthouse parking lot, the Nassau police said.

title: St. Paul Curling Victor
description: HASTINGS  ON  HUDSON, N. Y., Feb. 25The St. Paul (Minn.) Curling Club defeated the Ardsley C. C., 156, to win the 18th annual St. Andrew's international mixed bonspiel for the BarnesFiske Trophy today.

title: ISRAEL DECIDES TO PAY FAMILIES OF CRASH VICTIMS
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 25The Israeli Government today decided to pay families of the victims on the Libyan airliner shot down Wednesday over the Sinai desert.

title: Police Seize Bronx Man After Exchange of Shots
description: A Bronx man was arrested last night after allegedly fleeing his home in the Williams Bridge section when his wife arrived with detectives to arrest him on charges of criminal mischief for having damaged his wife's car, the police said.

title: WHN JOINS CAMP OF COUNTRY MUSIC
description: Such performers as Merle Haggard, Donna Fargo, Waylon Jennings, Charley Prideand. Kris Kristofferson are among those who have found a per manent home on New York radio. Today, station WHN, at 50,000 watts one: of the most powerful AM outlets in the metropolitan area, converts to a countrymusic format.

title: CLASSIFIED ADVERTISING INDEX
description: Classified Pages distributed in metropolitan New York and adjacent territory.

title: U.S. WOMEN CHOSEN FOR SOVIET TRACK
description: RICHMOND, Feb. 25 (AP)Five of the women who led the United States to an upset victory last year were named today to the United States' team for the second Soviet UnionUnited States indoor track meet to be held here March 16.

title: HANOI BARRACKS IN SOUTH STONED
description: DA NANG, South Vietnam, Feb. 25Mobs of demonstrators threw rocks at the bar racks of North Vietnamese members of the FourParty Joint Military Commission here and in Hue today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
In Defense of Solzhenitsyn
description: LONDONOn Jan. 8, 1973, The New York Times published an article by Semyon Vladimirov on Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn's financial and personal affairs. If Semyon Vladimirov can publish in The Times such false stories about my good friend, shouldn't answer him with the simple truth?

title: Fed Official Backs Checking Accounts That Pay Interest
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, indicated today that he approved the basic idea behind the controversial NOW account being used by savings institutions in Massachusetts.

title: Bach's Art of Fugue Performed On Organ by Kamiel D'Hooghe
description: Musicologists have speculated endlessly about the proper performance medium for Bach's Art of Fugue. Left incomplete at his death, this mighty compilation of 17 fugues and 4 canons on one principal theme has been arranged for almost every possible combination of instruments in lieu of any specific indication left by Bach himself.

title: CHAVEZ ASKS INQUIRY INTO LETTUCE TAINT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP)  Cesar Chavez, the farm labor organizer, called today for a Congressional investigation into the contamination of lettuce by a new pesticide that he said resembled nerve gas.

title: Man Charged With Raping Student in Teachers College
description: A 24yearold painter was arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 21yearold student Sunday afternoon in the basement of the library of Columbia University's Teachers College, the police reported.

title: WHOLESALE FOOD SURGED IN PRICE AFTER DOILAR CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Wholesale prices of many food commodities rose sharply in the first full week after devaluation of the dollar, and a Brookings Institittion economist said today that the increase confirmed the outlook for More disappointing figmes ahead for consumers.

title: Nader Urges Major Study Of U.S. Revenue Operations
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, proposed today that a threeyear study be made of all aspects of the operations of the Internal Revenue Service. The study should be made by experts in the tax field, named by Congress, Mr. Nader said in testimony before a Senate appropriations subcommittee.

title: New Wave of Strikes in Britain Takes First Toll of Air Service
description: LONDON, Feb. 26A series of strikes challenging the Government's program for curbing wages and prices threatens to cripple Britain's air, rail and hospital services this week.

title: Hockey First Major Sport To Provide Arbitration
description: The sport usually considered the least progressive in money matters, hockey; was the first to have arbitration in its contracts.

title: 200,000 Gallons Of Gasoline Spill Near West Point
description: More than 200,000 gallons of gasoline spilled into the Hudson River when a barge tanker struck a rock just below West Point, N. Y., in the predawn darkness yesterday, but most of the fuel evaporated by late afternoon, the Coast Guard reported.

title: 4 Contend for the Post of Bergen G.O.P. Chairman
description: HACKENSACK, Feb. 26 When the campaign rhetoric ends tomorrow night and the figures come out of the voting machines here, the tally may show that the Bergen. County Republican party has resolve a bitter internal fight by making a significant change in the way it operates.

title: American Party Ruled Out
description: BATON ROUGE, Feb. 26 (UPI)The American party can no longer be recognized as a political party in Louisiana, the state's Attorney General, William Guste, said today.

title: MALAVE, MURPHY BATTLE TO DRAW
description: In a 10round main event that had all 1,736 fans in the Felt Forum on their feet for the last three rounds, Edwin (Chu Chu) Malave of Greenwich Village and Irish Pat Murphy of Ridgefield Park, N. J., fought to a draw last night.

title: James C. Bailey, Father Of Recently Freed P.O.W.
description: KOSCIUSKO, Miss., Feb. 26 (AP)James C. Bailey, father of a recently freed prisoner of war, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.

title: CHESEBROUGH BIDS FOR HEALTH  TEX
description: ChesebroughPond's, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed principle to acquire HealthTex, Inc., a major producer of popularly priced children's apparel.

title: Teachers Honor Wilkins
description: The American Federation of Teachers presented its first annual civil rights award last night to Roy Wilkins, the executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: New Coalition to Press for Safer Toys
description: One dozen parent, consumer and women's groups announced yesterday the formation of a coalition that will attempt to haft the manufacture of toys that they maintain are physically and psychologically dangerous to children.

title: Collegians Toot Horns For N.I.T.
description: The pitchmen are out in force. Some make personal appearances, others use the mail and the telephone. This is the time of the basketball season to sell, allAmericans and to make bids for postseason tournaments, important ingredients for recruiting programs currently in full swing.

title: TORTUREDBYAGENTS, ARAB SAYS IN ISRAEL
description: HAIFA, Israel, Feb. 26  A court trying six Israelistwo nativeborn Jews and four Israeli Arabsaccused of spying for Syria focused today on assertions that the Israeli security service had tortured a defendant.

title: Vane Collectors Fail To Weather the Storm
description: Over the last month, nearly 20 antique weather vans valued at $400 to $5,000 each  have been reported stolen from roofs in Rockland, Orange and Ulster Counties.

title: Tile winning New Jersey daily lottery number, yesterday was:
SHOTS BY SNIPER HELD ACCIDENTAL
description: BABYLON, L. I., Feb. 26What was originally, believed to be a sniper attack on a Long Island State Parkway patrol car earlier this month is now thought to have been only stray shots from a gravel pit used for target practice.

title: Anderson Bids Juries Be Given Right to Set Life Drug Terms
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26  Warreh M. Anderson, the State Senate majority leader, proposed today that juries be given the right to decide if a convicted drug pusher is a heavy trafficker before the defendant is subjected to a mandatory life sentence, the penalty urged by Gbvernor Rockefeller for such offenders.

title: Two Guards and a School Aide Seized in Supermarket Holdup
description: Two school security guardsone recently released from prison after serving nearly nine years for murderand a school aide were arrested yesterday Morning during an attempted holdup of a Manhattan supermarket near Columbia University.

title: Caso Describes Plans for New Park at Mitchel Field
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 26Details of a plan fer the construction of a park and recreation complex on 67 acres of land it Mitchel Field were announced today by Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso.

title: JUROR GIVES FEE TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Casts. Fund stood at $1,034,697.48 as of yesterday, about $14,000 ahead of its predecessor butt approximately $21,000 behind the record of $1,055,877.91 set two years ago by the 59th yearly appeal.

title: Booklet on Care of Teeth Scored by Dentists' Group
description: CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP)  A booklet on dental care by, Herbert Denenberg, Pennsylvania's commissioner of insurance, contains misleading statements and misstatements, the American Dental Association asserted today.

title: People and Business
description: It appears to be only a matter of time before the official appointment of Thomas R. Bowmar, as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the 5250billionplus savings and loan industry.

title: COLOMBO SETTLES SUIT AGAINST C.B.S.
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System and Anthony Colombo, son of Joseph Colombo Sr., convicted perjurer and alleged mobster, have reached an agreement ending a $1million libel suit.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Howard J. Samuels presented a detailed plan yesterday for a takeover of the numbers game by the Offtrack Betting Corporation. He said it would cripple organized crime and pour millions of dollars into the city's communities for support of schools and other neighborhood projects.

title: Notes on People
description: McCall's magazine said it had settled out of court a dispute concerning the exclusivity of an article in Coronet magazine dealing with the breastcancer operation performed on Mrs. Shirley Temple Black. McCall's had sued Coronet's owners and distributors for $500,000 for claiming a Coronet story of Mrs. Black's operation was exclusive. McCall's claimed that its own article on the operation was the exclusive one. McCall's did not disclose the terms of the settlement.

title: Chess: Nona Gaprindashvili Keeps A Firm Grip on the Throne
description: For a decade, Nona Gaprindashvili has dominated women's chess. In 1963 she captured the women's world chess championship from Elisaveta Bykova with a landslide score of seven victories, four draws and no losses. Two years later, she firmly demonstrated her grasp on the title by turning back the challenge of Alla Kushnir of Moscow with seven victories, three losses and three draws.

title: Brainwashing Laid to U.S.
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26 (UPI)Izvestia accused the Pentagon today of brainwashing released United States prisoners of war and said the prisoners in turn brainwashed the American public about the Vietnam war. If one puts aside the emotions and touching scenes of family reunions, one feels at once the director's guiding handa giant propaganda and psychological campaign prepared by the Pentagon, the Government newspaper said.

title: Equity Financing
description: American Broadcasting Companies, said yesterday it planned to purchase on the open market in the next several months up to 300,000 shares of its common stock for various corporate purposes. The company's stock was up  at 53 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HENRI WEINTRAUB
description: Henri Weintraub, who was associated with Anne Klein, the dress designer, died Saturday in Gcishen (N.Y.) Hospital. He was injured Feb. 16 in Goshen in an automobile accident. He was 52 years old and lived at 18 Barry Drive, Westbury, L.I.

title: PRICES PLUMMET IN AWE TRADING
description: Investors' fears about inflation and tight money pushed prices sharply lower yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and in overthecounter trading.

title: Knife in Dog Is Removed
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) Benjamin Stevens said today that he and his wife were having a sausage snack in their kitchen when Kraut, their fourmonthold German shepherd puppy, jumped up, grabbed a 12inch butcher knife from the table and swallowed it. Mr. Stevens rushed the dog to the veterinary hospital at the University of Pennsylvania. Two hours surgery was performed, the knife was removed and the dog now has a surgical scar on his abdomen.

title: Yield on Treasury Bills Rose at Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Yields on United States Treasury bills rose in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: Secretariat Is Syndicated For Record $6.08Million
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)Secretariat, the 1972 horse of the year, has been syndicated for a record sum of $6.08million, the man handling the transaction said today.

title: Tokyo Leader Says Big Powers Bar Japan From Major Councils
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26The secretary general of Japan's governing LiberalDemocratic party denounced the world's major powers today for excluding Japan from important international councils, including the conference on Vietnam that opened in Paris today.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today.
Jazz Lures Tap Talent To Museum
description: It is small, smoky and copacetic and its patrons are knowledgeably enthusiastic. It is the New York Jazz Museum on 55th Street, and early Sunday evenings at show time it is host oto a wonderful collection of talented tap dancers.

title: MRS. MEIR IN U.S. FOR 10DAY VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Premier Golda Meir of Israel arrived here today for a 10day visit to the United States and said it was high tithe that there be a serious movement toward a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: MRS. MEIR IN U.S. FOR 10DAY VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Premier. Golda Meir of Israel arrived here today for a 10day visit to the United States and said it was high tithe that there be a serious movement toward a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Celebration in Prague
description: It was entirely appropriate that Soviet Communist party chief Leonid I. Brezhnev should be the central figure at the official Czechoslovak commemoration of the 25th anniversay of Communist seizure of power in Prague.

title: Publisher Editor
description: And 10 Reporters

title: Court Vacates Writ The City Obtained Against Peep Show
description: A fourjudge panel of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court, echoing earlier Federal court rulings, declared yesterday that the city's licensing mechanism for peepshow operators was of questionable constitutionality. The panel vacated an injunction the city had obtained against one such operator.

title: STOCK PRICES HIT BY INTEREST RISE
description: The stock market declined yesterday in its initial response to higher interest rates announced over the weekend. More than 1,000 issues finished with losses on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: New Inquiry Into Racial Clashes In Navy Urged by Rep. Dellums
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 Representative Ronald F. Dellums urged the House Armed Services Committee today to reopen an investigation into racial incidents on the aircraft carriers Kitty Hawk and Constellation.

title: MRS. HAROLD ZILLMANN
description: Mrs. Harold A. Zillmann, widow of a district manager of several Queens telephone company exchanges, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack at her home, 4325 Douglaston Parkway, Douglaston, Queens.

title: Mitchell Wilson, Science Writer And Popular Novelist, Dies at 59
description: Mitchell Wilson, the novelist and science writer, died of a heart attack yesterday morning at his home, 1016 Fifth Avenue. He was 59 years old. He also maintained a home with hi wife, Stella Adler, the actress, in Water Mill, N. Y.

title: Skilled Minorities Called City's Hope for Future
description: When William Cisco came home from serving in Vietnam with the Marines, the only work he could get was waxing floors Even then, the maintenance company soon laid him off.

title: Bronx District Will Vote For Assemblyman Today
description: Voters in the 85th Assembly District in the SouthCentral Bronx will pick a new Assemblyman today in a special election.

title: Tennessee to Honor Handy
description: NASHVILLE, Feb. 26 (UPI) The state has secured a portrait of W. C. Handy, the Memphis blues musician, and it will be the first portrait of a black to be hung in the State Capitol. The state museum director, Jean D. Kane, said the portrait had been obtained from Handy's widow, who lives in Yonkers, N.Y. Handy died in 1958 at the age of 85.

title: Sitting Bull Descendent Dies
description: L'ANSE, Mich., Feb. 26 (AP) Chief Herbert Hawkshield Welsh, believed to be the oldest living male descendant of Sitting Bull, died in Baraga County Memorial Hospital today following a brief illness. He was 70 years old.

title: KICKBACK CHARGE DENIED BY OFFICIAL
description: CAMDEN, Feb. 26 (AP)Arthur Ponzio, Public Works Commissioner of Atlantic City, denied in Federal Court here today that he had ever, accepted kickbacks from contractors who did business with Atlantic City.

title: STUDENTS SEIZED IN SALE OF DRUGS
description: Five high school studentsincluding two 14yearold boys and four college students were among 21 persons arrested yesterday on charges of selling narcotics at two colleges and two schools in Brooklyn.

title: Secret Story of Frank Costello That Was Almost Written
description: Ten days before he died, Frank Costello made one of the biggest decisions of his long life. He decided to talk.

title: Jan Peerce Sings Stirringly in Recital
description: Jan Peerce and John Gabriel Spiro gave a joint recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday night under the auspices of the American Committee for Shaare Zedek Hospital in Jerusalem. As in past concerts presented annually by the organization in the same hall, a capacity audience was on hand.

title: G.&W. TENDER OFFER FOR A.&P. EXTENDED
description: Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., yesterday extended its tender offer for 3.75 million shares of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company to March 16. The extension keeps the offer open while Gulf and Western is enjoined from buying the shares by a Federal court order.

title: Labor Presses Congress On Controls Inequalities
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. voted today to oppose extension of the economic stabilization law unless Congress adopts a series of specific measures to eliminate glaring inequalities from the wageprice controls Rogram.

title: Postel Wins Support From Riverside Club
description: City Councilman Robert I. Postel won the endorsement of the Riverside Democratic Club last night in his quest for the mayoral nomination in the party's primary election next June.

title: JOINT CHIEFS URGED INVASION OF NORTH
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)  The Joint Chiefs of Staff on occasion recommended a South Vietnamese invasion of North Vietnam, Adm. Thomas H. Moorer said in testimony made public today.

title: Black Hawks Opponent New York 2 Losses Short of League Mark
description: Sometime soon, after two more losses, the New York Islanders will tie the National Hockey, League record of 53 defeats in a season. Tonight they meet the Black Hawks at Nassau Coliseum in a game that means more to the slumping Chicagoans, who have their slimmest hold on first place in the West Division since switching from the East in 1970.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Bridge: 52 Pairs Participate Here  In a Charity Tournament
description: The first of a planned annual series of charity tournaments was played here during the weekend, and netted slightly more than $2,000 for the Muscular Dystrophy Associations. Fiftytwo pairs competed, and the winners were Chuck Lamprey of White Plains and Steve Labins of Hartford. Second were Mark Berger of Fort Lee, N. J., and Ed Andreasian of Great Neck, L. I.

title: The Flagship of Nelson Badly Damaged by Fire
description: PORTSMOUTH, England, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Britain's most famous warship, the 208yearold battleship Victory on which Lord Nelson was killed during the battle of Trafalgar, was badly damaged by fire here today.

title: Canada Suggests Forum For Truce Emergencies
description: PARIS, Feb. 26The international conference On Vietnam opened today with a proposal by Canada for a forum that could act on any future breakdawn of the ceasefire.

title: Labor Presses Congress On Controls Inequalities
description: BAL HARBOUR, Fla., Feb. 26The Executive Council of the A.F.L.C.I.O., voted today to oppose extension, of the economic stabilization Jaw unless Congress adopts a series of specific measures to eliminate glaring inequalities from the wageprice controls program.

title: Philippe of Fordham Track Future in France
description: Even though his smattering of French might not help him read the menu in some of the city's finer French restaurants, Martel Philippe has taken a logical approach in his decision to compete internationally for France in track.

title: John Prine's Songs Show Wide Range And Sophistication
description: WASHINGTON, Feb 26Twelve bishops of the African Methodist Episcopal Church, some of whom supported the reelection of President Nixon, condemned today the Administration's social policies is dehumanizing to poor and blacks.

title: Former Airline Executive Admits He Took Kickback
description: A former executive vice pres?? ident of American Airline?? pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiracy charge that he ha?? accepted kickbacks to awar?? business contracts for the air line.

title: Sports Today
description: BASKETBALL

title: Schools Without Leaders
description: The city's school principals are currently engaged in what may appear to the uninitiated observer of the New York education scene as a rather odd battle. Through their union, the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, the principals are contesting the Board of Education's claim that theirs is a position of management.

title: HANOI AIDE ASSERTS P.O.W. RELEASE WILL BE SUSPENDED BECAUSE U.S. AND SAIGON FAIL TO HONOR TRUCE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, Feb. 27A Nort Vietnamese spokesman declared today that there would be no further release of American prisoners of war until the United States stops concentrating their efforts on getting back prisoners while failing to correctly implement the Paris agreement.

title: Major Banks Raise Prime Rate to 6%
description: With a green light from Washington, the nation's major banks yesterday increased their prime lending rates to 6 per cent from 6 per cent.

title: Man Parking His Car Smashes it Into Store
description: A Manhattan jeweler who meant to park his car at the curb yesterday morning wound up inside his store instead, car and all. The police reported that the jeweler, Michael Weiner, escaped unscathed, which was more than could be said for either the vehicle or the store at 218 East 14th Street.

title: Priest Slain in Gaza
description: GAZA, Feb. 26 (UPI)The police today reported that Rev. Yohana Nimri, a Roman Catholic priest who had spoken in favor of Gaza Strip elections in cooperation with the Israeli occupation authorities, had been shot to death. Father Nimri, an Arab, was the only Catholic priest resident in the Strip.

title: CHRISTOPHER W. MARTIN
description: Christopher W. Martin, emeritus professor of public speaking at City College, where he was on the faculty from 1942 to 1967, died yesterday of cancar at his home, 3353 82d Sfreet, Jackson Heights, Queens. His age was 70.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE CORRUPT KINGDOM. The Rise and Fall of the United Mine Workers. By Joseph E. Finley. 315 pages. Simon & Schuster. $8.95.

title: 125 YAGHTS'BEGIN KEY S.O.R.C, RACE
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26  A total of 125 yachts set off today for Nassau, the Bahamas, 175 miles away, in the next to last but most important  race of the Southern Ocean Racing Conference series.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Engineer Recalls Bus Crash

title: MRS. BAR TOBIAS
description: Mrs. Frederica Bar Tobias, wife of Dr. Nicholas Bar, international banker and economist, died Feb. 7 of leukemia in Zurich, Switzerland, where she lived. She was 42 years old.

title: NEWS INDEX
description: News Summary and index, Page 39

title: Van Peebles Offers Roukin OneMan Show
description: A season without a Melvin Van Peebles musical? That theatrical dynamo, Sweet Sweetback in person, eftmuted that possibility Sunday when he brought his rousing oneman show; Out There by Your Lonesome, to Philharmonic Hall for a onenight stand. Van Peebles has been touring the country with the shownext week Chicago and then Detroitgiving a bravura performance himself.

title: WHOLESALE FOOD SORGED IN PRICE AFTER DOLLAR CUT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Wholesale prices of many food commodities rose sharply in the first full week after devaluation of the dollar, and a Brookings Institution economist said today that the increase confirmed the outlook for more disappointing figures ahead for consumers.

title: J. J. Kenny Is Convicted Of Extortion in jersey
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27A Mercer County jury tonight found John J. Kenny, the 54yearold former Hudson County political leader, guilty of extortion and misconduct in office.

title: Oswald Papers Valued At $17,700 by Court
description: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 26 (AP)  Lee Harvey Oswald's diary and other papers were ruled today to have great his torical value for which the Government must pay his widow $17,700, or almost six times what had been offered.

title: FRAUD IS ALLEGED IN COMPENSATION
description: NEWARK, Feb. 26  The State Commission of InvestigaLion says that it has developed evidence of fraudulent billing practices by some doctors and lawyers in the State's Work men's Compensation System.

title: A.T.&T. LONG LINES FILES NEW RATES
description: The Long Lines department of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed yesterday a new schedule of rates for interstate voicegrade private line services, generally used by business customers.

title: MERLE S. KLINCK
description: MANSFIELD, Conn., Feb. 26 (AP)Merle S. Klinck, former head of the department of agriculture engineering at the University of Connecticut, died yesterday in a, Hartford hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: 9,000Mile Cut in Penn Central's Trackage Is Urged by a Trustee
description: Jervis Langdon Jr., senior trustee of the bankrupt Penn Central Railroad, has asserted that the railroad must be slimmed down from its 20,000 miles of trackage but that system of at least 11,000 miles is essential to the populous Northeast.

title: BILL SEEKS HALT IN WOLF KILLINGS
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Representative G. William Whitehurst, Republican of Virginia, has introduced legislation calling for a United StatesCanadian agreement for a moratorium on the killing of the Eastern timber wolf and authorizing a study of the animal by the Department of the Interior, which considers it endangered.

title: DePugh, Minutemen's Founder, Granted Parole After 6 Years
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Robert Bolivar DePugh, founder of the Minutemen, a rightwing paramilitary organization, was granted a parole today by the United States Board of Parole after serving a little more than half of an 11year prison sentence for the illegal possession of firearms and jumping bond

title: Entertainment Events Today
description: Operas

title: DOUBLING HOURS IN PRIMARY GAINS
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26The Assembly today unanimously approved a measure that would more than double the primary election voting hours in New York City.

title: 2 Charges of Espionage Dropped in Ellsberg Case
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26The judge in the Pentagon papers trial ordered Daniel Ellsberg and Anthony J. Russo Jr. each acquitted today of one count of the espionage charges in their 15count indictment and scheduled the defense portion of the trial to begin tomorrow.

title: 39 States Are Planning No Tax Increases This Year
description: In sharp contrast to the pattern of the last few years, Governors and legislative leaders in 39 of the 48 states with legislative sessions this year have pledged no increase in taxes.

title: F.B.I. and Police Here Begin Inquiry on Met Vase
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, acting at the request of the Italian Government, began yesterday an investigation of the 2,500yearold Greek vase acquired last year by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Bangor, Wash., Is Worried by Plans for Submarine Base
description: BANGOR, Wash., Feb. 21 An overgrown puppy was the first to stop barking, and then the others came in close to smell the pants cuffs and wag their tails. Word to be suspicious of strangers apparently has not passed down to the neighborhood dog pack.

title: CARMEN DI CHIARA
description: STAMFORD, Conn., Feb. 26 Carmen Joseph DiChiara, vice president of the Nestl Trading Corporation, died yesterday of a heart attack while being taken to St. Joseph Hospital. He was 51 years old and lived at 36 Harvest Hill Jane.

title: Befogged Guideline
description: Only one thing emerges with clarity from the torrent of explanations of Phase 3 antiinflation controls issued yesterday by the White House and the Cost of Living Council: whatever slight hope exists for keeping 1973 wage increases inside the 5.5 per cent guidepost established by the defunct Pay Board depends on the dexterity of the council's new director, John T. Dunlop.

title: SANDMAN SEEKING. NIXON MAJORITY
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. is looking for a new Nixon majority to help, him defeat Governor Cahill in New Jer, sey's Republican gubernatorial primary.

title: Arthur Daley The Empty Bag
description: I felt so sorry for Joe Frazier when George Foreman knocked him down, said Jack Kent Cooke with clinical detachment.

title: Liner Sails to New Home
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 26 (UPI)The old passenger liner President Cleveland,  renamed the Oriental President, sailed out of the Golden Gate yesterday for her new home port of Hong Kong. The ship was sold to the Orient Overseas Line by the American President Lines after the company decided to end passenger liner service last year.

title: Beyond the City Limits
description: Statistically we are an urban nation. Yet back of every city, in both a figurative and a literal sense, is the country, the farmland, and the forest land where less than 10 per, cent of the population still lives. The hinterland, it is often called, or the boondocks, or sticks. Without that hinterland the cities would soon starve, but just as important in the big, enduring picture, is the certainty that is a part of the land itself.

title: SEVEN DIE IN CRASH OF JET IN ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, Feb. 26 (AP)Seven persons were killed today when an executive jet crashed only seconds after taking off. The pilots had reported to the control tower that he had struck some birds.

title: BILL SEEKS TO END OIL IMPORT QUOTA
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI) A bill to abolish the oil import quota was introduced in the Senate today as officials of the National Petroleum Council conceded a growing reliance on foreign energy sources.

title: CONTACTS DENIED BY EX RAIDER AIDE
description: A charge of tarripering leveled at an undesignated National Football League team by. John Madden, head coach of the Oakland Raiders, was denied yesterday by Ray Malavasi, a former assistant of Madden's and the object of the alleged tampering.

title: Flanigan Backs Multinational Concerns
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26A top assistant to President Nixon offered Congress today a general defense of multinational corporations, saying they had not exported jobs and had been a major help to the nation's balance of payments.

title: F.B.I. and Police Here Begira Inquiry on Met Vase
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation, acting at the request of the Italian Government, began yesterday an investigation of the 2,500yearold Greek vase acquired last year by the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: NIGHTSIDE It's almost, not quite, like sitting in someone's living room when you go upstairs at the Soerabaja, the restaurant at 140 East 74th Street (7444150). While diners chomp away or drink downstairs, entertainment customers go one flight up to catch the shows, which start about 10 P.M. in this unaccountably atmospheric building, which was once a private home. The quarters are comfortably largenot spacious, but space enough to stretch. It is dark and quiet, but you can see that the furnishings are nice. As you come off the stairs, you are practically onstage with the evening's star until you sidle off to the tables at front or rear. It's a place that rates the intime.

title: Europe on Guard
description: LONDONThe United States has just succeeded in terminatingso far as itself is concernedthe most humiliating war not merely in its own history but in that of most Western nations in modern times. It is comparable with the defeat of Russia by Japan in 1905, and much more ignominious than that of France in Algeria. One of the peculiar features is that the American Govermnent knew by 1967 that they had lost, and admitted as much publicly in 1968. Yet though they fought for over five years to extricate themselvei, as against a bare two years under the impression that they could win, the question still remains: Will they ever know what hit them?

title: Supreme Court Bars a Review of Abortion Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26The Supreme Court refused today to reconsider its decision liberalizing abortion laws in most of the country and dismissed a challenge to the New York law.

title: Napoles, Foe in Top Shape
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26 (AP) Jose Napoles, the world welterweight boxing championfrom Mexico, and Ernie (Indian Red) Lopez of Los Angeles are in perfect shape for their 15round title fight Wednesday night at the Forum, the California Athletic Commission said today.

title: DR. L. GRANT HECTOR, DEVISED NAVY FUSE
description: ARMONK, N. Y., Feb. 26Dr. L. Grant Hector who received a Presidential Certificate of Merit in 1948 for his part in developing the Navy's proximity fuse, died Saturday at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Veterans Hospital in Montrose. He was 78 years old.

title: Aetna Life and Casualty Reports Rise in Earnings
description: Net income of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in lash year's fourth quarter rose to $42.69million, or $1.60 a share, from the yearearlier $38.21million, or $1.42 a share.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: RIVAL CRITICIZES THIEU ON LIBERTY
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26Gen. Duong Van Minh, a political rival of President Nguyen Van Thieu, criticized the Thieu Government today for failing to restore civil and political liberties guaranteed by the Vietnam ceasefire agreement.

title: Samuels Offers a Plan for OTB To Take Over Numbers Game
description: Howard J. Samuels, president of the Offtrack Betting Corporation, yesterday presented a detailed plan for an OD3 takeover of the numbers game that he said would cripple organized crime and pour millions of dollars into the city's communities for support of schools and other neighborhood projects.

title: Chicagah Ain't So Great, Either
description: CHICAGOA few years ago, you could get a laugh out of Chicagoans by saying two words: John Lindsay. Handsome John had become the symbol of everything that didn't work in a big city. Hardly a day passed without something hitting the front pages about the latest Lindsay disaster in New York.

title: CONTROL OF RENT EXPECTED TO STAY
description: Two City Council leaders said yesterday they expected local rent control to be extended, as Mayor Lindsay urged on Sunday, but they expressed dissatisfaction with a major aspect of the program.

title: NOMINEE TO F.A.A. QUITS AIR FORCE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The White House admitted today that it had erred. The error will not shake the Republic but it cost a retired colonel more than $10,000 a year and the Administration a bit of face.

title: John J. Kenny Is Found Guilty Of Extortion and Misconduct
description: TRENTON, Feb. 27A. Mercer County jury tonight found John J. Kenny, the 54yearold former Hudson County political leader, guilty of extortion and misconduct in office.

title: Soybeans Up 15c; Trading Curbs Set
description: Prices of soybean futures have been marching ahead steadily by exactly the 15centabushel daily limit in the case of the old crop deliveries. Yesterday was no exception on the Chicago Board of Trade, with March soybeans moving up to $6.68 a bushel, another historic high, from Friday's close of $6.53.

title: Australia Establishes Ties With Hanoi
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 26 Australia and North Vietnam, former adversaries in the Vietnam war, established diplomatic relations today.

title: Mets Raise Seaver to $140,000
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26The spring training camps came alive in Florida today following the baseball labor settlement, and the New York Mets marked the occasion by signing Tom Seaver to a oneyear contract for $140,000.

title: KLEINDIENST BARS A HOFFA UNION BID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst said today that he would move quickly to block any bid by James R. Hoffa, the former teamsters' union president, to return to union office against the conditions of his release from prison.

title: P.O.W. HAILS NIXON, SCORES WAR FOES
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 26Antiwar demonstrators in the United States prolonged the Vietnam war and the release of American prisoners for from one to two years, a senior Air Force P.O.W. who was among the first to be released said here tonight.

title: Notes on People
description: McCall's magazine said it had settled out of court a dispute concerning the exclusivity of an article in Coronet magazine dealing with the breastcancer operation performed on Mrs. Shirley Temple Black. McCall's had sued Coronet's owners and distributors for $500,000 for claiming a Coronet story of Mrs. Black's operation was exclusive. McCall's claimed that its own article on the operation was the exclusive one. McCall's did not disclose the terms of the settlement.

title: Basketball Poll
description: The top 20 with points figured on a 201816141210987654321 basis (firstplace votes in parentheses) and wonlost records and total points:

title: MRS. THEODORE MILLER
description: Mrs. Gladys Ivie Miller, widow of Theodore J. Miller of the New York law firm of Dunnington, Bartholow & Miller, died Friday in Cuernavaca, Mexico. She lived in Katonah, N. Y.

title: Currency Trading Calmer; Dollar Strong, Gold at $81
description: LONDON, Feb. 26Europe's financial markets calmed down today but still remained unsettled after the near panic of last Thursday and Friday when speculators, in distrust of paper money, bid up gold to dizzy levels.

title: BORIS V. IOCANSON, SOVIET PAINTER, 79
description: MOSCOW, Feb. 26Boris V. Ioganson, a prominent realistic painter, who was president of the Soviet Academy of Arts from 1958 to 1963, died yesterday at the age of 79.

title: French Military Takes Control of Air Traffic
description: PARIS, Feb. 26 (Reuters)The military took over air traffic operations throughout France today in an attempt to cope with a weeklong strike by civilian controllers. But flights remained seriously reduced as pilots backed the work stoppage.

title: Goldwater Tourney Finale Will Be Played on Sunday
description: The final round of the sixth annual GoldwaterMarshall Invitation Master Chess Tournament will be played at the Marshall Chess Club, 23 West 10th Street, Saturday and Sunday, with play getting under way at 1 o'clock each afternoon.

title: Lansky Goes on Trial in Miami On Criminal Contempt Charges
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26  Meyer Lansky, reputed underworld financial figure, went on trial in Federal District Court here today on criminal contempt charges.

title: HENRY CHANIN, 79, BUILDER, IS DEAD
description: Henry I. Chanin, cofounder of the Chanin Construction Compatty, which erected the Chanin Building it 122 East 42d Street and built and managed many theaters and other properties in the city, did Sunday in Gracie Square Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: Commumnist Forces, After 24Hour Battle, Overrun 2 Major Positions in Cambodia
description: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, Feb. 27 (UPI)CambodianCommunist forces overran two major Government positions on Route 2 before dawn ttoday after more than 24 hours of fierce fighting, the Cambodian high command reported.

title: Pacers' Late Drive, Sparked by Keller, Beats Nets, 112107
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., Feb. 26 Billy Keller, a 5foot10inch backcourt sharpshooter, hit for 11 of his 26 points in the final quarter tonight to spark the defending champion Indiana Pacers to a 112107 victory over the New York Nets before a crowd of 7,580.

title: Soviet Said to Be Buiding Second Aircraft Cartier
description: WASHINOTON, Feb. 26The Soviet. Union appears to have started construction of second aircraft carrier and is reportedly taking additional steps that convince American military, analysts it intends to build a fleet of such vessels.

title: STATE LABOR BILL DRAWS CITY FIRE
description: ALBANY, Feb. 26The Lind. say administration and the city's largest union of public employes are opposing a bil here that they say would curl the powers of the city's office of Collective Bargaining anc increase the powers of the state's Public Employment Re. lations Board.

title: How to Enjoy a LowCholesterol Diet
description: Above all, Dr. George Christakis said, eating is, and should be fun.

title: Chinese Newsmen Out In Force for Sessions
description: PARIS, Feb. 26 (UPI)Led by Chi Pengfei, Peking's Foreign Minister, scores of Chinese officials, aides, interpreters and journalists are attending the international conference on Vietnam.

title: A StreetWise Planner John Eugene Zuccotti
description: The politicians and family friends packed into the Blue Room at City Hall heard the new chairman of the City Planning Commission speak out yesterday on the need to get government out into the neighborhoods. In easy, conversational tones, he read through his sevenpage text.

title: John Prine's Songs Show Wide Range And Sophistication
description: John Prine ended his hugely successful twohour evening songs Sunday at Tully Hall with a Hank Williams medley, and it was a gesture that put his whole achievement in perspective.

title: Pontiac Sets a Record
description: DETROIT, Feb. 26 (UPI)Production of 1973 model Pontiacs passed the halfmillion mark today35 days earlier than last year when the General Motors division hit the

title: Thich Tinh Khiet, Leader Of Vietnam Buddhists, Dies
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, Feb. 26 (AP)Thich Tinh Khiet, supreme patriarch of South Vietnam's Buddhists, died yesterday in Hue. He was 84 years old.

title: N.A.A.C.P. Head Minimizes Atlanta School Plan's Effect
description: Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colgored People, said yesterday that a compromise plan on school desegregation accepted by the organization for the Atlanta school system last week was of purely local significance and did not shange the N.A.A.C.P.'s basic commitment to quality integrated education.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL ROSE LAST WEEK
description: Steel production for the weep ended Feb. 24 hit its highest level of the year at 2,908,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. It was also the highest level since the week ended May 29, 1971, when output totaled 2,914,000 tons.

title: People in Sports: Feud Casualty
description: Al McGuire, the fiery basketball coach at Marquette University, said yesterday that he had declined an invitation to coach the United States team in a series of games against a team from the Soviet Union this spring.

title: Briefs on the Arts
description: Rochelle Owens, author of Futz and other controversialplays, has written The Karl Marx Play, an interracial work she describes as having evolved out of investigations of the life of Marx. It will have music by Galt MacDermot, the composer who provided the tunes for Hair and Two Gentlemen of. Verona, and lyrics by Miss Owens.

title: Advertising
description: Watched by five TV cameras, two professional manipulators of thought tried yesterday to give a Senate subcommittee an idea of the awesome and unused potential of electronic advertising.

title: Cahill Defends Integrity Of S.C.I. in Sherwin Case
description: TRENTON, Feb. 26Governor Cahill today defended the independence and complete integrity of the State. Commission of Investigation.

title: Big Band '73 Plays Jazz for Dancing
description: Most of the rehearsal bands in New Yorkgroups of professional musician who get together once a week to play bigband arrangements as a form of relaxation from whatever they are normally called on to playare concert jazz bands that play for listening, not dancing. Big Band '73, a 15  piece group that holds its weekly sessions on Tuesday nights at Goldie's in Valley Stream, L. I., is unusual in this respectit is designed for dancing.

title: Month After Truce, Saigon's War Mood Persis
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Feb. 26  The overriding reality of Vietnam, a month after the ostensible arrival of peace, is that virtually nothing has changed.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Two Guards and a School Aide Seized in Supermarket Holdup
description: Two school security guardsone recently released from prison after serving nearly nine years for murderand a school aide were arrested yesterday morning during an attempted holdup of a Manhattan supermarket near Columbia University.

title: POWERS TELLS A STRIKE IS POSSIBLE
description: Bertram A. Powers, president of Typographical Union No. 6 here, said yesterday that he was giving the parent, inter nationaf union, with headquarters in Colorado Springs, the required notification that a bargaining situation with New York's four major daily newspapers could result in a strike.

title: National Blue Cross to Adopt a New Symbol
description: The national Blue Cross Association announced yesterday a new syrnbol for its 80 local insurance plans a stylized human figure at the center of its cross to symbolize a shift from hospital emphasis to broader health care.

title: FOOD OUTLETS FAIL HEALTH INSPECTIONS
description: Twelve more restaurants and other foodprocessing establishments in the city were cited by the Health Department yesterday for failing their second Health Code inspections.

title: JUROR GIVES FEE TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: The 61st annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund stood at $1,034,697.48 as of yesterday, about $14,000 ahead of its predecessor butt approximately $21,000 behind the record of $1,055,877.91 set two years ago by the 59th yearly appeal.

title: News Summary and Index TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 27, 1973
description: The Major Events of the Day

title: Tokyo Leader Says Big Powers Bar Japan From Major Councils
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26The secretary general of Japan's governing LiberalDemocritic party denounced the world's major powers today for excluding Japan from important international councils, including the conference on Vietnam that opened in Paris today.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: For the second time in less than a year, inmates at Rahway State Prison staged a work stoppage yesterday to dramatize demands for parole reform.

title: Police Halt Jet at Kennedy To Seize Murder Suspect
description: Detectives chased an Eastern Airlines jet down a runway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday to capture a murder suspect.

title: Pandemonium Breaks Ouf At Libyan Service for 55
description: BENGHAZI, Libya, Feb. 26 (Reuters)Pandemonium broke out today at the funeral service here for 55 victims of the Sinai airline disaster Wednesday when a crowd of about 15,000 led by a young man surged forward crying for revenge against Israel.

title: WIRETAP REPORT BY TIME REJECTED
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Attorney General Richard G. Kleindienst denied today a report by Time magazine that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had tapped the telephones of a number of newsmen and White House aides with the approval of top officials in the Justice Department.

title: Hockey First Major Sport To Provide Arbitration
description: The sport usually considered the least progressive in money matters, hockey, was the first to have arbitration in its contracts.

title: Japanese Said to Plan End To Saturday Money Market
description: TOKYO, Feb. 26 (Reuters) Banking sources said today that Japanese banks are discussing a plan to close the Tokyo foreign exchange market on Saturdays starting March 10.

title: Bushman's Baths Destroyed In Blaze at Coney Island
description: Bushman's Bathsa popular Coney Island bathhouse and steam room for tens of thousands of swimmers over the last half centurywas destroyed last night by a threealarm fire.

title: Mackell Relinquishes Ferdinando Case to Nassau
description: MINEOLA, L. I., Feb. 26The Nassau County District Attorney's office will prosecute the case against Joseph Ferdinando, who is charged with grand larceny in a getrichquick scheme involving members of the staff of Queens District Attorney Thomas J. Mackell.

title: MRS, MEM IN ES. FOR 10 DAY VISIT
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Premier Golda Meir of Israel ardyad here today for a 10day visit to the Unitedi States and said it was high time that there be a serious movement toward a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Expert Finds No Guides on Secrecy
description: The First Amendment supplies no clear answer to the question of how much privacy the Government is entitled to in its decisionmaking, Alexander M. Bickel, the Yale professor and constitutional specialist, said yesterday in an address at Freedom House.

title: Suffolk Downs Races Off
description: BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP)Racing was canceled at Suffolk Downs today because of bad weather. The card was carried over to Wednesday.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 26 (UPI)The Western Athletic Conference today declared Brigham Young ineligible to represent it in the National Collegiate championship basketball tournament. The decision was prompted by an announcement of the N.C.A.A. tournament committee that the conference would lose its automatic berth if Brigham Young won the conference title.

title: Cordero Banned 10 Days; Turf Cup Victory Stands
description: MIAMI, Feb. 26 (AP)Angel Cordero Jr., the leading joekey in Hialeah's winter meeting, drew a 10day suspension today for careless riding on the backstretch in last Saturday's $136,200 Turf Cup victory. Then he went out and won today's feature race aboard Count Casper. The suspension begins Wednesday.

title: Liberia Seeking SelfHelp Donations From Public
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, Feb. 16 The 18month old administration of President William R. Tolbert Jr. is trying, to raise $10millionin costs andservicesfrom this country's 1.5million a citizens for series of selfhelp programs.

title: Couple Found Dead In Bronx Tenement; Child, 2, Unharmed
description: A young Bronx couple were found dead yesterday morning in a fourthfloor tenement apartment near Fordham. Road inicthe Bronx.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your Jan. 31 editorial Research for Power called for the Federal Government to carry out a comprehensive research effort aimed at developing new energy sources to meet this country's pressing needs.

title: CONTACTS DENIED BY EXRAIDER AIDE
description: A charge of tampering leveled at an undesignated National Football League team by John Madden, head coach of the Oakland Raiders, was denied yesterday by Ray Malavasi, a former assistant of Madden's and the object of the alleged tampering.

title: RHODESIA SUSPENDS MAIL TIE TO ZAMBIA
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Feb. 26  Rhodesia announced tonight that she had suspended postal services with neighboring Zambia.

title: Telling It Not Quite Like It Is
description: President Nixon is on reasonably firm ground in contending that many of the antipoverty and other social programs created by Democratic administrations in the 1960's failed in practice. But the way Mr. Nixon made the case was so partisan and selfserving that he probably was not too persuasive to those considerable number of people who still need convincing.

title: BOEING NET RISES AS SALES DECLINE
Pubhsher, Editor And 10 Reporters, Are Subpoenaed
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 President Nixon's reelection committee obtained subpoenas today ordering a dozen reporters and news executives to turn over all their notes, tapes and other private material relating to news articles on the bugging of the Democratic national headquarters here last June.

title: Loss to Celtics Could Dim New York Hopes in Race for Division Crown
description: Still without Willis (Tenderfoot) Reed, the New York Knicks face the Boston Celtics at Madison Square Garden tonight in what amounts to a last chance to keep alive the Atlantic Division race in the National Basketball Association.

title: Dance: Hamlet of Sorts
description: There are things that are beyond criticism, and things that are beneath criticism. There are times when criticism itself can become a merciful act of omission. I would probably have taken that line With the Robert Streicher Dance Company, apart from one significant factor. The factor is that the company has the financial supportsmall as I am certain it isof the New York State Council on the Arts.

title: Garelik, in Mayoral Bid, Implies Murphy Must Go
description: City Council President Sanford D. Gatelik, formally announcing his candidacy for Mayor, indicated yesterday that if elected he would dismiss Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy.

title: The Great Forgetting
description: WASHINGTON, Feb, 26What the country needs now at the end of the Vietnam war is not amnesty but amnesia.

title: 83 III With Food Poisoning
description: PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26 (AP) A spokesman for the city's health department said today that all 83 persons afflicted with food poisoning at a church dedication had been released from six city hospitals. Almost all the stricken persons were treated in emergency facilities and released after the incident yesterday, but two children and an elderly woman were hospitalized. They were released today.

title: LAWSUITS CHALLENGE BREAKUP OF O.E.O.
description: WASHINGTON, Feb., 26Three lawsuits were filed in Federal District Court here and one in Chicago today in attempts to head off the dismemberment of the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: New Jersey Sports
description: This year, for the first time, every high school basketball team in New Jersey is eligible to compete in the state tournament. A total of 348 teams are participating, of which seven will emerge as state championsfour from the public schools and three from the parochial schools.

title: Laos Sides Begin Talks On Details of CeaseFire
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, Tuesday, Feb. 27Representatives of the Vientiane Government and the Communistled Pathet. Lao began meeting yesterday to work out details of policing the Laos ceasefire signed last Thursday.

title: SHOP TALK
description: The accent is definitely French at Ophelie, a new costume jewelry boutique at the corner of Madison Avenue and East 61st Street. The entire stock is from France; so are the three partners who run it.

title: Solomon 61, 62 Victor Over Cooper at Hampton
description: HAMPTON, Va., Feb. 26 (AP) Harold Solomon, the fourthseeded American player, trounced John Cooper of Australia, 61, 62, in the opening round of the $35,000 Coliseum Mall tennis tournament today.

title: Drugs Are Less Popular, Junior High Adviser Says
description: Jim McHugh, a schopl drug counselor who wears maroon slacks and flowery shirts, spent part of yesterday trying to learn the identity of the 14yearold boy from Ditmas Junior High School who was among those picked up in drug raids in Brooklyn.

title: The Short Rope
description: Let us suppose that a man is drowning thirty feet from shore. A rescuer throws him ten feet of rope. He drowns. It would scarcely be logical to conclude: Rope is of no use in the prevention of drowning.

title: N.H.L. Scoring
Statement by LaborManagement Advisory Panel
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26Folowing is a statement issued today by the White House Labor  Management Advisory Committee:

title: Skilled Minorities Called City's Hope for Future
description: When William Cisco came home from serving in Vietnam with the Marines, the only work he could get was waxing floors. Even then, the maintenance company soon laid him off.

title: Crane, Falls Near Foley Sq.
description: A large construction crane collapsed yesterday at a building site on Cardinal Hayes Place behind the United States Court. House in Foley Square. The crane was being raised for operation when it crashed against an annex under construction. It narrowly missed hitting the rear of the existing courthouse and no one was injured.

title: Black Hawks Opponent New York 2 Losses Short of League Mark
description: Sometime soon, after two more losses, the New York Islanders will tie the National Hockey, League record of 53 defeats in a season. Tonight they meet the Black Hawks at Nassau Coliseum in a game that means more to the slumping Chicagoans, who have their slimmest hold on first place in the West Division since switching from the East in 1970.

title: D.A. AIDE AMUSED OF 2 SEX ATTACKS
description: A recently appointed Queens assistant district attorney was arraigned yesterday in Queens Criminal Court on charges of sexual abuse and menacing in separate knifepoint attacks on a teenaged girl and a young woman in the Rockaways last year.

title: SENATE APPROVES EXTENSION ON AID
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 The Senate voted today to allow the Government to spend money for foreign aid through the end of April end for the programs of the Department of Labor and Health, Education and Welfare through the end of June.

title: BILL WOULD CREATE CENTRAL EXCHANGE
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (Reuters)A bill to create a central stock market and provide for a national system for clearance and settlement of securities transactions will be introduced in the House of Representatives Thursday, the subcommittee on securities and finance announced.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: For the first time in the 20th century, hunters in Vermont will have a chance to pursue the wild turkey. An experimental 1973 spring gobbler hunt was recently approved by the state's fish and game board.

title: Business Briefs
description: Iran Oil Consortium Accord Reached

title: 8 PLAYERS REPORT TO YANKEES CAMP
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Feb. 26Eight players worked out on a muddy field today as the New York Yankees opened their early spring training camp three days late.

title: Worshiping Krishna Is Their Way of Life
description: The visitor, looking for the Radha Krishna Temple in the Cobble. Hill section of Brooklyn, endounters, a friendly housewife who says, Oh, you're going to the Harry Krishners. The neighborhood sure has changed, Now it's got all, kinds: But I guess they're harmless, even with their funny clothes and all.

title: DE ROOT FUNDS TIED TO RESEARCH
description: When she died in 1967 at the age of 91, Adelaide Milton de Groot left her paintings and the bulk of her fortune to the Metropolitan Museum of Art with instructions as to their disposal. In its use of the money as well as the Paintings, the museum has taken a broad construction of her wishes.

title: Garelik, in Mayoral Bid, Implies Murphy Must Go
description: City Council President San ford D. Garelik, formally an nouncing his candidacy fa Mayor, indicated yesterday tha if elected he would dismiss Police Commissioner Patrick V Murphy.

title: IN SALE OF DRUGS
description: Five high School studentsincluding two 14yearold boys and four college students were among 21 persons arrested yesterday on charges of selling narcotics at two colleges and two schools in Brooklynney said the operations netted almost $500,000 a year from sales to students at Brooklyn College, Kingsborough Community, in the Manhattan Beach section, Midwood High School, which is next to Brooklyn College in the Flatbush section, and Ditmas Junior. High School, also in Flatbush.

title: Ethics and Antiquities, an Issue for Museums
description: Great works of art over the last several thousand years have been pillaged, burned, bombed, neglected, discarded, ground up for lime if of marble, melted down if of gold or bronze, used to line shoes on canvasthis in Germany during the last days of World War IIpainted out, broken up, thrown away, and now and then reverently pre served. The wonder is that we have anything left to provide stock for our museums. The most sensational discovery of a work of art in many years, with a surrounding galaxy of other sensations, including the price paid for it, is of course the Metropolitan Museum's new Greek vase, Which, within the period of hardly more than a week, has made the name of Euphronios, its painterknown, until now, to only a handful of peoplealmost as well known to New Yorkers as that of Leonardo da Vinci.

title: TOPPER CORP. FILES CHAPTER XI PETITION
description: The Topper Corporation of Elizabeth, N.J., yesterday filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act in Federal District Court in Manhattan, listing liabilities of $32,795,000 and assets of $14,152,000.

title: Mets Raise Seaver to $140,000
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 26The spring training camps came alive in Florida today following the baseball labor settlement, and the New York Mets marked the occasion by signing Tom Seaver to a oneyear contract for $140,000.

title: Pope Paul Appoints Key Church Administrators
description: ROME, Feb. 26Pope Paul VI today started a longawaited shuffle in the Roman Catholic Church's administrative center, the Curia, by naming a new head of its department in charge of bishops and announcing other personnel changes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Incoming Passenger and Mail Ships

title: Fund Sharing Is Called Garden Path for Cities
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (UPI)The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, charged today that the Administration had led states, cities and towns down the garden path with its program of revenue sharing.

description: ACROSS

description: BASKETBALL

title: The Secret Story of Frank Costello That Was Almost Written
description: Ten days before he died, Frank Costello made one of the biggestdecisions of his long life. He decided to talk.
